<html><head></head><body>AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: $5.5 million Settlement Jane Doe v. ABC Trucking Company Cleveland, Ohio
BASENAME: 5-5-million-settlement-jane-doe-v-abc-trucking-company-cleveland-ohio
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 08/24/2009 09:08:27 AM
-----
BODY:
An energetic and sweet married woman was on her way to a fitness center during her lunch hour from work when she was broadsided by a 18 wheel truck which had run a red light. While she broke many bones in her body the impact caused a traumatic and force fueled injury to her brain. This injury was particularly disturbing as she was able to talk and, at times, seemed normal. However, the brain injury made it so she was unable to remember conversations or be able to independently function to take care of herself or others. The settlement allowed her to obtain brain injury therapy that was cutting edge at the time and resulted in some improvement. Unfortunately she is still unable to take care of herself, however a Trust set up to care for her has provided equipment and housing modifications.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: $4.65 million Settlement Baby Doe v. ABC Hospital Cincinnati, Ohio
BASENAME: 4-65-million-settlement-baby-doe-v-abc-hospital-cincinnati-ohio
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 11/10/2007 08:09:24 AM
-----
BODY:
This case involved nurses attempting to blame an OB for not attending to warning signs during a delivery. The OB indicated he was in the on call sleeping room the entire night and was never called in a timely manner. Lost in this senseless fight was the family of a little girl who was born brain damages for the failure of the nurses and the OB to act and deliver the child appropriately. After researching the records it was apparent the nurses had falsified the records to reflect calls to the OB they never made. Despite all this both Defendants pushed this case to the eve of trial before resolving the matter. The family has utilized the award to provide education, equipment, housing and nursing care to provide for their daughter who is now nearing her teenage years.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: $4.6 million Settlement Jane Doe v. ABC Hospital Cleveland, Ohio
BASENAME: 4-6-million-settlement-jane-doe-v-abc-hospital-cleveland-ohio
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/10/2007 09:10:45 AM
-----
BODY:
This was a tragic case of a young, happily married woman who was nearing the end of her second pregnancy when she became ill with strep throat. She went to a local hospital and was admitted with a fever and other abnormalities in her vital signs. Lab work came back which confirmed she was infected however both the nurses and her physician allowed the results to sit on the hospital&#x2019;s fax machine unchecked. She eventually became even more sick and additional signs of this progression were ignored by the staff and her physician. Her infection forced her into labor where she died as she gave birth to her second child. While remaining one of our most tragic cases, the settlement allowed her two young children and husband to secure college education funds and attempt to rebuild their lives.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: $3 million Verdict Leslie Hall v. Dr. Helmut Schrieber Cleveland, Ohio
BASENAME: 3-million-verdict-leslie-hall-v-dr-helmut-schrieber-cleveland-ohio
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/03/2002 08:13:44 AM
-----
BODY:
Les Hall elected to have bariatric surgery after having failed at losing weight for many decades. He went to Dr. Schrieber who had advertised his services and program for this type of surgery as one of the best in Ohio. After surgery, Les developed a leak in his intestinal tract at the area where the surgery was performed. Many signs and symptoms developed which were consistent with this leak however Dr. Schrieber did not follow up on these. Les eventually become infected throughout his body and, although he survived his ordeal, he suffered permanent and painful nerve damage which effects his ability to walk and take care of himself. At trial, Dr. Schrieber attempted to blame other physicians for his failure to follow up. A Cuyahoga County Jury returned a verdict in Les Hall&#x2019;s favor. Les&#x2019; client testimonial regarding my representation of him can be found on AVVO.com and this website. He remains a close friend and has referred me cases frequently throughout the years.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: $4.5 million Settlement John Doe v. ABC Hospital Columbus, Ohio
BASENAME: 4-5-million-settlement-john-doe-v-abc-hospital-columbus-ohio
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 12/04/2009 08:11:48 AM
-----
BODY:
A young boy was in the hospital for pain in his stomach. A radiology study was being done to determine the cause and possible surgery for it. Because of the pain his breathing was difficult and had to be continually monitored. During the study his family was with him and became concerned that he was not breathing correctly. Despite their protests the staff ignored them and proceeded with the study. He ultimately stopped breathing completely and suffered brain injury when they were not able to perform CPR in a timely manner because of the delay. Because of the workup and time spent investigating the case, we were able to settle this matter before filing the case. The settlement was used to set up a Trust for the child, enabling him to purchase special equipment and care to take care of his many needs due to his brain injury.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: $3.15 million Settlement Jane Doe v. ABC Hospital Cincinnati, Ohio
BASENAME: 3-15-million-settlement-jane-doe-v-abc-hospital-cincinnati-ohio
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 05/28/2005 09:13:15 AM
-----
BODY:
A young teenage developed a genetic spinal malformation and was eventually operated on at a local hospital. During the surgery her spinal cord was being monitored by staff to ensure it was not put under undue stress by the procedure. Unfortunately, the obvious signs on the monitor were overlooked by an inexperienced and negligent staff member allowing the surgery to proceed when it should have been stopped. Upon waking up she was found to be permanently paralyzed from the waist level down confining her to a wheelchair. After this settlement she was able to attend an outstanding University which was well known for being handicapped accessible, and now lives in a specially designed home to accommodate and help with her paralysis. She remains and inspirational client with an eye toward some day curing her condition. She is also now contemplating law school to help others.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: $2.5 million Verdict Casto v. Dr. Larry Holland Piqua, Ohio
BASENAME: 2-5-million-verdict-casto-v-dr-larry-holland-piqua-ohio
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 06/24/2005 09:14:51 AM
-----
BODY:
This remains the largest verdict in Miami County history. Jill and Nathan Casto were nearing the end of their pregnancy with their second child when she began to experience a decrease in her baby&#x2019;s movements. This is a well known sign of a decrease in the oxygen levels to an unborn child. Jill, a very intelligent and caring mom, called her OB numerous times to address this issue. She also visited his office. Both Dr. Holland and his staff continually ignored Jill&#x2019;s complaints until she eventually gave birth to a dead baby boy several days later. An Autopsy confirmed the boy had his umbilical cord wrapped around his neck, which was causing the lack of oxygen. If he had been properly cared for he would not have died and the family would have had their second child. Jill and Nathan have gone on to have another child. 
-----

This case was resolved after various experts were hired and a settlement demand was made prior to filing a lawsuit. The settlement was able to provide much needed medical care and even a trust to help treat the condition for the remainder of the client&#x2019;s lifetime.

TITLE: $1.7 million Settlement John Doe v. ABC Hospital Lima, Ohio

STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1

DATE: 11/22/2009 08:20:31 AM
-----
BODY:
This remains one of the most disturbing cases we&apos;ve ever handled. The client&#x2019;s were a happy and close knit family whose father had heart surgery. After surgery his wound became infected and was being treated with another operation. During the evening his wound began bleeding slowly but obvious signs were there. The nurse on staff that night was new and ignored the signs of bleeding. In addition, she later changed her records in an attempt to avoid liability. An expert in chart alterations was hired who caught her in this attempt. Despite the chart alteration and the obvious and gross negligence, the Defendant&#x2019;s fought and the case was not settled until years later and the week before trial.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: $2 million Verdict Woodruff v. Lima Memorial Hospital Lima, Ohio
BASENAME: 2-million-verdict-woodruff-v-lima-memorial-hospital-lima-ohio
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 04/24/2011 09:17:43 AM
-----
BODY:
Mr. Woodruff, a married man with numerous children, was admitted to LMH to have a procedure. While there he was placed on a ventilator after the procedure was completed. He began to show signs of a decrease in oxygen which was ignored by the nursing staff. In fact, they attempted to blame a physician for not responding to their alleged complaints. Eventually, because he was being deprived of oxygen, Mr. Woodruff became disorientated and he dislodged his breathing tube which caused him to go into arrest. This was also mismanaged and led to his eventual death. An Allen County Jury provided this award, which at the time was the largest verdict in the County&#x2019;s history.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: $2 million Settlement Jane Doe and family v. ABC Hospital Anonymous Ohio City
BASENAME: 2-million-settlement-jane-doe-family-v-abc-hospital-anonymous-ohio-city
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 04/18/2011 09:19:48 AM
-----
BODY:
A 59 year old woman just completed successful heart transplant surgery and was set to be discharged home. She developed shortness of breath and an x-ray confirmed fluid had collected around one of her lungs. A simple procedure needed to be done to drain the fluid and allow her to breath easier. The x-ray was ordered in the early morning hours by a Resident and then not properly communicated to various Attending physicians who saw her later that same day. Both Attending physicians failed to appreciate the x-ray findings and her condition began to deteriorate. Unfortunately she suffered a respiratory arrest when the fluid was not drained which left her with brain damage. She was unable to care for herself independently and required attention by her children at all times. This matter was settled a few weeks before trial and allowed for a Trust to be set up to pay for home nursing care, medical equipment and home modifications for her to live safely.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Prescription Drug Abuse Devastating State of Kentucky
BASENAME: prescription-drug-abuse-devastating-state-of-kentucky
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/27/2012 02:53:09 AM
-----
BODY:
Kentucky Gov. Steve Beshear and Attorney General Jack Conway have called for a bipartisan effort to pass House Bill 4, a law that takes aim at illegal pill mills and prescription drug abuse, an epidemic that kills about 1,000 Kentuckians each year, according to The Courier-Journal.<br><br>&#x201C;Every day that we delay strengthening our response to prescription drug abuse is another opportunity for a Kentuckian to fall victim to this devastating scourge,&#x201D; Beshear said. In fact, since the beginning of this year alone, more than 400 people have been hospitalized due to overdoses.<br><br>Something clearly needs to be done as the state has the sixth-highest rate of prescription overdose deaths in the nation, but the law does not come without controversy.<br><br>A call to action was issued to doctors by the Kentucky Medical Association regarding provisions in the bill that could possibly lead to privacy infringements and excessive oversight of legitimate medical practices, not to mention any reluctance from doctors to provide pain medication to legitimate patients.<br><br>The Kentucky Medical Association issued a &#x201C;call to action&#x201D; for doctors to contact lawmakers and express concerns over several hallmark provisions in the bill, which critics say could infringe on privacy and lead to excessive oversight of legitimate medical practices. Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong>Interests jockey for influence on Kentucky &apos;pill mill&apos; bill</strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a medical malpractice attorney in the state of Kentucky, believes it is imperative to stop physicians from writing prescriptions for pain pills that are too often abused or sold to those who abuse them, even if it means adjusting privacy rights.<br><br>&#x201C;This is an example of private physicians preventing the government from helping citizens and lowering health care costs by improving care and stopping abusive prescription practices,&#x201D; Crandall says.<br><br><strong>Please contact Steve Crandall with any of your medical malpractice questions in the state of Kentucky. </strong>

BODY:
A woman in her 50&#x2032;s was in her local hospital recovering from surgery when she began to develop pneumonia. Her oxygen saturation rates dropped several times during a days and she had signs of chest pain and infection in her lungs. These signs were ignored by the nurses and doctors and she eventually arrested and died in the early morning. Litigation ensued and we deployed numerous experts to prove this case. After many depositions, and before trial, we were able to resolve this matter. The decedent and her husband had adopted their grandchild, who was very young at the time of her death. The settlement enabled him to be better taken care of and look forward to a college degree.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: What Kind of Injuries Can Trigger a Malpractice Case?
BASENAME: what-kind-of-injuries-can-trigger-a-malpractice-case
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/14/2012 05:23:14 AM
-----
BODY:
We recently looked at what is considered medical malpractice in Ohio.<br><br><strong>We now would like to look at the type of injuries that can trigger a malpractice case in our state.</strong><br><br>In the state of Ohio, medical malpractice can include claims for:<br><ul><br>  <li>birth injury caused during labor and delivery</li><br>    <li>brain damage from a variety of errors</li><br>    <li>surgical errors of all kinds</li><br> <li>failure to diagnose a heart attack</li><br>   <li>a delay in the diagnose of cancer of any kind</li><br>    <li>medication overdose or errors in dosage</li><br>  <li>negligence causing respiratory or cardiac arrest</li><br> <li>nursing negligence</li><br>   <li>hospital negligence and leaving behind surgical instruments, sponges or towels inside a patient&#x2019;s body.</li><br></ul><br><strong>If you feel that you have a potential medical malpractice claim,&#xA0;contact Steve Crandall,&#xA0; a top rated medical malpractice lawyer in Cleveland.</strong>&#xA0; Steve is available to help answer your medical malpractice questions and guide you in determining your best next steps.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Ohio Medical Malpractice Claims Drop, But At What Cost?
BASENAME: ohio-medical-malpractice-claims-drop-but-at-what-cost
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/25/2012 02:49:19 AM
-----
BODY:
The Columbus Dispatch reports that medical malpractice claims dropped by 41 percent between 2005 and 2010, largely impacted by Ohio&#x2019;s tort-reform law.<br><br>The law, signed by Gov. Bob Taft in 2003, may now be having a negative effect on those with legitimate claims, though; after physicians complained that the skyrocketing cost of malpractice insurance premiums were forcing them out of business, a cap was placed on &#x201C;pain and suffering&#x201D; damages at $500,000 per occurrence, making some cases impractical to pursue.<br><br>The result of this bill was a record drop in closed claims to 2,988 in 2010, the lowest level since 2005, when the state began keeping records. Average malpractice payments declined by 38 percent over that five-year period, a total of $100 million.<br><br>Tim Maglione of the Ohio State Medical Association does not believe this decrease is drastic enough, though he adds, &#x201C;There is absolutely nothing in the law that closes the courthouse door to anyone that has a legitimate medical liability claim.&#x201D; Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2012/04/16/lawsuits-against-doctors-have-declined.html">Lawsuits against doctors decline</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top ranked medical malpractice attorney in the state of Ohio, does not believe this law makes any sense; the cap on &#x201C;pain and suffering&#x201D; does nothing to advance the purported purpose of the law or curb so-called frivolous claims, but rather further harms those patients whom a jury has indicated have meritorious claims and deserve compensation, according to Crandall.<br><br>&#x201C;What it really does is limit the liability of insurance carriers who have no laws on the amount they can charge physicians,&#x201D; Crandall says. &#x201C;The insurance industry used the physicians to do their bidding and help their business.&#x201D;<br><br>If you have questions about medical malpractice in Ohio, or if you&apos;ve been impacted by Senate Bill 281, <strong>please contact Steve Crandall with any of your medical malpractice questions. </strong>
 
-----
EXTENDED BODY:

-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Do State Employees Have Immunity from Medical Malpractice in Kentucky?
BASENAME: do-state-employees-have-immunity-from-medical-malpractice-in-kentucky
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/18/2012 05:35:45 AM
-----
BODY:
Yes, employees of the state have limited immunity based on their employment and all cases must be heard in the Board of Claims.<br><br>There are caps on the damages available in cases against the state of Kentucky including a cap of $100,000 per claim and $250,000 per occurrence.<br><br>Damages are also lowered by applying any insurance payments the injured party received for any damages.<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice in Kentucky<strong>,&#xA0;contact Steve Crandall,&#xA0; a top rated Kentucky medical malpractice lawyer .</strong>&#xA0; Steve is available to help answer your medical malpractice questions and guide you in determining your best next steps.
 
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: What Is Medical Malpractice in Ohio?
BASENAME: what-is-medical-malpractice-in-ohio
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 03/12/2012 03:15:29 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>A question that we&apos;re often asked is &quot;what is considered medical malpractice in Ohio?&quot;</strong><br><br>In the state of Ohio, medical malpractice occurs when a medical care provider, whether a physician, nurse, dentist, technician, hospital or nursing home, fails to act as a reasonably prudent care provider would act under same or similar conditions.<br><br>In a medical malpractice case, the patient must prove two things:<br><ol><br>    <li>the care provider owed them a duty, and</li><br>  <li>an act or failure to act breached this duty proximately causing them damages.</li><br></ol><br>The duty starts with a physician-patient or nurse-patient relationship, and it ensures the providers act within the national standard of care for a particular situation.<br><br>Do you have a potential case that falls into the category of medical malpractice in the state of Ohio? Do you question if a medical care provider acted in a reasonable manor?<br><br><strong>If so, contact Steve Crandall,&#xA0; a top rated medical malpractice lawyer in Ohio.</strong> Steve is available to help answer your medical malpractice questions and guide you in determining your best next steps.
 
-----

-----

-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Discovery Leads to New Hope for Colon Cancer Treatment
BASENAME: discovery-leads-to-new-hope-for-colon-cancer-treatment
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/06/2012 10:39:01 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>A new medical discovery by more than 200 researchers investigating colon cancer tumors may be able to lead to new, powerful treatments for this almost inevitably fatal disease.&#xA0;</strong><br><br>By attacking the discovered weak spots of these deadly tumors, scientists are looking to halt the genetic aberrations that allow the cancer to spread and thrive, according to The New York Times.<br><br>Although colon cancer research is progressing rapidly, it will still take some time for treatment of this disease that kills about 50,000 Americans a year to catch up. Some drugs that are used to block mutations in other forms of cancer, such as melanoma, may be able to assist in stopping the spread of colon cancer mutations as well.<br><br>As Gina Kolata writes, &#x201C;The possibility of helping selected colon cancer patients with drugs that are already on the market &#x2018;is actually thrilling,&#x2019;&#x201D; according to Dr. Raju Kucherlapati, the principal investigator for the colon cancer project and a professor of genetics and of medicine at Harvard Business School. Read the full details here:<br><br><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/19/health/research/vast-gene-study-raises-hopes-for-colon-cancer-drugs.html?_r=2"><strong>Gene Aberrations Seen as Path to Stop Colon Cancer</strong></a><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky, believes this study is a great breakthrough for a disease that, once spread, has only a 5 percent survival rate after five years.<br><br>&#x201C;It has long been believed that colon cancer could be attacked and treated through the evaluation of genetic markers,&#x201D; says Crandall. &#x201C;This study is a breakthrough in helping physicians detect colon cancer earlier and for patients who will be able to fight this cancer more effectively.&#x201D;<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky, <strong>contact Steve Crandall</strong>. Steve is available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Dayton Newspaper Reports that VA Clinic Paid Out $940,000 after Malpractice Claims
BASENAME: dayton-newspaper-reports-that-va-clinic-paid-out-940000-after-malpractice-claims
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 03/11/2012 03:30:09 AM
-----
BODY:
The Dayton Daily News reports that the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs paid out $940,000 in cases related to the deaths of eight patients at the Dayton VA Medical Center, which came under scrutiny after allegations that a dentist at a clinic had used improper hygiene for years, according to public records obtained by a newspaper.<br><br>Records requested by the Dayton Daily News reveal the center in southwestern Ohio has faced 72 medical malpractice claims since 2007, including those related to eight deaths between 2005 and 2008. There are pending claims over two deaths in 2009 and 2010. Twenty-two of the 72 claims involved the dental clinic, and most of those appeared to be linked to the infection control scandal that came to light last year, the newspaper said. Sixteen pending claims linked to the clinic seek a total of nearly $6.7 million.<br><br>The Dayton Daily News is now revealing the deaths linked to medical malpractice at the Dayton VA for the first time. The newspaper requested the medical malpractice database Feb. 15 under the federal Freedom of Information Act, and received it last week. Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong>Dayton VA paid 8 families in death lawsuits</strong><br><br>If you have questions about medical malpractice in Dayton, or if you&apos;ve been impacted by treatment at the Dayton VA Medical Center, <strong>please contact Steve Crandall with any of your medical malpractice questions. </strong><br><br>Steve is a top ranked medical malpractice attorney in the state of Ohio and a leading medical malpractice lawyer in Dayton.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Failing U.S. Health Care Sends Citizens Across the Border
BASENAME: failing-u-s-health-care-sends-citizens-across-the-border
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/16/2012 03:12:05 AM
-----
BODY:
Thousands of Americans are flocking to the Mexican border town of Mexicali, not for vacation or entertainment, but for affordable medical care, according to The New York Times.<br><br>From a root canal to a tummy tuck to laser surgery, cheaper medical options are being advertised all along the California/Mexico border, attracting health care commuters from nearby states.<br><br>More than 150,000 patients came to Mexicali in 2011 alone, increasing the city&apos;s economy by more than $8 million, according to officials. This includes a large number of Americans who cannot afford health care, as well as a growing group of middle-class patients looking for deals on elective surgeries usually not covered by insurance.<br><br>But it is not just the lesser costs that are driving people across the border for various procedures; many patients find that the Mexican doctors are more attentive and accessible when it comes to asking questions before and after operations and checkups.<br><br>&quot;Here, many Mexicans talk with pride about the easy access they have to their doctors, sending them frequent text messages with questions and expecting calls back within minutes,&quot; writes Jennifer Medina. &quot;One oft-repeated anecdote illustrates a sign of more compassionate care: nurses will warm a patient&apos;s hand before sticking him with a needle.&quot; Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/28/health/mexicali-lures-american-tourists-with-medical-care.html?pagewanted=1&amp;_r=1&amp;adxnnlx=1342022405-kjplKNYrteX02fpVj1Adcg">Mexicali Tour, From Tummy Tuck to Root Canal</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney in Ohio and Kentucky, feels these practices show the desperate need for health care reform in the U.S.<br><br>&quot;The fact that an increasing number of Americans are leaving our country to obtain medical care elsewhere, including Mexico, is an indictment of how poorly the U.S. health care system operates,&quot; says Crandall. &quot;When Mexico&apos;s physicians are able to provide more affordable and equally safe care, an alarm in Washington D.C. should be going off.&quot;<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall.&#xA0;</strong>Steve is available to help answer your &#xA0;questions and guide you in determining your next steps.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Is Surgery Really the Answer for Prostate Cancer?
BASENAME: is-surgery-really-the-answer-for-prostate-cancer
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/03/2012 10:34:54 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Many men with early-stage prostate cancer would do just as well to choose no treatment at all, according to a new clinical trial highlighted in The New York Times.</strong><br><br>&#x201C;&#x2026;Prostate cancer detection and treatment efforts over the past 25 years, particularly in the United States, have been woefully misguided, rendering millions of men impotent, incontinent and saddled with fear about a disease that was unlikely ever to kill them in the first place,&#x201D; writes Tara Parker-Pope.<br><br>Fear over the second-biggest cancer killer in men (second only to lung cancer) leads many diagnosed patients to quick decisions that could alter their lives forever; there are about 100,000 to 120,000 prostatectomy surgeries performed in the U.S. alone each year.<br><br>Large studies like this are now showing that early detection makes little, if any, difference in whether a man dies from prostate cancer. Over a 15-year study, there was no statistical difference in overall mortality rates between the surgical and observation groups.<br><br>&#x201C;Many men, when they hear about a diagnosis of prostate cancer, become fearful,&#x201D; said Dr. Timothy J. Wilt, the study&#x2019;s lead author and professor of medicine at Minneapolis Veterans Affairs Center for Chronic Disease Outcomes Research. &#x201C;They think if they aren&#x2019;t treated they will die from it. Our results clearly demonstrate that&#x2019;s not true. The overwhelming majority will not die of their disease if its left untreated.&#x201D; Read the full details here:<br><br><strong>&#xA0;<a href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/07/18/questioning-surgery-for-early-prostate-cancer/">Questioning Surgery for Early Prostate Cancer</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky, believes patients should consider all of their options and learn all of the facts before rushing into surgery that could result in severe and unnecessary complications.<br><br>&#x201C;One question for patients to ask is whether the surgeons are advocating surgery before it is indicated in order to generate volume and income for their practice,&#x201D; says Crandall.<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky, <strong>contact Steve Crandall</strong>. AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Misdiagnosis: When Medical Errors Lead to Tragedy
BASENAME: misdiagnosis-when-medical-errors-lead-to-tragedy
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/23/2012 07:25:10 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Misdiagnosis of an illness, failure to diagnose and delay of a diagnosis continue to be prevalent medical errors that could prove to be harmful or fatal to a patient. </strong><br><br><strong></strong>This was the case with 12-year-old Rory Staunton of New York.&#xA0;Two days after cutting his arm while playing basketball at his school gym, Rory&apos;s pediatrician&apos;s office sent him to the emergency room with symptoms of vomiting, fever and a pain in his leg, according to a recent article in <em>The New York Times. </em>He was given fluids and sent home with instructions to take Tylenol, a simple case of dehydration and an upset stomach, the doctors concluded.<br><br>&quot;Partially camouflaged by ordinary childhood woes, Rory&apos;s condition was, in fact, already dire,&quot; writes Tom Dwyer. &quot;Bacteria had gotten into his blood, probably through the cut on his arm. He was sliding into a septic crisis, an avalanche of immune responses to infection from which he would not escape.&quot; Rory died in the intensive care unit three nights later.<br><br>Vital signs, recorded while the family was still at the hospital, suggested Rory could be seriously ill. Three hours after Rory and his family were sent home from the ER, abnormal lab results warning of a possibility of sepsis were reported. The Stauntons were never notified with either of these facts.<br><br>&quot;For every hour&apos;s delay in giving antibiotics after very low blood pressure [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][septic shock] had set in, a study found, the survival rate decreased by 7.6 percent,&quot; the <em>Times </em>article states.<br><br>Findings by Rory&apos;s pediatrician before being sent to the ER and the 3 of 8 possible sepsis symptoms he was displaying at the hospital were also largely ignored or not treated accordingly by his doctors.<br><br>&quot;&apos;Above all,&apos; Ms. Staunton said, &apos;we know that Rory would not want no other child to go through what he went through.&apos;&quot; Read the full details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/12/nyregion/in-rory-stauntons-fight-for-his-life-signs-that-went-unheeded.html?pagewanted=1&amp;ref=nyregion" target="_blank">An Infection, Unnoticed, Turns Unstoppable</a></strong><br><br>&quot;Rory&apos;s death is unfortunately a tragedy I see several times a year when families call me to review their case,&quot; says Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky.<br><br>Crandall cites the sheer volume of patients seeking hospital care as a reason why ER care is so difficult, as many patients who may end up seeking further care are sent home due to the overwhelming numbers the staff and physicians face.<br><br>&quot;However, here it is clear the physicians did not take the time to review Rory&apos;s abnormal vital signs and the lab did not report the critical results to re-contact Rory&apos;s family. This is a foreseeable and completely avoidable death. AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Learning Medicine is One Thing, Learning Empathy is Another
BASENAME: learning-medicine-is-one-thing-learning-empathy-is-another
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/06/2012 03:09:45 AM
-----
BODY:
Greater physician empathy has been associated with fewer medical errors, better patient outcomes and fewer malpractice claims, according to The New York Times.<br><br>But the question remains: after the &quot;dehumanizing effects&quot; of medical training, is it possible for physicians to learn empathy?<br><br>The answer is yes, according to Dr. Helen Riess, director of the Empathy and Relational Science Program at Massachusetts General Hospital, who created a series of &quot;training modules&quot; that are &quot;designed to teach methods for recognizing key nonverbal clues and facial expressions in patients as well as strategies for dealing with one&apos;s own physiologic responses to highly emotional encounters.&quot;<br><br>Responses to the study have been enthusiastic so far, with doctors using the learned behaviors to more effectively interact with patients, true evaluators.<br><br>&quot;People tend to believe that you are either born with empathy or not,&quot; said Dr. Helen Riess. &quot;But empathy can be taught, and you can improve.&quot; Read the full details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/06/21/can-doctors-learn-empathy/?ref=health">Can Doctors Learn Empathy?</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall,&#xA0;a top rated medical malpractice attorney in Ohio and Kentucky, believes this research&#xA0;underscores what the New England Journal of Medicine studied long ago: that the majority of lawsuits are as a result of poor physician bedside manner.<br><br>&quot;It&apos;s more than just empathy and being nice, it is about setting expectations and informing the patient about the procedure, as well as explaining a bad outcome if one happens,&quot; says Crandall. &quot;More often patients seek out legal advice simply because they do not know why or how a bad result occurred; the physician does not communicate with them after an untoward result occurs.&quot;<br><br>If you have any medical malpractice questions within the states of Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall.&#xA0;</strong>

TITLE: Companies Put Aside Competition for the Benefit of Autism Drug Research

ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1

DATE: 07/09/2012 03:10:57 AM
-----
BODY:
Competition between pharmaceutical companies to develop the newest, best drug is commonplace in the medical world.<br><br>What is rare is when two competitors join forces, which is exactly what is happening in the race to develop drugs to treat mental retardation and autism, according to The New York Times.<br><br>Swiss pharmaceutical giant Roche and Seaside Therapeutics, a small private company, will be teaming up to save money and get their drug to the market sooner. These drugs might be able to relieve some of the behavioral problems associated with autism, especially in the form of fragile X syndrome which 100,000 Americans have.<br><br>While Roche is currently in second place of all companies, behind Novartis, in clinical trials, Seaside has valuable patents that could provide leverage in partnership; Seaside would give Roche exclusive rights to these patents and halt the development of their drug while receiving royalties off the drug put out by Roche.<br><br>&quot;This deal will establish the biggest effort to date,&quot; in autism drugs, said Luca Santarelli, head of neuroscience for Roche. Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/19/health/roche-and-seaside-team-up-to-develop-autism-drugs.html?_r=3&amp;ref=health">Competitors Form Partnership to Develop Autism Drugs</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall,&#xA0;a top rated medical malpractice attorney in Ohio and Kentucky, applauds the two companies willing to put aside their competition in order to get badly needed medication to the market.<br><br>&quot;What is also needed is money and efforts to find out why autism is on the rise in our country, as the number of children affected by this disease has skyrocketed,&quot; says Crandall.<br><br>If you have any medical malpractice questions,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall.&#xA0;</strong>Steve is available to help answer your &#xA0;questions and guide you in determining your next steps.<br><br>&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Two-Year Nursing Degrees No Longer Enough for Hospitals
BASENAME: two-year-nursing-degrees-no-longer-enough-for-hospitals
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/12/2012 03:11:30 AM
-----
BODY:
Hundreds of hospitals across the country are experiencing a changing shift in the educational demands for nurses, sending thousands of caretakers back to school, according to The New York Times.<br><br>With more than 600 schools opening up &quot;R.N. to B.S.N.&quot; programs, allowing registered nurses to earn bachelor&apos;s degrees, admission rates have skyrocketed in recent years.<br><br>&quot;Fueled by the growth in online courses,&quot; writes Richard Perez-Pena, &quot;enrollment in such programs is almost 90,000, up from fewer than 30,000 a decade ago, according to the American Association of Colleges of Nursing.&quot;<br><br>This means that community colleges, responsible for the education of 58 percent of newly minted nurses in 2008, will need to find new ways to continue their educational programs in the future, including partnering with four-year colleges and finding enough qualified instructors to meet this demand.<br><br>Half of the nation&apos;s 3 million registered nurses had a bachelor&apos;s or master&apos;s degree in nursing, according to a 2008 federal government survey, but the Institute of Medicine is calling for that figure to be raised to 80 percent by 2020.<br><br>&quot;The baccalaureate programs can&apos;t find enough qualified instructors, so they turn away tens of thousands of qualified applicants every year,&quot; said Geraldine Bednash, chief executive of the American Association of Colleges of Nursing. &quot;There&apos;s going to be a big need for community-college-educated nurses for a long time, but they may be increasingly limited to nonhospital settings.&quot; Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/24/education/changing-requirements-send-nurses-back-to-school.html" target="_blank">More Stringent Requirements Send Nurses Back to School</a></strong><br><br>As a top-rated medical malpractice attorney in Ohio and Kentucky, Steve Crandall knows that a lack of education can cause many harmful and potentially fatal mistakes in a medical setting.<br><br>&quot;Many of us assume an &apos;R.N.&apos; means they have a four year degree, but this is not true,&quot; says Crandall. &quot;These shortened degrees allow the student to pass the certification exam; however, they often turn out under-educated and grossly inexperienced nurses. The result is bad care for the patient population.&quot;<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall.&#xA0;</strong>Steve is available to help answer your &#xA0;questions and guide you in determining your next steps.<br><br>&#xA0;<br><br>&#xA0;

BODY:
The production of four types of mesh implants used to treat urinary incontinence, and known as controversial for years, has been halted by Johnson &amp; Johnson&apos;s Ethicon division, according to the New York Times.<br><br>Despite two large groups of lawsuits filed by women who claim the devices caused serious injury, J&amp;J stressed that the move was not a recall, according to the report, but was based on the products&apos; commercial viability &quot;in light of changing market dynamics, and is not related to safety or efficacy.&quot;<br><br>News broke this week that J&amp;J continued to sell one of these implants - the Gynecare Prolift - even after they were told to halt production by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration due to safety issues in 2007.<br><br>The four recently discontinued implants have been linked to serious injuries in women, including infections, pain and other complications, for years.<br><br>&#x201C;This is very good news for women because it takes several products off the market that have harmed a lot of women,&#x201D; said Diana Zuckerman, president of the&#xA0;<a title="The center&#x2019;s Web site." href="http://www.center4research.org/">National Research Center for Women and Families</a>, a public health advocacy group. However, she said, &#x201C;the bad news is that there are many other surgical meshes still on the market that are just as dangerous.&#x201D; Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/06/business/johnson-johnson-unit-will-stop-selling-urinary-implants.html?_r=3&amp;ref=health" target="_blank">Johnson &amp; Johnson Unit to Halt Urinary Implants</a></strong><br><br>This story comes to us too late, according to Steve Crandall,&#xA0;a top rated medical malpractice attorney in Ohio and Kentucky, who believes enough damage has already been done to numerous patients implanted with these defective devices that were solely left on the market to make money.<br><br>&quot;Thousands of women had them implanted with the hope it would help their urinary incontinence, which was caused mostly by childbirth,&quot; says Crandall. &quot;Instead, the implant made things much worse by actually quickly eroding into their bladder, vaginal wall and other areas. Numerous surgeries to remove this, unrelenting pain and often worsening urinary incontinence were the result.&quot;<br><br>If you have been harmed by one of these defective products, or have any medical malpractice questions,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall.&#xA0;</strong>Steve is available to help answer your &#xA0;questions and guide you in determining your next steps.<br><br>&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Are Hospitalists Really the Best Answer for Patient Care?
BASENAME: are-hospitalists-really-the-best-answer-for-patient-care
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/03/2012 03:09:07 AM
-----
BODY:
The differences between inpatient and outpatient care were examined in a recent blog for The New York Times, as well as a subspeciality created in the medical field to account for these differences: the &quot;hospitalist.&quot;<br><br>The position of the hospitalist was created when it was found that many internists could not keep up with the traditional method of practicing both inpatient and outpatient medicine at the same time. The role of the hospitalist would be for &quot;doctors who would work full time on the inpatient side, caring for hospitalized patients on the minute-to-minute basis that they require, ideally staying fully in touch with the patient&apos;s primary care doctor.&quot;<br><br>But <em>ideally</em>&#xA0;does not mean that these functions are always carried out; is a patient helped or hurt by having multiple doctors responsible for their care at different times?<br><br><em>&quot;</em>The net effect is that the inpatient and outpatient care of our patients is shared among a group of physicians who, ideally, all know and trust one another,&quot; said Danielle Ofri, M.D. &quot;It&apos;s not a perfect system by any means, but among the imperfect choices out there, it is probably the best.&quot;&#xA0;Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/06/07/the-ins-and-outs-of-the-doctors-day/?ref=health" target="_blank">The Ins and Outs of the Doctor&apos;s Day</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall,&#xA0;a top rated medical malpractice attorney in Ohio and Kentucky, does not believe patients can benefit from the care of multiple doctors who may or may not be communicating effectively with each other regarding a patient&apos;s needs.<br><br>&quot;The problem is hospitalists often do not know the patient as well as their long-time doctor and often shy away from becoming too involved in the care of a patient,&quot; says Crandall. &quot;Many times the hospitalists will defer to other physicians since they do not know the patient as well, which can lead to delayed care and mistakes.&quot;<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall.&#xA0;</strong>Steve is available to help answer your &#xA0;questions and guide you in determining your next steps.<br><br>&#xA0;<br><br>&#xA0;

According to Cleveland&apos;s News Channel 5&apos;s Investigators, an alarming statistic was released by the <a href="http://www.billadvocates.com/">Medical Billing Advocates of America</a>, a group of experts who help patients with fraudulent billing activity: &#xA0;mistakes are found on 90 percent of the approximately 11,000 medical bills they personally review each year.<br><br>Medical billing errors are placing a heavy burden on U.S. taxpayers. Medicare estimates it spent $28.8 billion in improper payments in 2011, while Ohio ranked eighth in improper payments in the U.S. in 2010.<br><br>Patients are commonly charged twice for the same service, charged for services they did not need or even charged for services they did not receive, according to the report.<br><br>&quot;There&apos;s no check and balance system. None,&quot; said Pat Willis, a Cleveland-area patient advocate for the Medical Billing Advocates of America. &quot;Nobody&apos;s checking out these insurance companies. Nobody&apos;s checking out these hospitals. They&apos;re just running rampant.&quot;<br><br>Willis has seen bills where patients have been charged up to $53 for latex gloves, $22 per cotton swab...even $1,000 for a toothbrush. Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong>Most northeast Ohio and U.S. medical bills contain mistakes, patient advocate says</strong><br><br>&quot;The single largest problem in health care today,&quot; says Steve Crandall, &quot;is the insurance companies and the control they have over how much a health care provider can bill patients and how much they will pay them to do that.&quot;<br><br>As a top rated medical malpractice attorney in Ohio and Kentucky, Crandall knows the harmful implications that inflated medical bills cause on a patient&apos;s finances. &quot;The overbilling and abuse of patients and their pocketbook reminds me of the government waste which gets uncovered from time to time, like the U.S. Navy paying $200,000 for a hammer or $1 million for a toilet seat,&quot; says Crandall. &quot;They both have the same thing in common: someone has gotten away with billing people like this in the past and will keep doing it until they are caught and stopped.&quot;<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall.</strong>

BASENAME: ohios-war-on-prescription-drug-abuse
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1

DATE: 06/18/2012 04:39:58 AM

BODY:
New emergency room protocols will make it more difficult for patients to receive narcotic painkillers from ERs and urgent-care centers, the source of nearly 40 percent of all painkillers, according to the Columbus Dispatch.<br><br>&quot;Strong pain pills will be harder to get; those who get them will be prescribed only a three-day supply,&quot; according to Alan Johnson of the Columbus Dispatch. &quot;There will be closer scrutiny of patient IDs, and some people might be required to take urine tests to detect possible drug use. A lost prescription will be harder to replace.&quot;<br><br>Despite the devastating statistics - drug-overdose deaths surpassed those from motor vehicle accidents in 2007 and one in eight teens have used powerful painkillers that they weren&apos;t prescribed (Reuters Health) - there is still a consistent problem with physicians overprescribing pain pills, according to Ohio state officials.<br><br>&quot;We don&apos;t want to be at war with people who practice medicine,&quot; said Gov. John Kasich at the opening of the Ohio Opiate Summit in Columbus. &quot;Nobody&apos;s going to want to be out of the circle on this.&quot;<br><br>Read the complete articles here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://www.crainscleveland.com/apps/pbcs.dll/section?category=framelink&amp;link=www.dispatch.com%2fcontent%2fstories%2flocal%2f2012%2f05%2f08%2fgovernor-restricts-pain-pill-access-in-ers.html&amp;oas=www.dispatch.com_content_stories_local_2012_05_08_governor-restricts-pain-pill-access-in-ers.html">Governor restricts pain-pill access in ERs</a></strong><br><br><strong><a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/07/us-painkillers-idUSBRE8460ZV20120507">One in eight teens misuses prescription painkillers</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top rated medical malpractice attorney in Ohio and Kentucky, believes any laws that seek to prevent this common and widespread problem should be applauded, but are long overdue.<br><br>&quot;There are many physicians who make a tremendous living writing pain pills to those who are addicted and, therefore, unable to stop themselves from being abused,&quot; said Crandall.<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall.</strong><br><br>&#xA0;

TITLE: Whistle-Blowers Spark Needed Change in Ohio Law
BASENAME: whistle-blowers-spark-needed-change-in-ohio-law
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 06/21/2012 04:40:34 AM

BODY:
Four former sales staff members tipped off authorities to Abbott Laboratories&apos; improper marketing of medication and will now split $84 million, according to the Columbus Dispatch.<br><br>&quot;Abbott made the payment to settle claims that it improperly marketed the neurologic medication Depakote for off-label, or unapproved, uses,&quot; according to Tim Feran of the Columbus Dispatch.<br><br>The payout, part of a $1.6 billion settlement, is considered to be the largest since the False Claims Act was revised over twenty-five years ago. Whistle-blowers were given more financial incentive to come forward by being awarded part of the settlement in the revised act.<br><br>Many states have their own False Claims Act, but Ohio does not. This &quot;whistle-blower protection law&quot; would encourage informants to come forward, according to Ohio Attorney General Mike DeWine, who supports Senate Bill 143 regarding this issue.<br><br>Read the complete article:<br><br><strong><a href="http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/business/2012/05/10/whistle-blowers-to-split-84-million.html">Whistle-blowers to split $84 million from Abbott Labs</a></strong><br><br>&quot;The amount awarded may seem excessive,&quot; said Steve Crandall, a top rated medical malpractice attorney in Ohio and Kentucky, &quot;but not when you consider the amount the company was stealing from consumers until these four individuals stepped forward to do the right thing.&quot;<br><br>Along with support for Senate Bill 143, Crandall believes Abbott Laboratories should be severely penalized so that they think twice before attempting dangerous practices in the future.<br><br>If you or a loved one have been harmed by medication error, including the drug Depakote,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall.&#xA0;</strong>Steve is available to help answer your &#xA0;questions and guide you in determining your next steps.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Patients to Pay More for Out-of-Network Care
BASENAME: patients-to-pay-more-for-out-of-network-care
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/11/2012 04:45:57 AM
-----
BODY:
The nation&#x2019;s largest health insurers have been accused of manipulating out-of-network care pricing, and now they are conning patients into significantly increased costs for this very coverage, according to The New York Times.<br><br>Despite an agreement reached in 2009 to finance an objective database of doctor&#x2019;s fees that patients and insurers nationally could rely on, these insurers are rapidly shifting to a calculation method based on Medicare rates, reducing reimbursement substantially since Medicare tilts its payments toward primary care, while most people go out of network for specialists.<br><br>While insurance companies defend this shift, saying exorbitant doctors&#x2019; fees are largely to blame, millions of insured families will be more vulnerable to catastrophic medical bills, even while paying higher premiums, co-payments and deductibles.<br><br>Fair Health, a new database being sought for legislation in New York, collects billions of bills from insurers to calculate a usual fee for each medical procedure in a given locality and allows consumers to compare likely out-of pocket costs.<br><br>Sandy Praeger, chairwoman of the health insurance committee of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, said consumers are being caught in the middle of a battle between insurers demanding discounts and doctors who resist by billing more than they expect to get paid. &#x201C;For some things, Medicare is really a poor payer,&#x201D; she said. &#x201C;So if that&#x2019;s the benchmark, that just magnifies the problem.&#x201D;<br><br>Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/24/nyregion/health-insurers-switch-baseline-for-out-of-network-charges.html?pagewanted=1&amp;_r=1">Insurers Alter Cost Formula, and Patients Pay More</a></strong><br><br>&#x201C;This is yet another example of the billion dollar insurance industry looking for more ways to collect ever rising premiums, pay less claims and maximize payments for out-of-network care being sought by patients,&#x201D; says Steve Crandall, a top rated medical malpractice attorney who has seen his fair share of patients being overcharged.<br><br>&#x201C;The insurance industry dictates whom the patients can see, what the doctors can charge and what premiums they can charge to do all this,&#x201D; says Crandall. &#x201C;How government has stood by and allowed this to happen is one of the biggest economic and social mistakes of our generation.&#x201D;<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky, <strong>contact Steve Crandall.</strong>
 
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Medical Billing: An Arcane System
BASENAME: medical-billing-an-arcane-system
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 06/13/2012 02:22:27 AM
-----
BODY:
The Cleveland Plain Dealer is running a year-long examination of a system that affects every patient in America, usually causing undue stress and a myriad of questions: medical billing.<br><br>The centers for Medicare Medicaid Services announced there would be a one-year delay in implementing tens of thousands of new medical billing codes; these codes dictate how much is paid to medical providers and who pays it.<br><br>&#x201C;The world of billing problems is as vast as medicine itself,&#x201D; according to Sarah Jane Tribble of The Plain Dealer. &#x201C;Among the many frequent complaints are: patients being billed for the wrong treatment, receiving double billing for the same treatment, being charged for more than an insurance contract allows or getting a bill for unexpected costs, such as a &#x2018;facility fee.&#x2019;&#x201D;<br><br>No one seems to want to take the blame for these medical billing issues; insurance companies claim the wrong codes are plugged in by hospitals and doctors due to human error or intentionally to get more money, while the other side claims there are too many arguments over whether services should be paid.<br><br>It is clear, though, who is truly paying for the downfalls of this arcane system: consumers.<br><br>&#x201C;Medical bills are one of the major reasons bankruptcies are being filed in the five northern Ohio counties served by the Legal Aid Society of Cleveland,&#x201D; said staff lawyer Michael Attali. Medical crises have also been linked to a large number of home foreclosures.<br><br>Read the complete first set of articles here and share your own medical billing stories:<br><br><strong><a href="http://www.cleveland.com/healthfit/index.ssf/2012/05/medical_billing_a_world_of_hur.html">Medical billing, a world of hurt: Error-prone system is headache for insurers, providers, patients</a></strong><br><br><strong><a href="http://www.cleveland.com/healthfit/index.ssf/2012/05/medical_billing_a_world_of_hur_1.html">Medical billing, a world of hurt: The most common errors, explained</a></strong><br><br><strong><a href="http://www.cleveland.com/healthfit/index.ssf/2012/05/share_your_medical_billing_err.html">Share your medical billing error story in our online survey</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top rated medical malpractice lawyer in Ohio and Kentucky, believes that this &#x201C;medical billing red tape&#x201D; underscores the major problems of our national healthcare system.<br><br>&#x201C;Many times billing errors seem purposeful as the companies hope people do not catch or follow up on the errors resulting in higher profits,&#x201D; said Crandall.<br><br>For any medical malpractice questions throughout the states of Ohio and Kentucky, <strong>contact Steve Crandall</strong>. Steve is available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your best next steps.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Medical Malpractice: Is &quot;I&apos;m Sorry&quot; Enough?
BASENAME: medical-malpractice-is-im-sorry-enough
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 06/08/2012 03:06:12 AM
-----
BODY:
Several hospitals across the country are adopting an apology program based on the assumption that saying &#x201C;I&#x2019;m sorry&#x201D; would make patients less likely to sue, reducing the number of medical malpractice lawsuits, according to WBUR, Boston&#x2019;s NPR news station.<br><br>Gabriel Teninbaum, an associate professor at Suffolk University Law School in Massachusetts, a state where these programs are making a foothold, believes that these methods are used by hospitals solely to save themselves, not to offer any comfort to the patients in question.<br><br>&#x201C;My concern is that a patient, after suffering a terrible injury as a result of an accident, will confuse a communication they have with their doctor as being intended to heal, when in fact it&#x2019;s intended to keep them from pursuing money damages,&#x201D; said Teninbaum.<br><br>One of the main issues raised regarding this program is the fact that, on average, patients who receive apologies tend to receive less money than patients did before the program was put in place because patients can be manipulated into underestimating the realistic amount of money they will need to carry on after such an injury.<br><br>Teninbaum believes there is a scenario that could work for the mutual benefit of both the hospital and the patient; as long as the patient is instructed to seek legal counsel from the very outset, the outcome could be positive for all parties involved.<br><br>&#x201C;&#x2026;What you&#x2019;re providing the patient with is empowerment so that they can go out and get educated on what their rights are,&#x201D; Teninbaum said. &#x201C;And from there, there can be a fuller transparent conversation where everyone is on the same page about how to resolve the matter.&#x201D;<br><br>Read the complete article here:<br><br><a href="http://www.wbur.org/2012/05/01/medical-apologies">Law Professor: Medical Apology Programs Might Manipulate Patients</a><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top rated medical malpractice lawyer in Ohio and Kentucky, agrees that these apology programs are yet another way to protect the care provider at the expense of the patient.<br><br>Crandall believes laws that are purposely written to protect physicians&#x2019; apologies and admissions of mistakes need to be changed; if he or she admits they were negligent, then this information should be allowed be presented to the jury in a court of law.<br><br>&#x201C;There are no laws to prevent the physician from bringing up when a patient thanks them or sends a kind note even when the patient is not fully aware of the mistake that physician made,&#x201D; said Crandall. &#x201C;How is that fair?&#x201D;<br><br>Steve Crandall is available to help answer your medical malpractice questions and guide you in determining your next steps; for any questions, contact Steve Crandall.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: America&apos;s Failing Healthcare System: Who is to Blame?
BASENAME: americas-failing-healthcare-system-who-is-to-blame
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/04/2012 04:33:19 AM
-----
BODY:
There is only one word to describe the American healthcare system, according to Dr. Otis Brawley, chief medical officer for the American Cancer Society: failure.<br><br>In a recent interview with The New York Times, Dr. Brawley spoke out about the assertion that the U.S. has the best health care in the world: &#x201C;It&#x2019;s not a great place to be sick if you are poor and uninsured and want consistent, basic care.&#x201D;<br><br>Dr. Brawley does not believe that the usual suspects are the only ones to blame for the shortcomings of the &#x201C;irrational&#x201D; American system, though; he says many American patients, particularly the wealthy, are &#x201C;gluttonous&#x201D; in their unwise consumption of health care resources and hurting themselves with overtreatment.<br><br>He has seen both sides of the patient spectrum throughout his medical career, from a patient in the early stages of colon cancer who shopped around until finding a doctor that would administer unnecessary chemotherapy, to a woman so in denial about her breast cancer that she did not go to a doctor until her breast literally fell off.<br><br>&#x201C;I blame patients, I blame doctors, I blame hospitals, I blame drug companies, I blame insurance companies,&#x201D; Dr. Brawley said. &#x201C;Our health care system is messed up because the system is designed to fail, and everybody is responsible for health care failing as it is now.&#x201D; The full details of the interview can be found here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/20/how-doctors-and-patients-do-harm/">How Doctors and Patients Do Harm</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top ranked medical malpractice attorney in Ohio and Kentucky, believes that rather than deciding whom to blame, the focus should be on finding solutions to this economic epidemic that is crushing everyone in its path.<br><br>&#x201C;While patients and physicians certainly have some responsibility, the main issue is the government&#x2019;s failure to hold billion dollar insurance companies responsible for their growing premium payments and lower payout for the care their insurance is supposed to provide,&#x201D; Crandall says.<br><br>Steve Crandall is available to help answer your medical malpractice questions and guide you in determining your next steps; for any questions, <strong>contact Steve Crandall.</strong>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Harmful, Unnecessary Drugs Prescribed to Nursing Home Patients
BASENAME: harmful-unnecessary-drugs-prescribed-to-nursing-home-patients
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/07/2012 04:37:47 AM
-----
BODY:
People place their loved ones in nursing homes in order for them to receive proper care and medical attention, but what happens when these facilities are not closely monitored?<br><br>More than one in five U.S. nursing homes are administering anti-psychotic drugs to people who do not have a condition that warrants their use, according to a Boston Globe study reported in USA Today.<br><br>These drugs, received unnecessarily by about 185,000 nursing home residents nationally in 2010, have powerful side effects, especially for patients suffering from Alzheimer&#x2019;s or other dementia-related ailments. However, many nursing homes are prescribing these potentially dangerous drugs to avoid agitation and combative behavior.<br><br>&#x201C;We have an inordinate amount of prescriptions written for a population that is already frail, and we know these drugs increase the risk for side effects, including death,&#x201D; said Michael Gloth, an associate professor at the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, specializing in seniors. &#x201C;So why are they being written?&#x201D;<br><br>Read the full details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://content.usatoday.com/communities/ondeadline/post/2012/04/report-antipsychotics-wrongly-prescribed-in-nursing-homes/1#.T6AR16uue6F">Report: Anti-psychotics wrongly prescribed in nursing homes</a></strong><br><br>&#x201C;Nursing home care is abysmal,&#x201D; says Steve Crandall, a top rated medical malpractice lawyer throughout Ohio and Kentucky, who believes the problem is only going to continue to get worse until something drastic is done.<br><br>This problem does not only affect the patients either, according to Crandall: &#x201C;While the patients are on the medication they are easier to care for and leave in their rooms. The problem is the patients are not being properly cared for and the increased use of medication causes additional cost for healthcare for all of us.&#x201D;<br><br>If you or a loved one have been affected by this improper medication process, or if you have any questions regarding medical malpractice in Ohio and Kentucky, <strong>contact Steve Crandall.</strong>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Older Transplant Patients Getting Second Chance at Life
BASENAME: older-transplant-patients-getting-second-chance-at-life
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/09/2012 04:43:43 AM
-----
BODY:
More patients over the age of 65 are being considered for heart transplants, patients who would have been routinely rejected just ten years ago, according to The New York Times.<br><br>Thanks to voluntary guidelines issued by the International Society for Heart and Lung Transplantation in 2006, hospitals are opening up their transplant candidacy to older people with otherwise overall good health, with some centers like the Cleveland Clinic and Johns Hopkins Medicine operating on patients in their early or even middle 70s.<br><br>&#x201C;Many of these older patients can transition to an even older age while maintaining a very good quality of life. Why would we deny someone that opportunity?&#x201D; said Dr. Mandeep Mehra, executive director of the Center for Advanced Heart Disease at Brigham and Women&#x2019;s Hospital in Boston and chairman of the committee that drew up the new guidelines.<br><br>Some transplant centers still do not want to risk such operations, though, even when statistics show insubstantial differences in survival rates based on age. There remains hearty debate that scarce organs should be allocated to young people, while seniors are placed on alternative lists to receive hearts from older donors that are not viable for younger patients. Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://newoldage.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/23/heart-transplants-for-older-patients/">Heart Transplants for Older Patients</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top rated medical malpractice lawyer in Ohio and Kentucky, believes that allowing older patients to receive heart transplants is a great reward to those who take care of themselves throughout their lifetime, allowing them the chance to continue this lifestyle with even more health and vigor.<br><br>He also believes we all need to look at the bigger picture when it comes to this issue: &#x201C;It is a great message for all of us to live healthy now, so we can continue to do so in the future.&#x201D;<br><br>For any medical malpractice questions throughout the states of Ohio and Kentucky, <strong>contact Steve Crandall.</strong><br>Steve is available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your best next steps.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: No Rhyme or Reason in Hospital Billing
BASENAME: no-rhyme-or-reason-in-hospital-billing
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/02/2012 04:28:11 AM
-----
BODY:
Patients go to hospitals with the expectation to get better, not to be buried with exorbitant hospital bills for years to come. The latter, however, is becoming more and more of a reality; hospital charges are all over the map, according to a new study reported recently in the Archives of Internal Medicine.<br><br>The New York Times recently highlighted this story when an insured California man spent four days admitted in a hospital and was subsequently charged $59,283 &#x2013; for an appendectomy. This amount is six times the fair price for performing an appendectomy in Northern California, according to the Healthcare Blue Book, and the cases only get more extreme from there; one patient was charged a staggering $182,955 for the routine surgery, and patients were given similar discrepancies in prices for a number of other procedures.<br><br>&#x201C;There&#x2019;s no rhyme or reason for how patients are charged or how hospitals come up with charges,&#x201D; said Dr. Renee Y. Hsia, the study&#x2019;s lead author and an assistant professor of emergency medicine at the University of California. &#x201C;There&#x2019;s no other industry where you get charged 100 times the same amount, or 121 times, for the same product.&#x201D;<br><br>Practical advice is offered to consumers for dealing with these out-of-control pricing practices that are not limited to the state of California, including: learning which hospitals are in their insurance network, obtaining an explanation of benefits regarding their insurance coverage and contacting the hospital and doctor for pricing estimates beforehand. Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/23/the-confusion-of-hospital-pricing/">The Confusion of Hospital Pricing</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top ranked medical malpractice attorney, believes a key player is responsible for the problem of overbilling patients: the medical insurance industry, who dictate exactly what procedures they will pay for and how much they are willing to pay for them.<br><br>As reimbursements paid to hospitals shrink each year, there is an increased pressure to admit and discharge more overbilled patients in order to maintain profit and recover the shortfall.<br><br>&#x201C;Without any laws to protect the patient or the hospitals, the insurance industry is free to charge more premiums and provide fewer benefits to the insured and the hospitals that care for them,&#x201D; says Crandall.<br><br>If you believe you are being overcharged for your procedures, or if you have any questions about medical malpractice in Ohio and Kentucky, <strong>please contact Steve Crandall.</strong>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: $2.9 million Settlement John Doe v. Anonymous Defendant Dayton, Ohio
BASENAME: 2-9-million-settlement-john-doe-v-anonymous-defendant-dayton-ohio
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 09/24/2012 09:14:13 AM
-----
BODY:
A man was in the hospital for injuries received at his home when an accident on his farm occured.   This accident would not have resulted in permanent injury but was serious enough to require a breathing tube until he improved.   His breathing tube was blocked by secretions and his vital signs worsened, however the nursing staff failed to appreciate the decrease in his condition.   Eventually he suffered a respiratory arrest which led to severe and permanent brain damage rendering him unable to care for himself.    The settlement will enable his care to be increased and may allow his family to purchase the equipment necessary to bring him home and to travel for additional therapies.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: New Brain Injury Prevention Technology in the Works
BASENAME: new-brain-injury-prevention-technology-in-the-works
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/30/2012 03:00:21 AM
-----
BODY:
Brain injury victims and Life Core Technologies, a Cleveland-based medical device company, recently got a major boost thanks to a $250,000 commitment by nonprofit venture development organization JumpStart Inc. to develop a patented disposable cerebral cooling system, according to the PR Newswire.<br><br>The Excel Cerebral Cooling System device will act as a cervical collar that immobilizes the patient&#x2019;s neck while simultaneously drawing heat away from the brain, allowing metabolism to slow down, cell membranes to stabilize and any inflammation of the brain to reduce.<br><br>&#x201C;Mild therapeutic hypothermia is needed as soon as possible after cardiac arrest, traumatic brain injury or stroke to minimize injury to the brain,&#x201D; JumpStart&#x2019;s Lee Poseidon said. &#x201C;This is an easy-to-use, non-invasive, highly effective solution to help decrease the potential long-term neurologic damage these already life-threatening incidents can cause.&#x201D;<br><br>Thanks to the investment, Life Core Technologies plans to advance additional scientific evidence of results for their device to be used by emergency first responders and in hospital intensive care units. Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong>JumpStart Invests $250,000 in Life Core Technologies, LLC</strong><br><br>Steve Crandall is hopeful this technology is designed and distributed quickly, as it could help thousands of patients a year decrease the effects of brain damage, an issue far too prevalent in the medical malpractice field.<br><br>Steve is a top ranked medical malpractice attorney in the state of Ohio and a leading medical malpractice lawyer in Cleveland.<br><br><strong>Please contact Steve Crandall with any of your medical malpractice questions. </strong>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Preventing Jackknife Truck Accidents
BASENAME: preventing-jackknife-truck-accidents
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/20/2012 04:47:27 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Jackknife accidents occur frequently in the US and injure many individuals and their families. &#xA0; </strong><br><br>In most cases these accidents are preventable and due primarily to driver error on the highway. &#xA0; Knowing how jackknife accidents happen can help the drivers around the trucks on the highway potentially avoid being part of such an accident.<br><br>A recent article looked at what causes jackknife truck accidents and how to prevent them:<br><br><em>Jackknifing occurs when the tractor and trailer components of a semi-truck get out of synch with each other. The trailer then swings to one side, putting the rig into an &quot;L&quot; or &quot;V&quot; shape.</em><br><br><em>More often than not, jackknifing happens because the wheels on the trailer lose their grip on the road. As such, jackknifing is more likely to occur in inclement weather or in situations where the truck driver attempts to stop suddenly by slamming on the brakes.</em><br><br>You can read more <a href="http://www.24-7pressrelease.com/press-release/understanding-and-preventing-jackknife-truck-accidents-307803.php">here...</a><br><br><strong>If you are someone in your family has been injured by a commercial trucking accident in Ohio or Kentucky, you should contact Steve Crandall and Crandall Law immediately to ensure their rights in such an accident are protected. &#xA0;</strong>
