AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Should Patients Have Access to Doctor&apos;s Notes?
BASENAME: should-patients-have-access-to-doctors-notes
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/21/2012 10:00:43 PM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Since the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (Hipaa) was passed in 1996, patients have had the right to read and even amend their own medical records.</strong><br><br>But what about the notes physicians take about their patients? Could these be misinterpreted or cause patients to excessively worry over minor abnormalities? A recent article in&#xA0;<em>The New York Times</em>&#xA0;examines this issue.<br><br>For one year, the study called OpenNotes allowed over 13,000 patients from three medical centers to have complete access to the notes their doctors wrote about them. At the end of the study, the results were resoundingly positive.<br><br>&quot;Approximately three-quarters of all the doctors said that such transparency had none of the dreaded impacts on their practice,&quot; writes Pauline W. Chen, M.D. &quot;Many felt there was more trust, better communication, more shared decision-making and increased patient satisfaction.&quot;<br><br>Patients who had full access to the notes of their physicians were better able to follow the treatment recommendations fully, according to the results of the study, which may lead to more widespread implementation of this program in other institutions.<br><br>&quot;While a portion of the doctors were hesitant at the beginning of the study,&quot; writes Chen, &quot;not a single one opted to stop sharing notes with patients after the study ended.&quot; Read the full details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/10/04/letting-patients-read-the-doctors-notes/" target="_blank">Letting Patients Read the Doctor&apos;s Notes</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky, is puzzled by the fact that very few patients choose to exercise the right to their own medical records.<br><br>&quot;There is a definite power in viewing your own chart,&quot; says Crandall. &quot;Not to mention, it can greatly increase the communication between yourself and your medical provider. Some patients even choose their provider or hospital based on free access to their chart via computer.&quot;<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall</strong>. Steve is available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.<br><br>&#xA0;

TITLE: Dayton Women with Cerebral Palsy Completes Triathlon
BASENAME: dayton-women-with-cerebral-palsy-completes-triathlon
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/23/2012 04:51:37 AM
-----
BODY:
Cerebral palsy is a severe and sometimes debilitating condition which can lead to the need for 24 hour care for the patient.<br><br>Yet earlier this month, a woman in Dayton rose beyond the chains of this condition and managed to excel both mentally and physically.<br><br>Veronika Zbrizher, a junior at Wright State University in Dayton Ohio who was born with cerebral palsy, completed a triathlon with the help of some local firefighters,<br><br>Zbrizher, unable to move independently, competed in the Great Buckeye Challenge, a relay triathlon held in Springfield, OH. She used a floatation device for the swimming portions and a bike/cart for the biking and running portions, and was assisted by a team of three local firefighters.<br><br>The ability of the CP person to excel is often tied also to the amount of medical care and treatment they can receive at a young age. &#xA0;Physical therapy, speech therapy and medical devices all help to provide the CP individual with the independence and ability to grow in this manner.<br><br><strong>If a birth injury has impacted the life of someone in your family, please contact Steve Crandall of Crandall Law to discuss your legal rights.</strong>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Asthma Inhalers Found to Affect Growth Permanently
BASENAME: asthma-inhalers-found-to-affect-growth-permanently
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/17/2012 04:26:28 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Children who use glucocorticoid inhalers to prevent asthma may have growth deficiencies that persist into adulthood, according to a study reported in&#xA0;<em>The New York Times</em>.</strong><br><br>Scientists found that children who inhale budesonide - sold under the brand name Pulmicort - were on average about half an inch shorter than those who used placebos in the study by the age of 25, with a greater decrease in adult height with a higher dose of the drug.<br><br>&quot;There are lots of studies that show the inhalant corticosteroids produce a decrease in growth in prepubertal children,&quot; said H. William Kelly, the study&apos;s lead author. &quot;But we have the first long-term prospective study that shows that you don&apos;t outgrow it.&quot; Read the full details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/09/03/use-of-inhalers-may-affect-growth/" target="_blank">Use of Inhalers May Affect Growth</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky, believes this is an article every parent that has a well-known genetically passed lung disease or child with asthma should read.<br><br>&quot;While inhaled steroids, used daily, can help keep asthma effects at bay their long term side effects when used in children is only now becoming known,&quot; said Crandall. &quot;This poses a dilemma for their parents; use the inhalers which help with day to day living, or rely on other medication which is not as useful but have less side effects.&quot;<br><div></div><br><div>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall</strong>. Steve is available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.</div><br><div></div><br><div></div><br>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Meningitis Outbreak: Could Other Drugs Be Affected?
BASENAME: meningitis-outbreak-could-other-drugs-be-affected
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/19/2012 02:05:58 AM

BODY:
<strong>The drug company responsible for the recent meningitis outbreak - 247 cases, including 19 deaths as of today - is now facing scrutiny over their shipments of more than 100,000 other drugs, according to&#xA0;The New York Times.</strong><br><br>The New England Compounding Center in Framingham, Mass. shipped more than 17,000 vials of the fungus-contaminated spinal injection drug to 23 states. The Food and Drug Administration and state health departments are now focusing on a list of more than 131,000 shipping invoices for other products from the Center across the U.S.<br><br>&quot;The products of most concern are drugs used during open-heart surgery and eye operations, and another steroid, triamcinolone, also used in spinal injections,&quot; writes Denise Grady and Abby Goodnough. &quot;But other products are suspect as well, and the list of drugs made by the company runs to 71 pages.&quot;<br><br>There have been troubling reports of at least four prior complaints regarding the sterility of the Center&apos;s products to the Massachusetts Board of Registration in Pharmacy.<br><br>The House Committee on Energy and Commerce spoke out recently about these deadly contaminants: &quot;We are determined to get to the bottom of how it occurred, whether it could have been prevented, and how we can ensure something like this never happens again,&quot; says Committee Press Secretary Debbee Keller. BODY:
<div>Elderly Medicare patients have been billed an additional $11 billion or more by medical professionals over the last decade due to expensive billing codes, according to&#xA0;NBC News.</div><br><div></div><br><div>Upcoding - &quot;the practice of charging for more extensive and costly services than &#xA0;delivered&quot; - has been found to be the practice of thousands of doctors in a recent study by the Center of Public Integrity.</div><br><div></div><br><div>While medical groups argue that, because seniors are living longer due to new technology, they are more complex and time-consuming to treat, CPI&apos;s report found little evidence to base this explanation on.</div><br><div></div><br><div>&quot;Healthcare providers also said the rise in fees may be a reaction to years of under-charging, and that the higher costs reflect more accurate billing,&quot; writes&#xA0;<em>NBC News</em>.&#xA0;Read the full details here:</div><br><div></div><br><div><a href="http://economywatch.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/09/17/13917477-doctors-billing-medicare-patients-at-higher-rates-report-finds?lite" target="_blank"><strong>Doctors billing Medicare patients at higher rates, report finds</strong></a></div><br><div></div><br><div>Steve Crandall, a&#xA0;top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky, believes the rise of medical billing code complaints may be part of a larger picture.</div><br><div></div><br><div>&quot;The physicians bill higher rates since the reimbursement amount paid to them for legitimate medical procedures continues to shrink,&quot; said Crandall, who also sees an overwhelming rise in the amount of patients physicians see and procedures performed in order to generate enough income to keep their practices profitable.</div><br><div></div><br><div>&quot;This bad cycle ends up hurting the patients in the long run as tired and worn out physicians will make more mistakes in an effort to keep up with the increased volume. Until this problem with our medical system is fixed, medical errors will increase.&quot;</div><br><div></div><br><div>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall</strong>. BODY:
A new study finds that many tumors in tens of thousands squamous cell lung cancer patients have mutations that might be treated by drugs that are already being developed or could be easily developed, according to&#xA0;<em>The New York Times</em>.<br><br>Drugs could potentially be tailored to match the different genetic abnormalities found in each patient of the disease that kills about 50,000 people each year.<br><br>With the study comparing the infected cells to the normal healthy cells of 178 squamous cell lung cancer patients, it was found that over 60% of the tumors would be particularly vulnerable to new cancer drugs that are already available or being tested in other cancers.<br><br>&quot;&apos;This is a disease where there are no targeted therapies,&apos;&quot; said Dr. Matthew Meyerson of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, referring to modern drugs that attack genetic abnormalities. &quot;&apos;What we found will change the landscape for squamous cell carcinoma. AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Will New Rules Protect Us from Commercial Trucking Accidents?
BASENAME: will-new-rules-protect-us-from-commercial-trucking-accidents
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/09/2012 06:09:39 AM
-----
BODY:
<span style="line-height: 13px;"><strong>A recent &#xA0;article examined new Laws and Rules to be implemented regarding trucking safety on our highways. &#xA0;</strong> </span><br><br><span style="line-height: 13px;">While this will help strengthen existing laws and help avoid some accidents, unfortunately many trucking companies and individual drivers will continue to violate laws and cause accidents which injure or kill many thousands of individuals a year. &#xA0;</span><br><h4 style="padding-left: 60px;">New Commercial Trucking Rules May Make American Roads Safer</h4><br><div style="padding-left: 60px;">The Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration, or FMCSA, announced at the end of August that it will implement several provisions of its ambitious strategic plan, Moving Ahead for Progress in 21<sup>st</sup>&#xA0;Century, or MAP-21. The FMCSA&#x2019;s goal is to develop 29 new rules in the next 27 months. These rules will likely improve safety for all road users over the next few years.</div><br><section id="article_content" style="padding-left: 30px;"><br><p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>Rule Changes to Take Place by October 2012</strong></p><br><p style="padding-left: 30px;">In an aggressive move, by this October, the FMCSA will change its rules on how it reprimands motor carriers that are found to be immediately dangerous to other drivers and a significant risk for&#xA0;<a href="http://www.ig-law.com/Personal-Injury/Truck-Accidents.shtml">truck accidents</a>. Currently, the agency can immediately shut down a company whose fleet is an imminent hazard to road safety. A carrier may be labeled an &#x201C;imminent hazard&#x201D; if it fails to take required safety precautions and creates conditions that may cause imminent death, serious injury or property or environmental damage before a formal proceeding can be completed.</p><br><br></section><strong><a title="read the complete article" href="http://knowledgebase.findlaw.com/kb/2012/Sep/642614.html">Click here to read the complete article...</a></strong><br><br><span style="line-height: 13px;">If you are someone you know is involved in an accident with a commercial truck of any kind, act fast and obtain legal counsel to protect your rights</span>

BASENAME: medical-errors-why-are-they-not-being-reported
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1

ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/05/2012 03:49:09 AM

BODY:
<div>Many patients who are victims of medical errors do not file formal complaints largely due to misunderstanding the bureaucracy, according to&#xA0;NBC News.</div><br><div></div><br><div>In a review of medical records by the U.S. Health and Human Services Department&apos;s inspector general, it was found that one in seven Medicare patients was harmed in the hospital over a single month.</div><br><div></div><br><div>&quot;An estimated 1.5 percent of Medicare beneficiaries experienced an event that contributed to their deaths, which projects to 15,000 patients in a single month,&quot; said the Inspector General.</div><br><div></div><br><div>While there are various places to file a formal complaint, many patients who are traumatized, disabled or unaware that they have been a victim of a medical error do not come forward. Without complaints, no accountability is taken by providers who may have made mistakes, often leading to these mistakes being repeated time and time again.</div><br><div></div><br><div>&quot;&apos;You really can&apos;t improve what you don&apos;t measure,&apos;&quot; said Dr. Julia Hallisy, president of the Empowered Patient Coalition. &quot;&apos;How do you know where to focus your improvement efforts if you haven&apos;t measured what&apos;s happening in the first place?&apos;&quot; Read the full details here:</div><br><div><strong>&#xA0;</strong></div><br><div><strong><a href="http://vitals.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/09/26/14101278-why-patients-dont-report-medical-errors#comments" target="_blank">Why patients don&apos;t report medical errors</a></strong></div><br><div></div><br><div>&quot;The real story here is the sheer number of medical errors that occur and the unwillingness of the medical profession to attempt to fix them,&quot; said Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky.</div><br><div></div><br><div>&#xA0;&quot;Rather than fighting lawsuits and spending time attempting to prevent valid claims from reaching the courthouse, this time and energy should be spent on improving patient care,&quot; said Crandall. &quot;In that way the medical profession can not only save lives, but improve care for those in the future as well.&quot;</div><br><div></div><br><div>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall</strong>. AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Pain-Relieving Steroid Injections Linked to Meningitis Outbreak
BASENAME: pain-relieving-steroid-injections-linked-to-meningitis-outbreak
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/07/2012 05:47:26 AM
-----
BODY:
Spinal steroid injections of preservative-free methylprednisolone acetate - a common treatment for back pain administered to millions of people in the United States every year - has been linked to an outbreak of meningitis, according to&#xA0;The New York Times.<br><br>Doctors suspect the steroid medicine has been contaminated with the Aspergillus fungus; the direct outbreak of meningitis, which does not spread from person to person, has killed seven people and infected tens of others since the story was first reported last week.<br><br>&quot;All the patients who became ill were treated with one or more injections between July 30 and Sept. 18,&quot; reports Denise Grady, &quot;and the incubation period - the time between exposure and when the patient gets sick - has ranged from seven days to about four weeks. That means that some patients may become ill in the next few weeks.&quot;<br><br>Symptoms have been known to include headache, dizziness, fever, loss of balance and slurred speech, many of which are stroke symptoms which make a correct diagnosis challenging. Detecting and treating the disease as early as possible is the best chance of curing it. Read the full details here:<br><br><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/03/health/meningitis-cases-are-linked-to-steroid-injections.html?_r=0" target="_blank"><strong>Meningitis Cases Are Linked to Steroid Injections in Spine</strong></a><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky, urges anyone who received pain-relieving steroid injections to heed caution to these symptoms.<br><br>&quot;Since the facts are just&#xA0;coming to light, steroid injections of any kind should be watched&#xA0;carefully, whether the location is the spine or elsewhere,&quot; says Crandall.<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall</strong>. Steve is available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Lack of Federal Drug Regulations Linked to Fatal Meningitis Outbreak
BASENAME: lack-of-federal-drug-regulations-linked-to-fatal-meningitis-outbreak
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/08/2012 06:49:32 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>This is a developing story where anyone who has had steroid injections for&#xA0;pain or orthopedic injuries should keep a close watch. &#xA0; A manufacturer of&#xA0;this common injectable apparently was not in accordance with safety&#xA0;standards resulting in a virus being injected along with the steroid.&#xA0;This virus has led to a number of deaths and critically ill patients. &#xA0; Be&#xA0;aware of this situation and ask your doctor before receiving any injection&#xA0;like this.</strong><br><br>The rising toll of those affected by the growing national outbreak of meningitis - 8 dead, over 100 ill and thousands potentially exposed, &#xA0;according to latest reports - have cast a harsh light on drug regulations, according to&#xA0;<em>The New York Times</em>.<br><br>The contaminated drugs all came from the New England Compounding Center (Framingham, MA), a compounding pharmacy that mixes up batches of drugs on their own for much lower prices than major manufacturers charge.<br><br>There have been a series of complaints against the compounding center in the past decade: the State Health Department inspected in 2006 and, &quot;according to a warning letter sent by the F.D.A. from that year, the company was accused of illegally producing a standardized anesthetic topical cream, inappropriately repackaging a drug, and telling doctors that using an office staff member&apos;s name was enough to put in an order, even though the rules require a prescription for a particular patient.&quot;<br><br>&quot;The Food and Drug Administration has more regulatory authority over a drug factory in China than over a compounding pharmacy in Massachusetts.&quot; said Kevin Outterson, an associate professor of law at Boston University.<br><br>Meningitis can be caused by viruses, bacteria or fungi, the latter being the case with the recent outbreak. The fungi type is the hardest to treat because it can cause strokes in patients, which has already occurred in multiple instances.<br><br>Dr. Anders Cohen, the chief of neurosurgery and spine surgery at the Brooklyn Hospital Center, said: &quot;We ask for the medication, it&apos;s in stock, we use it. I don&apos;t know if it&apos;s coming from A, B or C. This is kind of a wake-up call about where your stuff is coming from.&quot; Read the full details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/07/us/scant-drug-maker-oversight-in-meningitis-outbreak.html?pagewanted=1" target="_blank">Scant Oversight of Drug Maker in Fatal Meningitis Outbreak</a></strong><br><br>&quot;This article should alarm the general public who likely feel the FDA keeps our citizens safe from the manufacture and distribution of bad drugs in&#xA0;our country,&quot; says Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky.<br><br>&quot;In fact, federal oversight directly led to bad&#xA0;drugs being injected into our citizens.&#xA0; The&#xA0;result has been a number of dead and injured as a result. &#xA0;This should&#xA0;not be allowed to occur.&quot;<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall</strong>. Steve is available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Grave Human Error Results in Suspended Transplant Program
BASENAME: grave-human-error-results-in-suspended-transplant-program
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/27/2012 06:21:09 AM
-----
BODY:
A serious human error has led to the suspension of the forty year-old University of Toledo Medical Center&apos;s living kidney transplant program, according to&#xA0;<em>The Toledo Blade</em>.<br><br>Two operating room nurses were suspended for previously undisclosed actions, which is now being reported as placing a donated, viable kidney in the trash before it could be transplanted to the intended recipient, the male donor&apos;s sister. The organ would have been a perfect match for the patient in end-stage renal failure, who must now wait for another match. The patient was sent home that day, and the donor was discharged the following day.<br><br>&quot;We cannot fathom the disappointment that those impacted have experienced over the course of the last week,&quot; said Dr. Jeffrey Gold, chancellor and vice president for biosciences and health affairs at UTMC. &quot;The university cannot begin to express the sorrow that we feel that this unfortunate incident occurred. We apologize sincerely.&quot;<br><br>Doctors tried unsuccessfully for at least two hours to &quot;resuscitate&quot; the organ to make it usable, but to no avail. The kidney would have been implanted within one hour of removing it from the donor.<br><br>Dr. Gold could not recall a similar incident to this human error involving a living, viable kidney.<br><br>&quot;I am not aware of an incident identical to this,&quot; he said. Read the complete details here:<br><br><a href="http://www.crainscleveland.com/apps/pbcs.dll/section?category=framelink&amp;link=www.toledoblade.com%2fMedical%2f2012%2f08%2f23%2fUTMC-suspends-kidney-exchange-over-human-error.html&amp;oas=www.toledoblade.com_Medical_2012_08_23_UTMC-suspends-kidney-exchange-over-human-error.html" target="_blank">UTMC suspends kidney exchange over human error</a><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky, has seen his fair share of medical negligence by health care providers with devastating results, and believes the repercussions will be much more than just a few suspensions.<br><br>&quot;What the general public may not know regarding this case is recent Ohio Supreme Court decisions will likely shift the responsibility for payment of this case from private insurers to the state of Ohio,&quot; said Crandall. &quot;In this economic climate, and move toward better government fiscal responsibility, this shift is devastating to Ohio and the public institutions.&quot;<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall</strong>. --------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Foreign Objects: The Hidden Danger of Surgical Procedures
BASENAME: foreign-objects-the-hidden-danger-of-surgical-procedures
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/02/2012 07:33:11 AM
-----
BODY:
Every year, an estimated 4,000 cases of &quot;retained surgical items,&quot; or items left in the patient&apos;s body after surgery, are reported in the United States, according to&#xA0;<em>The New York Times</em>.<br><br>These items, which also include clamps, scalpels and scissors, &#xA0;are usually gauzelike sponges and are left largely due to human error based on the old-fashioned method of keeping manual count of the amount of sponges used,&#xA0;of which dozens are stuffed inside of a patient to control bleeding during a surgical procedure. The operating room declared all sponges accounted for in four out of five cases in which they were left inside a patient.<br><br>&quot;In most instances, the patient is completely helpless,&quot; said Dr. Verna C. Gibbs, the director of NoThing Left Behind, a national surgical patient safety project. &quot;We&apos;ve anesthetized them, we take away their ability to think, to breathe, and we cut them open and operate on them. There&#x2019;s no patient advocate standing over them saying, &#x2018;Don&#x2019;t forget that sponge in them.&#x2019; I consider it a great affront that we still manage to leave our tools inside of people.&#x201D;<br><br>While hospitals now have access to more technological approaches to accounting for all sponges used during a procedure, including radio-frequency tags and bar code technology, many do not want to commit to the extra cost needed to implement these policies.<br><br>The extra cost to have each sponge implanted with a tiny radio-frequency tag that will alert a detector if left inside the patient before closing them up? About $10 - roughly the cost of a single suture used in surgery. Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/09/24/when-surgeons-leave-objects-behind/?ref=health" target="_blank">When Surgeons Leave Objects Behind</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;has vast experience in this ongoing problem; in 2012 the office of Crandall Law tried a case in the Lake County Court of Common Pleas - Kelly Maron et. al v. Lake Health Systems and Dr. Timothy Pritchard - in which a surgical towel was left in Kelly&apos;s abdomen after a June 2009 surgery to remove colon cancer. &#xA0;The towel was not discovered until November 2009 and caused the removal of 2/3 of Kelly&apos;s small bowel and massive digestive issues which will last her entire life. This case received a verdict of $910,000 on August 30, 2012 and has been informally reported as the largest medical negligence verdict in Lake County history.<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall</strong>. Steve is available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.<br><br>&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Is Fifteen Minutes Long Enough to Digest the Doctor&apos;s Orders?
BASENAME: is-fifteen-minutes-long-enough-to-digest-the-doctors-orders
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 09/25/2012 07:41:20 AM
-----
BODY:
Advances in preventive medicine and public health have given patients plenty of proven recommendations to keep from getting sick, which may be difficult for a doctor to fully explain in the course of a 15-minute office visit, according to&#xA0;<em>The New York Times</em>.<br><br>While these recommendations can potentially prevent injuries and fatalities, doctors are finding there is not enough time in the day to get into detail about each topic with each patient. Some physicians may choose to focus on a select few topics per visit, while others may resort to giving patients typed lists to read at home instead.<br><br>&quot;But an increasing number of doctors, under mounting pressures from insurance companies and others to prove that they are delivering quality care, are simply scrambling to cover as many of the wellness recommendations as they can, piling on the dos and don&apos;ts...&apos;the grand information dump,&apos;&quot; writes Pauline W. Chen, M.D.<br><br>Adding to the timeliness issue is also the fact that there is little proof that telling patients and their families to do something will result in any changes in behavior, especially when the information is crammed into a 15-minute visit.<br><br>&quot;Ideally a visit with the doctor is 15 minutes that can be used to build &#xA0;a very powerful relationship and transfer crucial information that will make our patients healthier,&quot; says Dr. Robert Needlman, professor of pediatrics at the Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine. &quot;Because we have so little time, we have to be able to devote our time to the things that will make a difference.&quot;&#xA0;Read the full details here:<br><br><strong>How Much Can Patients Learn in a 15-Minute Doctor Visit?</strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky, points out that a lack of time to communicate effectively may not be at the fault of the doctors.<br><br>&quot;The root cause is the insurance industry and the ever-shrinking reimbursements paid to physicians for routine visits,&quot; says Crandall. &quot;As these shrink for no good reason, physicians are forced to schedule more volume to keep their fees in line. This results in fewer time and concentration for their patients.&quot;<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall</strong>. AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Test Rules Out Heart Attack Within Hour
BASENAME: test-rules-out-heart-attack-within-hour
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 09/05/2012 04:44:28 AM
-----
BODY:
A new breakthrough in the field of cardiology will determine whether a patient is having a heart attack hours earlier, which could potentially save significant time and space in emergency rooms, according to&#xA0;<em>The New York Times</em>.<br><br>Tests commonly used today can take four to six hours to rule out a heart attack, while the new test, published in Archives of Internal Medicine, takes under an hour to reach the same conclusion.<br><br>Taking into account the changes of levels of cardiac troponins, rather than waiting until they reach high levels when a heart attack is well under way, researchers were able to rule out heart attacks in 259 patients of a group of 436 - with 100 percent accuracy.<br><br>&quot;It&apos;s quite exciting to have a high proportion of patients ruled out very early,&quot; said Christian Mueller, professor of cardiology at University Hospital of Basel, Switzerland. Read the full details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/08/20/heart-attack-test-rules-out-false-alarms/" target="_blank">Heart-Attack Test Rules out False Alarms</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky, believes this new test is a welcome advance in cardiology that could save countless lives.<br><br>&quot;The lab study for detection of elevated troponin has long been available but took 4-6 hours to be of any use,&quot; said Crandall. &quot;By then valuable heart muscle damage may have already occurred. The advances...will aid in detection and treatment of heart attacks greatly.&quot;<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall</strong>. Steve is available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.<br><br>&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Sepsis: The Little Known Common Killer
BASENAME: sepsis-the-little-known-common-killer
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 01/08/2013 01:41:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>New York health officials are poised to make their state the first in the nation to require that hospitals aggressively look for sepsis in patients so treatment can begin sooner, according to&#xA0;The New York Times.</strong>

Sepsis, an abnormal and self-destructive immune response to infection or illness, often progresses from a high pulse rate and fever to severely low blood pressure, shock and organ failure.

With early warning signs that are difficult to tell apart from the flu or cold, clinicians routinely do not suspect this leading cause of death in hospitals until it is too late.

&quot;It&apos;s the most common killer in intensive care units,&quot; said Dr. Mitchell M. Levy, a professor at Brown University School of Medicine. &quot;It kills more people than breast cancer, lung cancer and stroke combined.&quot;

If physicians and nurses were trained to watch for sepsis, as they now routinely do for heart attacks, the response can be handled before it gets out of control.&#xA0;If started early enough, the treatment, which includes antibiotics and fluids, can reduce the &quot;relative risk mortality [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][of sepsis] by 40 percent.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/21/nyregion/one-boys-death-moves-state-to-action-to-prevent-others.html?_r=0" target="_blank">One Boy&apos;s Death Moves State to Action to Prevent Others</a></strong>

Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky, believes major change is needed to prevent the thousands that needlessly die from sepsis each year.

&quot;Many physicians ignore well known signs, symptoms and lab values which warn of sepsis during a time when it can be treated,&quot; said Crandall.

<strong>If you or someone you know was injured from medical malpractice, contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law&#xA0;for a free consultation.</strong>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Cerebral Palsy: An Increasing Health Problem
BASENAME: cerebral-palsy-an-increasing-health-problem
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 12/12/2012 07:00:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Despite advances in medical care, cerebral palsy remains a significant health problem. As many as 1 million people of all ages are affected, and that number has increased over time.&#xA0;</strong><br><br>Cerebral palsy is an umbrella term for a group of disorders affecting body movement, balance, and posture&#xA0;caused by abnormal development or damage in one or more parts of the brain that control muscle tone and motor activity (movement).<br><br>Most children with cerebral palsy require significant medical and physical care, including physical, occupational, and speech/swallowing therapy.<br><br>There is no cure for cerebral palsy. With early and ongoing treatment, &#xA0;the disabilities associated with cerebral palsy can be reduced, but the therapy regimen for a specific individual with cerebral palsy should be tailored to meet the needs of that individual.<br><br>Care for people with cerebral palsy is complicated, requiring a number of different services and specialists, and can be very expensive.<br><strong><a href="http://www.emedicinehealth.com/cerebral_palsy/article_em.htm#cerebral_palsy_overview" target="_blank">Learn more about the causes, symptoms and prevention of cerebral palsy.</a></strong><br><br>While the symptoms and treatment options for cerebral palsy are important, so is determining if the cause of cerebral palsy was due to malpractice. Many states provide a short limitation on how long an investigation into whether malpractice occurred, therefore it is important to call an attorney experienced in this diagnosis quickly.<br><br><strong>If anyone in your family or any friends have a child with cerebral palsy&#xA0;please call immediately&#xA0;for a free consultation.&#xA0;</strong>Our attorneys will provide you and your family with a free, no-obligation case review.

<div><strong>Nearly four months after Daniel Hughes, an 18-year old chemical engineering student at Ohio State, was hit and run over by a construction truck on campus September 5, no police report has been released.</strong>As Hughes tries to cope with a bone infection and the loss of roughly one-third of his body, including his right leg and hip, many details of the case remain unknown to him and his family.

OSU Police promised Steve Crandall, Daniel&apos;s attorney, a police report the week of October 8, and again in November. According to Ohio Revised Code, a traffic crash report, typically a three-to-four-page document that tells what happened and who is involved, should be made available within five days of the incident

&quot;It&apos;s frustrating to Daniel and his entire family that there&apos;s still no report or time frame for when the report will be released,&quot; Crandall said. &quot;What is delaying that report, or even a portion of the report so that we can interview witnesses? <strong>Two former nursing home workers are in jail after being caught on camera abusing an elderly patient whose daughter decided to take actions into her own hands, according to NBC News.</strong><br><br>Regina Battles, 20, and Irene Rodriguez, 22, formerly of Arbors at Buck Run in Bucks County, Pennsylvania, are charged with neglect of a care dependent person, reckless endangerment, simple assault and harassment after video footage showed them &quot;dumping&quot; a resident on a bed and &quot;manhandling&quot; the patient.<br><br>This ongoing abuse, which also included singing and yelling directly into the resident&apos;s face, happened repeatedly from October 16 to November 13, according to the Pennsylvania Department of Public Welfare.<br><br>The abuse was discovered by the patient&apos;s daughter who installed hidden cameras in her wheel-chair bound mother&apos;s room after becoming suspicious of the treatment she was receiving. AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Hospitals Placing Profits Over Patient Care
BASENAME: hospitals-placing-profits-over-patient-care
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 12/09/2012 07:00:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<div>

<strong>Consolidation in health care is creating a tightening bind for independent doctors across the country, according to a recent article in <em>The New York Times</em>.&#xA0;</strong>

Reduced Medicare reimbursements and higher technology costs are just some reasons why the percentage of independent doctors nationwide has dropped from 57 percent to 39 percent since 2000, according to estimates by Accenture, a consulting firm. Hospitals, private equity firms and health insurance companies are also acquiring physician practices at a rapid rate.

Doctors who have sold their practices and become employees of large hospitals describe growing pressure by the hospitals that dictate which tests and procedures to perform, how much to charge and which patients to admit. Unnecessary tests and procedures are largely performed and patients who do not need a hospital stay are admitted just to meet the hospital&apos;s financial goals.

&quot;We&apos;re seeing a lot more consolidation that we did 10 years ago,&quot; said Jeffrey Perry, an assistant director in the Federal Trade Commission&apos;s Bureau of Competition. &quot;Historically, what we&apos;ve seen with the consolidation in the health care industry is that prices go up, but quality does not improve.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/01/business/a-hospital-war-reflects-a-tightening-bind-for-doctors-nationwide.html?ref=health&amp;_r=0" target="_blank">A Hospital War Reflects a Bind for Doctors in the U.S.&#xA0;</a></strong>

<strong>&#xA0;</strong>&quot;This is another disturbing example of hospitals placing profits in front of the concern for the patients they treat,&quot; said Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky. &quot;Many patients are injured at hospitals they should not have been admitted to or by tests that should not have been ordered.&quot;

<strong>If you or someone you know was injured in a hospital anywhere in the United States, you should consult with a qualified attorney to determine why.&#xA0;Please contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law&#xA0;for&#xA0;a free, no-obligation case review.</strong>

</div>

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: The 7 Top Causes of Medical Malpractice Claims
BASENAME: the-top-causes-of-medical-malpractice-claims
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 12/06/2012 07:00:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-6102 size-thumbnail" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/informed-consent-150x150.jpg" alt="The 7 Top Causes of Medical Malpractice Claims" width="150" height="150">

The&#xA0;negligence of a doctors, nurses, hospitals, and other medical professionals and facilities contribute to hundreds of thousands of deaths per year in the U.S. alone &#x2013;&#xAD; about 440,000, to be exact. While some mistakes are inevitable, and not all mistakes are grounds for a claim of negligence, there are some errors that occur over and over again, contributing to the high number of preventable deaths each year.

According to Dr. RJ Roberts of the&#xA0;<a href="https://www.med.wisc.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">University of Wisconsin Medical School</a>, these are the 7 top causes of medical malpractice claims in the country:
<ol>
    <li><strong>Failure to Obtain Informed Consent &#x2013;</strong>&#xA0;Medical errors are caused when a patient is not fully informed of expected outcomes, potential risks and reasonable alternatives to the recommended course of action by the doctor, which can result in damages to the patient.</li>
    <li><strong>Cancer Misdiagnosis or Failure to Diagnose or a Delay in Diagnosis</strong>&#xA0;&#x2013;&#xA0;Approximately <a href="https://www.cancer.org/cancer/breast-cancer/screening-tests-and-early-detection/mammograms/limitations-of-mammograms.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">20% of screening mammograms</a> return false negative results in breast cancer patients. Doctors who do not follow up appropriately on false negative studies for this and other types of cancer may cause harm to the patient.</li>
    <li><strong>Negligent Procedures or Surgical Errors</strong>&#xA0;&#x2013; Years of medical school and procedural training cannot account for a doctor who is physically exhausted or mentally distracted. Sleep deprivation or stress may result in severe patient complications.</li>
    <li><strong>Wrong Diagnosis and Negligent Misdiagnosis of Fracture or Trauma</strong>&#xA0;&#x2013; Doctors who assume an illness or fracture is minor without following up with additional x-rays or diagnostic tests are liable for medical malpractice claims. Dependent on the location of the fracture, the failure to follow through can have severe consequences, including loss of a limb.</li>
    <li><strong>Delay in Diagnosis or Failure to Consult in a Timely Manner</strong>&#xA0;&#x2013; A hesitation to make a referral, whether it be to a specialist or a course of treatment, can result in adverse repercussions suffered by the patient as a result.</li>
    <li><strong>Medication Errors or Medication Malpractice Resulting from Negligent Drug Treatment</strong>&#xA0;&#x2013; It is estimated that one million medication mistakes happen each year &#x2013; about <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/leahbinder/2013/09/03/the-shocking-truth-about-medication-errors/#294ed02e10ab" target="_blank" rel="noopener">one mistake every day for every patient</a>. Prescription drug malpractice claims can also result from a doctor&#x2019;s poor handwriting on the prescription order and misinterpretation by a pharmacist.</li>
    <li><strong>Birth Injury Malpractice or Negligent Maternity Care Practice</strong>&#xA0;&#x2013;&#xA0;The two most common birth defect or birth injury medical malpractice claims arise from excessive use of oxytocin, specifically if the baby is experiencing distress, and the doctor&#x2019;s failure to ensure their patient is covered by another physician informed about the patient&#x2019;s clinical history should the primary doctor be unavailable.</li>
</ol>
There are many reasons for the increasing cases of medical malpractice in the United States. If you or your family have questions about medical errors that should not have occurred and are not fully explained by the care providers, safety would require you to&#xA0;investigate the matter with an attorney&#xA0;who specialized in medical malpractice.
<h2>How common is medical malpractice?</h2>
According to the Journal of the <a href="http://journalofethics.ama-assn.org/2016/03/pfor6-1603.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">American Medical Association</a> (JAMA), medical negligence is the <a href="https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2016-05-03/medical-errors-are-third-leading-cause-of-death-in-the-us" target="_blank" rel="noopener">third leading cause of death in the U.S.</a> - right behind heart disease and cancer.&#xA0;In 2012, over $3 billion was spent in medical malpractice payouts, averaging one payout every 43 minutes.

Please&#xA0;contact the attorneys&#xA0;of Crandall &amp; Pera Law if you have any questions regarding what you believe to be a medical malpractice claim.&#xA0;We will provide you and your family with a free, no-obligation case review. You can reach our Ohio team at <strong>&#xA0;</strong>877-686-8879, our Kentucky team at 877-686-8879, or use our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to find out more.

If you have questions about our practice areas, we invite you to learn more by clicking these links:

[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][table id=1 /][/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Major Oversights by F.D.A. in Meningitis Outbreak
BASENAME: major-oversights-by-f-d-a-in-meningitis-outbreak
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 12/05/2012 02:06:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<div><strong>The recent meningitis outbreak that has sickened nearly 500 people and killed 34 might have been prevented if it weren&apos;t for oversight failures by the Food and Drug Administration, according to <em>The New York Times</em>.</strong><br><br>In documents released following Freedom of Information Act request, it was found that the F.D.A. continuously backed away from threats against the New England Compounding Center - which manufactured the tainted drugs - even when the Center refused to provide records, citing lack of jurisdiction. In some cases, the agency would issue a warning nearly<em>&#xA0;2 years&#xA0;</em>after an inspection of the facility had been made.<br><br>Perhaps most troubling is the fact that the F.D.A. was alerted of a possible contamination of the drug involved in the meningitis outbreak as far back as October 2002, but the Center continued to ship the drug in defiance of the agency&apos;s concerns.<br><br>As stated in the article, &quot;By law, compounding pharmacies are regulated primarily by the states, but the pharmacies have grown over the years into major suppliers of some of the country&apos;s biggest hospitals. The F.D.A. is asking Congress for stronger, clearer authority to police them....&quot; Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/22/health/documents-show-fdas-failures-in-meningitis-outbreak.html?ref=health&amp;_r=0" target="_blank">Oversight Failures Documented in Meningitis Outbreak</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky, believes this new information displays the very disturbing nature of an agency like the F.D.A. taking shortcuts that end up harming the public it was created to protect.<br><br><strong>If you or a loved one have been injured by a manufactured product, drug, medical device or medical malpractice leading to wrongful death or other injury, you should consult a qualified attorney to protect your rights.</strong><br><br></div>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: A Link Between Diet and Colon Cancer Deaths?
BASENAME: a-link-between-diet-and-colon-cancer-deaths
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 12/02/2012 10:00:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<div><strong>Everyone knows a healthy diet can increase your overall fitness, but do the foods you eat have any affect on your chance of surviving a serious disease like colon cancer?</strong><br><br><strong>That answer is yes, according to a study published in The Journal of the National Cancer Institute.&#xA0;</strong><br><br>The study found that patients treated with Stage 3 colon cancer who consumed the most carbohydrates and foods with high glycemic loads had an 80 percent greater chance of dying or having a cancer recurrence that those with lower blood sugar levels.<br><br>Researchers believe insulin may play a critical role in colon cancer recurrence by fueling the growth of cancer cells and preventing cell death in cancer cells that have spread, according to the study.<br><br>&quot;It&apos;s not simply that all carbs are bad or that you should avoid all sugar,&quot; said Dr. Jeffrey A. Meyerhardt, lead author of the study. &quot;I think people should focus on a well-balanced diet.&quot; Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/11/09/can-foods-affect-colon-cancer-survival/?ref=health" target="_blank">Can Foods Affect Colon Cancer Survival?</a></strong><br><br>&quot;Diets rich in whole grains and short on sugar provide an incredible benefit for those with colon cancer,&quot; said Steve Crandall, a top-rated attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky. &quot;This association should prompt many who don&apos;t have cancer to eat this way as well. Such a diet will lead to weight loss and all the health benefits of a healthy lifestyle.&quot;<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;contact Steve Crandall. Steve is available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.</div>

DATE: 12/03/2012 05:39:00 AM

<strong>Physicians who are feeling the weight of insurance reimbursements have been forced to make many changes in their practices, including becoming cash only, according to <em>The New York Times.</em></strong><br><br>This route, often called &quot;concierge medicine,&quot; usually results for three reasons: to preserve the doctors&apos; incomes, to avoid the administrative hassles of insurance and to provide better care.<br><br>&quot;The current model for primary care is broken,&quot; said Dr. David Edelson, who runs a five doctor practice in Great Neck, N.Y. &quot;Either I can go down with the ship, sell my practice to a hospital or take my practice in the wrong direction. Or I can develop a better mousetrap, which is more time dealing with patients and their care.&quot; Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/24/your-money/dealing-with-doctors-who-accept-only-cash.html?ref=health" target="_blank">Dealing With Doctors Who Take Only Cash</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky, says concierge medicine is just one route physicians take to combat insurance reimbursements.<br><br>&quot;Many others increase the volume of patients to make more money,&quot; said Crandall, &quot;which leads to malpractice, wrongful death and cases of birth trauma as a result.&quot;<br><br>If you have been injured due to medical malpractice <strong>please call</strong> to investigate your matter fully. AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Top 10 Prevalent Causes of Truck Accidents
BASENAME: top-10-prevalent-causes-of-truck-accidents
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 11/21/2012 04:49:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<div><br><br><strong>About 77,000 accidents caused by the direct fault of a commercial truck driver occur each year, according to a report by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA).</strong><br><br>It is important to be alert at all times on the road as these accidents are caused by a variety of different factors:<br><ol><br>    <li><strong>Prescription Drug Use</strong> - 26% of truck accidents are caused by prescription drug use even though the &quot;FMCSA has some additional rules that prohibit the use of legally prescribed controlled substances (such as barbiturates, amphetamines, morphine, etc.) by safety-sensitive drivers involved in interstate commerce.&quot;</li><br>    <li><strong>Traveling Too Fast</strong> - 23% of truck accidents are caused by a direct violation of FMCSA&apos;s regulation 392.6, which states &quot;No motor carrier shall schedule a run nor permit nor require the operation of any commercial motor vehicle between points in such period of time as would necessitate the commercial motor vehicle being operated at speeds greater than those prescribed by the jurisdictions in or through which the commercial motor vehicle is being operated.&quot;</li><br> <li><strong>Unfamiliar with Roadway</strong> - 22% of truck accidents are due to drivers reading a map or directions during travel. The FMCSA posts helpful tips to follow&#xA0;<em>before</em> driving to prevent these very accidents.</li><br> <li><strong>Over-the-Counter Drug Use</strong> - Even something as seemingly harmless as cough medicine can be very dangerous while operating a 80,000 pound machine; 18% of truck accidents are caused by over-the-counter medications.</li><br> <li><strong>Inadequate Surveillance</strong> - 14% of all truck accidents are caused by truck drivers not being adequately aware of their surroundings. Over 1/3 of all accidents between large trucks and cars take place in the &quot;No-Zone&quot; located in large blind spots. Truck drivers should be fully aware of these limitations and drive with caution accordingly.</li><br>   <li><strong>Fatigue</strong> -&#xA0;Federal regulation states that commercial truck drivers cannot drive more than 10 consecutive hours, or more than 11 hours in a day, yet 13% of truck accidents are caused by the truck driver&apos;s fatigue.</li><br>    <li><strong>Illegal Maneuver</strong> - 9% of truck accidents are caused by a truck driver not following the rules of the road. While drivers of all vehicles should always follow traffic laws, truck drivers should be extra cautious as their vehicles are 25-50 times the size of others on the road.</li><br>    <li><strong>Exterior Distraction</strong> - Risky behavior while driving, such as&#xA0;&#xA0;talking on a cell phone, eating, reading, or adjusting the radio, accounts for 8% of trucking accidents.</li><br>    <li><strong>Inadequate Evasive Action</strong> -&#xA0;In the 3/4 of a second it takes for the brain to send the signal to brake to the time the foot actually applies the brake, a truck can travel over 60 feet. 7% of all trucking accidents are caused by a driver failing to slow or brake in sufficient time for stopped or stopping traffic.</li><br>   <li><strong>Aggressive Driving Behavior</strong> - 7% of accidents are caused by a truck driver not taking in account their visibility limitations or pure size of their vehicle while disobeying traffic laws, whether it be following too closely or cutting off other drivers on the road.</li><br></ol><br>&quot;Given &#xA0;the size and weight of these trucks, this negligence often leads to devastating injuries and death to whomever in the vehicle they hit,&quot; says Steve Crandall, a top-rated attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky whose specialties include commercial truck accidents.<br><br><strong>If you or a loved one are involved in a trucking accident, it is critical to act quickly and retain an experienced lawyer to ensure evidence is gathered to help bring these cases forward.&#xA0;</strong><br><br><strong>Please contact Steve Crandall if you have any questions regarding your commercial truck accident.</strong>&#xA0;Steve will provide you and your family with a free, no-obligation case review.<br><br></div>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: What is Cerebral Palsy?
BASENAME: what-is-cerebral-palsy
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 11/26/2012 03:12:34 AM
-----
BODY:
<div><strong>Cerebral palsy, a set of neurological conditions that affect the brain and nervous system, is one of the most common effects of a birth injury.</strong></div><br><div></div><br><div>Caused by damage to the cerebrum, cerebral palsy makes it difficult for those with the condition to learn and communicate. The numerous signs and symptoms of cerebral palsy generally show during the first three years of life; it is a possible diagnosis &#xA0;if a child:</div><br><div><br><ul><br>  <li>Achieves developmental milestones, such as crawling, walking, or speaking, later than his/her peers</li><br>  <li>Crawls in an unusual way</li><br> <li>Has abnormal muscle tone - the child will slouch while sitting.</li><br>  <li>Has difficulty feeding and sucking</li><br>   <li>Lies down in awkward positions</li><br>   <li>Can be easily startled</li><br>   <li>Favors one side of the body over the other</li><br>   <li>Has overdeveloped or underdeveloped muscles (has floppy or stiff movements)</li><br>  <li>Has bad coordination and balance (ataxia)</li><br>    <li>Has involuntary, slow writing movements (athetosis)</li><br>  <li>Has muscles that are stiff and contract abnormally (spastic paralysis)</li><br>   <li>Has hearing problems</li><br> <li>Has problems with eyesight</li><br>   <li>Has bladder control problems</li><br> <li>Has bowel movement control problems</li><br>  <li>Has seizures</li><br> <li>Has problems swallowing</li><br>  <li>Has a limited range of movement</li><br></ul><br><div><strong><a href="http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/152712.php" target="_blank">Read more about the causes and effects of cerebral palsy.</a></strong></div><br><div></div><br></div><br><div>Cerebral palsy is a devastating injury to a newborn and leads to drastic life changes for the entire family unit.</div><br><div></div><br><div>&quot;Discovering whether cerebral palsy was due to decisions or negligence made during delivery may help provide compensation to allow for better care and a better environment for the entire family,&quot; says Steve Crandall, a top-rated attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky whose specialities include birth injuries.</div><br><div></div><br><div><strong>If anyone in your family or any friends have a child with cerebral palsy please call immediately for a free consultation.&#xA0;</strong>Steve Crandall will provide you and your family with a free, no-obligation case review.</div>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: New Technology Used to Stop Medication Errors
BASENAME: new-technology-used-to-stop-medication-errors
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 11/28/2012 03:39:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>A new computerized system being test-driven at Children&apos;s Hospital in Minneapolis may be able to drastically reduce life-threatening medication errors by catching them before they happen.</strong><br><br>The system relies scanning the bar codes found on a patient&apos;s armband and a programmable &quot;smart pump.&quot; If the dose does not match up when a nurse scans these codes along with the medication - or if the order has been canceled by a doctor - the smart pump will send out an alert.<br><br>Medication errors are an even greater worry with infants and children as dosage must be tailored to their weight. In one month alone, the new system sent out 234 alerts to nurses in one 26-bed unit warning that something was incorrect.<br><br>The effectiveness of the new system is beginning to catch on; the system will begin rolling out to other hospitals within the next few months.<br><br>&quot;Humans are humans, we&apos;re fallible,&quot; said Bobbie Carroll, the director of patient safety at Children&apos;s Hospital in Minneapolis. &quot;No matter how diligent we try to be sometimes, errors happen. What we strive to achieve is creating as many safety nets as we can.&quot; Read the complete details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://www.startribune.com/lifestyle/health/177996571.html" target="_blank">On the health beat: An IV machine that stops errors</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky, welcomes this new technology as an important improvement in the continuous plague of medical mistakes.<br><br>&quot;Medication errors are far too common and cause many more deaths per year than most of us realize,&quot; said Crandall. &quot;Human error is the primary cause, as a result, any new technology like this is bound to save lives and improve patient care.&quot;<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky, <b>contact the attorneys of Crandall &amp; Pera Law</b>. Our attorneys are available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps<br>

BASENAME: omega-3s-reduce-risk-of-stroke

DATE: 11/19/2012 03:02:47 AM

BODY:
<strong>Eating fish high in omega-3 fatty acids slightly reduces the risk for stroke, according to a large review of studies reported in <em>The New York Times</em>.</strong><br><br>The same cannot be said for supplements of omega-3 fatty acids, though; while the data showed that 2-4 weekly servings of fish reduced the risk of stroke by 6 percent, supplements showed no significant effect on risk.<br><br>Eating fish packed with good nutrients may be curbing other unhealthy habits as well.<br><br>&quot;When you eat fish more frequently, you eat smaller amounts of potentially bad proteins like red meat,&quot; said Rajiv Chowdhury, an epidemiologist at the University of Cambridge. AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Meningitis Outbreak Causes Second Illness
BASENAME: meningitis-outbreak-causes-second-illness
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 11/05/2012 03:36:51 AM
-----
BODY:
<div><strong>Those recovering from the recent meningitis outbreak caused by a contaminated steroid drug may be at high risk for a second illness, according to&#xA0;The New York Times.</strong></div><br><div></div><br><div>About a third of the 53 patients treated for meningitis at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital in Ann Arbor, Michigan have returned with an epidural abscess, an infection near the spine where the drug was injected to treat back or neck pain that causes severe pain.</div><br><div></div><br><div>Other affected locations across the country have reported patients infected with abscesses as well, even while these patients have been taking powerful antifungal medicines.</div><br><div></div><br><div>&quot;This is a significant shift in the presentation of this fungal infection, and quite concerning,&quot; says Dr. Lakshmi K. Halasyamani, the chief medical officer at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital. &quot;An epidural abscess is very serious. It&apos;s not something we expected.&quot;</div><br><div></div><br><div>While many of these internal abscesses can be drained or cleaned out by a neurosurgeon, others may be wrapped around nerves that cannot be surgically removed.</div><br><div></div><br><div>&quot;In such cases, all doctors can do is give a combination of antifungal drugs and hope for the best,&quot; writes Denise Grady. &quot;They have very little experience with this type of infection.&quot; Read the full details here:</div><br><div></div><br><div><strong><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/03/health/second-illness-infects-meningitis-sufferers.html?ref=health&amp;_r=0" target="_blank">Second Illness Is Infecting Those Struck by Meningitis</a></strong></div><br><div></div><br><div>The fact that the deadly mistakes made by a U.S. drug manufacturer continues to inflict harm on patients is frightening to Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky.</div><br><div></div><br><div>&quot;Spinal epidural abscesses are very lethal and can cause both paralysis and death,&quot; says Crandall. &quot;If anyone has a family member who had this drug injected, they should call an attorney immediately to protect their rights.&quot;</div><br><div></div><br><strong>If this or any other contaminated drug has impacted the life of someone in your family,&#xA0;please contact Steve Crandall of Crandall Law to discuss your legal rights.</strong><br><div></div><br><div></div>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Flu Vaccines Help Prevent Senseless Deaths
BASENAME: flu-vaccines-help-prevent-senseless-deaths
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/25/2012 10:00:52 PM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Forty-three percent of American children who die from the flu are perfectly healthy beforehand, according to a new study by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention as reported by&#xA0;NBC News.</strong><br><br>Kids who are healthier actually die faster from the flu than kids with high-risk conditions, an average of four days versus seven days, according to the study. This could be due to the vigilance of parents with children with health problems or the theory that the immune system in some healthy children goes into overdrive.<br><br>Due to the unpredictability of the flu and how fast it can kill, vaccination is the best protective prevention, says the CDC&apos;s Dr. Karen Wong.<br><br>&quot;Flu kills anywhere between 3,000 people a year to 49,000 people a year,&quot; writes Maggie Fox, &quot;but only 51.5 percent of children aged 6 months to 17 years were vaccinated last year. Just under 75 percent of babies aged up to 2 were vaccinated.&quot;<br><br>The rates drop even more as children grow up; only a third of kids in the 13 to 17 age group get vaccinated.<br><br>&quot;I was one of those people who didn&apos;t think they needed it,&quot; says Regina Booth, whose 17-year-old son Austin died less than a week after showing flu-like symptoms in January 2011. &quot;I was one of those people who thought if you get the shot, you are going to get sick.&quot;<br><br>Austin, a high school varsity athlete, had been perfectly healthy just a week before his death. Read the full details here:<br><br><strong><a href="http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/49465633/ns/health-cold_and_flu/#__utma=14933801.138299176.1342398188.1350569512.1350606643.250&amp;__utmb=14933801.5.10.1350606643&amp;__utmc=14933801&amp;__utmx=-&amp;__utmz=14933801.1347708475.148.2.utmcsr=msnbc.msn.com|utmccn=(referral)|utmcmd=referral|utmcct=http://cmpwlaw.web13.hubspot.com/id/3032525/ns/us_news/&amp;__utmv=14933801.|8=Earned%20By=msnbc%7Ccover=1^12=Landing%20Content=Mixed=1^13=Landing%20Hostname=www.nbcnews.com=1^30=Visit%20Type%20to%20Content=Earned%20to%20Mixed=1&amp;__utmk=249665030" target="_blank">Teen&apos;s death shows how flu can kill in a flash</a></strong><br><br>Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky, believes the facts are simple: everyone should get the flu vaccine.<br><br>&quot;Even with advances in medicine, the flu claims thousands of lives per year,&quot; says Crandall. &quot;Getting a flu shot is inexpensive, only takes a few minutes, and is now available everywhere.&quot;<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall</strong>. AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Client Receives Reported Largest Malpractice Verdict in Lake Co. History
BASENAME: client-receives-reported-largest-malpractice-verdict-in-lake-co-history
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1

DATE: 10/29/2012 08:03:16 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Kelly Maron, 43, of Painesville, Ohio has been awarded what is believed to be the largest medical malpractice verdict in Lake County history - $910,000 - for severe damage to her upper abdomen during a June 2009 procedure.</strong><br><br>Maron, who was represented in her case against Lake Hospital System Inc. and Dr. Timothy Pritchard by Ohio medical malpractice lawyer Steve Crandall, had a surgical towel left in her upper abdomen during &#xA0;a resection of her colon that was not discovered for five months.<br><br>By November 2009, two-thirds of the length of Maron&apos;s small bowel had to be removed along with the towel, leading to a loss of her ability to properly digest food and an inability to leave her house.&#xA0;Maron, a married mother of three, &#xA0;was able to treat her colon cancer early, but the injuries sustained from the forgotten towel will cause her a lifetime of suffering.<br><br>&quot;I really felt it was a shame the two sides even allowed this case to go to trial,&quot; says Crandall. &quot;You hear an awful lot about frivolous lawsuits. But this was a frivolous defense.&quot;<br><br>Lake Health officials have reported a procedural change in the type of towels used during surgery as a result of this case.<br><br>Read the full details here:<br><br><strong>Surgical towel left in patient results in $910,000 verdict against Lake Health doctor</strong><br><br>Dean Maron speaks very highly on the personal treatment he and his wife received by Steve Crandall throughout their lengthy and successful case: &#xA0;&quot;Throughout the trial he showed his experience by never becoming rattled by the opposition&apos;s attorneys, or their tactics and questions; he was always one or two steps ahead of the defense, and his passion for our particular case was apparent not only to us, but the jury as well.&quot;<br><br>&quot;Stephen restored our faith in the legal system and attorneys in general,&quot; continues Dean Maron. &quot;My wife and I both consider him a friend and the only attorney we would ever consider if we ever become entangled in the legal system again.&quot;<br><br>If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall</strong>. AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Ohio Law Strips Consumer Rights, Protects Big Companies
BASENAME: ohio-law-strips-consumer-rights-protects-big-companies
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 11/02/2012 06:29:59 AM
-----
BODY:
<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Ohio&apos;s Consumer Sales Practices Act has been weakened to allow businesses that have been found guilty of defrauding consumers to dodge penalties, according to <em>The&#xA0;Plain Dealer</em>.</strong></p><br><p style="text-align: justify;">Local legislature all the way up to the U.S. Supreme Court have made it easier for corporations to conquer complaining consumers by forcing them into private arbitration.</p><br><p style="text-align: justify;">Mandatory arbitration bars consumers from ever taking &#xA0;a company to court for unresolved issues; one must plead their case to an arbitrator, usually one that the company picks, instead.</p><br><p style="text-align: justify;">Clauses keeping consumers from having disputes heard by a jury &quot;lurk in the user agreements for your cell phone, credit card, computer, insurance, satellite TV service, student loans, car loans, mom&apos;s nursing home, even your dating service,&quot; writes Sheryl Harris.</p><br><p style="text-align: justify;">In order to combat these clauses, consumers must be very aware of the ins and outs of every contractual agreement they make. Be sure to read notices companies send about contract changes and opt out of arbitration requirements when possible and speak up to state legislature about getting the Ohio consumer law restored. Read the full details here:</p><br><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong><a href="http://www.cleveland.com/consumeraffairs/index.ssf/2012/10/companies_keeping_consumers_ou.html" target="_blank">Companies keeping consumers out of courts: Plain Dealing</a></strong></p><br><p style="text-align: justify;">Steve Crandall, a top-rated medical malpractice attorney throughout Ohio and Kentucky, worries that many of Ohio&apos;s citizens are unaware of the rights being slowly stripped away from them by laws protecting big companies and the health care industry.</p><br><p style="text-align: justify;">&quot;These new laws, all passed in open forums, make it more difficult - if not impossible - to have your case heard in a court, or, in addition, cap reasonable damages which would be awarded if a citizen can ever get their case heard in court,&quot; says Crandall.</p><br><p style="text-align: justify;">&quot;All too often, people do not realize this until it is too late.&quot;</p><br><p style="text-align: justify;">If you have any questions regarding medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky,&#xA0;<strong>contact Steve Crandall</strong>. Steve is available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.</p>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Lowering Costs Worth Lesser Care?
BASENAME: lowering-costs-worth-lesser-care
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 03/01/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>With a growing number of iniatitives to control health care costs championed in recent years, doctors are looking for patients to be more cost conscious.</strong>

Programs such as pay-for-performance, where doctors earn money by meeting quality &quot;goals&quot; like controlling patients&apos; high blood pressure, and accountable care organizations, where clinicians and hospitals in partnership are paid a lump sum to cover all care, are aiming to replace the current model in which doctors are reimbursed for every office visit, test or procedure performed.

While health professionals claim to be open to controlling costs, they cite the fact that they must also consider their patient&apos;s opinions and willingness to be cost conscious when it comes to their own care as potential obstacles.

&quot;We need to begin to talk about these issues in a way that doesn&apos;t turn it into a discussion pitting money against life...&quot; said Dr. Susan Dorr Gold, professor of internal medicine and health management and policy at the University of Michigan. &quot;Because it&apos;s going to be tough otherwise trying to implement any cost-saving measures, if patients don&apos;t accept them.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Getting Patients to Think About Costs" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/02/21/getting-patients-to-think-about-costs/" target="_blank">Getting Patients to Think About Costs</a></strong>

Too often medical malpractice occurs as physicians do not order needed studies, tests or consultations out of fear of increasing costs. This can lead to delays in diagnosis, wrongful death and birth injuries in many cases.

<strong>If you or someone you love has been injured by medical malpractice,&#xA0;call the professionals at Crandall &amp; Pera Law for a free consultation.</strong>

 
-----
EXTENDED BODY:
