AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: X-ray Photos Could Reduce &quot;Wrong Patient&quot; Errors
BASENAME: x-ray-photos-could-reduce-wrong-patient-errors
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/02/2013 02:15:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Attaching a patient&apos;s photo to their X-rays can get around the problem of patient mix-ups that, while relatively rare, can lead to dire consequences, according to a recent study.</strong>

While it is estimated that X-ray identification errors occur in 1 out of every 10,000 patients, the fallout could be catastrophic when they do happen.

&quot;The patient could be diagnosed with cancer and then get an operation he shouldn&apos;t have while the patient who should have gotten the cancer diagnosis isn&apos;t getting the surgery,&quot; said Dr. Srini Tridandapani, the author of the study. &quot;So you could be affecting two patients.&quot;

Part of the problem is that doctors don&apos;t expect to get the wrong X-ray and often don&apos;t recognize the mistake when it happens. In the study, 10 radiologists were given 200 pairs of X-rays to read, one pair per patient; they caught only three out of 24 mismatches when no photo was attached but 16 out of 25 errors when photos were included.

The process of implementing photos remains to be seen, though; skeptics believe they may make it take longer to read X-rays or patients might not want photos of themselves included in their medical files. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Say &apos;Cheese&apos;: Photos may avert X-ray mix-ups, study finds" href="http://vitals.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/04/15/17724368-say-cheese-photos-may-avert-x-ray-mix-ups-study-finds?lite" target="_blank">Say &apos;Cheese&apos;: Photos may avert X-ray mix-ups, study finds</a></strong>

This interesting study suggests a way to avoid patient mix-ups or the wrong patient receiving negligence care due to a radiology study being interpreted for them when it was meant for another patient. bAdvances as simple as taking a photograph of the patient has helped stop medical negligence in this regard.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Gene Patents Delay Research, Affect Every Patient
BASENAME: gene-patents-delay-research-affect-every-patient
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/30/2013 11:12:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>A potential decision made by the US Supreme Court on a current case regarding patenting human genes could affect the health and lives of every American.</strong>

Myriad Genetics currently controls the patents on variations of two human genes - BRCA1 and BRCA2 - whose mutations provide a high risk of breast and ovarian cancer. With their exclusive rights, all BRCA tests are conducted by Myriad, meaning the company can set its own price free of competition and provides no opportunity for a second opinion. Genetic testing for breast cancer can cost up to $3,500.

Any data gleaned from the test results, such as geographic and demographic patterns, or new genetic variants are also kept by Myriad and not shared publicly. This could prove to be a deterrent to doctors being able to order the sequence of each person&apos;s genome to look for disease-related gene variations, which scientists say will be coming soon.

A Supreme Court decision will not just decide the fate of breast and ovarian cancer research, but healthcare as a whole. Who will conduct your medical tests, how those tests are interpreted, how and how fast drugs can be developed, and what your doctor can tell you about your health are just some of the issues attached to the decision.

&quot;The care available to patients should not be restricted because the naturally occurring building blocks of human biology have been inappropriately patented,&quot; said Dr. Jeremy A. Lazarus, president of the American Medical Association. &quot;Opportunities for scientific research and medical care based on human genes must remain available to all and exclusive to none.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Supreme Court gene patent decision could affect every patient" href="http://vitals.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/04/15/17734323-supreme-court-gene-patent-decision-could-affect-every-patient?lite" target="_blank">Supreme Court gene patent decision could affect every patient</a></strong>

The intersection of advanced medical research and business patents have negative effects on curative research of any kind. Should a cure for cancer or other diagnoses really be held up by patent arguments?

The Colorado Medical Board has filed 14 counts of unprofessional conduct against a Denver surgeon for various forms of medical malpractice, according to CBS News.

Dr. Warren Kortz is accused of leaving sponges and surgical equipment in patients as well as improperly using robotic surgery for kidney transplants.

Not only has Kortz misrepresented the success rate of the machine as the &quot;safest, best option,&quot; but he is also accused of not offering standard non-robotic surgical options for his patients.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Surgical Complications Increase Profits, Decrease Reform
BASENAME: surgical-complications-increase-profits-decrease-reform
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/29/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Hospitals may have little incentive to improve upon preventable surgical complications and mistakes because of the revenue they receive for longer stays and extra care from insurers, according to a new study published in <em>The Journal of the American Medical Association</em>.&#xA0;</strong>

Surgical complications that could be prevented, like blood clots, pneumonia or infected incisions, will remain high until the insurance payment system is changed to stop rewarding poor care, according to the study&apos;s researchers.

The study&apos;s analysis of over 34,000 surgical patients showed an average $30,500 increase in revenue for patients who required an extended stay as compared to patients without complications ($49,4000 versus $18,900). Private insurers paid far more for complications than did Medicare or Medicaid, or patients who paid out of pocket.

While the researchers are not suggesting hospitals deliberately cause complications to make money, they do point out the fact that the current payment system makes it difficult for hospitals to perform better when improvements can wind up costing them money.

To help reduce complications, insurers should not only quit paying for substandard care, but also should reward excellent care with bonuses. Hospitals should also be required to disclose their complication rates, because patients will shun those with high rates and force them to improve or shut down. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Hospitals Profit From Surgical Errors, Study Finds" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/17/health/hospitals-profit-from-surgical-errors-study-finds.html?ref=health&amp;_r=1&amp;" target="_blank">Hospitals Profit From Surgical Errors, Study Finds</a></strong>

This study confirms apparent medical negligence by allowing hospitals to profit from various cases of negligence. Tort reform has not led to a decrease in negligence, but rather an increase in avoiding responsibility for the malpractice, medication errors, surgical error, cerebral palsy and wrongful death such medical negligence causes.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Forty Superbug Cases in Ky. Hospital
BASENAME: forty-superbug-cases-in-ky-hospital
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/24/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Antibiotic-resistant superbugs dubbed &quot;nightmare bacteria&quot; by federal health officials have been found present in about 40 patients since July at a transitional-care hospital in Louisville, Kentucky.&#xA0;</strong>

Carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae, or CRE for short, are a family of superbugs that strike hospitalized patients and kill as many as half who get bloodstream infections.&#xA0;Hospitals can wind up with CRE cases if they are present in the patient upon admission, bacteria that have been sensitive to antibiotics become resistant, or if CRE is transmitted from patient to patient.

The investigation by the Kentucky Department for Public Health into the presence of superbugs at Kindred Hospital Louisville, a facility where patients often stay for weeks, has not attributed any deaths to CRE in Kindred patients so far. The presence of CRE in bodily fluids could mean the patient is &quot;colonized&quot; by the bacteria without developing an infection. Read the full details here:

<strong>Kindred had 40 CRE cases</strong>

Often times infections occur in nursing home residents through nobody&apos;s fault. However, if your loved one contracts a deadly bacteria while convalescing at a nursing home, you should investigate whether the facility&apos;s infection rate is unacceptably high due to poor sanitary conditions.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Ohio Program Aims to Curb Hospital Readmissions
BASENAME: ohio-program-aims-to-curb-hospital-readmissions
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/25/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>With hospital re-admissions costing the health care system more than $15 billion a year, a health coaching experiment in southern Ohio is aiming to lower the rate of returns by visiting patients at home.</strong>

The Care Transitions program, managed by the Council on Aging of Southwest Ohio, visits patients in their daily environment for the first few weeks after they are discharged from the hospital, helping to organize medicines, prepare healthy meals and find transportation to a doctor&apos;s appointment. By being able to complete these tasks, patients will theoretically be less likely to need another trip to the hospital.

Since the program began in mid-2012, only 8.6% of about 900 Medicare patients in the program have been readmitted to five area hospitals within 30 days. Meanwhile, Medicare patients not involved in the program were readmitted at a rate of 21.3% to the same hospitals.

Medicare estimates up to $12 billion could be prevented with better follow-up care for patients.

&quot;There&apos;s only so much the hospital can do,&quot; said Kim Clark, the program&apos;s manager at the Council on Aging. &quot;The goal is to coach them so they understand, &apos;What do I need to do when I&apos;m by myself?&apos;&quot; Read the full story here:

<strong>IN-DEPTH: Helping patients at home keeps them out of hospital</strong>

An uninformed patient is one of the most prevalent causes of medical malpractice nationwide. Through increased education and investing time and thoughtful care into each and every patient, hopefully hospitals will be able to decrease the rate at which medical mistakes are currently made.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Occasional Drink Okay During Pregnancy
BASENAME: occasional-drink-okay-during-pregnancy
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/26/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>While health officials advise abstinence, an occasional, small amount of alcohol during pregnancy may have zero effect on a child&apos;s development, according to a recent study published in BJOG, an international obstetrics and gynecology journal.&#xA0;</strong>

One in five pregnant women who were analyzed were &quot;light&quot; drinkers who had roughly one or two small glasses of wine a week. The children of these mothers did not show any delays in their emotional, behavioral or cognitive development when tested at age 5, as compared to children of women who abstained during pregnancy.

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 7.6 percent of pregnant women have at least an occasional drink, with this number rising to 10 percent among college-educated women and 14 percent among pregnant women between 35 and 44. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Really? An Occasional Drink Is O.K. During Pregnancy" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/04/22/really-an-occasional-drink-is-o-k-during-pregnancy/" target="_blank">Really? An Occasional Drink Is O.K. During Pregnancy</a></strong>

While moderate or heavy drinking during pregnancy is hazardous, an occasional alcoholic beverage does not lead to increases in cerebral palsy, birth defects or developmental delays.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: One Hospital&apos;s Attempt to Stop Medical Errors
BASENAME: one-hospitals-attempt-to-stop-medical-errors
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/23/2013 10:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Medical mistakes that affect hundreds of thousands of patients in the U.S. every year are typically kept quiet by hospitals, but Brigham and Women&apos;s Hospital in Boston is instead airing its mistakes in a monthly newsletter for its 16,000 employees.&#xA0;</strong>

Many hospitals rarely provide details of medical errors in fear of sparking lawsuits and scaring off patients, but this reluctance to candidly discuss with the entire staff how medical mistakes harmed patients also hampers wide discussion of how mistakes happen and can be prevented.

Brigham leaders are using the online newsletter to encourage staff to talk openly about their mistakes and propose solutions, helping to make sure those errors are not repeated.

Most issues tell a story of medical care gone awry through interviews with caregivers and often with patients, and describe the hospital&apos;s response.&#xA0;Patients are not named to protect their privacy and caregivers are posted anonymously so as not to discourage them from reporting problems.

&quot;Other institutions are putting data out there but we are pushing the envelope with our story-telling,&quot; said Dr. Allen Kachalia, associate chief quality officer. &quot;Many patients have just been surprised that we&apos;ve been asking them their side of the story.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Brigham and Women&apos;s airing medical mistakes&#xA0;&#xA0;" href="http://bostonglobe.com/lifestyle/health-wellness/2013/04/09/brigham-and-women-publishes-stories-medical-errors-focus-staff-attention-solutions/heFVdgGnLc2O9QqL1eiMnN/story.html" target="_blank">Brigham and Women&apos;s airing medical mistakes</a></strong>

Acknowledging medical mistakes and medical malpractice is the first step toward creating new policies or fixing current systems in order to improve patient care. By airing and discussing medical mistakes, hospitals could prevent them from happening again.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: 5 Questions You Should Be Asking Your Doctor
BASENAME: 5-questions-you-should-be-asking-your-doctor
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/22/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>In order to make the most of your annual physical exam, you should be spending more time having a conversation with your doctor in order to build a relationship rather than just having your body examined.</strong>

Dr. Richard Besser, M.D., who spent 18 years at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, offers the top five questions to ask your doctor at your next appointment:
<ol>
    <li><em>What is a BMI and what is mine? </em>Body mass index tells you how appropriate your weight is for your height and can tell you whether you are at increased risk for many disorders, including diabetes and heart disease.</li>
    <li><em>Which screening tests do I truly need?</em>&#xA0;Recommendations on screening have changed a lot. Talk about what is recommended for you and decide what you need.</li>
    <li><em>Do I need any shots?</em>&#xA0;There are 14 vaccinations that are recommended for some adults. If you don&apos;t ask the question, many doctors will forget to review what you&apos;ve had and what you need. Why put yourself at risk for an illness that can be prevented?</li>
    <li><em>Is there anything in my family history I should be worried about? </em>First thing to do is ask your doctor to help you compile a detailed family history. Then once you have that information, go over it and look for clues that might put your health at risk.</li>
    <li><em>If I change one lifestyle habit, what should it be?</em>&#xA0;The key to good health lies in healthy behaviors. Look to your doctor for advice on how to exercise more, eat better, stop smoking, get some sleep and control your stress levels.</li>
</ol>
Read the full details here:

<a title="Top 5 Questions for Your Doctor" href="http://abcnews.go.com/Health/top-questions-doctor/story?id=18861526#.UWcRiZPvsoo" target="_blank"><strong>Top 5 Questions for Your Doctor</strong></a>

One of the leading causes of medication errors, missed diagnoses, brain damage, medical malpractice and wrongful death are failure of the physician to listen to their patients. These questions can provide practical advice for every patient in order to receive the best care and avoid medical mistakes that can lead to catastrophic results.

<strong>Two Atlanta-based trucking companies have been shut down by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration for failing to cooperate with safety investigators in the past month.&#xA0;</strong>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Birth Injuries Increased By Tort Reform
BASENAME: birth-injuries-increased-by-tort-reform
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/18/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Tort reform measures to reduce &quot;defensive medicine&quot; that will, in turn, increase the risk of birth injuries nationwide persist even after a recent report by the non-partisan Commonwealth Fund ranks the costly U.S. health system dead last on patient safety.</strong>

Instead of instituting national policies that promote quality improvement, as the Commonwealth Fund suggests, the U.S. healthcare system continues to pass initiatives to allow doctors to do fewer tests in order to save costs, regardless of how many more lives are lost due to undiagnosed conditions.

Less testing is of particular concern when it comes to babies suffering from birth injuries, especially the form of brain damage caused by extreme jaundice known as kenicterus. An entirely preventable birth injury, kernicterus is caused by too high levels of bilirubin (yellow pigment &#xA0;created during the recycling of old blood cells) in the body.

Many health care providers fail to test bilirubin levels in the 60 percent of babies estimated to display symptoms of jaundice by the Centers for Disease Control. Many times the immediate measures needed to bring down the levels before brain damage occurs are not implemented, and measures that lead to less testing will only increase the number of babies who will suffer from this devastating birth injury nationwide. Read the full details here:

<strong>Tort Reform Measures Increase Risk of Birth Injuries Such as Kernicterus</strong>

Tort reform serves to protect physicians and hospitals who commit medical malpractice malpractice and has not been shown to benefit patients or decrease medical malpractice premiums.

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: ER Cost-Cutting Hurting Patient Care
BASENAME: er-cost-cutting-hurting-patient-care
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/17/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Emergency rooms have largely been blamed for excessive health care costs, but popular cost-cutting measures may be doing more harm than good for patient care, according to a new study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association.</strong>

Reducing ER visits for non-urgent care, which can cost up to five times more than care provided in a doctor&apos;s office, is a measure adopted by many hospitals. Several states proposed a policy to pay the bills for true emergencies, like a heart attack or ruptured aneurysm, but reduce or deny reimbursements for less serious cases like heartburn or constipation.

The problem with this method, according to the study, is the assumption that patients can predict the urgency of their diagnosis themselves based on initial symptoms. By reviewing nationwide records of nearly 35,000 ER visits, researchers found that nearly 90 percent of urgent cases presented the same primary symptoms, including abdominal discomfort, chest pain and fever, as the 6 percent of cases that were discharged and could have been treated in a doctor&apos;s office.

The state of Washington has instituted a different policy. By establishing programs designed to educate patients on how to access care and other statewide guidelines, as well as creating regularly updated reports on how emergency department resources are utilized, the state&apos;s policy has resulted in projected savings of over $31 million by the end of the fiscal year.

&quot;A policy that requires more coordination and more tailoring means more work than one that slashes benefits across the board,&quot; said Dr. Renee Y. Hsia, senior author of the study. &quot;But it is the right thing to do for patients.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="The Costs of Emergency Room Cost-Cutting" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/03/28/the-costs-of-emergency-room-cost-cutting/?ref=health" target="_blank">The Costs of Emergency Room Cost-Cutting</a></strong>

Services and staffing at emergency rooms throughout the country have been steadily cut over the last decade. This has led to increased wait times, poor medical care and numerous patients who are ignored or sent home despite having illnesses deserving of admission to the hospital.

<strong>If you or a family member believe you have a medical malpractice case,&#xA0;contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law&#xA0;today for a free case evaluation.&#xA0;<strong>Crandall &amp; Pera Law is&#xA0;</strong><strong>available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.</strong></strong>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: What Really Causes Heart Disease in Red Meat
BASENAME: what-really-causes-heart-disease-in-red-meat
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/11/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
A new study conducted by the Cleveland Clinic might prove a surprising new explanation of why red meat may contribute to heart disease.

Researchers believe a little-studied chemical that is burped out by bacteria in the stomach is the real culprit in the increased amount of heart disease seen in red-meat eaters, as opposed to long-held suspected factors, such as saturated fat and cholesterol, which may only be minor contributors.

The bacteria is quickly converted by the liver into TMAO, another little-studied chemical, that gets into the blood and whose levels turned out to predict heart attack risk in humans.

The study could lead to new treatments for heart disease and a new way to assess heart disease risk by looking for TMAO in the blood. While researchers do not believe it is best to avoid red meat entirely due to its essential protein and B vitamins, they do stress it would be much better in moderation. Read the full story here:

<a title="Study points to a new culprit in heart disease" href="http://www.nbcnews.com/id/51459488/ns/health-heart_health/#.UWWqB5Pvsop" target="_blank"><strong>Study points to a new culprit in heart disease</strong></a>

&#xA0;

Medical research furthering the knowledge on devastating cardiac disease can help medical professionals advise their patients on what they should avoid and diagnose heart disease symptoms faster.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Common Ailments Frequently Misdiagnosed
BASENAME: common-ailments-frequently-misdiagnosed
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/16/2013 08:34:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Common ailments like pneumonia and heart failure are the conditions most frequently misdiagnosed by primary care doctors and can lead to severe harm if not treated appropriately, according to a recent study.&#xA0;</strong>

Misdiagnoses occur most often during examinations when doctors have trouble getting a complete medical history from the patient and the failure of doctors to follow up and track tests and referrals. In order to reduce these medical errors, more doctors and hospitals need to engage the patient in their own health care and improve their access to physicians, according to Hardeep Singh, the study&apos;s lead author.

&quot;If we do it together with patients, providers and health care systems, we will have a much deeper impact of understanding and improving this problem,&quot; says Singh.

The most common misdiagnoses among 190 errors in primary care visits between October 2006 and September 2007 at a large urban Veterans Affair facility were pneumonia (6.7%), heart failure (5.7%), kidney failure (5.3%), cancer (5.3%) and urinary tract infections (4.8%). Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Pneumonia, heart failure among doctors&apos; most-missed diagnoses" href="http://ebn.benefitnews.com/news/pneumonia-heart-failure-doctors-most-missed-diagnoses-bloomberg-2731110-1.html" target="_blank">Pneumonia, heart failure among doctors&apos; most-missed diagnoses</a></strong>

Missed diagnoses of pneumonia and heart failure is a common problem in U.S. hospitals and leads to wrongful death, increased hospital bills and often severe permanent damages.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Medication Errors Decreased By Computerized Orders
BASENAME: medication-errors-decreased-by-computerized-orders
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/15/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Medication errors in hospitals that are both common and potentially fatal can be easily and substantially reduced according to a study published in the <em>Journal of the American Medical Informatics Association</em>.</strong>

By prescribing medications through computerized provider order entry (CPOE) systems medical professionals could decrease the likelihood of error on that order by 48 percent, leading to an estimated 17.4 million medication errors averted in the U.S. each year.

CPOE systems allow medication orders to be communicated over a computer network and, in turn, decreasing the risk of human errors including delays in order completion, handwriting or transcription errors, and the ordering of duplicate or incorrect doses or tests.

Despite the systems&apos; effectiveness at preventing medication errors, adoption and use in U.S. hospitals remains modest. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Reduction in medication errors in hospitals due to..." href="http://www.doctorslounge.com/index.php/news/pb/36186" target="_blank">Reduction in medication errors in hospitals due to...</a></strong>

Medication errors cost thousands of lives each year. A new computer system, which is designed to stop medication errors at the pharmacy level, is both an improvement and long overdue.

<strong>Depakote, a drug used to treat seizures, bipolar disorder and migraine headaches, could cause lasting negative effects when used while pregnant, recent studies suggest.&#xA0;</strong>

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has issued warnings about the use of Depakote while pregnant, which has reported risks of decreased IQ and a risk of autism for the child exposed to the drug while in the womb. Repetitive behaviors, communication problems and social behavior issues may also be effects that last well into childhood.

While these findings are reportedly dose dependent, a woman may have no choice but to run the risk of Depakote birth defects if she does not tolerate other anti-convulsant medications. Read the full details here:

States surrounding Ohio that have a speed limit of 70 mph are West Virginia, Michigan, Kentucky and Indiana.

&quot;We would need to research that issue in great detail to make any sort of conclusion on if the increase in speed is more dangerous,&quot; said Lt. Anne Ralston, spokeswoman for the Ohio State Highway Patrol. &quot;Regardless our goal is to enforce the laws with professionalism and fairness, which we will continue to do regardless of what the speed limit is.&quot; Read the full details here:

An online survey sent to the HealthLeaders Media Council also showed that more than 27 percent of these health care professionals said they had made an error resulting from fatigue, while nearly 65 percent said they had come close.

Much of the blame for exhausting work schedules could be placed on manual scheduling processes that lack visibility into the larger staff scheduling picture and offer alerts to compliance with staffing policies or regulatory requirements.

Nearly 40 percent of survey respondents also cited inadequate staffing levels as a concern, as the local vacancy rate for registered nurse positions is more than double the rate of unfilled vacancies seen in 2008. Read the full details here:

BODY:
<strong>A bill that will exempt many commercial vehicles from federal safety rules passed a Kentucky Senate Committee recently with one police-mandated change.</strong>

After Louisville Metro Police officials raised concerns that House Bill 125 would risk leaving unsafe trucks on the roads, the bill was amended to allow police to conduct random safety inspections. A provision that assumes a commercial truck driver to be drunk with a blood alcohol content of 0.04 - half the blood alcohol of most drivers - will be kept in place.

While the bill as originally presented would have allowed police to cite trucks for safety violations, it would not have allowed them to stop the trucks to look for problems.

Drivers of commercial trucks weighing between 10,001 and 26,000 pounds that are not crossing state lines will no longer have to keep daily driving logs or a medical card proving they are healthy enough to drive a truck due to the new bill. These vehicles can range from a pickup with a large trailer to a 24-foot box truck. Read the full details here:

<strong>Compromise truck bill passes Kentucky Senate panel</strong>

Exempting commercial trucks from portions of Federal Regulations is a dangerous idea. Commercial truck accident deaths rose by 8.7% from 2009 to 2011, according to the U.S. Department of Transportation, and it has been proven that regulations may be ignored when drivers are looking to shorten their time on the road.&#xA0;Thankfully the police in Kentucky questioned the logic of this attempted legislation, which likely would have led to more commercial trucking accidents in that state.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Health of US Newborns Ranked Last in Industrialized World
BASENAME: health-of-us-newborns-ranked-last-in-industrialized-world
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 06/03/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>The U.S. has the highest first-day death rate in the industrialized world, worse than 68 other countries, and the highest teenage birth rate of any industrialized country, according to a report released by Save the Children.&#xA0;</strong>

An estimated 11,300 American newborns die every year on the same day they were born - amounting to 50 percent more first-day deaths than all other industrialized countries <em>combined</em> - even though most of them could be saved with fairly cheap interventions.

Four products costing between 13 cents and $6 each - simple bag-and-mask devices to help babies breathe, the antiseptic chlorhexidine to prevent umbilical cord infections, antibiotics to treat infections, and steroid injections to delay preterm labor - could save one million newborns a year, according to the report.

&quot;Teenage mothers in the U.S. tend to be poorer, less educated, and receive less prenatal care than older mothers,&quot; the report says. &quot;Because of these challenges, babies born to teen mothers are more likely to be low-birthweight and be born prematurely and die in their first month. They are also more likely to suffer chronic medical conditions, do poorly in school, and give birth during their teen years.&quot;

High-quality care before, during and after pregnancy and access to the appropriate level of care at the time of delivery can also result in healthier moms giving birth to healthier babies. Home visits by nurses or community health workers are common in Europe, but very unusual in the United States. Read the full story here:

<strong><a title="More US babies die on their firsy day than in 68 other countries, report shows" href="http://vitals.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/04/30/17988462-more-us-babies-die-on-their-first-day-than-in-68-other-countries-report-shows?lite" target="_blank">More US babies die on their first day than in 68 other countries, report shows</a></strong>

Everyone knows teen pregnancies often place great stress on the teen and the teen&#x2019;s family, but here is evidence that teen pregnancy also poses tremendous risk for the baby.

-----
BODY:
<strong>Pregnant woman are warned not to use the migraine drug valproate sodium as it could result in lower IQ scores in their child, according to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.</strong>

The results of a recent study showed that children exposed to valproate products in the womb had a lower IQ at the age of six than children who were exposed to other antiepileptics.

Drugs containing valproate are used to prevent migraine headaches, treat epileptic seizures and manic episodes associated with bipolar disorder. Drugs containing valproate already carry a boxed warning for birth defects.

&quot;Valproate medications should never be used in pregnant women for the prevention of migraine headaches because we have even more data now that shows the risks to the children outweigh any treatment benefits for this use,&quot; said Russell Katz, the FDA&apos;s Director of the Division of Neurology Products. Read the full story here:

<strong><a title="FDA warns on use of certain migraine drugs during pregnancy" href="http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-05-06/lifestyle/sns-rt-us-migrainedrug-fdabre9450ps-20130506_1_valproate-neurology-products-fda" target="_blank">FDA warns on use of certain migraine drugs during pregnancy</a></strong>

Though Depakote and other drugs containing valproate already come with warnings of possible birth defects, this study is further evidence that no woman should take any medicine containing valproate during pregnancy.

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: PBDE Exposure Linked to Lower IQ, Hyperactivity
BASENAME: pbde-exposure-linked-to-lower-iq-hyperactivity
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/30/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Some intelligence and behavioral problems in young children may actually be caused by controversial fire retardant chemicals used in products that are supposed to protect kids, according to a new study presented at the Pediatric Academic Societies annual meeting.&#xA0;&#xA0;</strong>

Polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs) have mostly not been used in items like baby strollers, carpets and electronics in the U.S. since 2004 because of known health risks. However, since PBDEs are not very biodegradable, they may still exist in older products that people may have or continue to exist in the tissue of people who were exposed to the chemicals.

Prenatal exposure to PBDEs was associated to lower cognitive abilities at 5 and increased hyperactivity from 2 through 5 years old in the sample of 309 pregnant women and their children.

Each 10-fold increase in maternal exposure to the chemicals was linked to a four-point decrease in IQ scores which, while it might not seem like much in an individual, could have a big impact on the social interactions and overall economic stability if an entire population experiences this decrease.

&quot;To reduce PDBEs in pregnant women, hand washing to reduce dust ingestion is important,&quot; said Dr. Aimin Chen, assistant professor in the Department of Environmental health at University of Cincinnati College of&#xA0;Medicine. &quot;Also reducing PBDEs in the indoor environment may help, such as replacing carpet padding or polyurethane foams that contain PBDEs.&quot; Read the full story here:

<a title="Exposure to fire retardants during pregnancy linked to hyperactivity, lower IQ in kids" href="http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-204_162-57583009/exposure-to-fire-retardants-during-pregnancy-linked-to-hyperactivity-lower-iq-in-kids/" target="_blank"><strong>Exposure to fire retardants during pregnancy linked to hyperactivity, lower IQ in kids</strong></a>

PBDEs have been known to pose risks since before 2004. Even though they are no longer sold for most products, pregnant women and mothers need to be careful when using products that were sold before 2004.

<strong>A popular anitbacterial chemical found in hundreds of everyday products is under review by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration over concern for its safety.</strong>

Studies of triclosan - found in houshold antibacterial products from toothpaste to toys - suggest that the chemical could increase the risk of infertility and early puberty and other hormone-related problems in humans.

The FDA&apos;s 40-year review over whether triclosan is safe was supposed to be released in 2012, but the release is now planned for later this year. Until this review is finalized, companies are permitted to use the chemical in their products.

Consumer advocates have already questioned the chemical&apos;s use in the past after the FDA said it has no evidence soaps made with triclosan &quot;provide any benefit over washing with regular soap and water.&quot; Read the full story here:

There does not seem to be clear evidence whether Triclosan is safe; however, there also does not seem to be any clear evidence that it poses any benefit. With no proven benefit, why take the risk?

TITLE: Robot Doctors Make Remote Visits to Patients

<strong>Technology is rapidly changing the medical industry as doctors are beginning to make remote visits to patients in ICUs and other facilities via robots run by PCs or iPads, according to a recent article in <em>USA Today</em>.</strong>

These technological overhauls are being used to address shortages of staff and improvements to the level of service for patients, especially for hospitals farther away from experts.

The latest robots, dubbed RP-VITA, can either roam about on their own or be navigated remotely by doctors, guided by sensors and software that maps locations to avoid collisions. Doctors appear on the robot&apos;s screen much like a video chat and use front-facing lenses to zero in on their patients.

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Routine PSA Testing No Longer Recommended
BASENAME: routine-psa-testing-no-longer-recommended
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/24/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>The American Urological Association has reversed its stance on PSA testing for prostate cancer, no longer recommending routine testing for men due to harmful side effects.&#xA0;</strong>

Men under 55 should not get routinely screened with a PSA (prostate-specific antigen) test, and men over 80 are not recommended to get screened at all if they have a life expectancy less than 10 to 15 years, according to the AUA. Men who are between the ages of 55 and 69 may benefit most from the test, and should discuss the risks and benefits of the test with their doctor to decide if it is right for them.

The AUA stated to be &quot;outraged&quot; at this same recommendation one year ago, but have reversed course based on data that shows the mortality benefits of preventing prostate cancer with a PSA test for men ages 55 to 69 amounted to one male life spared for every 1,000 men screened over a decade.

Existing studies suggest that a diagnosis may do more harm than good because the test may pick up a tumor that is growing too slowly to pose a serious health threat while biopsies, surgeries and radiation can lead to urinary incontinence, impotence or other fatal complications. Read the full story here:

<strong><a title="Urologists no longer recommend routine PSA testing for prostate cancer" href="http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-204_162-57582847/urologists-no-longer-recommend-routine-psa-testing-for-prostate-cancer/" target="_blank">Urologists no longer recommend routine PSA testing for prostate cancer</a></strong>

This is a difficult issue, but the American Urological Association seems to have taken the controversial position that ignorance is bliss for men with tumors that are so slow growing they do not pose imminent risk.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: The #1 Cause of Medical Malpractice Claims
BASENAME: the-1-cause-of-medical-malpractice-claims
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/22/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>The most common cause of paid claims for malpractice at 28.6 percent is making errors in diagnosis, not overdoses or even surgical mistakes, according to a recent study.</strong>

More than 100,000 payments for diagnostic error occurred from 1986 to 2010, with these errors accounting for 33.8 percent of the disabilities and almost 40 percent of the deaths that resulted in malpractice payments.

Errors related to treatment and surgery were second and third most common, and all other errors combined - obstetric, medication, monitoring, anesthesia and the rest - accounted for only 20 percent of malpractice payments.

&quot;At the policy level, there is no institute that views it as their problem,&quot; said Dr. David E. Newman-Toker, an associate professor of neurology at Johns Hopkins, who believes physicians, hospitals and insurers all need to contribute to fix this widespread and devastating problem.

&quot;There&apos;s a lot of room for improvement,&quot; he continued. &quot;You can&apos;t get the treatment right if you don&apos;t get the diagnosis right.&quot; Read the full story here:

<strong><a title="Why Doctors Are Sued" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/04/29/why-doctors-are-sued/?partner=rss&amp;emc=rss" target="_blank">Why Doctors Are Sued</a></strong>

Studies continue to confirm that more patients are harmed by doctors failing to properly diagnose their ailments than by any other mistake. This is why it is so important for doctors to follow the rules of differential diagnoses and take steps to rule out the most urgent life-threatening dangers, rather than making assumptions about what they believe to be the proper diagnosis.

<strong>If you or a family member believe you have a medical malpractice case, including errors or delay in diagnosis,&#xA0;contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law&#xA0;today for a free case evaluation.&#xA0;<strong>Crandall &amp; Pera Law is&#xA0;</strong><strong>available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.</strong></strong>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: &quot;Never Events&quot; Continue at Alarming Rates
BASENAME: never-events-continue-at-alarming-rates
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/23/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Serious medical errors known as &quot;never events&quot; should <em>never</em> occur with proper vigilance by medical staff and surgeons, but even the most egregious errors - including operating on the wrong side of a brain - still happen more often than you might think.</strong>

In 2010, the Journal of Neurosurgery identified 35 documented cases of wrong-side craniotomies from 1996 to 2009 in the United States, but this figure does not include the additional cases that were settled and never brought to the attention of state medical licensing boards, courts and news organizations.

&quot;Wrong-site surgery is such an egregious system failure,&quot; said Charles Kenney, the author of <em>Transforming Health Care</em>. &quot;It&apos;s so devastating, not only to the patient and the patient&apos;s family, but also to the caregiving team because they have made about the worst mistake that they can make.&quot;

Many organizations have adopted so-called &quot;mistake-proofing&quot; protocols and checklists to prevent such errors as wrong-site, and even wrong-person, surgeries. These systems generally include indelible marking of the operative site and verification with medical records, as well as a &quot;timeout&quot; to be held in which the surgeon explains the details of the operation and permits all members of the team to ask questions and raise any concerns or objections.

&quot;The typical reaction in these cases is to assign blame,&quot; said Kenney. &quot;When that leads down the path to an individual, that&apos;s wrong. These events are systems or process breakdowns.&quot; Read the full story here:

<a title="Lawsuit accuses surgeon of operating on wrong side of woman&apos;s brain" href="http://www.stltoday.com/business/local/lawsuit-accuses-surgeon-of-operating-on-wrong-side-of-woman/article_cd2100bc-e56b-5981-9748-7c79af0bc430.html" target="_blank"><strong>Lawsuit accuses surgeon of operating on wrong side of woman&apos;s brain</strong></a>

It is frightening that surgeries continue to be performed on the wrong side of patients&#x2019; bodies.&#xA0; When the proper protocols are not put in place, or they aren&#x2019;t followed, patient safety is thrown out the window and tragedies result.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Skin Cancers Increase Risk of Other Cancers
BASENAME: skin-cancers-increase-risk-of-other-cancers
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/17/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
&#xA0;

<strong>People who have had common skin cancers, even those not typically treated with radiation or chemotherapy, may be at an increased risk of getting cancer again in their life, according to a new study.</strong>

The included more than 150,000 people who were followed for more than 20 years and found that women with nonmelanoma skin cancers were 26 percent more likely to later develop another form of cancer, including lung and breast cancer, compared with women who didn&apos;t have these skin cancers. In men, the risk increased by 15 percent.

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

A 2006 study showed there were 2.1 million cases of nonmelanoma skin cancer in the U.S.

The reason for the general increased risk of other cancers is unclear, although some researchers suspect that the cellular machinery involved in DNA repair may not work as well in some people. Read the full article here:

<a title="Skin cancer linked to other cancer risks, study finds" href="http://vitals.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/04/23/17883038-skin-cancer-linked-to-other-cancer-risks-study-finds?lite" target="_blank"><strong>Skin cancer linked to other cancer risks, study finds</strong></a>

The risk of developing other cancers later in life increases if one is previously diagnosed with skin cancer. This is a frightening conclusion with the incidence of skin cancer increasing so quickly.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Denial Over Need for Long-Term Medical Care
BASENAME: denial-over-need-for-long-term-medical-care
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/20/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Americans underestimate their chances of needing long-term care, with two-thirds of people over 40 having done little to no planning, according to a new poll by the AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research.&#xA0;</strong>

Government figures show nearly 7 in 10 Americans will need long-term care - three years, on average - at some point after they reach 65, whether it&apos;s from a relative, a home heath aide, assisted living or a nursing home.

Although most people expect family to step up if they need long-term care, 6 in 10 of those polled haven&apos;t even talked with loved ones about the possibility and how they&apos;d like it to work.

&quot;The expectation that your family is going to be there when you need them often doesn&apos;t mean they understand the full extent of what the job of caregiving will be,&quot; said Susan Reinhard, a nurse who directs AARP&apos;s Public Policy Institute.

Nearly 60 percent of those surveyed also underestimated the cost of a nursing home, which averages more than $6,700 a month. Medicare does not pay for the most common types of long-term care, but 37 percent of those surveyed mistakenly think it will pay for a nursing home and even more expect it to cover a home health aide when that is only approved under certain conditions. Read the full story here:

<strong><a title="Americans in denial about long-term care" href="http://vitals.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/04/24/17895542-americans-in-denial-about-long-term-care?lite" target="_blank">Americans in denial about long-term care</a></strong>

As with medical malpractice, nobody ever expects that they will be the one who ends up needing long-term care. As a result, few people are appropriately planning for this possibility.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Drug Overdoses Lead Accidental Deaths in Ohio
BASENAME: drug-overdoses-lead-accidental-deaths-in-ohio
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/21/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
&#xA0;

<strong>Drug overdoses continue to increase at record-high rates throughout the state of Ohio, causing about one Ohioan to die every five hours in 2011, according to figures released by the state Department of Health.&#xA0;</strong>

Prescription painkillers and a worsening heroin problem have caused accidental overdoses to jump 14 percent to 1,765 from 2010 statewide. Such overdoses remain the leading cause of accidental deaths in the state, ahead of car crashes and falls, a trend that began in 2007.

These dire statistics come at a time when Ohio has launched numerous efforts to crack down on illegal prescription painkiller use and distribution. Midway through 2011, Ohio enacted a law meant to reduce the number &#xA0;of pills-on-demand clinics, while changes in Medicaid rules are making it easier for doctors to prescribe medication that helps addicts beat the craving for drugs like heroin and painkillers.

&quot;It&apos;s like when we put more cars on the road, we&apos;re going to see more car crashes,&quot; said Christy Beeghly, the Health Department&apos;s Violence and Injury Prevention Program administrator. &quot;So we put more pills out there, we have more addiction and ultimately more overdoses.&quot; Read the full details here:

Ohio sees record-high overdose deaths in 2011

&#xA0;

An average of five Ohioans die every day from drug overdoses, more than any other type of accidental death. This demonstrates the significant danger that exists when doctors don&#x2019;t hesitate to prescribe narcotics.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Pregnancy Stresses Congenital Heart Problems
BASENAME: pregnancy-stresses-congenital-heart-problems
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/15/2013 08:37:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Congenital heart problems cause abnormal heartbeats that, even in their most manageable forms, can turn into a crisis once a woman becomes pregnant.</strong>

It is especially important for women born with congenital heart problems to discuss them with a cardiologist before becoming pregnant, even if they have had no problems since learning of a murmur early in life, because of the survival risks involved for both mother and baby.

&quot;A lot of patients believe since they are feeling well that they are cured of their heart disease,&quot; said Dr. Curt Daniels, director of the adolescent and adult congenital heart disease program at Ohio State. &quot;If you had heart surgery as a child, the majority are not cured.&quot;

The chances of being born with a heart defect are 0.8 in 1,000, making it the most common birth defect. The most common heart defects are ventricular septal defects (holes in the heart) and bicuspid aortic valves, in which there are two sections rather than the normal three.

Adults with congenital heart problems should be in the regular care of specialists, even if they had undergone surgery as a child, Daniels said. Read the full story here:

<a title="Abnormal heartbeat puts pregnancy at risk " href="http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2013/02/24/health/abnormal-heartbeat-puts-pregnancy-at-risk.html" target="_blank"><strong>Abnormal heartbeat puts pregnancy at risk</strong> </a>

The stress of pregnancy can turn an otherwise stable heart defect into a crisis. Any woman with a known heart defect should get a full cardiac work-up before getting pregnant.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Negative Effects of Limiting Doctors&apos; Work Hours
BASENAME: negative-effects-of-limiting-doctors-work-hours
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/16/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

<strong>Progressively limiting the number of hours that medical residents can work, in response to public concerns about errors arising from fatigue, may be causing more problems than the system was designed to address.</strong>

The latest mandate (2011) by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education allows medical interns to work no longer than 16 hours in a day. Residency programs that violate the restriction risk losing their accreditation.

But this limit on hours does not lower the workload of medical professionals at the same time; instead, interns are faced with covering the same amount of work as before in fewer hours. In response, some hospitals have adopted a &quot;night float&quot; system that means a resident just a year out of internship has to carry the work of as many as 12 interns at night, looking after more than 100 patients.

Contrary to expectations, studies have shown that interns have not been getting significantly more sleep and are also not happier nor are they studying more. Interns are spending less time in educational activities because the additional time required for such conferences and lectures would push them over the 16-hour limit.

&quot;You can&apos;t keep asking these young doctors to do more and more work in less time without affecting patient care,&quot; said Dr. Lara Gotein, a pulmonary and critical care physician at Christus St. Vincent Regional Medical Center in Santa Fe, N.M. &quot;Until we address the problem of overwork, we&apos;re just playing a shell game.&quot; Read the full article here:

<a title="The Impossible Workload for Doctors in Training" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/04/18/doing-the-math-on-resident-work-hours/" target="_blank"><strong>The Impossible Workload for Doctors in Training</strong></a>

Surprisingly, not permitting residents to work more than 16 hours in any given day is not improving patient safety and is not improving residents&#x2019; quality of life.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Doctors&apos; Apologies Inadmissible in Malpractice Suits
BASENAME: doctors-apologies-inadmissible-in-malpractice-suits
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/09/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>An apology or other sympathetic statement made by a healthcare official to a patient cannot be used as evidence of liability in medical malpractice cases, the Supreme Court of Ohio recently clarified.&#xA0;</strong>

This information cannot be used in cases filed after the &quot;medical apology statute&quot; legislation took effect in 2004, even if the treatment occurred before then or the doctor admits full responsibility.

&quot;Physicians are and should be sympathetic and empathetic,&quot; argued Dr. William Wulf, medical director of Central Ohio Primary Care. &quot;Fear of future legal action shouldn&apos;t impede that.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Doctors&apos; apologies can&apos;t be used against them in malpractice suits, justices rule" href="http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2013/04/24/doctors-apologies-cant-be-used-against-them.html" target="_blank">Doctors&apos; apologies can&apos;t be used against them in malpractice suits, justices rule</a></strong>

The rules of evidence in both state and federal courts have always allowed admissions of fault to be introduced as evidence at trial. Now there is one exception and it is <em>only</em> for doctors in Ohio. The Ohio Supreme Court has extended a statute that did not allow apologies - which may or may not be admissions of fault - to be used as evidence to now also excluding admissions of fault by doctors.

TITLE: &quot;False Positive&quot; Mammograms Have Psychological Toll
BASENAME: false-positive-mammograms-have-psychological-toll
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/14/2013 10:33:00 AM
-----
BODY:
&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

<strong>&quot;False positive&quot; results on mammogram screenings can cause women to adapt a psychological well-being more closely matched to that of breast cancer patients than healthy women, according to a new Danish study.&#xA0;</strong>

Of the more than 1,300 women studied, those who received false alarms reported symptoms of anxiety and depression that still lingered three years later, long after a cancer diagnosis had been ruled out.

&quot;It is comparable to a life crisis, like getting divorced or the death of a close family member,&quot; Dr. John Brodersen, the study&apos;s author, said of mammogram false positives. &quot;People don&apos;t trust their body anymore; they interpret their body systems differently....These women are turned from healthy people to people [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][at] risk, to people who are close to being sick.&quot;

While an x-ray of the breast is often to the first step in diagnosing breast cancer, it can also lead to unnecessary tests and procedures, such as biopsies and lumpectomies, not to mention stress. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends women between the ages of 50 and 74 to get a mammogram every two years. Read the full details here:

<a title="Psych Effects Linger After False Positive Mammograms" href="http://abcnews.go.com/Health/psych-effects-linger-false-positive-mammograms/story?id=18755858#.UZJcU7Xvsor" target="_blank"><strong>Psych Effects Linger After False Positive Mammograms</strong></a>

For every one women saved by cancer screening, 200 women are incorrectly told they have an abnormal finding and ten unnecessary surgeries are performed. The psychological toll is steep.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Most Harmful Medical Error: Bad Diagnoses
BASENAME: most-harmful-medical-error-bad-diagnoses
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/10/2013 11:31:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>While surgical mistakes and drug overdoses are common forms of medical malpractice that grab headlines, it is actually diagnosis errors that account for the most severe patient harm and the largest share of malpractice payouts.&#xA0;</strong>

Errors are made whenever a diagnosis is missed, wrong, or delayed, as detected by some subsequent definitive test or finding. Severe harm can result from delay or failure to treat a condition, or from treatment for a condition a patient did not actually have.

Diagnostic error-related malpractice payments amounted to $38.8 billion&#xA0;between 1986 and 2010, according to researchers, with an estimated 80,000 to 160,000 patients suffering misdiagnosis-related, potentially preventable, significant permanent injury or death every year in the U.S.

&quot;Diagnostic errors have been underappreciated and under-recognized because they&apos;re difficult to measure and keep track of owning to the frequent gap between the time the error occurs and when it&apos;s detected,&quot; said David E. Newman-Toker, associate professor of neurology at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine. &quot;These are frequent problems that have played second fiddle to medical and surgical errors, which are evident more immediately.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="There&apos;s no easy cure for bad diagnoses" href="http://www.futurity.org/health-medicine/theres-no-easy-cure-for-bad-diagnoses/" target="_blank">There&apos;s no easy cure for bad diagnoses</a></strong>

80,000 to 160,000 people suffer permanent injury or death because they are improperly diagnosed, but these numbers do not even account for those who are misdiagnosed and do not suffer severe injury. Altogether, it could be as many as 15% of all patients affected by bad diagnoses. Not surprisingly, misdiagnoses accounts for most malpractice payouts.

<strong>If you or a family member believe you have a medical malpractice case, including diagnosis errors,&#xA0;contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law&#xA0;today for a free case evaluation.&#xA0;<strong>Crandall &amp; Pera Law is&#xA0;</strong><strong>available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.</strong></strong>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Study Furthers Link Between Antidepressants and Autism
BASENAME: study-furthers-link-between-antidepressants-and-autism
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/07/2013 03:02:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<strong>A recent study in Sweden has created further evidence that antidepressant use during pregnancy increases the risk of autism spectrum disorders in children.&#xA0;</strong>

The study controlled for other variables like family income, parent educational level, and maternal and paternal age that have not been previously associated with autism. This is the second study in two years to associate antidepressant use during pregnancy with an increased incidence of autism in exposed children.

While the study did not exclude the possibility that severe depression, rather than antidepressants, created the association, the authors did urge patients to seek other treatments besides selective&#xA0;serotonin&#xA0;reuptake&#xA0;inhibitors (S.S.R.I.&apos;s) and&#xA0;tricyclicantidepressants.

&quot;Informed decisions would also need to consider weighting the wider risks of untreated depression with the other adverse outcomes related to antidepressant use,&quot; the study states. &quot;With the current evidence, if the potential risk of autism were a consideration in the decision-making process, it may be reasonable to think about, wherever&#xA0;appropriate,&#xA0;nondrugapproaches&#xA0;such as psychological treatments.&quot; Read the full <a title="details here:Study Links Autism With Antidepressant Use During Pregnancy" href="http://parenting.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/04/22/study-links-autism-with-antidepressant-use-during-pregnancy/" target="_blank">details here:</a>

<strong><a title="details here:Study Links Autism With Antidepressant Use During Pregnancy" href="http://parenting.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/04/22/study-links-autism-with-antidepressant-use-during-pregnancy/" target="_blank">Study Links Autism With Antidepressant Use During Pregnancy</a></strong>

This eye-opening research could help explain the wide use of anti-depressants caused birth defects, including autism, when used in pregnant women.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Dangers of Caffeine in Children, Teens
BASENAME: dangers-of-caffeine-in-children-teens
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/08/2013 09:11:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Caffeine use and withdrawal can cause headaches, heart arrhythmias and increased blood pressure in children and teenagers, according to a study published in the journal <em>Pediatrics in Review</em>.</strong>

Younger people have a lower tolerance for caffeine and could experience ill effects sooner than adults typically would, even with lower amounts of the substance. Doses of caffeine as small as 80 to 100 milligrams can cause withdrawal symptoms when it is cut off.

&quot;A couple sodas a day is even too much for the average kid,&quot; said Dr. Ebo Kwabena Blankson, the pediatrician author of the story.

Products like energy drinks are especially dangerous for children as they are estimated to contain 200 to 250 milligrams of caffeine with unlisted additives. Not surprisingly, most life-threatening conditions resulting from &quot;caffeine toxicities&quot; occur when teenagers mix energy drinks with alcohol.

&quot;What alcohol does is accelerate the effects of caffeine and block the awareness of alcohol,&quot; said Dr. Kanny Grewal, a cardiologist at OhioHealth. &quot;And that leads to more abuse.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Teenagers, caffeine don&apos;t mix, doctors say" href="http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2013/02/24/health/teenagers-caffeine-dont-mix-doctors-say.html" target="_blank">Teenagers, caffeine don&apos;t mix, doctors say</a></strong>

While the typical heart has one to three irregular beats per minute, caffeine use can increase these irregular beats up to six per minute.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: 3 Cleaning Techniques Combat Hospital Contamination
BASENAME: 3-cleaning-techniques-combat-hospital-contamination
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/03/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Human behavior may be at least as important as technological innovation when it comes to controlling C. difficile bacteria contamination of hospital rooms, a leading cause of deadly infections.&#xA0;</strong>

Over nearly two years at Cleveland Veterans Affairs Medical Center, researchers imposed three cleaning techniques to nearly eliminate the microbe: fluorescent markers whose disappearance after cleaning provided feedback on thoroughness, an ultraviolet radiation device to enhance regular cleaning, and a daily disinfection team requiring assessment and clearance of disinfected rooms by supervisory staff.

Before these procedures were put in place, 67 percent of rooms produce positive cultures for C. difficile. Use of fluorescent markers reduced it to 57 percent; automated UV radiation cut it to 35 percent; and imposing the supervised assessment and clearance made it so only 7 percent of rooms had positive cultures.

&quot;[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][These techniques are] not widely available right now,&quot; said Dr. Curtis J. Donskey, chairman of the hospital&apos;s infection control committee, &quot;and many hospitals are in the dark about how effective their cleaning processes really are.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Safer Hospital Rooms" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/04/15/safer-hospital-rooms/?ref=health" target="_blank">Safer Hospital Rooms</a></strong>

Infections occur in many patients, whether the cause is surgery or the hospital&apos;s environment. Infection control is increasing the detection of the bacterial responsible for many wrongful deaths and infections which lead to injury and death.

<strong>If you or someone you love has been injured by a defective product, drug, or malpractice,&#xA0;call the professionals at Crandall &amp; Pera Law for a free case evaluation.</strong>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Traumatic Brain Injuries: What You Need to Know
BASENAME: traumatic-brain-injuries-what-you-need-to-know
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/24/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>The reason traumatic brain injuries (TBI) are often overlooked is because the victim may continue to look and speak normally and not realize they have suffered an injury at all, delaying necessary care, according to a recent article in <em>The Legal Examiner.&#xA0;</em></strong>

These injuries can occur as a result of car crashes, slip and falls, or other severe impacts, but it is important to remember that they can also result without the head striking anything at all. When the neck is whipped back and forth, the brain could be striking the skull repeatedly, causing a traumatic injury from such force.

Dangerous symptoms can develop from sudden brain impact such as decreased cognition, change in mental state, or altered personality. The victim may also experience communication and language changes and/or brain epilepsy. Many never fully recover from brain injuries, but with quick treatment and proper rehabilitation, victims can live a full and active life. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Traumatic Brain Injuries Are Often Overlooked&#xA0;" href="http://stlouis.legalexaminer.com/head-brain-injuries/traumatic-brain-injuries-are-often-overlooked/" target="_blank">Traumatic Brain Injuries Are Often Overlooked</a></strong>

Traumatic brain injuries have many causes including traffic accidents, construction accidents, commercial trucking accidents and many other forms of negligence. The symptoms can be subtle or very alarming in their presentation and effect on the individual and their family.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Known Risky Medications Prescribed to Elderly Patients
BASENAME: known-risky-medications-prescribed-to-elderly-patients
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/06/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
&#xA0;

&#xA0;

<strong>Nearly one in five older patients enrolled in Medicare Advantage plans were prescribed at least one high-risk medication even though many of the drugs had safer substitutions, a study in <em>The Journal of General Internal Medicine</em> shows.&#xA0;</strong>

These drugs are found in a list of 110 drugs provided by health authorities to doctors giving to the elderly because their side effect risks are magnified. Included in the list are anti-anxiety medications like Valium that can lead to prolonged sedation, and in turn potentially deadly falls and fractures, as well as addiction.

The study found that as socioeconomic status grew lower, the likelihood of being prescribed a high-risk drug increased. Compared with people 65 and odler living in New England, those living in the southern region from Texas to South Carolina were about 12 percent more likely to be prescribed a high-risk medication.

The simultaneous use of multiple medications, a phenomenon known as polypharmacy, is a growing problem among people over 65, who take at least four prescription drugs on average. Adverse effects brough on by the combination of multiple drugs are thought to be responsible for nearly a third of all hospital admissions.

&quot;Polypharmacy is a major public health problem,&quot; said Dr. Amal Trivedi, one of the study&apos;s authors. &quot;Sometimes less is more, particularly for the elderly.&quot; Read the full details here:

<a title="Elderly Patients Routinely Prescribed Risky Drugshttp://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/04/15/older-pati" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/04/15/older-patients-too-often-prescribed-risky-drugs/?ref=health" target="_blank"><strong>Elderly Patients Routinely Prescribed Risky Drugs</strong></a>

&#xA0;

Nursing home negligence and neglect of the elderly occurs routinely in nursing homes and hospitals throughout the US. Elderly and nursing home patients are negligently prescribed risky drugs in an effort to make them calm and easier to care for, making staffing at these institutions easier.

<strong>If you or someone you love has been injured due to nursing home abuse or negligence,&#xA0;call the professionals at Crandall &amp; Pera Law for a free case evaluation.</strong>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Obamacare Increases Ky. Prescription Debate
BASENAME: obamacare-increases-ky-prescription-debate
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/18/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>The stakes over the long-simmering debate in Kentucky over &quot;collaborative agreements&quot; regarding prescription writing may be rising over details of the Affordable Care Act, according to a recent article in <em>The Courier-Journal</em>.&#xA0;</strong>

Under state law, nurse practitioners (NPs) can only write prescriptions if they have a collaborative agreement with a doctor who will vouch for him or her. NPs argue they have the expertise to independently&#xA0;prescribe non-scheduled drugs such and blood pressure and cholesterol medications, but doctors defend the agreements as essential for patient safety.

There are concerns that the Affordable Care Act will heighten doctor shortages and increase the need for NPs, especially in rural areas. Kentucky currently has more than 10,000 physicians and 3,000 advanced practiced registered nurses, a group that includes NPs.

A state work group is evaluating the impact of the Affordable Care Act on Kentucky&apos;s health workforce and recommendations that NPs be allowed to prescribe non-scheduled drugs without a collaborative agreement. Read the full details here:

<strong>Nurse practitioners vs. doctors - Obamacare raises debate</strong>

Unfortunately, our society is faced with the difficult decision of what is more important: quantity or quality. &#xA0;In order for more people to have access to basic care, less educated providers will be required to give that care. Our medical care system is undergoing dramatic changes.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: New ADHD Test Approved
BASENAME: new-adhd-test-approved
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/23/2013 08:57:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>The Food and Drug Administration has approved the first brain wave test to help diagnose attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and determine whether it is the cause of a particular behavioral problem in children.&#xA0;</strong>

About 9 percent of adolescents have ADHD, displaying hyperactive, impulsive and behavioral problems, and the average age of diagnosis is 7, according to the American Psychiatric Association.

Using an electroencephalogram, or EEG, the test measures combinations of theta and beta brain waves that tend to be more prevalent in children with ADHD The results showed that, with the Neuropsychiatric EEG-Based Assessment Aid, doctors would be able to make a more accurate diagnosis than using traditional methods like behavioral questionnaires and I.Q. testing alone, according to the FDA Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Brain Test to Diagnose A.D.H.D. Is Approved" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/16/health/brain-test-to-diagnose-adhd-is-approved.html?_r=1&amp;" target="_blank">Brain Test to Diagnose A.D.H.D. Is Approved</a></strong>

ADHD is a significant problem with some confusion over whether the diagnosis is being correctly made. An EEG, which is a test that has been available for decades, may offer some information which can predict this disorder.

<strong>Complaints about abuse and neglect in Ohio nursing homes have nearly doubled in the last year, according to Attorney General Mike Dewine&apos;s office.</strong>

Dewine&apos;s Medical Fraud Control Unit has opened 131 cases so far in 2013, compared with 74 in the same period last year. This includes 63 new cases in the month of June alone, according to <em>The Columbus Dispatch</em>.

The office&apos;s investigators recently used surveillance cameras to uncover <a title="shocking treatment of residents" href="http://www.cmpwlaw.com/blog/bid/297541/Ohio-Nursing-Home-Abuse-Caught-on-Camera" target="_blank">shocking treatment of residents</a> in a Zanesville nursing home, leading to the state&apos;s decision to shut down the facility. AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Generic Drug Makers Free of Liability
BASENAME: generic-drug-makers-free-of-liability
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/15/2013 01:30:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<strong>A recent ruling by the U.S. Supreme Court prohibits makers of generic drugs from being sued by patients who experience negative side effects, despite the severity of their injuries.&#xA0;</strong>

In overturning a $21 million judgment against Mutual Pharmaceutical, Supreme Court held that generic drug makers cannot be held liable for adverse side effects as long as the warning labels are identical to the drug&apos;s brand-name counterpart.

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration estimates that about three-quarters of prescriptions are for generic drugs, which are cheaper than their brand-name equivalents. Millions of Americans do not have the option to take brand-name drugs since insurance companies dictate what doctors prescribe.

It can sometimes take years after the drugs become available for their side effects to surface, and if the brand-name equivalent is no longer on the market, these generic drug makers do not have to update their labels. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Generic drug companies safe from liability suits, Supreme Court rules" href="http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/06/generic_drug_companies_safe_fr.html#incart_river" target="_blank">Generic drug companies safe from liability suits, Supreme Court rules</a></strong>

The FDA needs to recognize that generic drug manufacturers have the same obligation as brand-name companies to be held accountable if they do not provide doctors and patients with updated safety information.
