AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Prenatal Screening Breakthroughs Could Become the Norm
BASENAME: prenatal-screening-breakthroughs-could-become-the-norm
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/31/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Prenatal diagnosis, a routine part of obstetric care, is on the cusp of further revolutionary developments of highly accurate and noninvasive tests, according to a recent article in <em>The New York Times.&#xA0;</em></strong>

Prenatal tests have been developed for more than 800 genetic disorders, greatly reducing the need for amniocentesis, or inserting a long needle into the uterus to extract fluid and cells surrounding the fetus.

The newest screening test is so accurate in detecting Down syndrome that few, if any, affected fetuses are missed. It can also detect other genetic diseases, like extra copies of chromosomes and a missing sex chromosome, late in the first trimester of pregnancy.

While the test is currently only recommended for women at high risk for having a baby with a chromosomal abnormality, and not yet approved by the Food and Drug Administration, some doctors expect it to soon become routine for all pregnant women because it can be done earlier than other tests and reduce costs and the risk of complications. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Breakthroughs in Prenatal Screening&#xA0;" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/10/07/breakthroughs-in-prenatal-screening/?_r=1" target="_blank">Breakthroughs in Prenatal Screening</a></strong>

Exciting breakthroughs are close to being approved in the detection, screening and treatment of Down syndrome and other genetic diseases before birth.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: FDA Shortens Drug Approval Time, Raises Questions
BASENAME: fda-shortens-drug-approval-time-raises-questions
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 11/07/2013 12:49:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<strong>As the Food and Drug Administration expedites reviews, many safety questions are left unanswered about new drugs even after they are approved, according to a study in the Journal of the American Medical Association.</strong>

In an examination of 20 new drugs approved by the FDA in 2008, it was found that eight were given expedited review (5.1 years of clinical testing) and 12 standard review (7.5 years). But, in many cases, safety monitoring trials that were supposed to be conducted after the products were approved were either not conducted, not completed or not submitted to the FDA.

Of the drugs studied in 2008, the FDA required 85 follow-up trials to monitor for safety. By 2013, only 40 percent of those studies had been completed.

&quot;The testing of new drugs has shifted from a situation in which most testing was conducted prior to initial approval to a situation in which many innovative drugs are more rapidly approved after a small trial in a narrower patient population with extensive additional testing conducted after approval,&quot; the study&apos;s authors said.

While patient groups and drug companies applaud these measures in order to get medications into the hands of patients more quickly, critics say the FDA is approving products before they have been fully vetted. Read the full details here:

<strong>FDA&apos;s shorter approval time for new drugs raises questions</strong>

<span style="font-size: 1em;">This article demonstrates how important it is, when prescribed medication or given any medical advice, to ask questions and do as much research as possible.</span>

</span>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: New Doctors Lack Bedside Manner
BASENAME: new-doctors-lack-bedside-manner
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 11/05/2013 12:59:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Doctors in their first year out of medical school are unlikely to display communications skills that can improve a patient&apos;s recovery and lead to greater patient satisfaction, according to a new study from Johns Hopkins University.&#xA0;</strong>

Observers recorded the actions of 29 internal medicine interns for three weeks to see whether they used five valued communications skills: introducing themselves, explaining their role to the patient, touching the patient, asking open-ended questions like, &quot;How are you feeling today?,&quot; and sitting down with the patient for a conversation.

In total, interns only performed all five behaviors during just 4% of their visits. They only introduced themselves to patients 40% of the time and explained their medical role 37% of the time. The interns only sat down with their patients 9% of the time.

&quot;It&apos;s no wonder patients don&apos;t feel connected to what we are telling them, because many times we are not doing as much as we could to make that connection,&quot; said Dr. Lauren Block, a former general internal medicine fellow at Johns Hopkins. Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="It&apos;s not you, doctors are just rude" href="http://www.cnn.com/2013/10/25/health/time-doctors-rude/index.html?hpt=hp_bn13" target="_blank">It&apos;s not you, doctors are just rude</a></strong>

Bedside manner is important. As this article demonstrates, it not only makes the patient more trusting of the doctor, but it promotes greater healing. With increasing pressure to bill more due to lower health insurance reimbursement rates, this behavior is unlikely to improve without a concerted effort by hospital administrators and medical school leaders.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Breast Cancer Gene Mutation Carriers Face Great Uncertainty
BASENAME: breast-cancer-gene-mutation-carriers-face-great-uncertainty
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/29/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Women who test positive for the BRCA gene mutation face a lot of uncertainty and conflicting information regarding their surgical options, according to a recent article in <em>The New York Times</em>.&#xA0;</strong>

Women with BRCA mutations often opt for risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectory (RRSO), which removes the ovaries and fallopian tubes, but others consider going further and removing their uterus as well through a hysterectomy.

There is debate among experts over whether RRSO is the best strategy for all women, causing many patients to be caught in the middle, struggling to balance conflicting information about hysterectomy as part of risk-reducing surgery. There is also no way to predict what each individual will face in the future, regardless of her choice.

There is scant evidence that women with BRCA mutations are more likely to develop uterine cancer, but worries persist due to anecdotal cases and the fact that uterine cancer is the most commonly diagnosed gynecologic cancer.

&quot;The biggest challenge is trying to make those risk-benefit decisions every day, every time and get it right,&quot; said Dr. Susan Domchek of the Basser Research Center for BRCA. &quot;Some people you&apos;re overtreating, and some you&apos;re undertreating.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Weighing Surgeries in Light of a Breast Cancer Gene&#xA0;" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/10/07/weighing-surgeries-in-light-of-a-breast-cancer-gene/?_r=0" target="_blank">Weighing Surgeries in Light of a Breast Cancer Gene</a></strong>

Better safe than sorry? If women have a genetic predisposition for cancer, is it better to have a hysterectomy or just have their ovaries and fallopian tubes removed? This article demonstrates there is little agreement to this question.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Recall of Injectable Antibiotic
BASENAME: recall-of-injectable-antibiotic
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/30/2013 08:26:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>The Food and Drug Administration has alerted medical professionals to the recall of an injectable antibiotic used for a variety of bacterial infections, due to floating particles found in a sample of the drug.</strong>

Specs of metal, cotton fiber and hair were visibly found in vials of the lot H3A73444 of Cefepime for Injection USP and Dextrose Injection USP made by B. Braun Medical.

The drug was distributed to hospitals, pharmacies and medical suppliers nationwide and could result in blood clots causing stroke, heart attack and other catastrophic problems, according to the agency. Read the full details here:

<strong>Injectable antibiotic recalled for visible particles</strong>

Before any doctor prescribes you or a loved one the injection antibiotics of Cefepime and/or Dextrose, make sure you&#x2019;ve read this article.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Are Steroid Injections Really Best for Back Pain?
BASENAME: are-steroid-injections-really-best-for-back-pain
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/17/2013 09:38:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>New studies find that injecting any liquid, not just steroids, into the area around the spinal cord will help relieve back pain.</strong>

Epidurals are the most commonly used treatment for back pain, but these new studies suggest even plain saline solution works just as well as steroids to help reduce inflammation, enhance blood flow to the nerves and clean out scar tissue.

Because of the little different between the amount of relief provided by steroidal and nonsteroidal epidural injections, doctors may have to consider other viable options to help patients avoid the side effects many steroids cause.

&quot;...Most of the short-term benefit seems to be not from the steroids, but from the local anesthetic and saline, which may &apos;calm&apos; inflamed nerves that send pain signals,&quot; said Dr. Steven P. Cohen, a professor of anesthesiology at Johns Hopkins. &quot;Doctors should consider significantly reducing the steroid dose, or even not using steroids in patients who are at high risk.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Questioning Steroid Shots for Back Pain" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/09/19/questioning-steroid-shots-for-back-pain/?ref=health&amp;_r=2" target="_blank">Questioning Steroid Shots for Back Pain</a></strong>

Chronic back pain is one of the leading causes of worker&apos;s compensation claims, disability and even surgical intervention. Now a popular conservative treatment method is called into question.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Why Doctors Order Unnecessary Scans
BASENAME: why-doctors-order-unnecessary-scans
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/22/2013 01:16:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Doctors with a financial interest in magnetic resonance imaging (M.R.I.) machines may be more likely to order unnecessary scans for patients, according to a new <em>Radiology</em>&#xA0;study.</strong>

Researchers found that more patients received M.R.I. scans that indicate nothing is wrong if they are referred by a doctor who owns the machine. Of the 700 knee M.R.I. scans studied, 33 percent of patients indicating no abnormalities were referred by doctors who owned the machine, as compared with 25 percent of patients referred by those without a financial stake in the device.

&quot;There is a potential for bias in certain settings,&quot; said Dr. Matthew P. Lungren, the study&apos;s lead author and a fellow in radiology at Duke. &quot;The doctor should be transparent and acknowledge his interest. That should be disclosed.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Scans More Likely if Doctors Have Financial Stake" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/09/23/scans-more-likely-if-doctors-have-financial-stake/?ref=health" target="_blank">Scans More Likely if Doctors Have Financial Stake</a></strong>

Physicians who own and operate MRI scanners, and stand to make money if they are used, are unsurprisingly found to order an MRI test for their patients.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Prescriptions Affected by Location of Patients
BASENAME: prescriptions-affected-by-location-of-patients
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/28/2013 08:38:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Location is one of the largest factors determining what medications are prescribed, particularly to seniors, according to a study released by the Dartmouth Atlas Project.</strong>

The differences in prescriptions nationwide mean that some patients miss out on key treatments while others get risky ones, according to the study. More than 1 in 4 Medicare patients filled at least one prescription for medications long deemed high-risk for seniors, including muscle relaxants and anxiety relievers that can cause excessive sedation, falls and other problems in older adults.

Researchers showed that the type and amount of health care patients receive varies widely nationwide, with those who live where Medicare spends more not necessarily receiving quality care. Patients in the South were more likely to fill prescriptions for riskier medications, but less likely than those in other regions to receive long-recommended treatments for heart and bone conditions.

Doctors &quot;really need to ask themselves, &apos;Is there a good reason why my patients are getting less effective care than patients in the other regions,&apos;&quot; said Dr. Jeffrey Munson, who believes there would be far less variation if doctors were following guidelines on best medication practices. Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Where seniors live may affect what medication they are prescribed" href="http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-204_162-57607744/where-seniors-live-may-affect-what-medication-they-are-prescribed/" target="_blank">Where seniors live may affect what medication they are prescribed</a></strong>

In a lawsuit, the &#x201C;standard of care&#x201D; refers to what is expected of reasonable prudent doctor.&#xA0; This expectation isn&#x2019;t limited by geographical location. This article, however, demonstrates that the quality of care is not always consistent across the country. In the end, it is important to always do your research, ask questions, and be an advocate for you and your loved ones.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: System Implemented to Catch Medical Implant Flaws
BASENAME: system-implemented-to-catch-medical-implant-flaws
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/16/2013 09:17:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Following years of highly-publicized recalls on medical implants plagued by design and manufacturing flaws, a new electronic system will now be used to protect patients by catching problems earlier.&#xA0;</strong>

The Food and Drug Administration published new rules that require most medical devices sold in the U.S. - such as pacemakers and hip replacements - to carry a unique code used for tracking by federal health regulators. The make, manufacture date and lot number codes will be stored in a publicly accessible database to help regulators, doctors and companies monitor safety issues with devices.

&quot;Up until now medical devices were among the only products on the market that could not be uniquely identified,&quot; said Josh Rising, director of Pew Charitable Trusts&apos; medical device initiative. &quot;This is going to be a tremendous victory for all of those interested in improving the performance of devices.&quot;

Hospitals and insurers will be able to add the codes to patients&apos; medical records, helping them to quickly identify people who have received problematic implants and devices. Read the full details here:

<strong>FDA required tracking codes on medical implants</strong>

<strong>The U.S. emergency infrastructure received a near failing grade from the American College of Emergency Physicians&apos; latest &quot;report card,&quot; which states that shortages and reduced hospital capacity make it more difficult to access emergency care.&#xA0;</strong>

Such reduced access earned the nation a &quot;D+&quot; down from the overall &quot;C-&quot; grade from the group&apos;s last report in 2009.&#xA0;Emergency rooms could be used even more than the data predicts as more Americans gain insurance coverage under the Affordable Care Act.

The group&apos;s task force looked at scores of measure in five major categories - access to care, quality and patient safety, liability, injury prevention and disaster preparedness - and relied on data from the Centers for Disease Control and the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, among others.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Superbugs Responsible for 23,000 Deaths Per Year
BASENAME: superbugs-responsible-for-23000-deaths-per-year
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 10/08/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Drug-resistant germs, known as superbugs, infect more than two million people each year, 23,000 of which die from their infections, according to a recent NBC News article.</strong>

Although doctors have been warned of the problem for decades, up to half of prescriptions written for antibiotics are unnecessary, making the superbug problem even worse.

C. difficile is biggest killer by far, as reported by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and has become a scourge of hospitals. The infection is made possible when patients are heavily treated with antibiotics to fight other infections and can cause unstoppable diarrhea.

The most immediate problem is in hospitals and when patients do not finish a prescribed course of antibiotics. The CDC reported that no new antibiotics are in the immediate works that would kill any of these superbugs, meaning patients may have to be treated with older, more toxic drugs, or with cocktails of antibiotics that may cause side-effects.

&quot;If we are not careful, the medicine chest will be empty when we go there to look for a lifesaving antibiotic for somebody who has a deadly infection,&quot; sad CDC director Tom Frieden. &quot;Without care we will soon be in a post-antibiotic era. For some infections...we are already there.&quot; Read the full story here:

<strong>23,000 killed by superbugs in US each year, CDC says</strong>

Healthcare-acquired infections are rising every year and the ability of antibiotics to treat these infections is decreasing.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Diabetes Screening Recommended for All Pregnant Women
BASENAME: diabetes-screening-recommended-for-all-pregnant-women
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 01/27/2014 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>All pregnant women should be screened for gestational diabetes in order to reduce the risk of several potential birth complications, according to the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force.&#xA0;</strong>

The independent task force found an overall benefit to screening and treatment, including a reduced risk of preeclampsia in pregnant patients and of having an overly large baby and birth-related injuries to the newborn.

The group said women with no history of diabetes should be screened after 24 weeks of pregnancy.

About 240,000 of the 4 million women who give birth each year nationwide each year develop gestational diabetes, a condition on the rise as obesity and other risk factors increase among pregnant women. The condition occurs during pregnancy when the body does not produce enough insulin or use it correctly, leaving the body unable to convert starches and sugars from food into energy.

&quot;One of the key steps women can take to reduce the chances of gestational diabetes is having a healthy diet and being physically active prior to pregnancy,&quot; said Dr. Wanda Nicholson, a former member of the task force. Read the full story here:

<strong>Screen all pregnant women for diabetes, task force says&#xA0;</strong>

Every expectant mother should be screened for gestational diabetes.

TITLE: Study Finds No Reason for Differing Hospital Birth Costs
BASENAME: study-finds-no-reason-for-differing-hospital-birth-costs
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 01/23/2014 08:31:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>A new study that found no logical explanation for the cost of having a baby in a hospital in California ranging from $3,000 to $37,000 highlights the &quot;appalling&quot; state of healthcare nationwide, according to a recent <em>NBC News </em>article.&#xA0;</strong>

Even after adjusting for patient and hospital characteristics, researchers found the prices for uncomplicated deliveries ranged from $3,296 to $37,227, while those for a C-section ranged from $8,312 to nearly $71,000.

&quot;It is very common, not just in California, but in every state and every city around the country,&quot; said Dr. Jeffrey Rice, a former physician who set up a group called Healthcare Blue Book to help people compare prices. &quot;Every hospital gets to set their own prices. They get to negotiate their payment amounts with the insurance companies.&quot;

The federal government started publishing data on hospital charges in May, with the first numbers confirming that charges vary enormously, and for seemingly unclear reasons.

&quot;The number one thing consumers can do is ask about the cost of care before they get treatment,&quot; said Rice. &quot;If a provider won&apos;t tell you what their price is, you probably don&apos;t want to do business with that provider.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong>What&apos;s it cost to have a baby? Try $3,000 --- or $37,000</strong>

Before you undergo an elective or non-urgent medical treatment or procedure, be sure to ask about the associated costs, even if you have insurance. The differences between providers and hospitals can be significant, even within the same city.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: FDA Limits Dose of Common Drug Linked to Liver Failure
BASENAME: fda-limits-dose-of-common-drug-linked-to-liver-failure
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 01/24/2014 08:48:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>New recommendations by U.S. health regulators aim to limit the prescription of a commonly used drug, citing the risk of liver damage, according to a recent <em>NBC News </em>article.&#xA0;</strong>

Acetaminophen is widely used in both prescription and over-the-counter products to reduce pain and fever from acute injuries, post-operative pain, or pain following dental procedures. Limiting the quantity to less than 325 milligrams of acetaminophen per tablet, capsule, or other dosage unit will reduce the risk of inadvertent overdose, which can lead to liver failure, liver transplant and death, according to the Food and Drug Administration.

Inadvertent overdose from combination drugs containing acetaminophen accounts for nearly half of all cases of acetaminophen-related liver failure in the United States. The FDA also cited the fact that no available data showed that taking more than the recommended dose provided benefits that outweighed the added risks. Read the full story here:

<strong>FDA: Limit high-dose acetaminophen</strong>

Even Tylenol, if you take enough, can be harmful. Always take medications pursuant to how they are prescribed or, if over the counter, in accordance with the recommended dosage on the package.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: New Guidelines Decrease Dependence on Blood Pressure Drugs
BASENAME: new-guidelines-decrease-dependence-on-blood-pressure-drugs
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 01/17/2014 10:03:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Current widespread guidelines for blood pressure may be outdated, according to a report published in The Journal of the American Medical Association, which suggests that people over 60 can have a higher blood pressure before starting treatment to lower it.</strong>

Patients have been told to strive for blood pressures below 140/90, with some taking multiple drugs to achieve that goal, for more than 30 years. After five years of reviewing evidence, and weighing the risks associated with the medications used to bring pressures down, the guidelines committee concluded that the goal for people over 60 should be 150/90.

The group added that people over 60 who already take medications to lower blood pressure can continue if they are not experiencing side effects, but that there is a difference between lowering blood pressure with drugs and having lower pressure naturally.

&quot;We have this notion that if we can get blood pressure to normal, we will have the most health benefits,&quot; said Dr. Paul A. James, co-chairman of the guidelines committee. &quot;That&apos;s not necessarily true.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Hypertension Guidelines Can Be Eased, Panel Says" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/19/health/blood-pressure-guidelines-can-be-loosened-panel-says.html?ref=health&amp;_r=2&amp;" target="_blank">Hypertension Guidelines Can Be Eased, Panel Says</a></strong>

If you have high blood pressure, you should read this article.

<strong>A now defunct trucking company in North Canton, Ohio was found to terminate employees rather than abide by the proper safety precautions, according to an article in <em>Insurance Journal.</em></strong>

Star Air Inc. terminated two drivers who refused to continue driving for the company until safety issues were resolved. Both drivers did not have the name of the company, its home base or its U.S. Department of Transportation number displayed on their trucks.

One of the dismissed drivers was cited by the West Virginia State Police for hauling an excess load without a commercial driver&apos;s license, operating an overweight trailer and driving without a logbook.

Both drivers filed complaints with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration alleging the company discriminated against them in retaliation for activities protected by the 1982 Surface Transportation Assistance Act. The owner of Star Air Inc. will be paying them over $300,000 to resolve the lawsuit. Read the full article here:

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: New Mammogram Guidelines Increase Confusion for Patients
BASENAME: new-mammogram-guidelines-increase-confusion-for-patients
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 01/22/2014 08:43:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>A mammogram is the most basic test to screen for breast cancer, but differing guidelines in the medical community over when to begin testing has led to widespread confusion among patients, according to an <em>ABC News</em>&#xA0;article.&#xA0;</strong>

The United States Preventive Task Force recommends that women get mammograms starting at age 50, while the American Cancer Society advocates for screening to begin at age 40.

A new study contends that women have a baseline screening even earlier than the official guidelines, at age 35, because of the number of young women who develop the disease in their 20s and 30s.

Besides the discomfort associated with the test, there is a relatively small radiation exposure. False positives during testing can subject patients to biopsies that they otherwise&#xA0;would not have to have.

&quot;You have to look at the big picture,&quot; said Dr. V. Merle McIntosh, chief of breast surgery at Englewood Hospital. &quot;Do the benefits outweigh the risks of doing these tests? And for mammography, I would say a resounding yes. The benefits far outweigh those risks.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Should You Get a Mammogram?" href="http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/health/2013/10/07/should-you-get-a-mammogram/" target="_blank">Should You Get a Mammogram?</a></strong>

Every woman over the age of 30 should read this article or watch the video.

TITLE: Area Hospitals Among Worst for Common Surgeries
BASENAME: area-hospitals-among-worst-for-common-surgeries
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 01/07/2014 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Medicare has rated three hospitals throughout Ohio and Pennsylvania some of the worst facilities to receive hip and knee replacements, according to an NBC News article.&#xA0;</strong>

Out of nearly 200 hospitals analyzed, 95 were found to have elderly patients more likely to suffer significant setbacks. The nine rated to have the highest amount of readmissions and complication rates included Grant Medical Center in Columbus, Mercy St. Anne Hospital in Toledo, and the Pennsylvania Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania Health System in Philadelphia.

The analysis is part of the government&apos;s push to improve quality at the nation&apos;s hospitals instead of simply paying Medicare patients&apos; bills. About 600,000 patients in the traditional Medicare program have their hips or knees replaced each year.

In 2010, there were 719,000 knee replacements costing nearly $12 billion and 332,000 hop replacements costing nearly $8 billion, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. Read the full article here:

<strong>Medicare identifies best and worst hospitals for hip and knee replacements</strong>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Deadly Bacteria Spreads From Hospitals to Community
BASENAME: deadly-bacteria-spreads-from-hospitals-to-community
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 01/14/2014 07:01:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>A deadly bacteria that was once confined to hospitals is now emerging in communities with fatal results, according to USA Today.&#xA0;</strong>

Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, or MRSA, is a drug-defying bug that has proved more persistent than any other, causing much frustration as it spreads more widely. In recent years, new MRSA strains have reached far beyond hospitals to infect schoolchildren, soldiers, prison inmates, and NFL players.

MRSA infections sicken hundreds of thousands of Americans each year in various ways, from minor skin boils to deadly pneumonia, killing upward of 20,000. MRSA cases in children continue to rise 10% a year among youths ages 3 months to 17 years.

Modern medicine&apos;s struggle against antibiotic resistant bacteria has become the nation&apos;s most daunting public health threat.

&quot;Some of these bugs tend to come and go over decades, and the question now is what will happen with community-associated MRSA,&quot; said Bob Weinstein, an infectious disease physician for the Cook County Health and Hospitals System. &quot;How long will it be here before it wanes - or will it wane? We don&apos;t know.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Dangerous MRSA bacteria expand into communities&#xA0;" href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/12/16/mrsa-infection-community-schools-victims-doctors/3991833/" target="_blank">Dangerous MRSA bacteria expand into communities&#xA0;</a></strong>

The potential of contracting a MRSA infection is another good reason to be vigilant about protecting yourself from exposure to bacteria and viruses in the community setting. Wash those hands!

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Common Hysterectomy Procedure Called into Question
BASENAME: common-hysterectomy-procedure-called-into-question
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 01/15/2014 11:49:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>A widespread surgical technique used on thousands of women during hysterectomies is currently being debated after a Boston surgeon and his anesthesiologist wife blamed it for dangerously spreading her undetected cancer, according to the Boston Globe.</strong>

Morcellation, the technique in question, is typically employed during laparoscopic hysterectomies, a type of minimally invasive surgery. When a morcellator was used to cut Dr. Amy Reed&apos;s uterus, however, cancerous tissue spread throughout her abdominal cavity during the surgery, giving her stage 4 cancer.

Reed said the gynecologist at Brigham and Women&apos;s Hospital who did her hysterectomy did not inform her of the risk that morcellation can spread cancer.

About 600,000 hysterectomies are done in the United States every year, most done to treat benign fibroids using minimally invasive techniques. Morcellation is not generally recommended for use in patients who are known to have cancer.

Reed&apos;s husband believes doctors and hospitals are still using the procedure because it allows them to do more procedures faster. &quot;There is a lot of money involved in this business,&quot; he said. Read the full article here:

<strong>Boston surgeon and physician wife push to stop common procedure they say worsened her cancer</strong>

If you are considering, or recently had, a hysterectomy, you should read this article.

TITLE: Free Pilates Class Helps Breast Cancer Survivors
BASENAME: free-pilates-class-helps-breast-cancer-survivors
STATUS: Publish

ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 01/06/2014 09:46:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>A physical therapy center in southern Indiana will begin offering free Pilates classes this week for breast cancer survivors to help women bounce back from the physical and emotional fallout from the disease, according to an article in the <em>Courier-Journal</em>.&#xA0;</strong>

Shoulder problems, physical imbalances, muscle tightness and reduced strength are among the health issues that breast cancer patients and survivors sometimes contend with, according to Susie Stewart, instructor of the class at Floyd Memorial Physical Therapy Charlestown Road. The American Cancer Society recommends cancer survivors get at least 150 minutes of exercise a week, with strength training at least two days a week.

The one-hour class is based upon the Pink Ribbon Program that was started when a Pilates instructor was dismayed that breast cancer survivors were being discharged without a plan for physical therapy or rehabilitation. Read the full story here:

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Potential Harms Linked to Common Acid Suppressants
BASENAME: potential-harms-linked-to-common-acid-suppressants
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 12/17/2013 02:20:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Extended use of certain acid-suppressing drugs may be leading to an increase in anemia, neurological problems, or dementia, according to a new study published in&#xA0;<em>The Journal of the American Medical Association</em>.&#xA0;</strong>

People who use proton-pump inhibitors (P.P.I.&apos;s) and histamine 2 receptor antagonists, sold under brand names like Prevacid, Prilosec and Nexium, for two years or longer are at increased risk of vitamin B12 deficiency which can, in turn, cause these health problems, according to the study. Last year, nearly 157 million prescriptions were written for P.P.I.&apos;s alone.

Out of more than 200,000 patients studied, those who took P.P.I.&apos;s for more than two years were 65 percent more likely to have a vitamin B12 deficiency, with higher doses more strongly associated with the vitamin deficiency.

&quot;It&apos;s so much easier to allow a patient who is happy staying on the drug to do so,&quot; said Dr. T.S. Dharamarajan, vice chairman of medicine at the Montefiore Medical Center, &quot;but you have to consider the unintended harm.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Acid-Suppressing Drugs Linked to Vitamin B12 Deficiency&#xA0;" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/12/10/acid-suppressing-drugs-linked-to-vitamin-b12-deficiency/?_r=1" target="_blank">Acid-Suppressing Drugs Linked to Vitamin B12 Deficiency</a></strong>

Important new findings about the side effects of drugs many take to combat gastrointestinal issues. This news should be spread to ensure those who take these commonly prescribed and over the counter medications are aware of the severe issues they may cause.

TITLE: Gynecology Board Blocks Pelvic Pain Treatment for Men
BASENAME: gynecology-board-blocks-pelvic-pain-treatment-for-men
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 12/18/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Many male patients suffering from chronic pelvic pain are being denied treatment because of prohibitions placed on physicians by the American Board of Obstetrics and Gynecology, according to a recent article in <em>The New York Times.&#xA0;</em></strong>

On Sept. 12, the ABOG released a newly stringent and explicit statement of what its members could not do. Except for a few conditions, this restrictions include treating men. Failure to abide by this new rule could cause a physician to lose his or her board certification.

The board reversed its ruling to allow gynecologists to screen and treat men who are at high risk for anal cancer, but refuses to make an exception for pelvic pain, a condition poorly understood and frequently misdiagnosed in men.

According to the International Pelvic Pain Society, &quot;Gynecologists with the appropriate skills, experience and knowledge who choose to participate in the care of men with chronic pelvic pain should not be at risk of losing their board certification, solely because they participate in the care of patients who have a real need, suffer tremendously and have limited options for treatment.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Men With Pelvic Pain Find a Path to Treatment Blocked by a Gynecology Board&#xA0;" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/11/us/men-with-pelvic-pain-find-a-path-to-treatment-blocked-by-a-gynecology-board.html" target="_blank">Men With Pelvic Pain Find a Path to Treatment Blocked by a Gynecology Board</a></strong>

A recent trend of putting up medical barriers to stop GYN physicians from being able to help men, when they traditionally only treat women, must be torn down to effectuate and allow treatment for these chronic pain sufferers.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Powerful Pain Pills Prescribed to Non-Surgical Patients
BASENAME: powerful-pain-pills-prescribed-to-non-surgical-patients
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 12/11/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Prescription rates for powerful opioid pain pills that have high potential for abuse are high even for hospital patients who have not undergone surgery, according to a new study published in the Journal of Hospital Medicine.&#xA0;</strong>

More than 50 percent of patients studied who did not have surgery were prescribed an opioid, a type of narcotic painkiller including oxycodone and morphine, with over one-quarter of non-surgical patients still on the medications when they were discharged from the hospital, according to the report.

Overall, 43 percent of patients regardless of surgical status were given multiple opioid painkillers, with the average patient receiving about 68 milligrams of oral morphine daily.

&quot;Prior studies have found that higher opioid doses are associated with a heightened risk of adverse events,&quot; said Dr. Shoshana J. Herzig, a hospitalist at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston. &quot;Patients receiving doses of 100 mg per day or more are at substantially greater risk for serious problems, including severe breathing problems.&quot;

Painkiller abuse and addiction has been steadily on the rise over the last decade, with sixty percent of all drug overdose deaths linked to prescription medications in 2010. Since 2007, women have been at a higher risk of dying from a prescription drug overdose than from passing away in a motor vehicle accident. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Narcotic pain pill rates high for patients who don&apos;t have surgery: Study" href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/narcotic-opioid-pain-pill-rates-high-for-patients-who-dont-have-surgery/" target="_blank">Narcotic pain pill rates high for patients who don&apos;t have surgery: Study</a></strong>

Pain relievers are essential and it only seems humane to prescribe opioids for those in significant pain. At the same time, these medications are not without risk. They can lead to breathing problems and death. From a long term perspective, they can lead to crippling drug addictions. If you can avoid opioids, do so. If you need them, take as little as possible for as short of a term as possible.

If you or anyone in your family has suffered serious side effects or damages from a medication error you should seek legal investigation immediately.&#xA0;Crandall &amp; Pera Law&#xA0;is&#xA0;available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Widely Used Chemical Linked to Preterm Births
BASENAME: widely-used-chemical-linked-to-preterm-births
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 12/09/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Pregnant women may have an increased risk of preterm delivery when exposed to a group of hormone-mimicking chemicals called phthalates, according to a new study in JAMA Pediatrics.</strong>

Women who were found to have the highest levels of phthalate metabolites in their urine had a risk of preterm birth - an infant born before 37 weeks of pregnancy - that was two to five times higher when compared with women with the lowest levels. Preterm birth is a leading cause of death or long-term neurological disabilities in children, with one out of every eight children born prematurely, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Women who has &quot;spontaneous preterm delivery,&quot; meaning they didn&apos;t have a medical condition that could explain their early delivery, made the link between exposure to phthalates and risk of preterm delivery even stronger for researchers.

Phthalates are chemicals widely used in making flexible and durable plastics, adhesives, detergents, soaps, shampoos, hair sprays, perfumes and deodorants. People are exposed through contact with products containing these hormone-disrupting chemicals and by eating certain processed and canned foods.

&quot;For women who are interested in reducing their exposure, reducing use of personal care products, buying phthalate-free [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][products] when possible, and eating fresher foods may help, although research on that is limited,&quot; said study researcher John Meeker. Read the full details here:

<strong>Preterm births linked to phthalates</strong>

Do you know what phthalates are? If you or a loved one is pregnant, this article suggests you should find out.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Compounding Pharmacy Bill May Hinder Patient Safety
BASENAME: compounding-pharmacy-bill-may-hinder-patient-safety
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 12/10/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>A new bill passed by Congress regarding stricter regulations for compounding pharmacies may actually be doing less to keep patients safer, according to ABC News.&#xA0;</strong>

The Drug Quality and Security Act was passed to prevent a repeat of what officials have called the &quot;largest documented healthcare-related outbreak in the United States,&quot; when a New England Compounding Center made tainted steroid injections that killed 64 people and sickened about 700 others in a fungal outbreak in 20 states last year.

The bill would give large-scale compounding pharmacies the option to register with the Food and Drug Administration and adhere to stricter guidelines for testing and maintaining quality and sterility.

Opponents of the bill fear compounding pharmacies will not be treated like other drug manufacturers who have to adhere to mandatory guidelines because the bill does not require them. Supporters hope that compounding pharmacists will want to register with the FDA because doctors will prefer to use manufacturers perceived as safer.

&quot;It makes no sense to have two different tiers of drug manufacturers -- one that has to meet all the manufacturing guidelines and one that only has to meet some of them,&quot; said Dr. Michael Carome, who directs the health research group at Public Citizen. &quot;We believe in a level playing field.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Compounding Pharmacy Bill Might Not Make Drugs Safer" href="http://abcnews.go.com/Health/compounding-pharmacy-bill-make-drugs-safer/story?id=20904830" target="_blank">Compounding Pharmacy Bill Might Not Make Drugs Safer</a></strong>

Are compounding pharmacists safer? Should there be two sets of laws for the manufacture and sale of the same drugs? This article illustrates that the answers to these questions is not easy.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: New Transplant Program Preserves Lungs After Death
BASENAME: new-transplant-program-preserves-lungs-after-death
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 12/05/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>An innovative experiment aiming to preserve the lungs of donors that die outside of a hospital could help ease the viable organ shortage nationwide, according to NBC News Health.</strong>

Currently, the U.S. does not have a system to recover organs quickly enough from registered organ donors who die unexpectedly, even though the air left inside lungs keep them from deteriorating right away as other organs do.

&quot;There aren&apos;t enough lungs. We&apos;re burying them,&quot; said Dr. Thomas Egan, who is leading the project. &quot;It turns out your lungs don&apos;t die when you do.&quot;

The new system would immediately notify next-of-kin upon the death of an organ donor for permission to participate in the research, pump air into the lungs to preserve them while the body is transported and a lung perfusion to preserve the lungs even longer while looking for abnormalities. Lungs that pass will be transplanted into patients willing to take a chance on these nontraditional organs, as part of the study funded by the National Institutes of Health.

In the United States, more than 6,000 people died in 2012 while waiting for new lungs as just 1,700 lungs transplants are performed each year. Only 15 to 20 percent of donated lungs are usable, often because complications during the donor&apos;s hospitalization damage them.

&quot;The general public does not understand how hard it is to become an organ donor,&quot; said bioethicist Arthur Caplan of New York University&apos;s Langone Medical Center. &quot;Only 2 to 3 percent of people die in circumstances that let them be organ donors.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong>&apos;Lungs don&apos;t die when you do&apos;: New transplant program might ease shortages</strong>

The human body&#x2019;s resiliency is incredible. We now know that our lungs remain &#x201C;alive&#x201D; and viable hours after we die.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Blood Screening Delays Prove Dangerous for Newborns
BASENAME: blood-screening-delays-prove-dangerous-for-newborns
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 12/03/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Delays in routine screening blood tests given to newborns to check for several dozen medical disorders are causing babies to die or become permanently disabled nationwide, according to a report in&#xA0;<em>The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.&#xA0;</em></strong>

&quot;Heel prick&quot; tests have been performed for 50 years as a means to identify disorders in time to improve or save the lives of more than 12,000 newborns in the U.S. each year. &quot;The entire premise of newborn screening is to detect disorders quickly so babies can be treated early, averting death and preventing or limiting brain damage, disability and a lifetime of costly medical care,&quot; writes <em>Journal Sentinel</em>&#xA0;reporter Ellen Gabler.

Yet, at least 160,000 blood samples from newborns arrived late to labs across the country last year, according to analysis of tests from 31 states. As a result of this delayed lab work, many babies across the nation received delayed diagnoses of otherwise treatable illnesses.

&quot;[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][A]ny late test could be catastrophic for a child with one of the disorders caught by screening,&quot; writes Gabler. &quot;Hours can mark the difference between a child who suffers permanent brain damage and a child who lives a healthy life with a modified diet.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Hospitals put babies at risk with delays in newborn screenings" href="http://www.minnpost.com/second-opinion/2013/11/hospitals-put-babies-risk-delays-newborn-screenings" target="_blank">Hospitals put babies at risk with delays in newborn screenings</a></strong>

A must-read for any expectant mom or anyone considering having a baby. Newborn screening blood work is always drawn, but sometimes not sent to the lab or examined until it is too late for the baby to benefit from these results.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: FDA&apos;s Refusal to Test High-Risk Medical Devices
BASENAME: fdas-refusal-to-test-high-risk-medical-devices
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 12/04/2013 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Many high-risk devices that are widely used in the medical community have never been subjected to the rigorous premarket approval process the Food and Drug Administration routinely requires for new drugs, according to <em>The New York Times</em>.</strong>

Researchers fear that nearly a dozen medical devices, including external cardiac compressors, may never be thoroughly evaluated by the agency because they are presumed to be roughly equivalent to products already in use before the FDA began regulating devices in 1976.

These high-risk devices, meaning they sustain human life or pose an unreasonable risk to patients, include external pacemakers, access tubes implanted in blood vessels, a component of a lung device used for newborns, dental devices that are implanted near the brain, and screw systems used in spinal surgery. The FDA proposes downgrading the classification of these products so they are no longer considered high-risk instead of putting them through premarket approval.

&quot;People would be shocked to know that the FDA never got its act together to require the studies,&quot; said Diana Zuckerman, president of the National Research Center for Women and Families. Other devices, including defribrillators and implanted pacemakers, will remain high-risk and must undergo premarket approval. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="New Scrutiny for Medical Devices&#xA0;" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/11/18/new-scrutiny-for-medical-devices/?ref=health&amp;_r=1" target="_blank">New Scrutiny for Medical Devices</a></strong>

Everybody wants to get potential life-saving products on the market as soon as possible.&#xA0; This desire, however, must be balanced by rigorous testing. Products that may seem perfect, often times are not.

STATUS: Publish

BODY:
A young married woman who had two young boys was admitted to her local hospital for an infection of her wound site after a resent spine surgery. She needed and IV line established so she could receive fluids and her needed antibiotics to cure her infection. Had this happened she would have been fine, the infection cured by these medications. AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Staggering Infant Mortality Rate Sparks Change in Ohio
BASENAME: staggering-infant-mortality-rate-sparks-change-in-ohio
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/01/2014 11:38:00 AM
-----
BODY:
New statistics show that Ohio is just about the deadliest state for infants, ranking 48th for infant deaths, according to <em>The Columbus Dispatch</em>.

In 2012, 1,045 babies died before their first birthday, according to state officials. This has led the push for new state bills that would provide $25 million for community-based services such as food or transportation, require more detailed documentation of sudden infant deaths, create an infant-mortality commission, and require parents to be given safe-sleep educational materials before leaving the hospital.

Gov. John Kasich has already funded several programs for pregnant women, including hormone treatment for those at risk of early delivery, smoking cessation classes and promotion of the use of multivitamins and folic-acid supplements.

&quot;Our infant health is truly a reflection of the health of our state in total,&quot; said Columbus Democrat Charleta B. Tavares, co-sponsor of the bills along with Springboro Republican Shannon Jones. &quot;So if we can&apos;t ensure that our babies live past one year of age, we cannot guarantee any other population in the state of Ohio that they are going to have a healthy life.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Ohio lawmakers hope bills save babies" href="http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2014/02/13/lawmakers-hope-bills-save-babies.html" target="_blank">Ohio lawmakers hope bills save babies</a></strong>

It isn&apos;t clear why Ohio has such a problem with infant deaths. Hopefully, these bills can lead to answers and a decrease in infant mortality.

TITLE: $7.7 million Verdict Dr. Xiao Di and Nan Qiao v. Cleveland Clinic Foundation and  Dr. Andrew Esposito Cleveland, Ohio

ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/31/2014 09:07:41 AM
-----
BODY:
This case involved negligent actions during a medical procedure that left Dr. Di, a neurosurgeon formerly employed by the Cleveland Clinic Foundation, no longer able to operate. Back on Feb. 12, 2010, Dr. Di was performing surgery when he injured his left eye. Subsequent to that work-related injury, he underwent surgery to have his eye repaired. During that procedure, a hole was torn in Dr. Di&#x2019;s iris and his left pupil was destroyed due to the negligent actions of Dr. Esposito and the Cleveland Clinic Foundation medical team. After a 2 &#xBD; week trial, the jury awarded $7.7 million for the doctor&#x2019;s pain and suffering, loss of consortium and to replace prior and future lost wages.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Health and Safety Violations Continue to Plague Ky. Nursing Homes
BASENAME: health-and-safety-violations-continue-to-plague-ky-nursing-homes
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 03/17/2014 03:41:00 PM
-----
BODY:
Errors and violations continue to endanger nursing home residents across parts of Kentucky, according to inspections made by the Kentucky Cabinet for Health and Family Services.

State inspectors discovered five violations they believed placed the residents of the Masonic Home of Louisville in &quot;immediate jeopardy&quot; last year, including improper doses of medication and failing to ensure that medication errors were corrected.

The U.S. Centers for Medicare and Medicaid services levied a $413,173 penalty on the Masonic Home, along with a $113,296 total penalty on seven other long-term care facilities in the area.

In fact, 45 of the 46 facilities in Jefferson County had at least one deficiency in 2013, according to Families for Better Care, a nonprofit advocacy group that produces an annual report card of the nation&apos;s nursing homes.

According to Families for Better Care&apos;s executive director Brian Lee, &quot;Nursing homes have a tendency to have a yo-yo [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][effect] where they clean things up for a short period of time.&quot;

In regards to the findings at the Masonic Home, Lee added, &quot;If I had a loved one in that nursing home, I&apos;d be looking for the closest door with an exit sign above it.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong>Violations costly for Louisville nursing homes</strong>

Research nursing homes thoroughly before placing a loved one in a home. Even then, family and friends need to be active in their loved one&apos;s care.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Study Further Complicates Choices on Mammography
BASENAME: study-further-complicates-choices-on-mammography
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 03/31/2014 08:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
The results of a long-term health trial which found no difference in death rates from breast cancer among women who had regular mammograms and those who did not may further confuse the actual necessary rate of these exams, according to <em>The New York Times</em>.

The annual mammogram has been promoted vociferously and continuously as an essential way to protect oneself from breast cancer for decades. But, in light of accumulating data in addition to this trial, the benefits of regular mammography may prove to be negligible for women when it leads to false positives and overtreatment.

Attitudes have been changing in terms of intensive screening for other types of cancer; the American Urological Association has loosened its prostate cancer screening guidelines for men because of the potential for unnecessary, invasive treatment that often leads to incontinence and impotence.

Patients and their doctors will face much more nuanced choices as the days of one-size-fits-all screening may be ending. Women may now face options based on each woman&apos;s risk for breast cancer and her feelings about the prospect of unnecessary treatment.

As Dr. Russell P. Harris, a professor of medicine at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, stated, &quot;The balance between benefits and harms is more and more up in the air.&quot; Read the full details here:

<a title="For Women, a More Complicated Choice on Mammograms&#xA0;" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/12/health/for-women-a-more-complicated-choice-on-mammograms.html?ref=health&amp;_r=0" target="_blank">For Women, a More Complicated Choice on Mammograms</a>

All we have heard for years is the importance of annual mammograms. Now there appears to be some disagreement on whether an annual mammogram is right for every woman. This is something all women should discuss with their gynecologists.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Jury awards $7.7 million medical malpractice award to injured neurosurgeon
BASENAME: jury-awards-7-7-million-medical-malpractice-award-to-injured-neurosurgeon
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 03/24/2014 07:46:00 AM
-----
BODY:
Crandall &amp; Pera Law Attorney Steve Crandall recently won a significant victory for his client, Dr. Xiao Di and his wife Nan Qiao, in a medical malpractice case against the Cleveland Clinic Foundation and ophthalmologist Dr. Andrew Esposito.

On March 20, after just one day of deliberations, a Cuyahoga County jury found in favor of Dr. Di, a neurosurgeon formally employed by the Cleveland Clinic Foundation, and awarded him $7.7 million.

Back on Feb. 12, 2010, Dr. Di was performing surgery when he injured his left eye. Subsequent to that work-related injury, he underwent surgery to have his eye repaired. During that procedure, a hole was torn in Dr. Di&#x2019;s iris and his left pupil was destroyed due to the negligent actions of Dr. Esposito and the Cleveland Clinic Foundation medical team.

As a result of these injuries, Dr. Di is no longer able to operate as a neurosurgeon. After a 2 &#xBD; week trial, the jury awarded $7.7 million for the doctor&#x2019;s pain and suffering, loss of consortium and to replace prior and future lost wages. The case was heard by retired Cuyahoga County Judge Patrick Kelly.

Unfortunately for Dr. Di, his time in court may not be over. He is also party to an employment case against the Cleveland Clinic Foundation, challenging his termination.

See more of our latest victories on our &quot;Verdicts &amp; Settlements&quot; page, and&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law&#xA0;for a free case evaluation</a>&#xA0;if you or a family member believe you have a medical malpractice case.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Improper Sterilization Leads to Exposure of Incurable Brain Disease
BASENAME: improper-sterilization-leads-to-exposure-of-incurable-brain-disease
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 02/19/2014 08:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
A hospital in North Carolina exposed nearly 20 patients to an incurable brain disease after failing to properly sterilize surgical equipment, according to a recent<em>&#xA0;USA Today </em>article.

Novant Health Forsyth Medical Center in Winston-Salem apologized after exposing 18 neurosurgical patients to Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD), a degenerative fatal neurological disorder, after operating on a patient later confirmed to have the disease.

While the surgical equipment had been cleaned using typical sterilization procedures, they did not receive the enhanced procedures required for CJD.

It could take years if not decades for symptoms of the disease to show up, and there is no known cure. The disease has been associated with mad cow disease, although not the particular strain involved in this case.

&quot;We recognize that the risk to the patients is very small,&quot; said Jeff Lindsay, the hospital&apos;s president. &quot;However, we take any potential exposure seriously.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="20 exposed to incurable brain disease in N.C. hospital&#xA0;" href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/02/11/creutzfeldt-jakob-exposure/5389547/" target="_blank">20 exposed to incurable brain disease in N.C. hospital</a></strong>

This is a tragic story about the lack of sterilization at a hospital affecting many people. This clear negligence may cause brain damage and wrongful death.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Rare Gene Mutation Reduces Risk of Diabetes
BASENAME: rare-gene-mutation-reduces-risk-of-diabetes
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 03/06/2014 03:04:00 PM
-----
BODY:
Doctors are researching a rare mutation so effective in preventing Type 2 diabetes that they are looking to mimic the mutation&apos;s effect in developing a new drug, according to a recent <em>New York Times</em>&#xA0;article.

The mutation destroys one copy of the gene ZnT8, which is used by pancreas cells where insulin is made, and reduces risk of Type 2 diabetes by two-thirds.

Those with the mutation seem to make slightly more insulin and have slightly lower blood glucose levels for their entire lives. Even older people with bad habits - overweight, drinking, smoking - seem to be protected from the disease when they have this mutation. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Rare Mutation Kills Off Gene Responsible for Diabetes" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/03/health/rare-gene-protects-against-type-2-diabetes-even-in-obese-people.html?ref=us&amp;_r=1" target="_blank">Rare Mutation Kills Off Gene Responsible for Diabetes</a></strong>

A huge discovery may lead a new drug to ease or even eradicate Type 2 diabetes in the future. The ramifications of this discovery are staggering.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Common Pain Reliever Linked to Risks During Pregnancy
BASENAME: common-pain-reliever-linked-to-risks-during-pregnancy
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 02/27/2014 08:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
A new study published in JAMA Pediatrics finds that using acetaminophen - the active ingredient in Tylenol and other common pain relievers - during pregnancy may not be as safe as women have been told.

According to the study, the children of women who took the drug during pregnancy were about 40% more likely to be diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder than children of mothers who took none.

The probability of a child developing ADHD symptoms severe enough to require medication increased by 63% when his or her mother took acetaminophen during the last two trimesters of pregnancy and 28% when used in the third trimester alone.

The study underscores that, even when a medication is billed as safe, the safest route is for pregnant women to take it as rarely as possible and at the lowest effective dose, said UCLA obstetrician Dr. Daniel Kahn, a maternal-fetal health specialist who was not involved in the study. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Tylenol use during pregnancy linked to ADHD in kids, study finds" href="http://www.latimes.com/science/sciencenow/la-sci-sn-tylenol-pregnancy-adhd-risk-20140224,0,2353473.story#axzz2uM9B40yQ" target="_self">Tylenol use during pregnancy linked to ADHD in kids, study finds</a></strong>

This is just another example of why pregnant women should be extremely careful about what medications they take. They should always consult their OB before taking a new medication, even if it can be bought over-the-counter.

If you or anyone in your family has suffered serious side effects or damages from a medication error you should seek legal investigation immediately.&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">Crandall &amp; Pera Law&#xA0;is&#xA0;available</a> to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Longer Childbirths May Call for Less Intervention
BASENAME: longer-childbirths-may-call-for-less-intervention
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 02/14/2014 08:32:00 AM
-----
BODY:
Doctors are being warned not to intervene as quickly as currently suggested in births that involve epidural anesthesia, according to a recent study published in Obstetrics and Gynecology.

The study found that epidurals are associated with an even longer duration in the second stage of birth, the one in which women push, than is generally recognized, suggesting that some women may be subject to unnecessary interventions - including oxytocin, forceps, vacuum or a cesarean - by doctors who wrongly fear labor has become prolonged.

A normal second stage can take as long as 5.6 hours for women who get epidurals during their first births, and as long as 3.3 hours for those who do not get epidurals, according to the study.

Current guidelines by the American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists define an abnormally long second stage of birth as more than three hours for women who received an epidural and are giving birth for the first time, and more than two hours for first births without an epidural.

&quot;It&apos;s time to re-examine what normal and abnormal is, and revise our guidelines based on modern obstetric population,&quot; said Dr. Yvonne W. Cheng, the lead author of the study. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Study Suggests Misplaced Fears in Longer Childbirths" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/06/health/childbirth-study-sees-longer-labor-as-normal.html?_r=0" target="_blank">Study Suggests Misplaced Fears in Longer Childbirths</a></strong>

A new research paper indicates lengthening the second stage of labor, the pushing phase. This may lead to longer labors and the possibility of brain damage, increases in cerebral palsy or other birth injuries. The lengthening of labor, this study believes, would not lead to such birth complications however.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Surgical Technique May Cause Abnormal Growths, Cancer
BASENAME: surgical-technique-may-cause-abnormal-growths-cancer
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 02/17/2014 08:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
Problems emerging during uterine surgeries undergone by over 50,000 women a year are increasing concerns among doctors regarding the safety of the procedure, according to recent studies in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

The procedure known as morcellation is used to either remove fibroid tumors from the uterus or to remove the entire uterus, cutting the tissue into pieces that can be pulled out through tiny incisions. The technique is part of minimally invasive surgery and used to shorten recovery time and reduce risks of blood loss, infection and other complications.

Morcellation can be performed by hand with a knife or with an electrical device with a rapidly spinning blade, the latter the cause of the most problems with the surgery. The technique can spray bits of uterine tissue or fibroids around inside the abdomen like seeds, sometimes causing pain, infection or bowel obstruction.

In a few cases, morcellation techniques have also injured abdominal organs and blood vessels and even spread hidden cancer cells through a patient&apos;s abdomen, causing advanced cancer.

About 498,000 women in the United States had hysterectomy operations to remove the uterus in 2010, about 11 percent of which involved morcellation, according to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.

While Dr. Kimberly Kho, one of the study&apos;s authors, does not think the technique should be banned altogether, she does think doctors &quot;...could be more prudent and conservative with whom we use these instruments on and more systematic about preoperative evaluation to prevent morcellating detectable cancers.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Surgical Technique Is Linked to Abnormal Growths and Cancer" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/07/health/uterine-surgical-technique-is-linked-to-abnormal-growths-and-cancer-spread.html?_r=0" target="_blank">Surgical Technique Is Linked to Abnormal Growths and Cancer</a></strong>

An important article for any women who is contemplating or has had removal of uterine fibroids. A power tool and common procedure which employs this tool can lead to severe complications and cancer as a result.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Inadequate Care for Nursing Home Residents Pose Safety Concern
BASENAME: inadequate-care-for-nursing-home-residents-pose-safety-concern
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 02/18/2014 08:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
An Ohio nursing home with a history of taking on high-need patients is facing imminent shutdown after it was found, among other violations, to not be able to meet the needs of every resident, according to a recent article in <em>The Columbus Dispatch.</em>

Among the 130 people currently living at Carlton Manor in Fayette County, 27 are registered sex offenders. Diagnoses for high-need residents include schizophrenia, explosive personality disorder, traumatic brain injury, bipolar disorder, alcoholism, habitual cocaine use and suicidal.

As the state looks for new homes for the residents, it rekindles a debate over how to best achieve high-quality care for residents with violent backgrounds.

In Ohio, there is no special licensing or designation for nursing homes that care for violent residents, mentally ill patients or ex-cons. To keep its operating license, however, a nursing home must prove that it has the proper care plans and properly trained employees to handle every resident.

&quot;If a nursing home like Carlton Manor chooses to take on mental-health patients or criminal offenders, they can&apos;t say, &apos;We&apos;ll meet most of their needs,&apos; or &apos;We&apos;ll meet their needs on average.&apos; It has to meet the needs of every single resident,&quot; said Beverly Laubert, the Ohio Department of Aging&apos;s long-term-care ombudsman. &quot;And at Carlton Manor, that wasn&apos;t done.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Are nursing homes high-need residents at high risk?&#xA0;" href="http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2014/01/26/high-need-residents-high-risk.html" target="_blank">Are nursing homes high-need residents at high risk?</a></strong>

Nursing home negligence, neglect and even punitive conduct unfortunately occurs daily in the U.S. Many loved ones are unfortunately injured in nursing homes.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: New Infection Preventatives Address Doctors&apos; Attire
BASENAME: new-infection-preventatives-address-doctors-attire
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 02/12/2014 10:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
A new call to prevent and control infections in the medical workplace may mean an end to the doctor&apos;s white coat, according to a recent article in <em>The New York Times.&#xA0;</em>

The Society for Healthcare Epidemiology of America has issued guidance on what healthcare workers should wear outside of the operating room, suggesting hospitals to adopt a &quot;bare below the elbows&quot; policy that includes short sleeves and no wristwatch, jewelry or neckties during contact with patients in order to minimize infection risk.

The group also recommends that if the use of white coats is not entirely abandoned, each doctor should have at least two, worn alternately and laundered frequently, that they are encouraged to remove before approaching patients.

These recommendations, which are based on the biological plausibility of transmitting infection through clothing, are being suggested in addition methods already proven to reduce infection, including hand washing, bathing patients with antibacterial soap, and checklists for inserting intravenous lines.

&quot;Apparel should come next in level of concern,&quot; sad Dr. Gonzalo Bearman, a professor of medicine at Virginia Commonwealth University. &quot;The more patients are aware that apparel may impact hospital infections, the more doctors will consider how clean they are.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Goodbye to the Doctor&apos;s White Coat?" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/01/27/goodbye-to-the-doctors-white-coat/?ref=health" target="_blank">Goodbye to the Doctor&apos;s White Coat?</a></strong>

The &quot;white coat&quot; is a well known term for physicians given they usually wear one, especially in hospitals around the very sick. However, it has been unrecognized until recently these white coats may also carry and make infections worse through bacteria caught up in the fibers of the white coats.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Medical Costs Burden One in Four American Families
BASENAME: medical-costs-burden-one-in-four-american-families
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 02/10/2014 12:00:00 PM
-----
BODY:
Medical bills provided a financial burden for more than one out of four American families - 26.8 percent - in 2012, according to new data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Nearly 9 percent of families currently cannot make their medical bill payments, with a total of 16.5 percent facing financial issues stemming from medical costs in 2012. More than one-fifth of the 43,345 families surveyed were still paying off a medical bill that had been split into payments over time.

Not having health insurance was a big factor in not being able to pay off bills, but around one-fifth of the adults surveyed who had full insurance coverage still said it was difficult to pay bills.

&quot;Unpaid medical bills is the number one reason why families declare personal bankruptcy,&quot; said Karen Pollitz, a fellow at the Kaiser Family Foundation. &quot;It causes people to lose equity in their homes, to endanger their retirement and their kid&apos;s college education. It will destroy a family financially.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="More than one-fourth of American families faced financial burden due to medical costs" href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/more-than-one-fourth-of-american-families-faced-financial-burden-due-to-medical-costs/" target="_blank">More than one-fourth of American families faced financial burden due to medical costs</a></strong>

The costs of healthcare are staggering and often cause financial hardship and even bankruptcy for many US families. If individuals are not properly insured medically, or with disability insurance, a major injury or illness may wipe out whatever savings and ability to pay for daily items very quickly.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Lack of Vitamin D May Increase Risk of Preeclampsia
BASENAME: lack-of-vitamin-d-may-increase-risk-of-preeclampsia
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 02/11/2014 12:00:00 PM
-----
BODY:
Researchers have found that low vitamin D levels are associated with an increased risk for severe preeclampsia, a serious and sometimes fatal disorder of pregnancy, according to a recent article in <em>The New York Times</em>.

Characteristics of preeclampsia include high blood pressure and excess protein in the urine.

Using over 3,700 blood samples of women at an average of 21 weeks gestation, researchers found that 717 had mild of severe preeclampsia. Women with vitamin D levels higher than 50 had a 40 percent reduction in relative risk for severe preeclampsia compared with those with levels under 50. There was no association of vitamin D level with mild preeclampsia.

&quot;Severe preeclampsia is rare,&quot; said Lisa M. Bodnar, an associate professor of epidemiology at the University of Pittsburgh. &quot;And we can&apos;t determine whether low vitamin D causes it. Women should not run out to the drugstore and buy vitamin D supplements. If you&apos;re concerned, you should talk to your health care provider and continue to take your prenatal vitamins.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Low Vitamin D Tied to a Pregnancy Risk&#xA0;" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/01/30/low-vitamin-d-tied-to-a-pregnancy-risk/?_php=true&amp;_type=blogs&amp;ref=health&amp;_r=0" target="_blank">Low Vitamin D Tied to a Pregnancy Risk</a></strong>

An alarming association between a lack of vitamin D and severe complications for mom and baby have been found. This underscores the need for good prenatal care and the use of prenatal vitamins, along with eating right.
