TITLE: New Cholesterol Guidelines Spark Debate, Add to Patient Confusion
BASENAME: new-cholesterol-guidelines-spark-debate-add-to-patient-confusion
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 02/07/2014 09:36:00 AM
-----
BODY:
New cholesterol guidelines released by the American Heart Association and the American College of Cardiology may result in millions of people being unnecessarily given statins to prevent heart attacks and strokes, according to a recent article in <em>The Boston Globe</em>.

The treatment recommendations released by the two heart organizations have come under fierce criticism for overestimating the number of people predicted to have a 10-year risk or having a heart attack or stroke by 75 to 150 percent.

The treatment guide urges physicians to prescribe statins for patients between ages 40 and 75 whose 10-year-risk is 7.5 percent or greater.

&quot;It is possible that as many as 40 to 50 percent of the 33 million middle-aged Americans targeted by the new guidelines for statin therapy do not actually have risk thresholds exceeding the 7.5 percent level suggested for treatment,&quot; Dr. Paul Ridker and Nancy Cook, two heart researchers at the Brigham and Women&apos;s hospital, wrote in their commentary on the guidelines. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="New cholesterol guideline called inaccurate by top Boston heart researchers" href="http://www.boston.com/lifestyle/health/blogs/daily-dose/2013/11/18/new-cholesterol-guideline-called-inaccurate-top-boston-heart-doctors/xayiGfGPTASIsSAZyOyGWP/blog.html" target="_blank">New cholesterol guideline called inaccurate by top Boston heart researchers</a></strong>

New guidelines exist for the maintenance of cholesterol and other cardiac lab studies with medications. However, some cardiologist believe these guidelines are flawed. This only serves to confuse the issue for patients seeking to improve their health and lifestyle.

TITLE: IV Fluid Shortage Hits Nationwide
BASENAME: iv-fluid-shortage-hits-nationwide
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 02/05/2014 10:20:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>A nationwide shortage of the intravenous solutions used to help rehydrate patients who are sick and help treat other conditions is concerning many health professionals, according to <em>CBS News</em>.</strong>

Millions of bags of IV solution are used each week, and increased used by hospitals - potentially from this year&apos;s flu season - have led to a lack of supplies, according to the Food and Drug Administration.

As of Jan. 17, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said 40 states reported widespread flu virus infection. Though they don&apos;t track adult flu deaths, 20 children have died this season so far.

The shortage is causing the IV solutions to go for a much higher price; USA Today reports that a bag that would usually cost $1 to $1.25 is now going for five or six times the price.

Dozens of hospitals began reporting they were running out of IV fluids in mid-January, according to Valerie Jensen, associate director of the drug shortages program at the FDA. &quot;We know that hospitals are still reporting that they may only have a few days supply.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="U.S. facing concerning shortage of IV fluids" href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/nation-facing-dangerous-shortage-of-iv-fluids/" target="_blank">U.S. facing concerning shortage of IV fluids</a></strong>

IV solutions are commonly used and many times taken for granted. However, it appears manufacturing of a commonly used IV fluid is not able to keep up with the patient demands. &#xA0; This may be very serious if not fixed quickly and properly.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Unsafe Commercial Truck Equipment Not Controlled
BASENAME: unsafe-commercial-truck-equipment-not-controlled
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 02/06/2014 09:17:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Rear safety bars on semi-trailers are supposed to save your life, but WBNS-10TV in Columbus has found they are often too weak, corroded or bent to work effectively on many trucks throughout Ohio.&#xA0;</strong>

The guards are designed to keep a car from sliding underneath trailers in the event of a rear end impact at speeds of up to 30-35 miles per hour. But when they fail, the consequences can be catastrophic.

One of the main reasons these damaged bars are still on the road is a lack of enforcement; drivers and the owners of the semi-trucks they drive do not pay fines as a direct result of damages bars.

If the Ohio State Highway Patrol spots and notes a violation, the information is forwarded to the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio (PUCO). Of 170 violations submitted to the PUCO in the past three years, none have directly resulted in a fine. PUCO only fines truck companies if their overall safety rating falls below a certain standard.

&quot;It seems like they&apos;re not taking care of that part of the truck,&quot; said semi driver Lester Marriott. &quot;And that&apos;s important because in a collision, that keeps a car from going under.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="10 Investigates: Drivers Don&apos;t Face Fines For Damaged Under-Ride Bars" href="http://www.10tv.com/content/stories/2014/02/03/columbus-underride-guards-investigation-part2-11pm.html" target="_blank">10 Investigates: Drivers Don&apos;t Face Fines For Damaged Under-Ride Bars</a></strong>

This article demonstrates that safety isn&#x2019;t always a trucking company&#x2019;s primary goal. Without a financial threat, it is unlikely any companies will take the time to inspect and fix these safety defects.

TITLE: G.M. Defect Death Toll on the Rise

ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 06/18/2014 08:09:00 AM
-----
BODY:
The 13 acknowledged fatalities linked to defective ignition switches in General Motors cars may only be the beginning of the true death toll caused by the automaker, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

The faulty switch can cause a sudden loss of engine power and deactivate air bags in Chevrolet Cobalts, Saturn Ions and other small cars. G.M. began recalling 2.6 million cars only after 13 deaths and 32 accidents tied to this defect, even though the automaker knew of the problem as early as 2001.

G.M. has now recalled more than 13.5 million vehicles nationwide this year, as compared to nearly 758,000 recalls in 2013.

&quot;G.M. would be in the position to determine additional cases related directly to this defect based on lawsuits, incident claims and additional data reported directly to the automaker from its customers, dealerships, insurance companies, safety groups and other sources,&quot; said David Friedman, the acting chief of the N.H.T.S.A. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Agency Expects More Deaths From G.M.&apos;s Ignition Flaw" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/24/business/agency-expects-more-deaths-from-gms-ignition-flaw.html?_r=1" target="_blank">Agency Expects More Deaths From G.M.&apos;s Ignition Flaw</a></strong>

G.M. continues to exhibit a disturbing disregard for the rights and safety of the public as the clear product liability issue continues to see a rise in the death toll. Even if&#xA0;G.M. and Chevrolet are now showing remorse for the deaths of individuals who&#xA0;purchased cars with faulty ignition switches, the reality is, without&#xA0;personal injury lawyers who refused to give up this issue, none of this&#xA0;would have ever come to light.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Concerns About Testosterone&apos;s Effect on Heart Rise
BASENAME: concerns-about-testosterones-effect-on-heart-rise
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 02/03/2014 12:58:00 PM
-----
BODY:
A link between prescription testosterone and a potential increase in the risk of heart attacks has medical experts calling for more extensive warning labels on the drugs, according to a recent <em>New York Times </em>article.

A new study funded by the National Institutes of Health tracked about 56,000 older and middle-aged men around the country who were prescribed testosterone. Men 65 and older had double the rate of heart attacks in the months after starting the drug, as did those younger than 65 with a previous diagnosis of heart disease. There was no evidence of greater risk in the younger men without a history of heart problems.

Testosterone gels, patches, pellets and injections are widely marketed for symptoms of &quot;low T,&quot; including fatigue, low libido and loss of energy.

In November, a study in The Journal of the American Medical Association found that older men, many with a history of heart disease, had a nearly 30 percent increase in mortality, heart attacks and stroke after using testosterone. In 2009, a federally financed study intended to test whether testosterone gel could help elderly men build muscle and strength was halted early because of heart attacks and other cardiac problems in men using the drug.

Still, the drugs carry no mention of an increased risk on their labels or in advertising materials. Said Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, a senior adviser to the Washington advocacy group Public Citizen, &quot;Given that there have been several studies now, I don&apos;t see how the Food and Drug Administration can justify having no warnings of heart attacks at all.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="New Concern About Testosterone and Heart Risks" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/01/29/study-adds-to-concern-about-cardiac-risks-for-older-men-taking-testosterone/?_php=true&amp;_type=blogs&amp;_php=true&amp;_type=blogs&amp;_r=1&amp;" target="_blank">New Concern About Testosterone and Heart Risks</a></strong>

Sometimes using prescriptions which would seem to help can also cause an increased risk of life threatening events to occur. To any man contemplating the use of testosterone, a stark warning has been issued.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Prenatal Antidepressants May Increase Lung Problems in Babies
BASENAME: prenatal-antidepressants-may-increase-lung-problems-in-babies
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 01/30/2014 08:30:00 AM
-----
BODY:
Antidepressants taken during pregnancy, especially after 33 weeks, may increase the risk for both immediate and long-term lung problems in babies, according to a recent <em>CBS News</em>&#xA0;article.

The breathing problems, called persistent pulmonary hypertension, occur when high blood pressure in the lungs prevents oxygen from moving to the lungs through the rest of the body. Symptoms include rapid breathing, rapid heart rate, difficulty breathing and a blue tint to the skin.

Canadian researchers pulled seven studies that looked at breathing difficulties in newborns associated with antidepressant use. The studies that met the researchers&apos; criteria looked at selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors antidepressants, or SSRIs, a commonly-prescribed class of the medication which includes drugs like Lexapro, Prozac, Zoloft and Paxil.

Researchers estimate the overall risk may still remain low, occurring in about 2.9 to 3.5 births per 1,000, but this might be the very first review looking at this breathing risk in children of antidepressant-takers.

&quot;Decisions on treatment needs to be personalized,&quot; said study author Dr. Sophie Grigoriadis. &quot;Women need to make informed decisions by taking in all the risks of depression and its treatments.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Antidepressants during pregnancy may raise risk for lung problems in babies" href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/antidepressants-during-pregnancy-may-raise-risk-for-lung-problems-in-babies/" target="_blank">Antidepressants during pregnancy may raise risk for lung problems in babies</a></strong>

Women who are taking anti-depressants, and are pregnant or considering having children, should read this article.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: U.S. C-Sections 3x the Recommended Rate
BASENAME: u-s-c-sections-3x-the-recommended-rate
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/30/2014 10:54:00 AM
-----
BODY:
A recent lawsuit filed by a woman accusing her doctor of forcing a C-section brings light to the fact that the U.S. performs more than three times the recommended rate of surgical births, according to <em>The New York Times</em>.

Although the patient in question wanted to give birth naturally, her doctor pressured her to have a C-section, even allegedly going so far as to tell her that she would be committing the equivalent of child abuse without one and that her baby would be taken away from her.

This lawsuit is part of the debate over the use of C-sections and the rights of pregnant women to control their own bodies. Nearly 33 percent of U.S. births - almost 1.3 million - were by cesarean section in 2012, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The World Health Organization recommends that the rate should not be higher than 10 to 15 percent.

The increase in the number of C-sections has been attributed to a rise in high-risk pregnancies; a desire by doctors and mothers to schedule their deliveries; and fears of malpractice lawsuits should the baby be injured during a normal delivery, which typically takes far longer than a cesarean.

&quot;In my worldview, the right to refuse is uncircumscribed,&quot; said Dr. Howard Minkoff, chairman of obstetrics at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. &quot;I don&apos;t have a right to put a knife in your belly ever.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Mother Accuses Doctors of Forcing a C-Section and Files Suit" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/17/nyregion/mother-accuses-doctors-of-forcing-a-c-section-and-files-suit.html?ref=health&amp;_r=0" target="_blank">Mother Accuses Doctors of Forcing a C-Section and Files Suit</a></strong>

The issue of patient choice, particularly in a woman&apos;s ability to choose her preferred method delivering her child, is a sensitive matter. While physicians must always consider what is medically best for a patient, they cannot force care upon someone.

Further investigation into the allegations of Department of Veterans Affairs administrators manipulating waiting lists at its Phoenix medical center show that 1,700 patients never received care, according to&#xA0;<em>The New York Times</em>.

The average waiting time for initial primary care appointments at the Phoenix VA medical center - 115 days - was nearly five times as long as what the hospital&apos;s administrators had reported. Irregularities in how the 1,700 veterans were handled mean that &quot;these veterans may never obtain a requested or required clinical appointment,&quot; according to the acting inspector general&apos;s report.

The inspector general also reported that the falsified data may have led to more favorable performance reviews for hospital personnel and that some instances of potentially manipulated data had been turned over to the Justice Department.

Similar kinds of manipulation to hide long and possibly growing waiting times are &quot;systemic throughout&quot; the VA health care system&apos;s 150 medical centers serving 8 million veterans each year. AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Medicaid Patients in Poorer Health, Cost More
BASENAME: medicaid-patients-in-poorer-health-cost-more
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/29/2014 10:40:00 AM
-----
BODY:
Medicaid patients experience more surgical complications and cost more than patients with private insurance, according to a recent study in the journal <em>JAMA Surgery</em>.

Of nearly 14,000 patients studied, Medicaid patients were twice as likely to smoke and had higher rates of conditions that made surgery riskier, even though they were generally younger than the privately insured patients. The unhealthy conditions included diabetes, lung disease and blood vessel blockage.

Medicaid patients had more emergency operations and used 50 percent more hospital resources than patients with private insurance. Medicaid patients were also found to typically need extra time in the hospital - three days on average - and were more likely to return after going home from surgery.

Most importantly, Medicaid patients had two-thirds more complications in the month after their operations and were more than twice as likely to die, compared with those on private insurance.

&quot;We supported the expansion of Medicaid because it means that we can get patients into medical care and get them into optimum shape for an operation,&quot; said Dr. Darrell A. Campbell Jr., chief medical officer of the University of Michigan Health System. &quot;Being a heavy smoker predisposes you to get pneumonia after an operation. For a diabetic, if blood sugar is out of control, that increases the chances of a wound infection after surgery. If we can address these issues preoperatively, we can cut down the problems we see after an operation.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Poorer Health of Surgery patients on Medicaid May Alter Law&apos;s Bottom Line" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/18/us/poorer-health-of-surgery-patients-on-medicaid-may-alter-laws-bottom-line.html?ref=health&amp;_r=0" target="_blank">Poorer Health of Surgery patients on Medicaid May Alter Law&apos;s Bottom Line</a></strong>

Not surprisingly, Medicaid patients have been found to be in poorer health than those who have private insurance. The ramifications of this reality will continue to add stress and additional cost to the health industry, hospitals and individual physicians who provide care for low government reimbursements.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Cervical Cancer Risk Much Higher for Women 65+
BASENAME: cervical-cancer-risk-much-higher-for-women-65
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/23/2014 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
Cervical cancer may affect many more women over age 65 than previously believed, which could drastically affect current medical guidelines, according to a recent <em>NBC News</em>&#xA0;article.

A rare but very deadly disease, cervical cancer is diagnosed in 12,000 U.S. women every year and kills 4,000. Many women over the age of 65 believe they no longer need gynecological exams, but a recent study shows that the rate of risk for cervical cancer for this age group is actually 83 percent higher than previously thought.

The problem lies in the fact that current guidelines do not take into account the high rate of hysterectomy in the U.S. Even though 20 percent of U.S. adult women cannot get cervical cancer because they have had a hysterectomy, they are still included in risk calculations, skewing the data. The actual rate of cervical cancer is almost 25 women per 100,000 women aged 65 to 69.

The United States Preventive Services Task Force and the American Cancer Society currently recommend against routine yearly testing, recommending instead that women aged 21 to 65 get either a Pap smear or a test for HPV every three years. Women over 65 who have had three &quot;clear&quot; screens in a row are told they don&apos;t need the test any more.

&quot;We traditionally thought that the higher risk was among middle-aged women,&quot; said Anne Rositch, an assistant professor of epidemiology and public heath at the University of Maryland School of Medicine. &quot;But when we redid the data we found that the rate of cervical cancer continued to increase up to the ages of 65-69.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Older Women May Face Higher Risk of Cervical Cancer" href="http://www.nbcnews.com/health/womens-health/older-women-may-face-higher-risk-cervical-cancer-n101841" target="_blank">Older Women May Face Higher Risk of Cervical Cancer</a></strong>

Don&#x2019;t stop getting PAP smears after menopause.

The Kentucky State Police is aiming to keep the state&apos;s roadways safer by cracking down on one of the leading causes of semi-truck and commercial vehicle accidents: brake failure.

The KSP Commercial Vehicle Enforcement division conducted 95 inspections and issued 130 citations in a 24-hour nationwide inspection campaign earlier this month.

&quot;About 50 percent of the ones we found are brake related, usually with brake pads wearing too thin,&quot; said SP officer Harold Mosley. &quot;With commercial vehicles, they have to adjust their brakes, if they don&apos;t adjust them they can be rendered completely inoperative and not work at all.&quot;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Virtual House Calls: The Future of Medicine?
BASENAME: virtual-house-calls-the-future-of-medicine
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/22/2014 08:33:00 AM
-----
BODY:
As technology continues to advance, the current practice of the virtual house call may be the future of doctor-patient relationships, according to a recent article on Boston.com.

Communicating with patients via webcam is increasingly getting attention as a way to conveniently diagnose simple maladies, such as the cold or flu. One smartphone app lets consumers connect to a doctor for $49 a visit.

Some are calling this the future of medicine, but some states still restrict the kind of care and prescribing available via telemedicine, especially since doctors who practice by video-chat must be licensed in whatever states their long-distance patients live. While Medicare currently covers some forms of telehealth, it typically does not pay for in-home video exams.

There are other questions as well, including how to avoid overprescribing antibiotics.

Despite these hurdles, patient groups and technology advocates are pushing to expand the digital are to people with complex chronic diseases that make a doctor&apos;s trip more than just an inconvenience.

&quot;Think of taking your mom with Alzheimer&apos;s to a big urban medical center,&quot; said Dr. Ray Dorsey, a neurologist at the University&#xA0;of Rochester Medical Center. &quot;Just getting through the parking lot they&apos;re disoriented. That&apos;s the standard of care but is it what we should be doing?&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong>The Doctor Will See You Now Via Webcam</strong>

Healthcare is constantly evolving. What was standard of care five years ago is often outdated today.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Police Crack Down on Commercial Truck Accidents
BASENAME: police-crack-down-on-commercial-truck-accidents
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/08/2014 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
Police in Ohio and Pennsylvania are teaming up throughout the summer to help prevent highway crashes involving commercial trucks, according to Youngstown&apos;s WKBN 27.

The joint effort of the Ohio State Highway Patrol and Pennsylvania State Police Commercial Enforcement sections will be to increase awareness, enforce and inspect commercial vehicles committing crash-causing violations, such as following too closely and unsafe speed.

The target enforcement area along Interstate 80 will allow the two agencies to communicate across the state line about potentially dangerous trucks. They will also coordinate target safety enforcement times and random safety inspections.

In addition to overweight loads and speeding, higher-level inspections will look deeper for hidden problems, including mechanical failure or brake wear.

&quot;If they&apos;re not obeying the traffic laws, they can cause serious damage if they happen to crash,&quot; said Cpl. James R. Willochell, Pennsylvania State Police. &quot;We are out here for their safety and the motoring safety.&quot; Read the full story here:

<strong>Ohio, Pa. police targeting commercial crash-causing violations&#xA0;</strong>

If you feel that unsafe driving factors exhibited by truck drivers led to a major accident which impacted your family&#x2019;s life,&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">please contact the experienced attorneys of Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a>.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: VA Hospitals Delay Treatment, Endanger Veterans
BASENAME: va-hospitals-delay-treatment-endanger-veterans
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/06/2014 10:46:00 AM
-----
BODY:
Some Veteran Affairs clinics have been found to falsify records amid allegations that dozens of patients have died because of delays in medical treatments, according to a recent <em>USA Today </em>article.

Clerks at the Department of Veterans Affairs clinic in Fort Collins, Colorado were instructed to falsify appointment records so it appeared the small staff of doctors was seeing patients within the agency&apos;s goal of 14 days, according to the VA investigation. In reality, many of the 6,300 veterans treated at the outpatient clinic waited months to be seen.

Department officials revealed last month that 23 deaths of veterans were linked to delay cancer screenings dating back four years. A retired doctor recently alleged that 40 other veterans died at a VA hospital in Phoenix due to treatment delays.

Of the 9 million veterans the VA treats a year, the agency found that only 41% are seen within 14 days, down from 90% reported in 2012 under an old, now-abandoned measurement method. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="VA treatment records falsified, probe finds" href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/05/04/va-healthcare-delays-treatment-phoenix-cheyenne-deaths/8602117/" target="_blank">VA treatment records falsified, probe finds</a></strong>

The VA is supposed to take care of our soldiers medically, but they are&#xA0;not. In addition, when investigators begin looking into why, the VA is allegedly&#xA0;making it difficult to get to the bottom of how to take care&#xA0;of our armed forces.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Children in Ky. Top U.S. ADHD Diagnoses
BASENAME: children-in-ky-top-u-s-adhd-diagnoses
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/07/2014 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder diagnoses are increasingly rampant among children in the state of Kentucky, nearly double the national average, according to a recent article in <em>The Courier-Journal</em>.

The latest statistics from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show 19 percent of Kentucky children ages 4-17 have been diagnosed with ADHD at some point, the highest state percentage in the nation. The national average is 11 percent.

ADHD levels have risen steeply in the past decade nationwide, with 6 million children diagnosed at some point in their lives.

The reason for the increase in diagnoses is unclear. Some say overworked primary care doctors who aren&apos;t experts in the disorder may be over-diagnosing - and possibly over-prescribing - both locally and nationwide. Others theorize the numbers in Kentucky could be linked to rampant poverty or that children statewide may be genetically prone to the disorder.

&quot;We&apos;re probably over-diagnosing it to a certain extent,&quot; said Dr. Christopher Peters, a psychiatrist and assistant professor in the University of Louisville&apos;s pediatrics department. &quot;But these numbers indicate a problem. There are many kids in need.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Kentucky tops U.S. for ADHD" href="http://www.courier-journal.com/story/life/wellness/health/2014/05/02/kentucky-tops-us-adhd/8564911/" target="_blank">Kentucky tops U.S. for ADHD</a>&#xA0;</strong>

If your child suffers from ADHD, you should read this article.

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Guardians of Nursing Home Residents Denied Constitutional Right
BASENAME: guardians-of-nursing-home-residents-denied-constitutional-right
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/02/2014 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
The Kentucky Court of Appeals has unfortunately given guardians of nursing home residents the power to bind the resident to arbitration and deprive them of their constitutional right to a jury trial.

An overview of the related case, <a title="LP Pikeville LLC, v. Wright" href="http://162.114.92.72/COA/2013-CA-000959.pdf#xml=http://162.114.92.72/dtsearch.asp?cmd=pdfhits&amp;DocId=26198&amp;Index=D%3a%5cInetpub%5cwwwroot%5cindices%5cCourt%5fof%5fAppeals%5fIndex&amp;HitCount=12&amp;hits=7a+b7+c0+112+12d+19b+1f1+239+58f+70b+801+826+&amp;hc=2892&amp;req=wright" target="_blank">LP Pikeville LLC, v. Wright</a>, is as follows:
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><em>The Defendant Ginger Wright was appointed legal guardian for Mable Damron.&#xA0; Three years later, Damron became a resident of a long-term care facility (the &#x201C;Facility&#x201D;).&#xA0; As guardian, Wright executed all admission documents on Damron&#x2019;s behalf, including an optional agreement requiring the parties to the contract to arbitrate any disputes or claims against the Facility or its related entities.&#xA0; The arbitration agreement explicitly stated that the parties understood they were waiving their constitutional right to a jury trial.&#xA0;</em></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><em>Wright subsequently filed a complaint for medical malpractice, negligence, corporate negligence, and violations of statutory duties against the Facility and various affiliated companies.&#xA0; The Defendants filed a motion to dismiss or, in the alternative, to stay the action and compel arbitration as provided by the agreement.&#xA0; Wright responded that the agreement was unenforceable on several grounds, including that she lacked the authority to execute any agreement which waived Damron&#x2019;s right to a jury trial.&#xA0; The trial court agreed, asserting that a guardian does not have the authority to waive her ward&#x2019;s right to trial by jury.&#xA0;</em></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><em>The Court of Appeals reversed, holding that a court-appointed guardian has the authority to execute an arbitration agreement with a nursing home on behalf of her ward.&#xA0; It explained that the &#x201C;best interests&#x201D; of the ward in this situation must be informed by the legislative policies expressed in the federal and state arbitration acts. Wright did not waive Damron&#x2019;s right to bring claims against the Facility and related entities&#x2014;she only specified a forum where those claims must be argued.&#xA0; Accordingly, the Court of Appeals reversed the trial court&#x2019;s order. &#xA0;</em><strong>&#xA0;</strong></p>
Crandall &amp; Pera Law recommends that when offered binding arbitration during the admission process, just say no thanks. In order for the arbitration agreement to be enforceable, it must be an OPTION, not a requirement for admission. Again, just say no.

If you or someone you love has been injured due to nursing home abuse or negligence,&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">call the professionals at Crandall &amp; Pera Law for a free case evaluation</a>.&#xA0;Crandall &amp; Pera Law is&#xA0;available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Many Americans Refuse Health Insurance
BASENAME: many-americans-refuse-health-insurance
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/28/2014 11:48:00 AM
-----
BODY:
Eight million people signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act&apos;s six-month enrollment period, but many Americans remain voluntarily uninsured, according to a recent article in <em>The New York Times.</em>

Cost is a major factor for people who have decided to stay uninsured despite the law&apos;s requirement that most Americans get coverage this year or pay an income tax penalty of $95 or more.

Many people either do not qualify for federal subsidies or believe that the assistance is not enough to make insurance affordable, according to experts. Other facts for not enrolling include objections to the government&apos;s requiring it and feelings by some people that they simply do not need it.

People who have gone without health insurance or major illness for years can be especially resistant to investing in coverage, according to enrollment counselors. These people represent the next challenge for the Obama administration as it struggles to reduce the ranks of the uninsured and broaden support for the president&apos;s signature health care law. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Looking at Costs and Risks, Many Skip Health Insurance" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/22/us/looking-at-costs-and-risks-many-skip-health-insurance.html?_r=0" target="_blank">Looking at Costs and Risks, Many Skip Health Insurance</a></strong>

Despite Healthcare Reform, many Americans voluntarily choose to forgo health&#xA0;insurance. &#xA0; The lack of coverage for many Americans, as well as the costs&#xA0;associated with the uncovered, are straining the healthcare system and&#xA0;the debt of our country.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Healthcare Costs May Increase as Doctors Shift to Salaried Jobs
BASENAME: healthcare-costs-may-increase-as-doctors-shift-to-salaried-jobs
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/01/2014 01:19:00 PM
-----
BODY:
Primary care physicians and specialists&#xA0;worried about changes in the health care market are streaming into salaried jobs with hospitals, almost certainly causing more expensive heathcare in the short run, according to <em>The New York Times</em>.

While health economists agree the U.S. should move away from the traditional system of fee-for-service payments, where private positions are paid for each procedure and test, the change from private practice to salaried jobs may not yield better or cheaper care for patients. The current system drives up the nation&apos;s $2.7 trillion health care bill by rewarding overuse.

Many doctors on salary are offered bonuses tied to how much billing they generate, which could encourage physicians to order more X-rays and tests, according to Mark E. Smith, president of Merritt Hawkins, one of the nation&apos;s leading physician placement firms. Tests formerly performed in a private office may now also cost far more because of an additional hospital &quot;facility fee&quot; that is tacked on.

Today, about 60 percent of family doctors and pediatricians, 50 percent of surgeons and 25 percent of surgical subspecialists &#x2014; such as ophthalmologists and ear, nose and throat surgeons &#x2014; are employees rather than independent, according to the American Medical Association.

&quot;From the hospital end there&apos;s a big feeding frenzy, a lot of bidding going on to bring in doctors,&quot; said Robert Mechanic, an economist who studies health care at Brandeis University. &quot;And physicians are going in so they don&apos;t have to worry - there&apos;s a lot of uncertainty about how health reform is going to play out.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Apprehensive, Many Doctors Shift to Jobs With Salaries&#xA0;" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/14/us/salaried-doctors-may-not-lead-to-cheaper-health-care.html?ref=health" target="_blank">Apprehensive, Many Doctors Shift to Jobs With Salaries</a></strong>

Many people assume the doctors they see at the hospital are employees of that hospital. This was usually not the case, but now is becoming more and more common. In the next five years, most doctors will be employed by hospitals. Whether this is good for patient care or the cost of that care remains to be seen.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Stroke Survivors Driving Without Formal Evaluation
BASENAME: stroke-survivors-driving-without-formal-evaluation
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/18/2014 11:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Stroke survivors often resume driving without being formally evaluated, even after their&#xA0;ability to speak, think, see and control the body has been affected,&#xA0;according to new research presented at the&#xA0;American Stroke Association&apos;s International Stroke Conference.</strong>

Fewer than 6 percent of stroke survivors said they received a formal driving evaluation in the new survey, yet more than 51 percent returned to driving, many of them a month after suffering a stroke. Of those who took to the road, 31 percent reported that their strokes had &quot;some effect&quot; on basic activities of daily living, such as feeding, bathing and dressing oneself. Eleven percent reported the stroke had &quot;great effect.&quot;

&quot;Given the severity of stroke for some of these patients, it really surprised me that they would actually be able to get behind the wheel,&quot; said Dr. Shelly Ozark, a professor of neurology at the Medical University of South Carolina.&#xA0;&quot;There basically isn&apos;t anything on the books in the majority of states that demands people get retested in their driving abilities following a major health event such as stroke.&quot; Read the full details here:

<a title="Stroke Survivors Getting Behind the Wheel Without Evaluation" href="http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/stroke-survivors-getting-behind-wheel-without-evaluation-n29626" target="_blank"><strong>Stroke Survivors Getting Behind the Wheel Without Evaluation</strong></a>

It is frightening to think that stroke survivors who have difficulties with activities of daily living, such as feeding or bathing, are permitted to get behind the wheel of a car without an evaluation to determine whether they can safely drive.

America&apos;s prescription drug epidemic reaches deep into the medical community, producing enormous risks not only for the individuals, but the patients who trust in their care, according to a recent <em>USA Today</em>&#xA0;article.

More than 100,000 doctors, nurses, and other health professionals nationwide currently struggle with abuse or addiction, mostly involving narcotics such as oxycodone and fentanyl.

For every worst-case scenario - including three hepatitis outbreaks since 2009 caused by a health care worker using patients&apos; syringes - there are countless more practitioners whose drug-related errors are more isolated. &quot;Much of the damage goes unnoticed or undocumented; oversight mechanisms to detect, report and address drug problems in health care settings are haphazard and limited,&quot; states the article.

&quot;The medical community thinks it&apos;s immune from this disease, but that&apos;s not true,&quot; said Anita Bertrand, a Houston nurse anesthetist who became addicted to pain medication following an abdominal surgery. &quot;There are so many practitioners working impaired and we have no idea. ...We&apos;re doing a terrible job addressing this problem.&quot; Read the full story here:

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Promising Blood Pressure Treatment Fails
BASENAME: promising-blood-pressure-treatment-fails
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/16/2014 03:47:00 PM
-----
BODY:
A once promising treatment for severe high blood pressure has proven&#xA0;ineffective in a recent study published in <em>The New England Journal of Medicine.&#xA0;</em>

In the United States, 67 million people have high blood pressure. The treatment, called renal denervation, involves threading a tube through blood vessels into the renal arteries and zapping them with radio-frequency energy.

Although previous case reports and studies found astounding drops in blood pressure through renal denervation, the latest study on the treatment shows no significant difference in drops in blood pressure between a group who received the treatment and a group who only thought they were receiving it.

&quot;I think many people were anticipating there would be some degree of reduction and will be surprised there wasn&apos;t anything,&quot; said Dr. Deepak L. Bhatt, one of the study&apos;s authors. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Setback for High Blood Pressure Treatment" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/30/health/setback-for-promising-high-blood-pressure-treatment.html" target="_blank">Setback for High Blood Pressure Treatment</a></strong>

A new procedure which was devised to combat high blood pressure for those whom traditional medication does not work appears to not work well also. This invasive procedure proved to be no more useful than no procedure at all, meaning medication and life style changes remain the mainstay treatment for those with hypertension.

TITLE: U.S. Joins Global Initiative to Fight Infectious Diseases
BASENAME: u-s-joins-global-initiative-to-fight-infectious-diseases
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/07/2014 12:01:00 PM
-----
BODY:
The U.S. and 26 other countries have begun a new effort to prevent and fight outbreaks of dangerous infectious diseases before they spread around the globe, according to <em>NBC News.&#xA0;</em>

The Global Health Security Agenda will bolster local disease monitoring, develop tests for different pathogens and help regions create and strengthen systems to report and respond to public health emergencies.

Currently, over 80 percent of countries lack the health infrastructure necessary to spot a new infection rapidly and sound the alarm before it has time to gain a foothold and even spread into other countries.

Infectious diseases continue to be a growing concern with a new type of bird flu reported in China, a mysterious and deadly respiratory virus emerging in the Middle East, and the first appearance of a mosquito-borne virus in the Caribbean in the past year alone.

Germs &quot;do not recognize or stop at national borders,&quot; said Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius. &quot;A threat anywhere is indeed a threat everywhere.&quot; Read the full story here:

<strong><a title="U.S. Joins 26 Countries to Fight Outbreaks" href="http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/u-s-joins-26-countries-fight-outbreaks-n29666" target="_blank">U.S. Joins 26 Countries to Fight Outbreaks</a></strong>

All countries must work together to stop the spread of infectious diseases. A threat to one country represents a threat to all.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Research Shows Elongated Blood Clot Risk for New Mothers
BASENAME: research-shows-elongated-blood-clot-risk-for-new-mothers
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/08/2014 12:10:00 PM
-----
BODY:
Women may be at a higher risk for blood clots for at least 12 weeks after they give birth, doubling the amount of time that was previously thought, according to <em>CBS News</em>.

Blood clots can cause life-threatening conditions, including strokes and heart attacks, due to blocking blood flow to the brain and heart. The blood clot can also get stuck in the lungs, causing a pulmonary embolism or block blood flow to other organs, causing deep vein thrombosis.

Researchers determined that there was an almost 11 times higher risk of blood clots between zero to six weeks after giving birth, dropping to a little over twice as high during weeks seven through 12. One out of 10,000 women had a pregnancy-related blood clot 6-12 weeks after the baby was born.

New mothers should contact a medical professional immediately if they experience chest pain or pressure, problems with breathing, swelling or pain in one leg, severe and sudden headache or immediate loss of speech, vision, balance or strength on one side of the body.

&quot;Sometimes there&apos;s the notion that once they deliver they don&apos;t have to worry about these things,&quot; said Dr. Andrew Stemer, a Georgetown University neurologist. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Blood clot risk for women may last twice as long after pregnancy than once thought" href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/blood-clot-risk-for-pregnant-women-may-last-twice-as-long-as-previously-thought/" target="_blank">Blood clot risk for women may last twice as long after pregnancy than once thought</a></strong>

For three months following delivery, mothers need to be mindful of pain that shortness of breath, chest pain, severe headache, leg swelling or leg pain could be signs of a blood clot.

-----
BODY:
Prescription drug abuse is not only a continuing plague nationwide, but could also be a gateway for increased heroin use, according to a recent <em>NBC News</em>&#xA0;article.

There has been a roughly 20 percent increase in overdose deaths involving prescription painkillers since 2006, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

&quot;The pathway appears to be now moving from the prescription drugs to heroin, a very dangerous development,&quot; said Dr. Wilson Compton, deputy director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse.

The White House Office of National Drug control policy stated that many heroin users today appear to have gotten their start taking prescription pain drugs. Opioid prescription painkillers have the same effect on the brain and body as heroin does, causing physical addiction.

Health insurance companies must now cover substance abuse treatment under provisions of the 2010 Affordable Care Act. Read the full story here:

<strong><a title="Prescription Drugs Could Be Gateway to Heroin, Officials Say" href="http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/prescription-drugs-could-be-gateway-heroin-officials-say-n27491" target="_blank">Prescription Drugs Could Be Gateway to Heroin, Officials Say</a></strong>

The abuse of prescription pain killers and heroin has been a problem for a long time. Many of these abusers start out as innocent victims of negligence that causes unrelenting pain. Painkillers should be used as a last resort and thrown out as soon as possible.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Don&apos;t Wait Until Last Minute to Choose a Nursing Home
BASENAME: dont-wait-until-last-minute-to-choose-nursing-home
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/14/2014 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Taking the time to select the right nursing home is one of the most important steps families can take for the 1.4 million residents currently living in these often-feared institutional settings, according to a recent article in <em>The New York Times.&#xA0;</em></strong>

When paid for privately, the average cost for nursing home care ranges from $10,000 to $15,000 a month. Medicare does not pay for long-term nursing home care, only temporary skilled care, usually in the rehabilitation section of the home.

Finding the right facility is similar to shopping for a new car - it requires considerable preparation to become an educated consumer, writes Joanna R. Leefer in &quot;Almost Like Home,&quot; a user-friendly guide to choosing a nursing home.

&quot;The biggest mistake people make is waiting until the last minute, when faced with a crisis, to find a suitable facility,&quot; said Leefer. &quot;You&apos;re forced into an impulsive decision that you&apos;re not likely to be happy with unless you&apos;re really very lucky.&quot;

Once the family member is admitted, it is also critical to monitor their care. Check for any hints of physical abuse and signs of incipent or existing bed sores, which can become infected and hasten death. Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Nursing Home Unthinkable? Be Prepared in Case It&apos;s Inevitable&#xA0;" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/07/28/nursing-home-unthinkable-be-prepared-in-case-its-inevitable/?_php=true&amp;_type=blogs&amp;ref=health&amp;_r=0" target="_blank">Nursing Home Unthinkable? Be Prepared in Case It&apos;s Inevitable</a>&#xA0;</strong>

The nursing home population is continuing to increase and will so more now that baby boomers are entering the age where such an institution may be necessary. The influx of patients will lead to a further increase in nursing home negligence, wrongful death and over medication cases as well.

AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Cancer Survival Rates Differing by Age
BASENAME: cancer-survival-rates-differing-by-age
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 08/08/2014 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Although improved cancer treatments and screenings have helped children and older adults live longer over the last 30 years, teens and young adults with cancer have not experienced the same rates of survival, according to a recent <em>CBS News</em>&#xA0;article.&#xA0;&#xA0;</strong>

Since 1975, cancer survival rates for children 14 and under have increased by 25 percent, with adults over 40 seeing a nearly 20 percent gain over the same time period. Cancer patients aged 15 to 19, meanwhile, had survival rates that increased by about 17 percent while survival rates among 20 to 39 year olds increased by only about 13 percent.

To address the gap for this &quot;forgotten population,&quot; the &#xA0;UCLA Medical Center launched once of the first cancer programs in the country offering patients a team of experts, including psychiatrists and social workers, who specialize in treating the needs of teens.

&quot;What we need to do is really concentrate on this population...developing clinical trials and new therapeutics specifically for these patients,&quot; said Dr. Noah Federman, a pediatric hematologist and oncologist at UCLA&apos;s Daltrey/Townshend Teen &amp; Young Adult Cancer Program. &quot;This becomes a home for them...that&apos;s very important to getting through this emotionally&#xA0;and mentally, which then helps them physically.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Program to help &quot;forgotten&quot; teen cancer patients" href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/program-to-help-forgotten-teen-cancer-patients/" target="_blank">Program to help &quot;forgotten&quot; teen cancer patients</a></strong>

This serves as a reminder that cancer does not discriminate by age. It is good to see that doctors are making sure that no part of the population is being forgotten.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is&#xA0;</strong><strong>available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.</strong>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: New Guidelines for Preemie Drug Angers Manufacturer
BASENAME: new-guidelines-for-preemie-drug-angers-manufacturer
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 08/11/2014 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Scaling back use of a costly medicine given mostly to premature babies has caused a clash between the drug&apos;s manufacturer and the nation&apos;s leading pediatrician&apos;s group, according to a recent <em>CBS News </em>article.</strong>

The drug, sold under the brand name Synagis, guards against a common but usually mild virus that can cause serious lung problems.

New guidelines from the American Academy of Pediatrics say medical evidence shows the drug benefits few children other than very young preemies. Its new guidance recommends it only for infants born before 29 weeks, older preemies with chronic lung disease and those with certain heart problems, and certain other at-risk children younger than age 2.

Studies show the drug can slightly reduce risks for being hospitalized but doesn&apos;t shorten hospital stays or lessen chances for long-term complications or death. Advances in treatment for preemies in recent years make Synagis unnecessary for many, the academy says.

Since the drug has seen a 19 percent drop in sales over the first quarter in 2014, MedImmune and its parent company AstraZeneca have placed full-page ads in <em>The New York Times</em>&#xA0;and several other newspapers protesting pediatricians&apos; new recommended limits. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Pediatricians, MedImmune clash over costly drug for babies" href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/pediatricians-medimmune-clash-over-antiviral-for-babies/" target="_blank">Pediatricians, MedImmune clash over costly drug for babies</a>&#xA0;</strong>

Yet another example of insurance companies attempting to practice medicine and exert control over care and medicine their insureds need. Until insurance companies are held in check, the health care system will continue to spiral out of control.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Kentucky Drivers Protected by Commercial Vehicle Enforcement
BASENAME: kentucky-drivers-protected-by-commercial-vehicle-enforcement
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/13/2014 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>With&#xA0;over two million tractor-trailers on the road every day, Kentucky&apos;s Commercial Vehicle Enforcement division is working to prevent traffic accidents that could cause&#xA0;serious physical injury and property damage.</strong>

The division protects the state&apos;s infrastructure and enforces state and federal laws on commercial vehicles traveling Kentucky&apos;s roads.

In addition to inspections based at weigh stations, which see nearly 6,000 commercial vehicles roll through every day, sworn CVE officers travel the state&apos;s highways and interstates looking for traffic violators or anything else amiss on commercial vehicles. Unlike other law enforcement officers, CVE officers do not have to have probable cause to stop a commercial vehicle.

Drivers must have a medical examiner&apos;s certificate that shows they are physically capable of operating a truck, a commercial driver&apos;s license, shipping papers, inspection certificates and other supporting documentation. CVE officers also check that everything from brakes, lights, horn and steering axles are working properly and that the truck&apos;s tires are not flat.

Some violations can result in a truck being impounded, while others can result in federal fines in the thousands of dollars.

&quot;Safety is the utmost concern,&quot; said Officer Jared Newberry, spokesman of Commercial Vehicle Enforcement Region 2. &quot;The second concern is the infrastructure...We don&apos;t want several noncompliant companies damaging our bridges and highways.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Commercial vehicle enforcment workers promote safety, protect roads" href="http://www.bgdailynews.com/news/commercial-vehicle-enforcement-workers-promote-safety-protect-roads/article_d6ec62b7-4f74-5a24-a416-4c74d88aa916.html" target="_blank">Commercial vehicle enforcment workers promote safety, protect roads</a></strong>

Commercial trucks are the single largest cause of devastating injuries on America&apos;s highways. &#xA0; Regulations and enforcement, along with damages awarded in personal injury lawsuits, are the only deterrent the industry will respond to.

<strong><strong>If you feel that unsafe driving factors exhibited by truck drivers led to a major accident which impacted your family&#x2019;s life,&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">please contact the experienced attorneys of Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a>.</strong></strong>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Minimally Invasive Surgeries Underused Nationwide
BASENAME: minimally-invasive-surgeries-underused-nationwide
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/31/2014 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Despite the risk of fewer complications and less pain, U.S. hospitals are not using minimally invasive surgeries as often as they should, according to a study reported in a recent <em>NBC News </em>article.</strong>

A survey of 1,051 U.S. hospitals in 45 states found that while 71 percent used minimally invasive surgery to take out an appendix, only 28 percent to take out part of the colon, even though keyhole colon surgery has about a third the complication rate of open surgery. Additionally, only&#xA0;13 percent used the same approach for a hysterectomy&#xA0;and 32 percent to remove part of a diseased lung.

Urban hospitals are more likely to use techniques that involve small incisions, leading to less pain, fewer complications and smaller scars, than rural hospitals.

&quot;This disparity may be due to the broad range of surgical services some surgeons in rural areas are required to provide and a scarcity of surgical specialists in such areas with advanced skills in minimally invasive surgery,&quot; the study&apos;s doctors wrote in their report, published in the British Medical Journal. Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Hospitals Underusing Keyhole Surgery, Study Finds" href="http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/hospitals-underusing-keyhole-surgery-study-finds-n151071" target="_blank">Hospitals Underusing Keyhole Surgery, Study Finds</a></strong>

It is disappointing to see that physicians aren&apos;t using minimally invasive surgery more often even though the complication rate is less than the more invasive, traditional surgery.&#xA0;It is also disappointing to see that people who seek care in rural areas frequently seem to get poorer care than those in urban areas.

TITLE: Hidden Cameras Lead to Criminal Charges for Ohio Nursing Home
BASENAME: hidden-cameras-lead-to-criminal-charges-for-ohio-nursing-home
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 08/05/2014 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Placing hidden cameras inside nursing homes may seem extreme, but at one Ohio facility the act led to catching numerous criminal activities, according to Attorney General Mike DeWine&apos;s office.</strong>

Thirty-nine criminal charges have been filed against Autumn Health Care in Zanesville after relatives or residents began complaining to authorities in December 2012. The relatives allowed hidden cameras to be placed in certain rooms, and these allegedly captured footage of staff providing poor care and falsifying information.

The owner of the facility faces charges of corruption, Medicaid fraud and forgery, and an additional 16 charges have been brought against the facility as a whole. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Hidden cameras result in criminal charges against Ohio nursing home owner..." href="http://www.mcknights.com/hidden-cameras-result-in-criminal-charges-against-ohio-nursing-home-owner-including-substandard-care-and-forgery/article/358347/" target="_blank">Hidden cameras result in criminal charges against Ohio nursing home owner...</a></strong>

Should all patients in nursing homes be given the option of having cameras placed in the room? It may limit privacy but would likely increase the quality of care.

AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Cost of Some Generic Drugs Rapidly Increase
BASENAME: cost-of-some-generic-drugs-rapidly-increase
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 08/07/2014 07:15:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>The cost of health care does not serve the&#xA0;only sticker shock in the medical industry - some generic drugs have recently seen price increases of over 1,000 percent, according to a recent article in <em>The New York Times</em>.</strong>

Digoxin, a generic heart medicine prescribed for over 200 years, has seen its prices tripled over the last 10 months alone, with some patients now encountering costs of more than $1,000 plus hundreds of dollars in co-pays.

There has been no shortage of the drug to explain the increase in cost, according to the Food and Drug Administration. Digoxin is not hard to make and there have been no new patents or formulations. The only factor affecting the cost are company strategies intended to reap the benefits of selling an ancient, lifesaving drug.

In January, the National Community Pharmacists Association called for a congressional hearing on generic drug prices, complaining that those for many essential medicines grew as much as &quot;600, 1,000 percent or more&quot; in recent years. The price jumps especially affect smaller pharmacies who are unable to bargain for discounts.

One of the major fears of these steep price increases is that patients will stop filling prescriptions altogether for these drugs that are potentially saving their lives. Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Rapid Price Increases for Some Generic Drugs Catch Users by Surprise" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/09/health/some-generic-drug-prices-are-soaring.html?ref=health&amp;_r=1" target="_blank">Rapid Price Increases for Some Generic Drugs Catch Users by Surprise</a></strong>

Cost motivates many decisions; however, it is particularly disturbing to see the cost of medicines raised for no good reason and then see people not get the treatment they need.

TITLE: Ohio Mumps Outbreak Surpasses 2013 Nationwide Figures
BASENAME: ohio-mumps-outbreak-surpasses-2013-nationwide-figures
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/24/2014 11:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>More people have been diagnosed with mumps in Ohio in 2014 than in the entire United States last year, according to a recent <em>NBC News </em>article.</strong>

Health officials say there have been 439 cases statewide of the contagious infection as of June 24, as opposed to 438 in the entire country in 2013. More than 800 cases have been reported from 25 states so far this year.

Mumps is one of the infections prevented by the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine, which continues to be less than perfect, according to health officials.

&quot;Mumps is a problem because the mumps vaccine that we have is a good one, but it is not a perfect vaccine,&quot; says Dr. William Schaffner, an infectious disease expert at Vanderbilt University. &quot;Even after two doses of mumps vaccine, if you wait 10 or 15 years and you&apos;re exposed to mumps there is only about 85 percent protection.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Ohio Mumps Outbreak Now Worse Than Whole U.S. Last Year" href="http://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/ohio-mumps-outbreak-now-worse-whole-u-s-last-year-n139796" target="_blank">Ohio Mumps Outbreak Now Worse Than Whole U.S. Last Year</a></strong>

Why does Ohio have so many cases of mumps?

AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Discovered Smallpox Vials Raise Concerns
BASENAME: discovered-smallpox-vials-raise-concerns
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/30/2014 08:51:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>Vials of the smallpox virus found at the National Institutes of Health in Maryland are raising questions over how they went unnoticed for so long, according to a recent <em>CBS News</em>&#xA0;article.</strong>

Six glass vials were found to contain smallpox DNA, although health officials are still unsure if the samples are live and potentially dangerous. The startling discovery of the vials by a researcher at the NIH required a multi-agency response from the CDC, FDA, World Health Organization, FBI, and White House National Security Council as smallpox is a potential bioterrorism agent.

Since being eradicated in 1980, samples of the virus are only permitted in two high-security labs in the world - the CDC and the State Research Centre of Virology &amp; Biotechnology in Russia.

Dr. Stephan Monroe, deputy director of the National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases at the CDC said it was &quot;one of those flukes&quot; that&#xA0;the vials went unnoticed. &quot;Certainly one of the lessons learned from this episode is that laboratories around the world should have a firm idea of what they have in their collections and...should make an effort to do a complete inventory.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Smallpox vials suspected to contain live virus" href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/smallpox-vials-suspected-to-contain-live-virus/" target="_blank">Smallpox vials suspected to contain live virus</a></strong>

It is certainly good that this discovery was made, however, it is concerning that such a hazardous agent could be misplaced or forgotten about.

AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Sports and Brain Injuries: A Dangerous Connection
BASENAME: sports-and-brain-injuries-a-dangerous-connection
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/22/2014 01:21:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<strong>The dangerous consequences of sports-related blows to the head include many long-term and debilitating burdens, as described by many former athletes and detailed in a recent <em>CBS News </em>article.</strong>

All too often young athletes feel they are invincible and immune to any sort of long-term injury. But several ailments - such as chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a progressive neurodegenerative disease - can emerge from repeated blows to the head and concussions.

Many of the symptoms linked to CTE, including memory loss and cognitive decline and changes in moods and behavior, are related to symptoms of Alzheimer&apos;s, Parkinson&apos;s disease, and Lou Gehrig&apos;s disease. In fact, people who suffer repeated and traumatic brain injury are statistically at higher risk for developing these neurodegenerative conditions later in life.

&quot;...I lied about my symptoms for five weeks thinking I was doing the right thing,&quot; said Chris Nowinski, a former professional wrestler for World Wrestling Entertainment, who continued to compete despite persistent headaches. &quot;My ignorance cost me my career, cost me at least five years of my health with terrible post-concussion syndrome, and I don&apos;t know what it&apos;s going to cost me in the future. But CTE is what I fear most.&quot;

According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, as many as 3.8 million traumatic brain injuries occur each year from sports and recreational activities, and many people are still unaware of the acute symptoms associate with this injury. Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Athletes testify on traumatic brain injury" href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/athletes-testify-on-traumatic-brain-injury/" target="_blank">Athletes testify on traumatic brain injury</a></strong>

The NFL concussion studies are shedding light on what many victims of car crashes and other traumatic events already know: there is no such thing as a &#x201C;minor&#x201D; brain injury<strong>.</strong>

 
-----
EXTENDED BODY:

-----
EXCERPT:

--------
AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Permanent Tweak to Pediatric Lung Transplant Policy
BASENAME: permanent-tweak-to-pediatric-lung-transplant-policy
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/15/2014 08:06:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>The organ transplant policy for pediatric patients is getting permanently tweaked thanks to a family&apos;s successful fight to get a lung transplant for their dying 10-year-old daughter last spring, according to <em>ABC News</em>.&#xA0;</strong>

The Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network, which is under contract with the federal government to allocate organs, voted to allow children to be granted exceptions on a case-by-case basis to the so-called Under 12 Rule.

Normally, children under 12 who are waiting for a lung transplant are labeled &quot;priority 1&quot; or &quot;priority 2,&quot; and they get preferential treatment when child and adolescent lungs become available. Children younger than 12 only get offered adult lungs after they&apos;ve been offered to other matching candidates over 12 based on an algorithm called the LAS, or lung allocation score.

The family of Sarah Murnaghan fought the Under 12 Rule last year, claiming it was discriminatory because Sarah could be offered adult lungs only after they were offered to other matching adults. The OPTN created a temporary rule exception policy because of this case.

&quot;We know a lot of kids who are waiting and little people who are waiting,&quot; said Sarah&apos;s mother, Janet Murnaghan, at a news conference outside their Newtown Square, Pennsylvania home. &quot;Just knowing that they&apos;ll have greater access is a really amazing feeling.&quot; Read the full details here:

<a title="Sarah Murnaghan Case Prompts Permanent Lung Transplant Policy Tweak&#xA0;" href="http://abcnews.go.com/Health/sarah-murnaghan-case-prompts-permanent-lung-transplant-policy/story?id=24269684" target="_blank">Sarah Murnaghan Case Prompts Permanent Lung Transplant Policy Tweak</a>

This article highlights a couple of things. First, medical policies or rules aren&#x2019;t always correct or well-founded. Second, when you fight hard enough against unjust laws, you often can obtain a just result.

<strong style="color: #7c7c7c; font-family: Oxygen, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; line-height: 19.2455997467041px;">If you or your child have been injured due to medical malpractice, including a delay in diagnosis or treatment,&#xA0;please call&#xA0;to investigate your matter fully. Crandall &amp; Pera Law is&#xA0;</strong><strong style="color: #7c7c7c; font-family: Oxygen, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; line-height: 19.2455997467041px;">available to help answer your questions and guide you in determining your next steps.</strong>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Ohio Ranks Near Bottom in Long-Term Care
BASENAME: ohio-ranks-near-bottom-in-long-term-care
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/17/2014 10:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>The state of Ohio ranks 44th nationwide when it comes to the quality of long-term services, including home care, support for family caregivers, and nursing homes, according to a new report.&#xA0;</strong>

The AARP, The Commonwealth Fund and The SCAN Foundation evaluated how every state fares in 26 indicators in five main areas that measure long-term services and supports for older adults and people with physical disabilities, and their caregivers. New indicators this year include length of stay in nursing homes and use of anti-psychotic drugs by nursing homes.

Ohio is in the bottom one-fourth of the country when it comes to affordability and access, and quality of life and quality of care. The state is in the third quartile in the areas of choice of setting and provider, support for family caregivers, and effective transitions.

The good news is that Ohio was one of five states with the largest rates of improvement - more than 25 percent - over its performance on the first report released in 2011. The report also showed that the median annual cost of care for a private room in a nursing home in the U.S. is $82,950.

&quot;Americans want to live independently in their homes and communities as they age,&quot; said AARP Senior Vice President for Public Policy Susan Reinhard. &quot;States are starting to step up to meet this challenge, but more must be done in a short time to meet the changing needs of a growing older population.&quot; Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Long-term care: Ohio near bottom for services for seniors and physically disabled, ranks 44th&#xA0;" href="http://www.cleveland.com/healthfit/index.ssf/2014/06/long-term_care_ohio_near_botto.html" target="_blank">Long-term care: Ohio near bottom for services for seniors and physically disabled, ranks 44th</a></strong>

Frightening findings as our population ages. This reinforces the notion that those who have loved ones in need of nursing home care must do exhaustive research to find a facility that is right for them.

AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Needle-Free Flu Vaccine Recommended for Children
BASENAME: needle-free-flu-vaccine-recommended-for-children
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/11/2014 09:00:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>For the first time, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices has recommended a specific brand of flu vaccine for kids aged 2 to 8 - the needle-free vaccine - according to NBC News.</strong>

The ACIP advises the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which can decide whether to take or leave the advice. ACIP members agreed on studies that show FluMist, which is squirted up the nose, is more effective than a shot in the arm for kids.

If the CDC approves of this recommendation, it will become official policy - although parents and pediatricians will be free to give any flu vaccine to a kid. Kids with egg allergies should continue to get the vaccines given as shots that are formulated without chicken eggs.

The CDC recommends that just about everyone get a flu vaccine every year. Read the full details here:

<strong>No More Needles: Health Officials Recommend FluMist for Kids</strong>

This article will make kids under age 8 and their parents very happy. Fewer shots means more smiles.

AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Potential Stroke Cause Affects Conventional Monitoring
BASENAME: potential-stroke-cause-affects-conventional-monitoring
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/07/2014 08:46:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<strong>The results of two new medical studies may mean significant changes for how patients are monitored and treated following a stroke, according to <em>The New York Times</em>.&#xA0;&#xA0;</strong>

More than a half-million Americans every year have an ischemic stroke, the most common form, and at least a quarter of these cases have no apparent underlying cause. Atrial fibrillation, a common irregularity of the heartbeat that often goes unrecognized, may be causing up to a third of these strokes of unknown origin.

The findings of these studies are likely to encourage doctors to look more aggressively for signs of atrial fibrillation and prescribe more powerful anticoagulant medications to prevent clotting that can lead to additional strokes in these patients where a mild blood thinner is not enough.

Some patients may also need their hearts monitored much longer to detect abnormal rhythms. One of the studies found that atrial fibrillation was diagnosed in five times as many patients who wore special heart monitors for 30 days compared with those who underwent conventional 24-hour testing.

&quot;If more patients with atrial fibrillation can be detected, then more patients can receive appropriate stroke prevention therapy, and the hope is that more strokes, deaths, disability and dementia can be avoided,&quot; said Dr. David Gladstone, as associate professor in the department of medicine at the University of Toronto. Read the full details here:

<strong><a title="Longer Heart Monitoring Backed for Stroke Patients" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/06/25/longer-heart-monitoring-backed-for-stroke-patients/?_php=true&amp;_type=blogs&amp;_php=true&amp;_type=blogs&amp;ref=health&amp;_r=1&amp;" target="_blank">Longer Heart Monitoring Backed for Stroke Patients</a></strong>

There is a strong correlation between many strokes and atrial fibrillation. If you or a loved one has A-fib, makes sure the doctor is taking precautions to prevent a possible stroke.&#xA0;Similarly, if you or a loved one has a stroke, make sure your doctor investigates whether you have atrial fibrillation.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: 3D Mammograms May Bring Breast Cancer Breakthrough
BASENAME: 3d-mammograms-may-bring-breast-cancer-breakthrough
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/09/2014 02:56:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<strong>New 3-D technologies may be able to improve the accuracy of breast cancer scans and resolve some of the controversy around screening, according to NBC News.</strong>

It has been argued that mammography could be doing more harm than good because of the many false positives that send women for biopsies of lesions that often turn out to be harmless.

The new screening method, as published in the Journal of the American Medical Association, resulted in 15 perfect fewer call-backs for additional imaging, while at the same time spotting more tiny, aggressive and potentially fatal tumors. The study suggests that doctors may one day be able to differentiate between benign and malignant lesions without the need for a biopsy.

&quot;It allows us to peel away the layers and see underlying lesions that might be obscured by other tissue,&quot; said Dr. Sarah Friedewald, co-medical director of the Caldwell Breast Center. &quot;You can think of regular mammography as showing a closed book. With 3-D you are able to page through the book one page at a time without other information superimposed.&quot; Read the full article here:

<strong><a title="Breast Cancer Breakthrough? 3D Mammograms Offer Sharper Results&#xA0;" href="http://www.nbcnews.com/health/womens-health/breast-cancer-breakthrough-3d-mammograms-offer-sharper-results-n139611" target="_blank">Breast Cancer Breakthrough? 3D Mammograms Offer Sharper Results</a></strong>

On the heels of discussions questioning the utility of mammograms, this is great news. Ask your doctor about a 3-D mammogram.

<strong>As the negligent care of Veterans Affairs health facilities continues to be exposed nationwide, a local health center in Kentucky is finding that it is not in the clear either, according to <em>The Courier-Journal</em>.&#xA0;&#xA0;</strong>

Patricia Mahaun, a 26-year veteran of the Air Force, waited six months before she finally saw a doctor at the Louisville VA to get a possible urinary tract infection checked and get a flu shot. Stephen George, spokesman for U.S. Rep. John Yarmouth [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][KY-3] said his office has recently heard from about 20 veterans complaining about waits that lasted three or four weeks.

The VA cares for about 6.5 million veterans and other beneficiaries in its 150 medical centers and 820 community-based outpatient clinics nationwide. In April, a national report pointed to screenings delays that prevented prompt detection of possible gastrointestinal cancer in 76 veterans at VA hospitals and 23 related deaths.
