--------
AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: University of Louisville is Revolutionizing the Treatment of Spinal Injuries
BASENAME: university-louisville-revolutionizing-treatment-spinal-injuries
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/13/2015 09:24:20 AM
-----
BODY:
When Calven Goza&#x2019;s 2012 car crash left him unable to move anything below the chest, he expected that he would never walk again. That did not stop him from hoping he might do so again one day &#x2013; and thanks to a revolutionary program out of the University of Louisville, it looks like Mr. Goza&#x2019;s hopes were well-founded. This past December, he was able to move his leg for the first time since his accident.

So far, a total of five men &#x2013; Goza included &#x2013; have undergone the surgical treatment developed by the University. <a href="http://mtstandard.com/news/local/tech-student-paralyzed-by-wreck-can-move-legs-again-thanks/article_2ec0adb1-57e8-55cb-b1df-8e6a5a12220b.html">All five men have</a> &#x201C;regained movement in their legs, and can use them to help support them while standing. They&#x2019;ve also seen improvements in blood pressure regulation, bladder function, and sexual function.&#x201D;

Surgeons implanted electrodes near the vertebrae in the spine; in Mr. Goza&#x2019;s case, the T12 and L1 vertebrae. After recuperating from the surgery, the doctors began sending electrical pulses to the electrodes to &#x201C;map&#x201D; the spine, to see what combination of electrodes was having what effect. Because the study is ongoing, the researchers have not released all of the details about why the process works, or how they can map the spine. But Mr. Goza is living proof that whatever the University of Louisville is doing, it is definitely on the right path.
<h2>Paralysis by the numbers</h2>
Mr. Goza and the four other men in the study are lucky to have been chosen; more than 1,000 people were on the University&#x2019;s list, and nearly <a href="http://www.christopherreeve.org/site/c.mtKZKgMWKwG/b.5184189/k.5587/Paralysis_Facts__Figures.htm">6 million people</a> in the U.S. suffer with some form of paralysis. Of those 6 million, about 1.275 million are paralyzed as the result of a spinal cord injury. Like Mr. Goza, <a href="http://www.christopherreeve.org/site/c.mtKZKgMWKwG/b.5184255/k.6D74/Prevalence_of_Paralysis.htm">24% of those victims</a> were paralyzed in an auto accident &#x2013;&#xAD; the second most common cause of spinal cord injury-related paralysis in the country. Paralysis can happen if you are in an accident where:
<ul>
    <li>You collide with another vehicle or a stationary object</li>
    <li>You are not wearing your seat belt</li>
    <li>Your airbags fail to deploy, or your seat belt fails to keep you in the car</li>
    <li>You are hit by a drunk driver</li>
    <li>You suffer a traumatic brain injury</li>
    <li>You are riding a motorcycle without a helmet</li>
</ul>
We are very happy for Mr. Goza, and we hope that the University of Louisville continues to see such positive results from its new program. We also hope that one day its procedures will be available to everyone who can benefit from them.
<h3>Helping those who are seriously injured in car accidents</h3>
Crandall &amp; Pera Law assists victims of serious car accidents throughout Kentucky and Ohio. If a collision has left you paralyzed, we want to hear your story. Please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact our firm</a> to learn more about our services.
-----

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: American Nurses Association Seeks an End to Fatigue-Related Errors
BASENAME: american-nurses-association-seeks-end-fatigue-related-errors
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/04/2015 09:06:07 AM
-----
BODY:
<div class="layer text">

Sleep deprivation is a serious problem; it affects not only our overall health, but our ability to make decisions. When a healthcare provider is overly fatigued it can lead to catastrophic results. That is why the <a href="http://www.nursingworld.org/">American Nurses Association</a> is seeking to create policies to help keep nurses from working long shifts and mandatory overtime, hoping that fewer mistakes will be made if the nurses on duty are more awake and alert.

According to <a href="http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2015/01/30/nurse-fatigue/22618173/">Cincinnati.com,</a> the ANA wants employers such as hospitals to:
<ul>
    <li>Limit shifts to 12 hours or fewer and workweeks to 40 hours or fewer.</li>
    <li>Eliminate mandatory overtime.</li>
    <li>Keep consecutive night shifts to a minimum for nurses working both days and nights.</li>
    <li>Promote frequent rest breaks and provide sleep rooms or transportation when nurses are too tired to drive.</li>
    <li>Give nurses the right to reject work assignments to prevent fatigue.</li>
</ul>
Other states have already started addressing the problem of fatigued nursing staff. <a href="http://www.kentuckyonehealth.org/">KentuckyOne Health</a>, which bills itself as &#x201C;the largest and most comprehensive health system in the Commonwealth,&#x201D; employs &#x201C;flex nurses.&#x201D; These nurses work flexible hours and schedules so that no one works too long or while fatigued.
<h2>The dangers of fatigue</h2>
The article references a &#x201C;groundbreaking study in the journal Health Affairs in 2004 looked at 393 nurses over more than 5,300 shifts and found that those who worked shifts 12 1/2 hours or longer were <strong>three times more likely </strong>than others to make an error in patient care&#x201D; (<strong>emphasis ours</strong>). This is not surprising, as <a href="http://www.healthline.com/health/sleep-deprivation/effects-on-body">sleep deprivation</a> has been linked to impaired brain activity, memory problems, cognitive dysfunction and changes in mood. People who are chronically fatigued may not even have the physical energy to perform their jobs correctly. Cincinnati.com points to a study by the <a href="http://ajcc.aacnjournals.org/content/23/1/13"><em>American Journal of Critical Care</em></a> which claims that &#x201C;fatigued nurses are more likely than well-rested nurses to make <strong>faulty decisions that lead to decision regret</strong>, a negative cognitive emotion that occurs when the actual outcome differs from the desired or expected outcome&#x201D; when it comes to helping victims in critical care situations (<strong>emphasis ours</strong>).
<h3><strong>Learn more about the dangerous effects of fatigue</strong></h3>
At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we applaud the ANA for taking steps to reduce fatigue; it will make both nurses and their patients safer. For more information about what KentuckyOne Health is doing, or to discuss your experiences with sleep-deprived healthcare providers, we invite you to visit our website or <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact our Kentucky or Ohio offices</a>.

</div>
-----

-----

--------
AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Are Alternative Therapies Giving Real Hope to Traumatic Brain Injury Victims?
BASENAME: alternative-therapies-giving-real-hope-traumatic-brain-injury-victims
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/17/2015 12:40:34 PM
-----
BODY:
A traumatic brain injury, or TBI, may be life-altering. The actual injury to the brain can take many forms, and the effects can be present immediately or take weeks to manifest. No two brain injuries are alike, and the results can be range from mild to severe. Regardless of the classification of the injury, the effects can be devastating to victims and their families.

Therapy following a traumatic brain injury can be time-consuming and cost prohibitive. Long term treatments can include a mix of physical and occupational therapy, speech and language therapy, counseling, support groups, and medication. Because of the unique nature of every brain injury, there is no guaranteed path to recovery. Instead, a trial and error approach is used to determine the right mix of therapies for the victim.

An alternative therapy out of the Centre for Neuro Skills in Bakersfield, California, has so far yielded positive results. The Centre has been hosting drum circles every Tuesday and Thursday night for the last year and a half. Betty Mendez facilitates the circles, and says that every member participating in the therapy has shown signs of improvement since they started.
<h2>Why the therapy might be working</h2>
The theory is that &#x201C;any activity that crosses the midline of the body, like the act of drumming, helps the two hemispheres in the brain to start communicating again.

Richard Andretti, a client who was injured on a job site, says he looks forward to therapy as a respite from his week. He said, &#x201C;The thing about the drumming that helps me is that it takes it all away when I&#x2019;m banging the drum.&#x201D;

Mendez sometimes leads the group with a certain beat and sometimes allows someone else in the group to lead. The drum therapy is combined Reiki meditation, which Sarah Hartford, the activities director, says is an important part of the therapy. &#x201C;They&#x2019;re able to come and refocus their day after having kind of a crazy day with all the things they&#x2019;re doing in therapies and just kind of get back to their center,&#x201D; she said.

The value of some alternative medicines is highly questionable. However, the <a href="http://www.neuroskills.com/about-us/licenses-and-accreditations.php" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Centre for Neuro Skills</a> is accredited by CARF International (formerly the Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities) for its Brain Injury Specialty Programs. Until new research shines light into repairing traumatic brain injuries, it&#x2019;s important to know that there are alternative solutions.
<h3>Looking out for your loved ones</h3>
Crandall &amp; Pera Law provides comprehensive counsel to victims of traumatic brain injury throughout Ohio and Kentucky. If you or a loved one has suffered a traumatic brain injury, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> for a free consultation.
-----

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Kentucky Legislation to Establish Medical Review Panel
BASENAME: kentucky-legislation-establish-medical-review-panel
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/25/2015 03:11:53 PM
-----
BODY:
A state Senate committee approved legislation early this February that would create an autonomous panel to review potential lawsuits regarding medical malpractice. Senator Ralph Alvarado (R-Winchester) sponsored <a href="http://www.lrc.ky.gov/record/15rs/SB6.htm">Senate Bill 6</a> with the intention of reducing the number of frivolous medical malpractice suits and the associated cost to medical providers.

However, opponents of the legislation believe that the addition of a medical review panel would hinder justice by adding a complex maze of hurdles for plaintiffs to navigate before they gain access to the most fundamental right that this country offers; the right to a jury by one&#x2019;s peers. The civil justice system already is painfully slow and arduous. These proposed review panels will likely add many months, if not years, to the process of having a medical malpractice case heard by a jury. The process typically takes several years before an injured victim sees a courtroom now.&#xA0;&#xA0; Unfortunately, catastrophically injured patients often die from their injuries, while waiting for their day in court, because they can&#x2019;t afford desperately needed treatment. The companies pushing this bill through the Kentucky legislature are well aware that the longer it takes a case to reach a jury always is to their benefit. The more hurdles, the less likely an injured patient lives to see their day in court. It is that simple.

Unfortunately, the proponents of this bill are misguided, misinformed or worse. For instance, Kentucky attorneys and their clients can be subject to a claim of malicious prosecution if they bring a frivolous lawsuit against a medical care provider. In Kentucky, doctors and hospitals have, on multiple occasions, successfully prosecuted attorneys and their clients for bringing frivolous lawsuits. This threat, which many states do not have, alone deters many an attorney from filing a questionable lawsuit. In addition, as Senator Reginald Thomas (D-Lexington) pointed out, judges are already able to sanction or impose civil damages on lawyers for bringing meritless suits.

Along the same lines, a Louisville lawyer testified against the bill, saying, &#x201C;A Harvard University study, not paid for by trial lawyers, published in <em>The New England Journal of Medicine</em>, concluded portraits of a malpractice system that is stricken with frivolous litigation are overblown. The data tells us that medical negligence lawsuits in this state comprise of less than one half of 1 percent of all civil cases. That&#x2019;s the data.&#x201D;

The approval of the committee is a small step toward approval of the legislation. The initiative will next go to the full Senate for consideration. Kentucky has a rich tradition of protecting the rights of the less fortunate. Make no mistake &#x2013; this bill is the product of billion dollar insurance companies, and their wealthy insureds, who want to increase their profits at the expense of citizens&#x2019; rights. Don&#x2019;t let them do it. Call your representative and let them know that you oppose any attempt to strip you of your right to a speedy trial. Let them know they should oppose Senate Bill 6.

If you have questions about your rights, or have been a victim of medical malpractice, please contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law for a free consultation.
-----
EXTENDED BODY:

-----
EXCERPT:

-----
KEYWORDS:

-----


--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: New Report Finds One Third of Nation&#x2019;s Nursing Homes Receiving Lower Scores
BASENAME: new-report-finds-one-third-nations-nursing-homes-receiving-lower-scores
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/13/2015 09:34:10 AM
-----
BODY:
Nursing homes across the country received lower scores from the government&#x2019;s five star rating system. A survey published in USA Today assessed <a href="http://www.mansfieldnewsjournal.com/story/news/local/2015/02/22/ohio-nursing-home-quality-scores-drop-new-federal-ratings/23836615/">more than 15,000 facilities</a> with information collected from over 1.5 million consumers. The slip isn&#x2019;t because of a decline in quality of care, however, but because of tougher standards implemented by the government.

Nursing home ratings involved three main categories; inspection, quality measure, and staffing rating. Inspection includes multiple years of survey data and complaints. Quality measure includes pain reports, and falls and use of restraints, while the staffing rating assesses the mix of nurses and aides as well as average time a patient has access to care professionals.

Researchers said that in addition to the categories above, the study includes a measure of the use of anti-psychotic drugs. The use of these drugs comes along with a high risk factor for the elderly, especially those with dementia. The new study also refined the way in which staffing is studied.

Not all nursing homes are happy with the changes, <a href="http://www.microcapobserver.com/new-report-one-third-of-the-nursing-homes-across-usa-are-receiving-lower-scores-on-governments-five-star-quality-scale/236387/">saying that</a> &#x201C;Federal ratings for nursing homes were inaccurate and artificially inflated, federal officials readjusted quality standards, which brought the ratings of nearly a third of the nation&#x2019;s nursing homes down...&#x201D; Operators are worried that the general public will misinterpret the new ratings as a decline in care quality instead of a change in the ranking system.

The people most affected by the change seem to be welcoming it. Robyn Grant is the Director of Public Policy and Advocacy at the National Consumer Voice for Quality Long-Term Care. The group advocates for nursing home residents, and Director Grant released a statement saying, &#x201C;We&#x2019;ve been concerned for quite some time that the ratings have been over-inflated, particularly as they relate to quality and staffing. Rescaling the quality measures is going to result in more accurate reflections of quality care.&#x201D;

Choosing the right nursing home is difficult for any number of reasons, not least of which is the concern for an aging family member. We hope that these new standards provide a more accurate picture to prevent unnecessary suffering. To learn more about the new ratings system and how your loved one might be affected, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a>. We maintain multiple office locations throughout Ohio, West Virginia and Kentucky for your convenience.
-----

AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Ohio&#x2019;s Deadly I-75 Collapse
BASENAME: ohios-deadly-75-collapse
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/05/2015 09:42:46 AM
-----
BODY:
Heavy equipment was being used to separate the concrete deck on the Hopple Street overpass, a stretch of I-75 just north of downtown Cincinnati, when a late-night collapse left a construction worker dead and a big-rig driver injured. The span of bridge was being removed by Kokosing Construction as part of a three-year project to improve traffic flow and safety. At some point during the project, something went wrong, and the span fell.

Brandon William Carl, 35, of Augusta, Kentucky, was killed in the collapse, which brought hundreds of tons of concrete, metal and machinery on to the highway below. It took rescue workers <a href="http://www.wkyt.com/home/headlines/Deadly-bridge-collapse-shuts-down-I-75-in-Cincinnati-289105771.html">around four hours</a> to recover his body from the rubble using air bags and special equipment.

A tractor-trailer was passing under the bridge when rubble started to fall, causing driver Eric Meyers, 36, of Howell, Michigan to crash. Remarkably, Meyers wasn&#x2019;t seriously hurt. He was taken to University of Cincinnati Medical Center with minor injuries. Police Chief Jeff Blackwell <a href="http://detroit.cbslocal.com/2015/01/21/howell-man-injured-in-deadly-i-75-overpass-collapse-in-ohio/">said of the accident,</a> &#x201C;The big-rig driver is very lucky; in a matter of seconds his fate would have probably been different.&#x201D;

Police also said that the accident could have been much worse if the collapse had happened during a busy time on the interstate. Because the accident occurred around 10:30pm, instead of at rush hour, hundreds if not thousands of commuters&#x2019; lives were saved. Acting deputy director of the Ohio transportation department&#x2019;s southwest Ohio district, Gary Middleton, said the accident occurred during a &#x201C;routine operation&#x201D; and that Kokosing is a &#x201C;very safety-conscious&#x201D; contractor.

Kokosing could be fined for forcing lane closures and face disciplinary action by OSHA, the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration, which is investigating Carl&#x2019;s death. The company has had fewer than ten OSHA violations since 2003. Scott Allen, a spokesman for OSHA, said, &#x201C;That&#x2019;s a good track record for any company.&#x201D;

Though it could have been so much worse, this tragic accident left a young family fatherless and another man injured. Our thoughts and prayers are with the family of Brandon Carl, who left behind a fianc&#xE9;e and four children.
-----

AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Senate Bill 6 Includes Nursing Homes in Definition of Health Care Facilities
BASENAME: senate-bill-6-includes-nursing-homes-definition-health-care-facilities
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/16/2015 09:27:12 AM
-----
BODY:
In 2011, a jury in West Virginia awarded the family of a woman named Dorothy Douglas $91.5 million after Ms. Douglas died from neglect in a nursing home. It was a landmark case, and had that judgment been allowed to stand (it was reduced to $36.5 million later on) it might have sent a powerful message to facilities which prioritize profits over people. But instead of cheering for the justice system, the West Virginia legislature created Senate Bill 6 (SB6).

The bill expands the current definition of health care facilities to now include all operations of nursing homes. The bill gets rid of any distinction between ordinary negligence and medical negligence, which allows plaintiffs to sue for damages which are not part of the state&#x2019;s Medical Professional Liability Act.

In essence, the bill caps the amount of damages you can collect if a nursing home&#x2019;s gross negligence or abuse leads to the serious injury or wrongful death of your family member.
<h2>How the legislators are spinning the purpose of the bill</h2>
The legislature claims that large verdicts raise the costs of liability insurance, or that fear of a lawsuit will drive nursing home out of the state. They claim the bill makes sure that victims are compensated &#x201C;fairly.&#x201D;

<a href="http://wvmetronews.com/2015/02/24/lawmakers-fixing-nursing-home-loophole-in-medical-malpractice-law/">But here is the truth</a>: a person who is injured is only entitled to compensation amounts between $335,000 and $640,000 (depending on the circumstances) for an injury or a wrongful death, respectively. Now nursing homes which let their residents die, either from neglecting their needs or through abusive actions, are covered under these same caps.

While this bill makes its way into law, it&#x2019;s important to know the warning signs of nursing home abuse and neglect, especially since your options may be limited if your family member is hurt. If you have a loved one in a long-term care facility, be on the lookout for:
<ul>
    <li>Changes in behavior</li>
    <li>Physical or emotional withdrawal</li>
    <li>Unexplained injuries</li>
    <li>Bedsores</li>
    <li>Weight change or malnutrition</li>
    <li>Poor hygiene</li>
    <li>Unexplained hair loss or bleeding</li>
    <li>Missing items</li>
    <li>Unusual financial transactions</li>
    <li>Unexplained death</li>
</ul>
At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we are fighting every day for the victims of nursing home abuse and neglect. If you have a loved one in a nursing home in West Virginia, Ohio or Kentucky, it&#x2019;s important to have as much information about a facility and its caretakers as possible. If your loved one has been the victim or nursing home abuse or neglect, please contact us for a free consultation.
-----

--------
AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Is Your Doctor&#x2019;s Office Making You Sick?
BASENAME: doctors-office-making-sick
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/19/2015 08:13:57 AM
-----
BODY:
The Center for Disease Control and Prevention recently published a study that reports a substantial number of people have been infected by a potentially deadly bacteria who hadn&#x2019;t been in a hospital. Those infected had instead recently visited a doctor or dentist&#x2019;s office. The bacteria in question, <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/HAI/pdfs/cdiff/Cdiff_tagged.pdf"><em>C. difficile</em></a>, is a type of healthcare-associated infection (HAI) that caused an estimated half a million infections and 29,000 deaths in 2011.

The bacteria cause inflammation of the colon called colitis. People who take antibiotics and get medical care are at risk. Once infected, <em>C. difficile</em> can cause deadly diarrhea. Researchers found the bacteria in six out of seven outpatient clinics in <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2015/02/25/health/deadly-bacteria-doctors-offices/">2013 study</a> in Ohio. Dr. Cliff McDonald, a medical epidemiologist at the CDC, said, &#x201C;This is really an important issue. We need to understand better how people are getting C. diff.&#x201D;
<h2>Protecting yourself from C. diff</h2>
The CDC has compiled the following information about C. diff symptoms and prevention. First, the elderly and those with medical problems have the best chance of getting C. diff. The bacteria can live outside the body for a long time. An infection can spread from person-to-person on dirty equipment or on the hands of healthcare providers or visitors. Common symptoms include:
<ul>
    <li>Loss of appetite</li>
    <li>Nausea</li>
    <li>Belly pain and tenderness</li>
    <li>Watery diarrhea</li>
    <li>Fever</li>
</ul>
If you have any of the symptoms listed above, please seek professional medical attention. An infection is usually easy to treat with antibiotics, but, if left untreated, can require surgery to remove infected parts of the intestines. Infection is also more likely when taking a broad-spectrum antibiotic. These powerful drugs eliminate good gut bacteria, leaving prime conditions for C. diff. The bacteria isn&#x2019;t vulnerable to alcohol-based hand sanitizers, so it&#x2019;s best to wash your hands after a visit to the doctor&#x2019;s office.

When seeking medical care, make sure that any healthcare professional you come in to contact with has cleaned their hands. It&#x2019;s ok to ask your doctor to wash his hands before touching you. Also, be sure to wash your own hands after a visit to any office or hospital.

If you or someone you know has contracted <em>C. difficile</em>, or has suffered any medical condition as a result of a doctor or hospital visit, please contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law for a free consultation. We maintain multiple office locations throughout Ohio, Kentucky and West Virginia for your convenience.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Major Retailers Selling Fraudulent Herbal Supplements
BASENAME: major-retailers-selling-fraudulent-herbal-supplements
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/24/2015 07:15:37 AM
-----
BODY:
A <a href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/herbal-supplements-targeted-by-new-york-attorney-general/">recent investigation</a> by the New York Attorney General discovered that herbal supplements being sold by Target, GNC, Walmart and Walgreens were contaminated with substances not listed on their labels, and that some brands did not contain any of the product listed on the label. The findings have led to a series of class action lawsuits against the companies seeking compensation for damages and purchase refunds.

<img class="alignright wp-image-1990 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Herbal-Supplements-Dangerous-300x286.jpg" alt="dangerous supplements" width="300" height="286">On the face of it, herbal supplements seem at best to be harmless additions to your everyday diet. However, the findings presented by the New York Attorney General found that common herbal supplements contained contaminants that included common allergens. These undisclosed ingredients could cause allergic reactions, ranging from mild symptoms like itching or hives to major symptoms like anaphylactic shock resulting in death.

The Attorney General&#x2019;s office looked into top-selling store brands of Echinacea, Garlic, Ginkgo Biloba, Saw Palmetto, St. John&#x2019;s Wort, and Valerian Root. The supplements were DNA tested, and few were found to contain any plant DNA at all. Cease and desist letters were sent to the retailers demanding that the products be pulled from the shelves.

Among Walmart&#x2019;s store brand supplements, <a href="http://topclassactions.com/lawsuit-settlements/lawsuit-news/49382-herbal-supplement-scam-alleged-gnc-target-walgreens-wal-mart/">just 4%</a> were found to contain DNA from the plants listed on their respective labels. Walgreens faired slightly better, with 18%. Of the GNC supplements tested, 22% were found to have appropriate plant DNA, while Target scored best with 41%. Among the contaminants found were:
<ul>
    <li>Rice</li>
    <li>Beans</li>
    <li>Pine</li>
    <li>Citrus</li>
    <li>Asparagus</li>
    <li>Primrose</li>
    <li>Wheat</li>
    <li>Houseplant</li>
    <li>Wild carrot</li>
</ul>
The Food and Drug Administration requires that food manufacturers list the eight most common food allergens. However, manufacturers of herbal supplements fall into a sort gray zone. Drugs and foodstuffs are heavily regulated, where herbal supplements generally need to prove only that a given product is fit for human consumption.

Every level of the chain is responsible in this case, but the lawsuits are targeting major retailers for failing to verify the quality of the products in question. In this, as in all else, it&#x2019;s best to be as informed as possible.
<h3><strong>Trust Crandall &amp; Pera Law to help</strong></h3>
Crandall &amp; Pera Law provides comprehensive legal services to Ohio and Kentucky victims of product liability. If you have been taking herbal supplements and have experienced health problems as a result, or if you wish to learn more about the case, we invite you to contact our office to speak with a skilled personal injury lawyer today.

AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Ohio Nursing Homes Get Great Marks
BASENAME: ohio-nursing-homes-get-great-marks
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 04/01/2015 08:11:20 AM
-----
BODY:
For the last seven years, U.S. News &amp; World Report has published an annual &#x201C;Best Nursing Homes&#x201D; edition. The report helps families to search for information about care, safety, staffing and more for almost 16,000 nursing homes throughout the nation. This year&#x2019;s edition has good news for Ohio.

Ohio was ranked second in the nation for five-star rated nursing homes. Around 17% of the states&#x2019; facilities received the rating, the highest available. The national average of 5-star nursing homes is 21.7%. The lists are generally regarded as highly accurate, and make use of data provided by a program run by the Centers for Medicare &amp; Medicaid Services.

The report also includes some excellent information on choosing the right nursing home, covering costs, and guaranteeing good care. Choosing a nursing home for a loved one is difficult at best; this resource provides excellent help when you need it most.
<h2>Choosing the right nursing home</h2>
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-1995" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Ohio-Nursing-Homes-Highly-Rated-300x200.jpg" alt="Ohio nursing homes highly rated" width="300" height="200">How do you know which nursing home to choose? Think about this:
<ul>
    <li><strong>Who&#x2019;s paying?</strong> If you are able to privately pay for a loved ones care, your options may be a bit more open. However, most facilities accept Medicare or Medicaid. The Veterans Administration has a benefit program to provide care for veterans and their spouses. Also, if the care is long-term, some facilities are open to negotiation.</li>
    <li><strong>Location, location, location</strong>. A large part of your loved ones well-being will include healthy relationships. If you have to drive several hours to visit, you may want to reconsider. Additionally, it&#x2019;s harder to ensure ongoing quality of care if you are unable to visit often.</li>
    <li><strong>It never hurts to ask</strong>. Once you&#x2019;ve done your research online, it&#x2019;s time to visit and look around. Ask residents what they think, and ask as many of them as you can. Ask if the facility accepts Medicare or Medicaid. Ask the nurses about their jobs and their patients. Ask about diets and food quality and activities.</li>
</ul>
Even the best facilities can make mistakes. Armed with these tools, the risk of abuse or neglect can be minimized but never eliminated. If your loved one has been the victim of nursing home abuse or neglect, please contact us for a free consultation.

AUTHOR: digitallawmarketing
TITLE: Steve Crandall Tackles Distracted Driving with the Help of 650 Chagrin Falls Students
BASENAME: steve-crandall-tackles-distracted-driving-help-650-chagrin-falls-students
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/14/2015 01:06:44 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2007" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/IMG_2745-300x200.jpg" alt="Steve Crandall Speaks on Distracted Driving" width="300" height="200">There are few things more important than enriching, educating and protecting your community &#x2013; and Crandall &amp; Pera Law&#x2019;s very own Steve Crandall proved it just last week, when he gave a presentation to 650 members of the student body at Chagrin Falls High School. As part of the campaign to end distracted driving for good, Attorney Crandall represented the End Distracted Driving organization (<a href="http://enddd.org/">EndDD.org</a>). The CFHS students took part in this interactive presentation by analyzing and discussing their own feelings about and experiences with distracted driving. They were then asked to have that same discussion with their parents and guardians.

EndDD.org also allows drivers to take the pledge to drive without distractions. The school offered a prize raffle for any students who took the pledge and entered their names.
<h2>April is Distracted Driving Month</h2>
Attorney Crandall&#x2019;s EndDD.org presentation could not have been timelier, as April is Distracted Driving Month. According to the organization:
<ul>
    <li>Car crashes are the #1 cause of unintentional fatalities in America, killing about 100 people per day</li>
    <li>Driver error is to blame for about 90% of all car crashes</li>
    <li>At any given time, 9% of the driving population is using a cell phone, which leads to approximately 26% of all car crashes</li>
    <li>&#x201C;The activity in the area of the brain that processes moving images <strong>decreases by up to 1/3</strong> when listening [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][or] talking on a phone,&#x201D; leading drivers to miss about half &#x2013; <strong>50%</strong> &#x2013; of what is moving outside of the car, <em>even when they are looking out the windshield</em></li>
</ul>
Part of the problem could be that different states have different laws &#x2013; and sometimes the laws against distracted driving vary from town to town. In Ohio, there is a &#x201C;<a href="http://www.ncsl.org/research/transportation/cellular-phone-use-and-texting-while-driving-laws.aspx">local option</a>&#x201D; when it comes to hand-held cell phone bans, meaning that there is no one law governing the entire state. However, drivers younger than 18 may not use cell phones while driving at all, and no drivers are allowed to text while they drive. Police will enforce the bans on texting as well as the ban on younger drivers using a phone in the car. In Kentucky, drivers under the age of 18 and school bus drivers are prohibited from using a cell phone while driving, and no one is allowed to text; the cops uphold and enforce these laws as well.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we believe that any steps we can take to eliminate unnecessary injuries and deaths from our communities are the right steps. We encourage you to visit EndDD.org to <a href="http://enddd.org/the-facts-about-distracted-driving/">learn the facts</a>, and to take the pledge yourselves. If you have questions about distracted driving laws in Ohio or Kentucky, or if you want to learn more about becoming a presenter, we invite you to reach out to us today. Together we can save lives.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Honoring the Memory of Cincinnati Firefighter and Family Man Daryl Gordon, Who Died in the Line of Duty
BASENAME: honoring-memory-cincinnati-firefighter-family-man-daryl-gordon-died-line-duty
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/20/2015 12:47:01 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2016 size-full" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Cincinnati-Firefighter-and-Family-Man-Daryl-Gordon.jpg" alt="Cincinnati Firefighter and Family Man Daryl Gordon" width="301" height="360">In the early morning hours of March 26, 2015, Cincinnati lost a hero. Firefighter and family man Daryl Gordon lost his life in the line of duty when he fell into an elevator shaft of a burning apartment building. Having served almost 30 years and just months from his retirement, Fire Apparatus Operator and Explosive Ordinance Disposal Technician Daryl Gordon lost his life doing what he loved the most &#x2013; saving lives.

Gordon leaves behind his wife, Angela and their two daughters, Angelique and Chelsea.
<h2>Protecting the community we love</h2>
Fire fighters are an integral part of our community. They are our heroes. They are the ones who are willing to run into a burning building and carry people out to safety. Every shift they know that their lives could be in danger, yet they are willing to step into dangerous situations every day to keep the members of their community safe from fires.

FAO Gordon&#x2019;s life work was keeping people safe from fires, so we&#x2019;d like to share these safety tips that can help prevent fires, and to help you keep you safe if a fire starts in your home:
<ul>
    <li>Make sure all of the smoke detectors and fire alarm system works in your building. A beeping fire alarm needs new batteries.</li>
    <li>Check for electrical hazards.</li>
    <li>Keep matches and lighters away from children.</li>
    <li>Never store flammable liquids in your home.</li>
    <li>Explore your building and be aware of all of the safety exists.</li>
    <li>Decide on a meeting place where everyone will meet after getting out the apartment.</li>
    <li>Never use the elevator in case of a fire.</li>
    <li>Rehearse an escape route with all of the members of your household.</li>
    <li>Once you have safely escaped a fire call 911 immediately.</li>
</ul>
According to WCPO.com, federal investigators will look into what led up to FAO Gordon&apos;s tragic line-of-duty death. The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health will also take part in the investigation to determine if training or command played a role in fire fighter Gordon&apos;s death.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, our thoughts and prayers are with FAO Gordon&#x2019;s family, fellow fire fighters and the three firefighters who were injured in the Madisonville fire.

KEYWORDS:

-----


--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Don&apos;t Let the Fancy Amenities Fool You: Nursing Home Neglect in the Race for Medicare Dollars is Rampant
BASENAME: dont-let-fancy-amenities-fool-nursing-home-neglect-race-medicare-dollars-rampant
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/22/2015 10:02:49 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2019" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/nursing-home-neglect-200x300.jpg" alt="nursing home neglect" width="200" height="300">A recent <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/15/business/as-nursing-homes-chase-lucrative-patients-quality-of-care-is-said-to-lag.html"><em>New York Times</em></a> article describes how, despite the promised luxurious amenities, many nursing facilities have a poor quality of care. There is a massive shift going on in the nursing home industry to appeal to short-term Medicare patients and turning away from catering to lower-paying Medicaid patients. However, in the rush to appeal to higher-paying Medicaid patients, it is the patients themselves who are losing out because many of these facilities do not offer the care that these patients need.
<h2>The crux of the problem</h2>
When elderly patients leave the hospital after an illness or injury, they often stay in nursing homes funded by Medicare to recuperate before going home. Medicare pays 84% more for short-term patients than these nursing facilities get for Medicaid patients, which makes competition intense to attract the Medicare patients.

But a 2014 report by <a href="http://oig.hhs.gov/oei/reports/oei-06-11-00370.pdf">the Department of Health and Human Services&apos;</a> Office of Inspector General found that 22% of Medicare residents experienced adverse events during their stay at a nursing home. (An adverse event is described as one that required a prolonged stay in the nursing facility, transfer to a hospital, permanent harm, life-sustaining intervention or death.) The report estimates that 21,777 Medicare residents experienced an adverse event, and 2.6% experienced more than one; some of those patients experienced three events during a single stay at a nursing facility.
<h2>Abuse and neglect of the elderly</h2>
The <em>NYT</em> article talks about the lofty promises of care that the Watermark at Logan Square nursing facility in Philadelphia made to Dr. Lois Johnson-Hammerman, who ended up being taken to the emergency room with a dangerously infected bedsore. She was promised hot baths and quality health care, but in reality she had difficulty getting the staff to bathe her, change her diaper and turn her every few hours to prevent bedsores.

In another sad example of neglect, Mary Dwyer, age 87, checked into the Harborview Healthcare Center after having fallen and dislocated her shoulder when she fell. The care Mrs. Dwyer received at the nursing facility was negligent, as described by her family. They did not feed her properly, they did not reposition her in bed frequently, and in just one month after she lost 20 lbs. and developed a bed sore down to the bone. She was sent to the hospital to get care for her injuries and died a month later. Her family won $13 million in a wrongful death action, which the nursing home is appealing.
<h2>Protecting your loved ones</h2>
If you must put a loved one into a nursing facility, here are a few tips from the National Institutes of Health to keep in mind:
<ul>
    <li><strong>Consider</strong> what is most important to you in a nursing facility-- the quality of nursing care, the food, the physical therapy, connection to your religious faith? Is it important that the facility be close so that family and friends can easily visit?</li>
    <li><strong>Ask</strong> your friends, relatives, and social workers what facilities they recommend. Use their suggestions to make a short list.</li>
    <li><strong>Call</strong> each place on your short list. Ask about how many resident they have, what the costs are, and if they meet the priorities you considered earlier.</li>
    <li><strong>Visit </strong>the facility. Meet the director and the nursing staff.</li>
    <li>Ask questions. Look at the condition of the residents and notice if they seem well cared for and content. Does the place smell clean? Find out about the rate of turnover in the nursing staff, food service and social service departments. Finally, make a second, surprise visit at mealtime. Does the dining room look clean? Does the food look appetizing?</li>
    <li>Carefully read the contracts before you make your final selections. Talk with the director to get answers for your questions so that you are clear before you sign and pay.</li>
</ul>
Taking the time to select the right facility is vital in protecting your loved ones. If you have a loved one in a nursing home, visit as often as you can &#x2013; several times a week if possible &#x2013; to see the kind of care they are receiving. Be a constant presence and make sure that the staff knows that you are keeping an eye on your family members&#x2019; care.

If you have a loved one who has experienced abuse or neglect in a nursing facility, you may be able to take legal action against the facility. Schedule a consultation with a nursing home neglect attorney who can answer your questions and advise you of your rights.

Contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law today to discuss your nursing home negligence case. We&#x2019;ll give you the answers you need and fight to protect your rights.

AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: What You Need To Know About LIPITOR
BASENAME: what-you-need-to-know-about-lipitor
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/27/2015 03:08:45 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2023 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/danger-drugs-liptor-300x290.jpg" alt="danger drugs LIPITOR" width="300" height="290">Lipitor has been in the news for a long time. In 2012, the Food and Drug Administration released updates on health complications from Lipitor, including risk of high blood sugar and development of diabetes. A study released the same year found the post-menopausal women taking Lipitor were at a <a href="http://archinte.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1108676">48% higher risk</a> of developing diabetes than those who did not take the drug.
<h2>What is Lipitor?</h2>
Lipitor, which is manufactured by Pfizer, is a statin: statins are prevent the body from creating the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, which is used by the liver to create cholesterol. By preventing the production of the enzyme, statin drugs like Lipitor can help lower cholesterol and reduce the risk of heart attack or stroke.

Lipitor was approved for use by the FDA in 1996, and quickly became the gold standard for high cholesterol patients. The drug is extremely effective. It is chemically designed to block the production of &#x201C;bad&#x201D; cholesterol and raise levels of &#x201C;good&#x201D; cholesterol.
<h2>Why Lipitor can be dangerous</h2>
Unfortunately, Lipitor is not nearly the perfect cholesterol drug it was believed to be. Pfizer did not properly indicate potential risks until 2012 &#x2013; <em>sixteen years</em> after the drug became publicly available. Lipitor has a relatively high risk of serious side effects, including:
<ul>
    <li>Diabetes</li>
    <li>High blood sugar (hyperglycemia)</li>
    <li>Muscle and joint problems</li>
    <li>Myopathy (muscle tissue fiber damage)</li>
    <li>Rhabdomyolysis (severe myopathy resulting in muscle death)</li>
    <li>Liver disease or injury</li>
    <li>Cardiovascular disease</li>
</ul>
To date, about 2,000 lawsuits have been consolidated in the court of the District of South Carolina. The first of the bellwether trials (where a small number of cases are tried in lieu of all the cases, thus eliminating costly and time-consuming litigation while also giving the plaintiffs and the defendant, Pfizer, a good understanding of how a jury will find and how much compensation might be expected, should the jury find for the plaintiffs) are expected to begin in November of 2015. There is still time to file a lawsuit.

Medical side effects, though rare, can have serious implications. Taking Lipitor can have lifelong repercussions. If you or a loved one is currently taking Lipitor, please take the time to discuss these concerns with a medical professional. If you or someone you know has taken Lipitor in the past and suffered complications, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> to schedule a consultation at one of our multiple offices throughout Ohio and Kentucky.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Suit Alleges Testosterone Gels Mostly Prescribed For Off-Label Use
BASENAME: suit-alleges-testosterone-gels-mostly-prescribed-for-off-label-use
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/04/2015 12:20:07 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2040" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/gavel-300x199.jpg" alt="Gavel on sounding block" width="300" height="199">A slew of drugs have hit the market in the past few years to treat low testosterone in men. Some of these drugs are injectable and some come in the form of a topical gel. While there are many options, one thing is becoming clear; the side effects are outweighing the potential benefits.

There is a legitimate market for these drugs. A condition called male <a href="http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/male-hypogonadism/basics/definition/con-20014235">hypogonadism</a>, in which a man&#x2019;s body does not produce enough testosterone, can be treated with testosterone supplements. The condition can be inherited or be the result of injury or infection. In these cases, testosterone supplements can be a lifesaver.

When testosterone supplements are prescribed for anyone not suffering from hypogonadism, however, the effects can be disastrous. Topical gels can transfer to sexual partners, boosting testosterone to dangerously high levels in women. Because of a massive amount of lawsuits against the makers of &#x201C;Low T&#x201D; products, a consolidated suit is pending in the U.S. District Court in the Northern District of Illinois.

The consolidated suit could have important ramifications; mainly, it hopes to effect changes in the ability of drug manufacturers to advertise directly to potential customers. The suit claims that manufacturers essentially created a condition (Low-T) by spending millions of dollars on advertising campaigns.

<a href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/arleneweintraub/2015/04/06/whats-next-for-the-thousands-of-angry-men-suing-over-testosterone/">According to Forbes</a>, &#x201C;AbbVie [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][the manufacturer of AndroGel] initially estimated that hypogonadism affects about a million men, but shortly after AndroGel was approved in 2000, the company announced that the market had grown to at least four million potential patients. By 2003, the complaint says, that number was 20 million. &#x2018;These numbers did not, and could not represent, the number of men with the conditions for which AndroGel is indicated, which are believed to be substantially smaller,&#x2019; the complaint reads.&#x201D;
<h2>Dangerous side effects</h2>
These topical gels can also cause a range of other side effects in otherwise healthy men, including:
<ul>
    <li>Prostate cancer</li>
    <li>Enlarged blood cells</li>
    <li>Reduced sperm count</li>
    <li>Edema</li>
    <li>Enlarged breasts in men (gynecomastia)</li>
    <li>Sleep apnea</li>
    <li>High cholesterol</li>
</ul>
If you are currently taking a prescription testosterone supplement or have taken one in the past, we advise you to contact a medical professional for a full checkup. If you have suffered adverse effects from off-label use of any prescribed drug, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> for a free consultation at one of our Ohio or Kentucky offices.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]

AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Organic Food Companies Recall Spinach Products Due to Listeria Contamination
BASENAME: organic-food-companies-recall-spinach-products-due-to-listeria-contamination
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/29/2015 12:36:28 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2036 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/organic-spinach-300x200.jpg" alt="orgaic spinach recall" width="300" height="200">

Going organic is one of the latest trends in health food; organic foods are supposed to be free of harmful pesticides and growth-enhancing drugs. However, growing foods without harsh chemicals can have unintended consequences. A recent recall by four organic food companies highlights this issue.

Amy&#x2019;s Kitchen, Rising Moon Organics, Superior Foods, and Twin City Foods have recalled products because of listeria-contaminated spinach from an organic supplier. Some of the products sold by Twin City Foods were re-sold later under the Wegman&#x2019;s brand name.

While FDA policy does not require the supplier to be named or to comment on whether it is investigating a particular issue, <a href="http://abcnews.go.com/Health/amys-kitchen-recall-spinach-listeria-outbreak/story?id=29894726">ABC News</a> reports that Coastal Green LLC of Oxnard, California supplied &#x201C;leafy greens&#x201D; to all of the above-listed companies. Spokesman for the company, Paul Fanelli, said, &#x201C;We&#x2019;re in the middle of an investigation here as to what the root cause was of the listeria. Once we determine what that is, we&#x2019;ll change our policies and our procedures accordingly.&#x201D;
<h2>The dangers associated with listeria</h2>
Listeria is a bacterial contaminant. If ingested, it can cause listeriosis, a serious infection. The elderly, newborns, pregnant women, and those with a weakened immune system are at higher risk, but anyone can be infected if proper care isn&#x2019;t taken to wash raw foods. Common symptoms of listeriosis can include:
<ul>
    <li>Headache</li>
    <li>Stiff neck</li>
    <li>Confusion</li>
    <li>Loss of balance</li>
    <li>Convulsions</li>
    <li>Fever, fatigue, and headaches (in pregnant women)</li>
</ul>
According to the <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/treatment.html">Center for Disease Control and Prevention</a>:

&#x201C;Listeriosis is treated with antibiotics. A person in a higher-risk category (pregnant woman, older adults, and people with weakened immune systems) who experiences fever and other non-specific symptoms, such as fatigue and aches, within 2 months of eating contaminated food should seek medical care and tell the physician or health care provider about eating the contaminated food...Even with prompt treatment, some listeriosis cases result in death. This is particularly likely in older adults and in persons with other serious medical problems.&#x201D;

For a full list of the recalled products, we encourage you to visit the manufacturer&#x2019;s websites; Amy&#x2019;s Kitchen, Rising Moon Organics, Superior Foods, and Twin City Foods. These products are commonly distributed throughout the United States. Any organic food product containing spinach should be checked against a database. Any organic spinach products purchased recently should be thrown out. If you have any of the symptoms listed above, please seek medical attention immediately.

Listeriosis is a dangerous and potentially deadly illness. If you or a family member have gotten ill because of your food, or if a doctor failed to recognize the symptoms of the condition in a timely manner, Crandall &amp; Pera Law wants to hear your story. Please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact the firm</a> to speak with a skilled liability lawyer at one of our multiple office locations throughout Ohio and Kentucky.

AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Paramedics Dropped Gurney; Death Ruled Accidental
BASENAME: paramedics-dropped-gurney-death-ruled-accidental
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 05/08/2015 10:19:26 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2045" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/ambulance-300x171.jpg" alt="ambulance" width="300" height="171">The Northfield Fire Department responded to an emergency call on March 26. On arrival, paramedics were moving Charles Borton, 81, from his house to a waiting ambulance when they dropped the gurney, causing Borton to strike his head. Borton passed away three days later.

The Cuyahoga County Medical Examiner recently released a report that listed skull and brain injuries as conditions related to his death &#x2013; yet the primary cause of Borton&#x2019;s death was heart disease.

Though the circumstances surrounding Charles Borton&#x2019;s death do seem a bit &#x201C;odd,&#x201D; it is possible that the head injury he suffered led to a blood clot, which could have led to his death. It is also possible that the trauma affected already weakened blood vessels or a strained heart, and no information has come forth disputing it. According to the American Heart Association, &#x201C;Heart and blood vessel disease &#x2014; also called&#xA0;<a href="http://www.heart.org/HEARTORG/Conditions/More/MyHeartandStrokeNews/Coronary-Artery-Disease---Coronary-Heart-Disease_UCM_436416_Article.jsp">heart disease</a>&#xA0;&#x2014; includes numerous problems, many of which are related to a process called <a href="http://www.heart.org/HEARTORG/Conditions/Cholesterol/WhyCholesterolMatters/Atherosclerosis_UCM_305564_Article.jsp">atherosclerosis</a>. Atherosclerosis is a condition that develops when a substance called plaque builds up in the walls of the arteries. This buildup narrows the arteries, making it harder for blood to flow through. If a blood clot forms, it can stop the blood flow. This can cause a heart attack or stroke.&#x201D;

Charles Borton&#x2019;s head injury could have exacerbated any number of heart disease-related problems, leading to:
<ul>
    <li><strong>Heart attack.</strong> A heart attack happens when a clot blocks blood flow to a part of the heart. If the clot completely blocks blood flow, heart tissue can be damaged.</li>
    <li><strong>Ischemic Stroke.&#xA0;</strong>The most common type of stroke happens when blood flow to the brain is interrupted. A stroke can cause irreparable brain damage.</li>
    <li><strong>Hemorrhagic Stroke.</strong> This type of stroke happens when a blood vessel in the brain bursts. Hemorrhagic stroke can be the result of hypertension.</li>
    <li><strong>Heart failure. </strong>Heart failure can also be called congestive heart failure. As the heart weakens, it becomes unable to maintain an adequate amount of oxygenated blood to the body.</li>
    <li>Arrhythmia is irregular beating of the heart. Whether too fast or too slow, arrhythmia can cause a variety of health issues.</li>
    <li><strong>Heart valve problems. </strong>When heart valves don&#x2019;t work properly, they can allow too much or too little blood to flow through. In certain cases, heart valve problems can allow blood to flow the wrong way.</li>
</ul>
Or Mr. Borton&#x2019;s death could have been the direct result of his traumatic brain injury, and the case of death is listed as heart disease to avoid liability &#x2013; even though emergency workers are often exempt from liability when in the course of attempting to save a life, and the fall was ruled an accident. In any event, we wonder if this tragic case is not an example of post-mortem misdiagnosis.

For more information about liability laws in Ohio and Kentucky, we invite you to <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a>. Our skilled medical malpractice attorneys can help you learn more about your options.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Anti-Nausea Drug Zofran Has Serious Side Effects on Mom and Baby
BASENAME: anti-nausea-drug-zofran-has-serious-side-effects-on-mom-and-baby
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/06/2015 01:17:12 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2043 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Zofran-Has-Serious-Side-Effects-on-Mom-and-Baby-300x216.jpg" alt="Zofran Has Serious Side Effects on Mom and Baby" width="300" height="216">

The <a href="http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/DrugSafety/PostmarketDrugSafetyInformationforPatientsandProviders/ucm271924.htm">U.S. Food and Drug Administration</a> has warned that taking Zofran or its generic equivalent, ondansetron, while pregnant can cause serious birth defects. The product is still available because it has other uses, but pregnant women and doctors should be aware of the potential dangers of the drug.
<h2>What is Zofran?</h2>
The drug blocks natural chemicals that are responsible for nausea and vomiting. Zofran can be taken orally or intravenously. Zofran was originally intended to treat cancer victims suffering nausea as a result of surgery, radiation or chemotherapy. Because the drug is so effective, doctors are turning to the anti-nausea treatment for pregnant patients experiencing morning sickness.

According to the <a href="http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/003119.htm">National Institute of Health</a>, morning sickness usually occurs for the first three or four months of pregnancy, and eventually tapers off. While uncomfortable and frustrating, morning sickness poses very little health risks unless it is so severe that the pregnant mother loses a lot of weight because of &#x201C;severe vomiting.&#x201D;
<h2>Complications with morning sickness</h2>
If the nausea is severe and accompanied by vomiting, doctors can prescribe an anti-nausea drug. Unfortunately, drugs like Zofran are more likely to be prescribed during the first trimester, when the developing fetus is most vulnerable. The studies surrounding the drug are controversial, but four main potential birth defects have been identified:
<ul>
    <li>Musculoskeletal anomalies, such as club feet</li>
    <li>Mouth deformities, like cleft palate</li>
    <li>Jaundice</li>
    <li>Heart defects</li>
</ul>
If you are experiencing morning sickness and your doctor decides to prescribe medication, it is important that you discuss any potential side effects. While the studies regarding the effect of Zofran on pregnant women may not all agree, the Department of Justice filed a lawsuit against the drug&#x2019;s maker, GlaxoSmithKline, in 2012 for promoting off-label use of Zofran and other drugs. The lawsuit resulted in a $3 billion settlement.

GlaxoSmithKline readily admitted that the drug had not been tested on pregnant women; some patients taking the drug have reported rashes, shortness of breath, constipation, irregular heartbeat, dizziness, fainting, and difficulty breathing and swallowing.

If you were prescribed Zofran or its generic equivalent during your pregnancy, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> for more information. As a premier medical malpractice and liability law firm serving Ohio and Kentucky, we can help you understand your rights as a victim, and counsel you as to your next steps if you wish to pursue compensation.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Ohio State Malpractice Lawsuit Garners Little Attention
BASENAME: ohio-state-malpractice-lawsuit-garners-little-attention
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 05/01/2015 03:25:22 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-135" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/medical-featured-300x200.jpg" alt="Medical Malpractice" width="300" height="200">Becky Colcord had a CAT scan in 2004 at the Ohio State Medical Center. Her radiologist failed to notice a cancerous mass that was visible on the images. In 2010, she was diagnosed with bone cancer and underwent surgery at OSU. She received no follow-up treatment from the center. Colcord later had to undergo further cancer-related surgeries.

Last month, OSU settled with Colcord for $800,000 in the Ohio Court of Claims. As a matter of course, OSU admitted no liability by settling the lawsuit. This information was published in <a href="http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2015/03/30/osu_settles_lawsuit.html"><em>The Columbus Dispatch</em></a>, but the story has not been picked up by media giants or even anyone outside of the state. The sad fact of the matter is that settlements like this are becoming all too common.

Medical malpractice can devastate patients and their families. This particular case of malpractice falls under failure to diagnose; had Becky&#x2019;s pelvic mass been properly identified in 2004, she would not have faced later surgery. The lack of follow-up treatment after her surgery is particularly inexcusable in light of the original failure to diagnose.
<h2>A cascade of additional problems</h2>
A cancer diagnosis causes fear, anger, and anxiety. Time is of the essence, as early detection can drastically affect the treatment outcome. When doctors fail to correctly diagnose cancer, they rob their patients of timely treatment that could have saved them from long, drawn-out chemotherapy sessions, surgeries or even a tragic death. Cancer misdiagnosis can be the result of:
<ul>
    <li><strong>Mistakes made in the lab.&#xA0;</strong>If a lab technician makes an error or loses a culture, there could be a delay in the doctor&#x2019;s ability to recognize a cancer. Poorly or insufficiently trained technicians also increase the risk of a mistake, as do poorly maintained medical devices.</li>
    <li><strong>Failure to read the results correctly.</strong>Doctors who misread the lab results or ignore important elements of the results may diagnose a cancer patient with a different condition entirely.</li>
    <li><strong>Miscommunication between all parties.</strong>Failure to request or send medical histories, failure to include all parts of a test or failure to inform a patient about the results of a test could all lead to a delay in treatment. In some cases, a doctor who does not spend adequate time with his or her patients may not recognize that the lab results are wrong, or that the lab results actually belong to another patient.</li>
    <li><strong>Relying too heavily on past experience</strong>. While the experience of medical personnel is usually a benefit to patients, it can also sway a doctor or specialist to discount certain signs or avoid additional testing based on preconceived notions &#x2013; such as assuming a male patient&#x2019;s symptoms are not breast cancer simply because he is male.</li>
</ul>
No one should be made to suffer needlessly at the hands of competent medical professionals. If you or someone you know has suffered because of an undiagnosed illness, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law </a>to learn more about your rights and how we can help. We have secured the futures of people throughout Ohio and Kentucky, and we want to help secure yours, too.
-----

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Nursing Home Costs on the Rise
BASENAME: nursing-home-costs-on-the-rise
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/14/2015 08:13:16 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2064 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/nursing-home-rates-on-the-rise-300x200.jpg" alt="Senior woman with her caregiver at home" width="300" height="200">

Finding a nursing home for your loved one is never an easy process. A high standard of care and good reviews are a must, but these come with a high sticker price. Long-term care is more expensive than ever, making finding the right provider for your loved one more difficult than ever.

<a href="http://insurancenewsnet.com/oarticle/2015/04/20/aging-costs-on-the-rise-survey-says-a-614238.html">A recent industry survey found that</a> &#x201C;the median bill for a private room in a nursing home is now&#xA0;$91,250&#xA0;a year. This past year, it was&#xA0;$87,600, according to Genworth Financial, a&#xA0;Virginia-based life insurance company.&#x201D; The survey was based on 15,000 long-term care providers across the country. The findings were illuminating; prices varied greatly in different areas, with West Virginia averaging $107,631 for a year of care. That cost breaks down to just under $300 <em>per day</em>, which is far beyond the capabilities of most families.

With costs on the rise, nursing homes are catering to wealthier clients to help offset the high cost of care. For the less well off, these price increases and the associated quality of care can be the difference between life and death for an aging loved one.
<h2>How to pay for long-term care</h2>
There are alternatives to paying out of pocket. Medicare can cover short-term care costs and even home health aides, but will not help with long-term care. Medicaid can cover the entire cost of long-term care, but strict conditions must be met.

Additionally, the Veterans Administration Aid and Attendance assists veterans and/or their spouses. This little used resource can be a godsend when looking for quality care for your loved one.

Finding the right nursing home can affect your entire family&#x2019;s quality of life. There are resources to help you make that choice; we recommend the U.S. News &amp; World Report Nursing Home Search Tool. You can narrow your choices by region, by star rating (the standard 1 through 5 stars is applied) and by whether or not the facility accepts Medicare or Medicaid. You can also ask your doctor to make recommendations based upon your family members&#x2019; specific health needs.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is proud to represent nursing home residents and their families when their rights have been abused. If you live in Ohio, West Virginia or Kentucky, and you or your family members has been abused or neglected in some manner, we invite you to <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today.
-----
EXTENDED BODY:

--------
AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Did You Take Benicar For High Blood Pressure?
BASENAME: did-you-take-benicar-for-high-blood-pressure
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 05/18/2015 02:29:28 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2072" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/high-blood-pressure-300x200.jpg" alt="Did You Take Benicar For High Blood Pressure" width="300" height="200">Around 70 million adults in America have high blood pressure. That equates to one in three adults, and about <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/bloodpressure/facts.htm">half of these people use medication</a> to control their hypertension. High blood pressure increases the risk of heart attack, stroke, chronic heart failure, and kidney disease.

Benicar (olmesartan medoxomil) is a common prescription drug used to control hypertension. While the drug does lower the risk of cardiovascular problems, this may come at a higher cost than anyone anticipated.

Benicar has been linked to severe gastrointestinal problems. The <a href="http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/DrugSafety/ucm359477.htm">conditions caused by Benicar</a> include sprue-like enteropathy and villious atrophy, which destroys the finger-like villi in the intestinal that absorb nutrients from food. Symptoms can include chronic diarrhea, malnutrition and weight loss.

The side effects of Benicar are very similar to Celiac disease. Because of this, doctors can misdiagnose these side effects, which can have serious long-term health effects. A Food and Drug Administration report based on data from the Mayo Clinic called Benicar&#x2019;s side effects &#x201C;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3538487/">life-threatening</a>.&#x201D;
<h2>Signs and symptoms</h2>
While symptoms improved after stopping use of the drug, damage to the gastrointestinal system can be permanent. In addition to these severe effects, Benicar has been associated with:
<ul>
    <li>Abdominal pain</li>
    <li>Nausea</li>
    <li>Vomiting</li>
    <li>Kidney damage</li>
    <li>Liver damage</li>
    <li>Chest pain</li>
    <li>Arthritis</li>
    <li>Hair loss</li>
    <li>Angioedema (swelling of the skin)</li>
</ul>
Damage caused by the medication is not only serious in the short term, resulting in severe weight loss and malnutrition, but the long-term effects can accrue medical bills staggeringly quickly. When the villi of the intestine are damaged, it can become impossible for you to absorb necessary nutrients from food. In extreme cases, malnutrition can result in permanent organ damage and death.

Furthermore, Benicar may lead to fetal toxicity, making the drug especially dangerous to pregnant women. If the drug passes through the placental membrane, it could lead to developmental defects later. It could also potentially cause the death of your child.

If you are taking Benicar, we advise you talk to your doctor immediately. Other medications with less severe side effects are available. If you have experienced any of the side effects listed above from prescription Benicar and have found it necessary to seek medical attention, Crandall &amp; Pera Law is here to help you. Please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact our firm</a> to schedule a consultation at one of our multiple office locations throughout Ohio and Kentucky.
-----
EXTENDED BODY:

EXCERPT:

-----
KEYWORDS:

-----


--------
AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Electronic Health Records May Be More Dangerous Than Helpful
BASENAME: electronic-health-records-may-be-more-dangerous-than-helpful
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/20/2015 03:07:47 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2076" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/medical-health-records-300x200.jpg" alt="Electronic Health Records May Be More Dangerous Than Helpful" width="300" height="200">Electronic health records, or EHRs, are increasingly being included in medical malpractice lawsuits. The transition from paper records to electronic records has many stumbling blocks, not least of which include data management. In addition, the complexities of new record keeping systems can be challenging to doctors and nurses; learning to navigate new computer systems is daunting.

An <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2015/05/electronic-record-errors-growing-issue-in-lawsuits-117591.html">article published recently in Politico</a> names EHRs as a main cause of medical malpractice cases in the eyes of insurers as well:

&#x201C;According to a review by The Doctors Company, the largest physician-owned U.S. medical malpractice insurer, EHR issues were involved in only 1 percent of a sample of lawsuits concluded from 2007 through 2013. But that finding could be deceptive since it takes five or six years to close a suit, and during that period the numbers of such cases grew rapidly as electronic health records become more pervasive in hospitals and physician offices. The pace of these cases&#xA0;<a href="http://www.thedoctors.com/KnowledgeCenter/Publications/TheDoctorsAdvocate/CON_ID_006908">doubled</a>&#xA0;from 2013 to early 2014.&#x201D;

The lawsuits allege a variety of mistakes, from typos to imperfect voice recognition, that result in medication errors and bad status updates. Sometimes, the information contained in an EHR does not link up with reality. &#x201C;In one case, a patient in septic shock had suffered gangrene and a severe skin rash, but computer records read &#x2018;skin normal.&#x2019; They also showed repeated physician interviews with the patient &#x2014; when she was comatose,&#x201D; according to Politico.

A spokesperson for the Electronic Health Record Association said the industry &#x201C;takes very seriously the need to enhance the well-documented ability of EHRs to increase patient safety. It also recognizes the importance of looking for opportunities to identify and reduce any potential risk associated with development and use of EHRs.&#x201D;

However, the commitment of the industry to making EHRs safer and more valuable does not help when faulty medical records or prescription errors put your or your family at risk. The errors go beyond typos and misuse; the complexity of medical diagnoses can be difficult to relate in digital form. When doctors take an EHR as gospel, there can be significant information gaps that lead to fatal misunderstandings.

It is vital to understand the role that EHRs play in medical malpractice cases. While they offer an opportunity to increase safety and help doctors make better decisions, it should be understood that EHRs are still very much in their infancy. We will continue to bring you more information about how EHRs can affect your standard of care. In the meantime, if you have been misdiagnosed or untreated because of faulty records, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> for a free consultation at one of our office locations throughout Ohio and Kentucky.
-----
