AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Clogged Breathing Tubes Can Kill
BASENAME: clogged-breathing-tubes-can-kill
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/15/2015 10:19:22 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2070" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/breathing-machine-300x200.jpg" alt="Ventilator machine in hospital operating room" width="300" height="200">The <a href="http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/health-topics/topics/trach">National Institute of Health</a> tells us that, &#x201C;A tracheostomy (TRA-ke-OS-to-me) is a surgically made hole that goes through the front of your neck and into your trachea (TRA-ke-ah), or windpipe. The hole is made to help you breathe.

A tracheostomy usually is temporary, although you can have one long term or even permanently. How long you have a tracheostomy depends on the condition that required you to get it and your overall health.

Tracheostomies are generally performed when someone needs to be on a ventilator for a significant period of time. Ventilators support breathing, and are connected to a trach tube that supplies oxygen-rich air directly to the lungs. During ventilation, it is also necessary to suction out naturally occurring mucus to keep the airways clear.

Ventilators are lifesaving machines. As with all medical devices,&#xA0;they carry an inherent degree of risk. In this case, anyone on a ventilator is completely dependent on a health care provider to keep them alive. Often the patient is unconscious and unable to alert anyone if a problem occurs.
<h2>The dangers of unclean equipment</h2>
Ventilators and trach tubes are made from medical grade plastic, but the warm, moist air from exhalation and the natural bacteria present in the throat can lead to bacterial colony growth in the equipment. If the tubes are not cleaned regularly, mucus can build up inside of them, ultimately cutting off the oxygen flow that ventilators are designed to provide. When this happens, hypoxia sets in quickly. If help takes too long, death will follow shortly thereafter.

According to the <a href="http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/000013.htm">U.S. National Library of Medicine</a>, permanent brain damage can occur after only four minutes without oxygen, and death can occur in as little as four minutes after that.

If your loved one is on a ventilator, it is important to be vigilant and ask questions about the standard of care they are receiving. Unconscious or infirm patients benefit from having an advocate. When accidents happen, we are here to be your advocate. Please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> to learn more about your options if your loved one was harmed because of a negligent healthcare provider in an Ohio nursing home.

AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Woman Paralyzed Following Childbirth Wins Malpractice Suit
BASENAME: woman-paralyzed-following-childbirth-wins-malpractice-suit
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/26/2015 12:17:52 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2082" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/medical-malpractice-300x208.jpg" alt="medical malpractice" width="300" height="208">Andrea Larkin ran the Boston Marathon in 2004. After the race, she experienced dizzy spells and went to Dedham Medical Associates to be treated. There, she was seen by Dr. Jehane Johnston. Johnston ordered an MRI and CAT scan, which showed brain abnormalities.

According to the <a href="http://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2015/05/07/walpole-woman-awarded-million-medical-malpractice-case-lawyer-says/yxUOo2yzRNBZtVOzZSdvjL/story.html">Boston Globe</a>, these abnormalities required Johnston &#x201C;to place Larkin on a special list of patients with certain medical conditions that other doctors can access... Johnston failed to place Larkin&#x2019;s name on the list. When Larkin became pregnant four years later, her obstetrician was not aware of her brain issues because her name did not appear in the database.&#x201D;

Had Mrs. Larkin&#x2019;s obstetrician been aware of her condition, a caesarean section would have been ordered because of the danger to the mother during birth. Unfortunately, because of the Dr. Johnston&#x2019;s negligence, Mrs. Larkin delivered her daughter, Alexa, naturally. Within hours of Alexa&#x2019;s birth, Mrs. Larkin suffered a massive stroke, leaving her completely paralyzed except for some movement in her right arm.
<h2>Justice for the Larkins</h2>
Andrea Larkin goes to therapy sessions twice a week, but she requires caregivers and is mostly homebound. The Larkin family pays most of their expenses (such as for care givers) out of pocket, and it costs approximately $200,000 a year to get Mrs. Larkin the proper care she needs.

After years of litigation and endless medical expenses and experts, there is finally hope for Tim and Andrea Larkin. A jury awarded the family $35.4 million, finding Dr. Johnston and Dedham Medical Associates guilty of medical malpractice. Tim Larkin said he hopes the jury award &#x201C;can help bring some comfort to her moving forward to give her the best possible support that she needs,&#x201D; according to the Globe.

While doctors make small mistakes every day, what happened to Andrea Larkin and her family is inexcusable and devastating. A lack of accountability led to a mother being paralyzed and a family with mountains of medical expenses. We are happy that in this case justice was served.

If you or someone you know has been misdiagnosed or suffered because of a medical mistake, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law </a>to find out what your options are. We have successfully represented victims of medical malpractice all over Ohio and Kentucky, obtaining millions of dollars for our clients in jury verdicts and settlements. Let us help you protect your family and your future.

AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Pitocin and Birth Injuries: What You Should Know
BASENAME: pitocin-and-birth-injuries-what-you-should-know
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/29/2015 12:43:08 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2140" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Pitocin-and-Birth-Injuries-300x200.jpg" alt="Pitocin and Birth Injuries" width="300" height="200">Pitocin is the brand name of a <a href="http://www.drugs.com/mtm/pitocin.html">drug called oxytocin</a>, a natural hormone. Oxytocin is commonly administered to either induce labor or strengthen contractions during labor. While a Pitocin injection is generally considered helpful during difficult births, one study &#x201C;found that the use of Pitocin to induce or augment labor was linked to unexpected admissions to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) and to lower Apgar scores,&#x201D; according to the <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/07/pitocin-risks_n_3224811.html">Huffington Post</a>.

The danger to an unborn child can be serious and potentially fatal. Once Pitocin has been administered, labor is either induced or hastened. If complications develop, or go unrecognized, the baby can be starved for oxygen.&#xA0; Stronger contractions can increase the risk of shoulder dystocia, uterine rupture and placental abruption.&#xA0; Doctors generally weigh the risks against the rewards and determine when Pitocin is necessary.

However, the numbers do not lie. The use of Pitocin during labor statistically correlates to a higher rate of problems for infants after birth. The Huffington Post also reported that &#x201C;Pitocin use appeared to be a risk factor for babies being admitted to the NICU and staying for at least one day. It was also tied to&#xA0;<a href="http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/003402.htm">Apgar scores</a>&#xA0;of less than 7. A score under 7 is a red flag, indicating that the baby needs medical attention, but is not an indication that the newborn necessarily has a serious medical condition or that he or she will have lasting health issues.&#x201D;

Use of the drug comes with risks for mom too. Pitocin is administered intravenously, and both mother and child are carefully monitored during labor. However, it can have unintended side effects, especially in mothers who suffer from conditions like diabetes, high blood pressure, arrhythmia, and more. Allergic reactions to Pitocin can additionally complicate labor. Common symptoms of an allergic reaction to Pitocin include:
<ul>
    <li>Fast, slow, or uneven heart rate</li>
    <li>Excessive bleeding long after childbirth</li>
    <li>Headache, confusion, slurred speech, hallucinations, severe vomiting, severe weakness, muscle cramps, loss of coordination, feeling unsteady, seizure (convulsions), fainting, shallow breathing or breathing that stops</li>
    <li>Dangerously high blood pressure (severe headache, blurred vision, buzzing in your ears, anxiety, confusion, chest pain, shortness of breath, uneven heartbeats, seizure).</li>
</ul>
At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we have helped parents and their children from around Ohio and Kentucky who suffered because of problems with Pitocin injections. If you or your child were hurt as a result of Pitocin use during labor, you may be entitled to compensation. Please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> for a free consultation.

AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: New Research Uses Stem Cells To Repair Birth Defect
BASENAME: new-research-uses-stem-cells-to-repair-birth-defect
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 06/03/2015 02:16:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2147" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/stem-cells-300x228.jpg" alt="stem cells" width="300" height="228">&#x201C;Craniosynostosis (kray-nee-o-sin-os-TOE-sis) is a birth defect in which one or more of the joints between the bones of your baby&apos;s skull close prematurely, before your baby&apos;s brain is fully formed. When your baby has craniosynostosis, his or her brain can&apos;t grow in its natural shape and the head is misshapen.&#x201D; The definition of this birth defect comes from the <a href="http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/craniosynostosis/basics/definition/con-20032917">Mayo Clinic</a>, which goes on to say that current treatment methods involve surgery to separate the fused bones.

New research has pinpointed the cause of craniosynostosis, and may have applications for trauma injuries as well as solving the birth defect. According to <a href="http://www.news-medical.net/news/20150423/Stem-cell-treatment-repairs-birth-defect-provides-facial-regeneration-for-people-suffering-traumatic-injury.aspx">News Medical</a>, the research has shown that stem cells actively encourage the damaged bone to heal. If the lab trials prove successful, doctors may be able to avoid complicated, high-risk surgeries where they break the skull into pieces and staple it back together (the current method for fixing the problem). Rather, &#x201C;doctors will be able to help people who have suffered disfiguring facial injuries and infants diagnosed with craniosynostosis through biological means instead of multiple, high-risk surgeries.&#x201D;
<h2>Additional applications</h2>
The procedure could take up to ten years to become publicly available, but it appears to be worth the time and effort. With a true cure for craniosynostosis, children who would otherwise suffer lifelong debilitating injuries could lead normal, successful lives.

Additionally, the procedure can be used to reduce or relieve the effects of:
<ul>
    <li>Open head injuries caused by piercing objects</li>
    <li>Facial disfigurement as a result of an accident or a physical altercation</li>
    <li>Encephalocele, the condition where a baby&#x2019;s brain may poke through a part of its skull</li>
    <li>Skull fractures caused by repeated or jarring hits to the head</li>
</ul>
Research like this comes along once in a great while,&#xA0;but scientists like this are the ones who help to make the world a better place. These findings will wind up saving lives and preventing needless suffering, but, unfortunately, they are still quite a long way off from being commonplace. Until they are, medical bills must be paid and birth injuries can lead to a lifetime of physical and emotional suffering. If your child has suffers from a birth injury, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> for a free consultation in our Ohio or Kentucky office locations.

AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Medical Malpractice 101
BASENAME: medical-malpractice-101
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 06/19/2015 12:06:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<a href="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/medical-malpractice-in-kentucky-and-ohio.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2179" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/medical-malpractice-in-kentucky-and-ohio-300x208.jpg" alt="Medical Malpractice in Kentucky and Ohio" width="300" height="208"></a>We frequently bring you stories from the legal and medical community highlighting medical malpractice prevention and litigation, but rarely do we stop to analyze exactly what medical malpractice is and how it affects you. The following is intended to be a back to basics approach to medical malpractice that will help to more clearly define the concept.
<h2>What is medical malpractice?</h2>
Healthcare workers and physicians are expected to provide a reasonable standard of care in any situation; from emergency room triage to childbirth and at every point along the way, our healthcare system has contingencies in place designed to maximize the chance of a positive outcome for any patient.

When healthcare professionals deviate from these contingencies, malpractice has occurred. Additionally, if other professionals in a given field agree that an action was unwarranted or unnecessarily endangered a patient, malpractice has occurred.
<h2>Common types of medical malpractice</h2>
Medical malpractice is a broad term that covers any number of incidents. Some of the most common forms of medical malpractice include:
<ul>
    <li><strong>Failure to diagnose or misdiagnosis. </strong>A misdiagnosis, or worse, the failure to diagnose an injury or medical condition can lead to unnecessary pain and suffering. This pain can affect every surrounding a patient and lead to a decrease in the quality of life. Sometimes, errors cannot be fully corrected if too much time has passed.</li>
    <li><strong>Prescription and medication errors. </strong>From dosage errors to illegible handwriting, medication errors cause thousands of deaths every year, and even more injuries. Nurses, doctors and pharmacists may be held accountable for a medication error.</li>
    <li><strong>Emergency room errors.</strong> Emergency rooms can be chaotic places, but that does not mean the healthcare workers are exempt from the standard of care. Ignoring patients, misdiagnosing them, misreading their charts &#x2013; all of these can cause irreparable harm to a patient.</li>
    <li><strong>Surgery errors.</strong> From anesthesia mistakes to amputation errors to performing an operation despite open and obvious signs of risk to the patient, a surgical mistake can cause permanent damage to a patient. A doctor who performs a procedure in the attempt to save a person&#x2019;s life but fails to do so may not be guilty of malpractice, but a surgeon who operates under the influence &#x2013; even if the surgery goes perfectly &#x2013; is absolutely guilty.</li>
    <li><strong>Nursing home abuse and neglect.</strong> Caring for aging loved ones can be difficult and time-consuming. We often turn to long-term care facilities to provide for our loved ones, so it is doubly devastating to learn that your loved one has been abused or neglected by trusted professionals. Elder abuse or neglect is the failure of a healthcare professional to observe physical, behavioral, or emotional changes in a patient indicative of a problem.</li>
</ul>
While this list is hardly comprehensive, it does provide a concise idea of medical malpractice; namely, that malpractice is a failure on behalf of a healthcare worker or professional to provide an adequate level of care for you or someone you know. If you believe that you have been the victim of medical malpractice, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law </a>for a free consultation at one of our many offices throughout Ohio and Kentucky.
-----

AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Federal Government Immune to Malpractice Claims
BASENAME: federal-government-immune-to-malpractice-claims
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 06/01/2015 11:25:18 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2142" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/military-medical-malpractice-300x198.jpg" alt="military medical malpractice" width="300" height="198">T.J. Moore was a 19-year-old recruit when he arrived at Lackland Air Force Base last year for basic training. Doctors pulled him from normal training after test results revealed a genetic condition that can lead to sudden death during physical exertion.

Just 9 days later, despite the test results, Moore was running a mile-and-a-half test when he collapsed at the finish line. He was rushed to the hospital, where efforts to save his life failed. His mother, <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/20/us/service-members-are-left-in-dark-on-health-errors.html?ref=politics">Anita Holmes, said</a>, &#x201C;I raised T. J. as a single mother on little income for 19 years, and kept him safe. They had him for nine days and sent him home to me in a box.&#x201D;

This past December, Anita received an official report on the death of her son after months of inquiries. The official Air Force explanation stated that the military followed proper procedure. The explanation admitted no mistakes and no fault.
<h2><strong>Why service members have a more difficult time</strong></h2>
Serious medical mistakes happen all the time, and sometimes getting an accurate version of what went wrong can be difficult, expensive, and time consuming. However, our active-duty service members can have an even more difficult time. According to the <em>New York Times</em>, they &#x201C;are in a special bind, virtually powerless to hold accountable the health care system that treats them.&#x201D;

Service members must use the military medical system; they are unable to seek outside treatment without specific permission. If a service member is hurt or killed during a medical procedure, there is no legal recourse. The Federal Government has immunity and damage caps from cases of malpractice. Because of this totalitarian power, there is no incentive to change a very badly flawed system.

Any errors made by military doctors are not reported to a national database, but are instead reported to an internal database, and then only if a patient is disabled or dies during treatment. Active-duty patients are stonewalled in their efforts to find out about suspected mistakes, and there is no law that allows these people their basic rights as a citizen.

Our military affords us a degree of freedom unmatched anywhere in the world. They keep our borders safe and provide law and order for an incredible number of people. However, our active-duty service members deserve the right to know when they have been wronged. We will continue to fight for that right and for all those who have been injured because of somebody else&#x2019;s negligence.

If you have been a victim of negligence at the Cleveland VA Medical Center, the Lexington VA hospital or any of the military-supported medical centers in Ohio or Kentucky, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> for a free consultation.
-----

AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: 5 Tips for Choosing and Using the Right Sunscreen
BASENAME: 5-tips-for-choosing-and-using-the-right-sunscreen
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 06/08/2015 11:57:49 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2164 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/sunscreen-300x200.jpg" alt="Using the Right Sunscreen" width="300" height="200">

With the start of the summer approaching, we will all be spending a lot more time out of the house and in the sunlight. That means it is time to head to the pharmacy and facedown the confusion of picking up some sunscreen. With all of the choices of brands, and the varying SPFs and price points, sometimes you narrow your choice by which one has the best price and smells the best. But how do you know if it is effective?

An article by Consumer Reports outlines exactly what to look for, and narrows down their Top 15 choices. They recommend sunscreens which:
<ol>
    <li><strong>Have an SPF 30 (but be wary of numbers that are too high)</strong>. The FDA warns that any product claiming an SPF over 50 is &quot;inherently misleading,&#x201D; so choosing a product off the rack without doing your research first can hurt you. Still, you do not want a sunscreen which is too weak, either. Look into sunscreens with an SPF of 30 to start.</li>
    <li><strong>Block 97% or more of UVB rays. </strong>UVB is the Ultraviolet B spectrum of sunlight that causes redness in the skin and sunburn. The sun&apos;s UVB rays are higher in the summertime between 10am and 4pm, and they tend to damage the outer layers of the skin. Choose a sunscreen that provides sufficient UVB protection.</li>
    <li><strong>Provide broad spectrum coverage. </strong>UVA rays are always present in daylight all year round, and exposure to UVA rays accelerates the aging process. Those rays penetrate to deeper layers of the skin than the UVB rays. Exposure to UVA raises melanoma risk and can suppress the immune system. Broad spectrum sunscreen protects the skin from both UVA and UVB.</li>
    <li><strong>Are applied and re-applied every two hours when you are in the sun. </strong>The best sunscreen is the sunscreen that you actually use. Apply sunscreen after you dry off from taking a shower, and let it dry for 10 to 15 minutes before getting dressed to lessen the risk of staining your clothing. Re-apply sunscreen after two hours regardless of whether you see any redness, but also consider finding shade for a while to give your skin a break from the sun.</li>
    <li><strong>Are used in a ratio of 1 teaspoon per body part. </strong>Apply sunscreen liberally, using about one teaspoon per body part. Make sure you apply sunscreen to the inside of the arms and legs, the back of the neck and the tops of the feet.</li>
</ol>
A good sunscreen is the first preventative step to keeping yourself safe when outdoors. A serious sunburn is just as dangerous any other kind of burn, and in some cases could land you or your children in the hospital. Excessive exposure to the sun can also cause melanoma, a treatable yet still potentially deadly cancer.

We want everyone to stay safe and healthy this summer. If you do sustain an injury, we invite you to <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> to schedule a consultation at one of our offices in Ohio or Kentucky.

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: New Study Shows C-Sections Safer For Breech Births
BASENAME: new-study-shows-c-sections-safer-for-breech-births
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 06/22/2015 01:25:09 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2181" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/c-section-birth-300x199.jpg" alt="c section birth" width="300" height="199">A Canadian study recently published in the <a href="http://journals.lww.com/greenjournal/Abstract/2015/05000/Delivery_of_Breech_Presentation_at_Term_Gestation.24.aspx">journal of Obstetrics &amp; Gynecology</a> found that vaginal deliveries of breech babies were significantly more likely to result in birth injury that those delivered by planned C-section. The study included data from 52,671 breech deliveries, and concluded that planned C-section is by far the safest method of delivery for breech babies.
<h2>What is a breech baby?</h2>
During normal pregnancies, the baby shifts around in the womb. Full-term babies naturally rotate so that the head emerges first during delivery. In breech babies, this shift has not occurred, and the legs or buttocks are positioned to emerge first. While vaginal birth is possible for breech babies, there are significant risks to the infant.
<h2>What the study found</h2>
This new study, lead by Dr. Janet Lyons of the University of British Columbia, has quantified those risks, and the results are incredible. Breech babies can be delivered one of three ways; planned C-section, C-section during labor, or vaginally. Those delivered by planned C-section had the lowest incidence of birth injury. Breech babies delivered by C-section during labor were 2.79 times more likely to be injured, while those delivered vaginally were 3.6 times more likely to suffer a birth injury.

Dr. Lyons told the <a href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/05/06/for-breech-births-c-sections-may-be-the-safest-choice/?_r=1">New York Times</a> that &#x201C;The role of the provider is to decide who is suited to a vaginal breech and who is not, and to make sure the woman has all the information to make a good decision.&#x201D; While the final decision is ultimately up to the parents, it is imperative that both parents be fully aware of the risks that a natural birth poses to a breech baby.

Vaginal breech births can have <a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18803893">negative effects</a> on both mother and baby. During a vaginal breech birth, the baby isn&#x2019;t situated to minimize the pressures of labor, and can become stuck in the birth canal resulting in an emergency C-section. Additionally, the mother can suffer cervical or vaginal tearing from the unusual presentation that may require multiple surgeries to correct.

If you discover that your baby is in a breech position, the best single thing you can do is to be well informed. Consult with your doctor and your OBGYN to determine the risks to you and your baby. If you are uncomfortable with the conclusions, get a second opinion. There is everything to be gained by ensuring a healthy delivery for your child. If you or your child suffered injuries because of a breech birth, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> for a free consultation in one of our Ohio or Kentucky offices.

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Birth Injury and Your Family
BASENAME: birth-injury-and-your-family
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 06/12/2015 10:07:49 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2166 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/birth-injury-and-family-200x300.jpg" alt="Birth Injury and Your Family" width="200" height="300">

There is a big difference between congenital birth defects and birth injury. A birth injury, also called a birth trauma, is a physical injury to an infant that occurs during labor. While birth injuries are not terribly common, when they do happen the results can impact your child forever.

Birth injuries are complicated; not only in terms of the damage caused, but also in how the actual injury was allowed to happen. Pregnancy, from inception to delivery, often involves a large number of medical professionals, all of whom must share appropriate information at important stages throughout. From primary care physicians and OBGYN&#x2019;s to nurses and midwives, everyone must function as a team to ensure the health of your child.
<h2>Kinds of negligence</h2>
Childbirth is a delicate process from a medical standpoint &#x2013; though mothers in labor might find it otherwise. There are any number of problems that can arise in an instant, and the presence of a competent medical professional can be invaluable. Some of the more common types of birth injuries can include:
<ul>
    <li><strong>Prenatal negligence</strong> &#x2013; when screening or testing for certain conditions is omitted or improperly administered</li>
    <li><strong>Labor and delivery negligence</strong> &#x2013; when late-stage monitoring is not used or a healthcare worker fails to notice signs of infant distress</li>
    <li><strong>Negligent use of delivery tools</strong> &#x2013; when a vacuum or forceps causes physical harm to an infant when used improperly or in an untimely manner</li>
    <li><strong>Postpartum negligence &#x2013; </strong>when an appropriate standard of care is not administered to a vulnerable infant, resulting in severe injury or death</li>
</ul>
Most types of birth injuries are avoidable, which is all the more devastating to a parent left with a permanently disabled child. Birth injuries can be immediately apparent or take several months to manifest symptoms. In severe cases, infant death can result from improper care.

Birth injuries can and do result in lifelong conditions, including Cerebral Palsy, brachial plexus injury, and Klumpke&#x2019;s palsy to name but a few. Some of these conditions require lifelong medical care and support, and can be emotionally and psychologically devastating to a family.

If your family has been affected by a birth injury, you may be entitled to compensation for medical bills. Our experienced birth injury attorneys and registered nurses can be your family&#x2019;s advocate. If you think you have a case, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> for a free consultation in one of our Ohio or Kentucky office locations.
-----
EXTENDED BODY:

-----
EXCERPT:

-----

--------
AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Can Talking to Patients Prevent Doctors from Being Sued?
BASENAME: can-talking-to-patients-prevent-doctors-from-being-sued
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 06/15/2015 11:42:17 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2168" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/doctor-and-patient-talking-300x200.jpg" alt="doctor discussing with patient" width="300" height="200">Managing one&#x2019;s health is a tricky business: sometimes, you simply do not know what you do not know. That is why we rely on our doctors to answer our questions &#x2013; often before we even know what we want to ask &#x2013; and assuage our fears about new medications, upcoming surgeries or potential illnesses. Yet ask any person who has spent time in a hospital, and you are bound to hear horror stories of doctors only coming in for a few brief moments, or being &#x201C;handled&#x201D; entirely by nurses and interns, of having questions left unanswered.

As it turns out, that lack of communication seems to have a direct correlation to which doctors are sued and which are not. The <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/02/upshot/to-be-sued-less-doctors-should-talk-to-patients-more.html?emc=eta1&amp;abt=0002&amp;abg=0">New York Times</a> looked into numerous studies over the past few decades, and found that the &#x201C;primary care physicians [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][who are] sued less often are those more likely to spend time educating patients about their care, more likely to use humor and laugh with their patients and more likely to try to get their patients to talk and express their opinions. It seems that more likable physicians are less likely to have claims filed against them.&#x201D; In short, the studies show that communication between doctors and patients can reduce the chances of those doctors being sued for malpractice.
<h2>Poor communication and a failure to warn</h2>
The findings make sense, even if the numbers do not: after all, there is no empirical proof that a doctor who talks to his patients is less likely to make a mistake than a doctor who does not. However, the <em>Times </em>found that in one study from 1992, about a &#x201C;third of respondents said that their doctor would not talk openly to them, half said their doctor had tried to mislead them, and <strong>70 percent said that they were not warned about long-term neurodevelopmental problems in their children</strong>&#x201D; who had suffered a &#x201C;permanent injury&#x201D; or who had died (emphasis ours). Thus, the leading reason in these particular malpractice cases is a failure to warn about the potential dangers &#x2013; after all, a doctor who fails to speak with his patients seems most likely to fail to give them pertinent information about the risks a mother and her unborn child may face.

But there is hope: in 2000, the University of Michigan instituted a new program &#x201C;to improve communication around medical errors. When errors occurred, the program encouraged physicians to tell patients about them, how they happened, and what would be done to make them less likely to occur in the future.&#x201D; In follow up studies done in 2010 and 2014, medical malpractice claims dropped by 36% and 58% respectively, and that the costs associated with litigation had dropped more than 60% in both years.

As medical malpractice attorneys, we can attest to just how poor communication often is between patients and their doctors. The <em>Times</em> article draws attention to a very important finding: namely, that patients can be better consumers of healthcare, and that doctors can be better purveyors of healthcare, if the lines of communication are open. A doctor who talks to her patients will likely have better informed and more satisfied patients, and could decrease her chance of being sued for malpractice over a failure to war or inform. It is certainly a start in the right direction.

If you have questions about what constitutes medical malpractice, or of you wish to discuss your experiences with an experienced injury attorney, we invite you to <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a>. We maintain offices throughout Ohio and Kentucky for our clients&#x2019; convenience.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
-----

AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: When Is a Common Risk Actually Malpractice?
BASENAME: when-is-a-common-risk-actually-malpractice
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 06/29/2015 12:59:16 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2082" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/medical-malpractice-300x208.jpg" alt="medical malpractice" width="300" height="208">Surgery is inherently risky. Actively sedating a person and invasively altering an internal part of the body carries a relatively high risk even in routine cases. Competent professionals working together can minimize, and in most cases, eliminate, any major risk to a relatively healthy patient. However, care and responsibility don&#x2019;t end with the surgery. Post-operative evaluations can be crucial to the continued health of a patient.

Melissa Gravitt underwent surgery at age 36 to increase her chances of a successful pregnancy. During the procedure, her small bowel was perforated &#x2013; a serious problem, yes, but a commonly accepted risk for the procedure Ms. Gravitt was undergoing. The surgery was deemed a success and she was sent home.

According to <a href="http://chronicle.augusta.com/news/crime-courts/2015-06-11/jury-returns-157-million-verdict-medical-malpractice-trial">The Augusta Chronicle</a>, Ms. Gravitt went to an emergency room the next day complaining of high fever, racing pulse, and abdominal pain. Three days later she was back, this time with a distended abdomen and vomiting. Her doctor Peter Grossman admitted her to the hospital, but failed to order the CT scan that would confirm her perforated bowel for a further two days.

Because of Dr. Grossman&#x2019;s failure to recognize Ms. Gravitt&#x2019;s symptoms, she had to undergo further surgeries to correct the problems caused by the bowel perforation. On June 11, a Richmond County, GA Superior Court jury awarded over $1.57 million to Melissa Gravitt to cover the medical expenses resulting from her doctors&#x2019; negligence and pain and suffering.
<h2>Risks of abdominal surgery</h2>
If you have recently undergone abdominal surgery, or are planning on having abdominal surgery for any number of reasons, you are at risk of a bowel perforation. Untreated, a bowel perforation can lead to peritonitis, which can be fatal. Knowing the signs and symptoms of bowel perforation could save your life. The <a href="http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/000235.htm">National Institutes of Health</a> recommends contacting a medical professional if you experience:
<ul>
    <li>Blood in your stool</li>
    <li>Changes in bowel habits</li>
    <li>Fever</li>
    <li>Nausea</li>
    <li>Severe abdominal pain</li>
    <li>Vomiting</li>
</ul>
When a medical professional fails to recognize that symptoms or behaviors point to medical condition, they are guilty of malpractice. Malpractice can lead to unnecessary pain and suffering, as in the case of Melissa Gravitt. At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we have successfully prosecuted a number of bowel perforation cases, including the Stamper verdict of $1.2 million that was reported by the <a href="http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/courts/2014/09/11/medical-malpractice-lawsuit/15460567/">Cincinnati Enquirer</a>. If you or someone you know has been misdiagnosed, or has suffered because a medical professional overlooked important details, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact a Crandall &amp; Pera Law office</a> in Ohio or Kentucky offices for a free consultation.
-----

AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Former Pro-Tort Reform Congressman LaTourette Now Looks to Sue Doctor for Medical Malpractice
BASENAME: former-pro-tort-reform-congressman-latourette-now-looks-to-sue-doctor-for-medical-malpractice
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 06/26/2015 01:25:57 PM
-----
BODY:
Longtime former United States Congressman Steve LaTourette has recently been diagnosed with an advanced form of pancreatic cancer. This type of cancer is aggressive and our hearts go out to his family and loved ones, as well as to Mr. LaTourette himself. In fact, Mr. LaTourette may seek to preserve his testimony on video for the legal case due to the aggressive nature of the cancer he is fighting.

According to <a href="http://www.politico.com/story/2015/05/steve-latourette-lawsuit-federal-government-cancer-medical-malpractice-118338.html">Politico.com</a>, the former Congressman &#x201C;filed administrative claims against the government for what he says was negligent care from the Office of the Attending Physician of the U.S. Congress, which oversees lawmakers&#x2019; primary care&#x2026; [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][and] is planning to sue for past and future medical expenses, lost wages and compensation for his mental anguish and suffering&#x201D; stemming from his advanced pancreatic cancer. Mr. LaTourette believes the physicians caring for him were negligent and he now is seeking damages for this negligence.
<h2>A history of hurting constituents who filed cases like these in the past</h2>
Ironically, while in office, Mr. LaTourette was a huge proponent of tort reform and perpetually attempted to limit or even block a patient&#x2019;s right to sue his or her physician for malpractice. Looking at LaTourette&#x2019;s track record, it is safe to say that he has had a &#x201C;problem&#x201D; with medical malpractice cases in general, as well as the same type of plaintiffs&#x2019; attorneys he has now hired, for a long time.

<a href="http://www.ontheissues.org/OH/Steven_LaTourette.htm">OnTheIssues.org</a> records the voting record of the country&#x2019;s politicians in multiple areas. LaTourette has voted &#x201C;yes&#x201D; on issues such as &#x201C;restricting frivolous lawsuits (Sep 2004),&#x201D; &#x201C;limiting medical malpractice lawsuits to $250,000 damages (May 2004)&#x201D; and &#x201C;capping damages &amp; setting time limits in medical lawsuits (Mar 2003&#x201D;).
<h2>The heart of the matter</h2>
The numerous and restrictive barriers to justice and the ridiculously low caps on damages will now impact Mr. LaTourette and his family personally. Even if Mr. LaTourette&#x2019;s case is proven correct, he and his family will face severe limitations on the amount of damages he can receive as well as bars on the type of damages he can even ask for. It is certain Mr. LaTourette and his family will view the issues from an entirely different perspective. Hopefully Mr. LaTourette and his family can take this perspective and advocate what they now should know is the correct view; meritorious lawsuits should have no caps or limitations of any kind.

The problem is not that LaTourette wants to sue his doctor. Cancer misdiagnoses cases are incredibly difficult, and if it is a true case of malpractice than he and his family deserve to be compensated for the future they have lost. The problem is that LaTourette, and other lawmakers, should already know Tort Reform is incredibly wrong and unfair to anyone wrongfully injured by medical malpractice <strong><u>before</u></strong> they become a victim themselves.

To learn more about our medical malpractice services in Ohio or Kentucky, we invite you to <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a>.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]

AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Understanding the Risk Factors of Your Baby Developing a Brain Injury
BASENAME: understanding-the-risk-factors-of-your-baby-developing-a-brain-injury
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/06/2015 11:39:01 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2166" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/birth-injury-and-family-200x300.jpg" alt="birth injury brain injury" width="200" height="300">Parents of babies born with birth injuries wonder why their child had to have this experience. Birth injuries can range from something relatively minor that will eventually heal, to severe injuries such as hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy. But there are some indications that your child may suffer an injury that can be explained and detected before you go into labor, such as:
<ul>
    <li>Fetal Macrosomia (when the baby is much larger than he or she should be for his or her gestational age, or if the infant is heavier than 8 lbs. 13ozs, and the mother&apos;s pelvis is not large enough for the child&apos;s head to pass)</li>
    <li>Breech presentation</li>
    <li>Prolonged labor</li>
    <li>Induction of labor</li>
    <li>Use of epidural</li>
    <li>Delivery with instruments such as forceps and vacuum</li>
    <li>Premature delivery (before 37 weeks)</li>
</ul>
Babies who suffer severe injury at birth and survive will often face difficult lives filled with many challenges including developmental delays, cerebral palsy, cognitive difficulties and other disabilities. Raising a child with all of these health challenges can be costly and stressful. In some cases, the child will have ongoing medical needs that will cost the family a significant amount of money each month.
<h2>Can you pursue a medical malpractice lawsuit for a birth injury?</h2>
If your child is born with brain injuries or any other birth injuries caused by the doctor&apos;s or hospital&#x2019;s negligence, you may wonder if your case is eligible for filing a medical malpractice lawsuit. If you believe your child&#x2019;s injury was the result of negligence, or if the signs of a potential injury were there but they were ignored, then you may be able to bring a medical malpractice lawsuit on behalf of you child and yourself. The lawsuit can help you recover money for:
<ul>
    <li>Medical bills, such as hospital stays and surgical procedures</li>
    <li>Medication and prescription costs</li>
    <li>Rehabilitation costs, including tools and technologies you use in your home to care for your child</li>
    <li>Loss of income, both past, present and future if you must now care for your child full-time</li>
    <li>Pain and suffering of you or your child</li>
    <li>Funeral expenses if the injury should lead to a tragic loss of life</li>
</ul>
Living with a child with a serious birth injury can be challenging, but you do have options. We invite you to <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> in Kentucky and Ohio to find out more about your options.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: What Are the Warning Signs of Nursing Home Abuse or Neglect?
BASENAME: what-are-the-warning-signs-of-nursing-home-abuse-or-neglect
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/13/2015 12:43:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2019 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/nursing-home-neglect-200x300.jpg" alt="nursing home abuse in kentucky" width="200" height="300">Nursing home abuse is a shameful problem that has been growing in prevalence as our population ages. As more baby boomers live longer and move into nursing homes in their later years, increasing numbers of people are being mistreated by the staff at these facilities. According to the Kentucky Elder Abuse Committee&apos;s annual report, more than 47% of patients in nursing homes (who have dementia) have been abused or mistreated by their caregivers.

Fortunately, there are several warning signs that you can look out for if you suspect that your elderly loved one is not being cared for properly, including:
<ul>
    <li>Infections</li>
    <li>Unexplained bruises and other injuries</li>
    <li>Medication errors</li>
    <li>Weight loss, dehydration, hunger</li>
    <li>Withdrawal from social activities, depression, fearfulness, lethargy</li>
    <li>Unsanitary living conditions</li>
    <li>Bedsores</li>
    <li>Missing valuables, money</li>
</ul>
If you see these or any other signs of neglect or abuse you are obliged by law to report it. You can report the abuse to the manager of the nursing home and you and report it to Kentucky Adult Protective Services at 800.752.6200. If it is an emergency situation where the individual has been seriously injured dial 911 immediately.
<h2>Preventing nursing home abuse</h2>
There is so much that you can do to prevent elder abuse. Educating yourself about the signs and symptoms, and encouraging others to learn them too, is a great first step in helping to end abuse and neglect. Remember:
<ul>
    <li>If you see signs of abuse, you should report it right away</li>
    <li>Visiting your loved ones in their nursing homes more often makes it more difficult for &#x201C;caretakers&#x201D; to abuse or neglect your family member</li>
    <li>Surprise visits at mealtimes can ensure that your parent, sibling or grandparent is both hydrated and properly nourished</li>
    <li>Keep an eye on your family members&#x2019; medications. Make sure that they are taking them according to the schedule and dosage amounts on the bottle</li>
    <li>Active listening is key. Be aware of any changes in attitude or personality, and ask questions about your family members&#x2019; experiences and happiness. Often, elders who are being abused or who have witnessed others being abused do not report it because they fear retaliation. Keep the lines of communication open, and look for a new home if your loved one feels unsafe.</li>
</ul>
Crandall &amp; Pera Law offers comprehensive representation to families with loved ones in nursing homes in Kentucky and Ohio. Please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> to find out how we can help you.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: The 5 Types of Elder Abuse in Kentucky Nursing Homes
BASENAME: the-5-types-of-elder-abuse-in-kentucky-nursing-homes
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/07/2015 10:08:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2019 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/nursing-home-neglect-200x300.jpg" alt="nursing home neglect" width="200" height="300">People are living longer today than they ever have, and the number of our elders who are in nursing home care keeps growing at a rapid pace. The 2010 U.S. Census recorded the greatest number of people age 65 and older in all of the history of the census at 40.3 million, which is about 13% of the population of this country. By the year 2050, those age 65 and older will comprise 20% of the total U.S. population. Those who are age 85 and older are the fastest growing segment of the U.S. population.

Along with the greater numbers of elders in nursing homes is the greater incidence of nursing home abuse. One of the ongoing challenges with identifying and curtailing this rampant abuse is getting people to report it. According to the National Research Council, only one in 14 cases of elder abuse is ever reported to authorities, which means that a huge number of cases of abuse, exploitation and neglect go unreported each year.

There are five general categories of abuse that our senior citizens endure every day at the hands of their caregivers including:
<ol>
    <li><strong>Physical abuse</strong>. Physical abuse can take the form of hitting, punching, kicking, shoving, restricting an elder to one room and using unnecessary restraints</li>
    <li>Any kind of unwanted, non-consensual sexual contact, touching and sexual assault</li>
    <li><strong>Psychological</strong>. Making threats, cursing, scolding and disparaging the elderly person</li>
    <li>Modifying documents without the elder&apos;s consent, forging and cashing checks, charging their account for unneeded services</li>
    <li><strong>Neglect</strong>. Neglect of a person in elder care can range from failing to maintain clean living conditions, insufficient access to medical care, neglecting personal hygiene, nourishment and hydration</li>
</ol>
<h2>How to report elder abuse in Kentucky</h2>
Kentucky is a mandatory reporting state, (KRS 209.030) which means that if you see or suspect elder abuse you are required by law to report it. You can call a toll-free number anonymously to report any instances of nursing home abuse in Kentucky: 800.752.6200. If you want to make a report about a nursing facility, you can contact the Office of the Inspector General at 502.564.7963.

If you have a loved one who has experienced abuse in a nursing home, you may be able to take legal action against the facility. Make sure that you have reported the abuse to the proper authorities and then talk to an experienced nursing home abuse attorney who will help you to hold the responsible parties liable for your loved ones&#x2019; injuries.

If your loved one has suffered an injury at a nursing home, we want to help make sure the responsible party is held liable for your loved one&#x2019;s suffering. At Crandall &amp; Pera Law we will protect your interests and help you get the justice you deserve. Please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> to schedule a free consultation to discuss your case at our offices in Kentucky and Ohio.

--------
AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Understanding How Brain Injuries Can Affect Your Newborn
BASENAME: understanding-how-brain-injuries-can-affect-your-newborn
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/17/2015 10:49:58 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2166" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/birth-injury-and-family-200x300.jpg" alt="birth injury brain injury" width="200" height="300">Birth injuries can be the result of many different complications during the process of prenatal care, labor and delivery, and in post-partum care for your newborn. Oxygen deprivation to the infant&#x2019;s brain can cause the most severe birth injuries. When the doctor fails to monitor the baby, perform a Cesarean section in time or commits any other preventable error, this can contribute to severe brain injuries in the infant.
<h2>Birth injuries by the numbers</h2>
In the U.S. approximately six to eight of every 1,000 infants are born with a birth injury, which means that 28,000 infants are born each year with a birth injury according to <a href="http://www.hcup-us.ahrq.gov/">HCUP data</a>. The National Healthcare Quality Report lists the ten most common birth injuries in the U.S. as:
<ul>
    <li>Brachial plexus palsy</li>
    <li>Bone fractures</li>
    <li>Cephalo-hematoma</li>
    <li>Perinatal asphyxia</li>
    <li>Intracranial hemorrage</li>
    <li>Subconjuctival hemorrhage</li>
    <li>Facial paralysis</li>
    <li>Spinal cord injuries</li>
    <li>Cerebral palsy</li>
</ul>
As many as half of the birth injuries that occur in the U.S. are due to preventable medical errors.
<h2>Hypoxic brain injuries</h2>
Anoxia occurs when decreased oxygen gets to the brain; hypoxia occurs when anoxia goes on too long which then leads to irreversible brain cell death, also known as ischemia. Usually, these conditions are the result of decreased blood flow. Some of the more common causes of hypoxia include:
<ul>
    <li>Placental insufficiency</li>
    <li>Placental abruption</li>
    <li>Umbilical cord injuries or prolapse</li>
    <li>Congenital heart defect</li>
    <li>Too much medication used to cause contractions during labor</li>
    <li>Infections</li>
    <li>Shoulder dystocia</li>
</ul>
A hypoxic-ischemic injury can cause permanent damage leading to cerebral palsy and can even result in death. It is a rare birth injury that occurs in approximately three of 1,000 births.

Of the infants born with hypoxic-ischemic injuries, between 15 and 20% of them will die closely following their birth. Those who survive face a life of neurological problems such as cerebral palsy, epilepsy, learning disabilities and mental retardation.

Discovering that your much anticipated new baby has been born with a life-altering birth injury can be devastating and heart breaking. If they live, these injuries will have a lasting impact on your child&#x2019;s life and their future. If your baby suffered a brain injury at birth, at Crandall &amp; Pera Law we want to help you get justice. Please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> to make an appointment at our Ohio or Kentucky offices.

--------
AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: New Study May Speed Recovery of Brain Injury Victims
BASENAME: new-study-may-speed-recovery-of-brain-injury-victims
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/29/2015 12:07:58 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2657 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/Brain-Injury-300x225.jpg" alt="New Study May Speed Recovery of Brain Injury Victims" width="300" height="225">

Recovering from a brain injury can be long and difficult process. Cognitive and physical therapies are time-consuming, and results often depend on the individual circumstances of the case. When someone suffers a brain injury, time saved is brain saved; the faster doctors can intervene, the better the chances of a full recovery.

In the past, it was believed that the best way to heal after suffering a brain injury was rest and inactivity, to prevent changes in blood flow and to allow injuries to heal as best as possible. However, a promising new study by a nurse in Cleveland may change the way doctors treat patients after a brain injury.

Kate Klein began working at the Cleveland Clinic&#x2019;s Neurointensive Care Unit some time ago. She noticed that the majority of patients were bedridden, and also knew that current medical practice has found that getting patients out of bed as soon as possible after an injury helped to promote healing. She began to wonder if there was a difference between bodily injury and brain injury.

In response, she designed and carried out a study on over 600 patients. During the year it took to conduct the test, Klein got more than half of her patients out of bed, sometimes on their first day in the ICU. Her findings were amazing. According to <a href="http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2015/07/06/419519145/people-with-brain-injuries-heal-faster-if-they-get-up-and-get-moving">National Public Radio</a>, &#x201C;What she found was that getting up and moving had clear benefits. Patients who started their rehabilitation earlier spent less time in the ICU and less time in the hospital. &#x2018;They have less pressure ulcers, less infections and spend less time on the ventilator if they need ventilator therapy,&#x2019; says Klein. And most say they feel a lot better.&#x201D;

In response to Klein&#x2019;s efforts, the Cleveland Clinic has installed ceiling-mounted lifts to help get patients out of bed. The results have been nothing short of amazing. One patient, a mother, spoke for the first time after walking outside the hospital for the first time.

Doctors believe that the experience gained by performing routine tasks like walking down a hallway, sitting outside on a bench, or even getting out of chair help to promote brain healing. These familiar tasks engage the brain, and can begin to let the brain rewire itself to compensate for an injury. Doctors caution that this research is still in its early stages, and that not all brain injuries may respond the same way to this treatment. However, thanks to Kate Klein in at the Cleveland Clinic, there is more hope from brain injury victims than ever before.

When brain injuries happen, the medical costs can be staggering. Hospital stays, rehabilitation, and cognitive and behavioral therapy sessions can add up quickly. If you or someone you know suffered a brain injury during an accident, you may be entitled to compensation. Please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> today for a free consultation at one of our offices in Ohio or Kentucky.
-----

--------
AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: The Untold Stories of Stillbirths Are the Most Important Ones
BASENAME: the-untold-stories-of-stillbirths-are-the-most-important-ones
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/20/2015 11:55:38 AM
-----
BODY:
The <em>New York Times</em> has been publishing personal stories about the heart-wrenching experience of mothers delivering stillborn children. To the average person, such stories might seem too personal to share, the grief too deep to express properly &#x2013; but to the thousands of women whose children are stillborn, bringing the topic to light could offer some relief or catharsis. The<em> Times</em> reports that <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/23/health/after-a-stillbirth-a-silent-delivery-room.html">1 in 160 pregnancies</a> will result in a stillbirth, which means the chances are high that someone you know and love will experience this terrible tragedy.
<h2>Potential causes for a loss</h2>
Dr. Eleni Michailidis, whose loss of her son Alexander is recounted in the article, states that approximately half of all stillbirths have no known cause. A stillbirth, referred to as fetal death in the medical field, occurs when a child dies in the womb after 20 weeks. If a child dies in the womb before 20 weeks, it is generally categorized as a miscarriage. According to the <a href="http://www.marchofdimes.org/loss/stillbirth.aspx">March of Dimes</a>, the other 50% of fetal deaths may be attributed to:
<ul>
    <li>Birth defects</li>
    <li>Placental abruption</li>
    <li>Physical trauma to the mother, such as a car accident</li>
    <li>Undiagnosed or untreated infections</li>
    <li>Chronic health conditions, including diabetes</li>
    <li>The advanced age (over 35 years) of the mother</li>
    <li>Obesity</li>
    <li>High blood pressure in the mother</li>
    <li>&#x201C;Multiple gestation,&#x201D; or carrying two or more babies at one time</li>
</ul>
With the exception of a car accident, which could not be anticipated, each of these scenarios can occur if a doctor fails to warn the mother of a potential problem. Many times, improper monitoring of a pregnancy &#x2013; high-risk or not &#x2013; may lead to the loss of the baby. In some of the most tragic experiences, however, it is the medical team&#x2019;s negligence during the labor and delivery process which leads to the wrongful fetal death. Failing to discover a problem with the umbilical cord in a timely manner could deprive a child of oxygen, leading to brain damage or death. Waiting too long to perform a C-section is another cause of stillbirths, especially if the mother presents with bleeding, a sign of placental abruption.

These are delicate and challenging cases; for many families, the pain is too new and too raw to think about much else. But if a doctor&#x2019;s negligence led to the stillbirth of a child, then that doctor should be held accountable for the loss. Furthermore, a mother may require additional medical procedures or treatments associated with the event. Perhaps most important, a family who has experienced the death of their child should have access to the highest levels of aftercare and counseling to help them regroup. All of these things cost money &#x2013; money which insurance companies will be loath to give unless their hands are forced.

The unexpected loss of a child is almost too heart-breaking to bear; discovering that loss may have been prevented cold be even more so. At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we understand the challenges of these cases, and we understand how to win. Steve Crandall won the largest verdict in Miami County in a case involving a wrongful fetal death caused by a complication with the umbilical cord; Marc Pera won a verdict in Hamilton County for $2.25 million not long after, which remains one of the highest if not the highest verdict in the area for a stillbirth lawsuit. We have what it takes to help you at the moment you need help the most.

To find out more, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law today</a>, and schedule a no-obligation consultation in one of our offices in Kentucky or Ohio. You will find a safe and secure place to discuss your needs and your goals.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: NHTSA Acknowledges Failures In GM Recall Investigation, But Issues No Consequences
BASENAME: nhtsa-acknowleo-consequences
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 06/16/2015 01:53:30 PM
-----
BODY:
The Federal Transportation Department recently released two internal reports that detailed the course of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration&#x2019;s investigation of defective ignition switches in vehicles produce by General Motors.

The <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/06/business/nhtsa-admits-missing-clues-to-gm-ignition-defects.html?nl=afternoonupdate&amp;emc=edit_au_20150605&amp;_r=0">New York Times</a> reports &#x201C;While the reports still focused blame for the defect squarely on G.M., the nation&#x2019;s largest automaker, they also included an unusually blunt assessment of mistakes made by regulators. The agency, for example, admitted it had clues of the defect that it did not pay attention to, and acknowledged that it failed to use its full authority to hold G.M. accountable.&#x201D;

The internal reports have caused a stir in Congress and are instigating a series of changes to the NHTSA&#x2019;s investigative procedures. However, the agency&#x2019;s new administrator, Mark Rosekind, told the <em>Times</em> &#x201C;that he had not disciplined or fired any government officials for their role in failing to force G.M. to fix its defective small cars before the automaker began recalling 2.6 million Chevrolet Cobalts, Saturn Ions and other affected models in February of last year.&#x201D;

This is negligence of the highest order; at a minimum, hundreds of people were aware of the public hazard created by the defective switches and not one person took appropriate action.&#xA0; General Motors employees, including engineers and inside and outside lawyers, actively worked to hide the fact that a faulty ignition switch was present and killing people in their vehicles.

In addition, and even more inexcusable, the watchdog agency by the taxpayers and for the taxpayers mishandled evidence to such a degree that Senators are calling for agency-wide reforms. The agency admitted a failure to acknowledge evidence, and in doing so put unknown numbers of lives at risk. At every step of the way, the system failed those it was intended to protect.

Ultimately, we must question whether an agency so rife with error can self-correct. If no employees are going to be fired or disciplined for an error of such magnitude, is it possible that the same mistake can be made with same people in place? When this question affects millions, can we trust those who failed us in the past? In effect, who watches the watchmen?

If you or someone you know have been affected by the GM ignition recall, or have suffered needlessly because of the lack of action on behalf of a trusted government agency, please contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law for a free consultation. We maintain offices throughout Ohio and Kentucky for your convenience.

--------
AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Understanding the Damage that Damage Caps Cause
BASENAME: understanding-the-damage-that-damage-caps-cause
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/06/2015 09:17:03 AM
-----
BODY:
When politicians speak of tort reform, they try to appeal to a large base of voters by skewing the facts about lawsuits. They purposely make victims (and attorneys) sound like greedy penny-pinchers who are purposely &#x201C;gaming&#x201D; the system for a payday. And they do this so that people will vote for them, because they sound like they are advocating for justice.

But there is no justice in tort reform &#x2013; there never has been, and there never will be. All the proof you need is <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/25/us/amtrak-derailment-victims-face-a-liability-limit.html">in the case of Kathryn Varnum</a>, a woman so severely injured in the May 12<sup>th</sup> Amtrak derailment that her medical expenses are already up to $200,000 and her treatment is still far from complete. She has already had multiple procedures (and may be facing more) after fracturing her hip, back and leg, and is largely confined to a wheelchair. She can no longer work, and the doctors cannot tell her when she may be able to return to her job. She is being cared for by her husband who was also seriously injured in the derailment, and is reliant upon her parents to help ferry her to various hospitals and appointments.

All of their money is gone, and there is no guarantee of more money coming in. And Ms. Varnum and her husband, Declan McFarland, risk receiving only a limited amount of funds because of a &#x201C;congressionally mandated cap on liability for Amtrak accidents can leave victims with enormous bills [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][and is] aimed at keeping railroad companies in operation when hit with major lawsuits.&#x201D;

In other words, Congress ensured that injured Plaintiffs could only sue for a limited amount of money.&#xA0; &#xA0;As Harvard professor John C.P. Goldberg explained, &#x201C;When Congress enacted the cap, it made the judgment that victims of large-scale railroad crashes will be among those who have to bear the cost of keeping Amtrak up and running.&#x201D; By limiting how much compensation Amtrak can provide, either through a trial or a settlement (they chose to settle), victims are essentially paying to help keep Amtrak running.
<h2>A history of choosing corporations over people</h2>
This is not, sadly, the first time victims will be made to pay. The <em>Times</em> cites a 2008 Metrolink commuter train crash that occurred in California; 199 people were injured and 24 people died. &#x201C;Judge Peter D. Lichtman, now retired, said an additional $64 million beyond the liability cap was needed to properly compensate victims&#x2026;. But he was unable to get more because of the federal limit on damages.&#x201D; Judge Lichtman was forced to decide which family &#x201C;deserved&#x201D; more money, even if it meant taking away compensation from other victims.

The Amtrak case highlights the true problem with capping damages: the victims are hurt all over again. Damage caps make the injured parties help bear the cost of keeping a corporate entity up and running even though it has acted negligently. The same is true for medical malpractice caps, too. It is incredibly insulting at best and unjust and unfair at worst. Tort reform may be needed in some jurisdictions, but caps are almost never the answer. &#xA0;Victims&#x2019; ability to obtain the help they need to move forward, after horrific losses and suffering, should not be limited by arbitrary caps.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is dedicated to helping catastrophic personal injury victims throughout Ohio and Kentucky. To learn more about our services, or to find out how damage caps could hurt your recovery, we invite you to <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us today</a>.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Nursing Home Worker Guilty of Financial Abuse
BASENAME: nursing-home-worker-guilty-of-financial-abuse
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/03/2015 11:05:59 AM
-----
BODY:
Dawn Miller, 33, of Hankins, New York recently pled guilty &#x201C;<a href="http://poststar.com/news/blotter/former-nursing-home-worker-sent-to-prison-for-theft/article_3461afea-22fd-11e5-8f7b-cb983d9a2204.html">to scheme to defraud</a>&#x201D; for thefts she perpetrated during her employment at Indian River Nursing Home in Granville. Miller was sentenced to 1 to 3 years in state prison and was ordered to pay restitution for the nearly $4,500 she stole from residents. According to the Post Star, &#x201C;She was found to have taken money from numerous residents&#x2019; personal accounts and to have created fake paperwork indicating it was used for legitimate purposes.&#x201D;

This story sheds light on one of the more insidious forms of nursing home abuse; namely, that not all negligence involves the physical care of patients. Your elderly family members are also at risk of having their money stolen from them, making it impossible to ensure their continued care. Financial abuse is a particularly difficult subject, as it requires monitoring your loved one&#x2019;s assets and proving that improprieties exist. If your loved one suffers from dementia, it can be even more difficult to trace a chain of events.
<h2>Common signs of abuse and neglect</h2>
Financial abuse carries its own particular set of symptoms, and they may not be immediately recognizable. Often times, elderly patients&#x2019; accusations are ignored by family members who are not intimately familiar with their loved one&#x2019;s finances. This is especially true in cases where one parent is in a nursing home and the other is not; if you cannot access your parents&#x2019; accounts, you may not realize they are being drained until it is too late.

In order to protect your family members, familiarize yourself with their finances, and look out for missing items and any transactions that are out of the ordinary. If you see new charges to an account, it is reasonable to request that the facility explain any new or different charges. Listen carefully to what your loved ones say, and pay particular attention if your loved one mentions that something might be missing.

If you or someone you know has been the victim of elder abuse, it is important that you take action as soon as possible. Crandall &amp; Pera Law serves clients in nursing homes throughout Kentucky, and our experienced legal team can help guide you through the steps you need to take to protect your loved one. Please contact us to visit one of our offices in Kentucky or in Ohio to learn more.

--------
AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Is Your C-Section Medically Necessary?
BASENAME: is-your-c-section-medically-necessary
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/30/2015 10:30:13 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2665 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/Is-Your-C-Section-Medically-Necessary-300x200.jpg" alt="Is Your C-Section Medically Necessary" width="300" height="200">

A new article from the <a href="http://www.bmj.com/content/350/bmj.h2410">British Medical Journal</a> published on June 10 recommends that guidelines for Cesarean delivery as a delivery method should be reviewed. The recommendation is made in light of new evidence that links C-sections with childhood chronic disease and long-term health issues.

Dr. Jianmen Liu of Peking University and Dr. Jan Blustein of New York University&#x2019;s School of Medicine reviewed a series of studies that linked C-sections and chronic health issues. During the review, the team found some 20 studies that connect Type 1 diabetes with C-sections, 23 that linked the delivery method to asthma, and 9 related to obesity.
<h2>Understanding the risks with C-sections</h2>
In some cases, a Cesarean section is a potentially life-saving medical procedure &#x2013; for both the baby and the mother. It allows for safe delivery during complicated births, and can help prevent debilitating conditions caused by anoxia or hypoxia, where the baby does not get enough oxygen to his or her brain and suffers permanent brain damage as a result.

However, C-sections are still surgical procedures, and that means there will be risks to the mother and the child. If a surgeon cuts too deeply or in the wrong spot, both the baby and the mother could risk permanent scarring or excessive bleeding. The study references &#x201C;caesarean [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][sections as being] associated with increased risk of admission to a neonatal intensive care unit,&#x201D; especially if the procedure was not planned, or if the child had to be delivered prematurely.

If the procedure is delayed and the doctor must now rush, if the anesthesiologist makes an error, or if there is a secondary problem that is not addressed by the medical providers, both mother and child are at potential risk for life-long repercussions.

Choosing a C-section can affect both your life and the life of your child forever. Making an informed decision can mean the difference between a healthy child and a sickly one. We invite you to <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> to learn more, or to learn whether your child may have been the victim of labor or delivery negligence. We maintain offices in both Ohio and Kentucky for your convenience.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
-----
