AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Feds Cut Medicare and Medicaid Funding to Kentucky Nursing Home
BASENAME: feds-cut-medicare-and-medicaid-funding-to-kentucky-nursing-home
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/13/2015 02:35:45 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-1995" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Ohio-Nursing-Homes-Highly-Rated-300x200.jpg" alt="Ohio nursing homes highly rated" width="300" height="200">Federal officials have cut funding for Hurstbourne Care Center at Stony Brook in Louisville following an investigation by the state Cabinet for Health and Family Services. The facility was found to have been dangerously understaffed. The Office of Inspector General released a 700-page report on the conditions. Some of the problems, cited by <a href="http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/local/2015/07/13/feds-cut-funds-louisville-nursing-home/30108299/">The Courier-Journal</a>, included:
<ul>
    <li>&#x201C;Insect infestations that left two residents- one a quadriplegic- screaming for help from staff because of ants crawling on them in a bed.</li>
    <li>Chronic staff shortages that one nurse described as &#x2018;ghost staffing,&#x2019; workers listed on schedules who were not actually on duty.</li>
    <li>Unattended or unexplained injuries, including a resident&#x2019;s broken leg apparently suffered in a fall, an injury that went undetected for 16 hours.</li>
    <li>Rooms and units that reeked of urine, clogged toilets, feces smeared on floors and in bathrooms and residents who complained of being forced to lie for hours in their own urine because no one was available to help them to a bathroom or change them.&#x201D;</li>
</ul>
In addition to the cessation of funds, the facility is to be fined $629,000 for a variety of violations. Florida-based Consulate Health Care operates the nursing home, and it is unknown whether it will remain open in the future. Federal funding will continue until August to allow state officials and families time to relocate their loved ones to other facilities.

This case, which unfortunately required federal intervention to resolve, constitutes elder abuse and neglect to the highest degree. At the Hurstbourne Care Center, some residents were unable to eat without assistance and were at risk of malnutrition without that aid. According to the investigative report, &#x201C;One resident at risk of choking was observed eating a paper napkin.&#x201D;

When major care providers operate health facilities with an eye on the bottom line, people suffer. While it pays to research and prepare to move your loved one to a nursing home or full-time care facility, you ultimately must trust a caregiver with your loved ones&#x2019; life. When a caregiver betrays that trust, we are here to protect your rights and get you the compensation you deserve. If your loved one has suffered abuse or neglect at a nursing home in Kentucky or Ohio, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> today for a free consultation.

--------
AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: How Your Doctor Treats Gestational Diabetes Could Affect Your Child&#x2019;s Life
BASENAME: how-your-doctor-treats-gestational-diabetes-could-affect-your-childs-life
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/12/2015 02:36:53 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2850" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/How-Your-Doctor-Treats-Gestational-Diabetes-Could-Affect-Your-Child&#x2019;s-Life-300x199.jpg" alt="Gestational Diabetes Could Affect Your Child&#x2019;s Life" width="300" height="199">Gestational diabetes is a complication of pregnancy that affects how your body uses sugar. Doctors are not sure exactly what causes gestational diabetes, but fluctuating hormones in both your body and in the placenta can block the effectiveness of naturally secreted insulin and cause elevated sugar levels. When this happens, both you and your baby are at a higher risk of complications during birth.

The good news, of course, is that gestational diabetes, properly known as gestational diabetes mellitus, is manageable and treatable. While Mom may be more susceptible to developing diabetes after pregnancy, the odds of a successful delivery are higher than ever before.
<h2>Potentially dangerous drugs</h2>
Gestational diabetes mellitus is considered Type II diabetes, in which the body manufactures insulin but does not use it properly to control sugar levels. There are many different types of drugs that are available to treat Type II diabetes, all with their own merits. However, <a href="http://injurylawyer-news.com/2015/07/glyburide-tied-higher-gestational-diabetes-birth-injury-risk-insulin/">a new study</a> has linked Glyburide to a higher risk of complications in newborns.

The study, which included 9,000 women, looked at the differences between natural insulin therapy and prescription Glyburide during pregnancy. The findings are nothing short of incredible; when pregnant women diagnosed with gestational diabetes were treated with Glyburide, the risk of complications during pregnancy went through the roof.

According to the study, infants whose mothers received glyburide during pregnancy, were:
<ul>
    <li>41% more likely to be admitted to NICU</li>
    <li>40% more likely to have hypoglycemia</li>
    <li>63% more likely to suffer respiratory distress</li>
    <li>50% more likely to be delivered via cesarean than a natural birth</li>
</ul>
<a href="http://archpedi.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=2211139">The study concluded that</a>, &#x201C;Newborns from privately insured mothers treated with glyburide were more likely to experience adverse outcomes than those from mothers treated with insulin. Given the widespread use of glyburide, further investigation of these differences in pregnancy outcomes is a public health priority.&#x201D;

If you or your spouse was diagnosed with gestational diabetes during pregnancy and were treated with glyburide, and your child suffered birth defects or complications, we can help protect you and your child. Crandall &amp; Pera Law has helped thousands of medical malpractice victims throughout Ohio and Kentucky secure a better future. Please contact us to find out more.
-----
EXTENDED BODY:

-----
EXCERPT:

-----
KEYWORDS:

-----


--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Two Boys Hospitalized with Severe Sunburn
BASENAME: two-boys-hospitalized-with-severe-sunburn
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/26/2015 07:38:08 PM
-----
BODY:
An Oklahoma mother sent her 5 and 7-year-old sons off to daycare for a day of fun at a splash park. Before the trip, Shaunna Broadway called Happiness is Learning to find out if she was required to provide sunscreen for her fair-skinned boys. She was assured that the facility would supply sunscreen and take proper precautions. When Broadway picked them up after the trip, the boys were crying in pain.

Connor and Trae Broadway suffered second- and third-degree burns after the daycare failed to supply and apply sunscreen. They were airlifted from an emergency room to a burn hospital in Texas, and are undergoing treatment for their painful injuries.

The Happiness is Learning Center has since shut down, and has remained unavailable for comment to the major media sites. <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2015/07/28/health/boys-sunburn-daycare-irpt/">According to CNN</a>, &#x201C;The day care service has been visited in the past... for a list of non-compliance violations. These violations include expired fire extinguishers, incorrectly placed and updated food menu, and &#x2018;no one on staff with a current director&#x2019;s credential.&#x2019;&#x201D;
<h2>Why sunburns are more serious than you might think</h2>
Second-degree burns are serious. The first two layers of skin are damaged, and if the burn is larger than 3 inches in diameter, it is treated as a major burn that needs professional attention. Third-degree burns are far worse, and extend through all layers of the skin and underlying fat. These burns can require skin grafts to repair the worst of the damage. Both boys developed blisters from their burns so severe, that CNN issued a warning on its website for viewer discretion.

While the immediate damage from a burn is painful, repeated burns can have long-term health effects. This makes a new social media trend all the more worrisome. A recent article from <a href="http://6abc.com/health/sunburn-art-becoming-dangerous-new-trend-on-social-media/856394/">ABC Action News</a> highlighted a growing fashion trend in which teens are using stencils and sunblock to burn tattoos on to their skin. This new trend, popularizing a dangerous condition, has potentially disastrous consequences. The best way to counter this trend is to monitor and inform your friends and family. Repeated and extreme exposure to UV rays can result in skin cancer, while even brief exposure can cause painful burns.

If your children have been exposed to dangerous conditions, or injured due to an Ohio or Kentucky care facility&#x2019;s negligence, you may be entitled to compensation. Please stay safe, and <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> today for a free consultation.
-----

--------
AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Bizarre Counterfeit Spinal-Hardware Has Insurance Companies Suing Doctors
BASENAME: bizarre-counterfeit-spinal-hardware-has-insurance-companies-suing-doctors
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/31/2015 01:06:17 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2905 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Bizarre-Counterfeit-Spinal-Hardware-253x300.jpg" alt="Bizarre Counterfeit Spinal-Hardware" width="253" height="300">

A civil complaint has been filed on behalf of dozens of insurance companies. The complaint alleges a huge national health care fraud scheme involving the use of, and billing for, fake surgical hardware, and implicates fifteen surgeons and seventeen hospitals across the country.

According to the complaint, Spinal Solutions, LLC, of California, engaged in the production and distribution of fake spinal implants as long ago as 2007. The company would then sign an agreement to have doctors implant their non-FDA approved devices and pay kickbacks to those who participated.

The doctors involved allegedly entered into &#x201C;sham agreements&#x201D; with Spinal Solutions. For example, &#x201C;...Maryland surgeon Dr. Randy Davis entered into a &#x2018;sham agreement&#x2019; with Spinal Solutions and was paid $458,962 in kickbacks in exchange for getting the... products used in surgeries at the University of Maryland&#x2019;s Baltimore Washington Medical Center,&#x201D; according to <a href="http://america.aljazeera.com/watch/shows/america-tonight/articles/2015/5/28/lawsuit-allegation-fake-spinal-parts-used.html">Aljazeera America</a>.

What may be worse is the level of conscious participation these agreements required. The fake spinal parts were delivered via private jet, and the surgeons participating in this counterfeit ring are alleged to have received cash, vacations, free plane trips, and other kickbacks for implanting the fake medical devices.

The healthcare facilities that are implicated participated by falsely justifying surgeries and deliberately ignoring the activities of surgeons and their supply chain. These hospitals then billed insurance companies as if the parts were from an approved source, sometimes marking up the false products as much as 250%.

On top of this, patients who were implanted with the fake devices may have a difficult time finding out. Paper trails were complicated and, allegedly, intentionally obscured. Scott Lederhaus, the president of the Association for Medical Ethics, said, &#x201C;This has got to end. The spine industry is corrupt and it needs a washing from top to bottom.&#x201D;

Participation in this counterfeit ring is gross negligence to the highest degree. Medical facilities and surgeons agreed, with intent and knowledge aforethought, to put patients at risk by using untested, unapproved medical devices&#xA0;purely for financial gain. The fact that they betrayed the trust of their patients and did not consider the potential lifelong ramifications of implanting fake medical devices shows the degree of their negligence, and those affected deserve to be compensated.

If you or someone you know has been affected by the quality of an implanted medical device, or has had a breach of trust with a healthcare facility or provider, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> today for a free consultation in one of our Ohio or Kentucky office locations.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Feds Levy Huge Fine Against Kentucky Nursing Home
BASENAME: feds-levy-huge-fine-against-kentucky-nursing-home
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/24/2015 02:38:57 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2890 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Feds-Levy-Huge-Fine-Against-Kentucky-Nursing-Home-300x200.jpg" alt="Feds Levy Huge Fine Against Kentucky Nursing Home" width="300" height="200">

Diversicare of Nicholasville has received the largest fine in recent years after a January inspection found that an outbreak of scabies went on for months and affected 45% of residents. The facility was fined $891,350 because of the operators&#x2019; unwillingness to respond to nurses and their supervisors complaints about residents with rashes.

One of the residents had to be hospitalized, and others developed bacterial infections. This is an extreme case of elder neglect, and the federal government responded with an equally extreme fine. These residents, under Diversicare&#x2019;s care, were unable to speak for themselves, and the facility neglected even to respond to the nurses who attempted to speak on their patients&#x2019; behalf.
<h2>What is scabies?</h2>
Scabies is caused by a burrowing mite called <em>Sarcoptes scabei</em>. As the mites burrow into the skin, they cause intense itching which can result in red, irritated rashes. While the condition isn&#x2019;t fatal on its own, it is extremely uncomfortable. The mites can cause breaks in the skin, leaving the victim vulnerable to bacterial infections and other conditions.

<a href="http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/scabies/basics/definition/con-20023488">According to the Mayo Clinic</a>, &#x201C;Scabies is contagious and can spread quickly through close physical contact... Because of the contagious nature of scabies, doctors often recommend treatment for entire families or contact groups.&#x201D; The facility, the report said, failed to wash linens and did not properly disinfect rooms and furniture.

Scabies is easily treatable with prescription creams. The ease of resolving the infestation makes the conditions at Diversicare all the worse. According to Kentucky.com, &#x201C;33 residents... were infested with scabies...Nearly all of the infested senior citizens were listed as having moderate to severe cognitive impairments.&#x201D;

Elder abuse and neglect is a serious matter. When you choose a nursing home for your loved ones, you are placing their health and well-being in the hands of trusted professionals. When that trust is breached, you are entitled to compensation for the physical and emotional suffering of your loved one and your family members. The attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law are experienced in dealing with nursing home abuse and neglect cases in Kentucky and in Ohio, and can help you get the compensation you deserve. <a href="/Contact.shtml">Contact us today</a> for a free consultation.

--------
AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Medical Malpractice by the Numbers
BASENAME: medical-malpractice-by-the-numbers
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/17/2015 12:51:35 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2877 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/medical-malpractice-101-300x300.jpg" alt="medical malpractice in kentucky and ohio" width="300" height="300">

Medical malpractice can devastate patients and their families. When a doctor is guilty of malpractice, he or she has failed to administer an appropriate standard of care. Malpractice comes in many forms, and it is much more prevalent that you think.

A report by <a href="http://www.businessreviewusa.com/finance/5070/How-hospitals-can-avoid-medical-malpractice-suits">Business Review USA</a> says, &#x201C;According to the Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA), medical negligence is the third leading cause of death in the U.S., and the number of medical malpractice suits filed each year is more than 85,000. Among fatal medical injuries, 12,000 individuals die during an unnecessary surgery and 7,000 from medication errors...&#x201D; Unless something changes drastically, it does not seem likely that these numbers will change.
<h2>What constitutes medical malpractice?</h2>
While there are many different circumstances that fall under the category of medical malpractice, all have one thing in common; a doctor or healthcare provider failed to act reasonably. In other words, a doctor did not act as a reasonably careful doctor should have in those circumstances.

Some of the more common areas of medical malpractice include:
<ul>
    <li><strong>Birth injuries.</strong> Birth injuries and birth trauma are almost always the result of inattention to detail during labor. Birth injury or trauma can have lifelong consequences.</li>
    <li><strong>Failure to diagnose and misdiagnosis. </strong>Failure to diagnose can allow a disease to progress and become untreatable. Mistaking one condition for another can have similar effects, and both can be fatal.</li>
    <li><strong>Medication errors. </strong>Over- or under-dosing can have a serious effect on your health or recovery. Being prescribed the wrong medication entirely can be disastrous.</li>
    <li><strong>Emergency room errors.</strong> Prompt treatment can minimize damage and promote faster recovery. The wrong treatment can turn even minor injuries into life-threatening conditions.</li>
    <li><strong>Dangerous drugs&#xA0;and defective devices. </strong>Whether your doctor did not adequately research your condition or new information has come to light, your life can be altered when medicine goes wrong.</li>
    <li><strong>Nursing home abuse or neglect. </strong>The elderly are at higher risk of abuse or neglect because they may lack the ability to be their own advocates.</li>
</ul>
At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we protect the rights of the young and old. If you or someone you know has been the victim of malpractice, neglect or abuse by a medical professional, you may be entitled to compensation. Please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today for a free consultation at one of our office locations throughout Ohio and Kentucky.
-----

AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Flying Pigs Remind Us of the Dangers of Trucking Accidents
BASENAME: flying-pigs-remind-us-of-the-dangers-of-trucking-accidents
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 09/08/2015 12:30:35 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2914 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/Dangers-of-Trucking-Accidents-300x200.jpg" alt="Dangers of Truck Accidents in Kentucky" width="300" height="200">

In early June, a tractor-trailer carrying 2,200 piglets overturned on Rt. 35 in Xenia, Ohio. The single vehicle accident caused only minor injuries to the driver and passenger. However, the cargo caused no small problem for authorities in Xenia Township.

According to <a href="http://abc7chicago.com/news/-big-rig-wreck-spills-thousands-of-piglets-on-highway/774719/">ABC7 News</a>, &#x201C;Numerous agencies and volunteers worked to corral the animals after the rash Monday night on U.S. Route 35 in Xenia Township, near Dayton. Crews picked up the squealing pigs by their hind legs. They were taken to Greene County Fairgrounds. Authorities say... some of the animals ran into a nearby wooded area.&#x201D;

This recent mishap highlights a rarely mentioned aspect of big rig wrecks; namely, that the cargo itself can be hazardous. Details surrounding the accident are unclear, but pending an investigation it appears that the driver lost control during the last leg of his trip from South Carolina. Driver fatigue was likely a factor.

Big rigs are dangerous, and not only because they represent up to 80 tons hurtling down the road at highway speeds. Mechanical failures, load shifting, and human error can wreak havoc on roadways and with traffic when these trucks crash.

In this case, the roadway had to be closed to facilitate the cleanup of livestock. The accident left between 300 and 400 piglets dead, with the rest running around a busy highway and the surrounding woods. If this truck had been carrying hazardous materials instead, a full HAZ-MAT crew would have been required to respond to the accident and the repercussions could have been far more severe.

When trucks spill their load, they can create road hazards and obstacles that drivers are not used to seeing. Luckily, this accident happened at night in a relatively low traffic area. Had it happened in broad daylight on a major highway, the damages could have been much worse.

Whether the cause is driver fatigue or a mechanical mishap, the company that owns the truck is responsible for any damages caused. The driver in this case has since <a href="http://www.whio.com/news/news/local/semi-crashes-on-us-35-west-at-xenia/nmYcr/">lost his license</a>. Accidents happen, and when big trucks are involved, the consequences are usually disastrous. Our experienced truck accident attorneys can help if you have been involved in an accident. <a href="/Contact.shtml">Contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> today to meet with us at one of our Ohio or Kentucky offices.
-----

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Dr. Kelsey, Pioneer of FDA Drug Trials, Dies at 101
BASENAME: dr-kelsey-pioneer-of-fda-drug-trials-dies-at-101
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 09/04/2015 01:43:52 PM
-----
BODY:
Dr. Frances Oldham Kelsey, a Canadian pharmacologist instrumental in preventing birth injuries from medications, <a href="http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/849632">died on August 7</a> at the age of 101. Dr. Kelsey&#x2019;s passing is notable because of her lifetime of work protecting the public from dangerous drugs and medications. Her most notable accomplishment led to the ban of thalidomide in the U.S.

Dr. Stephen Ostroff, acting commissioner of the US Food and Drug Administration, said of her passing, &#x201C;Our nation lost a true pioneer in public health and consumer protection.&#x201D; Because of her efforts, countless birth defects were prevented and the United States passed legislation that gave rise to the modern regulatory practices of the FDA.
<h2>Her history with the FDA</h2>
Dr. Kelsey began working for the FDA in 1960; one of her first assignments was to review an application to allow Richardson-Merrill to sell thalidomide, a tranquilizer and painkiller intended to reduce morning sickness in pregnant woman, in the United States. Despite its popularity in other countries and pressure from the company to approve the drug, Dr. Kelsey insisted further research was necessary.

Her efforts led to the discovery that thalidomide dramatically affected a fetus and caused serious birth defects. Children of mothers who took thalidomide during pregnancy were born without limbs and sometimes did not survive birth. At her insistence, thalidomide was never approved for sale in the United States.

John F. Kennedy presented Dr. Kelsey with a President&#x2019;s Award for Distinguished Federal Civilian Service in 1962. In 2000, she was inducted into the National Women&#x2019;s Hall of Fame. Dr. Kelsey retired in 2005 after 45 years in the service of public health. Because of her work, an entire generation was spared the emotional anguish and lifelong suffering that thalidomide caused in other countries.

Today, the FDA&#x2019;s drug-approval process is far more stringent and complex than it was in 1960. This is due, in part, to Dr. Kelsey&#x2019;s efforts and her insistence that the public be protected whatever the cost:

&#x201C;Her efforts on thalidomide fueled the passage of legislation giving the FDA greater oversight and regulation of pharmaceutical products, requiring drug companies to conduct phased clinical trials to demonstrate efficacy of a new drug, in addition to safety, obtain informed consent from participants, and report side effects to the FDA. The regulations also gave the FDA greater control over drug advertising.&#x201D;

While the procedures are still imperfect, they have protected countless lives and prevented needless suffering.

Dr. Ostroff said, &#x201C;Our nation owes a great debt of gratitude to Dr. Frances Oldham Kelsey for her decades of service to public health.&#x201D; We at Crandall &amp; Pera Law would like to add our own thanks to Dr. Kelsey. Without her, untold numbers of children would never have had a chance at life, and countless more would be at risk without the protections afforded by the FDA.&#xA0; While the struggle continues to refine the system, mistakes can be made; if you or someone you know has suffered because of a faulty medication or medical device, please contact us today to schedule an appointment in one of our Ohio or Kentucky offices.

Dr. Frances Oldham Kelsey, a Canadian pharmacologist instrumental in preventing birth injuries from medications, <a href="http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/849632">died on August 7</a> at the age of 101. Dr. Kelsey&#x2019;s passing is notable because of her lifetime of work protecting the public from dangerous drugs and medications. Her most notable accomplishment led to the ban of thalidomide in the U.S.

Dr. Stephen Ostroff, acting commissioner of the US Food and Drug Administration, said of her passing, &#x201C;Our nation lost a true pioneer in public health and consumer protection.&#x201D; Because of her efforts, countless birth defects were prevented and the United States passed legislation that gave rise to the modern regulatory practices of the FDA.
<h2>Her history with the FDA</h2>
Dr. Kelsey began working for the FDA in 1960; one of her first assignments was to review an application to allow Richardson-Merrill to sell thalidomide, a tranquilizer and painkiller intended to reduce morning sickness in pregnant woman, in the United States. Despite its popularity in other countries and pressure from the company to approve the drug, Dr. Kelsey insisted further research was necessary.

Her efforts led to the discovery that thalidomide dramatically affected a fetus and caused serious birth defects. Children of mothers who took thalidomide during pregnancy were born without limbs and sometimes did not survive birth. At her insistence, thalidomide was never approved for sale in the United States.

John F. Kennedy presented Dr. Kelsey with a President&#x2019;s Award for Distinguished Federal Civilian Service in 1962. In 2000, she was inducted into the National Women&#x2019;s Hall of Fame. Dr. Kelsey retired in 2005 after 45 years in the service of public health. Because of her work, an entire generation was spared the emotional anguish and lifelong suffering that thalidomide caused in other countries.

Today, the FDA&#x2019;s drug-approval process is far more stringent and complex than it was in 1960. This is due, in part, to Dr. Kelsey&#x2019;s efforts and her insistence that the public be protected whatever the cost:

&#x201C;Her efforts on thalidomide fueled the passage of legislation giving the FDA greater oversight and regulation of pharmaceutical products, requiring drug companies to conduct phased clinical trials to demonstrate efficacy of a new drug, in addition to safety, obtain informed consent from participants, and report side effects to the FDA. The regulations also gave the FDA greater control over drug advertising.&#x201D;

While the procedures are still imperfect, they have protected countless lives and prevented needless suffering.

Dr. Ostroff said, &#x201C;Our nation owes a great debt of gratitude to Dr. Frances Oldham Kelsey for her decades of service to public health.&#x201D; We at Crandall &amp; Pera Law would like to add our own thanks to Dr. Kelsey. Without her, untold numbers of children would never have had a chance at life, and countless more would be at risk without the protections afforded by the FDA.&#xA0; While the struggle continues to refine the system, mistakes can be made; if you or someone you know has suffered because of a faulty medication or medical device, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today to schedule an appointment in one of our Ohio or Kentucky offices.

--------
AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Friday Night Lights Out: The Truth about Football and Long Term Brain Damage
BASENAME: friday-night-lights-out-the-truth-about-football-and-long-term-brain-damage
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/19/2015 08:49:00 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2882 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/The-Truth-about-Football-and-Long-Term-Brain-Damage-300x225.jpg" alt="The Truth about Football and Long Term Brain Damage" width="300" height="225">

The National Football League recently agreed to pay former players nearly $1 billion in compensation to settle the class action lawsuit against them. The plaintiffs were <a href="http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/22/us/nfl-concussion-lawsuit-settlement/">more than 5,000</a> former NFL players who were &#x201C;suffering from dementia, depression or Alzheimer&apos;s that they blamed on blows to the head&#x201D; and started the class action suit against the NFL, &#x201C;accusing it of concealing the dangers of concussions and rushing injured players back onto the field while glorifying and profiting from the kind of bone-jarring hits that make for spectacular highlight-reel footage.&#x201D; The final approval on the settlement came this past April from a federal judge.

Some people are incredibly angry at Roger Goodell, for putting the NFL&#x2019;s profits before its players. Some people blame the players themselves, accusing them of being greedy. Some people want to end football forever; some want to change the rules; some want to say that there&#x2019;s no excuse now, and that playing football when you know the dangers is no different than lighting a cigarette or driving drunk.

However, regardless of your position, this much is crystal clear: we all now have definitive proof that repeated blows to the head &#x2013;&#xAD; even those which do not cause a concussion &#x2013; cause a devastating brain injury called Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy (CTE). CTE is &#x201C;a progressive degenerative disease of the brain found in athletes (and others) with a history of repetitive brain trauma, including symptomatic concussions as well as asymptomatic subconcussive hits to the head.&#x201D; At this point, whether or not the NFL or its doctors knew about the dangers they placed their athletes in is almost irrelevant (which makes it no less despicable). What is relevant is the following question: If the NFL would pay nearly $1 billion to compensate former players for their brain injuries, which occurred while playing football, why would any parent voluntarily allow their son or daughter to play football?

Playing football leads to brain damage. Permanent, devastating brain damage. The numbers are in; <a href="http://www.medpagetoday.com/Neurology/HeadTrauma/44760">the science is clear</a>. Every single player at every single age is at risk.

And that includes your child.
<h2>Why your child is at-risk of developing CTE from playing sports</h2>
Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy used to be called &#x201C;punch drunk,&#x201D; because the condition was observed so frequently in boxers. It was not until the last decade that it became apparent football causes CTE due to the repetitive blows to the head.&#xA0; It occurs when a person takes repeated blows to the head, over a certain period of time, even when they do not result in a concussion. While not every football player will develop CTE, it is now clear the overwhelming majority of players will. This is due to &#xA0;repeated trauma causing a build-up of a protein called tau. Tau normally makes sure that the <a href="http://www.foxnews.com/health/2014/10/31/tau-protein-not-plaque-may-cause-alzheimers-study-says/">nerves in your brain</a> are operating smoothly, but after football related blows to the head, it twists and collapses into what doctors call &#x201C;tangles.&#x201D; These tangles directly lead to irreversible brain damage.

This is the worst part: according to Boston University, &#x201C;these changes in the brain can begin months, years, or even decades <strong>after the last brain trauma or end of active athletic involvement</strong>&#x201D; (emphasis ours). That means that one season of middle school football can cause your child to suffer a debilitating, degenerative brain disease that could lead to dementia, violent tendencies and even suicide.

Imagine what four years of high school football can cause. Imagine what 15 years of professional football in the NFL leads to.
<h2>Choose life</h2>
The underlying problem with all of this doesn&#x2019;t only lie with Goodell and the NFL: it lies with every single person who watches the games, who buys the merchandise, who lets their children play a game that may one day cause them to <a href="http://edition.cnn.com/2012/12/01/sport/football/nfl-chiefs-shooting/">kill their families and then themselves</a>. It&#x2019;s about choosing a life where your child has an <a href="http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/sports/concussion-watch/76-of-79-deceased-nfl-players-found-to-have-brain-disease/">80% chance of developing CTE</a>. It&#x2019;s about not examining the <a href="http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/football/study-cte-linked-domestic-violence-article-1.1978936">causes of domestic violence</a> that plague American football players.

Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy is real. It is linked to football. It is killing our kids. And until we, as parents and community members, decide to stand up and say &#x201C;No more!&#x201D; it will continue to do so.

It&#x2019;s time to stop choosing football. Choose the future. Choose your children. Choose life.
-----

--------
AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Tracy Morgan Big Rig Accident Sparks Calls For Reform
BASENAME: tracy-morgan-big-rig-accident-sparks-calls-for-reform
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 09/14/2015 05:08:45 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2926" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/Big-Rig-Truck-Accident-300x200.jpg" alt="Big Rig Truck Accident" width="300" height="200">Last year, Tracy Morgan and his entourage were traveling on the New Jersey turnpike when a tractor-trailer struck their limo bus. The comedian was critically injured and lost his close friend, 62-year-old comedian James McNair. Three other passengers were badly hurt in the accident.

Christopher Hart, Chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, informed those <a href="http://thehill.com/policy/transportation/250857-ntsb-tracy-morgan-crash-caused-by-speed-driver-fatigue">attending the hearing</a> that the &#x201C;driver in the Cranbury crash had been on duty for 13&#xBD; hours of a 14-hour day, with more driving planned. <strong>He had been awake more than 28 hours </strong>when his truck struck the limo van, including an overnight drive from his residence in Georgia to the distribution center at which he was based&#x201D; (emphasis hours).

Hart&#x2019;s detailing of the NTSB&#x2019;s findings highlights national issues with big rigs on the road. The accident occurred while Congress was debating changes to federal regulations for truck-driver scheduling. Currently, drivers must take a 30 minute break for every 8 hours of driving, are not supposed to drive more than 10 hours in an 11 hour work-day, and have a maximum work week of 70 hours, after which they must take a 34-hour break before continuing a job or starting a new one. With the conclusion of the NTSB&#x2019;s investigation, more voices than ever are calling for national reform and Congress has paused its look into loosening restrictions like these.

The AFL-CIO Transportation Trades Department <a href="http://thehill.com/policy/transportation/251275-unions-tracy-morgan-crash-findings-should-be-a-wake-up-call-for-feds">has spoken out</a>, claiming that the high-profile accident should be a &#x201C;wake-up&#x201D; for federal regulators. Ed Wytkind, President of the AFL-CIO TTD, went so far as to describe the situation as a &#x201C;driver fatigue crisis&#x201D; in a blog post.

In this case, the driver of the truck was charged with death by auto and four counts of assault by auto. Tracy Morgan settled with Walmart earlier this year for an undisclosed amount, but the wounds he suffered and the attention this case has garnered will hopefully leave a more lasting mark. Until federal regulations prevent this sort of accident from happening, if injured, you may need help recovering from the companies that operate these too often dangerous vehicles. If you or someone you know has been involved in a big rig accident, <a href="/Contact.shtml">please contact</a> an Ohio or Kentucky office of Crandall &amp; Pera Law for a free consultation today.
-----

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: How Possible Is It to Diagnose a Potential Stroke Victim?
BASENAME: how-possible-is-it-to-diagnose-a-potential-stroke-victim
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 09/11/2015 11:48:57 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2922 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/How-Possible-Is-It-to-Diagnose-a-Potential-Stroke-Victim-300x200.jpg" alt="How Possible Is It to Diagnose a Potential Stroke Victim" width="300" height="200">

Mike Fuller has filed a complaint against Southwestern Illinois Health Facilities, Inc. doing business as Anderson Hospital Urgent Care. The <a href="http://madisonrecord.com/stories/510633888-anderson-hospital-doctors-deny-liability-in-patient-s-medical-malpractice-suit-over-stroke">complaint alleges</a> that due to the facilities&#x2019; negligence, Fuller suffered a stroke that left him unable to move his limbs, accrued staggering medical expenses, and caused him pain and suffering.

According to the complaint, agents of the company allegedly failed to examine Fuller&#x2019;s carotid arteries and failed to order imaging for a &#x201C;diabetic, hypertensive, former smoker who was later documented to have significant coronary artery disease.&#x201D;

When cases like this come along, there are significant factors to consider. Fuller&#x2019;s past behavior and history certainly should have been indicative of a potential problem, but Southwestern Illinois Health Facilities has the resources to argue any motion and counter any case that Fuller can argue.
<h2>Know the risk factors</h2>
Strokes are the number 4 killer of <a href="http://www.heart.org/idc/groups/heart-public/@wcm/@adv/documents/downloadable/ucm_307206.pdf">people in Ohio,</a> and the number 5 killer of <a href="http://www.heart.org/idc/groups/heart-public/@wcm/@adv/documents/downloadable/ucm_307175.pdf">people in Kentucky</a>. Any of the following lifestyle factors automatically put you in a higher risk category of suffering a stroke; smoking, high blood pressure, sedentary lifestyle, poor diet, high cholesterol, poor weight management, or drug use. If you have any of these lifestyle factors, you should know the signs and symptoms of stroke. The faster you are treated for a stroke, the better your chances of a full recovery. The <a href="http://yourdiseaserisk.wustl.edu/YDRDefault.aspx?ScreenControl=YDRGeneral&amp;ScreenName=YDRStrokeFact_Sheet#q5">symptoms of a stroke</a> include:
<ul>
    <li>Sudden weakness or numbness, especially in one side of your body</li>
    <li>Sudden loss of vision or problems seeing</li>
    <li>Sudden confusion, inability to speak or understand others</li>
    <li>Sudden dizziness and lack of coordination</li>
    <li>Sudden severe headache</li>
</ul>
Failure to diagnose cases are rarely a straightforward. In the case of a stroke, the waters may be even muddier. Strokes are preventable, mostly through healthy living, and they are treatable within a reasonable time frame. While there is no guaranteed test of who will or will not suffer a stroke, there are certain indicators that a patient may be in a high-risk category. Failure to monitor people exhibiting those risks may increase their chances of having a stroke, and could be construed as medical malpractice depending on the circumstances.

If you or someone you know has suffered a stroke while under medical care, our experienced medical malpractice attorneys are here to help. Our skilled legal staff and registered nurses work together for you. Please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> to reserve a consultation in one of our offices throughout Ohio and Kentucky.

AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Onglyza and Kombiglyze XR Linked to Pancreatic Cancer and Heart Failure
BASENAME: onglyza-and-kombiglyze-xr-linked-to-pancreatic-cancer-and-heart-failure
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 09/18/2015 01:09:33 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2943 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/Onglyza-and-Kombiglyze-XR-Linked-to-Pancreatic-Cancer-300x200.jpg" alt="Onglyza and Kombiglyze XR Linked to Pancreatic Cancer" width="300" height="200">

For adults with Type 2 diabetes, there is a range of drug regimens available to control the condition. However, two drugs have recently been linked to acute pancreatitis leading to precancerous changes and an increased risk of heart failure.

Onglyza or Kombiglyze XR both belong to a class of Type 2 diabetes medications called incretin mimetics. Both contain the active ingredient saxagliptin, and work by increasing the amount of incretin released by the intestine. Incretin plays an important role in regulating the amount of insulin secreted by the pancreas.
<h2>Type 2 diabetics taking these drugs are at risk</h2>
According to the Food and Drug Administration, there have been reports of acute pancreatitis in patients taking Onglyza. Saxagliptin should not be prescribed to people who have a history of pancreatitis (inflammation of the pancreas) because it is not known whether the medication can increase the risk for the disease.

In 2014, the FDA issued a safety alert after a study found that Onglyza was responsible for a 27% increase in the risk of hospitalization for heart failure. The drug is still available for sale, and is still being prescribed despite the known risks.

Your doctor should be aware of your family history, and should not prescribe either of these drugs if you have any risk factors for pancreatitis or a heart condition. However, some doctors may not be aware of the adverse side effects of these drugs. If you are taking Onglyza or Kombiglyze XR for Type 2 diabetes, you should discuss alternative treatment options with your doctor.

If you or someone you know is currently taking or has taken Onglyza or Kombiglyze XR for Type 2 diabetes, you should have a full physical examination as soon as possible and talk to your doctor about alternative treatments.

You may be entitled to compensation if you have suffered any injuries or damages while taking these medications. Our experienced medical malpractice and defective medical device attorneys can get you the compensation you deserve. Visit the Crandall &amp; Pera Law offices in Ohio or Kentucky, or <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us today</a> for a consultation with an experienced defective drug litigation attorney.

--------
AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Still Hate Plaintiff&#x2019;s Lawyers? If the DOJ Had Hired Some, GM Might Have Actually Been Held Accountable
BASENAME: still-hate-plaintiffs-lawyers-if-the-doj-had-hired-some-gm-might-have-actually-been-held-accountable
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 09/28/2015 10:22:57 AM
-----
BODY:
The General Motors ignition switch debacle has been splashed across the news in varying degrees for years. The Department of Justice has recently ended the controversy with decisive action, and it looks like the story is just going to go away. News media&#x2019;s coverage of the agreement has been perfunctory at best.

We submit that the Department of Justice handled the GM ignition switch scandal astoundingly badly. As a condition of the final settlement, there will be no criminal charges. General Motors was fined less than $1 billion, significantly less than Toyota received several years ago for their sticking accelerator issue.
<h2>Why everyone should be outraged</h2>
The deaths were the result of a decade long cover-up, perpetuated by the company&#x2019;s intentional conduct to hide the issue. This type of gross corporate negligence is inexcusable, and the Department of Justice essentially punished GM with a slap on the wrist.

The DOJ agreed to defer prosecution in the case, placing the company on a three-year probation. The charges, by the way, would have been for failure to disclose a defect. Not for intentional conduct, not for killing people &#x2013; but for failing to report a problem. The DOJ said that GM&#x2019;s executives were extraordinarily cooperative after the issue was uncovered. Tell that to the families of those killed by their mistake.

No indictments, no criminal charges: no one will be punished for directly causing the deaths of 124 people. No one will suffer financially with the possible exception of GM&#x2019;s stockholders. The DOJ managed to shove a little more money into the government&#x2019;s coffers, and in doing so, passed on the message that killing people with your products, while frowned upon, is ultimately forgivable if you apologize.
<h2>Protecting the people once again</h2>
GM&#x2019;s ignition switch recall was an outrage, and constituted negligence in the highest degree. The company lied about the scope and scale of the issue and lied about the number of people affected. They attempted to save face by downplaying an issue that cost 124 people their lives. The number of deaths, by the way, was not freely submitted by GM but was instead uncovered by plaintiff&#x2019;s lawyers diligently working to correct a life-threatening wrong.

The difference between a good resolution to this abhorrent situation and the resolution that we got is very simple. The difference is about 5 plaintiff&#x2019;s lawyers that could have represented the friends and families of those who were killed by GM&#x2019;s gross negligence. Those lawyers would have ensured that the message hit home for GM &#x2013; that people suffered on their watch because of their mistakes. General Motors and the Department of Justice should be ashamed.

The power of an experienced plaintiff personal injury attorney cannot be denied. At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, our personal injury lawyers help people, like the victims of the GM defect, every single day. To learn more about our services, please contact us to reserve a consultation time at one of our offices in Ohio or Kentucky.

AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: An Open Letter to Parents of High School Football Players
BASENAME: an-open-letter-to-parents-of-high-school-football-players
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 09/24/2015 11:19:24 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-2973 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/High-School-Football-Players-and-Head-Injury-300x200.jpg" alt="High School Football Players and CTE" width="300" height="200">

New research from the Department of Veterans Affairs and Boston University has found that &#x201C;87 of 91 deceased NFL players tested were found to have evidence of the brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or CTE.&#x201D; The study found that the prevalence of the disease is overwhelming; &#xA0;96% of former players had evidence of CTE, and 79% of <em>all players at all levels</em> showed signs.

And yes, that includes your high school age children.
<h2>All players AT ALL LEVELS show signs of CTE</h2>
One more time; all players, at all levels. PBS reports that &#x201C;CTE [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][was found] in the brain tissue in 131 out of 165 individuals who, before their deaths, played football either professionally, semi-professionally, in college <strong>or in high school</strong>&#x201D; (emphasis ours). That does not mean that your child is merely at an increased risk of possibly developing the disease. It means that your child is virtually guaranteed to develop symptoms of CTE if he or she plays football.
<h2>What is CTE?</h2>
Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy was technically <a href="http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/sports/league-of-denial/the-four-stages-of-cte/">discovered in 2002</a>, in the brain of a former football player named Mike Webster. Before that, it was called &#x201C;punch drunk,&#x201D; a term reserved almost exclusively for boxers. Thus, we always *knew* about CTE; we just did not have an official name for it.

There are four stages to the disease:
<ul>
    <li><strong>Stage One. </strong>The protein tau builds up in unconnected parts of the brain, usually around the frontal lobe or the crown. Tau can lead to irreversible brain damage by &#x201C;interrupting normal functioning and eventually killing nerve cells,&#x201D; according to Frontline.</li>
    <li><strong>Stage Two.</strong> As the tau affects more brain cells, you can observe changes in behavior of the afflicted person. Depression, rage and poor impulse control are common.</li>
    <li><strong>Stage Three.</strong> The tau has expanded into the temporal lobe, and begins to affect the hippocampus and amygdala. Confusion is a common result; memory loss another.</li>
    <li><strong>Stage Four.</strong> Frontline puts it best: &#x201C;The brain becomes deformed and brittle, and cognitive function is severely limited. By Stage 4 tau deposits have overwhelmed the brain, killing many nerve cells and shrinking it by roughly half its size.&#x201D;</li>
</ul>
This is what will happen to your children when you let them play football.
<h2>Playing with fire</h2>
If you still believe that your child will beat the odds, consider these numbers from the <a href="http://www.nsc.org/learn/safety-knowledge/Pages/injury-facts-chart.aspx">National Safety Council</a>:
<ul>
    <li>Chance of dying from heart disease, the Number 1 killer in America: 1 in 7</li>
    <li>Chance of dying in a car crash: 1 in 112</li>
    <li>Chance of dying from a fall: 1 in 144</li>
</ul>
Chance of a football player developing CTE: <strong>96 out of 100.</strong>

There is one more piece of crucial information that you, as parents of high school football players, need to know: CTE cannot necessarily be diagnosed in living players. Your high school football player is likely to already have some evidence of CTE, and there is the distinct possibility that <strong>no doctor will be able to diagnose it.</strong> This has nothing to do with the quality of your doctor or the facility in which he or she works, and everything to do with the test itself. It is only possible to reach a definitive conclusion after a player has died &#x2013; and by then, it is too late.

This is a real disease affecting thousands of men and women around the country. We cannot change the past, but as parents we can take steps towards securing a better future. That starts with putting an end to high school football by refusing to let our children play. As parents, it is our duty to protect our kids as best we can by making the hard decisions for them when they cannot make those decisions themselves.

Choose the future. Choose your children. Choose life.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
-----

--------
AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Crusading for Justice: Honoring the Work of Those Who Would Protect You from Negligence at the American Museum of Tort Law
BASENAME: crusading-for-justice-honoring-the-work-of-those-who-would-protect-you-from-negligence-at-the-american-museum-of-tort-law
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/02/2015 11:25:06 AM
-----
BODY:
On September 26, 2015, the American Museum of Tort Law (the first and only museum of its kind) opened its doors in Winsted, Connecticut &#x2013; the hometown of the museum&#x2019;s creator and founder, Ralph Nader. It is not your typical museum; instead of interactive art or history exhibits, you can see the 1963 Chevrolet Corvair that led Mr. Nader to write <em>Unsafe at Any Speed</em>, the book that helped Americans see that they deserved to be treated with respect and dignity &#x2013; and that defective product manufacturers needed to be held accountable &#x2013; when they suffered a serious personal injury.

It seems almost serendipitous that Mr. Nader&#x2019;s museum opened only a week or so after the GM recall debacle, because it once again underlines the importance of having dedicated counsel on the side of injured consumers. Car safety, factory safety, medical safety, air quality control, the dangers of football: these issues, which so many people scoffed at when they first arose, have been challenged and addressed because of the work of Plaintiffs&#x2019; Bars and attorneys all over the country.
<h2>&#x201C;The cruelest movement I&#x2019;ve ever encountered&#x201D;</h2>
At the heart of the museum lies the ever-changing debate regarding tort reform. <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/26/us/ralph-naders-tort-law-museum-seeks-to-keep-his-crusade-evergreen.html?smprod=nytcore-iphone&amp;smid=nytcore-iphone-share">The New York Times</a> quotes Mr. Nader as saying that &#x201C;&#x2019;Tort law is being run into the ground, maligned, caricatured and slandered because it&#x2019;s effective,&#x2019;&#x201D; and that the &#x201C;conservative agenda of tort reform, which seeks limits on lawsuits and financial awards, [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][is] &#x2018;the cruelest movement I&#x2019;ve ever encountered.&#x2019;&#x201D;

This new museum could help to counter the push for tort reform throughout the country, by reminding people about the good done by personal injury lawyers and consumer protection agencies. Some of the exhibits on display examine:
<ul>
    <li>The history of the Ford Pinto&#x2019;s problems with exploding gar tanks</li>
    <li>The Dalkan shield, an unsafe IUD that was linked to pelvic inflammatory disease and harmed more than 200,000 American women</li>
    <li>The Stella Liebeck case, where a woman suffered second and third degree burns from a cup of McDonald&#x2019;s coffee</li>
    <li><a href="http://www.nhregister.com/general-news/20150926/ralph-naders-american-museum-of-tort-law-opens-in-winsted">Big Tobacco&#x2019;s fall from power,</a> as the New Haven Register describes it</li>
    <li>The infamous &#x201C;<a href="http://abnormaluse.com/2012/06/the-flaming-rat-case-a-revisonist-analysis.html">Flaming Rats</a>&#x201D; case, which forced manufacturers and facilities owners to take responsibility for their own shoddy training, and to be held liable for the injuries their workers sustained when that training was not in place</li>
</ul>
In the end, the American Museum of Tort Law offers a fascinating look into what it takes to make the world a better and safer place for our families. While the museum may look like a &#x201C;greatest hits&#x201D; collection for Ralph Nader, it explore so much more than just his contributions. And it reminds us that those contributions can sometimes take years and years of persistence, rejection and dedication before they come to fruition.

As personal injury attorneys, we fight many of the same battles that Ralph Nader fights, albeit on smaller scales. The legal communities we join allow us to work together to fight on a larger scale. Everything we do, we do to help our clients have better futures &#x2013; and to make it less likely that future generations will have to fight the same battles over and over again. So if you happen to be in Connecticut (or are a student, practitioner or passionate follower of the justice system), consider making the American Museum of Tort Law one of your stops. We bet it will be a fascinating day.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law offers comprehensive counsel for medical malpractice and catastrophic personal injury victims throughout Ohio and Kentucky. To learn more about our services, we invite you to <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a>.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Horrifying Conditions Found In Kentucky Nursing Home
BASENAME: horrifying-conditions-found-in-kentucky-nursing-home
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/12/2015 11:49:22 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-3486 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Horrifying-Conditions-Found-In-Kentucky-Nursing-Home-300x200.jpg" alt="Horrifying Conditions Found In Kentucky Nursing Home" width="300" height="200">

In July of this year, Wave 3 news reported (in an understated way) that a Jeffersontown, Kentucky nursing home had lost its certification to care for Medicare and Medicaid patients. According to <a href="http://www.wave3.com/story/29521475/report-finds-deficiencies-at-nursing-home-medicare-medicaid-patients-to-be-moved">Wave 3</a>, &#x201C;In late May, the CHFS Office of Inspector General completed several investigations that were begun after receiving complaints about Hurstbourne Care Centre at Stony Brook, located at 2200 Stony Brook Drive. CHFS cited Hurstbourne Care Centre for numerous violations of state and federal laws that regulate the health and safety standards for care by nursing homes.&#x201D;

The investigations resulted in Medicare and Medicaid patients being relocated to other, approved facilities. Upon closer inspection, however, one realizes that the reasons for the loss of certification were quite horrific. The report by the Centers for Medicare &amp; Medicaid Services include deficiencies like:
<ul>
    <li>A resident interview revealed that ants were in the resident&#x2019;s bed and crawling all over the resident&#x2019;s body. The resident was scared and screamed for help from the staff.</li>
    <li>A resident was found on the floor, and no physician was notified. According to records, there was no evidence that precautions were taken against another fall. An x-ray taken 16 hours later showed a broken right tibia.</li>
    <li>A resident was not weighed weekly in direct violation of a physician&#x2019;s order. The resident lost 9.4% of total body weight in a month. Records showed that caloric intake was not properly monitored during that time.</li>
    <li>Residents were observed smoking on the grounds while unsupervised, indicating a failure to ensure a plan of care.</li>
    <li>A resident suffered an eye injury that remained untreated and unexamined for 30 days after the injury occurred.</li>
</ul>
The scope of negligence on behalf of this facility is overwhelming. What is more shocking, perhaps, is that the after an investigation by Kentucky officials, the facility was not shut down. Losing Medicare and Medicaid approval may ultimately prove devastating to the facility, but how much more damage will they be allowed to do before the business fails?

The regulatory system for nursing homes is obviously not working properly. That this level of neglect and abuse is even possible is downright horrifying. Elder abuse is very real, and when it occurs on an institutional level it is absolutely unforgivable.

If your loved one is in a nursing home or long-term care facility, you have placed faith in a facility and its&#x2019; personnel to take care of them. When that faith is betrayed, you and your loved one may be entitled to compensation. Our experienced and compassionate Kentucky nursing home abuse attorneys can help get you the compensation you deserve. Please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> today for a free consultation at one of our offices in Kentucky or in Ohio.

AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: IVC Filters: What You Should Know
BASENAME: ivc-filters-what-you-should-know
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/09/2015 10:25:30 AM
-----
BODY:
[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][caption id=&quot;attachment_3473&quot; align=&quot;alignright&quot; width=&quot;300&quot;]<img class="size-medium wp-image-3473" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/IVC-Filters-300x300.jpg" alt="artery, heart" width="300" height="300"> artery, heart[/caption]

An inferior vena cava (IVC) filter is designed to stop a blood clot from traveling to the lungs. It is implanted into the inferior vena cava, the largest vein in the body. The filters are designed and intended to be used in patients who are unable to take blood thinners. IVC filters come in two types; permanent and retrievable.

Patients who experience clotting issues while taking blood thinners are good candidates for permanent implantation, which causes fewer problems. However, retrievable IVC filters are commonly used in situations where blood thinners are ill-advised, such as after accident trauma, bleeding, or surgery.

It is this group that is at the highest risk. The retrievable IVC filters are prone to a host of problems. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) announced a safety alert in 2010, and another in 2014, detailing the types of issues regarding retrievable IVC filters. These include:
<ul>
    <li><strong>Device migration.</strong> The filters dislodge from the implantation site and travel through the body. The filter is then unable to perform as indicated and is likely to cause other problems.</li>
    <li><strong>Filter perforation. </strong>The filter stays in place but, due to improper placement or a change in conditions, punctures the side of the vein. This results in internal bleeding and can be fatal.</li>
    <li><strong>Filter fracture.</strong> The filter breaks apart in place, allowing clots to pass through in the heart or lungs, causing potentially fatal embolisms.</li>
    <li><strong>Detached device components. </strong>Parts of the filters break free and circulate through the bloodstream. This can be particularly dangerous because there are now multiple pieces that can puncture different parts of the body, leading to severe internal bleeding, pulmonary embolisms, and death.</li>
</ul>
The FDA is aware of the problem and has issued two major safety communications in regards to the device. The latest report said, &#x201C;The FDA recommends that implanting physicians and clinicians responsible for the ongoing care of patients with retrievable IVC filters consider removing the filter as soon as protection from pulmonary embolism is&#xA0;no longer needed.&#x201D;

If you or a loved one has been implantable with a retrievable IVC filter, you should speak with a medical professional immediately to determine the best way to proceed. If you or someone you know has been injured because of a defective medical device, you may be entitled to compensation. Our experienced defective medical device attorneys in Ohio and Kentucky can help you through a confusing and painful time. <a href="/Contact.shtml">Contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law</a> today for a free consultation.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
-----
EXTENDED BODY:

-----
EXCERPT:

-----
KEYWORDS:

-----


--------
AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: It Has Begun: One High School&#x2019;s Decision to Put the Safety of Students First
BASENAME: it-has-begun-one-high-schools-decision-to-put-the-safety-of-students-first
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/06/2015 09:36:18 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-3390" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/High-School-Football-Injuries-300x200.jpg" alt="High School Football and Head Injuries" width="300" height="200">It would have seemed impossible, extraordinary, even unfathomable a few years ago &#x2013; but the exodus has begun, and it is starting with Maplewood Richmond Heights High School in Missouri. This year&#x2019;s homecoming game will be a game of soccer, because in June the school board voted to disband their football team &#x2013; a football team that had gone to the state championship only 5 years ago. Lest you think this was the decision of only the Board, know this: the decision to ultimately disband the team came in large part from the very players themselves.

<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/29/sports/football/As-Worries-Rise-and-Players-Flee-a-Missouri-School-Board-Cuts-Football.html?smprod=nytcore-iphone&amp;smid=nytcore-iphone-share">The New York Times</a> cites Nelson Mitten, &#x201C;the school board president, [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][who] said that the series of injuries [sustained by the school&#x2019;s team] last season led the board to discuss disbanding the team. The students were polled about their interests, and just 15 said they would try out for the team this season, including only five returning players.&#x201D;

&#x201C;When you simply don&#x2019;t have the players, it&#x2019;s obvious,&#x201D; the school board president explained. &#x201C;I had two parents informally raise concerns, but this was more of a student-participation-driven decision. It withered.&#x201D;

And these players are not alone.
<h2>Taking steps around the country</h2>
Other schools around the country have seen interest wane, leading them to disband their teams. Ridgefield Memorial High School in New Jersey only had 13 students show up for varsity tryouts. Camden Hills Regional High School in Maine had to cancel games because of the sheer number of injuries their experienced players sustained, and they believed their younger player were at risk. All in all, &#x201C;the number of male high school football players has fallen to about&#xA0;<a href="http://www.nfhs.org/ParticipationStatics/PDF/2014-15_Participation_Survey_Results.pdf">1.08 million this year</a>, a 2.4 percent decline from&#xA0;five years ago.&#x201D;

Even the mighty Pop Warner organization is feeling the squeeze, as its numbers fall each year. It is currently being sued by a parent whose 25 year old son committed suicide; brain scans showed that he had chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or CTE.
<h2>A call to action for parents and school boards alike</h2>
It is time for us to stop thinking about &#x201C;tradition&#x201D; and to listen to our children, who are making their stances known. Decreasing numbers of participants and increasing numbers of injuries &#x2013; football is hurting our children. It has led to the deaths of three students this season alone, and the year has only just begun. How many more children have to die before we all, as a collective group, put an end to this horrific game?

The doctors have spoken. Your children have spoken. It is time to put an end to high school football once and for all.

Choose the future. Choose your children. Choose life.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
-----

AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Cutting Edge Science Gets Paralyzed Man Walking
BASENAME: cutting-edge-science-gets-paralyzed-man-walking
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/16/2015 05:40:03 PM
-----
BODY:
<a href="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Cutting-Edge-Science-Gets-Paralyzed.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-3549" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Cutting-Edge-Science-Gets-Paralyzed-300x200.jpg" alt="Science Gets Paralyzed to Walk" width="300" height="200"></a>The impossible dream of reanimating broken nerve connections just got one step closer to reality. Recent research published in the <em>Journal of NeuroEngineering and Rehabilitation </em>has shown that direct brain control can be used to control the legs after a spinal cord injury. For the first time in this case, scientists are attempting to allow direct brain control of the muscles involved. Scientists in this case used a combination of an electroencephalogram (EEG) system and direct muscle stimulation with electrodes.

The study&#x2019;s participant has been paralyzed for five years as the result of injury. He is categorized as a paraplegic, and does not have sensation in or the use of his legs. <a href="http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2015/09/150923213931.htm">Science Daily</a> said that in preparation for the experiment, &#x201C;Mental training was initially needed to reactivate the brain&apos;s walking ability. Seated and wearing an EEG cap to read his brainwaves, the participant trained to control an avatar in a virtual reality environment. He also required physical training to recondition and strengthen his leg muscles.&#x201D;

After almost 20 weeks of intensive training, he was able to walk a 12-foot long course with the aid of a body support system. This experiment serves as a proof-of-concept for the neurological community. In time, the researchers hope to use brain implants and implanted electrodes to develop a more seamless version of this technology.

Lead researcher Dr. Zoran Nenadic said, &#x201C;We hope that... implant[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][s] could achieve an even greater level of prosthesis control because brain waves are recorded with higher quality. In addition, such an implant could deliver sensation back to the brain, enabling the user to feel their legs.&#x201D;

This experiment is a rare treat for us. We so often bring news of risks and dangers that have lifelong impacts; in this case, we get to tell you that there is hope on the horizon for victims of spinal cord trauma.

However, a full solution may be many years down the road. In the meantime, medical bills and lifestyle changes require compensation. Until we get to the point where simple surgery can repair life-altering injuries, experienced personal injury attorneys are necessary to help you get the compensation you deserve. If you or someone you know has suffered a traumatic injury with life-altering consequences, we are here to fight for your rights. Visit Crandall &amp; Pera Law at our Kentucky or Ohio locations, or <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today for a free consultation.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]

AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Suffering Woman Victim of Surgical Malpractice
BASENAME: suffering-woman-victim-of-surgical-malpractice
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/23/2015 08:50:58 AM
-----
BODY:
In 2011, Rita Vasquez underwent cervical spine surgery at Our Lady of the Resurrection Medical Center in Chicago. The surgery was intended to relieve the severe pain that she was suffering as a result of a compressed disc. Instead, Vasquez sustained serious injuries including vascular injury, hemorrhage, nerve injury, and continued bodily pain.

Vazquez filed suit this past September against her surgeon, Dr. Michel Malek, alleging negligence. According to the <a href="http://cookcountyrecord.com/stories/510640533-patient-sues-doctor-alleging-medical-malpractice-in-cervical-spine-surgery">Cook County Record</a>, &#x201C;The suit says Malek failed to protect vasculature and neurological structures at the time of the surgery from damage and excessive bleeding.&#x201D; Vazquez is seeking compensation for her emotional distress, pain and suffering, and lost time and wages.
<h2>What is cervical spine surgery?</h2>
Cervical, in this case, refers to the part of the spine from the base of the brain to the bottom of the neck. Surgery on this area is complex; there are many important structures to navigate, from blood vessels and nerve endings to the esophagus and trachea.

The most common form of cervical spine surgery is called Anterior Cervical Decompression and Fusion (ACDF). The procedure is intended to eliminate root nerve pain that can translate into pain and weakness in other parts of the body. During the procedure, surgeons must navigate a complicated maze of vessels and organs. The esophagus, and by extension the trachea, must be moved out of the way to allow unimpeded access to the cervical vertebrae. Several layers of tissue must be cut or removed to allow access to the spine. Finally, tools must be inserted through all of these layers to allow surgeons to grind bone spurs and screw plates on to your spine.

This kind of surgery is invasive and carries a high risk of complications. The primary complication of ACDF is dysphagia, or difficulty swallowing. Sometimes, the degree of dysphagia is so high that a feeding tube is required. Occasionally, dysphagia is present before surgery as a result of a herniated disc. In these cases, it can be exacerbated during surgery and require a feeding tube for months after the operation.

The benefits of the surgery (i.e., relief from chronic pain) often outweigh the risks, but no one should be made to suffer unintended consequences of surgery. If you or someone you know has undergone ACDF surgery and suffered complications, you may be entitled to compensation. The experienced medical malpractice attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can help you during a difficult and emotional time. <a href="/Contact.shtml">Contact us today</a> for a free consultation at one of our offices in Kentucky or Ohio.
-----
