--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Forcing Hospital Residents to Work 30+ Hour Shifts Is a Bad Idea
BASENAME: forcing-hospital-residents-to-work-30-hour-shifts-is-a-bad-idea
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/05/2016 04:15:51 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-3769" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/Forcing-Hospital-Residents-to-Work-30-Hour-Shifts-Is-a-Bad-Idea-300x200.jpg" alt="Forcing Hospital Residents to Work 30+ Hour Shifts Is a Bad Idea" width="300" height="200">If you watch hospital procedurals on television, you are already familiar with the concept of the bleary-eyed doctor being forced to operate after little to no sleep in the last 24 hours. We have looked into the effects of sleep deprivation in nurses, and it stands to reason that they are not the only group of medical professionals who could hurt you or themselves is too fatigued to work.

Because of this, a study was done in 2011 by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education which limited the number of hours a resident could work, and hospitals around the country followed suit by adopting those restrictions. Now, a new study is testing whether or not patient care improves if the same doctor stays with the patient from the beginning &#x2013; and that means some young doctors might be working shifts that last for 30 hours or more.
<h2>The details of the study</h2>
The impetus for the study revolves round the idea that patients who are handed off from doctor to doctor in the initial hours of their visit are in more danger of being hurt, harmed or neglected in some way, or that it is more likely that mistakes can be made when a patient does not have one constant doctor monitoring his or her recovery. The research is funded in part by the National Institutes of Health, and is being run by the University of Pennsylvania.

The <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/some-new-doctors-are-working-30-hour-shifts-at-hospitals-around-the-us/2015/10/28/ab7e8948-7b83-11e5-beba-927fd8634498_story.html">Washington Post</a> reports that:

&#x201C;6,000 internal medicine trainees at 63 programs across the country [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][are participating in the study]. About 2,400 are first-year physicians&#x2026;. 31 programs will stick to current rules on resident work hours. Along with the 16-hour limit for first-year trainees, second- and third-year doctors are restricted to 24 consecutive hours of work. Residents may not work more than 80 hours a week, must have one day off every seven days and may not work overnight more often than every three days &#x2014; all averaged over one month.&#x201D;

The remaining 32 programs leave scheduling up to the director&#x2019;s discretion. If the director wishes to put residents on for 30-hour long shifts, he or she can.
<h2>Why this might prove to be a terrible idea</h2>
Aside from the obvious dangers of being treated by a sleep-deprived doctor &#x2013; or a doctor who feels obligated to take OTC caffeine pills in order to stay awake &#x2013; patients will be seen by new, young medical students. First, second and even third year residents may not have the adequate knowledge to respond to a crisis appropriately even when they are fully rested, let alone when they are exhausted. Yes, there must come a time when they are pushed from the nest, so to speak &#x2013; but adding the burden of sleep deprivation right at the beginning could lead to disastrous results.

Furthermore, this study began less than half a year ago, in July. We were unable to locate any information regarding which programs were participating in the study, with the exception of any listed in the Post article and any programs in New York, which are by law unable to participate. The ethics panel at U Penn &#x201C;deemed the study&#x2019;s risk to patients and new doctors minimal, and said <strong>hospitals did not have to inform either</strong>&#x201D; (emphasis ours) about their participation in the study, which means it is entirely possible that your recent trip to the hospital put you in the care of a second-year resident who had not slept in the last 24 hours &#x2013; <em>and no one was required to tell you.</em>

Even if the study proves that longer shifts can improve patient safety, the lack of transparency &#x2013; the inability of a consumer to obtain crucial information about his or her health provider, to make an informed decision about how he or she wishes to be treated &#x2013; seems dishonest and wrong. You should be allowed to know how long your doctor will work in each shift, and to decide whether or not you feel comfortable sticking with one healthcare provider or being seen by more than one.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we believe that healthcare providers and facilities owe you a duty of care that extends to pertinent information such as how long your doctor might be on-shift. If you are injured because a sleep-deprived doctor was incapable of making the right decision to protect you, you may have a claim for medical negligence. Please <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">contact us</a> to speak with an experienced medical malpractice attorney in our Ohio or Kentucky office locations.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Hot Pockets Save Ohio Man (and Other Tall Tales the Media Tell)
BASENAME: hot-pockets-save-ohio-man-and-other-tall-tales-the-media-tell
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/03/2016 07:45:12 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-3766" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/Hot-Pockets-Save-Ohio-Man-and-Other-Tall-Tales-the-Media-Tell-300x200.jpg" alt="Hot Pockets Save Ohio Man (and Other Tall Tales the Media Tell)" width="300" height="200">Hot Pockets are the irresistibly hot and &#x201C;delicious&#x201D; choice of children everywhere and college kids on a budget. Nestl&#xE9; offers over 20 varieties of the microwave turnovers, ranging from breakfast to dessert. The frozen products have fed children and adults alike for over 30 years. But recently, the brand added a new skill set to its r&#xE9;sum&#xE9;.

Jason Bartley was running errands on November 10. On his way home, he took extra time to stop and grab some Hot Pockets. The detour, it appears, may have saved his life.
<h2>Saved by a craving for a snack?</h2>
Jason lives at an apartment complex in Akron; his building turned into a raging inferno that Tuesday when a plane lost control and crashed into the building. According to <a href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/ohio-plane-crash-man-buy-hot-pockets/">CBS News</a>, &#x201C;The 10-seat Hawker H25 business jet clipped utility wires and crashed into the four-unit apartment building, sparking a fire that destroyed the building, Ohio State Highway Patrol Lt. Bill Haymaker said. Nobody was home at any of the apartments, and there were no other injuries.&#x201D;

The plane was scheduled to land at a small airport just two miles from the apartment building. Because Jason decided to stop for the Hot Pockets, he was not at home when the plane crashed into his building.

Roberta Porter, who lives a block away from the apartment, also suffered a near miss. She was driving home when she saw the plane drop suddenly and crash into the building. She admitted to CBS News that if she had been driving faster, the plane could have clipped her car.
<h2>The real truth about accidents</h2>
This story, though terrifying, is an example of how news media contribute to perceptions of artificial risks. Plane crashes dominate headlines because of the nature and scale of the destruction they cause. However, both Jason Bartley and Roberta Porter were far more likely to have been in a car accident that day than to have been struck by the business jet. Consider this data from a report by <a href="http://traveltips.usatoday.com/air-travel-safer-car-travel-1581.html">USA Today</a>:

&#x201C;The National Transportation Safety Board compiles aviation accident data. Preliminary statistics for 2008 show only 20 accidents for U.S. air carriers operating scheduled service. This works out to nearly zero accidents per million flying miles. No one died, and only five people were seriously injured.&#x201D;

While we have seen more news reports in recent years about plane crashes, they really are far rarer than the media would let you believe. Car accidents, on the other hand, happen every day, and the consequences can be devastating.

If you or someone you know has been injured in an accident, Crandall &amp; Pera Law can fight for your rights. Our experienced Kentucky and Ohio personal injury lawyers can help get you the compensation you deserve. <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">Contact us</a> today for a free consultation.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Jimmy Carter Is Cancer Free Thanks To Revolutionary Drug
BASENAME: jimmy-carter-cancer-free-thanks-revolutionary-drug
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/14/2016 04:19:28 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-3790" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/Jimmy-Carter-Is-Cancer-Free-Thanks-To-Revolutionary-Drug-300x200.jpg" alt="Jimmy Carter Is Cancer Free Thanks To Revolutionary Drug" width="300" height="200">Every now and then, we find a story that gives us hope &#x2013; not only for the direction medical science can take us, but for the families of patients with terminal diseases. So it is our great pleasure to announce that former President Jimmy Carter is cancer free thanks to a new drug. In early December, he announced to his Sunday school class at his church that doctors did not find any cancer at all during his last visit.
<h2>Advanced cancer responds to new drug</h2>
Carter suffers from stage 4 melanoma. According to the <a href="http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/melanoma/basics/definition/con-20026009">Mayo Clinic</a>, &#x201C;Melanoma, the most serious type of skin cancer, develops in the cells (melanocytes) that produce melanin &#x2014; the pigment that gives your skin its color. Melanoma can also form in your eyes and, rarely, in internal organs, such as your intestines.&#x201D; The advanced stage of Carter&#x2019;s melanoma means that cancerous cells have spread throughout his entire body.

The former President believes his remission is directly linked to a new cancer drug called Keytruda. The drug, generically known as pembrolizumab, uses a different approach to fighting cancer. While most drugs on the market work to boost and support the immune system, Keytruda disrupts a tumor&#x2019;s ability to hide from the immune system, letting the body&#x2019;s natural defenses work to shrink tumors in combination with other therapies like radiation.

According to a recent report by <a href="http://www.nbcnews.com/health/cancer/heres-look-keytruda-drug-jimmy-carter-says-made-his-tumors-n475561">NBC News</a>, &#x201C;...cancer experts note that it&apos;s not at all clear that the drug itself is what shrank Carter&apos;s tumors. The former president was also treated with radiation to his brain and had a large tumor on his liver removed.&#x201D; However, the success rate of advanced cancer treatment with Keytruda is undeniable.
<h2>Hope for advanced cancer sufferers</h2>
The success rate of Keytruda is so great that the Food and Drug Administration gave it accelerated approval in 2014. The FDA based the accelerated approval on a study led by Dr. Antoni Ribas of the University of California Los Angeles. The clinical trial found that Keytruda shrunk tumors for over 70% of patients, and the effects continued even after the drug was no longer being administered.

While the cure for cancer remains elusive, treatment is making huge strides. Keytruda is just one of them; teams of researchers around the world are responsible for making people healthier than ever. We at Crandall &amp; Pera Law support the efforts of everyone who works to improve the quality of life. To learn more, <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">contact us</a> today to speak with dedicated injury lawyers serving Ohio and Kentucky.

&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Should There Be a Legal Age Limit for Playing Football?
BASENAME: should-there-be-a-legal-age-limit-for-playing-football
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/11/2016 06:10:38 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-3785" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/Should-There-Be-a-Legal-Age-Limit-for-Playing-Football-300x200.jpg" alt="Should There Be a Legal Age Limit for Playing Football?" width="300" height="200">A recent <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/07/opinion/dont-let-kids-play-football.html?smprod=nytcore-iphone&amp;smid=nytcore-iphone-share">op-ed piece in the New York Times</a> asks the same questions we have been asking: namely, should children &#x2013; whose brains and bodies are still developing &#x2013; be allowed to play football? It was written by <a href="http://bennetomalufoundation.org/about-bennet-omalu/">Bennet Omalu</a>, the man who discovered the link between chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) and football. The new Will Smith movie, <em>Concussion,</em> is based upon Dr. Omalu&#x2019;s work in this area. To say that it is an op-ed worth reading is an understatement, because no one understands the dangers as well as he does.

Dr. Omalu believes that a legal age restriction should be placed upon those who want to play football. He writes:

&#x201C;The human brain becomes fully developed at about 18 to 25 years old. We should at least wait for our children to grow up, be provided with the information and education on the risk of play, and let them make their own decisions. No adult, not a parent or a coach, should be allowed to make this potentially life-altering decision for a child.

We have a legal age for drinking alcohol; for joining the military; for voting; for smoking; for driving; and for consenting to have sex. We must have the same when it comes to protecting the organ that defines who we are as human beings.&#x201D;

In some ways, the argument we have been making mirrors Dr. Omalu&#x2019;s, especially when it comes to not letting your children play football. CTE can have devastating effects on people who engage in contact sports, and the effects may not be apparent until much, much later in life. The traumatic contact can destroy the neurons in our brains, and as the doctor puts it, &#x201C;In more than 30 years of looking at normal brain cells in the microscope, I have yet to see a neuron that naturally creates a new neuron to regenerate itself. We are born with a certain number of neurons. We can only lose them; we cannot create new neurons to replenish old or dying ones.&#x201D; Once those neurons are gone, they are gone for good &#x2013; and no amount of therapy or medication can bring them back.
<h2>This is not an outlier opinion</h2>
In October, we wrote about schools throughout the country that are disbanding their football teams, as a result of poor turnout for the players. Many times, the decisions are brought about by the students themselves; their parents did not forbid them to play &#x2013; they simply chose not to.

It is also important to remember that football players are not the only ones at risk. All contact sports which present the opportunity to sustain a head or brain injury &#x2013; boxing, mixed martial arts, hockey, rugby and even soccer, to some extent &#x2013; can increase your child&#x2019;s risk of developing CTE.

Permanent brain damage and a life of debilitating pain, mental confusion or personality changes are no longer hypotheticals. These are real, proven effects of CTE. It is time we put the safety of our children before tradition, and considered making football a game for adults only.

It&#x2019;s time to stop choosing football. Choose the future. Choose your children. Choose life.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: New Study Finds Chemicals In E-Cigarettes Linked To Lung Disease
BASENAME: new-study-finds-chemicals-in-e-cigarettes-linked-to-lung-disease
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/19/2016 12:58:51 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-3793" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/New-Study-Finds-Chemicals-In-E-Cigarettes-Linked-To-Lung-Disease-300x200.jpg" alt="New Study Finds Chemicals In E-Cigarettes Linked To Lung Disease" width="300" height="200">The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has issued a proposed rule that would allow the regulation of e-cigarettes. For now, however the products remain unregulated, and there is a distinct lack of information about the potential harm that the popular product could cause.

In light of that fact, researchers from the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health designed a study to test flavored e-cigarettes and e-cigarette liquids for hazardous flavoring compounds. The results were published in <em>Environmental Health Perspectives </em>in early December, and the findings are devastating to say the least.
<h2>Study find most e-cigarettes contain hazardous substances</h2>
The team tested 51 sample substances for the chemicals diacetyl, acetoin, and 2,3 pentanedione. Diacetyl is linked to a condition known as &#x201C;popcorn lung&#x201D; (because it first showed up in workers inhaling popcorn flavoring). The other two chemicals are classified as &#x201C;high priority&#x201D; respiratory threats by the Flavor and Extract Manufacturers Association. The team found that 47 of the 51 flavors contained at least one of the three chemicals.

Study co-author David Christiani, Elkan Blout Professor of Environmental Genetics, told <a href="http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2015/12/popcorn-lung-seen-in-e-cigarette-smokers/">Harvard News</a>, &#x201C;Since most of the health concerns about e-cigarettes have focused on nicotine, there is still much we do not know about e-cigarettes. In addition to containing varying levels of the addictive substance nicotine, they also contain other cancer-causing chemicals, such as formaldehyde, and as our study shows, flavoring chemicals that can cause lung damage.&#x201D;
<h2>Respiratory damage not the only risk</h2>
The lack of federal regulation does not just pose a risk of respiratory disease. Faulty power supplies and improper combinations of parts have resulted in exploding e-cigarettes that cause serious physical harm. While further research is required, the most effective way to reduce the dangers of e-cigarettes would be regulation at the federal level.

Until legislation is enacted that gives the FDA the authority to regulate these devices, you and your loved ones remain at risk. If you or someone you know has developed a chronic respiratory condition after using an e-cigarette, or been injured by a faulty device, you may be entitled to compensation. The experienced personal Ohio and Kentucky injury attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can fight for your rights and help get you the compensation you deserve. <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Contact us </a>today for a free consultation.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Stalled Cleveland Clinic Malpractice Case to be Decided by Ohio Supreme Court
BASENAME: 3798
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/22/2016 01:49:43 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-3799" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/Stalled-Cleveland-Clinic-Malpractice-Case-to-be-Decided-by-Ohio-Supreme-Court-300x200.jpg" alt="Stalled Cleveland Clinic Malpractice Case to be Decided by Ohio Supreme Court" width="300" height="200">A retired Air Force colonel is attempting to right a wrong, but he will need the Ohio Supreme Court to intervene. David Antoon underwent surgery to remove his cancerous prostate gland in January of 2008. The cancer is gone, but Antoon was left impotent, incontinent, and unable to work following the allegedly botched surgery.
<h2>Why the Supreme Court is involved</h2>
Ohio allows a four-year window to file suit for medical malpractice. With a new filing in the Supreme Court in 2015, Antoon is well outside the four-year window. However, he claims that the Cleveland Clinic obstructed his ability to file a suit within the appropriate time frame by denying access to records and other discovery. The delays caused by the Clinic caused Antoon to drop his first suit in 2011 because of rising legal costs.

<a href="http://www.cleveland.com/healthfit/index.ssf/2015/12/ohio_supreme_court_to_decide_f.html">Cleveland.com</a> summed up the heart of the issue concisely, reporting, &#x201C;Over the past six years, Antoon has filed several lawsuits and regulatory complaints seeking to pierce what he describes as a veil of medical secrecy surrounding his case. In 2010, CMS cited the Clinic for failing to take appropriate actions to resolve Antoon&apos;s complaints, withholding information in a complaint file from an inspector, and failing to maintain proper consent forms for surgical patients.&#x201D;
<h2>Proof would drop the suit</h2>
The root of the contention is whether or not Antoon&#x2019;s surgeon, Dr. Jihad Kaouk, was present during his surgery. The CMS, in a separate inspection, found that Kaouk was performing what are known as concurrent surgeries, using doctors-in-training and other support staff to handle the routine details of surgery and only going hands-on during part of the procedure. While this is not unusual, it is important to Antoon, so much so that he offered to drop his lawsuit if the hospital could prove that Dr. Kaouk was present in the operating room.

The case is making waves because of the elapsed time. Heather Stutz, an attorney for the Ohio Hospital Association (among others), said, &#x201C;Litigating a claim more than four years after the alleged malpractice presents the same difficulties in terms of obtaining relevant and reliable evidence, imposing an unacceptable burden on [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][medical] providers.&#x201D;

While the case appears to be fairly straightforward, in that the Cleveland Clinic intentionally denied discovery to prevent Antoon from successfully pursuing a case, the devil is in the details. The Cleveland Clinic has a reputation for malpractice; our own Steve Crandall successfully fought and won a malpractice case against the Cleveland Clinic, resulting in a $7.7 million verdict for his client.

Whatever the circumstances, medical malpractice is devastating to its victims. If you or someone you know has been a victim, the compassionate and experienced medical malpractice attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can be your advocates. <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">Contact us</a> today for a free consultation with an experienced medical malpractice lawyer in Ohio or Kentucky.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: The &#x201C;Hot&#x201D; Toy Of The Season Keeps Exploding
BASENAME: the-hot-toy-of-the-season-keeps-exploding
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/25/2016 06:18:15 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-3802" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/scooterboard--300x200.jpg" alt="The &#x201C;Hot&#x201D; Toy Of The Season Keeps Exploding" width="300" height="200">Hoverboards were everywhere this holiday season, but mostly they resided at the top of Christmas lists around the country. Parents snapped up the toy anywhere they could get it, and with the high demand, it was inevitable that the market would be flooded with knock-offs when the original manufacturer couldn&#x2019;t keep up.

It wasn&#x2019;t long before problems began to crop up; <a href="http://www.wired.com/2015/12/why-hoverboards-keep-exploding/">WIRED</a> reported in mid-December that &#x201C;An exploding two-wheeler&#xA0;burned down a house in Louisiana&#xA0;a few weeks ago;&#xA0;another scooter&#xA0;combusted in the same state in the past week. A gyroboard caused significant damage to a home&#xA0;in New York&#xA0;a few days ago. Ata mall in Washington this week, a scooterboard caught fire and shoppers were forced to evacuate. The perceived danger is significant enough that major airlines have banned the little vehicles altogether.&#x201D;
<h2>Why is this happening?</h2>
Sometimes the boards are plugged in and charging; sometimes, they seem to explode for no reason during use. The problem lies with the Lithium Ion batteries used in the devices. Li-ion batteries power just about everything we use on a daily basis, from cell phones to tablets and laptops. These expensive devices use high-quality batteries from reputable manufacturers.

With the production rush for the holiday season, manufacturers of hoverboards turned to mass-produced li-ion batteries from China. Quality control at some of these plants is less than ideal, and can result in an internal misalignment that can cause the batteries to short and discharge all of their stored power explosively. Even if the product is manufactured correctly, constant collisions can damage the delicate internal components with the same result.

Even if the batteries are fine, the charging cables may be defective. Jay Whitacre, Professor of Materials Science &amp; Engineering at Carnegie Mellon University, said, &#x201C;If there is not proper protection to the cells, and if the charger is defective, the cells can be severely overcharged. In cases of severe overcharge, even perfectly made cells will eventually fail...&#x201D;
<h2>Keep your children safe</h2>
Parents everywhere be warned; there is no clear way to know which devices are affected. Worse, there is no good way to test for the problem, which can manifest after just a few charges or after hundreds of uses. If getting the device out of your house isn&#x2019;t an option, keep a fire extinguisher handy and only charge the devices under supervision.

If you or someone you know has been injured because of a defective product, you may be entitled to compensation. The experienced Ohio and Kentucky defective product attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can evaluate your case and help get you the compensation you deserve. <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">Contact us</a> today for a free consultation.

&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Recognizing Elder Abuse And Neglect
BASENAME: recognizing-elder-abuse-and-neglect
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/02/2016 09:46:44 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-3808" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Recognizing-Elder-Abuse-And-Neglect-300x200.jpg" alt="Recognizing Elder Abuse And Neglect" width="300" height="200">Last November, we <a href="http://www.patientsrightsblog.com/long-term-care-in-kentucky-is-not-over-regulated/">wrote</a> about the purported overly strict enforcement of patient safety regulations in Kentucky. In that writing, we discussed the state of long-term care in the Bluegrass State, noting in particular that 40% of nursing homes ranked &#x201C;below average&#x201D; according to the Centers for Medicare &amp; Medicaid Services. That number means that your loved one is at higher risk of nursing abuse or neglect simply by living in a long-term care facility in Kentucky.

Recognizing signs of abuse or neglect in your loved one can be difficult. While some signs and symptoms are obvious, others are more challenging. Coupled with the emotional involvement, it can be extremely hard to admit that your loved one has been a victim at the hands of a trusted care provider.
<h2>Keeping your loved ones safe</h2>
The best way to prevent the mistreatment of your loved one in a long-term care facility is to visit as frequently as you can. If you cannot visit as often as you would like, try to remain in near-constant contact, either though the phone or through the computer. (You might be surprised how much your parent or grandparent loves using a smartphone or tablet for face-to-face communication.) Being involved in your love one&#x2019;s life is the best way to catch a problem early on. Ask about daily activities, including medications and physical therapy, staff interactions, and anything else that comes to mind. The best preventer of abuse and neglect is information.

Additionally, look for these common signs when you are visiting:
<ul>
    <li>Unexplained injuries, including cuts, bruises, burns and broken bones</li>
    <li>Bedsores</li>
    <li>Changes in behavior</li>
    <li>Physical or emotional withdrawal</li>
    <li>Weight change/malnutrition</li>
    <li>Depression</li>
    <li>Unresponsiveness</li>
    <li>Poor hygiene</li>
    <li>Unexplained hair loss</li>
    <li>Unexplained bleeding</li>
    <li>Missing items</li>
    <li>Out of the ordinary financial transactions</li>
</ul>
Elder abuse or neglect can take many forms; psychological and emotional abuse are devastating, and physical abuse can be deadly, but financial abuse can leave you and your family unable to provide continuing care for your loved one. Don&#x2019;t let embarrassment hurt your loved one; talk to them and take immediate steps if you suspect any type of abuse or neglect.

The experienced nursing home abuse and neglect attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can help you. We can evaluate your case and help get you the compensation you deserve. <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">Contact us </a>today for a free consultation in one of our offices in Kentucky.

&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Healthcare Is Big Business, No Matter How You Slice It
BASENAME: healthcare-is-big-business-no-matter-how-you-slice-it
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/29/2016 08:29:57 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-3805" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/Healthcare-Is-Big-Business-No-Matter-How-You-Slice-It-300x200.jpg" alt="Healthcare Is Big Business, No Matter How You Slice It" width="300" height="200">As patients and consumers, we see hospitals as places whose primary job is to help us get well. Hospitals, however, are still businesses, and for every doctor or nurse who genuinely cares about us, there is an administrator somewhere looking at the bottom line. A recent article on <a href="http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2016/01/14/report-cincinnati-hospital-profits-up-2014/78739080/">Cincinnati.com</a> reports that Cincinnati&#x2019;s hospitals experienced a &#x201C;surge in net income&#x201D; in 2014 &#x2013; a combined $645.1 million throughout Greater Cincinnati.

Admittedly, a large percentage of this income is derived from investments and grants, as well as philanthropic efforts on behalf of others, but the problem we have is not really with the amount of money the hospitals have made. It is with the fact that a large portion of the money has gone to increasing the capacity of the hospitals even though attendance is dropping. It is not that fewer people need hospitals; it is that the amount of time patients are allowed to stay is decreasing. According to independent market analyst Allan Baumgarten&#x2019;s &#x201C;Ohio Health Market Review,&#x201D;&#xA0;occupancy levels are lower now than they were in 2008.
<h2>Why all the expansion?</h2>
So why keep building and acquiring facilities if patients are being forced into shorter stays? It could be related to the increase in Medicare and Medicaid subscribers throughout Ohio. It works like this: the government funds the costs of in-patient stays for Medicare subscribers, and contributes to the cost for Medicaid subscribers. With more people enrolling, the hospitals have a valid claim to increase the size of their facilities. However, because no hospital is going to pick up the cost of an overnight stay once the government stops paying for it, those patients are forced out, too. In the end, it looks like you need more space &#x2013; and can then justify that expense &#x2013; even though your occupancy levels are lower now than ever.

No one wants to stay in the hospital longer than they need to, but shortening hospital stays can lead to a slew of problems. Unfortunately, the longer stays that so many patients need are now astronomically high (<a href="http://www.beckershospitalreview.com/lists/average-cost-per-inpatient-day-across-50-states-in-2010.html">more than $2500 a night in Ohio</a>, and that was back in 2010; the prices have almost certainly risen since then) that people are forced to leave. We believe that every patient&#x2019;s need for care trumps the needs of big business.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we fight on behalf of people whose lives have changed irreparably because of poor care or negligence. If you or your loved one was released too early from a hospital and suffered a preventable injury or illness because of it, we may be able to help. Please <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">contact us</a> to speak with an experienced medical malpractice attorney in Ohio or Kentucky.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: New Diagnostic Tool Shows Mild Brain Injuries Can Leave Lasting Damage
BASENAME: new-diagnostic-tool-shows-mild-brain-injuries-can-leave-lasting-damage
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/05/2016 04:05:48 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-3952" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/New-Diagnostic-Tool-Shows-Mild-Brain-Injuries-Can-Leave-Lasting-Damage--225x300.jpg" alt="A new study from the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center used an advanced form of MRI to look for abnormalities in brain matter in soldiers who suffered mild traumatic brain injuries. The results could have far-reaching implications in the field of concussion detection and treatment. Concussion testing is behind the times The current state of concussion testing and treatment is simply not adequate. Most doctors rely on disconjugate eye movements, known as saccades, to determine whether a patient is concussed. These tests are informal and rely a great deal on individual interpretation.  Gerard Riedy, the neuroradiologist at Walter Reed who led the study, told Technology Review that, &#x201C;...the clinical tools available for assessing the injury, which include a patient&#x2019;s history, evaluations of cognitive skills like memory and attention, and tests of certain motor skills, require a large degree of subjective interpretation.&#x201D;  For soldiers in particular, diagnosis by symptoms is difficult, as the effects of traumatic brain injury share many similarities with post-traumatic stress disorder. The difficulties in diagnosing and treating mild traumatic brain injury are what make Riedy&#x2019;s research so important.  Riedy&#x2019;s team scanned more than 800 soldiers who had been diagnosed with mild TBI with their advanced MRI, looking for abnormalities in white matter. White brain matter consists primarily of axons, structures that are responsible for firing brain impulses and making connections. They found that almost 52 percent of the soldiers scanned had some type of white matter abnormality or scarring. Vital research gives hope The team&#x2019;s findings were incredible, not only because of the degree of the damage that was discovered, but also because normal MRI and CT scans were unable to detect the damage. The results provide evidence that even mild TBI can lead to long-lasting effects.  We have great hope that research like Riedy&#x2019;s will help TBI sufferers everywhere. At the moment, treatment options for TBI are limited by the lack of information about how, exactly, the brain is affected. Unfortunately, until this technology becomes widespread, TBI victims are in limbo, often requiring continuing care and with no hope for a full recovery.  If you or someone you know has suffered at traumatic brain injury as a result of an accident, you may be entitled to compensation. The experienced traumatic brain injury lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can help fight for your rights. Contact us today for a free consultation at one of our offices in Ohio or Kentucky." width="225" height="300">A new study from the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center used an advanced form of MRI to look for abnormalities in brain matter in soldiers who suffered mild traumatic brain injuries. The results could have far-reaching implications in the field of concussion detection and treatment.
<h2>Concussion testing is behind the times</h2>
The current state of concussion testing and treatment is simply not adequate. Most doctors rely on disconjugate eye movements, known as saccades, to determine whether a patient is concussed. These tests are informal and rely a great deal on individual interpretation.

Gerard Riedy, the neuroradiologist at Walter Reed who led the study, told <a href="http://www.technologyreview.com/news/544846/brain-scars-detected-in-concussions/">Technology Review</a> that, &#x201C;...the clinical tools available for assessing the injury, which include a patient&#x2019;s history, evaluations of cognitive skills like memory and attention, and tests of certain motor skills, require a large degree of subjective interpretation.&#x201D;

For soldiers in particular, diagnosis by symptoms is difficult, as the effects of traumatic brain injury share many similarities with post-traumatic stress disorder. The difficulties in diagnosing and treating mild traumatic brain injury are what make Riedy&#x2019;s research so important.

Riedy&#x2019;s team scanned more than 800 soldiers who had been diagnosed with mild TBI with their advanced MRI, looking for abnormalities in white matter. White brain matter consists primarily of axons, structures that are responsible for firing brain impulses and making connections. They found that almost 52 percent of the soldiers scanned had some type of white matter abnormality or scarring.
<h2>Vital research gives hope</h2>
The team&#x2019;s findings were incredible, not only because of the degree of the damage that was discovered, but also because normal MRI and CT scans were unable to detect the damage. The results provide evidence that even mild TBI can lead to long-lasting effects.

We have great hope that research like Riedy&#x2019;s will help TBI sufferers everywhere. At the moment, treatment options for TBI are limited by the lack of information about how, exactly, the brain is affected. Unfortunately, until this technology becomes widespread, TBI victims are in limbo, often requiring continuing care and with no hope for a full recovery.

If you or someone you know has suffered at traumatic brain injury as a result of an accident, you may be entitled to compensation. The experienced traumatic brain injury lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can help fight for your rights. Contact us today for a free consultation at one of our<a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank"> offices</a> in Ohio or Kentucky.

<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-4159" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/CPW-Law-Ranked-As-First-Tier-Best-Law-Firm-by-U.S.-News-World-Report-300x199.jpg" alt="Crandall &amp; Pera Law Ranked As First-Tier Best Law Firm by U.S. News &amp; World Report" width="300" height="199">Crandall &amp; Pera Law recently received some incredible news from the U.S. News &amp; World Report. Our firm was ranked among the top of the top law firms in the states of Ohio and Kentucky. We are proud of our accomplishment and want to share it with you, because our clients are the ones who make our work possible.

In order to qualify for the Best Law Firm ranking, we had to start with lawyers who know how to build a winning case. Our partners are highly qualified, but we couldn&#x2019;t have won this award without the support of our entire team. They are dedicated and hard-working individuals, and we invite you to learn more about them.
<h2>What a First Tier ranking means</h2>
<em>U.S. News &#x2013; Best Lawyers</em> offers a comprehensive look at the legal profession that is trusted around the world. They collect information from attorneys and clients all over the world, looking for feedback in the areas of:
<ul>
    <li>Expertise</li>
    <li>Responsiveness</li>
    <li>Understanding of a business and its needs, or of a client and his or her needs</li>
    <li>Cost-effectiveness</li>
    <li>Civility</li>
    <li>Integrity</li>
    <li>Whether they would refer another client to the firm</li>
    <li>Whether they consider the firm a worthy competitor</li>
</ul>
<em>U.S. News</em> considers 6.7 million evaluations and more than 55,000 lawyers practicing in 185 metropolitan areas throughout the country. &#x201C;The first tier in each metropolitan area includes those firms that scored within a certain percentage of the highest-scoring firm(s)&#x201D; <a href="http://bestlawfirms.usnews.com/methodology.aspx">in each area.</a>

Crandall &amp; Pera Law was ranked a First Tier Top Law Firm for our efforts and achievements in medical malpractice law in Ohio and in Kentucky. It is work that we take very seriously. We believe in patient&#x2019;s rights, and work hard to protect our clients&#x2019; interests from the armies of lawyers that big businesses and insurance companies use to litigate malpractice cases. Our services are highly personal and tailored to meet the needs of our clients. We fight every day to protect the victims of medical malpractice and get them the compensation they deserve.

Ranking in the First Tier is incredible, and the recognition is gratifying. It is immensely more gratifying that <em>U.S. News &amp; World Report</em> depends heavily on client feedback for reference. We truly value our clients, and we are grateful that they took the time to tell someone how they felt about us. You have our deepest thanks and the promise that we will continue to work as hard as we can to protect you.

We thank our peers, our clients, and our team for this honor. We couldn&#x2019;t have done it without you.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: What Goes Down Must Come Up
BASENAME: what-goes-down-must-come-up
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/12/2016 05:19:35 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-4156" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/ThinkstockPhotos-175017523-300x200.jpg" alt="What Goes Down Must Come Up" width="300" height="200">The National Highway Traffic Administration has released the official fatality statistics report for 2014. The report is encouraging; our nation&#x2019;s roadways have never had a safer year. Unfortunately, data trends have to continue in order to show progress, and preliminary data for 2015 shows &#x201C;a troubling increase in the number of fatalities&#x201D; according to the agency itself.
<h2>Good news first</h2>
The total number of traffic fatalities for the year 2014 came in at 32,675. While more than 30,000 deaths is nothing to celebrate, it is the lowest number of fatalities in over a decade. More encouraging is the rate per 100 million vehicle miles traveled (100Mvmt). In 1990, there were 2.08 deaths per 100Mvmt; in 2014, that number was nearly halved, coming in at 1.07.

These numbers were excellent, especially in light of the circumstances. There are more cars on the road now than there were in 90s, and more cars means more miles traveled. For all that, 2014 is still the safest year on record. Sadly, 32,675 deaths is still far too many; <a href="http://kpic.com/news/auto-matters/auto-fatality-rate-hits-historic-low-in-2014-but-early-stats-on-2015-are-sobering">KPIC 4</a> reported on why:
<ul>
    <li><strong>Drunk driving crashes</strong> continue to represent roughly one-third of fatalities, resulting in 9,967 deaths in 2014.</li>
    <li>Nearly half (49%) of passenger vehicle occupants killed were <strong>not wearing seat belts</strong>.</li>
    <li>The number of <strong>motorcyclists killed</strong> was far higher in states without strong helmet laws, resulting in 1,565 lives lost in 2014.</li>
    <li><strong>Cyclist deaths</strong> declined by 2.3 percent, but pedestrian deaths rose by 3.1 percent from the previous year. In 2014, there were 726 cyclists and 4,884 pedestrians killed in motor vehicle crashes.</li>
    <li><strong>Distracted driving</strong> accounted for 10 percent of all crash fatalities, killing 3,179 people in 2014.</li>
    <li><strong>Drowsy driving</strong> accounted for 2.6 percent of all crash fatalities; at least 846 people died in these crashes in 2014.</li>
</ul>
<h2>Bad news for next years&#x2019; report</h2>
With preliminary data suggesting that traffic fatalities were up more than 8% in 2015, Secretary Anthony Foxx of the U.S. Department of Transportation says the agency will put greater effort into safety initiatives. Unfortunately, the NHTSA blames human error for 94% of all collisions, meaning that safety initiatives may not be enough.

The 2014 NHTSA traffic fatality report is encouraging, but it still reports 32,675 deaths. Those numbers do not tell the whole story; 32,675 families lost a loved one that year, affecting untold numbers of lives. When someone you love is hurt or injured in an accident, life is never the same.

If you or a loved one has been injured in an accident, you may be entitled to compensation for your injuries, lost wages, and more. The experienced and compassionate personal injury attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can help fight for your rights and get you the compensation you deserve. <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">Contact us </a>today for a free consultation in one of our offices throughout Kentucky and Ohio.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Tractor-Trailer Crash Devastates Raccoon Creek
BASENAME: tractor-trailer-crash-devastates-raccoon-creek
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/09/2016 06:21:09 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-3958" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Tractor-Trailer-Crash-Devastates-Raccoon-Creek-225x300.jpg" alt="Tractor-Trailer Crash Devastates Raccoon Creek" width="225" height="300">In early November, a tractor-trailer driver lost control of his rig and crashed into Raccoon Creek in Newark. The truck was loaded with phosphoric and sulfuric acid. A mix of the toxic substances, as well as diesel fuel from the damaged truck, leaked into the stream in the popular recreational area.
<h2>Hazmat spill has dire consequences</h2>
The site was closed for two days while crews worked to contain the spill and clean the area, but the damage was done almost immediately. According to <a href="http://www.news-herald.com/general-news/20151119/officials-thousands-of-fish-die-in-creek-after-central-ohio-truck-crash">The News Herald</a>, &#x201C;State Department of Natural Resources&#x2019; Division of Wildlife spokeswoman Karen Norris... [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][told] The Columbus Dispatch [that]&#xA0;nearly 6,400 fish were killed in Raccoon Creek in Newark. The crash and spill affected about 1.5 miles of the Licking County stream.&#x201D;

This spill is devastating beyond the local contamination. The Raccoon Creek Partnership has spent more than 30 years and countless hours of volunteer efforts to clean up the creek. The area had been devastated by mining activities, leaving the overall health of the watershed severely compromised. A 1984 sampling of the creek found only two fish, both of the same species. In 2005, thanks to the partnership&#x2019;s efforts, 244 fish representing 13 species were thriving in the river.

This single accident represents a significant setback to a three-decade effort by thousands of volunteers. One moment of inattention, and years of dedicated effort were erased. The driver has been charged with failure to maintain control, though no trial date has been set as of this writing.
<h2>Cargo spills pose threat to all</h2>
Though regrettable, this incident is not unique. Fuel and cargo spills are all too common during big rig accidents. Whether they are the result of distracted driving or negligent loading practices, cargo spillage can have devastating impacts on our environment and create significant health hazards for drivers and emergency responders. This is yet another instance that highlights the need for cohesive federal regulation of the trucking industry.

If you or someone you know has been injured in a trucking accident, you may be entitled to compensation for your injuries. The experienced truck accident attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can help fight for your rights, whether your injuries were the result of an accident or exposure to toxic substances. <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">Contact us</a> today for a free consultation at one of our office locations throughout Ohio or Kentucky.

&#xA0;[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: If You&#x2019;re Not Furious at Takata Yet, Keep Reading
BASENAME: if-youre-not-furious-at-takata-yet-keep-reading
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/18/2016 02:54:47 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-4162" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/If-You&#x2019;re-Not-Furious-at-Takata-Yet-Keep-Reading-300x200.jpg" alt="If You&#x2019;re Not Furious at Takata Yet, Keep Reading" width="300" height="200">For more than a year, we have read bits and pieces of news about the exploding Takata airbags. We applauded the fines, begged Honda to take action, and deplored the state of the auto industry that it would continually put its profits at the top of its priority list. It didn&#x2019;t seem like it could get any worse for Takata &#x2013; and then the <em>New York Times</em> dropped a bombshell on February 12, 2016: &#x201C;<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/13/business/takata-discarded-evidence-of-airbag-ruptures-as-early-as-2000.html?_r=0">Takata Discarded Evidence of Airbag Ruptures as Early as 2000</a>.&#x201D;

The Times article reports that:

&#x201C;[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][T]estimony in a Florida court showed that Takata&#x2019;s own engineers discarded evidence that may have shown otherwise as long as 16 years ago. As early as 2000, around the time the propellant, which includes a compound called ammonium nitrate, was introduced into Takata models, failures occurred during internal testing.

But Takata altered its test data to hide the failures from its biggest customer, Honda, and a senior Takata executive ordered some of the evidence be discarded, the testimony said.&#x201D;

They knew. <strong>They knew.</strong> Takata <em>knew</em> it was manufacturing a product with the potential to fail, and <em>changed the data to hide the evidence.</em> This is worse than ignorance, worse than negligence; it is a criminal act. It is fraud. They are incredibly lucky that no one has charged them with manslaughter (as Forbes.com suggested <a href="http://fortune.com/2014/06/05/could-gm-be-charged-with-murder/">might be possible for GM</a> back in June of 2014). Those airbags have injured hundreds of people, and are directly linked to 10 deaths. They sold 54 million of those faulty inflators in the US alone.
<h2>Honda may not be as responsible as they first seemed</h2>
Because Takata manipulated its data regarding the airbag failures before it presented that data to Honda, Honda may not be accountable for as much of the blame as people originally thought. <strong>This does not mean they are innocent</strong>: remember, once the airbags started exploding, Honda was slow to recall the vehicles or <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/12/business/air-bag-flaw-long-known-led-to-recalls.html">to admit there was a problem</a>. All this new information tells us is that Takata is an even greedier, more reprehensible company than we originally thought.

It is time to take drastic steps in this country to ensure the safety and protection of our citizens. Companies who commit crimes like these should be banned from doing business in the US, where they hurt our citizens intentionally and knowingly and then get away with it. Takata is not alone in this: if it were up to us, VW would be banned, too, for their actions last year with the emissions tests. Americans <a href="http://www.cnbc.com/2010/04/16/Top-10-Class-Action-Lawsuits.html?slide=11">don&#x2019;t take lightly to lying</a> &#x2013; just ask AOL Time Warner, anyone working for Big Tobacco or the manufacturers of defective breast implants. From now on, maybe we should stop trying to boycott their products and simply refuse to allow them to sell anything in the US.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier personal injury and medical malpractice law firms serving Ohio and Kentucky. If you were hurt because of a dangerous product, or have sustained an injury or loss because of a defective airbag, please <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">contact us</a> to find out more about your rights.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]

TITLE: Congratulations, Marc Pera, on Being Recognized for Your Service to Your Clients!
BASENAME: congratulations-marc-pera-on-being-recognized-for-your-service-to-your-clients
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/01/2016 04:14:59 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-full wp-image-4171" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Screen-Shot-2016-03-01-at-3.11.41-PM.png" alt="Congratulations, Marc Pera, on Being Recognized for Your Service to Your Clients!" width="290" height="291">All of us at Crandall &amp; Pera Law are so proud to announce that Marc Pera has been named to the American Institute of Personal Injury Attorneys&#x2019; list of 10 Best in Ohio for Client Satisfaction! Marc&#x2019;s tireless dedication to his clients serves as the basis of the award, and as anyone in our offices can tell you, there is no one more deserving than him.
<h2>What is the American Institute of Personal Injury Attorneys?</h2>
The AIOPIA was founded in 2014 with a two-fold purpose: to provide people in need of skilled personal injury services with a way of choosing the right lawyer for those needs, and to honor those attorneys who have built a reputation for their positive relationships with their clients. <a href="http://aiopia.org/mission-statement/">As their website says</a>:

&#x201C;Attorneys who are recognized by the American Institute&#x2019;s Personal Injury Division are what we consider the best in the industry for client satisfaction. It is our mission to do so that the perspective new client will be able to take this knowledge and use it in making the tough decision on what attorney or firm to hire. It is the intent of American Institute&#x2019;s Personal Injury Division to aid these prospective new clients by saving them time and effort in their own research.&#x201D;

Attorneys like Marc Pera are nominated by their clients or their peers specifically because of their relationships with their clients. An independent Board of Regents reviews their status with the applicable State Bar to ensure that the lawyer has no grievances filed against him or her, looks into any publications, significant victories and/or professional associations, and then researches the attorneys&#x2019; reviews and ratings. If all of the criteria is met or exceeded &#x2013; you can <a href="http://aiopia.org/selection/">find the complete list here</a>, if you like &#x2013; the attorney is nominated for the award.

There are close to 5000 personal injury attorneys in Ohio. Marc Pera of Crandall &amp; Pera Law was selected as one of the 10 Best in the state &#x2013; not because of his track record of successful verdicts ad settlements (although he has that, too) but because of the highest levels of ethical service which he provides to his clients. When you work with Marc Pera, you work with an attorney who genuinely cares about the outcome of your case.

Congratulations on your latest award, Marc. We are all very proud of you &#x2013; even if we&#x2019;re not surprised that you won. You deserve it!

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Proposed Legislation Could Help Ohio&#x2019;s Uninsured Motorist Problem
BASENAME: proposed-legislation-could-help-ohios-uninsured-motorist-problem
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/26/2016 05:26:22 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-4168" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Proposed-Legislation-Could-Help-Ohio&#x2019;s-Uninsured-Motorist-Problem-300x200.jpg" alt="Proposed Legislation Could Help Ohio&#x2019;s Uninsured Motorist Problem" width="300" height="200">Ohio has a serious problem with uninsured motorists. Every time you drive, you are sharing the road with uninsured motorists, and even the most defensive driver is still at risk from other motorists. Uninsured motorists are breaking the law, but worse, are posing a threat to you and your loved ones. A new House Bill is intended to incentivize drivers to comply with financial responsibility laws and reduce the risk to law-abiding citizens.
<h2>A growing threat</h2>
Jeff Smith, Director of Government Affairs for the Professional Independent Agents Association of Ohio, wrote a letter to <a href="http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/editorials/2016/01/16/1-house-bill-takes-aim-at-uninsured-motorists.html">The Columbus Dispatch</a>. He said, &#x201C;According to data from the Bureau of Motor Vehicles, the risk of being involved in an accident on Ohio&#x2019;s roads has decreased by 21 percent in the last 10 years, but the likelihood of being involved in an accident with a motorist who is uninsured or who can&#x2019;t provide proof of insurance has gone up by 550 percent. To top it off, uninsured drivers were at fault in these crashes more than 65 percent of the time.&#x201D;

&#xA0;

The safest driver in the world still has no control over other drivers. Driving without insurance is a deeply irresponsible act with very real consequences. In almost every state, driving without car insurance is illegal. Despite this, the Insurance Research Council reported that in 2012, the most recent year for which data is available, uninsured motorists claims totaled $2.6 billion in the United States.

&#xA0;

If the proposed Bill is enacted, Ohio will join the ranks of 10 other states that have enacted &#x201C;no pay, no play&#x201D; laws. These laws limit an uninsured driver&#x2019;s ability to claim damages in an accident. According to the <a href="http://www.insurance-research.org/">Insurance Research Council</a>, &#x201C;no pay&#x201D; laws reduce uninsured motorist rates by 1.6% on average. That math still leaves over a million uninsured drivers on the road. It&#x2019;s a start, but more needs to be done to address the growing problem.

In the meantime, uninsured motorists continue to pose a threat to law-abiding citizens. If you or someone you know has been in an accident with an uninsured motorist, the experienced Kentucky and Ohio personal injury lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can help get you the compensation that you need for medical expenses and lost wages. <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">Contact us</a> today for a free consultation.

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Alzheimer&#x2019;s Disease Might Be Transmittable
BASENAME: alzheimers-disease-might-be-transmittable
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/23/2016 09:23:51 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-4165" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Alzheimer&#x2019;s-Disease-Might-Be-Transmittable-300x217.jpg" alt="Alzheimer&#x2019;s Disease Might Be Transmittable" width="300" height="217">Last year, researchers in the UK reported autopsy results that suggested that Alzheimer&#x2019;s disease might be transmitted during certain medical treatments. The scientific community met the report with skepticism, as no real research had been conducted up until then. Skepticism is the heart of science; without more work, it is possible that other factors were at play. However, a new report in January seems to support the earlier findings.
<h2>How Alzheimer&#x2019;s works</h2>
No one knows what causes Alzheimer&#x2019;s disease, but we have learned a great deal about the effects. The disease disrupts the way the brain works at the chemical and electrical level. This happens when protein clusters, called amyloid plaques, build up between nerve cells. At the same time, twisted proteins build up between nerve cells. Over time, nerve cell death leads to loss of brain matter.

Amyloid plaques are observed after the disease is fairly progressed, and these plaques are what have researchers worried. The report in January detailed the autopsies of 7 people who had died as a result of Creutzfeld-Jakob disease (CJD), a rare brain-wasting disorder. All 7 of the people autopsied had received surgical grafts of a brain membrane years earlier. The grafts were unfortunately contaminated with a protein responsible for CJD.

According to a report in <a href="http://gizmodo.com/controvertial-transmittable-alzheimer-s-theory-is-sta-1755168062">Gizmodo</a>, &#x201C;Five of the seven brains analyzed also showed signs of Alzheimer&#x2019;s disease. This was odd because the individuals, age 28 to 63, were too young to have developed the amyloid plaques indicative of the neurological disorder... This suggests that that the &#x2018;seeds&#x2019; of certain neurological diseases can be transmitted during certain medical procedures&#x2014;or even through contaminated surgical instruments.&#x201D;

The earlier autopsy report found that victims of CJD had acquired the disease from a growth hormone made from the glands of cadavers, some of which were contaminated with the proteins that cause the disease. While this growth hormone is no longer made the same way, it still remains a cause for concern.
<h2>Knowledge is power</h2>
The real danger is that amyloid plaques are sticky, and standard sterilization techniques don&#x2019;t work on them. This means that it is possible to transfer amyloid plaques through surgery. However, these findings are actually a good thing. Neuropathologist Herbert Budka, co-author of the latest paper, told <a href="http://www.nature.com/news/more-evidence-emerges-for-transmissible-alzheimer-s-theory-1.19229">Nature News</a>, &#x201C;It is our job as doctors to see in advance what might become a problem in the clinic.&#x201D;

We at Crandall &amp; Pera Law support all research efforts into health concerns that affect our friends, family and clients. If you have questions about medical malpractice, we invite you to <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">contact us</a> at one of our locations throughout Ohio or Kentucky

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Kentucky&#x2019;s Senate Bill 6 Can Only Harm Injury Victims
BASENAME: kentuckys-senate-bill-6-can-only-harm-injury-victims
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/04/2016 01:26:23 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-4191" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Kentucky&#x2019;s-Senate-Bill-6-Can-Only-Harm-Injury-Victims-300x200.jpg" alt="Kentucky&#x2019;s Senate Bill 6 Can Only Harm Injury Victims" width="300" height="200">For the last six years, Senator Ralph Alvarado (R-Winchester) has sponsored Senate Bill 6 and met with failure in the House. The bill proposes to create review panels that would screen medical malpractice claims for patients seeking judgment. While the Bill has been amended several times, the primary goal remains the same. In fact, we wrote about this issue at the same time last year.
<h2>What they want you to believe</h2>
Senator Alvarado believes that the creation of review panels would save time and money for those pursuing a medical malpractice claim. The review panels would be chaired by an attorney and populated by three physicians. One of each of the physicians would be chosen by the plaintiff and defendant, and the partially formed committee would select the third.

Supporters of the bill maintain that the creation of these panels would accomplish three main goals. They believe that SB 6 would:
<ul>
    <li>Prevent frivolous lawsuits and save time and money for claimants.</li>
    <li>Reduce the amount of malpractice claims.</li>
    <li>Reduce the amount of time it takes to resolve a malpractice claim.</li>
</ul>
<h2>Why the reality is such a terrible idea</h2>
The big hype centers on the time period for review; <a href="http://www.bizjournals.com/louisville/news/2016/01/15/medical-malpractice-lawsuit-kentucky-legislation.html">press about the bill</a> &#x201C;claims&#x201D; that the panel has 30 days to decide the merit of a case. Unfortunately, and as usual, this isn&#x2019;t the full story. As a matter of fact, it&#x2019;s not even the <em>right</em> story.

Medical malpractice cases are incredibly complex. They can involve multiple acts of negligence from multiple providers, and even a specially convened panel of three doctors will likely not have the expertise necessary to evaluate a claim. Additionally, the 30-day time frame is not just a misrepresentation; it is an outright lie. Based on the language in the bill, it can take an average of <em>six months </em>just to file a claim. The entire time you are waiting for your claim to come before this panel, you&#x2019;ll need to foot your doctors&#x2019; bills, deal with losing your income, and living with the pain of your injury. Our review of other states&#x2019; experience with review panels demonstrates that the average time to file a claim is closer to 18 months.

Senate Bill 6 is a solution in search of a problem, and it is a terrible solution. The following are the counterpoints to the goals of SB 6:
<ul>
    <li>There are already stiff penalties in place for bringing frivolous lawsuits.</li>
    <li>Reducing malpractice claims comes from reducing malpractice, not tort reform.</li>
    <li>Convening specialized panels for each case will greatly increase the amount of time it takes to get a case to court, not decrease it.</li>
</ul>
The candidate selection process for the review panel would require doctors, working with a lawyer, to decide whether a claim had merit before it was tried in court. The panel is made up of local doctors who are far more likely to side with their colleagues than with you, if for no other reason than they know that someday they may be sitting on the other side of the table awaiting judgment rather than being the Judge. Following their decision, the panel would publish an expert opinion that could be used at trial. That opinion would be virtually un-appealable. If the panel gets it wrong, if a mistake is made in the process, if the judgment is unfair, you will have little to no legal recourse moving forward, because the legislature has essentially taken away your right for a fair impartial trial by your peers &#x2013; a right that is guaranteed by the Kentucky constitution, as well as the United States Constitution.

The 7<sup>th</sup> Amendment guarantees the right to a trial by jury. When a jury is convened to hear a case, the members of the jury are members of the community. In this way, trial by jury ensures that a community is able to regulate conduct locally. In this way, a community is given a voice to the benefit of all. It is unfathomable that doctors should be shielded from judgement by the community. No other profession is given such an elite status. If this bill is allowed to pass, why shouldn&#x2019;t every person only be judged by someone who works in the same field as them? Shouldn&#x2019;t engineers, teachers, lawyers, electricians and heavy-machinery operators be afforded the right to a review panel of their friends, rather than be judged by randomly selected members of their community? Fortunately, that is not the way the system works. Lawyers and judges go to great lengths to educate the uneducated jury about the issues so that they can make a fair and impartial decision.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we fight for your rights. All citizens are entitled to a trial by jury; the type of claim does not change that right. Victims of medical malpractice suffer enough. It is a bridge too far to take away their constitutional rights. We are vehemently against SB 6.

Medical malpractice is devastating to victims and their families. The dedicated and experienced medical malpractice attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law work to protect these victims and make sure justice is served. If you or someone you know has been the victim of medical malpractice, you may be entitled to compensation for your injuries. We can evaluate your case and help get you the compensation you deserve. <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">Contact us</a> today for a free consultation.

&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: It&#x2019;s Official: Zika Virus Has Arrived In Ohio
BASENAME: its-official-zika-virus-has-arrived-in-ohio
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/15/2016 05:26:03 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-4297" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/It&#x2019;s-Official-Zika-Virus-Has-Arrived-In-Ohio-300x200.jpg" alt="It&#x2019;s Official: Zika Virus Has Arrived In Ohio" width="300" height="200">Mosquito season is just around the corner, and Ohio public health officials are worried. There are currently five confirmed cases of Zika virus in the state. While those cases were contracted in other parts of the world, mosquitoes are able to pick up the virus and transmit it to others.
<h2>What is Zika virus?</h2>
According to <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/westnile/faq/genquestions.html#vaccine-available">the Centers For Disease Control and Prevention</a> (CDC), &#x201C;Zika is a disease caused by Zika virus that is spread to people primarily through the bite of an infected&#xA0;<em>Aedes</em>&#xA0;species mosquito. The most common symptoms of Zika are fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis (red eyes). The illness is usually mild with symptoms lasting for several days to a week.&#xA0;People usually don&#x2019;t get sick enough to go to the hospital, and they very rarely die of Zika.&#x201D;

Unfortunately, Zika disease has been linked to an increase in the birth defect known as microcephaly. Pregnant women who have been infected can give birth to children that suffer reduced brain growth resulting in smaller head size. The condition can cause lifelong problems, including seizures, developmental delays and disabilities.

The problem with Zika is that after the initial symptoms, it can be difficult to detect. The virus lives on in the host, and common antibody tests are ineffective because the tests cross-react with Dengue fever antibodies and can produce a false positive.

Mosquitoes capable of carrying the disease are common in the US and exist in pockets all over the state. In response to the five known cases and the potential threat for widespread infection in Ohio, public health officials gathered in early March to discuss preparedness.
<h2>Zika related birth defects are a cause for concern</h2>
Dr. Mary DiOrio, medical director of the Ohio Department of Health, told <a href="http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2016/03/01/State-holds-Zika-exercise.html">The Columbus Dispatch</a> that talks were expected to focus on mosquito control and public outreach. She said, &#x201C;My hope from this exercise is that, by having these conversations now, we will know exactly &#x2014; if we get a case of Zika during our mosquito season &#x2014; what steps will be taken by all of the entities in that area.&quot;

You can reduce the mosquito population in your area by eliminating standing water on and around your property. However, these precautions cannot guarantee that Zika won&#x2019;t be in Ohio this spring. So far, no residents have tested positive for the disease, but only time will tell.

If your child has suffered a birth defect as a result of trauma or substandard prenatal care, you may be entitled to compensation. The compassionate Ohio birth injury lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can help you in your time of need. <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">Contact us</a> today for a free consultation.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Another Reason to Throw Out Your Representative
BASENAME: another-reason-to-throw-out-your-representative
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/11/2016 12:53:50 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright wp-image-4206 size-medium" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Another-Reason-to-Throw-Out-Your-Representative-300x203.jpg" alt="Another Reason to Throw Out Your Representative" width="300" height="203">

Biotechnology giant Monsanto is the company that no one knows about. Founded in 1901, the company initially produced food additives before expanding into industrial chemicals. During a growth phase, the company manufactured controversial products including DDT, Agent Orange, and others. Today, the biotech behemoth is a multinational corporation; they have divested much of their chemical business and focus primarily on biotechnology.

Unfortunately, some of the controversial decisions made by Monsanto in the past continue to cause problems today. For more than forty years, Monsanto was the sole producer of the chemical polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB). Production during that time period amounted to almost 1.25 billion pounds of the chemical.

According to the <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/01/business/monsanto-could-benefit-from-a-chemical-safety-bill.html?smprod=nytcore-iphone&amp;smid=nytcore-iphone-share">New York Times</a>, &#x201C;The chemicals were initially admired for their ability to prevent fires and explosions in electrical transformers and other equipment. But as the use of PCBs skyrocketed nationwide in products as varied&#xA0;as paints, pesticides and even carbonless copy paper, evidence mounted that they were contaminating the environment and potentially causing&#xA0;health problems including cancer and immune-system complications.&#xA0;<a href="http://www.epa.gov/aboutepa/epa-bans-pcb-manufacture-phases-out-uses">The E.P.A. banned their production in 1979</a>.&#x201D;

The PCB ban halted production, but did nothing to address the incredible amount of the chemical that was such an essential part of our infrastructure for so long. Now, older structures, including sewer systems and school buildings, are struggling to comply with new directives aimed at reducing PCB levels in water and building materials; renovations to remove contaminated materials are costly, and expose workers and building occupants to hazardous conditions.
<h2>A better future? Not yet</h2>
Pending legislation in Congress designed to replace the outdated Toxic Substances Control Act contains language that specifically addresses the Monsanto PCB problem, but not in a way that protects anyone. Instead, the paragraph could help shield the company from legal liability for a toxic chemical that only it made.

Seattle is one of six cities currently suing Monsanto to help cover the costs of removing the toxic substance. City attorney Pete Holmes said, &#x201C;Call me a dreamer, but I wish for a Congress that would help cities with their homeless crises instead of protecting multinational corporations that poison our environment.&#x201D; A spokeswoman for Monsanto said the company had received no preferential treatment.

The bottom line? Big businesses spend a great deal of time and money to protect their interests. When those efforts extend to the Federal government, closer scrutiny is required. Our government is supposed to protect our citizens, not the financial interests of individual corporations.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we work to protect your rights. When you are hurt or become sick because of a business decision that values dollars over lives, we fight for you and your family. Our skilled attorneys in Ohio and Kentucky have years of experience fighting big business and their insurance companies, and will fight for you when you need us. <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">Contact us </a>today for a free consultation.
