AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Erb&#x2019;s Palsy
BASENAME: erbs-palsy
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/20/2017 02:38:23 PM
-----
BODY:
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/1oUxIBk2uNk" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

Well what you should know about Erb&#x2019;s palsy is that it is an injury that occurs, oftentimes in newborns, at the time of delivery. What happens is that when a newborn is coming through the birth canal, at the last moment when the head peaks, unfortunately some children their shoulder will get stuck under the pubis symphysis, which is part of the pelvis, the woman&#x2019;s pelvis. When that shoulder gets stuck the obstetrician will, or is faced with, essentially, an obstetrical emergency; they have to get that baby out of the birth canal within a relatively short period of time because the time that shoulder is stuck the umbilical chord is also compressed so the baby is not getting oxygen and blood.

What happens then is the doctor has to get this baby out, so they will put the woman, the mother, through a series of maneuvers to try to release that shoulder, it&#x2019;s the anterior shoulder, and get that baby delivered. In doing so, if the doctor isn&#x2019;t careful, they can put excessive traction on the baby&#x2019;s head trying to get the baby out from under the pubis. And when they do that they can cause this angle between your head and your shoulder to be extended and when that happens you can stretch what&#x2019;s called the brachial plexus, which is a series of nerves, c1 through c6, that innervate your arm and hands and provide the necessary nerves for function and feeling in that part of the body. If you stretch it too far you can tear or completely avulse the nerve from the spinal column, and when we say avulse we mean literally pull that nerve root completely out of the spinal cord. When that happens the child is ultimately delivered, when the child is ultimately delivered, the pediatrician will note that the child&#x2019;s arm is oftentimes limp or it will turn in shortly after birth and that will tell the pediatrician, uh-oh we have an Erb&#x2019;s Palsy.

Then they will evaluate the child and will make a decision whether or not that Erb&#x2019;s palsy is something will resolve, most of them will resolve, it&#x2019;s just a stretching, but the severe ones, oftentimes where the doctors have put excessive traction on that head trying to get that child out, won&#x2019;t resolve and that baby will be left with permanent disability, will ultimately require multiple surgeries to try to return the function to the best of whatever they can, but they will never have a normal, completely normal functioning arm.

There&#x2019;s a whole realm of-- there&#x2019;s a whole spectrum of injury from mild to very severe and people can ultimately be very deformed as a result of a severe Erb&#x2019;s palsy. Inevitably, Erb&#x2019;s palsy is almost always due to a widening of that angle between the head and the shoulder during the birthing process. Almost always, that widening is due to traction by the delivering physician in trying to get the child out. It could also happen, I guess if you used forceps, these big clamps that go around a child&#x2019;s head, and if a physician pulls too hard on the head, that could happen, or a vacuum, they put a vacuum suction cup on the end of a child&#x2019;s head and pull it out. But usually, it&#x2019;s an obstetrician&#x2019;s hands on a child&#x2019;s head and they&#x2019;re pushing down on that head trying to get that anterior shoulder, the upper shoulder, the shoulder that&#x2019;s pointing up towards the mothers belly button, trying to get that shoulder under the pubic bone. If a woman has a child with Erb&#x2019;s palsy, they should have somebody look into it. Often times, it&#x2019;s not due to negligence but if you have an Erb&#x2019;s palsy, your child has an Erb&#x2019;s palsy, odds are it was related to traction by a physician.

One final point is a temporary Erb&#x2019;s palsy, that&#x2019;s a whole different game, that can occur through mild traction and those almost always resolve on their own. When we&#x2019;re talking about excessive traction it is usually an avulsion of a nerve. So if a woman has a child and she&#x2019;s told, &#x201C;these nerve roots are avulsed in your child and we&#x2019;re going to have to perform surgery to try to restore the function to your child&#x2019;s arm the best that we can.&#x201D; That mother, I would suggest, needs to go talk to an attorney and have somebody look at the care and treatment of that delivery.

Erb&#x2019;s palsy is just one of several possible results from birth complications referred to as brachial plexus injuries. These injuries, in turn, stem from problems during birth. The proximate cause of Erb&#x2019;s palsy can range from breech presentation to delayed delivery to shoulder dystocia; in short, the more difficult the birth, the more likely there are to be complications.

Your healthcare providers are responsible for evaluating the position of your baby and the overall chances that a complication will arise well before you go into labor. There are early intervention options to help delivery go as smoothly as possible; doctors can help an infant into a more favorable position for natural birth, or determine well in advance that a Cesarean section is safest for both mom and baby.

Minor brachial plexus injuries involving stretching the nerves, a condition that can heal spontaneously or with minor therapy. Major brachial plexus injuries involve tearing the nerve bundle out of the spinal column; outside of science fiction, there is no way to reconnect severed nerves. A severe brachial plexus injury can cause permanent and irreversible Erb&#x2019;s palsy.

If medical negligence affected your child&#x2019;s quality of life, the experienced Ohio and Kentucky medical malpractice attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can evaluate your case and help get you the compensation you deserve. Call our Kentucky medical malpractice attorneys at 877.651.7764, our Ohio medical malpractice attorneys at 877.686.8879 or <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today for a free consultation.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Commercial Bus Drivers Are Subjected to the Same Conditions as Commercial Truck Drivers &#x2013; With the Same Results
BASENAME: commercial-bus-drivers-subjected-conditions-commercial-truck-drivers-results
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/17/2017 02:03:12 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-5488" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Commercial-Bus-Drivers-Are-Subjected-to-the-Same-Conditions-as-Commercial-Truck-Drivers-&#x2013;-With-the-Same-Results-300x200.jpg" alt="commercial-bus-drivers-are-subjected-to-the-same-conditions-as-commercial-truck-drivers-with-the-same-results" width="300" height="200">Early last year, an Ohio jury awarded Mark Soberay $27 million in damages for injuries he sustained in an accident as a passenger on a Greyhound bus. The accident happened when the bus driver fell asleep and rear-ended a tractor-trailer; Soberay sustained multiple injuries in the wreck, including a severed urethra, injuries requiring an amputation of his right leg, and various soft tissue injuries and shattered bones that required more than thirty surgeries to repair.
<h2>Fatigued drivers are dangerous drivers</h2>
<a href="http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2016/02/greyhound_bus_driver_fell_asle.html">Cleveland.com</a> reported, &#x201C;The case hinged on a&#xA0;rule in Greyhound&apos;s handbook that says drivers &#x2018;are to stop every approximately 150 miles or three hours&#x2019; to inspect the tires. The rulebook also says driver&apos;s should take the stops as an opportunity to get some &#x2018;fresh air&#x2019; to ward off driver fatigue... Greyhound officials testified that they consider the 150-mile rule a &#x2018;guideline&#x2019; and do not punish drivers for not following it.&#x201D;
<h2>The real issue</h2>
Fatigued driving is a serious problem; it&#x2019;s just one of the contributing factors that reversed a 50 year decline in highway fatalities. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration reports more than 100,000 fatigue-related crashes every year, and a recent study found that even one hour of lost sleep doubles the risk of a crash. Opting to take the bus or the train has long been seen as a safer option, but when accidents do happen, the risk of catastrophic injury or death is much higher.

When negligent drivers are coupled with negligent companies, it&#x2019;s only a matter of time before someone gets hurt. Transportation companies and their employees are responsible for the safety of their passengers; when that safety is compromised, the company is liable for any and all damages and injuries. If you or your loved one has been injured in a commercial carrier accident, you may be entitled to compensation for medical bills and lost wages. The experienced Ohio and Kentucky bus accident attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can evaluate your case and help get you the compensation you deserve. For a free consultation, call our Ohio attorneys at 877.686.8879, our Kentucky bus crash attorneys at 877.651.7764, or <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Inclement Weather Left Bus Accident Victims Waiting For Paramedics For Three Hours
BASENAME: inclement-weather-left-bus-accident-victims-waiting-paramedics-three-hours
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/23/2017 12:40:51 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-5504" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/ThinkstockPhotos-513469649-300x171.jpg" alt="Inclement Weather Left Bus Accident Victims Waiting For Paramedics For Three Hours" width="300" height="171">The recent spate of inclement weather in Maryland was responsible for a slew of highway crashes. The largest accident has been called the worst in Baltimore&#x2019;s recent history; more than sixty vehicles piled up on the highway after a fuel tanker slid off a bridge and exploded when it struck the roadway below. The massive accident killed two and injured dozens; traffic was snarled for hours as first responders worked amidst freezing conditions to get victims to safety.

Just one mile ahead of the conflagration and resulting pileup, the victims of another smaller pileup were forced to wait hours for emergency services to respond. An eastern Kentucky tour bus en route to New York City slid on ice and crashed into a box truck that had struck other vehicles. Passenger Katrina Conley told <a href="http://www.wymt.com/content/news/eky-tour-bus-involved-in-weather-related-crashes.html">WYMT</a>, &#x201C;We had to sit on the bus for like three hours because the fire department got to us but they couldn&#x2019;t get any ambulances to us. They said they had like 60 ambulances out, and I guess at the time the other wreck... had more serious injuries... so most of the ambulances went there.&#x201D;
<h2>An accident that shouldn&#x2019;t have happened</h2>
According to the <a href="https://www.fmcsa.dot.gov/regulations/title49/section/392.14">Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration&#x2019;s</a> regulation &#xA7;392.14, &#x201C;Extreme caution in the operation of a commercial motor vehicle shall be exercised when hazardous conditions... adversely affect visibility or traction. Speed shall be reduced when such conditions exist. If conditions become sufficiently dangerous, the operation of the commercial motor vehicle shall be discontinued and shall not be resumed until the commercial motor vehicle can be safely operated. Whenever compliance with the foregoing provisions of this rule increases hazard to passengers, the commercial motor vehicle may be operated to the nearest point at which the safety of passengers is assured.&#x201D;

Essentially, the decision as to whether conditions are too hazardous to continue is up to the driver. As with any provision that relies on individual decision, the basis for evaluation becomes a standard of care; in other words, actions are judged on the basis of whether the majority of people with similar qualifications would make the same decision in similar circumstances. Determining a breach of standard of care is often complicated, but in this case, it&#x2019;s fairly straightforward. The sheer number of accidents that occurred that day offers overwhelming evidence that travel conditions were hazardous at best.
<h2>Passengers have rights</h2>
Common carriers like this tour bus are not exempt from the threats of the road; when bad judgment and poor conditions coincide, people get hurt. A driver is responsible for the health and safety of all passengers. If a commercial driver&#x2019;s risky behavior caused you harm, you may be entitled to compensation for injuries and lost wages. The experienced Kentucky common carrier attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can evaluate your case and help get you the compensation you deserve. Call our Kentucky bus accident attorneys at 877.651.7764, our Ohio bus accident attorneys at 877.686.8879 or<a href="/Contact.shtml"> contact us</a> today for a free consultation.

&#xA0;

&#xA0;
-----
EXTENDED BODY:

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Who Pays Your Medical Bills When An Uninsured Driver Causes Bodily Injury?
BASENAME: pays-medical-bills-uninsured-driver-causes-bodily-injury
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/02/2017 02:18:58 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-5574" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Who-Pays-Your-Medical-Bills-When-An-Uninsured-Driver-Causes-Bodily-Injury-300x200.jpg" alt="who-pays-your-medical-bills-when-an-uninsured-driver-causes-bodily-injury" width="300" height="200">It&#x2019;s a situation that pops up far more often than we like to think. A sudden impact, the tinkle of glass, the dust settling from a recently deployed airbag; if you&#x2019;re lucky, your vehicle&#x2019;s crash protection systems worked flawlessly, reducing your risk of serious injury. Unfortunately, that&#x2019;s not always the reality; fully one-third of all accidents in Ohio result in an injury each year. More than 9,000 of those injuries are incapacitating, meaning that victims required serious medical intervention or rehabilitation.
<h2>A widespread problem</h2>
What&#x2019;s worse than suffering catastrophic injuries in an auto accident? Finding out that the person who hit you is uninsured. Despite steep penalties designed to keep uninsured drivers off the roads, more than 1 in 10 drivers in Ohio are uninsured. According to the most recent data available from the <a href="http://www.iii.org/fact-statistic/uninsured-motorists">Insurance Information Institute</a>, Ohio has the 17<sup>th</sup> highest rate of uninsured drivers in the nation. Recovering from catastrophic injuries after an auto accident is hard enough; finding out that the driver who caused them is uninsured can be devastating.

Ohio is an at-fault state; whoever causes an accident is on the hook to pay for any damages. Unfortunately, the state does not require drivers to carry uninsured/underinsured motorist insurance, and many people opt out of the extra coverage in an effort to save money. While reducing your monthly premium can save you in the short run, insufficient insurance coverage can be ruinous in the long run.
<h2>How to get compensation</h2>
If you suffer injuries in an accident caused by an uninsured driver, there are two options to recover damages; you can file a claim for uninsured motorist benefits with your own insurance company, or you can sue the uninsured driver. Navigating even these basic steps can be complicated and time-consuming, especially when recovering from serious injuries. Experienced legal counsel can help you determine which path offers the best chance of recovering damages and help you plan for the future.

Even if the person who caused your accident is in poor financial health, a current judgment in your favor can be collected in the future. You don&#x2019;t have to suffer financial hardship for injuries and damages that weren&#x2019;t your fault. If you have been injured by an uninsured driver or in any other accident, the experienced Kentucky and Ohio auto accident attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can evaluate your case and help get you the compensation you deserve. Call our Kentucky legal team at 877.651.7764, our Ohio legal team at 877.686.8879 or <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today for a free consultation.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: New Study Suggests That Better Sleep Could Speed Healing For TBI Victims
BASENAME: new-study-suggests-better-sleep-speed-healing-tbi-victims
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/31/2017 01:16:28 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-5571" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/New-Study-Suggests-That-Better-Sleep-Could-Speed-Healing-For-TBI-Victims-300x200.jpg" alt="new-study-suggests-that-better-sleep-could-speed-healing-for-tbi-victims" width="300" height="200">A new study from Canada could mean better results for victims of traumatic brain injury. The research, recently published in the journal <em>Neurology, </em>examined the sleep habits of 30 patients who had been hospitalized for moderate to severe traumatic brain injury (TBI) following an accident. The results from the University of Montreal are the latest findings that are helping to establish a firm link between good sleep and brain health.
<h2>An important discovery</h2>
From <a href="http://www.natlawreview.com/article/uninterrupted-sleep-may-advance-healing-patients-tbi">The National Law Review</a>, &#x201C;The findings in this study showed that as the brain heals, sleep patterns also improve. Gosselin&#x2019;s theory is that it could work just as well in reverse order, i.e., if sleep patterns are normalized on a 24 hour cycle, neuron repair would be accelerated.&#xA0;Supporting this theory is an earlier study showing a link between cognitive rest and TBI symptoms.&#x201D;

This link doesn&#x2019;t just provide hope for TBI victims; it may be an important tool in the fight against neurodegenerative disease like Alzheimer&#x2019;s and chronic traumatic encephalopathy. Jeffrey Iliff, a brain scientist at Oregon Health &amp; Science University in Portland, told <a href="http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/01/04/460620606/lack-of-deep-sleep-may-set-the-stage-for-alzheimers">NPR</a>, &#x201C;&#x2019;Changes in sleep habits may actually be setting the stage&#x2019; for dementia. The brain appears to clear out toxins linked to Alzheimer&apos;s during sleep.... And, at least among research animals that don&apos;t get enough solid shut-eye, those toxins can build up and damage the brain.&#x201D;

Today&#x2019;s problems, tomorrow&#x2019;s solutions

While further research is needed, the findings at the very least indicate that regulating sleep can&#x2019;t make a brain injury worse. If further studies confirm that the link between brain health and sleep works both ways, these results could become a powerful tool in the treatment of brain injuries and disorders. While research like this may ultimately find a cure for a damaged brain, the world we live in today offers only limited options for recovery.

For now, victims of TBI require extensive therapy, rehabilitation and other continuing care, all of which contribute to mountains of medical bills. Recovery and treatment options may not be immediately clear, and the future can be very uncertain. Experienced legal counsel isn&#x2019;t an extreme option; sometimes, it&#x2019;s the only way to protect your family. When you need us, the experienced Ohio and Kentucky traumatic brain injury lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can fight for your family and help get you the compensation you need. For a free consultation, call our Ohio legal team at 877.686.8879, our Kentucky legal team at 877.651.7764 or contact us today.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Tractor-Trailer Driver&#x2019;s Methamphetamine Use Caused This 2015 Fatal Pileup
BASENAME: tractor-trailer-drivers-methamphetamine-use-caused-2015-fatal-pileup
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/27/2017 12:03:14 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-5561" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Tractor-Trailer-Driver&#x2019;s-Methamphetamine-Use-Caused-This-2015-Fatal-Pileup-300x200.jpg" alt="tractor-trailer-drivers-methamphetamine-use-caused-this-2015-fatal-pileup" width="300" height="200">Last June in Tennessee, a seven-car pileup in a construction zone killed six people and injured eighteen more. An investigation into the crash found that the tractor-trailer responsible for the initial collision was traveling at better than 80mph into a zone of heavy traffic; no attempt was made to slow down or evade the snarled traffic. After months of investigation, federal officials with the National Transportation Safety Board reported that the truck&#x2019;s driver, Benjamin Brewer, was probably fatigued and had tested positive for the drug methamphetamine.
<h2>How it happened</h2>
Investigators found that Brewer had not slept for at least 40 hours leading up to the crash; initial reports cited a 50-hour long-haul run from Kentucky to Florida and back. Allegedly, Brewer checked in regularly with his employer during that time, indicating that both the driver and the trucking company knowingly violated federal duty regulations. Worse, Brewer shouldn&#x2019;t have been on the road at all, a fact that a simple commercial driver&#x2019;s license database like the one proposed by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration would have disclosed, but his employer should have discovered nonetheless.

From the <a href="http://www.nydailynews.com/news/crime/tired-truck-driver-high-meth-caused-car-crash-killed-article-1.2817742">New York Daily News</a>:

&#x201C;In its release of the probable cause findings for the June 2015 crash, the National Transportation Safety Board also cited a failure in the employee screening process to determine that driver Benjamin Brewer of London, Kentucky, had been fired from a previous trucking job two years earlier because of illegal drug use. A hair test administered under an unrelated court order less than three months before the crash had also turned out positive for meth... &#x2018;The driver in this crash should not have been behind the wheel of a large truck,&#x2019; said NTSB Chairman Christopher A. Hart. &#x2018;As long as human beings drive trucks, they must be rested and unimpaired.&#x2019;&#x201D;
<h2>Drugs and driving don&#x2019;t mix</h2>
The loss of life and the injuries sustained by victims of Brewer&#x2019;s (and his employer&#x2019;s) negligence is unforgivable, but the circumstances are hardly unusual in the commercial trucking industry. Big companies focus on the bottom line, leaving truck drivers with the option of driving fatigued or turning to illegal stimulants when coffee just won&#x2019;t cut it anymore. According to data from the <a href="https://www.fmcsa.dot.gov/safety/data-and-statistics/large-truck-and-bus-crash-facts-2014">FMCSA</a>, around 40% of the drivers who test positive for drugs after a fatal accident were using some form of stimulant.

Benjamin Brewer shouldn&#x2019;t have been allowed behind the wheel of a commercial truck; his proven history of drug use and abuse directly caused the deaths of six people and the emotional pain and suffering of dozens more. When companies ignore the law and drivers ignore common sense, people suffer. At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we fight for victims and their families when they need us most. Our experienced Kentucky commercial truck accident attorneys can help get you the compensation your family deserves in their time of need. For a free consultation, call our Ohio truck accident attorneys at 877.686.8879, our Kentucky truck accident attorneys at 877.651.7764, or <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Kentucky&#x2019;s Medical Centers Are Duking It Out Over Christ Hospital&#x2019;s Expansion Plans
BASENAME: kentuckys-medical-centers-duking-christ-hospitals-expansion-plans
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/14/2017 11:44:08 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-5656" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Kentucky&#x2019;s-Medical-Centers-Are-Duking-It-Out-Over-Christ-Hospital&#x2019;s-Expansion-Plans-300x200.jpg" alt="kentuckys-medical-centers-are-duking-it-out-over-christ-hospitals-expansion-plans" width="300" height="200">There is a certain level of irony over two medical giants fighting to death over land use near the Buttermilk Pike, but truth is stranger than fiction. But it&#x2019;s also an important story &#x2013; one that should be given a little more status, perhaps, than it has &#x2013; for a few reasons.

To recap: Christ Hospital Health Network bought some land that sits on I-71 and I-75 in Northern Kentucky. They want to build a new outpatient surgical center there (a $24 million project), and according to <a href="http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2017/02/02/st-e-christ-duking-out-over-nky-surgery-center/97052036/">Cincinnati.com</a>, would be the anchor building for new housing and retail buildings. In order for Christ Hospital to build there, they need a certificate of need: a document from Kentucky&#x2019;s Cabinet for Health and Family Services that will &#x201C;control costs by preventing unnecessary construction or duplication of services.&#x201D;

But St. Elizabeth Healthcare says the new center would be &#x201C;an unfair effort to cherry-pick wealthier patients in a market where nine outpatient surgical centers already operate at less than full capacity&#x201D; by Christ Hospital, because there are already nine &#x201C;ambulatory surgical centers&#x201D; in the northern Kentucky region. St Elizabeth, which merged with St. Luke&#x2019;s system back in 2008, owns six of them.
<h2>A corporate giant, an overly selective hospital &#x2013; or something else altogether?</h2>
The problem can be viewed in two ways: St. Elizabeth&#x2019;s system is essentially a monopoly, which means that Christ Hospital is offering some much-needed competition. However, St. Elizabeth also bears the weight of caring for patients on Medicaid &#x2013; a weight that Christ Hospital would avoid by serving an area that is much more likely to be well-insured. (The Cincinnati.com article offers a more extensive explanation of the problems, which we would encourage you to read.)

From our perspective, there&#x2019;s a different problem altogether: namely, that patients often forget that hospitals are businesses first, and providers second. We&#x2019;re watching two of the best hospitals systems in the region (Christ Hospital is #1 in Cincinnati and #5 in Ohio, and St. Elizabeth is #5 in the Cincinnati metro area, though they earned the #3 spot in Kentucky) fight for more patients, and for specific &#x201C;kinds&#x201D; of patients, in order to make money. There has been no discussion of what kinds of new technologies or services either system will offer &#x2013; only discussions about how much more money they can make. And while both promise to be cost-effective for patients, there is no indication that people will save any more money.

There are some extraordinary doctors in each of these systems, and some not-so-extraordinary ones, too. But at the end of the day, these medical &#x201C;titans&#x201D; aren&#x2019;t battling it out for your health: they&#x2019;re doing it for your money. It&#x2019;s why civil lawsuits against hospitals on behalf of injured patients are often the only truly effective tool for stopping dangerous practices. You have to hit them where it hurts: their wallets.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we represent the best interests of medical malpractice victims in Kentucky and Ohio. We have successfully represented clients who have been hurt in hospitals served by both the Christ Hospital Health Network and St. Elizabeth Healthcare. If you need an attorney who will fight for you, Crandall &amp; Pera Law is here. To work with our medical malpractice lawyer, please call out Kentucky office at 877.651.7764, or our Ohio team at 877.686.8879. You can also reach us through our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: The Future Is Now: There Are Disease Destroying Robots at Christ Hospital
BASENAME: future-now-disease-destroying-robots-christ-hospital
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/17/2017 10:52:50 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-5664" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/https-www.cpw-law.comcontact-us-300x200.jpg" alt="The Future Is Now: There Are Disease Destroying Robots at Christ Hospital" width="300" height="200">Let&#x2019;s start with the premise that robots are cool. Autonomous cars, drones, BB-8, that machine that mixes drinks on cruises &#x2013; there seems to be no limit to what technology can do to benefit the world. And while there are considerable (and justifiable) concerns over issues like liability and artificial intelligence, new tech has done much to help the medical field, and to improve patient safety.

Perhaps nowhere is this more obvious than at Christ Hospital in the greater Cincinnati area, where there are five Xenex LightStrike Germ-Zapping Robots being used to &#x201C;zap&#x201D; dangerous, infectious pathogens that can lead to hospital-acquired infections, or HAIs.

Christ Hospital is not the only one using this type of technology; UC Health has also used robots to clean and sanitize rooms. However, as <a href="http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2017/01/23/new-fangled-robots-zap-infectious-bugs-christ-hospital/96783296/">Cincinnati.com</a> explains:

&#x201C;UC Health has been using UV blasters as a tool against infections; yet the UC Medical Center was among the four area hospitals <a href="http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2017/01/09/us-punishes-4-cincinnati-area-hospitals/96211876/">penalized for their infection rates</a>. Christ Hospital says the older technology uses mercury bulbs to create the light, while the Xenex LightStrike Germ-Zapping Robot uses pulsed xenon, which emits a light intense enough to penetrate cell walls and fuse the DNA of microorganisms. The fusing renders the microorganisms unable to reproduce or mutate, killing them on surfaces without contact or chemicals.&#x201D;
<h2>Putting an end to HAIs at Ohio hospitals</h2>
Hospital-acquired infections are a serious problem in Ohio hospitals &#x2013; indeed, in hospitals throughout the country. To combat the problem, the Centers for Medicare &amp; Medicaid Services rolled out the <a href="https://www.medicare.gov/hospitalcompare/HAC-reduction-program.html">Hospital-Acquired Condition Reduction Program</a> in October of 2014. In short, CMS started reducing payments to worst-ranking hospitals in terms of preventing and/or reducing the number of HAIs they have. Scores are based on the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) Patient Safety Indicator (PSI) measure (90 composite required), as well as measures taken to prevent and reduce the number of the following infections:
<ul>
    <li>Central Line-Associated Bloodstream Infection (CLABSI)</li>
    <li>Catheter-Associated Urinary Tract Infection (CAUTI)</li>
    <li>Surgical Site Infection (SSI) &#x2013; colon and hysterectomy</li>
    <li>Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) bacteremia</li>
    <li>Clostridium difficile Infection (CDI)</li>
</ul>
If you&#x2019;re interested in how these scores are assigned, this easy-to-read <a href="https://www.stratishealth.org/documents/HAC_fact_sheet.pdf">fact sheet</a> may help.

Hospital-acquired infections can be life-threatening, so Christ Hospital&#x2019;s new xenon-based robots are a definite step in the right direction to reduce, and hopefully one day eliminate, the pathogens which harm so many. We must be careful, though, to remember that even high tech gadgets can fail or falter, and that hospitals should be held accountable when good tech goes bad, and people suffer as a result.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we help victims of medical malpractice in Ohio and Kentucky secure a better future. We have the experience you want on your side when you make a claim for compensation against a hospital. To learn more about our services, or to schedule a free consultation with a skilled medical malpractice attorney in Ohio or Kentucky, we invite you to fill out this <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>, or to call our offices: 877.686.8879 (Ohio) and 877.651.7764 (Kentucky).

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: NBC&#x2019;s Today Show Reignites Decades Long Campaign for Underride Guards
BASENAME: nbcs-today-show-reignites-decades-long-campaign-underride-guards
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/02/2017 02:47:11 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-5712" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Jayne-Mansfield-300x199.jpg" alt="NBC&#x2019;s Today Show Reignites Decades Long Campaign for Underride Guards" width="300" height="199">On June 29, 1967, Hollywood bombshell Jayne Mansfield performed in a nightclub act in Biloxi, Mississippi. Later that night, she, some of her friends and three of her children piled into a car to head to New Orleans where Mansfield had another engagement the next day. The 34-year-old actress never made it; she and the other adults in the front of the car were killed instantly when the driver rear-ended a tractor-trailer. The high profile death made headlines and prompted the first calls for underride guards on the back and sides of big trucks almost exactly half a century ago.

Thirty years later, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration made rear underride guards mandatory and gave the safety mechanism a name: Mansfield bars. However, proponents of underride guards then and now claim that Mansfield bars aren&#x2019;t enough; trucks need side guards as well to protect against grisly accidents with gruesome results. Most passenger cars strike trailers at almost exactly head height, and underride incursions often shear off the top of these smaller vehicles with devastating consequences.
<h2>Why we still don&#x2019;t have side guards</h2>
From <a href="http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/side-underride-crashes-kill-200-people-year-will-congress-act-n711721">NBC News</a>, &#x201C;Side guards are still not required, even though the NTSB, which investigates accidents, concluded that they would reduce injuries and deaths on America&apos;s roads. It issued a non-binding recommendation to the NHTSA in April 2014 that all new trailers have side protection systems. The Truck Trailer Manufacturers Association, the industry&apos;s lobbying arm, has opposed a side guard requirement for years. It referred NBC News to a 2014 letter to the NHTSA that cited the added cost, technical challenges and concern that the guards could weaken parts of a trailer or dangerously increase their weight.&#x201D;

As usual, a lobbyist group is arguing points that simply don&#x2019;t hold water. There is no technological or materials barrier to side underride guards; there is simply a price of implementation. Just like product formulations and drug costs, Europe is ahead of the game. Commercial trucks across the pond have rear and side underride guards; bridges aren&#x2019;t collapsing under the increased weight, nor has there been a rash of trailer collapses from weakened frames. Instead, a valuable safety feature is preventing deaths from underride incursions.

More than 200 people die and many more are seriously injured each year in the US from underride truck accidents. These deaths and injuries are not pretty, and they are largely preventable. Unfortunately, until bureaucracy catches up with common sense, families will continue to suffer the consequences of commercial truck accidents that leave victims maimed or dead. If your loved one was injured or killed in a commercial truck accident, you may be entitled to compensation for medical bills, lost wages and other damages. The experienced Ohio and Kentucky commercial truck accident attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can evaluate your case and help get you the compensation you deserve. For a free consultation, call our Kentucky legal team at 877.651.7764, our Ohio legal team at 877.686.8879, or <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today.

&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: The Cost Of A Life: Historic Verdict In Pitocin Birth Injury Case Is Justified
BASENAME: cost-life-historic-verdict-pitocin-birth-injury-case-justified
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/28/2017 02:02:29 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-5708" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/The-Cost-Of-A-Life-Historic-Verdict-In-Pitocin-Birth-Injury-Case-Is-Justified-200x300.jpg" alt="the-cost-of-a-life-historic-verdict-in-pitocin-birth-injury-case-is-justified" width="200" height="300">After four years, justice has been served for Ohio couple Nicole Welker and her partner, Justin Brinkley. The couple gave birth to a son in 2012, but complications during the labor left baby Justinian with &#x201C;cerebral palsy and catastrophic disabilities&#x201D; according to the lawsuit. After spending two years contending with the realities of Justinian&#x2019;s care, the couple filed a lawsuit. It was another two years before the case was heard, but after four years of trials and travails, the young family will finally get the help they deserve; a civil court jury awarded the plaintiffs a record $14.5 million in damages.

The facts The lawsuit centered on Dr. Thomas Carnevale&#x2019;s use of Pitocin to induce labor; according to pretrial memos, Welker received an inappropriately high dose of the drug despite the fact that her labor was progressing normally. In addition to the inappropriate administration, Dr. Carnevale failed to stop the administering the drug when the fetal heart rate dropped.

From The Legal Intelligencer, &#x201C;The memo said the fetal heart rate progressively slowed for the next hour, dropping to 60 beats per minute by 8:10 p.m., and Carnevale took some steps to expedite the delivery. By that point Carnevale should have taken Welker off Pitocin, the memo said, but Welker remained on the drug for the rest of the delivery. By 8:20 p.m., the memo said, the baby&apos;s head was crowning so it could have been delivered by vacuum or forceps, but the delivery continued for about another 10 minutes before Carnevale cut an episiotomy and the baby was born.&#x201D;
<h2>Why the award was necessary</h2>
Justinian suffers from spastic tetraparesis cerebral palsy (meaning all four limbs are affected) with impaired cognition. He experiences seizures and a condition called global aphasia, meaning that his ability to understand or express language has been severely compromised. He will never be able to socialize normally, never go on a first date, never drive a car; in short, he will never be able to lead a normal life. Justinian will likely require around the clock medical care for the rest of his natural life, and his parents have had to cover costs from specialized equipment to retrofitting their house with ramps, mechanical lifts and other devices.

Large verdicts make headlines and are a bone of contention. Some claim that large malpractice verdicts result in higher insurance costs, and therefore higher healthcare costs. Others point to a broken legal system &#x2013; but not one of those arguments considers the value of a life. In this case, the jury was asked to assign an annual cost of healthcare through the year 2063. Remember, that&#x2019;s twenty-four hour

care for the next forty-six years; suddenly, $14 million doesn&#x2019;t sound like so much money anymore.

Birth injuries of any kind are devastating. Parents hope for a better life for their children, but they&#x2019;ll settle for a normal life; when birth injuries happen, a normal life is a blessing. If your child suffered a birth injury, you may be entitled to compensation for medical bills, therapy and other care. The experienced Kentucky and Ohio birth injury attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can evaluate your case and help get you the compensation you deserve. For a free consultation, call our Ohio legal team at 877.686.8879, our Kentucky legal team at 877.651.7764, or <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us </a>today.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: &#x201C;More Than 16,000 Complaints of Sexual Abuse Have Been Reported Since 2000:&#x201D; CNN&#x2019;s Report on the Safety of Nursing Home Residents
BASENAME: 16000-complaints-sexual-abuse-reported-since-2000-cnns-report-safety-nursing-home-residents
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/23/2017 12:00:34 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-5704" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/&#x201C;More-Than-16000-Complaints-of-Sexual-Abuse-Have-Been-Reported-Since-2000-&#x201D;-CNN&#x2019;s-Report-on-the-Safety-of-Nursing-Home-Residents-300x200.jpg" alt="more-than-16000-complaints-of-sexual-abuse-have-been-reported-since-2000-cnns-report-on-the-safety-of-nursing-home-residents" width="300" height="200">Being a plaintiff injury attorney means you&#x2019;re going to hear some truly devastating stories. You&#x2019;re going to work with people whose lives have been turned upside down, who have lost loved ones, and who have been permanently injured in some way. When you work with nursing home residents, like our team in Kentucky does, you&#x2019;re going to see a lot of really heart-breaking cases of neglect and physical abuse involving a vulnerable part of society: the elderly. It&#x2019;s never easy, but you work hard and you fight even harder on behalf of the people who need you.

But some stories are even more horrific than you can imagine. A recent CNN investigatory piece, titled &#x201C;<a href="http://www.cnn.com/interactive/2017/02/health/nursing-home-sex-abuse-investigation/">Sick, Dying and Raped in America&#x2019;s Nursing Homes</a>,&#x201D; is one of those stories. Actually, it&#x2019;s a collection of stories about the atrocities committed against an aging population throughout the country &#x2013; not just in Kentucky, but in every state. According to their research:

&#x201C;More than 16,000 complaints of sexual abuse have been reported since 2000 in long-term care facilities (which include both nursing homes and assisted living facilities), according to federal data housed by the <a href="https://acl.gov/">Administration for Community Living</a>. <strong>But agency officials warned that this figure doesn&apos;t capture everything</strong> -- only those cases in which state long-term care ombudsmen (who act as advocates for facility residents) were somehow involved in resolving the complaints&#x201D; (emphasis ours).

CNN&#x2019;s own research showed that between 2013 and 2016, more than 1,000 nursing homes were cited by the federal government &#x201C;for mishandling or failing to prevent alleged cases of rape, sexual assault and sexual abuse at their facilities.&#x201D; Almost 10% of them had more than one citation. Close to 500 facilities didn&#x2019;t contact the police, didn&#x2019;t do thorough background checks on employees, and didn&#x2019;t investigate accusations.
<h2>Why are so many nursing home residents sexually abused?</h2>
Rape and sexual abuse are rarely about sex: they about power. And few people are more powerless than elderly patients suffering from degenerative diseases, or from conditions like Alzheimer&#x2019;s or dementia. Patients in nursing homes need help taking care of themselves for a variety of reasons, which can make them easy targets for abuse or neglect. They simply cannot fend off an abuser.

Furthermore, many nursing home abuse victims are unable to point out their attackers. They may suffer from visual impairment or cognitive disabilities, or may be unable to communicate verbally in any way. CNN points out that &#x201C;victims with dementia and other diseases are often considered such unreliable witnesses that even cases in which an assailant confesses to the crime can end up being thrown out or result in little punishment for the defendant.&#x201D;
<h2>Protecting nursing home residents from abuse</h2>
First and foremost, facilities need to be held accountable for crimes committed against their residents, no matter what kind of crimes they are. In order to do that, though, we must implement some kind of reporting system to keep track of these abuses, and to ensure that that these reports get to the proper authorities.

We must also demand that any incident of abuse, sexual or otherwise, is thoroughly investigated by the facility, and by the police. This means treating these cases like the crimes they are: witness interviews, preservation of evidence, and justice for the victims.

Prevention of these crimes is critical. To that end, a handful of states have passed laws allowing cameras to be placed in residents&#x2019; rooms (Kentucky isn&#x2019;t one of them), but there are other issues regarding privacy that can complicate the matter, especially if the resident shares a room. Until the law is clear, nursing homes need to properly train and supervise their employees.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we stand up for the rights of our clients, and seek justice for those whose rights have been violated. Our trusted team of Kentucky nursing home abuse attorneys help guide you when your elderly loved one has been harmed. To learn more about our services, or to schedule a complimentary consultation, please call 877-686-8879 or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Pill Mill Doc Charged with 74 Counts of Malpractice Over Opioid Prescriptions
BASENAME: pill-mill-doc-charged-74-counts-malpractice-opioid-prescriptions
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/07/2017 02:41:46 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-5742" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Pill-Mill-Doc-Charged-with-74-Counts-of-Malpractice-Over-Opioid-Prescriptions-300x200.jpg" alt="pill-mill-doc-charged-with-74-counts-of-malpractice-over-opioid-prescriptions" width="300" height="200">The opioid epidemic in America is becoming more serious with each passing year. Opioid-related overdose deaths have been rising at a staggering rate; 2014 saw more than 28,000 deaths, though that number was quickly outpaced by the 33,000 overdose deaths in 2015. According to the <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/drugoverdose/epidemic/">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a>, more than half a million people died from drug overdoses between 2000 and 2015, a rate of 91 deaths each and every day.

There is some debate over how much blame to assign to prescribing practices in the past. In some cases, the <a href="https://www.patientsrightsblog.com/middle-public-health-crisis-doctors-caused/">opioid prescriptions</a> are undoubtedly appropriate; in others, their use is determined on a case-by-case basis. As in all things, however, there are outliers; some physicians are worse offenders than others. A recent bust in Nevada saw 74 counts of malpractice filed against a Dr. Robert Rand for allegedly running a &#x201C;pill-mill.&#x201D;
<h2>The story</h2>
From the <a href="http://www.rgj.com/story/news/2017/02/02/pill-mill-doctor-faces-74-counts-malpractice-opioid-prescriptions/97429086/">Reno Gazette-Journal</a>:

&#x201C;The malpractice complaint alleges&#xA0;Rand &#x2018;violated the standards of practice in regard to opioid prescribing, practiced medicine beyond the scope of training and competence, engaged in unsafe and unprofessional conduct and maintained substandard medical records.&#x2019; The patients involved in&#xA0;the complaint were prescribed &#x2018;massive amounts&#x2019; of highly addictive opioid narcotics, including doses at several times the &#x2018;high dose threshold,&#x2019; the complaint said. Only one of the 18 patients in the complaint is described as deceased. Rand is charged in connection with the death of 33-year-old Michael Yenick, a former Manogue High School football player who died of alcohol and oxycodone intoxication.&#x201D;

While Dr. Rand cools his heels in the Washoe County Jail, the Nevada Board of Medical Examiners is considering the evidence. That agency can strip Rand of his medical license, but they have no further powers. Instead, Rand will face criminal drug distribution charges down the road. At the moment, there&#x2019;s a chance that Rand will be released from jail before the medical board has a chance to consider his case, leaving a potential criminal free to continue writing prescriptions indefinitely.
<h2>With great power comes great responsibility</h2>
Healthcare providers are held to higher standard of care for a reason; they are entrusted with the health (and by extension, the lives) of the people they treat. This trust, and the powers that go with it (the ability to prescribe otherwise dangerous substances to treat legitimate illnesses), come at a high cost- obtaining a doctorate takes money, time, and a great deal of discipline. Sometimes, medical professionals forget that with great power comes great responsibility; when they do, real people suffer serious consequences.

If your loved one has been the victim of medical negligence or misdiagnosis, you may be entitled to compensation for medical bills, lost wages and other damages. The experienced Kentucky and Ohio medical malpractice lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can evaluate your case and help get you the compensation you need. For a free consultation, call our Ohio legal team at 877.686.8879, our Kentucky legal team at 877.651.7764, or <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Infant Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy and Birth Injuries
BASENAME: infant-hypoxic-ischemic-encephalopathy-birth-injuries
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/16/2017 02:26:21 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-5767" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Infant-Hypoxic-Ischemic-Encephalopathy-and-Birth-Injuries-300x200.jpg" alt="infant-hypoxic-ischemic-encephalopathy-and-birth-injuries" width="300" height="200">Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy (HIE) is a catastrophic medical condition that occurs during childbirth. It happens when the brain and other organs suffer damage due to a lack of blood or oxygen. It is a common enough condition that birth doctors should anticipate it and take the necessary steps to prevent it.
<ul>
    <li>Hypoxia refers to the brain and different organs</li>
    <li>Ischemia refers to low blood flow</li>
    <li>Encephalopathy is the damage that occurs to the brain because of the improper amount of blood or oxygen</li>
</ul>
If the lack of blood or oxygen flow is too prolonged or severe, serious birth injuries or death can result.
<h2>HIE symptoms</h2>
Common symptoms of Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy include:
<ul>
    <li>Amniotic fluid that is meconium-stained</li>
    <li>A low heart rate</li>
    <li>Difficulty breathing</li>
    <li>Improper or pale skin color</li>
    <li>Excess blood acid</li>
</ul>
Diagnostic tests are used to determine if the newborn has HIE. Common tests include a CT or MRI scan, an echocardiography test, and an ultrasound. An EKG or EEG test may also be used. HIE can range from moderate to severe.

Newborns with mild symptoms may live a relatively normal life. Children with severe symptoms often live with pain and some tragically have a shortened life expectancy. Common medical problems can include:
<ul>
    <li>Cognitive difficulties</li>
    <li>Delays in the development of motor skills</li>
    <li>Neurodevelopmental delays</li>
    <li>Epilepsy</li>
</ul>
The true depth of HIE may not be known until the child is three or four years old.
<h2>HIE causes</h2>
HIE should be anticipated during pregnancy, delivery, and after birth. Doctors and hospitals should anticipate and monitor the known causes during the pregnancy, including checking for:
<ul>
    <li>Maternal diabetes</li>
    <li>Preeclampsia &#x2013; a well-known pregnancy complication involving high blood pressure</li>
    <li>Heart disease</li>
    <li>Placenta-related circulation problems</li>
    <li>Abuse of alcohol and drugs</li>
    <li>Fetal anemia</li>
</ul>
Infections and malformation of the lungs can also contribute to HIE prior to the delivery process.

Birth delivery complications can include an abnormal position of the fetus, a ruptured placenta or uterus, a lengthy delivery, problems with the umbilical cord, and excessive bleeding.

HIE can also be due to a lack of proper care after the delivery. Some well-known postpartum HIE problems include:
<ul>
    <li>Heart or lung disease</li>
    <li>Sepsis, meningitis, and other infections</li>
    <li>Low blood pressure</li>
    <li>Trauma to the brain or skull</li>
    <li>A congenital malformation of the brain</li>
</ul>
There are some treatment options, if done timely, that may help reduce the immediate complications from HIE. Mechanical ventilators can help a baby breathe. Medications can help with seizures. In the long-term, many children with HIE need extensive rehabilitative care.

The Kentucky birth injury malpractice lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law know how crushing an HIE diagnosis of your child can be. We understand the distress and anxiety about the child&#x2019;s ability to function normally and lead a healthy life. To speak to a caring experienced Kentucky trial attorney, please phone us at 877-686-8879. You can also reach us through our <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">contact form</a>.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Can Cutting the Cord Too Soon Decrease Your Child&#x2019;s IQ?
BASENAME: can-cutting-cord-soon-decrease-childs-iq
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/14/2017 02:44:05 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-5764" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Can-Cutting-the-Cord-Too-Soon-Decrease-Your-Child&#x2019;s-IQ-300x199.jpg" alt="can-cutting-the-cord-too-soon-decrease-your-childs-iq" width="300" height="199">It has long been established that, once a baby is born, the doctor will clamp down on the umbilical cord and snip it right away. The whole reason for doing this was to reduce the risk to the mother of hemorrhaging. As it turns out, that associated risk wasn&#x2019;t really a risk at all, and recent studies show that the benefits to delaying the cut are too good to ignore.

This January, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, or ACOG, &#x201C;became the latest major medical organization to formally recommend that doctors routinely wait before clamping and cutting the cord,&#x201D; as per the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/02/well/family/doctors-no-longer-rush-to-cut-the-umbilical-cord.html?smprod=nytcore-iphone&amp;smid=nytcore-iphone-share&amp;_r=0"><em>New York Times</em></a>. They join with the American Academy of Pediatrics, the World Health Organization and the American College of Nurse-Midwives in advising that doctors hold off on severing the umbilical cord. In their announcement, ACOG states:
<ul>
    <li>&#x201C;In term infants, delayed umbilical cord clamping increases hemoglobin levels at birth and improves iron stores in the first several months of life, which may have a favorable effect on developmental outcomes.</li>
    <li>Delayed umbilical cord clamping is associated with significant neonatal benefits in preterm infants, including improved transitional circulation, better establishment of red blood cell volume, decreased need for blood transfusion, and lower incidence of necrotizing enterocolitis and intraventricular hemorrhage.</li>
    <li>Given the benefits to most newborns and concordant with other professional organizations, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists now recommends a delay in umbilical cord clamping in vigorous term and preterm infants for at least 30&#x2013;60 seconds after birth.&#x201D;</li>
</ul>
The extra blood and iron contributes to the newborn&#x2019;s brain development; the <em>Times</em> cites a <a href="http://www.bmj.com/content/343/bmj.d7157">2011 trial in Sweden</a> where children who had delayed cord cutting &#x201C;had modestly higher scores in fine motor and social skills&#x201D; and were less likely to be iron-deficient in their early months of life. Because iron deficiency and poor oxygenation can lead to difficulties later, cutting the cord too soon may even be detrimental in some ways. There is also the chance that, given &#x201C;umbilical cord blood contains immunoglobins and stem cells... researchers speculate that delayed cord clamping might aid immune function and tissue healing,&#x201D; but this has not yet been studied.

The benefits of delayed clamping to pre-term child have long been espoused by most medical organizations, but now more and more groups are coming forward about the benefits for term babies as well. The <em>Times</em> claims there are currently 16 studies regarding cord clamping protocols, all of which may yield useful information for helping to protect both mothers and their children &#x2013; and that&#x2019;s something we can stand behind.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law provides comprehensive counsel to injury victims throughout Ohio and Kentucky. For more information about our services, or to speak with a skilled birth injury attorney, please call out Ohio office at 877.686.8879, our Kentucky team at 877.651.7764, or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">contact form</a>.

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: H.R. 1215: Congressional Tort Reform Designed to Destroy Your Rights
BASENAME: h-r-1215-congressional-tort-reform-designed-destroy-rights
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/08/2017 01:18:53 PM
-----
BODY:
[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][caption id=&quot;attachment_5746&quot; align=&quot;alignright&quot; width=&quot;300&quot;]<img class="size-medium wp-image-5746" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/H.R.-1215-Congressional-Tort-Reform-Designed-to-Destroy-Your-Rights-300x200.jpg" alt="h-r-1215-congressional-tort-reform-designed-to-destroy-your-rights" width="300" height="200"> Gavel on a book[/caption]

We&#x2019;ve spoken quite a bit about tort reform in the past, and the dangers it poses to victims of serious personal injuries and medical malpractice. We&#x2019;ve fought it in the state legislatures in Ohio and Kentucky, when such bills came up, and we&#x2019;ve fought it in the court of public opinion, too. Limiting a victim&#x2019;s ability to collect fair and just compensation not only makes it more difficult for that person to survive, but it undermines any real accountability that the negligent party has.

It should come as no surprise, then, that we will proudly fight against federal attempts to cave into the corporations at the expense of their victims. The <a href="https://www.law.cornell.edu/rules/frcp/rule_38">Seventh Amendment of the U.S. Constitution</a> guarantees your right to a civil trial by jury. For all the masquerading that H.R. 1215 does, at its core, it is in violation of your Constitutional rights.
<h2>What is the Protecting Access to Care Act of 2017?</h2>
You can <a href="https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/115/hr1215/text/ih">read the full text</a> here, but let&#x2019;s start with the summary of the bill, H.R. 1215, itself: &#x201C;To improve patient access to health care services and provide improved medical care by reducing the excessive burden the liability system places on the health care delivery system.&#x201D; In short, it&#x2019;s a bill designed to take away your rights to a jury trial, and to limit how much compensation an injury victim can collect.

Remember: medical errors are the third leading cause of death in this country. This new bill will destroy any incentive that the medical industry has to actually fixing that problem.
<h2>What damage caps will H.R. 1215 put into place?</h2>
The new bill places no caps on economic damages, a small silver lining on a thunderstorm cloud. It will, however, drastically limit the amount of non-economic damages you may be able to collect &#x2013; and in a sneaky way, too. From the bill (excerpts in bold were emphasized by us):
<ul>
    <li>&#x201C;In any health care lawsuit, <strong>the amount of noneconomic damages, if available, shall not exceed $250,000, </strong>regardless of the number of parties against whom the action is brought or the number of separate claims or actions brought with respect to the same injury.&#x201D;</li>
    <li>&#x201C;<strong>The jury shall not be informed about the maximum award for noneconomic damages</strong>. An award for noneconomic damages in excess of $250,000 shall be reduced either before the entry of judgment, or by amendment of the judgment after entry of judgment, and such reduction shall be made before accounting for any other reduction in damages required by law.&#x201D;</li>
    <li>&#x201C;In any health care lawsuit, each party shall be liable for that party&#x2019;s several share of any damages only and not for the share of any other person. <strong>Each party shall be liable only for the amount of damages allocated to such party in direct proportion to such party&#x2019;s percentage of responsibility</strong>.&#x201D;</li>
</ul>
<h2>Additional concerns about the bill</h2>
Damage caps have always been a problem, but we have deeply-rooted concerns about the rest of the bill, as well.&#xA0;H.R. 1215 also stands to:
<ul>
    <li>Eliminate the class-action lawsuit</li>
    <li>Make all healthcare claims federal claims, thus eliminating any states&#x2019; individual laws</li>
    <li>Allow insurance companies to pay out claims via payments, as opposed to all at once</li>
</ul>
It is worth noting, perhaps, that plaintiff attorneys &#x2013; those of us who fight for victims &#x2013; will have their fees limited, but defense attorneys &#x2013; those who represent the negligent parties who caused you harm &#x2013; have no such limitations placed on their salaries. In other words, the doctor who missed your cancer diagnosis, or the nurse who mislabeled your chart and caused a drug overdose, or the surgeon who perforated your bowel but didn&#x2019;t fix it in time: their attorneys can charge whatever they want.
<h2>Why is H.R. 1215 bad for victims and their families?</h2>
This Congressional bill aims to fix a &#x201C;crisis&#x201D; that even medical malpractice insurers say does not exist, and has not existed for more than a decade. According to <a href="http://www.cincinnati.com/story/money/2017/01/11/gop-sees-malpractice-crisis-experts-do-not/96466290/">Cincinnati.com</a>, the Doctors Company, one of the country&#x2019;s largest medical malpractice insurance providers, says &#x201C;Doctors are paying less for malpractice insurance than they did in 2001 &#x2013; without any inflation adjustment.... And the rate of claims has dropped by half since 2003.&#x201D;

Despite a <a href="http://www.latimes.com/business/hiltzik/la-fi-mh-another-study-shows-why-tort-reform--20140919-column.html">WEALTH of evidence</a> to the contrary, including years&#x2019; worth of <a href="http://www.takejusticeback.com/who-we-are/fact_v_fiction">studies</a>, <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/stevecohen/2015/03/02/on-tort-reform-its-time-to-declare-victory-and-withdraw/#33c1f27b63ea">research</a>, data collection, and so on, this Congress continues to perpetuate the lie that limiting the civil justice system, in terms of which kinds of lawsuits you can bring and in how much money a victim can collect, will do anything at all to save money when it comes to health care.

It won&#x2019;t. <a href="https://www.patientsrightsblog.com/tort-reform-damage-caps-protect-hospitals-not-patients/">It never has</a>. It never will. All tort reform has EVER done is hurt people more. The Protecting Access to Care Act of 2017 essentially says that it doesn&#x2019;t matter how severe, how catastrophic, your injuries are: they&#x2019;re worth $250,000 &#x2013; period. We understand that for a lot of people, that seems like a lot of money. So, we want to ask you this:

If a surgeon accidentally amputates your arm when he was supposed to be fixing a tendon in your leg, is that only worth $250,000?

If a doctor fails to recommend an emergency C-section because the umbilical cord is wrapped around your baby-to-be&#x2019;s neck, and now your child has permanent brain damage, is that only worth $250,000?

If a doctor prescribes the wrong dose of medication to your spouse and it kills him or her, is that only worth $250,000?

We urge everyone, whether you have had need of a medical malpractice or personal injury attorney or not, to <a href="http://www.house.gov/representatives/find/">please contact your Representatives</a> and tell them to vote &#x201C;No&#x201D; on H.R. 1215. The only ones who will benefit from this bill are the ones who caused you harm.

In the meantime, Crandall &amp; Pera Law will continue to fight against this egregious bill. We will not back down and we will not give up. Our team has always fought to give a voice to the voiceless, and to protect the rights and futures of the injured. You can rely on us to do the same now.

To learn more about Crandall &amp; Pera Law&#x2019;s services, please <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> at any time. You can reach our team of Ohio lawyers at 877.686.8879 and our team of Kentucky attorneys at 877.651.7764.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: What the Sorin 3T Contamination Debacle Means for Infected Patients
BASENAME: sorin-3t-contamination-debacle-means-infected-patients
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/21/2017 12:46:57 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-5772" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/What-the-Sorin-3T-Contamination-Debacle-Means-for-Infected-Patients-300x226.jpg" alt="What the Sorin 3T Contamination Debacle Means for Infected Patients" width="300" height="226">We recently wrote about the Sorin 3T Heater-Cooler System, a medical device used in invasive open chest surgeries that was the subject of a recent investigation by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The agency found that the device had been contaminated during the manufacturing process with a devastating type of bacteria know as <em>Mycobacterium chimaera</em>. Worse, a defect in the design of the device caused a related organism, <em>Mycobacterium abcessus</em>, to be aerosolized and sprayed out through the device&#x2019;s vent fan.
<h2>What makes mycobacteria so dangerous</h2>
First and foremost, the majority of surgeries that require the use of the Sorin 3T Heater-Cooler system are not minimally invasive procedures to repair minor damage. Any surgery that requires the chest cavity to be open and the cessation of heart activity requires serious recuperation time for individuals who were already health-compromised to begin with. For perspective, the most common open chest surgeries include coronary bypass, heart transplants and lung transplants.

When a chest surgery patient is infected with mycobacterium, there are no immediate symptoms. In fact, the very nature of this family of bacteria makes them difficult to detect and treat; through the ages, mankind has battled mycobacteria that cause leprosy and tuberculosis with very little success until the advent of modern medicine. Mycobacteria are extremely slow growing and very hardy; they have a triple-layered cell wall that makes them nearly impervious to antibiotics or any other treatment. In fact, any condition hazardous enough to kill a mycobacteria infection in a human would kill the human long before the infection was eliminated.
<h2>The cure is worse than the disease</h2>
Currently, mycobacteria infections are treated with long-term, high-dose antibiotics. This treatment can wreak all kinds of havoc on a healthy human being; in a patient living with an artificial valve or organ transplantation issues, this cure could be fatal. Undergoing open chest surgery places tremendous strain on the body. Recovery times are measured in months and years; after a transplant, immunosuppressant drugs can be required for the rest of a patient&#x2019;s life. When an avoidable infection requires high-dose therapy or even revision surgery (to replace an infected valve), quality of life doesn&#x2019;t suffer- it plummets.

Healthcare doesn&#x2019;t happen at a single point. Instead, it&#x2019;s an entire web of researchers, manufacturers, drug makers and care providers that work together to keep you and your loved ones safe and healthy. This network is held to higher standard of care because it all supports to most vital part of our world- our loved ones. When any party is negligent, from design to manufacturing to diagnoses, real people suffer real consequences. At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we fight against negligent healthcare providers and protect patients&#x2019; rights. If you believe that you or your loved one has been the victim of medical malpractice or negligence, our experienced Kentucky and Ohio medical malpractice attorneys can evaluate your case and help get you the compensation you deserve. For a free consultation, call our Kentucky legal team at 877.651.7764, our Ohio legal team at 877.686.8879, or <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">contact us</a> today.

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: According to the Nurses, the ER Doctors at Akron City Hospital Are &#x201C;Out of Practice&#x201D; and &#x201C;Unprepared&#x201D;
BASENAME: according-nurses-er-doctors-akron-city-hospital-practice-unprepared
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/23/2017 01:03:33 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-5775" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/According-to-the-Nurses-the-ER-Doctors-at-Akron-City-Hospital-Are-&#x201C;Out-of-Practice&#x201D;-and-&#x201C;Unprepared&#x201D;-300x200.jpg" alt="according-to-the-nurses-the-er-doctors-at-akron-city-hospital-are-out-of-practice-and-unprepared" width="300" height="200">If you are in the midst of a medical emergency, you should go to the emergency room &#x2013; but not the one at Akron City Hospital, according to nine Registered Nurses on the staff. In an interview with the Akron Beacon Journal, one on-staff RN said &#x201C;I&#x2019;m astonished by how much [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][the USACS physicians] don&#x2019;t know about how to take care of patients. It&#x2019;s mind-blowing.&#x201D;

This is not a charge to be leveled lightly. Akron City Hospital has a Level 1 trauma emergency department. The <a href="http://www.amtrauma.org/?page=traumalevels">American Trauma Society</a> defines that as &#x201C;a comprehensive regional resource... capable of providing total care for every aspect of injury &#x2013; from prevention through rehabilitation.&#x201D; Level 1 centers don&#x2019;t rely on any other facilities or hospitals; they are capable of handling all manner of healthcare needs and emergencies in-house.

It is safe to assume, therefore, that if you are being treated at a Level 1 center, you should be met by skilled, trained doctors and nurses who can correctly diagnose and treat whatever illness or injury you have. But according to the nursing staff at Akron City Hospital, there is no guarantee of this when you enter their center; instead, there have been multiple errors made in the emergency room. The <em>Beacon Journal</em> reports:

&#x201C;The nurses said they have witnessed and intervened when some of the new doctors delayed time-sensitive treatment for stroke patients, prescribed potentially fatal overdoses of common drugs like insulin and heart medication and misread EKGs, a medical test that can reveal whether someone is having a heart attack.&#x201D;
<h2>What&#x2019;s wrong with the doctors in the ER at Akron City Hospital?</h2>
This problem all started with a contract dispute. For forty years, a group of doctors (the Summa Emergency Associates) staffed the ER. In December, the negotiations between the SEA and Summa, the parent company of the hospital, failed. Summa chose to contract with US Acute Care Solutions (USACS) instead.

Since then, the nurses have seen increased delays in the diagnosis and treatment of stroke victims and heart attack sufferers, and a constant turn-over of the staff. Many of the ER doctors now serving Akron City Hospital come from out-of-state, and work for a few days at a time. There is no time to develop any kind of relationship with the patients, and many of the nurses claims they don&#x2019;t know what happens to patients once they leave the nurses&#x2019; care.

It is also worth noting that &#x201C;In February, a national accreditation board <strong>stripped Summa of its ability to train emergency medicine residents beginning July 1</strong>&#x201D; (emphasis ours). Those who claim that the problems in the ER of Akron City Hospital are just the &#x201C;normal&#x201D; kinds of problems that accompany big changes will do well to remember that residents are the step between interns and physicians. Without proper training, they will be unprepared to work in an ER &#x2013; and unable to be licensed to do so, either.

Yet because of the turn-over with attending physicians, it is these residents who are essentially running the ER at Akron City Hospital.
<h2>Delayed diagnosis is a type of medical malpractice</h2>
It only takes minutes for brain cells to start dying, leaving a patient with permanent brain damage. This is why accurate and swift diagnosis of conditions like stroke is critical to the process. Over the last few months, Akron City Hospital&#x2019;s &#x201C;door-to-needle&#x201D; time has increased, on average, by nine minutes. That is a life-threatening amount of time for someone who has suffered a stroke. Being unable to diagnose a stroke, and/or taking too much time to treat a patient with the symptoms of a stroke, is medical malpractice. The <em>Beacon Journal</em> does not report whether or not anyone has died at Akron City Hospital as a result of the changeover this year, but the nurses are clearly afraid &#x2013; enough so, that they are telling their own family members and friends to avoid the ER if they can.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we believe that every patient has the right to the best possible healthcare. We also believe that this story needs further investigation by an outside source, not just someone from Summa. If the Akron City Hospital really is in such tumult, patients&#x2019; lives could be at risk.

If you or a loved one has been injured at the Akron City Hospital, Crandall &amp; Pera Law can help. Our Ohio medical malpractice attorneys have the experience, the skills and the resources you want on your side. To find out more about our services, or to schedule a consultation at one of our offices throughout Ohio, please call 877.686.8879, or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml" target="_blank">contact form</a>.
