AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: New Report on Women and Dangerous Medical Devices
BASENAME: new-report-women-dangerous-medical-devices
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 06/09/2017 12:55:38 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6081" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/Doctor-talking-to-patient-300x226.jpg" alt="New Report on Women and Dangerous Medical Devices" width="300" height="226">The American Association for Justice has released a new report detailing the history of women being negatively impacted by dangerous drugs and medical devices. The report, entitled From Accutane to Zonite: A History of Dangerous Drugs &amp; Devices Marketed to Women<em>, </em>showcases how women have, historically, been disproportionately affected by dangerous drugs and medical devices. Many drugs and medical products are marketed specifically to women, such as certain acne drugs or antidepressants. Others are specifically created and marketed to contend with female-only medical issues, like pregnancy.

The report also details how the civil justice system is often the ultimate fail safe for dangerous drugs and medical devices. Safety checks, such as approval processes at the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are, unfortunately, not always as discerning as they could be, especially with drugs and products designed or marketed to female populations.
<h2>Civil litigation can save women&#x2019;s lives</h2>
Dangerous medical products, such as transvaginal mesh or power morcellators, have long plagued women&apos;s healthcare options. When the FDA expedites approval, there are often quality control issues and harmful or deadly health risks that are simply overlooked due to lack of proper oversight from governmental agencies and pharmaceutical corporations. This timely American Association of Justice (AAJ) report highlights decades upon decades of gender inequalities in prescribing and providing safe medical care. Because of the legal recourse afforded to them by civil litigation, women have been empowered to fight back against substandard medical products, care, and drugs. The report spans from the 1880s to the present.

Julie Braman Kane, who serves as President of AAJ, weighs in. &#x201C;This timely report sheds light on the disturbing ways women have been preyed upon by corporations in the name of profit,&#x201D; she says. &#x201C;More than a century of gender inequality in research and unhindered corporate greed continue to put women at risk of exposure to dangerous drugs and medical devices. We must protect women&#x2019;s access to justice to ensure they can end their silent suffering and hold corporations accountable when corporations refuse to put Americans&#x2019; safety first.&#x201D;

The House of Representatives is currently entertaining a bill, <a href="https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/1215" target="_blank">H.R. 1215</a>, that would give blanket immunity to corporations who market and sell these dangerous drugs and devices if they were at any point approved by the FDA. Even if they were later determined to be dangerous, the blanket immunity would still stand. This report goes a long way in showcasing why this pending legislation is deleterious to American citizens.

If you or someone you love has suffered because of a dangerous medical product or drug, the experienced Ohio and Kentucky medical malpractice attorneys of Crandall &amp; Pera Law are here to help you. We can discuss your case with you and fight for maximum compensation. You are welcome to call our Ohio legal team at 877.686.8879, our Kentucky team at 877.651.7764, or <a href="/Contact.shtml">complete our contact form</a> today.

--------
AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Dear Parents: Please Keep Your Children Away from Football
BASENAME: dear-parents-please-keep-children-away-football
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 06/20/2017 09:35:59 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6038" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Football-and-CTE-300x161.jpg" alt="football and cte" width="300" height="161">School&#x2019;s finally let out, and summer vacation is in full swing here in Ohio. That means pool parties, barbeques, amusement parks and summer concerts are all back. But before you know it, you&#x2019;ll see the flyer, or get an email or a text, about tryouts for the upcoming season for football. It might be the first year for your child, or maybe he (or she) has been playing for years.

Consider this our formal plea: please don&#x2019;t let your kids play football this year.

We know you&#x2019;ve heard the statistics. We know you&#x2019;ve read the literature, or maybe seen the movie <em>Concussion</em>. We know you&#x2019;ve attended the meetings with coaches who outline in great, possibly almost repetitive, detail the different programs that are in place to protect your child&#x2019;s precious and still-forming brain. We know that you&#x2019;ve raised concerns about this game that, perhaps, you yourself played for years, and that you&#x2019;ve done the research and spoken with your child&#x2019;s pediatrician. Your child is careful, and his (or her) coaches are concerned, and the school has invested in protective gear.

We know that brain injuries happen to <em>other people&#x2019;s children</em>. <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/19/sports/football/haunted-by-a-players-death-a-coach-walks-away-from-his-sport.html?smprod=nytcore-iphone&amp;smid=nytcore-iphone-share" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Until they don&#x2019;t</a>.
<h2>We need to talk about the true risk</h2>
Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy (CTE) is a progressive, degenerative brain disease that disproportionately affects people who play contact sports and activities &#x2013; like football, boxing, soccer, MMA, etc. &#x2013; as well as anyone else with a history of repetitive brain trauma. It can begin after one hit. It can take years to develop. It might never develop at all.

And it&#x2019;s that last option &#x2013; that it might never actually happen &#x2013; that allows many people to assume that it will be okay. Even though the number of players who test positive for the disease falls between 87% (<a href="http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/article/new-87-deceased-nfl-players-test-positive-for-brain-disease/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">per PBS</a>) and 95.6% (per <a href="http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/study-956-percent-of-deceased-nfl-players-tested-positive-for-cte/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CBS Sports</a>), <em>it&#x2019;s not 100%</em>. So there&#x2019;s a <em>chance</em> that it won&#x2019;t be your child. There&#x2019;s a <em>chance</em> that he (or she) will be perfectly fine.

There are people who cancel backyard parties because there&#x2019;s a 50% chance of rain. Yet, the chance of your child not developing CTE after years of playing football falls <strong>between 4.4% and 13%</strong>. These numbers are based off of years of methodical research by doctors and scientists: men and women who have devoted their lives to working with the brain. These are about the same odds you have of beating <a href="http://www.cancercenter.com/lung-cancer/stages/tab/non-small-cell-lung-cancer-stage-IV/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">stage IV lung cancer</a> (10%), and worse than the odds of surviving <a href="https://www.cancer.org/cancer/breast-cancer/understanding-a-breast-cancer-diagnosis/breast-cancer-survival-rates.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">stage IV breast cancer</a> (22%), at least five years after being diagnosed.

<strong>Read more:</strong>
<ul>
    <li>Top NFL Exec Finally Acknowledges Link between Football and CTE</li>
    <li>An Open letter to Parents of High School Football Players</li>
    <li><a href="https://www.patientsrightsblog.com/this-is-your-brain-on-sports/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">This Is Your Brain on Sports</a></li>
    <li>Friday Night Lights Out: The Truth about Football and Long Term Brain Damage</li>
    <li>Should There Be a Legal Age Limit for Playing Football?</li>
    <li>College Football Players Diagnosed with CTE Confirms Warnings from Concussion Legacy Foundation</li>
    <li>First Extreme Sport Athlete Diagnosed with Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy</li>
    <li><a href="https://www.patientsrightsblog.com/despite-controversy-over-cte-progress-is-made/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Despite Controversy Over CTE, Progress Is Made</a></li>
    <li>CTE Research Is Incredible, but Prevention Is the Only Sure Cure</li>
</ul>
<h2>Living with permanent brain damage</h2>
When it comes to catastrophic injuries, we know what kinds of challenges victims face; we&#x2019;ve been fighting on behalf of those victims for years. And as former malpractice defense attorneys, we know what kind of fight the insurance company will put up when it comes to getting the care you need.

A traumatic brain injury can affect a victim for the rest of his or her life. CTE is caused by repetitive brain injuries, and it&#x2019;s permanent: once your child is diagnosed, he or she will have that condition forever, and it will progressively get worse. The symptoms and effects, <a href="http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/chronic-traumatic-encephalopathy/basics/symptoms/con-20113581" target="_blank" rel="noopener">as per the Mayo Clinic</a>, may include:
<ul>
    <li>Difficulty thinking (cognitive impairment)</li>
    <li>Impulsive behavior</li>
    <li>Depression or apathy</li>
    <li>Difficulties with speech</li>
    <li>Short-term memory loss, and eventual dementia</li>
    <li>Difficulty planning and carrying out tasks (executive function)</li>
    <li>Emotional instability, including irritability and aggression</li>
    <li>Motor impairment (tremors, mobility, muscle weakness, etc.)</li>
    <li>Inclination toward substance abuse</li>
    <li>Suicidal thoughts or behavior</li>
</ul>
People with CTE in its advanced stages may engage in behaviors that lead to their own deaths, either willingly or unknowingly. And there is only a 4.4-13% chance that it <em>won&#x2019;t</em> happen if your child continues to play football each year.

So this year, as every year, we ask you: Please. Don&#x2019;t let your kids play football this year. The decision could very well save their lives.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier personal injury law firm serving clients throughout Ohio and Kentucky. Please call 877.651.7764 for our Kentucky legal team, 877.686.8879 for our Ohio legal team, or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to learn more about our services.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Birth Injuries: Avoidable Risks with Potentially Lifelong Complications
BASENAME: birth-injuries-avoidable-risks-potentially-lifelong-complications
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 06/16/2017 09:38:41 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6052" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/Brain-Damage-Delivery-300x200.jpg" alt="birth injuries" width="300" height="200">Most parents&#x2019; express wish is simply to have a healthy baby, but sometimes things go terribly wrong in the last few hours of delivery. Birth can be a complex process, and when medical interventions are necessary, risks arise.

Although many birth injuries do not have permanent effects, some do require follow-up care, or even cause costly, debilitating lifelong complications. Because of the nature of birth injuries, subsequent medical care can often be financially devastating to families.
<h2><strong><em>Unlike birth or genetic defects, birth injuries are often preventable and occur during any phase of the delivery process</em></strong></h2>
Today, legal recourse is available to make sure those medical professionals who are at fault in birth injuries pay for necessary care. What are the most potentially serious birth injuries?
<ul>
    <li><strong>Brachial plexus injury</strong>: This nerve injury affects the arm and hand, often as a result of a difficult delivery or a collarbone fracture. These injuries range in severity, with some resolving entirely and others remaining permanently. For those with lifelong complications, the nerve pain and paralysis can impede education and inhibit employment options.</li>
    <li><strong>Bone fractures</strong>: Any number of bones can be injured prior to or during delivery; however, the majority of these fractures heal quickly and without serious intervention. In some cases though, such as fractures of the spinal column as a result of forceps misuse, the resulting paralysis or neurological issues can be irreversible.</li>
    <li><strong>Cerebral palsy</strong>: This incurable injury can actually result from a range of birth injuries, some genetic, others environmental, and still other from preventable asphyxia, infections, or traumatic handling during delivery. Degrees of deficiencies vary, but cerebral palsy generally results in muscular issues: lack of tone and control, problems with coordination and balance, postural issues, and difficulties with reflexes. Cerebral Palsy rarely affects intelligence, but speech and communication may be impaired or severely hindered.</li>
    <li><strong>Intracranial or subarachnoid hemorrhage</strong>: These are both varieties of bleeding within the skull and brain as a result of head injury or trauma during the birth process. The symptoms of these hemorrhages are formidable, including seizures, coma, and even death.</li>
    <li><strong>Meconium aspiration syndrome</strong>: Meconium is the infant&#x2019;s first stool. In some difficult deliveries, meconium is released into the amniotic fluid prior to or during birth. If the meconium gets into the infant&#x2019;s lungs, it can lead to pneumonia and pulmonary hypertension through the child&#x2019;s first decade of life.</li>
    <li><strong>Perinatal asphyxia</strong>: As with any asphyxia, this disorder occurs when the infant, does not receive sufficient oxygen. Depending on the duration of the deprivation, the results can range from minimal to grave, including seizures, shock, coma, or ineliminable neurological damage.</li>
</ul>
While the majority of hospital births in the US occur without any significant complications, about <a href="http://www.rightdiagnosis.com/b/birth_injury/stats.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">7 in every 1000</a> births do lead to injuries. In some of these situations, the medical professionals involved are accountable for the damages and ongoing medical care these infants require.

If your infant has suffered one of the aforementioned injuries during delivery, contact the experienced Kentucky and Ohio medical negligence lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law. We will meet with you to discuss your individual situation and help to get you the compensation you deserve. For a free consultation, call our Kentucky legal team at 877.651.7764, our Ohio legal team at 877.686.8879, or <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today.
<h3>Related Articles</h3>
<ul>
    <li>What is the Difference Between a Birth Injury and a Birth Defect?</li>
    <li>Fracking May Lead to Lower Birth Weights for Babies Born Nearby</li>
    <li>Keeping Your Baby Safe by Eating Better During Pregnancy</li>
    <li>Avon, Ohio Child with Seizure Disorder Meets April the Giraffe</li>
    <li>When Are Medical Professionals Liable for Inadequate Prenatal Care?</li>
    <li>Dedicated Louisville Birth Injury Attorneys Seek Justice for Families</li>
</ul>

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Checklists: Avoiding Sepsis, Saving Lives
BASENAME: checklists-avoiding-sepsis-saving-lives
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 06/23/2017 01:34:42 PM
-----
BODY:
Sepsis is a systemic infection that kills one-quarter of the patients who contract it, but hospitals are taking a new approach to preventing and managing the illness. Even the most slight of injuries can expose patients to danger. Sepsis can follow even a minor infection, but can lead to grave consequences. Medical professionals in New York state are tackling the problem with the least likely resource&#x2014;red tape. Application of a detailed checklist can help prevent sepsis, diagnose it early, and make sure best practices are followed for treatment&#x2014;all of which lead to better outcomes for patients. When hospitals do not adhere to these protocols, patients can die, and doctors can be held legally responsible.
<h2><em>What is sepsis?</em></h2>
The human body has a few methods of handling infection: fever, white blood cells, and antibodies. In healthy people with minor cases, the person may not even realize he or she has an infection, because the immune system handles the problem swiftly and efficiently. In more serious cases, the signs of an infection like a high or prolonged fever, swelling, redness, malaise, and pain lead sufferers to seek medical treatment. In some cases, the immune response goes awry, leading the body&#x2019;s defenses to attack healthy tissue&#x2014;the beginning of sepsis. Without intervention, sepsis progresses to abnormal temperature (high or low), high heart rate, high respiratory rate, decrease in urine output (as the kidneys become unable to cope with the influx of material), altered mental status, changes in cardiac rhythm, pain, and low blood pressure. Not every patient with sepsis will experience every symptom, and many of the symptoms experienced can be confused with symptoms of other infectious processes. This means that sepsis can be missed, particularly in patients who have co-occurring or acute health issues.
<h2><em>Utilization of a checklist</em></h2>
In the New York case of Rory Staunton, age 12, a fall at school and subsequent infection led to a tragic outcome after sepsis set in. Staunton&#x2019;s family came together with medical professionals and lawmakers to create &#x201C;Rory&#x2019;s Regulations,&#x201D; which require hospitals to work through a series of checklists when presented with a patient suspected of suffering from sepsis. Because delays in treatment result in increased mortality, the checklist&#x2019;s ability to facilitate and speed the ministration process at other hospitals in the US has already resulted in an estimated 22% reduction in post-surgical deaths.

No checklist, however, can take the place of involved and informed doctors, nurses, and aides working directly with patients, observing their vital signs and symptoms, making educated diagnoses, and prescribing proven treatments. When sepsis is missed, or treatment is unnecessarily delayed, the results for patients can be fatal, and families can be left bereft and baffled by the loss of their loved one. In these times, legal counsel can provide guidance, assurance, and assistance in making sure that hospitals are held accountable.

If you or a family member has been injured or died after contracting sepsis and not receiving timely or adequate treatment, please contact the experienced Kentucky and Ohio medical negligence lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law. We will meet with you to discuss your family&#x2019;s individual situation and help to get you the justice and compensation you deserve. For a free consultation, call our Kentucky legal team at 877.651.7764, our Ohio legal team at 877.686.8879, or <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: When Are Medical Professionals Liable for Inadequate Prenatal Care?
BASENAME: medical-professionals-liable-inadequate-prenatal-care
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 06/29/2017 03:05:05 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6068" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/prenatal-care-negligence-300x225.jpg" alt="prenatal care negligence" width="300" height="225">As parents, we do everything in their power before the birth of their child to ensure a healthy delivery: prenatal vitamins and doctor&#x2019;s visits, birthing classes &#x2013; even enjoying a baby shower with friends and family, secure in the idea that the welcome infant is safe in the womb. But barring genetic ailments, there are still dangers to the unborn child that can come at the misconduct or misinformation distributed by a medical professional. In these cases, the impacts can range from merely scary but short-term, to serious and potentially life threatening to both child and mother. In these cases, the hospital, doctors, pharmaceutical companies, midwives, and other birthing professionals are legally responsible for the harm they have caused.
<h2><strong><em>What are some prenatal birth injuries?</em></strong></h2>
There are two main categories of prenatal birth injuries: the first involves the pregnant woman taking or being exposed to a medication or communicable disease, without clear notification of the potential dangers to the unborn child. The second type of prenatal birth injury involves situations where medical professionals fail in their due diligence in caring for a pregnant woman, with injurious consequences to the woman or unborn child.

For example, if a drug company fails to adequately test a medication for safety, and then allows it to be prescribed to pregnant women, leading to adverse effects, not only would the prescriber be at fault, so would they pharmacy that failed to check for interactions and the pharmaceutical company. Even typically innocuous substances can be hazardous to the developing child: take folic acid, for instance. Pregnant women are advised to consume adequate levels of folic acid before and during pregnancy to prevent spina bifida. However, in excessive amounts, folic acid itself causes birth defects. A medical professional who failed to advise a patient of the proper dosing of folic acid would be at fault for any resulting birth injuries.

Another concern that many pregnant women and their partners are made aware of it the risk of preeclampsia, a condition involving high blood pressure that can lead to seizures and death for both mother and infant. There are few treatments once preeclampsia has developed, so the primary goal is to closely monitor pregnant women for any risk factors or changes in their baseline medical statistics. Should a doctor fail to notice, or worse, ignore the incipient signs of preeclampsia, the doctor and the hospital that employs him or her could be held responsible for any subsequent birth injuries. Common prenatal negligence include:
<ul>
    <li>Exposure to toxins</li>
    <li>Failure to disclose genetic testing outcomes</li>
    <li>Inappropriate medical tests or care</li>
    <li>Failure to treat gestational diabetes</li>
    <li>Failure to diagnose rubella (German measles)</li>
    <li>Failure to diagnose or treat group B strep</li>
</ul>
The statute of limitations on birth injuries in Kentucky and Ohio is only one year, thus it is vital to seek legal counsel if your infant was injured through the neglect or misconduct of a medical professional prior to, during, or after birth. Contact the experienced Kentucky and Ohio birth injury lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law, who will meet with you to discuss your child&#x2019;s unique situation and help to get your family the compensation you deserve. For a free consultation, call our Kentucky legal team at 877.651.7764, our Ohio legal team at 877.686.8879, or <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today.
<h3>Related Articles</h3>
<ul>
    <li>What is the Difference Between a Birth Injury and a Birth Defect?</li>
    <li>Fracking May Lead to Lower Birth Weights for Babies Born Nearby</li>
    <li>Keeping Your Baby Safe by Eating Better During Pregnancy</li>
    <li>Avon, Ohio Child with Seizure Disorder Meets April the Giraffe</li>
    <li>Birth Injuries: Avoidable Risks with Potentially Lifelong Complications</li>
    <li>Dedicated Louisville Birth Injury Attorneys Seek Justice for Families</li>
</ul>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Lives at Risk When Putting Patients Under Anesthesia
BASENAME: lives-risk-putting-patients-anesthesia
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 06/27/2017 01:57:45 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6070" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/anesthesia-errors-300x200.jpg" alt="anesthesia errors" width="300" height="200">A lot of patients worry about anesthesia. Perhaps it&#x2019;s discomfort with the notion of being brought to an unconscious state where they cannot feel pain, and then returned to awareness with no memory of the intervening events. While anesthesia, when properly administered, has become safer in recent decades, errors persist, leading to grim outcomes for patients. In <a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26492481" target="_blank">2013</a>, the death rate in the US from anesthesia errors was three per 10,000 surgeries.
<h2><em>Causes and types of anesthesia errors</em></h2>
Trying to assign causation to accidents can be challenging, but in a medical setting the amount of assiduous record-keeping that accompanies even the most minor procedure can be extremely helpful to researchers and analysts. In the case of anesthesia errors, most issues fell into one or more of three categories: lack of monitoring, failure to follow proper procedures, and problems with equipment.&#xA0; As we look at the most common types of anesthesia errors, it becomes clear which cause or causes are the most likely to have been at play:
<ul>
    <li>Failing to emphasize the importance of preoperative protocols</li>
    <li>Failing to properly monitor patients before, during, and post anesthesia</li>
    <li>Failing to fully read the patient&#x2019;s medical history or interactions with the patient&#x2019;s medications</li>
    <li>Allergic reactions</li>
    <li>Utilizing defective equipment</li>
    <li>Incorrectly intubating the patient</li>
    <li>Administering excessive amounts of anesthesia for the particular procedure or patient&#x2019;s needs</li>
    <li>Administering insufficient amounts of anesthesia for the particular procedure or patient&#x2019;s needs</li>
</ul>
<h2><em>Effects of anesthesia errors</em></h2>
Not every anesthesia error leads to permanent issues for the patient. Some can be minor, annoying, or even dismissed entirely. However, as the effects of anesthesia are cumulative over a lifetime, any over dosage or misuse can lead to problems in the future if the patient needs to go under anesthesia again. Particularly for patients who are already seriously ill, the repercussions of anesthesia errors can become acute. Patients <a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26492481" target="_blank">under a year of age or older than 65</a> are at the greatest risk of serious complications or death. Other not insubstantial risks include:
<ul>
    <li>Damage to the circulatory system</li>
    <li>Damage to the nervous system</li>
    <li>Cardiovascular collapse</li>
    <li>Cardiac rhythm issues</li>
    <li>Asphyxia (lack of oxygen)</li>
    <li>Brain damage</li>
    <li>Spinal cord injuries, including possible paralysis</li>
    <li>Malignant hyperthermia</li>
    <li>Seizures</li>
    <li>Stroke</li>
    <li>Coma</li>
    <li>Death</li>
</ul>
The most <a href="http://anesthesiology.pubs.asahq.org/article.aspx?articleid=1933404" target="_blank">common</a> severe complications involve respiratory issues leading to asphyxia, brain damage, or death.

While anesthesia is safer than ever, there are still risks, particularly in the very young, the very old, or those with compromised health situations. If you or a loved one has been injured through an anesthesia error, please contact the experienced Kentucky and Ohio medical negligence lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law, who will meet with you to discuss your individual situation and help to get you the justice, treatment, and compensation you deserve. For a free consultation, call our Kentucky legal team at 877.651.7764, our Ohio legal team at 877.686.8879, or <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today.

&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Car Crashes Kill Kids, but Safety Seats Save Lives
BASENAME: car-crashes-kill-kids-safety-seats-save-lives
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/03/2017 02:07:35 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6064" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/child-safety-car-seat-300x200.jpg" alt="child safety car seat" width="300" height="200">Twenty percent of children who were involved in a car crash with a fatality were not buckled properly, or they were not wearing a seat belt. Forty-three percent of the children who died in traffic crashes were unrestrained, 15% were sitting in the front seat, and 9% were riding in a vehicle with a driver who was under the influence of alcohol: so says a study conducted by researchers from Brigham and Women&apos;s Hospital in Boston and University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas, and published in the Journal of Pediatrics. The study&apos;s primary data source was the Fatality Analysis Reporting System (FARS) of the National Highway Transportation Safety Administration (NHTSA).

There was a wide range of variability regarding the percentage of children involved in fatal crashes throughout the states. The study reports that the percentage of unrestrained or inappropriately restrained children varied from 2% in New Hampshire to 38% in Mississippi. In Kentucky, 16% of the child fatalities there was no restraint or inappropriate restraint use, 77% of deaths occurred in accidents on rural roadways and 12% the speed limit was between 65-50 mph.

In Ohio, 14% of the children who died in traffic crashes in the study were unrestrained or improperly restrained, 34% of the fatal crashes occurred on state highways and 9% of the vehicles were traveling between 65-80 mph.

<a href="http://www.iihs.org/iihs/topics/t/child-safety/fatalityfacts/child-safety" target="_blank">The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety</a> (IIHS) reports that all 50 states and the District of Columbia have child restraint laws, but despite more children being restrained, many still ride unrestrained. One of the goals of the study was to provide lawmakers with data to help improve safety regulations that effect children&apos;s safety.&#xA0; The over-arching message that the study shows with glaring clarity is that parents must be far more vigilant about making sure that their children are properly restrained when they are passengers in a motor vehicle. As the study reveals, an improperly restrained child is no safer than an unrestrained child when it comes to a fatal car crash.

According to the study, a mere 10% improvement in the use of appropriate child restraint in cars would decrease the national child fatality rate significantly, reducing it from 0.94 per 100,000 to 0.56 per 100,000. Study authors also hope that the results of their research will have some impact on the federal level regarding child safety regulations.

What can you do as a parent? Make sure that your children are properly restrained every time they get into the car. If you are not sure is your child&#x2019;s safety seat is installed properly, the <a href="https://www.safercar.gov/cpsApp/cps/index.htm" target="_blank">NHTSA</a> has a national child safety seat inspection station locater database on its website. Just enter your state or zip code and you can find a location near you.

If you or someone you care about has suffered a serious injury in a car crash, the team at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can help. Our Ohio car accident lawyers know how to figure out what happened, how to identify and prove fault for any type of accident. If you want help now, please call 877.686.8879 or <a href="/Contact.shtml">complete our contact form</a> to schedule an appointment.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: &#x201C;Internet of Things&#x201D; Raises Questions about Liability
BASENAME: internet-things-raises-questions-liability
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/14/2017 11:10:04 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6054" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/Distracted-Driving-300x200.jpg" alt="&#x201C;Internet of Things&#x201D; Raises Questions about Liability" width="300" height="200">How many times do you utilize the Internet each day? To answer that question, you might be thinking about each time you log on to complete your work, order a pizza, or check out your favorite social media site. But, you probably utilize the Internet far more often than you realize. Your home&#x2019;s security system, your GPS system, and even your fitness monitor use the Internet to provide the services you want and need. It is called the Internet of Things (IoT), and this state of the art technology is turning up in every corner of our lives.

As with all forward movement, these technical advances bring up questions about legal issues and liability for injuries related to these products. The tech website <a href="https://iot-for-all.com/iot-raises-new-challenges-assigning-liability/" target="_blank">IoTForAll.com </a>offers an example of this type of injury:

An individual is driving down the road in the rain, relying on a phone GPS app and electronic road signs to provide information about roadway conditions. The devices communicate that the street temperature is above freezing, even though the surface is frozen. The vehicle tires begin to spin out and the car veers off into a ditch, causing substantial injuries to the driver and the passenger. When the driver talks to an attorney, the question arises&#x2014;who should be held accountable?
<h2>Identifying liability for IoT injuries</h2>
Determining liability in an IoT case is a challenging task. In the scenario above, there may be numerous liable parties, including:
<ul>
    <li><strong>The creator of the driving app.</strong> If the driving app malfunctioned and provided incorrect information that the driver relied upon to his detriment, the company that created the app may be liable.</li>
    <li><strong>The company that manufactures and operates the sensors.</strong> If the signs and GPS app worked correctly but transmitted inaccurate information based on the malfunction of the sensors, the manufacturers and operators of the sensors may hold some responsibility for the injuries.</li>
    <li><strong>The road sign operator.&#xA0; </strong>Perhaps the road sign operator read the sensors incorrectly and programmed incorrect information into the signs. He and the company he works for may be liable.</li>
    <li><strong>The third-party that provided the software. </strong>Each of these devices likely relies on some type of software that is provided to them by a third-party company. If the software caused incorrect information to be communicated, the third-party company may be deemed responsible.</li>
</ul>
Each of these theories of liability could be plausible under this scenario, yet they do not include all of the possibilities. Even the telecom company that transmitted the data to your phone may have some liability for your injuries in a car crash.

Unfortunately, there are no concrete answers to these questions. Traditionally, product liability cases rely on the establishment of a relationship between an event and a resulting injury. IoT cases raise questions about causation and how transmission of information fits into the equation. There are even questions about whether IoT apps and software actually fall under the classification of products. Time will likely provide answers to these questions, as the courts take on an increasing number of IoT related matters.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier personal injury law firm serving clients throughout Ohio and Kentucky. If you sustained an injury after using a defective product, because of another person&#x2019;s negligence, or in a crash of any kind, we may be able to help. Please call our Ohio car crash lawyers at 877.686.8879, our Kentucky auto accident attorneys at 877.651.7764, or fill out our contact form to make an <a href="/Contact.shtml">appointment</a>.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Kentucky Truck Crashes Caused by Improperly Loaded Cargo
BASENAME: kentucky-truck-crashes-caused-improperly-loaded-cargo
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/10/2017 02:43:49 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6058" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/truck-accidents-300x206.jpg" alt="truck accidents" width="300" height="206">Large, commercial trucks are built to haul massive loads on busy highways. An important part of a truck driver&apos;s job is to make sure that the truck he or she is driving has a load that is the correct weight and properly secured before they hit the road. Truck crashes caused by unsecured cargo can be deadly for the truck driver and the other motorists with whom they share the road. <a href="https://www.fmcsa.dot.gov/regulations/cargo-securement/cargo-securement-rules" target="_blank">The Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration</a> (FMCSA), is the federal agency that is part of the U.S. Department of Transportation that governs commercial vehicle safety. The FMCSA has Cargo Securement Rules. The purpose of the cargo securement rules is to reduce the number of traffic crashes caused by cargo shifting within or falling from commercial vehicles.

If a truck driver is responsible for causing an accident caused by improperly loaded cargo, unsecured cargo, or an overloaded truck, the driver and their employer may be liable for the injuries and property damage.
<h2>Unsecured cargo can create road debris</h2>
One of the hazards created by unsecured cargo is road debris. If you are driving a passenger vehicle and you end up in a collision with road debris that fell from a truck, you may be able to take legal action and recover compensation from the truck driver, the owner of the truck or trucking company, the shipper and any other responsible party.

A study released last summer by the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety reported that more than 200,000 crashes involved road debris on U.S. roadways in the past four years. Road debris caused approximately 39,000 injuries and more than 500 deaths between 2011 and 2014. Jurek Grabowski, research director for the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety said of the study, &#x201C;This new report shows that road debris can be extremely dangerous but these crashes are preventable.&#xA0; Drivers can easily save lives and prevent injuries by securing their loads and taking other simple precautions to prevent items from falling off the vehicle.&#x201D;

Cargo that is not properly loaded or secured can easily shift in transit, which can make the truck become unbalanced leading to a greater tip over hazard or danger of jack knife.

Anyone who has suffered a serious injury from an accident with a tractor trailer with an unsecured load or improperly loaded cargo may benefit from having a conversation with an experienced Kentucky truck accident attorney who can offer legal guidance about the merits of your case.

Truck crashes can be complicated to investigate, but when you have been injured in a truck accident you need an experienced Kentucky truck accident attorney to find out who is at fault and who can be held liable for your injuries. The lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law are here to help you recover the compensation you need to get back to your life after your accident. For help with any truck accident case, please phone Crandall &amp; Pera Law&#x2019;s Kentucky office at 877.651.7764, our Ohio office at 877.686.8879, or <a href="/Contact.shtml">fill out our contact form</a> to schedule an appointment.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Failure to Diagnose a Blood Clot Leads to an Amputation
BASENAME: failure-diagnose-blood-clot-leads-amputation
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/06/2017 02:28:35 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6060" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/amputation-300x214.jpg" alt="amputation blood clot" width="300" height="214">When she was just 18-years-old, Ms. Schneider saw Dr. Huribal for pain in her left leg, but the doctor failed to diagnose the blood clot that was causing the pain. When the pain grew worse, Schneider went to Griffin Hospital, where she was also sent home because the doctors there <em>also</em> failed to diagnose the blood clot. Her condition deteriorated quickly and she was rushed to the hospital, where doctors concluded that nothing could be done to save the leg, so it had to be amputated.

Ms. Schneider filed a lawsuit against Dr. Huribal and the Southern Connecticut Vascular Center for medical negligence. A CT Superior Court jury awarded her $25 million. Schneider had already settled with Griffin hospital for an undisclosed amount according to a story in the <a href="http://www.ctpost.com/local/article/Trumbull-doctor-ordered-to-pay-25-million-for-9972397.php" target="_blank"><em>CT Post</em></a>.
<h2>Diagnostic errors and medical malpractice</h2>
While there have been efforts within the health care community to improve patient safety, diagnostic errors have not received the same amount of attention and focus despite how common they are. A Harvard Medical Practice Study reported that diagnostic error accounted for 17% of preventable medical errors, and a systematic review of autopsies covering four decades reveals that about 9% of patients had experienced a major diagnostic error that went undetected while the patient was alive. (<a href="https://psnet.ahrq.gov/primers/primer/12/diagnostic-errors" target="_blank">Patient Safety Network</a> of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality AHRQ).
<h2>Proving medical malpractice</h2>
In Ms. Schneider&#x2019;s case, the diagnostic error was clear. Two physicians who examined her missed the blood clot resulting in the amputation of her leg, but it was not difficult to draw a line of causation between the doctor&#x2019;s failure to diagnose the blood clot and the injury. That is not always the case for others.

To prove medical negligence, the plaintiff must have evidence that proves first that a doctor-patient relationship existed, and that the doctor&#x2019;s actions or failure to act was a breach of the accepted standard of care for that specialty. The plaintiff must then be able to show how the breach caused the injury, and the damages resulting from the injury. A medical expert investigates the incident and provides testimony on how the doctor&#x2019;s actions were negligent.

Ms. Schneider would probably be happy to give back the millions of dollars she will receive because of her doctor&#x2019;s negligence to have her own leg back. Taking legal action against those who caused your injury hopefully inspires a change that ensures that the same mistake is never repeated.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier medical malpractice law firm serving clients throughout Ohio and Kentucky. If your medical malpractice was the cause of your injury, you are encouraged to call our medical malpractice attorneys at 877-686-8879 in Ohio and 877-686-8879 in Kentucky. You may also schedule a free consultation through our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>. We take cases on a contingency fee basis.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: The Federal Government Got It Wrong &#x2013; But the States Are Getting It Right
BASENAME: federal-government-got-wrong-states-getting-right
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/20/2017 02:46:25 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6049" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/Lawsuit-300x200.jpg" alt="lawsuit" width="300" height="200">At the end of June 2017, the U.S. House of Representatives passed HR 1215, the Bill which limits your right to a fair trial by a jury of your peers, and limits the amount of recovery a medical malpractice victim may be awarded. Now, that Bill will move onto the Senate, which will likely vote on it after the recess.

The federal government got this wrong &#x2013; very wrong. Instead of looking to protect victims, they instead voted to enact a law based off of the myth that tort reform is good for the American people. It&#x2019;s not. It never will be. All tort reform does is harm innocent victims even more.

The Bill passed only a couple of weeks after Florida ruled that damage caps were unconstitutional &#x2013; a decision that rallied us. And though the passing of HR 1215 is a blow, we are cautiously optimistic about the fate of tort reform, because a Wisconsin appellate court has just ruled that the state&#x2019;s damage caps are unconstitutional, too.
<h2>A horrific case of medical negligence</h2>
The case involved one of the most egregious acts of medical negligence we have ever heard of. In 2011, a mother of four developed a Strep A infection. The strep was undiagnosed by doctors, and eventually led to septic shock. As a result, all four of the woman&#x2019;s limbs were amputated. A Wisconsin jury awarded her $25.3 million dollars &#x2013; $8.8 million which went to economic damages, like lost wages and medical expenses. Wisconsin, however, caps all non-economic damages at $750,000, and the decision ended up being appealed.

The <a href="http://www.jsonline.com/story/news/investigations/2017/07/05/wisconsins-cap-medical-malpractice-awards-unconstitutional-courts-rules/451418001/" target="_blank">Journal-Sentinel reports</a> that Judge Joan Kessler wrote this in the unanimous opinion:

&quot;We conclude that the statutory cap on non-economic damages is unconstitutional on its face.... Wisconsin&apos;s cap on non-economic medical malpractice damages <em>always</em> reduces non-economic damages <em>only</em> for the class of the most severely injured victims who have been awarded damages exceeding the cap, yet always allows full damages to the less severely injured malpractice victims.&quot;

Wisconsin&#x2019;s damage caps are 3x the amount that a person might be expected to receive under the Protecting Access to Care Act of 2017, and the appellate court still knew that limiting this patient&#x2019;s damages to $750,000 was the wrong idea. There is every reason to believe the case will go to the state&#x2019;s Supreme Court. We can only hope that they, too, will side with the patient.

What this woman and her family has suffered is unconscionable, but under HR 1215, this type of medical malpractice will be treated just the same as any other. If that meant that doctors and healthcare professionals would finally be held accountable for their actions, we could at least understand <em>why</em> someone might believe in the myth of tort reform.

But that won&#x2019;t happen. Instead, families will continue to be hurt under an unjust law based on a lie. That is we why urge you to <a href="https://www.senate.gov/senators/contact/" target="_blank">contact your Senators</a> and ask them not to pass this dangerous Bill into law.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we promise that we will keep fighting for our clients, their families, and for justice. To learn more about our services, please call our Kentucky medical malpractice lawyers at&#xA0;877.651.7764,&#xA0;our Ohio medical negligence attorneys at 877.686.8879, or fill out our&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>.

<strong>Read more about tort reform and HR 1215:</strong>
<ul>
    <li>THE ABA STANDS WITH PATIENTS: HR 1215 IS DANGEROUS</li>
    <li>H.R. 1215: CONGRESSIONAL TORT REFORM DESIGNED TO DESTROY YOUR RIGHTS</li>
    <li>NEW BILL WOULD REMOVE EFFECTIVE CHECKS ON MEDICAL MALPRACTICE</li>
    <li>STATE AND FEDERAL EFFORTS TO LIMIT DAMAGES IN MEDICAL MALPRACTICE CASES</li>
    <li>TORT REFORM IN OHIO: GOOD FOR RAPISTS, BAD FOR VICTIMS</li>
</ul>
<strong>From the Patients&#x2019; Rights Blog:</strong>
<ul>
    <li><a href="https://www.patientsrightsblog.com/h-r-1215-aims-stifle-victims-rights-medical-malpractice-cases/" target="_blank">H.R. 1215 Aims to Stifle Victim&#x2019;s Rights in Medical Malpractice Cases</a></li>
    <li><a href="https://www.patientsrightsblog.com/tort-reform-damage-caps-protect-hospitals-not-patients/" target="_blank">Tort Reform and Damage Caps Protect Hospitals, Not Patients</a></li>
</ul>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Avon, Ohio Child with Seizure Disorder Meets April the Giraffe
BASENAME: avon-ohio-child-seizure-disorder-meets-april-giraffe
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/17/2017 02:23:35 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6052" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/Brain-Damage-Delivery-300x200.jpg" alt="birth injuries" width="300" height="200">Alex Johnson is 11 years old, and he loves April the giraffe. Like more than a million others, he watched Animal Adventure Park&#x2019;s giraffe cam. He watched April give birth to her daughter, Tajiri &#x2013; so excited that the little calf was finally here. So, when the Make-A-Wish Foundation asked what he wanted to do, Alex chose to go to Harpursville, New York in order to meet April and her family.

It&#x2019;s a really heart-warming story, but a bittersweet one, too: after all, Make-A-Wish makes dreams come true for children with life-threatening illnesses, and that is what Alex has. During Alex&#x2019;s birth, there we complications stemming from oxygen deprivation. As a result, he suffers from epilepsy, visual impairment, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and the effects of a brain injury. He is completely nonverbal, communicating through head nods and by shaking his arm.

<a href="http://www.wday.com/news/4280014-ohio-boy-seizure-disorder-gets-wish-meet-april-giraffe-calf-she-birthed-live-stream" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WDAY 6 reports</a> that &#x201C;Make-A-Wish Central New York gave Alex stuffed giraffes before his visit and [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][Alex&#x2019;s mother said they] &#x2018;treated him like a king.&#x2019;&#x201D;
<h2>Oxygen deprivation can lead to life-threatening injuries and conditions</h2>
All birth injuries are serious; newborns are incredibly vulnerable, and what might be a minor injury to a child could have life-long effects on a baby. Oxygen deprivation, either pre-term or during the labor process, affects up to 4 million babies each year. About a quarter of those children will die as a result. Others may develop conditions like <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/injuries/hypoxic-ischemic-encephalopathy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy</a>, or HIE,&#xA0;which can lead to permanent brain damage. It may also lead to seizure disorders, developmental delays, cerebral palsy, or any number of life-threatening conditions.
<h2>Common causes of lack of oxygen during birth</h2>
So what leads to a baby being deprived of oxygen at birth? Some of the most common causes include:
<ul>
    <li>Undiagnosed preeclampsia</li>
    <li>Undiagnosed or untreated infections</li>
    <li>Physical trauma</li>
    <li>Shoulder dystocia</li>
    <li>Excessive use of labor drugs like Pitocin</li>
    <li>Placental abruption</li>
    <li>Prolapsed nuchal cords</li>
    <li>Delayed C-sections</li>
    <li>Failure to monitor the mother and child during pregnancy</li>
</ul>
Not all birth injuries are a result of medical negligence, but proper pre-partum and delivery care can reduce the chances of a child sustaining life-threatening oxygen deprivation. If you ever feel like your child is not responding or acting the way he or she normally does, trust your gut and seek medical attention as quickly as you can. It is better to be safe.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier medical malpractice law firm. Our Ohio birth injury attorneys help families whose lives have been changed by an act of medical negligence. To learn more, please call 877.686.8879, or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>. We also maintain offices throughout Kentucky: 877.651.7764.
<h3>Related Articles</h3>
<ul>
    <li>What is the Difference Between a Birth Injury and a Birth Defect?</li>
    <li>Fracking May Lead to Lower Birth Weights for Babies Born Nearby</li>
    <li>Keeping Your Baby Safe by Eating Better During Pregnancy</li>
    <li>When Are Medical Professionals Liable for Inadequate Prenatal Care?</li>
    <li>Birth Injuries: Avoidable Risks with Potentially Lifelong Complications</li>
    <li>Dedicated Louisville Birth Injury Attorneys Seek Justice for Families</li>
</ul>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Your Heartburn Medication Could Be Deadly, But No One Quite Knows Why
BASENAME: heartburn-medication-deadly-no-one-quite-knows
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/24/2017 01:36:40 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6046" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/heartburn-medication-300x287.jpg" alt="heartburn medication" width="300" height="287">Our firm has always handled defective and dangerous drug litigation, so we pay close attention to studies and reports that are published in reputable news sources and in medical journals. Much of the news lately has been focused on the dangers associated with opioid painkillers, and fentanyl in particular, but a recent piece in the <em>New York Times</em> looked at a study involving heartburn medication.

Specifically, the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/05/well/live/heartburn-drugs-may-increase-risk-of-early-death.html?rref=collection%2Fsectioncollection%2Fhealth&amp;_r=0" target="_blank">article summarized</a> a study which &#x201C;compared people who used P.P.I.s [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][proton pump inhibitors] with those who used H2 receptor antagonists&#x201D; for relief of heartburn and acid reflux. Based on the research, patients who take PPI-based medications, like Nexium, Prilosec and Prevacid, were at a greater risk of death than those who took H2 receptor drugs, like Zantac or Pepcid.
<h2>Understanding the study</h2>
Researchers from the Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis looked at <a href="http://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/7/6/e015735" target="_blank">case histories</a> of almost 350,000 people listed in the VA healthcare system. Of those cases, 275,933 people used PPIs, and 73,355 used H2 blockers, all between 2006 and 2008. The team then looked at the number of deaths over the next few years (a median of 5.71, per the study), and discovered that PPI users had a 25% increased chance of dying over patients who used H2 blockers. The risk increased for users depending on how long they took the medication.
<h2>What is causing this increase?</h2>
The truth is, no one is quite sure. It could be the way a body metabolizes vitamins and minerals, or it could be related to the bacteria in our stomachs. As Dr. Folasade P. May explained to <a href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/heartburn-drugs-proton-pump-inhibitors-ppi-risks-prilosec-nexium-prevacid/" target="_blank">CBS News</a>, &quot;If the group taking PPIs was dying more often, what were they dying of?... Are they dying of heart disease, losing weight, or dying from a mix of medical problems? The PPI group was older and sicker. I would argue if you follow an older, sicker population, then they&apos;re likely to have more deaths anyway.&#x201D;

The research team stressed that this correlation, <em>not</em> causation: in other words, they will not say that PPI drugs are the definitive reason behind people dying &#x2013; merely that users die more often than non-users.
<h2>Should I be worried about my heartburn medication?</h2>
Not necessarily. If you are prescribed a PPI medication for a serious condition, like a bleeding ulcer, then you should not stop taking the drugs without first consulting your doctor. If you are a regular user of OTC medications with PPIs, you should seek medical advice, anyway; your heartburn or reflux could indicate a more serious condition.

However, you should be aware that PPIs do have a list of potentially serious side effects associated with them. These risks include an increased chance of:
<ul>
    <li>Stroke</li>
    <li>Kidney disease</li>
    <li>Susceptibility to infections like C. diff and pneumonia</li>
    <li>Bone fractures</li>
    <li>Dementia</li>
</ul>
If you regularly take a medication with the proton pump inhibitor, speak with your doctor about your options. If you or a loved one takes a PPI, but you were not told of the potential side effects, speak with a defective drug attorney right away.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier medical malpractice law firm serving clients throughout Ohio and Kentucky. To speak with an experienced dangerous drug lawyer about your case, please fill out this <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to request a consultation. You can also call out Ohio team at 877.686.8879, or our Kentucky team at 877.651.7764.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Event Data Recorders in Trucks and Cars Can Prove How a Collision Really Happened
BASENAME: event-data-recorders-trucks-cars-can-prove-collision-really-happened
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 07/28/2017 12:17:17 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6042" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/Event-loggers-300x169.jpg" alt="event data recorders and accidents" width="300" height="169">Let&#x2019;s say you are stopped at an intersection on a quiet back road. You take a glance to each side, and proceed to make a left-hand turn. The next thing you know, your airbag has deployed, your arms are scratched up and your car is sitting on the side of the road, facing the opposite direction. The cops ask you what happened, and you cannot remember &#x2013; but another person at the scene claims you made a left while he was going through the intersection, and that you caused the accident.

In a scenario like this, where perhaps the evidence cannot definitely point to which driver was liable for the crash, the insurance company, an accident reconstructionist or your injury attorney may ask to see the data from the Event Data Recorder, or EDR, in your vehicle. An EDR (also called a &#x201C;black box&#x201D;) is a piece of tech installed in many cars which is activated by your supplemental restraint controllers &#x2013; the controllers which activate your seatbelt or airbags. The EDR can record the engine speed, the vehicle speed, the position of the throttle, the seatbelt engagement switch: it all depends on the make and model of your car. Some vehicles save 5 seconds&#x2019; worth of data; others might store 25 seconds&#x2019; worth. This data can help us determine whether you cut off the other vehicle, or if the driver was speeding, and then attempted to hit the brakes to avoid a collision.

For commercial trucks, the tech is a bit different. Most semis don&#x2019;t come equipped with airbags, but because of the strict regulations on their emissions, &#x201C;all modern truck engines use an electronic engine control module (ECM) that monitors engine and vehicle operating parameters. The primary function of the ECM is to control the engine, but it can also serve the secondary function of recording engine and vehicle information.&#x201D;
<h2>Making a case for another driver&#x2019;s liability after a crash</h2>
The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has advocated the use of EDRs since 1997, <a href="https://www.nhtsa.gov/research-data/event-data-recorder" target="_blank">claiming</a> &#x201C;EDRs could provide information that is very valuable to understanding crashes, and which can be used in a variety of ways to improve motor vehicle safety.&#x201D; And this is true &#x2013;but all technology is subject to glitches or malfunctions, and not all recorders will capture data in all circumstances.

Because of this, it is critical that an EDR not be the only piece of evidence your attorney uses. Eye witness accounts, the condition of the roads, videos or photos pulled form traffic cameras and medical reports are all important pieces of evidence, and your attorney will use all of them (when applicable) in conjunction with the EDR&#x2019;s information to build a case for another driver&#x2019;s liability.

Dealing with the after effects of a serious car crash can be challenging; finding the right injury lawyer to represent your needs shouldn&#x2019;t be. Crandall &amp; Pera Law provides comprehensive representation on behalf of car accident victims throughout Kentucky and Ohio. To speak with a member of our Kentucky team, please call 877.651.7764; in Ohio, please call 877.686.8879. You can also fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to request a consultation.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: A Recent Tragedy Highlights the Importance of Informing New Parents About Infants and Immunity
BASENAME: recent-tragedy-highlights-importance-informing-new-parents-infants-immunity
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 08/07/2017 02:51:03 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6040" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Infants-and-Immunity-300x200.jpg" alt="infants and immunity" width="300" height="200">Finding out that you&#x2019;re going to be a parent is simultaneously one of the most exciting and one of the scariest moments in your life. The realization that you will soon be required to care for a tiny human is daunting, to say the least. A thousand questions follow, and though 9 months may seem like a long time, it goes by in a flash that ends with a million more questions. Throughout that time, first-time parents are bombarded with information from every side about prenatal care, the process of childbirth, and postnatal follow-up.
<h2>How important information gets lost</h2>
During the blitzkrieg of information that follows a positive pregnancy test, parents-to-be don&#x2019;t have the luxury of research time. Instead, they struggle to adapt to the idea that new routines and priorities have entered their lives. Mostly, it&#x2019;s a desperate, headlong rush to stay on top of mundane details while preparing for a whole new life.

From <a href="http://abc13.com/health/newborn-dies-after-developing-meningitis-from-herpes-virus/2230599/" target="_blank">ABC 13</a>:

&#x201C;Nicole and Shane Sifrit welcomed baby Mariana on July 1. A week later -- two hours after the couple&apos;s wedding -- they say they noticed that the girl was not eating and would not wake up when they tried to get her to respond. &#x2018;It&apos;s horrific,&#x2019; Nicole Sifrit said. &#x2018;She had quit breathing, and all her organs just started to fail.&#x2019; The couple left their wedding early to take Mariana to Blank Children&apos;s Hospital in Des Moines, where they learned that she had contracted meningitis HSV-1, caused by the herpes virus -- the same virus that causes cold sores.&#x201D;

Exactly how Mariana contracted HSV-1 will likely remain a mystery. Both of her parents tested negative for the virus, though Johns Hopkins Medicine suggests that the infection point could have been a well-wishing visitor. According to the <a href="http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs400/en/" target="_blank">World Health Organization</a>, approximately 67% of the global population carries the virus, which is mostly harmless in those with fully developed immune systems. Most people aren&#x2019;t even aware that they are carriers.

Unfortunately, newborns are highly susceptible to infection; they are born without a functioning immune system. Whatever protection they are afforded comes from their mother through placental transfer and breast milk; breastfed babies get sick far less often than their bottle-fed counterparts. However, no amount of passive immunity can prevent a point infection from developing into a full-blown illness. Babies simply lack the ability to fight systemic infections until they are around 5 months of age.
<h2>A failure to communicate</h2>
Healthcare professionals are aware of this fact and do their best to inform new parents of the risks of exposing their children to visitors and situations that can pose health risks. However, new parents are dealing with a million details when a baby arrives; despite these efforts, the messages don&#x2019;t always stick.

The Sifrit&#x2019;s have experienced an unbelievable tragedy, and our thoughts and prayers are with the young family. Despite her terrible loss, Nicole Sifrit hopes that other new parents can learn from her loss, imploring new parents to, &#x201C;Keep your babies isolated. Don&#x2019;t let just anyone visit them. Make sure they are constantly washing their hands. Don&#x2019;t let people kiss your baby. And make sure they ask before they pick up your baby.&#x201D;

All patients have rights, including newborns. Hospitals and other healthcare facilities work diligently to ensure a safe and protected environment for their patients, but sometimes, even the best efforts aren&#x2019;t enough to prevent a tragedy. At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we fight for those who can&#x2019;t fight for themselves to help families recover after a medical mistake. For a free consultation, call our Kentucky legal team at 877.651.7764, our Ohio legal team at 877.686.8879, or <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: It&#x2019;s Official: Football Leads to CTE
BASENAME: official-football-leads-cte
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 08/11/2017 11:24:47 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6038" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Football-and-CTE-300x161.jpg" alt="football and cte" width="300" height="161">Chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or CTE, is a degenerative brain disease linked to contact sports and brain trauma. For several years, the focus has been on professional football players, with a back-and-forth, does-it-or-doesn&#x2019;t-it approach to whether or not playing in the NFL will increase a person&#x2019;s chance of developing the disease.

Researchers from the Boston University School of Medicine and the VA Boston Healthcare System have finally laid that question to rest. Their findings were published in the <a href="http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2645104" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>Journal of the American Medical Association</em>:</a> &#x201C;In a convenience sample of 202 deceased players of American football from a brain donation program, CTE was neuropathologically diagnosed in 177 players across all levels of play (87%), <strong>including 110 of 111 former National Football League players </strong>(99%)&#x201D; (emphasis ours).

In the interest of full transparency, researcher Dr. Ann McKee admits that there is &#x201C;selection bias&#x201D; in the samples used, because &#x201C;many families [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][of former NFL players] have donated brains specifically because the former player showed symptoms of C.T.E,&#x201D; per the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/07/25/sports/football/nfl-cte.html?rref=collection%2Fsectioncollection%2Fhealth&amp;action=click&amp;contentCollection=health&amp;region=stream&amp;module=stream_unit&amp;version=latest&amp;contentPlacement=6&amp;pgtype=sectionfront&amp;_r=0" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>New York Times</em></a>. Still, based on the number of players who have died since the BU researchers started studying CTE (1300), even if only these 110 players were diagnosed with the condition, &#x201C;the minimum C.T.E. prevalence would be close to 9 percent, vastly higher than in the general population.&#x201D;

<strong>Read more:</strong>
<ul>
    <li>Ohio CTE Injury</li>
    <li>It&#x2019;s Official: Football Leads to CTE</li>
    <li>Dear Parents: Please Keep Your Children Away from Football</li>
    <li>Top NFL Exec Finally Acknowledges Link between Football and CTE</li>
    <li>An Open letter to Parents of High School Football Players</li>
    <li><a href="https://www.patientsrightsblog.com/this-is-your-brain-on-sports/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">This Is Your Brain on Sports</a></li>
    <li>Friday Night Lights Out: The Truth about Football and Long Term Brain Damage</li>
    <li>Should There Be a Legal Age Limit for Playing Football?</li>
    <li>College Football Players Diagnosed with CTE Confirms Warnings from Concussion Legacy Foundation</li>
    <li>First Extreme Sport Athlete Diagnosed with Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy</li>
    <li><a href="https://www.patientsrightsblog.com/despite-controversy-over-cte-progress-is-made/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Despite Controversy Over CTE, Progress Is Made</a></li>
    <li>CTE Research Is Incredible, but Prevention Is the Only Sure Cure</li>
</ul>
<h2>Looking at the numbers</h2>
There were 202 brains, and the median age* of the deceased player was about 66 years old. The average amount of years played was between 13 (for mild CTE) and 16 (for severe CTE).

What the study found was players who were diagnosed with mild CTW pathology were considerably younger (media age 44) than those diagnosed with severe CTE pathology (median age 71). Suicide was the leading cause of death for those with mild pathology; neurodegenerative conditions, like dementia and Parkinson&#x2019;s, was the leading cause of death for those with severe pathology.

The study also divided the groups into levels of play:
<ul>
    <li>111 played in the NFL / 110 diagnosed</li>
    <li>8 played in the Canadian Football League &#x2013; 7 diagnosed</li>
    <li>14 played semi-professionally / 9 diagnosed</li>
    <li>53 played in college / 48 diagnosed</li>
    <li>14 played in high school / 3 diagnosed</li>
    <li>2 played pre-high school / 0 diagnosed</li>
</ul>
The good news is that the numbers are significantly lower for players at the high school (and, obviously, pre-high school) level. The bad news is that the diagnoses <em>exists</em> for three players who only played up through high school. And while the sample size for those players is small, just over 20% of the donated brains of high-school players showed signs of CTE.

Twenty percent. A fifth of the brains. Just from playing in high school.

This latest study is important, but unsurprising; after all, we&#x2019;ve been making this case for the last two years. As injury attorneys, we see first-hand how a permanent brain injury can turn a family&#x2019;s world upside down. We know that CTE is progressive, which means it will get worse and worse for the victim. We know there is no cure: once you have the disease, it is with you until you die.

Choose the future. Choose your children. Choose life.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier personal injury and medical malpractice law firm serving clients throughout Ohio and Kentucky. Please call our Ohio team at&#xA0;877.686.8879, our Kentucky team at&#xA0;877.651.7764, or fill out this <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to learn more about our services.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Ohio State Fair Tragedy Reveals a Disturbing Trend
BASENAME: ohio-state-fair-tragedy-reveals-disturbing-trend
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 08/15/2017 01:32:21 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6036" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Roller-coaster-injuries-300x296.jpg" alt="Ohio State Fair Accident" width="300" height="296">The story of the Ohio State Fair&#x2019;s ride malfunction that left several injured and one man dead has made headlines across the country. The ride, called the Fire Ball, swings riders 40 feet in the air while spinning them at 13 revolutions per second. On July 27, the thrill ride ended in tragedy when an unknown malfunction caused sections of the ride to come apart and threw riders great distances at high speeds. The ride had been inspected only hours earlier, prompting the manufacturer to sent notices to operators to suspend use until further notice.
<h2>How many people are injured or killed each year by rides?</h2>
This disaster is not an isolated incident. From <a href="http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/number-accidents-due-amusement-park-rides-might-be-higher-you-n787286" target="_blank">NBC News</a>: &#x201C;The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission estimated that 30,900 injuries caused by amusement park attractions were seen by hospital emergency departments in 2016 alone. Those injured are out of millions of people who visit carnivals, fairs and festivals each year, the Outdoor Amusement Business Association, which represents much of the mobile amusement industry, estimates. Since 2010, the CPSC reports that there have been 22 fatalities caused by thrill rides, including Wednesday&#x2019;s death in Ohio.&#x201D;

Just last year, three young girls fell nearly 40 feet when a Ferris wheel cabin tipped over at the Greene County Fair in Tennessee. Worn rivets on the ride failed and allowed a part of the ride to become lodged in the frame, a problem that earlier inspections failed to reveal. One of the girls, just 6 years old, suffered a traumatic brain injury and spent nearly two months on life support following the incident. Her family continues to suffer the consequences of her injuries.

While these are the most recent tragedies, they are by no means the only ones with fatal consequences:
<ul>
    <li>In July 2015, 18-year-old Gregory Horan died at Ijams Nature Park in Tennessee during a rope course adventure when he fell and his harness malfunctioned, asphyxiating him.</li>
    <li>In January 2015, a 15-year-old Boy Scout died after sustaining a head injury during a zip line ride in Arizona.</li>
    <li>In October 2013, five members of the same family were exiting a ride at the North Carolina State Fair when it began to move. One family member sustained brain and spinal cord injuries.</li>
    <li>In June of 2007, a then 13-year-old girl had her feet severed after a cable broke on the Superman Tower of Power ride, at Six Flags Kentucky Kingdom. Doctors were only able to reattach one of her feet, leaving her permanently disabled.</li>
</ul>
<h2>When fun becomes dangerous</h2>
Amusement park rides are designed to thrill us by offering a taste of danger; adrenaline junkies seek the tallest coasters, the longest drops, and the tightest loops. Ride designers and manufacturers walk a tightrope between danger and safety; the biggest thrills also present the biggest risks. Inspection procedures are designed to prevent tragedy, and scheduled maintenance should replace parts before they are in danger of failing, not after. Despite these efforts, incidents like the Ohio State Fair tragedy still happen.

When multiple inspections and best practices aren&#x2019;t enough to prevent a tragedy, determining fault requires moving up the line. At some point from inception to design to engineering to manufacturing, a mistake caused an accident that ended a young man&#x2019;s life and left a family grieving an untimely loss.

The Kentucky and Ohio personal injury attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law fight for families who have been affected by an injury or death resulting from negligence. If your loved one was injured or killed because of someone else&#x2019;s negligence, you may be entitled to compensation for lost wages, medical bills or other expenses. For a free consultation, call our Kentucky legal team at 877.651.7764, our Ohio legal team at 877.686.8879, or <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today.
