AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Elderly Truck Drivers Linked to Increase in Truck Accidents
BASENAME: elderly-truck-drivers-linked-increase-truck-accidents
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 08/24/2017 01:41:21 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6029" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Truck-Drivers-300x199.jpg" alt="Older Truck Drivers Dangerous" width="300" height="199">In response to the shortage of truck drivers in the U.S., trucking companies have turned to recruiting retired men and women to fill those job. In a study conducted last year by <a href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/trucking-semi-industry-recruiting-retirees-commercial-drivers-accidents/" target="_blank">CBS News</a>, between 2013 and 2015, there were more than 6,636 trucking accidents involving older drivers, and that there was a 19% increase in accidents involving both commercial truck drivers and bus drivers who were age 70 and older. As the trucking companies recruit these older drivers, might they be contributing to potentially higher numbers of traffic crashes on the highways?

The CBS article highlighted these stories of truck crashes caused by older truck drivers:
<ul>
    <li>A driver who was 76 years old who rolled over the top of three cars killing ten people in Oklahoma in 2009.</li>
    <li>In Newark, NJ, a bus was T-boned by another bus driven by a 70-year-old driver. Two people were killed in August 2016.</li>
    <li>A truck hauling stones driven by a 74-year-old driver slammed into traffic in a construction zone injuring ten people in Binghamton, New York in August 2016.</li>
</ul>
This is a sensitive issue in many ways because there are federal laws against age discrimination in employment. So, it would be illegal for trucking companies to place an arbitrary age limit on truck drivers. Also, given that everyone is different, not every driver over age 65 is going to automatically be an unsafe driver simply because they are over age 65. Given that as people age, reaction time and stamina can decrease, the National Highway Transportation Safety Administration considered requiring skills test for older drivers of commercial vehicles, but those plans were scrapped because there was a shortage of drivers and because of age discrimination laws.

While it is not fair to say that just because a driver is older they are going to be a hazard behind the wheel, one of the challenges with older drivers is that they tend to have more disqualifying medical conditions. Another <a href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/how-medically-unfit-commercial-drivers-end-up-behind-the-wheel-greyhound-bus-crash/" target="_blank">CBS News</a> story revealed that commercial truck drivers can hide underlying medical conditions that could disqualify them from working. Often, with age comes an increase in those medically disqualifying medical conditions.

Right now, in the United States if you can pass the medical screening test, you can become a truck driver regardless of your age. The airline industry is also facing a shortage of pilots, but they require pilots to retire at age 65.

Any kind of age discrimination in employment is against the law, but if the <a href="https://www.fmcsa.dot.gov/faq/what-medical-conditions-disqualify-commercial-bus-or-truck-driver" target="_blank">Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration</a> (FMCSA) strengthened and enforced its regulations about training and health qualifications for all drivers on a regular basis, they would not be discriminating against older drivers. Ask the family members of those ten people who were killed on an Oklahoma highway on the way to a family celebration if it might be time to address the issue of making sure that every truck driver regardless of age is indeed in healthy enough condition to drive safely.

The lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law are here to help you recover the compensation you need to get back to your life after your injuries from a truck accident. For help with any questions regarding a truck accident case, please phone Crandall &amp; Pera Law&#x2019;s Kentucky office at 877.651.7764, our Ohio office at 877.686.8879, or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to schedule an appointment.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: 5 Examples of Catastrophic Injuries
BASENAME: 5-examples-catastrophic-injuries
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 08/22/2017 01:09:05 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6031" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Brain-Injury-300x240.jpg" alt="catastrophic injury" width="300" height="240">Surviving an accident can leave you with anything from minor cuts and scrapes, to a catastrophic injury from which you never fully recover. Whether you were involved in a truck accident, you suffered devastating burns in a fire or explosion, or you suffered a head injury from a fall, catastrophic injuries are serious and require life-long medical care and often nursing care just to get through the day.
<h2>What are catastrophic injuries?</h2>
A catastrophic injury is a severe injury to the spine, spinal cord, or brain, and may also include skull or spinal fractures. This is a subset of the definition for the legal term catastrophic injury, which is based on the definition used by the <a href="https://www.ama-assn.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">American Medical Association</a>.
<h2>What are some of the common causes of catastrophic injury?</h2>
There are countless possible causes of catastrophic injury. Here are a few examples:
<ul>
    <li>Car accidents</li>
    <li>Workplace accidents</li>
    <li>Truck accidents</li>
    <li>Bicycle accidents</li>
    <li>Falls from height</li>
    <li>Sport and recreational activities</li>
    <li>Construction accidents</li>
    <li>Medical mistakes</li>
    <li>Defective medical devices or drugs</li>
</ul>
<h2>Examples of catastrophic injuries</h2>
Here are some examples of different types of catastrophic injuries caused by the negligence, carelessness or recklessness of another individual:
<ol>
    <li><strong>Traumatic brain injury</strong> can result in life-long cognitive dysfunction, abnormal speech and language, emotional difficulties, and limited ability to move their arms and legs.</li>
    <li><strong>Spinal cord injury</strong> can result in partial or complete paralysis, respiratory and circulatory problems, exaggerated reflexes and spasms, chronic pain, loss of bowel and bladder control.</li>
    <li><strong>Severe burn injury</strong> can cause infections, limb loss, disfigurement, and permanent disability depending on the location and extent of the burns.</li>
    <li><strong>Limb loss</strong> in an accident can cause tremendous physical and emotional challenges for the amputee and his or her loved ones.</li>
    <li><strong>Ruptured kidneys, spleen, liver or bowels</strong> from a car crash or other accident can cause internal bleeding, which can be life-threatening.</li>
</ol>
<h2>Lifelong costs associated with a catastrophic injury</h2>
If you sustain an injury which requires ongoing medical attention and long periods of hospitalization, you will be unable to work and in some cases unable to care for your own daily needs. The medical expenses, the cost of daily nursing care and other related expenses can ruin a person financially. Some of those costs include:
<ul>
    <li>Emergency medical expenses</li>
    <li>Continuing medical care</li>
    <li>Visiting nursing care</li>
    <li>Medications</li>
    <li>Physical and occupational therapy</li>
    <li>Counseling</li>
    <li>Medical equipment such as a hospital bed at home, wheel chairs, a lift</li>
    <li>Costs to retro-fit a home to accommodate a wheelchair</li>
    <li>Lost wages</li>
    <li>Diminished earning capacity</li>
    <li>Pain and suffering</li>
    <li>Emotional distress</li>
    <li>Disfigurement</li>
</ul>
One of the biggest challenges with a catastrophic injury is that the effects of the injury persist long after the accident. A person who suffered a spinal cord injury may develop respiratory problems long after the injury occurred, or a person who sustained a traumatic brain injury might seem perfectly normal in appearance, but faces challenges such as blinding headaches, memory loss, and cognitive difficulties which can make it virtually impossible for them to keep a job and to maintain personal relationships.

Sometimes people just assume that they will get enough compensation from the at fault party&apos;s insurance company, but that is rarely the case unless you are working with a skilled personal injury attorney who knows how to engage with the experts who can calculate the long-term costs of your medical care into the future. You might not have any way of knowing what is a fair amount of compensation for your injuries and the ongoing damage that they are wreaking on your life.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, our practice involves standing up for the rights of our clients who have suffered serious injuries because of someone else&apos;s negligence. You reap the benefits of our decades of experience fighting for justice and winning compensation for our clients. For compassionate advocacy, you are welcome to call our Kentucky personal injury lawyers at 877-686-8879, our Ohio injury attorneys at 877-686-8879, or complete our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to make an appointment.
<h3>Also consider</h3>
<ul>
    <li>Medical Malpractice in Kentucky</li>
    <li>Medical Malpractice in Ohio</li>
</ul>
-----

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Ohio Car Accident Statistics and Causes of Traffic Crashes
BASENAME: ohio-car-accident-statistics-causes-traffic-crashes
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 08/17/2017 02:48:55 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6033" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Distracted-Driving-Accidents-300x200.jpg" alt="causes of car accidents" width="300" height="200">The Ohio Department of Public Safety manages the data on traffic crashes that occur each year in the state. Keeping track of these numbers gives you an idea of how many crashes are still occurring and the amount of injuries and property damage these accidents cause. Unless you have been involved in a car accident and suffered serious injuries, you may not be able to grasp the magnitude of how it can devastate your life. Knowing how often crashes occur, how many people are injured and lose their lives may motivate drivers to step up their level of caution and safety when they are driving. To the extent that it is in your power to be a safer driver, doing so saves lives--even maybe your own.
<h2>Ohio traffic accident statistics for 2016</h2>
<ul>
    <li>There were 305,964 total traffic crashes</li>
    <li>Of those crashes, 1,054 were fatalities and 77,514 had injuries-- 9,207 of which were incapacitating, serious injuries</li>
    <li>Of the vehicles involved in those crashes, 503,890 were passenger vehicles, 4,342 were motorcycles and 23,474 were med/heavy trucks</li>
    <li>There were 12,243 alcohol-related crashes with 313 having fatalities and 5,076 involved injuries</li>
</ul>
<a href="http://www.publicsafety.ohio.gov/links/2016CrashFacts.pdf" target="_blank">(Ohio Department of Public Safety</a>)
<h2>What is causing these traffic crashes?</h2>
The roadways are an unsafe place because drivers tend to misjudge their ability to operate a motor vehicle while engaging in other activities that take their attention at the same time such as using their mobile phone or typing or reading text messages. Drivers don&apos;t realize that they have had too much to drink, so they get behind the wheel and cause a terrible crash. And many drivers do not understand how dangerous it is to drive when they are overly tired. Drowsy driving can be as dangerous as drunk driving.
<h2>Seeking compensation for injuries from traffic crashes</h2>
Whenever there is a car accident, there is the potential for serious injuries. Driver error is the leading cause of any kind of motor vehicle accident, and when that error arises out of negligence, the injured party may be able to take legal action against the driver who is at fault in causing the accident. If the injured party is successful in proving the other driver&apos;s negligence, they may recover compensation for their pain and suffering, medical expenses, lost income and other damages.

Suffering an injury in a serious car accident can be a devastating experience. You often lose time at work, have mounting medical bills and you may face years of pain and the inability to do those things you once enjoyed. If you are looking for aggressive representation from a trusted team of Ohio car accident attorneys, look to Crandall &amp; Pera Law For a free, no-obligation consultation call 877-686-8879 or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> now.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: What are the Warning Signs of Nursing Home Abuse and Neglect?
BASENAME: warning-signs-nursing-home-abuse-neglect
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 08/31/2017 03:10:59 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6026" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Nursing-home-abuse-200x300.jpg" alt="nursing home abuse" width="200" height="300">If you are watching for signs of abuse or neglect in an elder who lives in a nursing home, you&apos;re not necessarily looking for a black eye or a broken wrist. While some of the signs include unexplained bruises or broken bones there are other, more subtle signs that you should also be keeping an eye out for.

In case you might be thinking that nursing home abuse or neglect is rare, the <a href="https://www.ncoa.org/public-policy-action/elder-justice/elder-abuse-facts/" target="_blank">National Council on Aging</a> (NCOA) reports that about 1 in 10 Americans over age 60 have experienced some form of elder abuse, however because elder abuse is chronically under-reported, only about 1 in 14 incidents of abuse are reported to authorities.

The NCOA cites the following as warning signs of abuse of elders in general as bruises, pressure marks, broken bones, burns and abrasions, and signs of neglect can include bedsores, poor hygiene and unusual weight loss, but there are also other signs that you can look for in your relative or in the facility environment.

Because they receive federal funding from the Center for Medicare and Medicaid (CMS), law mandates nursing homes must meet certain health, safety and staffing level regulations. When a nursing home is found to be in violation of these regulations, CMS can penalize them with fines and withholding a percentage of reimbursements until the deficiencies have been resolved.
<h2>Examples of warning signs of nursing home abuse or negligence</h2>
The following are some additional warning signs that your loved one might be in a situation where their care is being neglected, or they are being abused:
<ul>
    <li><strong>Noticeable physical changes,</strong> changes in mood and temperament. Have you seen significant weight loss, poor grooming and hygiene, dehydration and malnourishment, or other physical signa like bedsores, that your loved one is not being cared for properly?</li>
    <li><strong>Heavily medicated or sedated</strong>. When you come to visit does your loved one always seem to be heavily sedated and unresponsive? Do not be shy about asking why they are so heavily medicated and what other options might be available.</li>
    <li><strong>Inadequate staffing levels</strong> and high staff turnover. Adequate staffing levels are vital to maintaining a healthy, safe environment for residents. If it seems like staffing levels have dropped or if they seem inadequate, raise your concerns with the administrators.</li>
    <li><strong>Unsanitary conditions.</strong> There is never an excuse for a nursing facility to be unclean and unsanitary because this can lead to the spread of infections and disease.</li>
    <li><strong>Refusing care from specific staff members.</strong> If your loved one says that they do not want a specific staff member to attend to them, you should find out what happened if you can, report it to the administrators immediately, and then follow-up to find out what has been done to address your concerns.</li>
    <li><strong>Residents injuring other residents</strong>. When residents are not adequately supervised, some residents can injure other residents</li>
    <li><strong>Unsatisfactory response from staff.</strong> If you have been noticing some of the troubling signs listed above, and you have mentioned them to nursing home staff yet you have seen no evidence that the issues have been addressed, it might be time to report the facility to the state authorities.</li>
    <li><strong>Uneasy feeling about the facility</strong>. Trust your gut. If you get a bad feeling that something is not right, do not hesitate to ask questions and follow-up. Nursing homes operate in apart from public view, so much of what goes on there is never known until an outside visitor who sees something is willing to say something.</li>
</ul>
<h2>What are the benefits of working with a Kentucky nursing home negligence and abuse attorney?</h2>
Sure, you can file a complaint about the alleged incidents of neglect or abuse you saw regarding your loved one in a nursing home, but if you are looking to make sure that something like this does not happen to another resident, and it you want to recover the additional medical expenses and compensation for your loved one&#x2019;s pain and suffering and mental anguish, then you will want to work with a skilled attorney. Building a nursing home negligence case takes the skill and experience that our legal team possesses. We fight for your loved one&#x2019;s right to be cared for properly and to live in a safe, nurturing environment. We make sure that those responsible for your relative&#x2019;s injuries are held accountable through the civil justice system.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, our compassionate Kentucky nursing home negligence attorneys stand up for the rights of our clients who have suffered injury and trauma at the hands of nursing home staff, and we aggressively pursue those responsible holding them accountable. You may contact us to learn more about our services, or to schedule a complimentary consultation by calling 877-686-8879 or <a href="/Contact.shtml">filling out our contact form</a> now.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Jackknifing Dangers on Kentucky Roadways
BASENAME: jackknifing-dangers-kentucky-roadways
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 09/08/2017 02:34:54 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6109" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Jackknifing-Dangers-on-Kentucky-Roadways-300x200.jpg" alt="Jackknifing Dangers on Kentucky Roadways" width="300" height="200">You are driving down the highway, attempting to pass a tractor trailer, when the truck jackknifes. Before you have a chance to react, there is a 50,000-lb tractor trailer skidding in your direction. It is every driver&apos;s worst nightmare, and it happens far too often on the roadways of Kentucky.

Jackknifing occurs when a truck&apos;s trailer swings towards the cab, forming an L or V shape that is similar to a folding pocketknife. These incidents can be extremely dangerous for others driving on the roadway in the vicinity of the truck. The out of control trailer may push the cab, causing the truck to spin in a circle on the road. Cars in its path may be pushed into oncoming lanes of traffic, or crushed underneath the weight of the truck.
<h2><strong><em>What causes a truck to jackknife?</em></strong></h2>
Jackknifing truck accidents can happen for a number of reasons. Loss of traction is the mechanical reason these incidents occur, as the trailer&apos;s brakes fail to adequately slow or stop the wheels. The main vehicle may slow down, but the trailer continues moving at the same speed, causing it to slide toward the cab. Blown tires are a common cause of jackknifing. If a tire blows while the truck is traveling at high speeds, the vehicle could jackknife.

An experienced Kentucy truck accident lawyer knows that driver negligence is often part of the issue. Some examples of driver actions that lead to jackknifing include:
<ul>
    <li><strong>Reckless driving in dangerous road conditions.</strong> Drivers have a duty to operate their trucks in a cautious manner, particularly when the road is wet or icy. Braking issues commonly occur in poor weather conditions. If the driver is traveling too quickly on a slick roadway, the trailer may lose traction and jackknife.</li>
    <li><strong>Excessive speeds.</strong> Trucks need space and time to brake correctly. When operators travel at excessive speeds, they may not allow themselves enough time or distance to properly stop the truck. When a truck driver slams on brakes, it may cause the trailer brakes to lock and slide on the road, also resulting in a jackknife.</li>
</ul>
The attorneys of Crandall &amp; Pera Law are concerned about your well-being and your ability to afford the level of medical treatment needed after a serious crash. To schedule a no obligation consultation with one of our experienced Kentucky truck accident lawyers, please call 877-686-7764 or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact</a><u> form</u>.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Bluegrass Assisted Living Fails to Protect Its Patients, Like So Many Other Kentucky Facilities
BASENAME: bluegrass-assisted-living-fails-protect-patients-like-many-kentucky-facilities
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 09/06/2017 11:52:13 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6021" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Nursing-Home-300x200.jpg" alt="nursing home negligence" width="300" height="200">On August 13, 2017, a man named Charles M. Ball allegedly walked into two separate rooms at the <a href="http://www.wdrb.com/story/36198961/elizabethtown-man-accused-of-sexually-abusing-male-residents-of-assisted-living-facility#.WZ8EcXnx-dI.email" target="_blank">Bluegrass Assisted Living</a> facility in Elizabethtown and sexually assaulted two separate residents. Mr. Ball claims it was all a big misunderstanding; the Elizabethtown Police Department claims he confessed. The families are distraught, and Ball&#x2019;s employer, Tender Touch Senior Services, Inc. refused to comment.

What happened at Bluegrass Assisted Living is just another example of the systemic problem of abuse and neglect in our nursing homes. Earlier this year, CNN created an in-depth piece of investigatory journalism titled &#x201C;<a href="http://www.cnn.com/interactive/2017/02/health/nursing-home-sex-abuse-investigation/" target="_blank">Sick, Dying and Raped in America&#x2019;s Nursing Homes</a>.&#x201D; It said:

&#x201C;More than 16,000 complaints of sexual abuse have been reported since 2000 in long-term care facilities (which include both nursing homes and assisted living facilities), according to federal data housed by the&#xA0;<a href="https://acl.gov/" target="_blank">Administration for Community Living</a>.&#xA0;But agency officials warned that this figure doesn&#x2019;t capture everything&#xA0;&#x2014; only those cases in which state long-term care ombudsmen (who act as advocates for facility residents) were somehow involved in resolving the complaints.&#x201D;

Over the course of three years (2013 through 2016), more than 1000 facilities faced federal citations &#x201C;for mishandling or failing to prevent alleged cases of rape, sexual assault and sexual abuse,&#x201D; and many of them had more than one citation. Half of them didn&#x2019;t even get the police involved, or run proper background checks, or pursue any real investigation at all.

Kentucky is among the worst offenders in the country. In 2014, the <a href="http://kycir.org/2014/10/22/a-powerful-nursing-home-owner-and-a-push-for-medical-review-panels-in-kentucky/" target="_blank">Kentucky Center for Investigative Reporting</a> found that &#x201C;As of Oct. 1, Kentucky had 284 nursing homes rated on the [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][U.S. Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services] database, and a third of those had scores of one or two stars.... Only eight states had a higher percentage of below-average homes.&#x201D; They also discovered &#x201C;The state had just racked up a record 190 cases of &#x2018;immediate jeopardy&#x2019; among nursing home patients, according to the Health and Family Services Cabinet, and had gotten a D on its Families for Better Care report card.&#x201D;
<h2>We need to do better for our families</h2>
As of this writing, there are 293 nursing homes in Kentucky. Our own Cabinet for Health and Family Services lists more than 100 assisted living facilities. While you can use the <a href="https://www.medicare.gov/nursinghomecompare/results.html#state=KY&amp;lat=0&amp;lng=0&amp;AspxAutoDetectCookieSupport=1" target="_blank">Nursing Home Compare</a> site to see how well or how poorly your loved one&#x2019;s nursing home facility is, it does not provide rankings for assisted living facilities. The only research you can do easily involves online reviews &#x2013; and the reviews of Bluegrass Assisted Living are suspiciously high, given the number of complaints we have heard over the years. The same may be true of other assisted living facilities throughout the state.

It falls on all of us to protect our loved ones from harm. Here are a few signs to keep an eye open for:
<ul>
    <li>Unsanitary conditions</li>
    <li>Dangerous or &#x201C;cluttered&#x201D; walkways</li>
    <li>Broken or malfunctioning medical equipment</li>
    <li>Low staff numbers</li>
    <li>Residents refusing care from certain staff members</li>
    <li>Poor or inadequate security measures in place</li>
    <li>Uncertainty or generic answers from staff about how your loved one is doing</li>
    <li>Changes in the residents&#x2019; hygiene, appetites or personalities</li>
    <li>Heavily medicated, restrained or isolated residents</li>
    <li>Multiple people in the halls who you don&#x2019;t recognize, and who are not visiting a specific resident</li>
</ul>
Finally, trust your gut: if something seems wrong, it probably is. If you believe your family member has been abused, it is time to call an attorney who can help.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law handles complex claims on behalf of injured, neglected and abused nursing home and assisted living facility residents, as well as their family members. Our attorneys in Lexington and Louisville have the skills, experience and resources to help you fight for justice. To learn more about our services, or to schedule a complimentary consultation, please call&#xA0;877-686-8879&#xA0;or&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">fill out our contact form</a>&#xA0;now.

&#xA0;

&#xA0;[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Truck Driver Overdoses Cause Major Roadway Dangers
BASENAME: truck-driver-overdoses-cause-major-roadway-dangers
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 09/05/2017 01:28:02 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6023" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Under-the-influence-of-medication-300x200.jpg" alt="dangerous truck drivers on medication" width="300" height="200">Substance abuse is a serious problem in cities across the country. Not only are law enforcement officials overwhelmed with the effects of these self-destructive behaviors, but innocent citizens are being impacted as impaired drivers take to the roadways. This problem is so prevalent that vehicle crashes caused by driver overdoses are becoming a common occurrence.&#xA0; Further exacerbating the problem is the fact that many of these incidents involve truck drivers.

In 2016, Ohio law enforcement reported more than 4,500 drug-related crashes, according to <a href="http://abc6onyourside.com/news/local/overdoses-on-the-road-drugged-driving-rises-as-a-menace-08-18-2017" target="_blank">ABC6 in Columbus</a>. This disturbing number represents a 21% increase in these crashes since 2013. As reported by the <a href="https://www.nhtsa.gov/behavioral-research/drug-and-alcohol-crash-risk-study" target="_blank">National Highway Traffic Safety Administration</a>, fatalities in crashes where drugs were involved increased significantly from 2,003 in 1993 to 7,438 in 2015.
<h2>Recent truck overdosing accidents in the news</h2>
Tragically, the news has been filled with drug-related truck accidents in recent months. <a href="http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/hamilton-county/green-township/police-revive-truck-driver-who-overdosed-on-i-74" target="_blank">WCPO Cincinnati </a>recently reported on a tractor trailer driver who reportedly overdosed while driving on Interstate 74. According to the report, the driver lost consciousness right before the truck jackknifed in the middle of the roadway. Other drivers pulled him from his cab and began performing CPR while waiting for emergency services. He was revived with Narcan, a substance used to revive people from opioid overdoses, and transported to the hospital. The driver was charged with operating a vehicle under the influence, failure to maintain control of his vehicle, and operation of a commercial motor vehicle while under the influence of a controlled substance.

In July, another truck driver overdose occurred in Cleves. The driver of a fuel truck was found passed out and bleeding from the nose in a gas station bathroom. His truck was reportedly running, which suggested that he was planning to operate it on the roadway. Heroin and pain pills were reportedly found inside of the truck.
<h2>Impaired truck operators place drivers and passengers at increased risk of harm</h2>
Experienced Ohio truck accident lawyers know that tractor trailers create a risk on the highways, even when the driver operates the vehicle in a safe and proper manner. When the operator is impaired and under the influence of drugs, the risk of serious harm and death increases significantly. An overdose can cause a driver to pass out or experience convulsions&#x2014;while driving a 60,000-lb vehicle at high speeds on a crowded roadway.

The attorneys of Crandall &amp; Pera Law understand the severity of injuries associated with truck driver overdoses, and the financial burdens that often accompany them. To reserve a no-obligation consultation with an experienced Ohio truck accident lawyer, please call 877-686-8879 or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Holding Hospitals Accountable for Negligent Credentialing
BASENAME: holding-hospitals-accountable-negligent-credentialing
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 09/12/2017 01:26:47 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6112" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Holding-Hospitals-Accountable-for-Negligent-Credentialing-300x200.jpg" alt="Holding Hospitals Accountable for Negligent Credentialing" width="300" height="200">Kentucky&apos;s highest court is considering the liability of a hospital that negligently credentials physicians and medical professionals. As reported by the <a href="http://www.somerset-kentucky.com/news/lcrh-involved-in-kentucky-supreme-court-case/article_3a3a9c7e-8395-11e7-8b1e-b7efaec1bc82.html" target="_blank">Commonwealth Journal</a>, Lake Cumberland Regional Hospital (LCHR) is involved in a case before the Kentucky Supreme Court and the outcome could have far-reaching implications for hospitals and medical centers across the state.

The case stems from a back surgery performed at LCHR by a doctor who was licensed by the Kentucky Board of Medical Licensure, but was not an employee of the hospital. The patient sued the physician and the hospital based on allegations of paralysis and pain. She entered a settlement with the doctor, but received no award from the hospital after a lower court dismissed her case against the institution. The patient appealed the decision to the Appeals Court and won. The hospital then filed an appeal to that decision, which placed the case in front of the state Supreme Court.
<h2><strong><em>The argument for hospital accountability </em></strong></h2>
If it is ultimately decided that the hospital engaged in negligent credentialing, the institution may be liable for damages under the patient&apos;s medical malpractice claim. The argument for accountability centers on the surgeon, who was not an employee of the hospital. He worked at the hospital as an independent contractor and was granted staff privileges. According to the Commonwealth Journal, the doctor had reportedly been sued numerous times for malpractice in other states. He also allegedly had a history of substance abuse.

The patient argued that, by allowing the physician to perform her procedure, the hospital breached its duty to provide her with proper care, which included credentialing the physician who performed her surgery. Her argument essentially asserts that relying on the surgeon&apos;s license, without additional credentialing, is inadequate to meet a reasonable standard.
<h2><strong><em>The argument against hospital liability </em></strong></h2>
Conversely, the hospital asserted that there is no law or regulation requiring hospitals to perform credentialing for an independent contractor. It was also argued that if the court created a new cause of action for negligent credentialing, it would be placing an undue burden on small and rural medical centers.

While the court has yet to reach a ruling in the case, one justice did inquire about the difference between negligent credentialing and negligent hiring, which is a common cause of action in personal injury cases.

The skilled Ohio and Kentucky medical malpractice lawyers of Crandall &amp; Pera Law have successfully handled numerous medical malpractice cases. Please call our Ohio office at 877-686-8879, or in Kentucky at 877-686-8879. You can also fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to schedule a no-obligation consultation.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: When Injury Causes Curvature of the Spine
BASENAME: injury-causes-curvature-spine
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 09/21/2017 02:41:50 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6126" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/When-Injury-Causes-Curvature-of-the-Spine--270x300.jpg" alt="When Injury Causes Curvature of the Spine " width="270" height="300">Severe spine curvature is a painful and debilitating condition that can greatly diminish an individual&apos;s quality of life. While this complication can be caused by a wide range of congenital diseases, it may also occur when a person&apos;s negligence causes injury to an innocent victim&apos;s spine. Treatment is extensive, long-term, and expensive, but a successful personal injury claim can go a long way toward helping a victim secure the medical treatment he or she needs.

<strong><em>What is curvature of the spine?</em></strong>

Some spine curvature is completely normal, and even healthy spines gently curve in order to absorb the shock of everyday movements. Problems arise when the natural curve of the spine becomes deformed, causing it to move away from the center of the back. There are three general types of types of spine curvatures:
<ul>
    <li>This sideways curvature causes the spine to move into an S or C shape. It is the most common form of the condition. When this type of curvature is present, an individual may present with one shoulder higher than the other or uneven hips. Severe back pain and discomfort is often associated with scoliosis.</li>
    <li>This is an inward curvature of the lower back. An individual may appear to have a hollowed lower back, with pronounced buttocks. Fracturing or slippage of the vertebrae are conditions that commonly lead to lordosis. It can make movement in certain direction difficult and cause extensive back pain.</li>
    <li>This fairly common condition presents as a humped upper back that curves by at least 50 degrees. Individuals may experience weakness in the legs and back, with severe cases causing extreme pain.</li>
</ul>
Each of these conditions is degenerative, meaning that it can worsen with time. Spinal cord injury victims may experience increased deterioration of the spine and worsening loss of function. Because extensive spinal curvature may not be immediately apparent following an accident, it is important that a treating physician perform diagnostic measures that can identify the condition or potential for development of the condition in the future.

The medical malpractice lawyers of Crandall &amp; Pera Law assist spine injury victims through some of the most difficult times in their lives. We serve clients throughout Ohio and Kentucky. To schedule a no obligation appointment, complete our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>. You can also reach us by phone in Kentucky at 877-686-8879 and in Ohio at 877-686-8879.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Using Technology to Prevent Sponges Left Inside of Surgical Patients
BASENAME: using-technology-prevent-sponges-left-inside-surgical-patients
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 09/19/2017 02:36:46 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6119" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Using-Technology-to-Prevent-Sponges-Left-Inside-of-Surgical-Patients-300x200.jpg" alt="Using Technology to Prevent Sponges Left Inside of Surgical Patients" width="300" height="200">Preventable medical errors are a major problem for hospitals and patients across the country. As reported by the <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/to-your-health/wp/2016/05/03/researchers-medical-errors-now-third-leading-cause-of-death-in-united-states/?utm_term=.e452882bdccc" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Washington Post</a>, these complications are now the third leading cause of death in the United States, ranking only behind cancer and heart disease. Surgical mistakes are a significant part of these errors. Each year, thousands of surgical patients have had to endure operations on incorrect body parts, unnecessary surgeries meant for other individuals, and surgical instruments left inside of their bodies. When patients leave the hospital with medical instruments, sponges, and other objects sewn into their bodies, they are negligently placed in danger of serious illness and even death.

Approximately 11 occurrences of surgical sponges being left inside patients take place in the United Sates each and every day. Experienced surgical error lawyers have seen how these negligent actions cause unnecessary pain and suffering. These errors often require additional surgical procedures to correct the mistake and treat resulting complications, including:
<ul>
    <li>Mass infections</li>
    <li>Digestive dysfunctions</li>
    <li>Breathing difficulties</li>
    <li>Coughing up blood</li>
    <li>Urinary and bowel dysfunctions</li>
</ul>
<strong><em>A surgical safety system could prevent patient injuries </em></strong>

Traditionally, hospitals use manual methods to ensure that all surgical sponges are accounted for after a procedure. According to a study reported by <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/03/08/surgery-sponges-lost-supplies-patients-fatal-risk/1969603/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">USA Today,</a> researchers at New York&apos;s Mount Sinai found that these manual counts were only effective 77% of the time when items were left inside of patients. An additional study by Minnesota&apos;s Mayo Clinic uncovered even more disturbing data. These researchers found that counts were ineffective in 68% of cases where a surgical sponge was left inside of a patient.

To address these ineffective measures, more than 500 hospitals nationwide are using a new surgical safety system to prevent surgical sponge errors. A computerized counting system is used to uniquely identify each surgical sponge individually. This provides surgeons and their supporting staff an opportunity to account for each separate sponge before closing a patient at the completion of surgery.

Old accounting systems relied on a whiteboard that was erased when the surgery was completed. The new system maintains an electronic, permanent record that can be assessed as needed at later dates. One provider of this accounting system <a href="http://www.grbj.com/articles/88626-hospitals-absorb-surgical-safety-system" target="_blank" rel="noopener">estimates</a> that it has prevented more than 1,300 retained surgical sponges, which would have cost the health care industry about $825 million.

When surgeries leave patients with unexpected pain or additional complications, the attorneys of Crandall &amp; Pera Law help them bring claims against all responsible health care providers. With offices in Ohio and Kentucky, we are here when you need us. Please call us in Kentucky at 877-686-8879, in Ohio at 877-686-8879 or complete our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to reserve an appointment.

&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Long-Term Effects When a Birth Injury Leads to Limb Deficiencies
BASENAME: long-term-effects-birth-injury-leads-limb-deficiencies
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 09/14/2017 01:45:07 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6115" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Long-Term-Effects-When-a-Birth-Injury-Leads-to-Limb-Deficiencies-300x200.jpg" alt="Long-Term Effects When a Birth Injury Leads to Limb Deficiencies" width="300" height="200">Every year, thousands of newborns are injured during the birthing process by physicians who act in a negligent manner. These injuries may result in various physical disabilities, including but not limited to limb deficiencies. Compensation may be sought from the treating physician and medical center. But, when seeking compensation for a birth injury, it is important to not only consider the immediate damage, but also the challenges that these children will face throughout their lives.
<h2><strong><em>What is a limb deficiency?</em></strong></h2>
A limb deficiency refers to a condition where an individual&apos;s arms, hands, legs, or feet are debilitated in some way. These conditions can appear in a variety of ways. A child may not be able to move a portion of, or an entire limb, or one limb may be significantly smaller than the other. These conditions often stem from congenital conditions that develop within the womb, but an experienced birth injury lawyer knows that they can also be caused by physician actions during a birth, including:
<ul>
    <li>Failure to deliver in a timely manner</li>
    <li>Forceful extraction of the baby from the birth canal</li>
    <li>Failure to commence a cesarean section in a timely manner</li>
    <li>Improper administration of medications during the labor and delivery phase</li>
</ul>
<strong><em>Long-term consequences for children with limb deficiencies</em></strong>

Children with limb deficiencies face substantial challenges during their critical formative years. The deficiency may give them an abnormal physical appearance that can lead to a lack of confidence. They may face teasing and name calling from other children. Those with movement limitations may not be able to participate in common childhood activities like riding a bike or playing on a jungle gym. Special accommodations may be necessary for school, as well as other desired extracurricular activities.

All of these consequences have a long-term effect on the psychological wellbeing of a child. Treatment for these conditions often includes the encouragement of self-care and independence, along with tools for adaptation. In some cases, surgical procedures are used to improve the cosmetic appearance caused by the deficiency. These treatments exemplify the difficulties faced by children with limb deficiencies and negligent physicians should be held adequately accountable when their actions cause this type of harm.

Birth injuries can prove extremely difficult for a child and the family. That is why the attorneys of Crandall &amp; Pera Law diligently advocate to secure high value compensation when helpless babies are harmed by medical malpractice. If you are considering a birth injury claim, call one of our conveniently located offices to schedule a confidential consultation. We serve residents of Ohio and Kentucky. Pease call us at 877-686-8879 in Ohio, in Kentucky at 877-686-8879, or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Aaron Hernandez: &#x201C;One of the Most Advanced Cases&#x201D; of CTE Researchers Have Ever Seen
BASENAME: aaron-hernandez-one-advanced-cases-cte-researchers-ever-seen
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 09/25/2017 11:35:16 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6129" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/GettyImages-541831614-300x200.jpg" alt="Aaron Hernandez: &#x201C;One of the Most Advanced Cases&#x201D; of CTE Researchers Have Ever Seen" width="300" height="200">Aaron Hernandez was 23 years old when he was convicted of murdering Odin Lloyd. He was 27 years old when he hung himself in his cell in a Massachusetts prison, a mere 5 days after being acquitted of murdering two other people. He played a grand total of 44 games before his arrest.

After his death, an autopsy was done, and his brain was examined in a study done by Boston University. Those results, according to the <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/09/21/aaron-hernandez-was-suffering-from-advanced-form-of-cte-family-files-suit-against-nfl/?utm_term=.f5409a551339" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>Washington Post</em></a>, found &#x201C;The 27-year-old had the second-most severe form of the disease [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][chronic traumatic encephalopathy] and one of the most advanced cases that researchers had seen in a subject his age.&#x201D; Despite his young age and the few number of games he played, Aaron Hernandez&#x2019;s brain showed signs of Stage III CTE &#x2013; a level of degeneration usually found in players twice his age.

His family has filed a lawsuit against the New England Patriots and the NFL: &#x201C;The lawsuit says the Patriots performed preseason exams of Hernandez and should have recognized signs of cognitive impairment. The NFL was &#x2018;fully aware of the damage that could be inflicted from repetitive impact injuries and failed to disclose, treat or protect him from the danger of such damage.&#x2019;&#x201D;
<h2>When will enough be enough?</h2>
This is not about turning Aaron Hernandez into a hero or a victim; it is about recognizing that for all the safety precautions, all the technology, all the big talk and lofty promises, <strong>no one is effectively protecting these players from permanent, life-threatening brain injuries</strong>.

As a reminder, this is what we <em>do</em> know.
<ul>
    <li>CTE has been linked to increased aggression, erratic behavior, and suicidal thoughts.</li>
    <li>Jovian Belcher, Tyler Sash, Ray Esterling, Dave Duerson, Andre Waters, and Junior Seau all killed themselves, and they all had CTE</li>
    <li>96% to 99% of deceased NFL players&#x2019; brains show signs of CTE</li>
</ul>
CTE cannot be diagnosed until a person has died, so there is no definitive way to determine whether or not a player has the disease &#x2013; but there are signs and symptoms. When players start presenting with these symptoms, we need to acknowledge them and treat the players as best we can, not ignore them and hope for the best. And we need to start doing it in high school, because <strong>as many as 20% of high school football players</strong> end up with the disease.

CTE is a progressive disease. There is no cure. It will eventually kill you. And if you play football, it almost certainly will.

Please. Choose the future. Choose your children. Choose life.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier personal injury law firm serving Ohio and Kentucky. We protect the rights of traumatic brain injury victims of all ages. Please call our Ohio brain injury lawyers at&#xA0;877.686.8879, our Kentucky TBI attorneys at&#xA0;877.651.7764, or fill out this&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>&#xA0;to learn more about our services.
<ul>
    <li>Ohio CTE Injury</li>
    <li>It&#x2019;s Official: Football Leads to CTE</li>
    <li>Dear Parents: Please Keep Your Children Away from Football</li>
    <li>Top NFL Exec Finally Acknowledges Link between Football and CTE</li>
    <li>An Open letter to Parents of High School Football Players</li>
    <li><a href="https://www.patientsrightsblog.com/this-is-your-brain-on-sports/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">This Is Your Brain on Sports</a></li>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Truck Drivers Abusing Opioid Pain Killers Cause Increasing Crash Risk in Ohio
BASENAME: truck-drivers-abusing-opioid-pain-killers-cause-increasing-crash-risk-ohio
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/05/2017 02:18:40 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6180" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Opioid-Pain-Medication-Theft-in-Kentucky-Nursing-Homes-300x223.jpg" alt="Truck Drivers Abusing Opioid Pain Killers Cause Increasing Crash Risk in Ohio" width="300" height="223">In Cincinnati, Ohio, the driver of a tractor trailer lost consciousness while using heroin crashed his truck into a guardrail on Interstate 74 in the westbound lanes. Law enforcement reported that the driver blacked out after taking heroin and his truck rolled backward and struck a guardrail. A police officer was able to revive the driver with an opioid antidote and he was charged with impaired driving and other violations. (<a href="https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/ohio/articles/2017-08-18/police-truck-driver-in-ohio-crash-blacked-out-after-heroin" target="_blank" rel="noopener">USNews</a>)

The driver of a fuel tanker truck in Cleves, Ohio, overdosed at a gas station as his truck engine was running. The driver was found slumped on the floorboards of his truck, bleeding from the nose with heroin pills in the truck according to law enforcement. The driver was questioned by police and taken to Hamilton County Justice Center. (<a href="http://wreg.com/2017/07/12/fuel-truck-driver-overdosed-at-gas-station-with-vehicle-running-cleves-police-say/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WREG.com</a>)

Opioid use is fast becoming a serious safety risk for truck accidents in Ohio and throughout the United States. Where there was once a focus on the dangers of drunk driving, drug use among truck drivers is seen as an increasing cause of truck crashes in this country. The two incidents regarding overdosed truck drivers both concerned heroin use, which is not a prescription opioid, but heroin abuse often begins when an individual became addicted to prescription opioid pain killers.

Driving a truck is grueling work with demanding deadlines and schedules. If a truck driver is in pain from an injury or a health condition or just from the consequences of aging and doing sedentary work, they may turn to pain killers to enable them to keep their tough schedules. <a href="https://www.fmcsa.dot.gov/regulations/rulemaking/2016-27398" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration</a> (FMCSA) regulations prohibit truck drivers to use opioid pain killers while they are driving, they can do so if they get a letter from their doctor saying that they can do so. There is nothing keeping a driver from using opioids and other drugs without disclosing them because federal regulations do not currently include opioid pain killers in truck driver drug tests.

In February, the <a href="https://www.regulations.gov/document?D=DOT-OST-2016-0189-0001" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Department of Transportation</a> (DOT) proposed a new rule which would add four opioids to the panel of drugs that truck drivers are tested for:&#xA0; hydrocodone, hydromorphone, oxymorphone, and oxycodone. These drugs can seriously impair a driver&apos;s ability to operate a large truck safely, and they are notorious for causing those who take them to become addicted.
<h2>What are commercial truck fleet operators doing to combat drug use in truck drivers?</h2>
Currently, pre-employment, post incident, and random drug testing are done through urine testing, however, there is a movement afoot in favor of hair follicle drug testing because it is far more accurate that urine testing. Hair follicle testing can detect evidence of narcotic drug use as far back as 90-day, while a urine test can show evidence of about 60 days back. Additionally, it is impossible to cheat a hair follicle test, as the samples are collected by the technician conducting the test. Hair follicle testing costs as much as twice the price of a urine test, but its accuracy makes it worth the expense.

The comprehensive highway legislation, the FAST Act, which became law in 2015 under former President Obama, directs the FMCSA to accept hair follicle testing to satisfy the federal drug testing mandate for truck operators, but the law does not require them to do so until the department of Health and Human Services publishes guidelines for testing. These guidelines were due to Congress by December 2016; however, they are not expected to be completed until early 2018.

A coalition of 13 large commercial truck fleet operators has been pressing the FMCSA to allow them to use hair follicle testing alone rather than conducting both hair and urine testing because of the high cost of conducting both tests. Seven members of Congress sent a letter to the FMCSA in support of the trucking companies&apos; request. (<a href="http://www.ccjdigital.com/congressional-reps-ask-fmcsa-to-move-quickly-in-allowing-carriers-to-drug-test-drivers-via-hair-sample/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CCJ</a>)

Anyone who has suffered an injury in a truck accident caused by a truck driver who was impaired by drugs, you may be able to take legal action against the driver and the trucking company to recover compensation for your injuries and other losses.

The Ohio truck accident attorneys of Crandall &amp; Pera Law are here to fight for fair compensation for you after a serious crash. To schedule a free consultation with one of our experienced Ohio truck accident lawyers, you are welcome to call 877-686-7764 or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>.

AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: Never Events and Surgical Malpractice: Know Your Rights
BASENAME: never-events-surgical-malpractice-know-rights
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/03/2017 01:29:33 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6177" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Never-Events-and-Surgical-Malpractice-Know-Your-Rights-300x200.jpg" alt="Never Events and Surgical Malpractice: Know Your Rights" width="300" height="200">There are some acts of medical negligence so egregious, so catastrophic, that there is no way to excuse them. We call these &#x201C;never events,&#x201D; because they are never supposed to happen. The term was invented by the National Quality Forum, a non-profit organization dedicated to patient safety and promoting quality healthcare.

The NQF has a detailed <a href="https://www.cms.gov/Newsroom/MediaReleaseDatabase/Fact-sheets/2006-Fact-sheets-items/2006-05-18.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">list of never events</a>, but there are five in the area of Surgical Events:
<ul>
    <li>&#x201C;Surgery performed on the wrong body part</li>
    <li>Surgery performed on the wrong patient</li>
    <li>Wrong surgical procedure on a patient</li>
    <li>Retention of a foreign object in a patient after surgery or other procedure</li>
    <li>Intraoperative or immediately post-operative death in a normal health patient (defined as a Class 1 patient for purposes of the American Society of Anesthesiologists patient safety initiative)&#x201D;</li>
</ul>
Despite the name, these types of errors do occur more often than they should. Between 1990 and 2010, there were &#x201C;9,744 paid malpractice settlement and judgments for surgical never events,&#x201D; according to one piece in the journal <a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23257079" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>Surgery</em></a>. Out of those events, &#x201C;Mortality occurred in 6.6% of patients, permanent injury in 32.9%, and temporary injury in 59.2%.&#x201D; The researchers estimate that just over 4,000 surgical never events occur in U.S. hospitals each year. You can <a href="http://content.hcpro.com/pdf/content/287732.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">read the full article here</a>.

This information was gathered from data in the <a href="https://www.npdb.hrsa.gov/hcorg/whatYouMustReportToTheDataBank.jsp" target="_blank" rel="noopener">National Practitioner Data Bank</a>, which collects information on medical malpractice payments and actions taken by licensing boards and facilities against medical personnel. However, not all adverse actions will end up being reported to the NPDB, which means the number of those actions will likely be higher than reported.
<h2>Surgical never events happen in Ohio hospitals, too</h2>
It can be easy to look at national statistics and assume they&#x2019;re happening &#x201C;elsewhere,&#x201D; but Ohio hospitals and medical facilities have their fair share of never events as well. (You can see the Leapfrog Group&#x2019;s <a href="http://www.leapfroggroup.org/hospitals/search/list/states/Ohio" target="_blank" rel="noopener">full list of never event reporting here</a>.)

For example: in June of 2009, Kelly Maron underwent surgery to treat colon cancer. She was treated by Dr. Timothy Pritchard at a Lake Health Systems facility. In November of 2009, Kelly underwent another surgery because a <strong>surgical towel was left inside her upper abdomen during the first procedure</strong>. Kelly sought the counsel of Crandall &amp; Pera Law&#x2019;s Steve Crandall, and in 2011 filed a lawsuit against Pritchard and Lake Health. A jury found Dr. Pritchard and Lake Health Systems equally negligent in Kelly&#x2019;s case, and awarded her $910,000 in damages; it was believed to be the largest verdict ever rendered in Lake County.

Surgical malpractice of any kind is terrible, but circumstances like the ones Kelly Maron underwent are especially tragic. They are also entirely preventable. When a doctor or hospital fails to uphold its duty to do no harm, you may be entitled to compensation for your lost wages, your pain and suffering, your medical bills, and more.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we fight on behalf of patients who have sustained serious, even life-altering injuries as a result of medical negligence. If you or your loved one were the victim of a never event, we want to help. To speak with an experienced Ohio medical malpractice lawyer, please call<strong>&#xA0;</strong>877-686-8879. To work with a medical negligence attorney in Kentucky, please call 877-686-8879. You can also fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to learn more.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Kentucky Truck Accidents in Construction Zones
BASENAME: kentucky-truck-accidents-construction-zones
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/02/2017 02:06:54 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6168" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Kentucky-Truck-Accidents-in-Construction-Zones-300x200.jpg" alt="Kentucky Truck Accidents in Construction Zones" width="300" height="200">You are driving along a familiar stretch of Interstate 75 when you see a slowdown up ahead and they you see the construction zone signs and you dread the slowdown this will cause. Road construction zones are required to maintain and expand our highways and roadways in safe condition. Those warning signs, the flashing lights, the orange cones, all those elements are designed to catch drivers&apos; attention and remind them to slow down and become more alert as they move through road construction zones to avoid accidents. It seems like regardless of all the safety measures and warning signs, accidents continue to occur in construction zones.

An unfortunate example of a construction zone accident on a Kentucky highway cost the lives of six people in July. <a href="http://www.bgdailynews.com/news/six-dead-in-crash-on-i/article_af66c464-15bf-5e7a-96ff-6092a32f7711.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>The Bowling Green Daily News</em></a> reported on the terrible crash that took the lives of four members of a family that was returning to their home in Indiana from a Florida vacation, another man in a separate vehicle and a truck driver were also killed. The crash occurred at about 10:30 pm in the northbound lanes of I-65 in an area where road construction was going on. It is also a place where the highway merges from three lanes to two lanes. One of the trucks, according to the <em>Daily News</em>, was stopped because of congestion in the right lane and the two passenger vehicles were behind it. A second semi, which was traveling in the same lane, failed to stop and it crashed into the first passenger vehicle and setting off a chain reaction crash.

Kentucky state trooper Jeremy Hodges was quoted in the <em>Daily News </em>story: &#x201C;With the work construction going on, whether the workers are present or not, everyone needs to pay attention. Be alert and be cognizant of your surroundings and slow down in the work zones.&#x201D;
<h2>Tips for safe driving in construction zones</h2>
The <a href="https://safety.fhwa.dot.gov/wz/resources/fhwasa03012/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Federal Highway Administration</a> offers these tips on avoiding construction zone accidents:
<ul>
    <li>Stay alert and minimize distractions</li>
    <li>Keep your headlights on</li>
    <li>Pay attention to the road, &quot;listen to the signs,&quot; watch for brake lights and be prepared to react quickly</li>
    <li>Merge into the proper lane</li>
    <li>Do not tailgate. Keep a safe driving distance between your car and the vehicle in front of you</li>
    <li>Obey the posted speed limits</li>
    <li>Change lanes safely</li>
    <li>Follow instructions from Flaggers</li>
    <li>Expect the unexpected in a construction zone</li>
    <li>Be patient</li>
</ul>
Also, be mindful when you are driving around tractor trailers and other large, commercial trucks to keep a safe distance from them in construction zones and on the highway. Large trucks have a much longer braking distance than passenger vehicles and they do not maneuver easily to avoid crashing into the smaller, more nimble vehicles with which they share the roadways.

Stay alert in construction zones and help keep our roads as safe as possible.

If you or someone you care about has been injured in an accident with a tractor-trailer or any other type of large, commercial truck, the skilled truck accident attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law are here to represent your interests as you pursue compensation for your injuries.

The skilled Kentucky truck accident lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law are ready to fight for the compensation you need after your serious injuries from a truck accident. You are encouraged to call Crandall &amp; Pera Law&#x2019;s Kentucky office at 877.651.7764 or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to schedule a free consultation now.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Kentucky Medical Malpractice Screening Panels
BASENAME: kentucky-medical-malpractice-screening-panels
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/10/2017 10:45:33 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6186" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Kentucky-Medical-Malpractice-Screening-Panels-300x200.jpg" alt="Kentucky Medical Malpractice Screening Panels" width="300" height="200">In June 2017, a new law went into effect in Kentucky, which calls for &quot;Medical Review Panels&quot; to review medical negligence cases before they can be filed in the court house. Sen. Ralph Alvarado (R-Winchester), who is also a physician, sponsored the legislation with the intention of limiting medical malpractice litigation in Kentucky. Now that <a href="http://www.lrc.ky.gov/recorddocuments/bill/17RS/SB4/bill.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SB4</a> is in effect, an individual who wants to file a medical malpractice lawsuit must first file a complaint with the Kentucky Cabinet for Health and Family Services, which would then convene a panel to review the claim and decide if the case has sufficient merit to proceed to trial. There is a fee to file a complaint. If both parties agree, the review panel can be bypassed and the plaintiff can proceed to file their lawsuit.

<a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2017/07/01/trying-beat-new-screening-panel-law-lawyers-file-96-medical-malpractice-cases-ky-t-his-week/444520001/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>USA Today</em></a> reported that Alvarado said this new law will eliminate &#x201C;frivolous, nonsense lawsuits&#x201D; that &#x201C;happen all the time,&#x201D; which is a completely debunked statement which attempts to support the idea that there is a medical malpractice crisis in the United States, but that is just not true. Attempts at tort reform have been going on for decades while there is no evidence that the so-called crisis even exists. In a story in the <em>Washington Post</em>, Michael Matray, editor of Medical Liability Monitor, was quoted, &quot;It&apos;s a wonderful time for doctors looking for coverage, and it&apos;s never been better for insurers.&quot; The story reports that doctors are paying less for malpractice insurance than they did in 2001, and the rate of claims has dropped by half since 2003.

Prior to the passage of this new law, if an individual suffered an injury because of medical negligence, for example, if the doctor had misdiagnosed a disease, or a nurse made a pharmaceutical error, the injured party would have to show evidence of the following before they could pursue a civil claim for medical negligence:

There existed a doctor-patient relationship, which shows the doctor&apos;s duty of care to the patient
<ul>
    <li>The physician or other medical professional violated the standard of care</li>
    <li>The patient suffered an injury</li>
    <li>The violation or breach of the accepted standard of cares was the direct cause of the patient&#x2019;s injury</li>
</ul>
<h2>Kentucky Medical review panels</h2>
Now, in Kentucky, plaintiffs have a new hurdle to overcome in that they must present their evidence to the screening panel, which will decide whether the case can proceed to trial.

Kentucky joins 17 other states, which also have requirements that medical malpractice cases must be heard by a screening panel before trial. (NCSL.org)

The screening panel has nine months to reach a decision. If they have not reached a decision within nine months, the plaintiff can proceed to court. Filing a complaint with the screening panel tolls the statute of limitations until 90 days after the medical review panel has made their decision.
<h2>How is the screening panel composed?</h2>
The medical review panel or screening panel consists of one lawyer and three health care providers. The attorney acts as the chairperson of the panel, but does not have a vote. At the medical negligence trial, the screening panel&apos;s opinion may be admitted as an expert opinion.

Regardless of their findings, the medical review panels do not prevent plaintiff&apos;s from proceeding to trial.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier medical malpractice law firm serving clients throughout Kentucky and Ohio. If you would like to discuss your case with an experienced medical malpractice lawyer today, please fill out this <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to request a free consultation now. You can call our Kentucky team at 877.651.7764, or our Ohio team at 877.686.8879.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: A Breakthrough May Allow Doctors to Diagnose CTE in Living Patients
BASENAME: breakthrough-may-allow-doctors-diagnose-cte-living-patients
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/12/2017 02:14:47 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6189" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/A-Breakthrough-May-Allow-Doctors-to-Diagnose-CTE-in-Living-Patients--300x200.jpg" alt="A Breakthrough May Allow Doctors to Diagnose CTE in Living Patients " width="300" height="200">On September 26<sup>th</sup>, a team of researchers at Boston University&#x2019;s School of Medicine found something interesting in spinal fluid: a protein that could help detect chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or CTE, in the brains of patients who are still alive. CTE is a degenerative brain disease, which researchers have discovered in those that play football at the professional, college and even high school level.

From the <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/breakthrough-may-lead-to-ability-to-diagnose-cte-in-living-football-players/2017/09/26/a6e1e8c4-a2bb-11e7-ade1-76d061d56efa_story.html?utm_term=.b293c82e4844" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Washington Post</a>:

&#x201C;In a new study published Tuesday [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][September 26, 2017] in the journal PLOS ONE, researchers from BU and the VA Boston Healthcare System studied the brains of 23 former football players who were diagnosed with CTE, in addition to those of 50 non-athletes who suffered from Alzheimer&#x2019;s disease and 18 non-athlete controls. They found <strong>significantly elevated levels of a protein related to inflammation called CCL11</strong> in the group of ex-players compared with the non-athletes. The levels were even higher in those who played the game longer&#x201D; (emphasis ours).

This is an extraordinary development in the fight against the degenerative CTE. Until this discovery, no one had discovered a way to diagnose living patients with CTE; the diagnosis had to come post-mortem, during an autopsy.

The research into CCL11 as an indicator of CTE is still very, very new. At this point, the team at BU needs to determine whether or not the protein &#x201C;is a reliable sign of CTE, and that it can distinguish CTE from other degenerative brain diseases. And they must understand more precisely how levels of CLL11 that can be measured in the bloodstream reflect those present in the brain,&#x201D; as explained in the <a href="http://www.baltimoresun.com/health/maryland-health/la-sci-sn-cte-biomarker-football-20170926-story.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Baltimore Sun</a><em>.</em>

Still, the signs are positive. While CCL11 <em>was</em> found in brains of people with Alzheimer&#x2019;s, too, the levels were significantly higher in those brains diagnosed with CTE, and higher still when compared to tests run on people who were &#x201C;cognitively healthy&#x201D; when they died. Because the protein was found in spinal fluid (it is, as the <em>Baltimore Sun</em> points out, &#x201C;generally understood that anything that has escaped the brain into cerebrospinal fluid will find its way into circulating blood as well&#x201D;), a blood test for CTE could well be on its way.
<h2>Another nail in the coffin for CTE and football</h2>
We have been pouring through the evidence of the link between playing football and developing CTE for the last couple of years, and the latest study out of BU strengthens that link. The levels of CCL11 in the brains of former football players rose with the amount of time of play. In other words, the longer a person played football, the more of the protein could be found in the prefrontal brain.

We continue to ask: please &#x2013; do not let your children play football. It is basically guaranteed that they will develop a degenerative brain disease which could lead to depression, dementia, violent tendencies and suicidal thoughts. As parents ourselves, we know that there are so many things we cannot control; so many risks that we can attempt to prepare our children for, but may not be able to stop.

The decision to keep our kids of the gridiron? That <em>is</em> in our control. This is a risk we <em>can</em> avoid, a future we <em>can</em> help prevent.

Please. Choose the future. Choose your children. Choose life.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier medical malpractice and personal injury firm serving Ohio and Kentucky. We handle complex brain injury claims and lawsuits, and we do not stop fighting for our clients&#x2019; rights and futures. To learn more about our services, please call our Ohio brain injury lawyers at&#xA0;877.686.8879, our Kentucky TBI attorneys at&#xA0;877.651.7764, or fill out this&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>.

    <li>Aaron Hernandez: &#x201C;One of the most Advanced Cases&#x201D; of CTE Researchers Have Ever Seen</li>
    <li>It&#x2019;s Official: Football Leads to CTE</li>
    <li>Ohio CTE Injury</li>
    <li>Dear Parents: Please Keep Your Children Away from Football</li>
    <li>Top NFL Exec Finally Acknowledges Link between Football and CTE</li>
    <li>An Open letter to Parents of High School Football Players</li>
    <li><a href="https://www.patientsrightsblog.com/this-is-your-brain-on-sports/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">This Is Your Brain on Sports</a></li>
    <li>Friday Night Lights Out: The Truth about Football and Long Term Brain Damage</li>
    <li>Should There Be a Legal Age Limit for Playing Football?</li>
    <li>College Football Players Diagnosed with CTE Confirms Warnings from Concussion Legacy Foundation</li>
    <li>First Extreme Sport Athlete Diagnosed with Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy</li>
    <li><a href="https://www.patientsrightsblog.com/despite-controversy-over-cte-progress-is-made/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Despite Controversy Over CTE, Progress Is Made</a></li>
    <li>CTE Research Is Incredible, but Prevention Is the Only Sure Cure</li>
</ul>[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
