AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Hospitals Charged with Negligence in Drug Diversion Lawsuits
BASENAME: hospitals-charged-negligence-drug-diversion-lawsuits
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/23/2017 01:30:45 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6208" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/GettyImages-521624342-300x200.jpg" alt="Hospitals Charged with Negligence in Drug Diversion Lawsuits" width="300" height="200">After surgery or when they are experiencing severe pain, hospital patients are given powerful pain medications as part of their treatment. But what happens when a patient who is in excruciating pain from a terminal illness receives Tylenol, an over-the-counter headache remedy instead of the more powerful opioid pain medication Oxycodone. When a hospital patient or nursing home resident&apos;s pain medications are stolen and swapped out with a replacement medication, the crime is referred to as drug diversion, and as one aspect of the opioid epidemic it is rampant in the health care system in the United States.

<a href="http://www.pharmacytimes.com/contributor/erica-lindsay-pharmd-mba-jd/2016/01/the-high-cost-of-drug-diversion" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>Pharmacy Times</em></a> defines drug diversion as, &quot;the transfer of a prescription drug from a lawful to an unlawful channel of distribution or use.&quot; The estimated cost of controlled prescription drug diversion and abuse to both public and private insurers is about $72.5 billion each year. Physicians, nurses, pharmacists and other medical professionals with easy access to the medications in their workplace have all been found diverting drugs either to support a personal habit, or to sell for profit.

In July 2017, the U.S. Department of Justice conducted the largest ever health care fraud enforcement action in a national health care fraud takedown, which resulted in charges against more than 412 individuals responsible for $1.3 billion in fraud losses. <a href="https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/national-health-care-fraud-takedown-results-charges-against-over-412-individuals-responsible" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Medicare Fraud Strike Force</a> charged 412 defendants across 41 federal districts including the Northern District of Ohio and the Western District of Kentucky, where 11 defendants were charged with defrauding the Medicaid program.&#xA0; In one case, four defendants, including three medical professionals, were charged with distributing controlled substances and fraudulently billing the Medicaid program.

The defendants allegedly participated in schemes to submit claims to Medicare, Medicaid and Tricare for treatments that were not medically necessary and in some cases never provided. &#x201C;Last year, an estimated 59,000 Americans died from a drug overdose, many linked to the misuse of prescription drugs. This is, quite simply, an epidemic,&#x201D; said Acting Administrator Rosenberg. &#x201C;There is a great responsibility that goes along with handling controlled prescription drugs, and DEA and its partners remain absolutely committed to fighting the opioid epidemic using all the tools at our disposal.&#x201D;
<h2>The consequences of drug diversion</h2>
In Pennsylvania, 17 patients are suing the Jefferson Regional Medical Center for negligence after being denied pain medication after a hospital pharmacy technician replaced it with a medication that had a similar appearance. The complaint alleges that an estimated 362 patients may have received non-narcotic medication after the pharmacy technician replace it. The Pharmacy tech pleaded guilty to illegally acquiring a controlled substance, theft, and recklessly endangering another person. she was ordered to serve six to 12 months in jail with three months of probation. The negligence claim includes allegations that the hospital failed to check medications that were being given to patients, the failure to supervise employees and the failure to have a system in place to inventory medications and prevent their theft according to a story in the <a href="http://www.post-gazette.com/local/south/2017/09/13/Jefferson-Hospital-pa-lawsuit-oxycodone-pills-pain-medication-cheryl-ashcraft/stories/201709130197" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>Post-Gazette</em></a>.

In Iowa, nine patients filed a lawsuit against Iowa Methodist Medical Center, which accuses the hospital of negligence in failing to supervise a pharmacy technician who stole Fentanyl in 2016 between August and October. The employee used a syringe to withdraw the medication and they refilled the vials with a saline solution. The pharmacy technician admitted to the charges, was fired and relinquished his state license. As of August 2017 no criminal charges have been filed and the case is with the Assistant U.S. Attorney according to a story in the <a href="http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/health/2017/08/23/no-charges-filed-despite-ex-hospital-employees-admission-he-stole-patients-painkillers/594702001/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>De Moines Register</em></a><em>.</em>

If you or a loved one has suffered a serious injury because your pain medication was taken away or an imposter drug was substituted for it by a medical professional, the experienced medical malpractice lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law are here to help you. We have the knowledge and the skill to present a compelling case on your behalf. You are welcome to call our Ohio lawyers at 877.686.8879 and our Kentucky attorneys at 877.651.7764 to schedule an initial consultation to discuss your case. You can also contact us through our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Electronic Logging Devices Mandate Can Prevent Drowsy Driving and Improve Truck Safety
BASENAME: electronic-logging-devices-mandate-can-prevent-drowsy-driving-improve-truck-safety
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/18/2017 01:36:07 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6205" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Electronic-Logging-Devices-Mandate-Can-Prevent-Drowsy-Driving-and-Improve-Truck-Safety--300x200.jpg" alt="Electronic Logging Devices Mandate Can Prevent Drowsy Driving and Improve Truck Safety" width="300" height="200">Truck drivers who are required to maintain record of duty status (RODS) logs will soon be required to use an electronic logging device (ELD) thanks to the mandate from the <a href="https://www.fmcsa.dot.gov/hours-service/elds/electronic-logging-devices" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration</a> (FMCSA) that requires ELDs to be installed in commercial trucks by December 18, 2017. The FMCSA intends for the devices, which connect to the trucks electronic control module (ECM), to automatically record the date, time, location, how long the engine has been running and how many miles the vehicle has traveled. The device must also authenticate the user with their driver ID. An ELD tracks when the vehicle is in motion, when it is shut down and when the driver&apos;s duty status changes.

The goal of the ELD mandate is to automatically provide a tamper-proof record of the driver&apos;s compliance with the FMCSA&apos;s Hours of Service (HOS) regulations. HOS rules govern how many hours a truck driver can drive, how long they can go between breaks and how long those breaks need to be before they can restart their work day. Truck drivers are not supposed to drive for too many days in a row, or drive for more than 11 hours at a stretch.

Until the advent of ELDs, however, truck drivers logged those details on paper logs.&#xA0; If the driver was involved in a truck accident, one of the most important things to examine in the ensuing investigation was the driver&apos;s ROD log. Now that this data is being tracked electronically and directly from the truck&#x2019;s engine, accident investigators will get an accurate gauge of the factors that might have contributed to causing the crash.
<h2>The FMCSA hopes that ELDs will reduce truck crashes from driver fatigue</h2>
<a href="https://www.vtti.vt.edu/research/ctbs/index.php" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Center for Truck and Bus Safety of Virginia Tech Transportation</a> Institute conducted a study that revealed commercial truck drivers who used ELDs had 11.7% fewer crashes and 5.1% fewer predicable crashes than commercial drives who did not use an ELD.

<a href="https://crashstats.nhtsa.dot.gov/Api/Public/ViewPublication/812318" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The National Highway Transportation Safety Administration (</a>NHTSA) reports that there were 667 traffic fatalities from truck accidents and 30,000 injuries in 2015, which is up from the previous year by 1 percent and 11 percent respectively.

This is not to say that large commercial truck drivers are the only motorists who drive on too little sleep and cause accidents. Drowsy driving is what the <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/features/dssleep/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a>(CDC) calls a &quot;public health epidemic,&quot; with more than 70 million American adults having some type of sleep disorder. Tackling the safety challenge of drowsy driving in commercial truck drivers is because they operate massive vehicles that can cause catastrophic accidents when the driver falls asleep at the wheel while driving on the highway among other smaller, more vulnerable passenger vehicles.

The accident attorneys of Crandall &amp; Pera Law understand the severity of injuries associated with accidents caused by drowsy truck drivers, and the financial burdens that often accompany them. You are welcome to reserve a no-obligation consultation with an experienced Ohio truck accident lawyer by calling 877-686-8879, one of our Kentucky truck crash lawyers by calling 877-686-8879, or filling out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>.

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Can a New Medical Procedure Help Restore Consciousness to Our Loved Ones in Vegetative States?
BASENAME: can-new-medical-procedure-help-restore-consciousness-loved-ones-vegetative-states
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/16/2017 11:33:34 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6195" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Can-a-New-Medical-Procedure-Help-Restore-Consciousness-to-Our-Loved-Ones-in-Vegetative-States-300x200.jpg" alt="Can a New Medical Procedure Help Restore Consciousness to Our Loved Ones in Vegetative States?" width="300" height="200">Medical research is moving so quickly now that it can be hard to keep up with the developments. Recently, a story about nerve stimulation caught our eye &#x2013; not because of the risks that might be associated with it, but because of an extraordinary response it has had on a man in a persistent vegetative state (PVS).

<a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/sep/25/nerve-implant-restores-consciousness-to-man-in-vegetative-state" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Guardian</a> reports that a new &#x201C;treatment challenges a widely-accepted view that there is no prospect of a patient recovering consciousness if they have been in PVS for longer than 12 months.&#x201D; By stimulating the vagus nerve, doctors were able to elicit a response form a man who had been in this state for 15 years. The patient had severe brain injuries as a result of a car crash; he had been in a persistent vegetative state ever since. But after doctors fitted him with the implant, he seemingly regained consciousness. The article says:

&#x201C;He started to track objects with his eyes, began to stay awake while being read a story and his eyes opened wide in surprise when the examiner suddenly moved her face close to the patient&#x2019;s. He could even respond to some simple requests, such as turning his head when asked &#x2013; although this took about a minute.

Angela Sirigu, who led the work at the Institut des Sciences Cognitives Marc Jeannerod in Lyon, France, said: &#x2018;He is still paralyses, he cannot talk, but he can respond. Now he is more aware.&#x2019;&#x201D;
<h2>How does the implant work?</h2>
The device is surgically implanted into the vagus nerve &#x2013; the longest cranial nerve in the body, running from your brain stem all the way to your stomach. The device was placed in the area of the patient&#x2019;s neck, and stimulator was implanted in his chest. Once the device is set, it sends little pulses of electricity to the vagus nerve.

There was no guarantee it would work: after all, as <a href="http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/09/experimental-nerve-stimulation-therapy-partially-revives-man-long-term-vegetative-state" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>Science</em></a> explains &#x201C;Such nerve stimulation has been explored as a therapy for a wide range of disorders such as epilepsy, depression, arthritis, and cluster headaches, although it&#x2019;s unclear exactly why it works.... Electrically stimulating the thalamus can temporarily rouse a person in a minimally conscious state, and Sirigu wondered what would happen if she stimulated it for long periods of time.&#x201D;

What happened, in short, was that it worked. The patient&#x2019;s progress has, of course, been slow &#x2013; but it is <em>there</em>. And that is extraordinary, because being in a persistent vegetative state is a frustrating half-life for both the patients suspended there, and for their families. In a coma, a person is more or less in a prolonged sleep; in PVS, that person may have some low-level brain function, but not enough to communicate wants and needs to their caretakers.

This experimental therapy may have just changed all of that, opening a new world of possibility for victims and their loved ones. There is no way of knowing how much farther the patient can or will progress with more treatment &#x2013; but it&#x2019;s a pretty good start.

The brain injury attorneys of Crandall &amp; Pera Law help families fight for their loved ones and their futures. With multiple offices in Ohio and Kentucky, we are always nearby when you need us the most. To schedule a free consultation, please complete our&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> or call us: in Kentucky, at&#xA0;877-686-8879; and in Ohio, at&#xA0;877-686-8879.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Traumatic Brain Injury Can Have Catastrophic Consequences
BASENAME: traumatic-brain-injury-can-have-catastrophic-consequences
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/26/2017 02:00:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6267" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Traumatic-Brain-Injury-Can-Have-Catastrophic-Consequences-300x194.jpg" alt="Traumatic Brain Injury Can Have Catastrophic Consequences" width="300" height="194">While the headlines seem to be full of stories about professional football players and traumatic brain injury (TBI), playing sports is not the most common way a person might suffer a traumatic brain injury. Being injured in a car crash or falling are the two most common ways in which Americans suffer TBI. <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/traumaticbraininjury/basics.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a> (CDC) estimates that 2.5 million Americans suffered from a traumatic brain injury, with 14% caused by traffic accidents and 40% as the result of a fall.

The severity of a TBI can range from mild to severe. When a person sustains a brain injury in a car crash where the vehicles were traveling at high speed when they collided, the delicate structures of the brain, which is essentially floating inside of the protective skull, can collide back and forth between the inside front and back of the skull. With severe brain injury, there is often loss of consciousness which can range from just a few seconds or a day or more if the accident victim ends up in a coma.
<h2>What is the life impact of a traumatic brain injury?</h2>
After suffering a traumatic brain injury in a car crash, there is no such thing as a typical long-term effect from the injury as all injuries are different. There are some symptoms and lasting effects that tend to be common among TBI victims, and the Ohio Valley Center for Brain Injury Prevention and Rehabilitation at Ohio University (OVC) <a href="http://ohiovalley.org/informationeducation/long-termconsequences/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">lists the following</a>:
<ul>
    <li>Seizures</li>
    <li>Cognitive deficits</li>
    <li>Depression</li>
    <li>Aggression</li>
    <li>Unemployment or social isolation</li>
    <li>Premature death</li>
    <li>Decline in cognitive function</li>
    <li>Progressive dementia</li>
    <li>Parkinsonism</li>
    <li>Endocrine dysfunction, hypopituitarism</li>
</ul>
According to OVC, TBI is a chronic health condition that has a long-term, deleterious effect on overall health for some individuals. The type and severity of the effects of TBI may be proportional to the severity of the injury.
<h2>Life care planning after a traumatic brain injury</h2>
When an individual has suffered a catastrophic injury such as a traumatic brain injury, the injury will cause lasting damage that will impact the quality of their life. As part of a lawsuit to recover financial compensation for their injuries, the injured person would have to present a comprehensive calculation for how much it will cost to cover the ongoing medical care and all the other costs associated with caring for someone with a permanent brain injury.

The injured person would work catastrophic injury attorney to develop a plan that would take into consideration their care at home or health care facility, what kinds of medical equipment they might require, medications and vocational issues such as their functional capacity.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, our TBI attorneys represent your interest when you have been hurt and have permanent injuries because of someone else&#x2019;s negligence. If you would like compassionate, yet aggressive representation, you are welcome to call our Kentucky lawyers at 877-686-8879, our Ohio team at 877-686-8879, or use our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to make an appointment now.

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: This Promising Cancer Vaccine Needs Our Help to Get it to the Public
BASENAME: promising-cancer-vaccine-needs-help-get-public
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/26/2017 04:46:43 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6272" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/GettyImages-845559356-300x199.jpg" alt="This Promising Cancer Vaccine Needs Our Help to Get it to the Public" width="300" height="199">October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month, a campaign designed to raise awareness about the signs and symptoms of breast cancer, and to help women and families find the resources they need if they are fighting cancer. Imagine, for a minute, how different things could be if October was National Breast Cancer <em>Vaccine</em> Month, instead.

As it turns out, it could be &#x2013; thanks to <a href="https://www.lerner.ccf.org/immuno/tuohy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Dr. Vincent Tuohy</a> of the Cleveland Clinic. For the last 15 years, Dr. Tuohy has struggled to find funding for vaccines that could eradicate breast and ovarian cancers. <a href="http://www.freshwatercleveland.com/features/tuohy102617.aspx" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Fresh Water Cleveland</a> reports:

&#x201C;If Tuohy&apos;s lab results are any indication [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][of a vaccine that works], he may be well on his way. Over the last two years, Tuohy has been conducting animal research by transgenically manipulating mice to develop breast cancer within 10 months of age. Some of the mice were vaccinated at two months old, while others were not given vaccines. &#x2018;At 10 months, none [of the vaccinated mice] had tumors, and all of the control mice had tumors,&#x2019; says Tuohy, who has replicated the same results three times with success.&#x201D;

A vaccine that prevents breast cancer; that&#x2019;s 40,000 lives saved. A vaccine that can prevent ovarian cancer; that&#x2019;s another 15,000 women saved from death. A total of 55,000 lives could be saved <em>every year</em>.
<h2>Why doesn&#x2019;t anyone want to fund this extraordinary research?</h2>
It all comes down to money. The National Cancer Institute gives five times more money to treatment than it does to prevention, and they&#x2019;re not the only ones. Science is so focused on curing the disease once it develops, that it has largely ignored the idea of preventing that development in the first place.

Another concern, especially when it comes to cancer funding, is that &#x201C;cancer&#x201D; is not <em>a</em> disease &#x2013; it&#x2019;s hundreds of diseases, and those illnesses can be further split within each group. For example, the type of cancer Dr. Tuohy&#x2019;s vaccine would target is called Triple Negative Breast Cancer &#x2013; a cancer responsible for about 50% of all breast cancer-related deaths (though it only accounts for between 16% and 20% of all breast cancers.)

But once you have a vaccine that works for one, you can create different vaccines that would target others. And thanks to the efforts of a number of grassroots organizations, Dr. Tuohy was given a $6 million grant from the Department of Defense, of all things, to pursue his research. His paper about his work with a vaccine for ovarian cancer is scheduled to be published in the peer-reviewed journal <em>Society of Cancer Research</em> next month.
<h2>Help make a breast cancer vaccine a reality</h2>
The Cleveland community has stepped up efforts to help Dr. Tuohy, but this type of scientific breakthrough takes time, effort and money. One of the programs that supports Dr. Tuohy&#x2019;s efforts is <a href="http://www.brakesforbreasts.com/brakes-for-breasts" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Brakes for Breasts</a> &#x2013; an organization made up of more than 100 independent auto shops throughout the country, and started by two women from Cleveland. The Women Who Care About Breast Cancer Coalition, founded by Dr. Marjorie Moyar and Race for the Cure organizer Susan Larson, is also helping in the fight for funding, and has worked with organizations like Daughters of Penelope, the Philoptochos Society, and the Junior League.

Let&#x2019;s all do our part this year in the fight against breast cancer. Supporting the work of Dr. Tuohy&#x2019;s vaccines could ensure that he meets his goal of clinical trials in 2018. We hope you&#x2019;ll join us in helping him achieve that goal, and finding a way to prevent breast and ovarian cancer for good.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier medical malpractice and personal injury law firm serving clients throughout Ohio and Kentucky. To learn more about our services, please fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>, or call us: 877-686-8879 in Kentucky, and 877-686-8879 in Ohio.

&#xA0;[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: A Deadly Collision with a Fire Truck in Cleveland
BASENAME: deadly-collision-fire-truck-cleveland
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 11/06/2017 01:55:31 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6292" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/GettyImages-492262953-300x200.jpg" alt="A Deadly Collision with a Fire Truck in Cleveland" width="300" height="200">On October 9<sup>th</sup>, a ladder truck from the Cleveland Division of Fire was returning from a call when it was hit by a car. The woman driving the car was pronounced dead on the scene, and the force of the collision was enough to eject a car seat from the from the vehicle; thankfully, no child was in the seat at the time. According to <a href="http://fox8.com/2017/10/09/driver-killed-when-car-crashes-head-on-into-cleveland-fire-truck/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Fox 8 Cleveland</a>, &#x201C;Investigators reconstructed the crash to help determine exactly what happened. Police said they believe the woman was driving faster than the posted 25 mile-per-hour speed limit when she crossed the center line and hit the fire truck.&#x201D; One firefighter was taken to the hospital.

This was the second accident between a car and a CDF truck; a few hours earlier, on October 8<sup>th</sup>, a different ladder truck was blocking off an accident when a car struck it. In that collision, no one was injured, and no further details were given about that crash.
<h2>Ohio&#x2019;s laws regarding emergency vehicles</h2>
Under the law, Ohio considers these to be &#x201C;<a href="https://law.justia.com/codes/ohio/2016/title-45/chapter-4511/section-4511.01/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">public safety vehicles</a>:&#x201D;
<ul>
    <li>Ambulances</li>
    <li>Cop cars (including vehicles by local/municipal, state or federal officers)</li>
    <li>Fire trucks and vehicles used by volunteers</li>
    <li>EMS/EMTS trucks/vans</li>
</ul>
Anyone driving an emergency or public safety vehicle may pass through an intersection (including those with red lights) when he or she is responding to an emergency situation. They may also use &#x201C;<a href="https://law.justia.com/codes/ohio/2016/title-45/chapter-4511/section-4511.031/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">portable preemption signal devices&#x201D;</a> when responding to an emergency, which change the sequence of traffic lights, creating a &#x201C;green&#x201D; where there was one a red. In fact, public safety vehicles are exempt from <a href="https://law.justia.com/codes/ohio/2016/title-45/chapter-4511/section-4511.041/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">almost every traffic law</a> in Ohio, as long as the driver is &#x201C;responding to an emergency call, is equipped with and displaying at least one flashing, rotating, or oscillating light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of five hundred feet to the front of the vehicle and if the driver of the vehicle is giving an audible signal by siren, exhaust whistle, or bell,&#x201D; though &#x201C;This section does not relieve the driver of an emergency vehicle or public safety vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons and property upon the highway.&#x201D;

Of course, we want our emergency vehicles to be able to clear a path to the hospital or the scene of a crime, and to get to whomever needs them &#x2013; but this can sometimes create confusion on the roadways. That is why, once a driver hears the signal or sees the flashing light, he or she must be aware of where the vehicle is, and yield the right of way. If a fire truck, ambulance, police car or other emergency vehicle is behind you on any road, or traveling in the opposite direction towards you on a one-lane roadway, you should immediately pull to the right to get out of the way. If one of these vehicles is approaching an intersection, but you would normally have the right of way, proceed slowly so the emergency vehicle can cross through an intersection.

Emergency services cannot behave recklessly, because the safety of other drivers is one of their priorities. But they are given leeway in following the rules when responding to a fire or a call, and as such, we must be on guard when we share the road with them.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier personal injury firm serving clients throughout Ohio and Kentucky. To learn more about our services, or to schedule a free consultation with an experienced Ohio truck accident lawyer, please call<strong>&#xA0;</strong>877-686-8879 or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>. You can reach out Kentucky attorneys at 877-686-8879.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Medical Review Panels Deemed Unconstitutional by Kentucky Judge
BASENAME: medical-review-panels-deemed-unconstitutional-kentucky-judge
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/31/2017 01:45:37 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6283" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/GettyImages-584207652-300x200.jpg" alt="Medical Review Panels Deemed Unconstitutional by Kentucky Judge" width="300" height="200">Franklin Circuit Judge Philip Shepherd has come down on the side of justice, and declared Kentucky&#x2019;s new law regarding medical review panels is unconstitutional. The <a href="http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/politics/ky-legislature/2017/10/30/medical-review-panels-law-kentucky-struck-down/812570001/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Courier-Journal</a> cited Judge Shepherd&#x2019;s order:

&quot;The effect of the medical review panel process is not the reduction of frivolous negligence claims, but rather, the erection of barriers to the court system. Those that cannot afford the additional delays and costs should not be prevented from pursuing their constitutional right to a &apos;remedy by due course of law.&apos; &quot;

Plans to challenge the order are already being made by the Governor&#x2019;s office, according to a spokeswoman. For now, however, the rights of victims of medical malpractice are safe in Kentucky.
<h2>Why Kentucky&#x2019;s medical review panels posed a problem to malpractice victims</h2>
On June 29, 2017, Kentucky implemented a law that required victims of medical malpractice and nursing home abuse and neglect, to submit all lawsuits to the Cabinet for Health and Family Services. Once submitted, a panel of three medical providers and one attorney were supposed to review the case within 6 months of receiving it. Even if they felt no negligence had occurred, their opinion would be submitted, <em>as evidence</em>, into any lawsuit brought before a court.

<strong>Read more:</strong>
<ul>
    <li><a href="https://www.patientsrightsblog.com/kentucky-news-laws-effect-think-know/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Kentucky Has Some News Laws in Effect That We Think You Should Know About</a></li>
    <li><a href="https://www.patientsrightsblog.com/medical-malpractice-review-panels-become-kentucky-law/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Medical Malpractice Review Panels Become Kentucky Law</a></li>
    <li>Kentucky Medical Malpractice Screening Panels</li>
    <li><a href="https://www.patientsrightsblog.com/tort-reform-damage-caps-protect-hospitals-not-patients/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Tort Reform and Damage Caps Protect Hospitals, Not Patients</a></li>
    <li>Kentucky Legislation to Establish Medical Review Panel</li>
    <li>Kentucky&#x2019;s Senate Bill 6 Can Only Harm Injury Victims</li>
</ul>
The State claimed this would cut down on the number of &#x201C;frivolous&#x201D; lawsuits brought against facilities each year. But as any plaintiff&#x2019;s medical malpractice attorney, or victim of medical malpractice, could tell you, this assumption is based on myths.

<strong>First</strong>, there are very few frivolous medical malpractice lawsuits because the costly expenses associated with bringing these cases. Necessary expert fees and document production can cost hundreds of thousands of dollars if a case goes to trial; Crandall &amp; Pera Law regularly takes cases that cost that much or more. All of those costs are paid out by the firm, because our attorneys work on contingency. If we took cases without merit, our firm would be bankrupted &#x2013; and so would every other plaintiff firm in the country. In fact, that is one of many reasons most Crandall &amp; Pera Law cases are referrals from other firms: we have the financial resources to prosecute even the most complex malpractice case.

<strong>Second</strong>, you have the right to a fair trial. An opinion submitted by doctors about doctors is hardly unbiased in and of itself; in a trial situation, it would be a boon to the defense, making the playing field unlevel. Furthermore, the doctors on the panel do not even have to practice in the specialty that caused you harm. As Judge Shepherd points out in his order, &#x201C;a dermatologist or social worker might be called upon to render an opinion about malpractice allegations against a brain surgeon.&quot;

<strong>Finally</strong>, the fees of the panel &#x2013; which could run to the thousands of dollars &#x2013; would need to be paid by the party it sides with. Who do you think has more money: a hospital, or a single mother of three who cannot work because a surgical error left her unable to walk?

Judge Shepherd did the honorable thing, by ensuring justice for the victims of medical malpractice. We have fought against this law before, and we will fight against it in the future, if it is challenged by the state. Crandall &amp; Pera Law will always fight for people who have been hurt by medical malpractice, another person&#x2019;s negligent actions, or because of the abuse or neglect of nursing home staff. To learn more about our services, or to speak with a Kentucky injury lawyer, please call 877-686-8879 or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form.</a> We also offer injury and medical malpractice services in Ohio: 877-686-8879.

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: The Cleveland Clinic Foundation Isn&#x2019;t the Hospital System It Says It Is
BASENAME: cleveland-clinic-foundation-isnt-hospital-system-says
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 10/30/2017 09:57:04 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6279" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/The-Cleveland-Clinic-Foundation-Isn&#x2019;t-the-Hospital-System-It-Says-It-Is-300x200.jpg" alt="The Cleveland Clinic Foundation Isn&#x2019;t the Hospital System It Says It Is" width="300" height="200">The Cleveland Clinic right here in Ohio enjoys a certain reputation for excellence. In fact, <em>U.S. News &amp; World Report </em>ranks them <a href="https://health.usnews.com/best-hospitals/area/oh/cleveland-clinic-6410670" target="_blank" rel="noopener">second in the nation</a> for overall care. If you weren&#x2019;t from the area, you might think that having the Cleveland Clinic right around the corner would be a boon, if you ever needed care.

We are, however, from the area. And we also know that the <em>U.S. News</em> ranking is an outlier. The fact is, when you look at every other ranking system, the Cleveland Clinic Foundation has a long and storied history of problems, is frequently cited for its dangerous processes and environments, and is repeatedly subject to lawsuits alleging medical negligence and malpractice. We should know; Steve Crandall won a $7.7 million jury verdict against the Cleveland Clinic Foundation in 2014 for malpractice, on behalf of one of its own neurosurgeons &#x2013; and that is not the only case our firm has taken.
<h2>How bad are the Cleveland Clinic Foundation&#x2019;s safety scores, really?</h2>
In December of 2014, Kaiser Health News released a <a href="http://cdn.kaiserhealthnews.org/attachments/HACPenaltyChart.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">penalty chart</a> for every hospital that accepted Medicare patients, with scores regarding their ability to eliminate hospital-acquired infections. Each facility was given a score of 1-10 (1 being the best, and 10 being the worst) for central-line associated bloodstream infections, catheter associated urinary tract infections, and serious complications, like blood clots, falls and bed sores. Each of these conditions, remember, are largely preventable.

Here are the Cleveland Clinic Foundation&#x2019;s scores:
<ul>
    <li>Serious complications: 10</li>
    <li>Central line infections: 8</li>
    <li>Urinary tract infections: 7</li>
    <li><strong>Total HAC score: 8.375</strong></li>
</ul>
Even though the CCF has been routinely ranked as one of the best hospitals in the country, they were penalized by Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) for how poorly they handled HACs.

And that is only one group.
<h2>Recent rankings from &#x201C;respected&#x201D; databases</h2>
Here is how the Cleveland Clinic Foundation measures up now, according to three popular data collators.

<strong>Leapfrog Group</strong>

The news about the CCF&#x2019;s problems started really making headlines in 2012, when the Leapfrog Group gave the Clinic a <a href="http://www.healthleadersmedia.com/leadership/leapfrogs-new-safety-report-card-alarms-hospitals" target="_blank" rel="noopener">safety score of &#x201C;D.&#x201D;</a> Its most recent grade is an &#x201C;A,&#x201D; so it looks like the Clinic made a massive improvement in only 5 years &#x2013; pretty impressive, no?

Well, actually, no. And here is why: Leapfrog Group, like U<em>.S. News</em>, relies entirely on what is voluntarily given, as well as what can be found publicly, to grade its hospitals. Furthermore, with a little digging into that safety score, you realize that Leapfrog&#x2019;s scores are modal: they rely on whatever grade is earned the most often, not an average of the grades.

Here is how that plays out in the real world, using the category &#x201C;<a href="http://www.hospitalsafetygrade.org/h/cleveland-clinic-foundation" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Problems with Surgery</a>.&#x201D; There are 7 areas of that particular category. The Cleveland Clinic earned a ranking of &#x201C;above average&#x201D; in four of them:
<ol>
    <li><strong>Surgical wound splits open</strong>: someone monitors surgery patients to ensure that their stitches stay intact.</li>
    <li><strong>Death from treatable serious complications</strong>: patients are monitored to ensure that no complications arise, and if they do, those patients are treated correctly so the patient doesn&#x2019;t die.</li>
    <li><strong>Collapsed lung</strong>: they can treat a collapsed lung.</li>
    <li><strong>Accidental cuts and tears</strong>: surgeons don&#x2019;t cut where they&#x2019;re not supposed to cut.</li>
</ol>
Note that these &#x201C;above average&#x201D; scores don&#x2019;t indicate how often collapsed lungs happen, or how quickly patients are treated if they develop a complication. All we know for sure is that the surgeons <em>can</em> treat the condition, and that people don&#x2019;t die from complications that often.

Now, let us look at the other three areas:
<ol>
    <li><strong>Serious breathing problem</strong>: a complication that sometimes develops after surgery. CCF is ranked &#x201C;average&#x201D; in this category.</li>
    <li><strong>Dangerous object left in patient&#x2019;s body</strong>: the textbook example of a &#x201C;never event.&#x201D; CCF is ranked &#x201C;below average&#x201D; in this category.</li>
    <li><strong>Dangerous blood clot</strong>: clots can form when tissue is damaged during surgery. If the clots travel into the brain or heart, they can be fatal. CCF is ranked &#x201C;below average&#x201D; for the number of their patients who develop clots.</li>
</ol>
If you took an average of these categories, the grade would <em>not</em> be an &#x201C;A.&#x201D; But Leapfrog doesn&#x2019;t average its scores, and that is why a hospital like the Cleveland Clinic Foundation, which scores below average when it comes to leaving foreign objects inside of a body during surgery, can still be rated as an &#x201C;A&#x201D; hospital.

And to add insult to injury? The Clinic didn&#x2019;t supply any data at all when it came to <a href="http://www.leapfroggroup.org/hospital/profile/Cleveland+Clinic+Foundation" target="_blank" rel="noopener">infections</a>.

<strong>GuideStar</strong>

<a href="https://www.guidestar.org/Home.aspx" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GuideStar</a> bills itself as &#x201C;the world&apos;s largest source of information on nonprofit organizations.&#x201D; Since the Cleveland Clinic Foundation is a non-profit teaching hospital (with a budget of $4.5 billion), GuideStar includes it in its database.

But just like Leapfrog, GuideStar relies on entirely <a href="https://www.guidestar.org/profile/91-2153073" target="_blank" rel="noopener">self-reported information</a>. The data and information you see has been written by the CCF, and provided to GuideStar. Its financials and operations are behind a paywall, but there is a section titled &#x201C;Board Leadership Practices,&#x201D; which reviews things like CEO oversight, and assessment of the Board&#x2019;s performance. This section also covers ethics and transparency, and is, interestingly enough, is left blank.

<strong>Consumer Reports</strong>

Consumer Reports also offers a ranking system for the Cleveland Clinic Foundation. Their overall Safety Score is a 54, and <a href="https://www.consumerreports.org/cro/2012/10/how-we-rate-hospitals/index.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">their rankings</a> are based on information provided by the CMS, and &#x201C;from scientifically-based data on patient experience and outcomes as well as certain hospital practices gathered from public sources. Some of that information is available elsewhere.&#x201D; That data includes information about:
<ul>
    <li>Hospital-acquired infections (central line infections, surgical site infections, MRSA, <em> diff</em> and catheter-associated urinary tract infections)</li>
    <li>Childbirth (and avoiding C-sections)</li>
    <li>Safety scores (hospital acquired infections, readmissions, mortality &#x2013; and its avoidance &#x2013; scans, medication and communication)</li>
    <li>Heat surgery (bypass, aortic valve and congenital)</li>
    <li>Patient experience</li>
</ul>
The also review cleanliness of rooms and bathrooms, communication, and pain control, among others.

In the Consumer Reports review, Cleveland Clinic Foundation is all over the map, scoring &#x201C;better&#x201D; than average for chest scanning, but &#x201C;worse&#x201D; than average when it comes to the readmissions of Medicare patients. You can <a href="https://www.consumerreports.org/health/hospitals/cleveland-clinic/safety-score/6410670/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">find all of their rankings here</a>.
<h2>Medical negligence lawsuits in Ohio</h2>
There is no one database that contains the exact number of medical malpractice lawsuits have been filed against the Cleveland Clinic Foundation, or how many people have died as a result of poor care. Because of the <a href="https://www.npdb.hrsa.gov/resources/npdbstats/npdbStatistics.jsp#contentTop" target="_blank" rel="noopener">National Practitioner Data Base</a>, we can tell you that there were 216 medical malpractice payments made by Ohio doctors in 2016, and that there were 2,283 adverse actions reported. We can tell that you 2,088 doctors had state licensure actions taken, but only 24 doctors were involved in anything regarding their clinical privileges.

To recap: there were 2,283 cases of adverse actions, but only 24 doctors had their clinical privileges revoked.
<h2>Why all of these numbers matter</h2>
We know that most people rely on reviews &#x2013; either from friends or from online &#x2013; when they want to try a new service or product. We&#x2019;ve even recommended looking at the reviews ourselves, as part of your research. But you have to take them with a grain of salt, especially when they come from databases where self-reporting is necessary.

The Cleveland Clinic Foundation may have an &#x201C;A&#x201D; grade from one source, or a high rank from another, but the doctors and medical personnel there are just as fallible as any other, and, in some cases, more than others. If you sustained an injury because of medical malpractice, you shouldn&#x2019;t be afraid to come forward, just because it&#x2019;s a nationally known facility. The right malpractice attorney knows how to stand against up against the &#x201C;big guys,&#x201D; and will have the skills, experience and financial resources necessary to take them on when you&#x2019;ve been hurt.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier medical malpractice law firm serving clients throughout Ohio and Kentucky. We invite you to read more about our successful cases, and to <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> if you have any questions. To schedule an appointment in Ohio, please call 877-686-8879. For our Kentucky team, please call 877-686-8879.
-----

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: A Medical Emergency Leads to Fatal Multi-Car Crash on I-75
BASENAME: medical-emergency-leads-fatal-multi-car-crash-75
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 11/09/2017 09:27:30 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6297" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/A-Medical-Emergency-Leads-to-Fatal-Multi-Car-Crash-on-I-75-300x200.jpg" alt="A Medical Emergency Leads to Fatal Multi-Car Crash on I-75" width="300" height="200">On Monday, October 23<sup>rd</sup>, a tractor-trailer driver hauling plywood on I-75 lost control of his vehicle, hitting another car as he entered the median. The plywood came loose form the bed of the truck and flew across the lanes of traffic. Several cars were involved in the incident, according to the report on Kentucky.com, but the driver of the truck died at the hospital.

The loose cargo contributed to the swerving, and collisions, of the other vehicles at the scene, but it was a medical emergency that started the cascade effect. The <a href="https://www.fmcsa.dot.gov/regulations/medical/medical-examination-report-form-commercial-driver-medical-certification" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration</a> (FMCSA) &#x201C;requires that interstate commercial motor vehicle drivers maintain a current Medical Examiner&#x2019;s Certificate (MEC), Form MCSA-5876 to drive. As part of the physical, drivers are required to fill out the medical history portion of the Medical Examination Report (MER) Form, MCSA-5875.&#x201D; On their site, they have packages related to hearing, vision, seizures and diabetes, all of which require separate guidelines and actions from their drivers.

The FMCSA requires drivers to be <a href="https://www.fmcsa.dot.gov/faq/what-happens-if-driver-not-truthful-about-hisher-health-history-medical-examination" target="_blank" rel="noopener">truthful in their medical history</a>. In fact, &#x201C;Deliberate omission or falsification of information may invalidate the examination and any certificate issued based on it. A civil penalty may also be levied against the driver under 49 U.S.C. 521(b)(2)(b), either for making a false statement of for concealing a disqualifying condition.&#x201D;

However, a medical condition will not necessarily disqualify a driver from being issued an MEC; some conditions, like diabetes, high blood pressure and stable angina have exemption clauses. Prescribed medications, including controlled substances, are also allowed, provided the driver&#x2019;s doctor says that the driver is safe to work as long as he or she takes the medication.
<h2>Assessing liability in a medical emergency that leads to a truck accident</h2>
Let us say, for example, that a driver with a perfectly healthy medical record suffers a heart attack while behind the wheel of the truck. If there is no previous medical history to indicate a potential heart attack, and if he or she tests clean for all drug use &#x2013; if it really was, by all accounts, an unavoidable emergency &#x2013; then the driver and his company may not be liable for the damages.

In some cases, however, multiple parties may be liable for the truck crash, including the driver, the trucking company, the medical examiner, the doctor or even the drug manufacturer. Those cases might include:
<ul>
    <li>The driver deliberately lying about his or her history</li>
    <li>The driver using medication or controlled substances while not under the supervision or prescription of the doctor</li>
    <li>The trucking company failing to disqualify a driver whose health indicates he or she is unsafe to drive</li>
    <li>Deliberate omission or falsifications by the doctor or medical examiner, leading to a driver being certified when he or she should not have been</li>
    <li>A defective medical device, such as a pacemaker, failing to function while the driver is on the road</li>
    <li>A dangerous reaction to a prescription drug that was not previously disclosed to the driver</li>
</ul>
One of the first things our Kentucky truck accident lawyers do, when looking into a collision, is request a copy of the black box data. Commercial trucks have devices which can record what happened before the crash. While the device will not specifically say &#x201C;The driver had a heart attack,&#x201D; the information it provides can help fill in any gaps about what happened.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we fight on behalf of people who have sustained serious, life-threatening injuries because of a collision with a commercial vehicle. If you were hurt in a truck crash, our Kentucky team is ready to help. Please call 877-686-8879 or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to learn more. You can also reach us in Ohio by calling 877-686-8879.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Neglected WWII Vet Dies in Nursing Home, Crying Out for Help
BASENAME: neglected-wwii-vet-dies-nursing-home-crying-help
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 11/20/2017 01:30:48 PM
-----
BODY:
James Dempsey was a decorated WWII veteran. He died in 2014, at the age of 94, while at the Northeast Atlanta Health and Rehabilitation Center. On the day he died, he called out for help six times: &#x201C;Nurse, help me please!&#x201D; he called. &#x201C;I can&#x2019;t breathe.&#x201D;

By the time the nurses showed up, Mr. Dempsey was unresponsive. It took an hour before anyone called 911. The staff started and stopped CPR multiple times, and laughed when they could not get his oxygen machine to work. We know this happened, because a DeKalb County judge allowed WXIA-TV to publish the <a href="https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/disturbing-video-shows-dying-wwii-vet-neglected-nursing-home-193149764.html?.tsrc=fauxdal" target="_blank" rel="noopener">hidden camera video footage</a> that showed exactly what happened.

<strong>WARNING:</strong> the following video is graphic in nature. Viewer discretion is advised.

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/lU6NlK3OQDc" width="650" height="366" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

The nursing home learned of the video in 2015, but it took then <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2017/11/18/veteran-dies-calling-help-gasping/876787001/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">10 months to fire the nurses</a>, according to a <em>USA Today</em> report. <em>Newsweek</em> reports that it took until September of 2017 &#x2013; three years &#x2013; before the nurses were made to <a href="http://www.newsweek.com/nurses-laugh-wwii-veteran-calls-help-and-dies-716102" target="_blank" rel="noopener">surrender their licenses</a>. Northeast Atlanta Health and Rehabilitation is still open and operational, despite &#x201C;Medicare records show[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][ing] the nursing home facility was cited at least two dozen times for serious health and safety violations, including &#x2018;immediate jeopardy&#x2019; levels, the worst violation. Medicare withdrew one payment and the facility has been fined $813,113 since 2015.&#x201D;
<h2>This type of abuse and neglect is not unique to Georgia</h2>
What happened to Mr. Dempsey is horrific, but it is far from a one-off experience. In August of 2017, the Department of Health and Human Services Office of the Inspector General issued a memo about its ongoing research into reports of abuse and neglect in nursing homes which take on Medicare patients. (Private facilities, or facilities which do not accept Medicare, will not be included.) <a href="https://oig.hhs.gov/oas/reports/region1/11700504.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">That memo is damning:</a>

&#x201C;For example, OIG&#x2019;s recent audit reports on critical incident reporting at group homes showed that group home providers did not report up to 15 percent of critical incidents to the appropriate State agencies. Furthermore, OIG&#x2019;s study of adverse events in [Skilled Nursing Facilities, or SNFs] found that an estimated 22 percent of Medicare beneficiaries experienced adverse events during their SNF stays. These adverse events included infections, pressure ulcers, and medication-induced bleeding. Medical record review determined that 69 percent of these patient-harm events could have been prevented had the SNF provided better care. Over half of the residents harmed during their SNF stays required hospital care to treat the adverse event.&#x201D;

Kentucky has also had more than its fair share of problems when it comes to abuse and neglect. As we discussed in September, Kentucky is among the worst offenders in the country. Brian Lee, the executive director of the non-profit citizen advocacy group <a href="https://familiesforbettercare.com/about/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Families for Better Care</a>, told the&#xA0;<a href="http://kycir.org/2014/10/22/a-powerful-nursing-home-owner-and-a-push-for-medical-review-panels-in-kentucky/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Kentucky Center for Investigative Reporting</a> that &#x201C;there&#x2019;s widespread abuse, neglect, mistreatment of residents occurring in far too many nursing homes.&#x201D;

Earlier this year, the <em>Courier-Journal</em> reported on Kentucky&#x2019;s <a href="http://www.courier-journal.com/story/life/wellness/health/2017/07/11/kentucky-and-indiana-called-worst-u-s-long-term-care-elderly-disabled/417755001/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">poor rankings for long-term care services</a> for the elderly and disabled, as well as the State&#x2019;s programs for transitioning elderly individuals into assisted living facilities and nursing homes. The rankings, compiled by the AARP Foundation, said &#x201C;Kentucky&#x2019;s worst ranking &#x2013; 49th &#x2013; came in quality of life and quality of care. That&#x2019;s a broad category that encompasses such measures as the rate of employment for working-age adults with certain disabilities; the percent of high-risk nursing home residents with pressure sores; and the percent of long-stay nursing home residents who are receiving an antipsychotic medication.&#x201D;

What happened to Mr. Dempsey is beyond tragic. At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we fight on behalf of Kentucky families and nursing home residents who have suffered pain and loss because of the negligent or abusive actions of nurses, doctors, staff and volunteers. If your loved one has been hurt, we may be able to help. Please call&#xA0;877-686-8879&#xA0;or fill out our&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>&#xA0;to learn more.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Doctors Continue to Practice After Repeated Malpractice Suits
BASENAME: doctors-continue-practice-repeated-malpractice-suits
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 12/11/2017 01:56:00 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6364" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/GettyImages-695337976-1-300x132.jpg" alt="Doctors Continue to Practice After Repeated Malpractice Suits" width="300" height="132">The public often has a distorted idea of what happens when a doctor is charged with medical malpractice. A common assumption is that, if the charge is meritorious, the doctor will no longer practice medicine. Thus, when doctors continue to practice after one or more meritorious cases of malpractice, their patients are often rightfully concerned. In Kentucky and Ohio, the prevalence of medical professionals continuing to practice regardless of the number of cases against them, even if many have been settled, continues to grow. Many patients are none the wiser since the information is not required to be provided to patients.
<h2><strong><em>What happens after a malpractice suit?</em></strong></h2>
Depending on the disposition of the suit &#x2013; whether it went to trial and the doctor was found guilty or not, or whether it was settled out of court &#x2013; the outcome for the doctor could be very different. If the case went to trial and was dismissed, while there will still be a record of the accusation and charges, no action will be taken in terms of consequences. In cases that have been settled, or wherein the doctor was found liable, there is usually a financial payment to compensate the injured patient. This creates a permanent record of the charge. Depending on the severity, the doctor may lose his or her license to practice medicine in the state. However, the overwhelming majority of negligent doctors suffer no consequences other than their insurance premiums rising, due to a claim having been paid.

The penalties surrounding licensing are not decided by the court, but rather by the State Medical Board, which has considerable discretion about punitive measures. Even if a doctor admits to committing &#xA0;medical malpractice, he or she will not likely have any action taken against their license to practice medicine. Every case is unique.
<h2><strong><em>How to protect yourself and your family from dangerous doctors</em></strong></h2>
Unfortunately, the onus for checking whether your family doctor has been sued for malpractice, or settled such suits, is on you. While the state licensure board is responsible for disciplining or removing dangerous doctors from practice, many escape consequences. One Kentucky report for the years 1990-2002 found that only one quarter (<a href="https://www.citizen.org/sites/default/files/ky_medmal_report.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">24%</a>) of doctors with five or more medical malpractice payouts were disciplined by the Board. However, the information for malpractice suits and settlements can often be obtained via the internet.

The Ohio State Medical Board does not directly address malpractice claims for the public, but licensing information is <a href="https://elicense.ohio.gov/OH_HomePage" target="_blank" rel="noopener">online</a>, provided you know the doctor&#x2019;s first and last name. In Kentucky, the same data is also freely accessible <a href="http://www.docinfo.org/#!/search/query" target="_blank" rel="noopener">online</a>. For information about whether claims have been brought against your doctor in either Kentucky or Ohio, you can call the County Clerk&#x2019;s office directly, because these lawsuits are public record. Before seeing any new doctor, it is wise to check his or her licensing status and whether any legal action has been taken against him or her. The <a href="https://www.bbb.org/en/us/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Better Business Bureau website</a> is another resource to check for issues.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, our medical malpractice attorneys are here to be your voice when doctors fail in their required standard of care, for your or for a family member. If you are seeking a caring, yet aggressive legal representative, please contact our Kentucky lawyers at 877-686-8879, our Ohio lawyers at 877-686-8879, or use our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to make an appointment.
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Medical Device Tracking Needed to Protect Consumers
BASENAME: medical-device-tracking-needed-to-protect-consumers
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 12/04/2017 01:34:16 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6349" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/GettyImages-468837188-300x229.jpg" alt="Medical Device Tracking Needed to Protect Consumers" width="300" height="229">When your car has a recall, you might get a letter in the mail, or an email, or even a personal phone call from the dealership where you purchased it. If a food in your fridge is recalled, you can check your receipt and the tracking information on the product itself to see if it is a concern. But what happens when your implanted hip replacement or pacemaker has an issue?

That is the basis of a new effort by consumer advocates who wish to know the serial numbers on medical implants. The laws exist already to move forward with <a href="http://www.startribune.com/effort-to-improve-tracking-of-medical-devices-divides-industry-consumer-groups/451942493/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">unique device identifiers</a>, or UDIs &#x2013; but no one seems to know just how to start implementing those laws.
<h2><strong><em>Growing population, urgent need </em></strong></h2>
Implanted medical devices go far beyond joints and hearts, into nearly every category of medicine available, including:
<ul>
    <li>Sensory and brain implants, such as cochlear implants and neurostimulators</li>
    <li>Heart and circulatory implants, like stents, artificial hearts, and pacemakers</li>
    <li>Bone and joint implants, including pins, rods, plates, joints, and screws</li>
    <li>Contraceptive implants, both intrauterine and placed elsewhere in the body</li>
    <li>Cosmetic and prosthetic implants</li>
    <li>Urological implants, for issues such as bladder or fecal incontinence, including transvaginal mesh</li>
</ul>
According to the American Joint Replacement Registry, nearly <a href="https://www.odtmag.com/contents/view_online-exclusives/2016-12-12/american-joint-replacement-registry-releases-third-annual-report/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">half a million joint replacement surgeries</a> alone were done in the US between 2012 and 2015. The number of Americans walking around with an unregistered, untraceable, and potentially defective medical implant or device is staggering.<strong><em>&#xA0;</em></strong>
<h2><strong><em>Consumer protection and accountability</em></strong></h2>
If automotive dealers can implement infrastructure, paperwork, and fees associated with VIN&#x2019;s, then it seems entirely feasible for the healthcare and insurance industries to do the same. The problem, however, is twofold: first patient privacy laws, to start, may prohibit the transmission of information about patients to manufactures. This means the collection work would have to be done by someone else.

Manufacturers do support a detailed data collection record. The Executive Vice President of device manufacturer AdvaMed, a man named Don May, told the <em>Star Tribune</em> &quot;We support the collection of the UDI in the electronic health record, where it can actually be used to really help track patient outcomes and be used in a more proactive way around postmarket surveillance. If we are really concerned about patient safety, then let&apos;s go to the tool that makes the most sense.&quot;

This leads us to point number two: the &#x201C;someone else&#x201D; in charge of data collection &#x2013; Medicare. This will be a time-consuming and costly process, and Medicare may not be sufficient for the task. The funds will need to come from somewhere, but this federal program may not be able to supply them.

The best possible outcome for patients would be a threefold responsibility process. Manufacturers of all medical devices need to use the same format and issue alerts through a nationwide system accessible to both medical professionals and individuals; doctors and healthcare facilities practitioners need to conscientiously track patients&#x2019; implants throughout their lives; and insurance companies need to assist in maintaining accurate patient contact records for each implant.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, our defective medical device attorneys make sure your voice is heard when health care companies sell dangerous products.&#xA0; If you need considerate, yet tenacious legal representation, please contact our Ohio lawyers at 877-686-8879, our Kentucky attorneys at 877-686-8879, or use our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to make an appointment.

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Pediatric Neurosurgeons Operate Before Birth to Improve Outcomes for Infants with Spina Bifida
BASENAME: pediatric-neurosurgeons-operate-birth-improve-outcomes-infants-spina-bifida
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 11/30/2017 11:22:17 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6344" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/GettyImages-481826196-300x200.jpg" alt="Pediatric Neurosurgeons Operate Before Birth to Improve Outcomes for Infants with Spina Bifida" width="300" height="200">Spina bifida affects 1 in 1,000 births worldwide, and while the causes of the disease are not fully understood, there seems to be a link to a <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/tools-of-the-trade/the-benefits-of-folic-acid/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">lack of prenatal folic acid</a>. The severity of spina bifida varies from case to case, but it involves the tissue of the spinal cord failing to fully close, leading to issues with mobility, bladder and bowel issues, and hydrocephalus (fluid buildup in the brain).

Surgeons have been exploring fetal surgery for spina bifida for over 20 years to reduce the severity of the defect, as spinal column exposure to amniotic fluid exacerbates the damage. The risk of early delivery as a result has always been present, but a new surgical technique, including the use of a fiber optic fetoscope, is making it possible to operate earlier, preserving more spinal cord functionality and leading to better outcomes for children and families. However, future risks remain for mothers who have undergone these procedures.
<h2><strong><em>Surgery before birth</em></strong></h2>
Beginning in the 1990s, medical professionals developed the open procedure, wherein the uterus is lifted out of the mother&#x2019;s abdomen, cut, and then surgery is performed on the fetus, before it is returned to the uterus, which is then mechanically shut and returned to the mother&#x2019;s abdomen. The <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/23/health/fetal-surgery-spina-bifida.html?_r=0" target="_blank" rel="noopener">new surgical procedure</a> still involves removing the uterus from the mother&#x2019;s abdomen; however, at that point instead of making one or more large cuts, a device called a fetoscope is used through one small incision and tools through a second small incision. These fewer, smaller wounds are less injurious to the uterus,&#xA0; not unlike the way laparoscopic tools reduce recovery time for joint and other surgeries. Additionally, the use of a fetoscope allows mothers to carry their pregnancies closer to full-term than the former open procedure allowed.

One other notable difference between the open and fetoscopic procedures is how the surgeons inflate and reflate the uterus. In the open version, amniotic fluid is saved and replaced at the end of the surgery. In the fetoscopic version, the amniotic fluid is drained, the uterus is inflated with carbon dioxide during the procedure to give doctors the best visualization of the spina bifida defect as they repair it, and then the uterus is refilled with saline solution. There is some concern that carbon dioxide could lead to neurological issues after delivery, but no consensus has been reached on the issue.
<h2><strong><em>Risks to mother and infant</em></strong></h2>
Any pre-birth surgery carries the danger of inducing labor; therefore, surgeons only perform the surgery on fetuses who have passed the point of viability, around 500 grams or 24 weeks gestational age. The perils of &#x201C;uncomplicated&#x201D; <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/labor/dealing-with-preterm-labor/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">preterm birth</a> for underage or underweight infants vary, but can lead to physical and mental disabilities, or even death. Birth injuries are also possible, due to the undeveloped musculoskeletal system of the infants involved. Threats are also present for mothers who undergo these procedures, regardless of the fetal outcome. Spina bifida pre-birth surgeries that involve fully cutting into the uterus can lead to uterine scarring, which in turn increases the incidence of cesarean section births for future pregnancies. When surgical errors occur, the outcomes can be dire for mothers and potentially impact their future fertility.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, our birth injury attorneys represent the interests of your family and your child, when he or she suffered harm during the birth process. If you are looking for compassionate, yet determined legal representation, please call our Ohio lawyers at 877-686-8879, our Kentucky lawyers at 877-686-8879, or use our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to make an appointment now.

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;
-----

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Tesla Announces New State-of-the-Art Electric Semi-Trucks
BASENAME: tesla-announces-new-state-art-electric-semi-trucks
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 12/28/2017 03:00:42 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6418" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/GettyImages-531622164-300x200.jpg" alt="Tesla Announces New State-of-the-Art Electric Semi-Trucks " width="300" height="200">The future is officially here. Elon Musk&#x2019;s Tesla company has developed a rig that can travel <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/innovations/wp/2017/11/17/teslas-latest-creation-an-electric-big-rig-that-can-travel-500-miles-on-a-single-charge/?utm_term=.8aedcf39877f" target="_blank" rel="noopener">500 miles on just one single charge</a>. The announcement is a follow-up to Tesla&#x2019;s difficulties in developing Tesla 3, which was intended to be a mass-market electric sedan. Musk&#x2019;s bold claims have the industry talking about the future of trucking and the safety of these semi-trucks.

Musk makes quite a few claims about the new vehicles, including:
<ul>
    <li>The ride is so smooth that truck drivers will feel like they are driving a racecar.</li>
    <li>The computer display panels make it so easy to operate that non-truck drivers can drive it smoothly.</li>
    <li>The new truck does not produce any emissions, which makes it environmentally friendly.</li>
    <li>The newly designed big rigs perform as well or better than a diesel engine, at a much better price than current rigs.</li>
    <li>The trucks can go 500 miles on just one battery charge, and travel 60 mph during that trip. Musk claims that since the average semi-rig trip is less than 250 miles, a truck should be able to make two trips on a single charge.</li>
    <li>The trucks can charge during a driver&#x2019;s 30-minute break or while the inventory is being unloaded.</li>
    <li>The trucks will need little maintenance because they do not have transmissions or gears and have four motors. Musk made the bold claim that his company&#x2019;s new trucks should be able to travel a million miles without breaking down.</li>
    <li>The autopilot standard should improve safety.</li>
</ul>
Walmart has already announced it will buy fifteen of the new Tesla trucks, and other trucking companies are getting on board as well. However, many in the trucking industry are skeptical about Musk&#x2019;s ability to deliver on these claims. The failure of the sedan electric model has made potential buyers hesitant to order the new trucks.
<h2>Who is liable in a collision with a Tesla truck?</h2>
Right now, if you are in a collision with a traditional commercial vehicle, you have a few options for recovering damages: you can make a claim against the manufacturer of the truck (if there is a defective part); you can make a claim against the driver; and/or you can make a claim against the trucking company or employer. When Tracy Morgan was hit by a Wal-Mart truck a few years ago, he sued Wal-Mart. (The driver himself faced criminal charges.)

But if one of these trucks is involved in a collision, whose fault is it? If there is a defect in the truck or its software, then Tesla could be held liable. If the truck is not properly maintained, then it might fall to the companies which buy the trucks. Furthermore, the idea that it is so easy to drive that even a non-CDL licensed driver could handle it is also a bit worrying. You have to pass a specific test to driver a tractor-trailer, and undergo training to learn how to maneuver these giant vehicles on the road. All the touch screens in the world won&#x2019;t help if the driver doesn&#x2019;t understand the importance of cargo load weight, or if he or she becomes distracted.

Finally, there is the issue of the autopilot feature. While some people herald driverless vehicles as the safer alternative, we&#x2019;re not so sure. After all, &#x201C;Tesla&#x2019;s &#x2018;Autopilot&#x2019; system [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][in its cars] is designed to perform limited tasks.... However, the system is meant to augment, not replace the driver. The vehicle&#x2019;s human driver and his overreliance on the system were at fault [for a crash in 2016], the NTSB concluded,&#x201D; per the <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/trafficandcommuting/how-safe-is-safe-enough-to-put-driverless-cars-on-the-nations-roadways/2017/12/10/9a1aa348-d519-11e7-b62d-d9345ced896d_story.html?utm_term=.66b2c99263f7" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>Washington Post</em></a>. If a truck driver feels he or she doesn&#x2019;t need to pay as close attention, because the autopilot is in control, there could be more accidents, not fewer &#x2013; and then the battle begins as to who will be held accountable for the injuries you sustained.

It&#x2019;s not that Tesla&#x2019;s invention isn&#x2019;t extraordinary, or that we oppose driverless vehicles in theory; we just want to make sure the laws are equipped to handle these new types of claims. Legal battles over who is liable just stretch out the amount of time it takes for an injury victim to receive his or her compensation &#x2013; time that he or she might not have. Our first priority is always to those who need it, no matter what happens.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, our Kentucky truck accident lawyers are committed to helping victims of truck driving accidents and the families of deceased victims get justice. We will hold manufacturers liable if their trucks are defective and have caused physical and emotional harm. Please call us at 877-686-8879 or use our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to review your case with our experienced attorneys.
