AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: 58-Year Old Woman Killed by a Truck Driver Whose License Was Suspended
BASENAME: 58-year-old-woman-killed-truck-driver-whose-license-suspended
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 12/26/2017 01:41:28 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6415" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/GettyImages-472355114-1-300x171.jpg" alt="58-Year Old Woman Killed by a Truck Driver Whose License Was Suspended" width="300" height="171">This past October, the <em>Journal News</em> reported that a <a href="http://www.journal-news.com/news/truck-driver-license-was-suspended-time-fatal-hamilton-crash/Qg465CwlEgzB6eebGEuaXJ/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">concrete bucket truck crashed</a> into the rear-end of an SUV, killing the vehicle&#x2019;s driver and causing the car to burst into flames. The driver of the truck, according to the Hamilton Police department, did not have a valid operator&#x2019;s license. Investigators believe that the truck was going 65-mph in a 35-mph zone, and that failure of the brakes to work properly appears to have contributed to the truck crash.

The 58-year old woman who was killed in the accident was a hospital nurse who left behind a husband, two sons and two grandchildren.
<h2>Liability for this accident</h2>
Who is liable in this case depends on a full investigation and an examination of the truck&#x2019;s braking systems. The possible defendants include:
<ul>
    <li>The driver, due to the fact that he was speeding and failed to have control of the truck.</li>
    <li>The trucking company, if they were aware that the operator&#x2019;s license was suspended or failed to inquire about the license.</li>
    <li>The manufacturer of the brakes, if the brakes were defective and their failure caused the accident.</li>
</ul>
The husband and sons of the woman can claim wrongful death damages against the responsible parties. The parents of the woman could also demand damages. Wrongful death damages include the funeral and hospital bills, as well as the loss of financial and emotional support the woman would have provided each family member. They also include the pain and anguish of the family members, the loss of guidance and care she would have given her loved ones, and any likely inheritances.

In addition, experienced Ohio truck accident lawyers will likely claim that the driver should pay punitive damages due to the fact that his license was suspended. If the trucking company was aware of the license suspension, they may also be responsible for punitive damages.

If you were injured in a truck accident or a loved one was tragically killed, the experienced Ohio truck crash lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can help. We have an impressive record of truck accident settlements and jury awards. Please call us at 877-686-8879 or use our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to review your case with our experienced attorneys.

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: For the Victims of Amtrak&#x2019;s Latest Crash, There is Still More Horror to Come
BASENAME: victims-amtraks-latest-crash-still-horror-come
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 12/21/2017 01:56:17 PM
-----
BODY:
[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][caption id=&quot;attachment_6412&quot; align=&quot;alignright&quot; width=&quot;300&quot;]<img class="size-medium wp-image-6412" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Screen-Shot-2017-12-21-at-11.54.24-AM-300x194.png" alt="For the Victims of Amtrak&#x2019;s Latest Crash, There is Still More Horror to Come" width="300" height="194"> Photo Credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times[/caption]

On December 18<sup>th</sup>, An Amtrak train, traveling from Seattle to Portland, derailed in DuPont, Washington. Thirteen cars jumped the tracks, several of which fell over the side of an overpass and onto the highway below, damaging five different vehicles. Around 100 people sustained injuries, and three fatalities have been reported thus far.

The Amtrak Cascades 501 train was traveling about 80 mph when it came into the turn &#x2013; an eerily similar scenario to the 2015 Amtrak 188 crash in Philadelphia. That derailment left eight people dead.

The initial shock of the derailment is still being processed, and the injured may still be tending to their wounds. The families of the victims may be in the midst of planning funerals. The entire situation is awful &#x2013; and entirely preventable.
<h2>Failure to uphold the laws left three people dead</h2>
In 2008, a head-on train crash in California killed 25 people. In response to the tragedy, Congress mandated that all passenger railroads implement positive train control (PTC) safety systems by <a href="https://www.fra.dot.gov/ptc" target="_blank" rel="noopener">December 31, 2015</a>. PTC, in brief, can slow down a speeding train automatically, if it senses that the train is moving too quickly. Had it been implemented the way the law required, Amtrak 501 would not have been able to hit a 30 mph curve at 80 mph; it would have automatically slowed down, to take the curve at a safer speed.

Instead, Congress kotowed to the railroads, extending the deadlines. As one <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/i-survived-an-amtrak-crash-this-weeks-victims-are-in-for-a-rude-awakening/2017/12/20/b0e9af4e-e5a7-11e7-a65d-1ac0fd7f097e_story.html?hpid=hp_no-name_opinion-card-b%3Ahomepage%2Fstory&amp;utm_term=.e2aaea9cd97e" target="_blank" rel="noopener">survivor of the Philadelphia crash</a> explained in an op-ed for the Washington Post, &#x201C;Railroads complained about the costs and threatened not to run their trains unless Congress pushed the deadline to 2018. Congress caved completely, allowing railroads to defer PTC without penalty. Congress even allowed an additional loophole: If railroads &#x2018;showed progress,&#x2019; they didn&#x2019;t have to start using PTC until 2020.&#x201D;

Amtrak has installed PTC systems in its Northeast corridor, which runs from Boston to DC, but not on other commuter rail lines. The delay, in part, is caused by who uses the lines. Amtrak travels on some of the same rail lines as freighter trains &#x2013; and freight rail companies, as the <em>New York Times</em> explains, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/20/us/amtrak-train-safety.html?_r=0" target="_blank" rel="noopener">don&#x2019;t necessarily see the benefit in installing the systems.</a> (It is also safe to assume they would prefer not to have to pay for any costs associated with it, either.)

Furthermore, the rails themselves are owned by different regional transit authorities. When the Times tried to get a full answer from Sound Transit (which owns the track Amtrak 501 was traveling), the reporters were referred to Amtrak and Washington&#x2019;s Department of Transportation. When the reporters called Amtrak, they were told to call Sound Transit. No one wants to take accountability for yet another deadly-but-preventable crash.
<h2>Adding insult to literal injury</h2>
There is another problem for victims of the crash, as well. In 1997, Congress decided that all Amtrak claims would be capped at $200 million. That number was revised in 2015, to $295 million, after the Philadelphia derailment &#x2013; but as the writer for the Post explained:

&#x201C;that was far from sufficient to compensate the eight families who lost loved ones and the 200 passengers who suffered life-changing injuries. Amtrak ended up paying only a fraction of the damage it had inflicted. The victims ended up bearing a large part of their own medical costs and lost wages. Meanwhile, Amtrak&#x2019;s chief executive &#x2014; who ran what the NTSB described as a railroad lacking a &#x2018;safety culture&#x2019; for eight years &#x2014; retired without so much as a slap on the wrist.&#x201D;

It is no longer enough to pass legislation; our Congress must fully enforce it, and force the railroads to implement the federally-mandated safety systems. Amtrak cannot be allowed to continue in its current path, putting its own profits ahead of the safety of its passengers. No matter who is responsible for paying for the PCT systems, this latest loss of life falls squarely on Amtrak&#x2019;s shoulders.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier personal injury and medical malpractice law firm serving clients throughout Ohio and Kentucky. If you sustained an injury because of an act of negligence, we may be able to help. Please call our Kentucky lawyers at&#xA0;877-686-8879, our Ohio lawyers at&#xA0;877-686-8879, or use our&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>&#xA0;to make an appointment.[/fusion_builder_column][/fusion_builder_row][/fusion_builder_container]

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: An Algorithm May Be the Key to Reducing Child Abuse and Neglect
BASENAME: algorithm-may-key-reducing-child-abuse-neglect
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/08/2018 12:38:56 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6424" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/GettyImages-637968486-300x300.jpg" alt="An Algorithm May Be the Key to Reducing Child Abuse and Neglect" width="300" height="300">There is an interesting thing happening in Allegheny County. In 2016, the police department started using a predictive algorithm when screening incoming calls of reported child abuse or neglect. They are the first in the country to use the system as a back-up to human screeners &#x2013; a second opinion, as the <em>New York Times Magazine</em> puts it &#x2013; to determine whether or not a child is at high-risk of being injured, abused or neglected in the future.

From the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/02/magazine/can-an-algorithm-tell-when-kids-are-in-danger.html?_r=0" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>Times Magazine</em></a>:

&#x201C;Nationally, 42 percent of the four million allegations received in 2015, involving 7.2 million children, were screened out, often based on sound legal reasoning but also because of judgment calls, opinions, biases and beliefs. And yet more United States children died in 2015 as a result of abuse and neglect &#x2014; 1,670, according to the federal Administration for Children and Families; or twice that many, according to leaders in the field &#x2014; than died of cancer.&#x201D;

There are approximately 14,000 allegations made in Allegheny County each year. About 7,000 of them are screened out. What the predictive algorithm does is help the department of Children, Youth and Families (CYF) which calls warrant closer inspection. The algorithm does <em>not</em> decide whether or not children are pulled from the home. Instead, it identifies the children at the most risk of danger; CYF then determines whether or not to pursue the allegations further.
<h2>How does the program work?</h2>
The algorithm is designed to find patterns. Every single police department in the country (not just Allegheny County) has files on record for allegations of child abuse or neglect. It would take human screeners hours &#x2013; maybe days &#x2013; to comb through them all. Instead, the algorithm looks at all the data at once, &#x201C;using well over 100 criteria maintained in eight databases for jails, psychiatric services, public-welfare benefits, drug and alcohol treatment centers and more.&#x201D;

The exact process is proprietary, but ultimately, the program reviews the data and renders its analysis based on that data. It provides a number on a scale of one (safe) to 20 (high risk). Screeners report that number, and then CYF decides about whether or not to investigate.
<h2>Does the algorithm work?</h2>
Yes. Yes, it does.

Before the implementation of the program, about half of the cases Allegheny County investigated were considered low risk. This ate up valuable time that that CYF could have spent working with children who were in more serious, and more immediate, danger. Over the last 18 months, the percentage of low-risk cases dropped from half to a third.

But even more important, the number of high-risk cases been screened into the system increased. The <em>Times</em> admits that the number only went up by a few percentage points &#x2013; but it&#x2019;s still progress.

There is one other benefit to using the program, too. It doesn&#x2019;t fall prey to racial bias:

&#x201C;In 2015, black children accounted for 38 percent of all calls to Allegheny County&#x2019;s maltreatment hotline, double the rate that would be expected based on their population. Their rate of being placed outside their home because of maltreatment was even more disproportionate: eight out of every 1,000 black children residing in the county were placed outside their home that year, compared with just 1.7 of every 1,000 white children.&#x201D;

The algorithm is helping to reduce that bias. True, it may have more data available if more allegations are reported in regard to black families &#x2013; but because race isn&#x2019;t a factor in the program&#x2019;s analysis, it has actually limited the effects of bias.

As more and more states get onboard with the program, we can only hope they will consider bringing it here. According to the Child Welfare League of America, <a href="http://www.cwla.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/OHIO.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Ohio had 172,445 child neglect referrals</a> in 2015. Of those referrals:
<ul>
    <li>79,215 reports were referred for investigation</li>
    <li>23,006 were victims of neglect (44%), physical abuse (44.3%) and sexual abuse (20.4%)</li>
    <li>74 children died</li>
</ul>
<a href="https://www.cwla.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/KENTUCKY-revised-1.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Kentucky had fewer referrals &#x2013; 101,094</a> &#x2013; than Ohio, but a higher percentage of those cases (55,209) were investigated. CWLA found a &#x201C;rate of 18.7 per 1,000 children&#x201D; were victims of neglect (92.2%), physical abuse (8.3%) and sexual abuse (4.8%). Sixteen of the children died.

The algorithm may not predict which children are in immediate danger, but by finding a pattern, it can help reduce (and perhaps even eradicate) future abuses. And anything that helps protect kids seems like a good idea to us.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier personal injury and medical malpractice law firm serving clients throughout Ohio and Kentucky. To learn more about our services, or to schedule a free consultation with a lawyer at one of our multiple locations, please fill out this <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>, or call us: 877-686-8879 in Ohio, and 877-686-8879 in Kentucky.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Keeping Your Baby Safe by Eating Better During Pregnancy
BASENAME: keeping-baby-safe-eating-better-pregnancy
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/02/2018 12:40:41 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6421" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/GettyImages-669281432-300x200.jpg" alt="Keeping Your Baby Safe by Eating Better During Pregnancy" width="300" height="200">The amount of folk wisdom offered to expecting mothers can be overwhelming: Eat this, do not eat that, gain weight, but not too much weight, and so forth. Particularly if you have struggled to become or stay pregnant, the risks are all too real. Recently, a <em>Journal of American Medicine</em> study linked common <a href="https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/article-abstract/2659557" target="_blank" rel="noopener">pesticides used on fruits and vegetables</a> to problematic reproductive assistance outcomes. When the birth process goes awry, interventions are needed, and can sometimes lead to birth injuries at the hands of well-intentioned but unskilled medical professionals.
<h2><strong><em>High pesticide consumption linked with unsuccessful pregnancies</em></strong></h2>
The JAMA study was not focused on any one particular pesticide or chemical. Instead, the emphasis was on pesticide residue, from unwashed or incompletely washed fruits and vegetables, and whether a high rate of consumption had any impact on the live birth rate. No mothers were told <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/beginning-stages/keeping-yourself-and-your-baby-healthy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">what to eat or what not to eat</a>; instead, scientists measured the average intake of pesticide residue based on what the women reported eating. All the mothers were clients at a fertility center at a teaching hospital.

Scientists already knew that excessive pesticide intake in animals seemed to correlate to lower live birth rate, but were unsure of whether such a connection was true for humans, and particularly for women who had become pregnant using reproductive assistance or technology. The results suggested that women who had the highest average ingestion of pesticide residue had an 18% lower probability of becoming pregnant, and a 26% lower chance of having a live birth. It is important to note that all the women in the study ate levels of pesticide residue that were within the range of typical human exposure.
<h2><strong><em>Common sense and good nutrition</em></strong></h2>
Does this mean pregnant women should forego all fruits and vegetables? Clearly not. While organic foods may vary in terms of specific production and pesticide exposure, they are usually lower in pesticide residue than food not labeled as organic. Avoiding all fresh produce could have more significant negative results for your baby.
<ul>
    <li>Infants who lack <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/2017/08/baby-needs-vitamin-k-healthy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">vitamin K</a> can have trouble clotting, and vitamin K is typically found in green, leafy vegetables.</li>
    <li>Folate is a B vitamin which protects babies from neural tube defects like spina bifida, and can be found in fruits; green, leafy vegetables; enriched grain-based products; and legumes.</li>
    <li>Calcium to builds a baby&#x2019;s bones during a mother&#x2019;s pregnancy. If she is not consuming enough calcium in her diet, her body will steal calcium from her own bones to make her baby strong, leaving her prone to osteoporosis as she ages. Calcium is ingested through dairy products, dark green leafy vegetables, and fortified foods.</li>
</ul>
Even women who are just considering becoming pregnant should consume a balanced diet, including a multi-vitamin if a doctor thinks it is necessary. Birth injuries can result from doctors&#x2019; failure to note nutritional deficiencies in mothers and infants, possibly leading to permanent results, disabilities, or death. Consuming a diet that is nutrient-balanced and low in pesticides does not just improve the chances for women to become and stay pregnant, it allows any person to lead a full and healthy life.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, our birth injury attorneys work diligently to make your needs, and the voice of your child and family, heard.&#xA0; If you are seeking an empathetic, adamant legal representative, please contact our Kentucky lawyers at 877-686-8879, our Ohio team at 877-686-8879, or use our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to make an appointment.
<h3>Related Articles</h3>
<ul>
    <li>What is the Difference Between a Birth Injury and a Birth Defect?</li>
    <li>Fracking May Lead to Lower Birth Weights for Babies Born Nearby</li>
    <li>Avon, Ohio Child with Seizure Disorder Meets April the Giraffe</li>
    <li>When Are Medical Professionals Liable for Inadequate Prenatal Care?</li>
    <li>Birth Injuries: Avoidable Risks with Potentially Lifelong Complications</li>
    <li>Dedicated Louisville Birth Injury Attorneys Seek Justice for Families</li>
</ul>

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: People Are Leaving Ohio and Kentucky in Droves &#x2013; But Why?
BASENAME: people-leaving-ohio-kentucky-droves
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/10/2018 02:59:26 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6428" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/GettyImages-92651120-300x223.jpg" alt="People Are Leaving Ohio and Kentucky in Droves &#x2013; But Why?" width="300" height="223">Every year, United Van Lines releases its list of which states saw the most inbound and outbound moves. Illinois topped the list of people moving away (643% of all moves were outbound), and Vermont topped the list of people moving in (68% of all moves were inbound). Overall, it seems people are moving more west or further south.

Ohio and Kentucky both made the list for outbound moves, with <a href="https://www.unitedvanlines.com/contact-united/news/movers-study-2017" target="_blank" rel="noopener">7<sup>th</sup> and 8<sup>th</sup> place</a>, respectively. But why? According to United Van Lines, the top 5 reasons included:
<ul>
    <li>Jobs located outside of the state (65% in Ohio, 54% in Kentucky)</li>
    <li>Retirement (19.2% in Ohio and in Kentucky)</li>
    <li>Relocation for family (13.9% in Ohio, 25.7% in Kentucky)</li>
    <li>Lifestyle changes (6.6% in Ohio, 7.9% in Kentucky)</li>
    <li>Health reasons (3.8% in Ohio, 4.5% in Kentucky)</li>
</ul>
Most of Ohio&#x2019;s outbound population was age 34 or younger, whereas Kentucky saw the highest spike for people over the age of 65. In both states, households with an average annual income of $150,000 were the most likely to leave.

The fact that high-income households &#x2013; and young people &#x2013; are leaving both states should be worrying. Aging states with lower incomes often demand more assistance from state and federal governments, which can increase taxes and slow down development. As it turns out, though, our neighbors are fining some pretty ingenious ways to increase revenue, and make Ohio and Kentucky look more attractive to outsiders.

Appalachian tourism.
<h2>A new way of experiencing &#x201C;coal country&#x201D;</h2>
The San Francisco Chronicle recently reported on the ways Ohio, Kentucky and West Virginia have been reinventing themselves, both as <a href="http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Tourism-in-coal-country-Digging-into-culture-12455595.php" target="_blank" rel="noopener">tourist destinations and as cultural centers</a>: &#x201C;A Shawnee, Ohio, event re-enacted a Prohibition rally outside the real-life former speakeasy.... Ohio&apos;s Winding Road takes visitors back to the birth of the U.S. labor movement.&#x201D; Ohio has also seen a pickup in <a href="http://www.cleveland.com/travel/index.ssf/2017/12/ohio_sees_increase_in_overseas.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">international tourism</a>. Cleveland now has two flights directly to and from Iceland, and Great Lakes USA has worked with international students and travelers seeking a more &#x201C;authentic&#x201D; American experience.

While Ohio has sought to create new opportunities in and around its towns &#x2013; the Chronicle writer called it &#x201C;Rust Belt Chic&#x201D; &#x2013; Kentucky has largely focused on ecotourism. &#x201C;In Corbin, Kentucky, they&apos;re constructing an elk-viewing area on a former mountaintop mine,&#x201D; as well as an &#x201C;ecology education site.&#x201D; The goal is to bring in and educate tourists and wildlife enthusiasts, who can see how changes in the mountain top&#x2019;s structure has created an ideal habitat for elk, deer, bear and birds. In Eastern Kentucky, the <a href="http://www.moreheadtourism.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">&#x201C;More to Morehead&#x201D; campaign</a> has helped generate enough income to make Rowan County the 5<sup>th</sup> most visited area of Appalachia. Visitors can explore the lake and the local woods, but also pop in for a cup of coffee or shop at the boutiques downtown.
<h2>Why tourism matters to all of us</h2>
As anyone who lives in a tourist destination can tell you, visitors help the local economy. They generate revenue, increase the need for workers, and help lower residents&#x2019; annual tax bill. All of this helps local and state governments fund social programs, fix crumbling infrastructure, and create new spaces to be enjoyed by locals and tourists alike. It&#x2019;s a win/win.

But there is another benefit to this influx of revenue outside of taxes: health. United Van Lines listed health reasons in last place for both Ohio and Kentucky &#x2013; and it&#x2019;s no wonder. Coal Country has long had a reputation for poor water supplies, dirty air and touch soil (despite evidence to the contrary for that last one). More revenue means better clean-up, and better healthcare, too. Local clinics and hospitals often see a share of that revenue, which means they can increase their reach. Rural areas have been especially hard-hit when it comes to <a href="https://www.patientsrightsblog.com/federal-demands-doctors-hospitals-may-prove-unreasonable/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">access to care</a>. The more revenue our states being in, the better chance at increasing that access.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we do more than serve the community in Ohio and Kentucky. We live here. We raised our children here. We have a vested interest in the success of our communities, and look forward to seeing all the ways life can improve here.

Our firm offers comprehensive representation to residents and visitors alike. If you were injured by another driver, because of an act of medical malpractice, while visiting a worksite, or through any act of negligence, we want to help. Please call our Kentucky team at <strong>877-686-8879</strong>, our Ohio team at <strong>877-686-8879</strong>, or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to learn more.

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Which Automakers Saw the Biggest Recalls in 2017?
BASENAME: automakers-saw-biggest-recalls-2017
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/15/2018 10:00:29 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6434" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/GettyImages-808760672-300x178.jpg" alt="Which Automakers Saw the Biggest Recalls in 2017?" width="300" height="178">For many, 2016 was the Year of the Recall. Takata&#x2019;s defective airbags accounted for much of that total, but almost every major automaker faced a recall that year. As of December 20<sup>th</sup>, however, 2017 had seen its fair share of recalls, too: <a href="https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/news/big-and-noteworthy-auto-recalls-of-2017/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">28,146,661 recalled vehicles</a>, to be exact. It falls far short of the 52,985,779 vehicles recalled in 2016, but it&#x2019;s still a large enough number to warrant closer inspection.

According to Road Show, these were the automakers who saw the greatest numbers of recalls in 2017:
<ol>
    <li><strong>Fiat Chrysler: 3,939,250 vehicles recalled</strong>. Dodge faced problems with their rollover technology (mostly in Rams) and for defective oil cooler lines, which increased the chance of a fire.</li>
    <li><strong>Honda: 3,319,327 vehicles recalled</strong>. Accords in particular had a defect which could lead to car fires, and their Odysseys&#x2019; second row of seats did not always latch correctly. If the driver braked too hard, or was hit by another car, the seats themselves could come loose.</li>
    <li><strong>Ford: total number unknown</strong>. There were more than a million F-Series trucks recalled, though, for a defect that could lead to the doors appearing closed, even though they were open.</li>
    <li><strong>Hyundai: 1,549,778 vehicles recalled</strong>. Seat belts detaching (Sonata) and potential manufacturer mistakes in the engines (Santa Fe) were the primary reasons for recalls.</li>
    <li><strong>BMW: total number unknown</strong>. The 3 Series models were recalled because the engine could short circuit, whereas the i3 electric cars put drivers at risk of a serious neck injury. Of all the recalls last year, the i3 recalls are the only ones without a fix or patch.</li>
    <li><strong>Tesla: 31,472 recalled vehicles</strong>. Model S vehicles have a parking break problem (they don&#x2019;t release). Model X vehicles were recalled for the brake problem as well as an issue with seat cable, which could send the rear passenger seat behind the driver crashing into the driver in a collision.</li>
</ol>
<h2>My vehicle was recalled. What do I do?</h2>
If you, like millions of other drivers, find yourself with a car or truck that has been recalled, don&#x2019;t panic. Many recalls deal with issues that are not life-threatening. (<a href="https://www.consumerreports.org/cro/magazine/2015/01/what-to-do-if-your-car-gets-recalled/index.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">A misplaced sticker could lead to a recall</a>.) You should receive an email or a letter in the mail from the dealership or the manufacturer. If you think your car or truck is part of a recall, but you have not been notified &#x2013; or if you are just curious &#x2013; you can enter your vehicle identification number (VIN) at <a href="https://www-odi.nhtsa.dot.gov/owners/SearchSafetyIssues" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SaferCar.gov and search for it directly</a>.

It costs you nothing to fix or replace a defective part. If the dealership tries to charge you, contact the manufacture. If that doesn&#x2019;t work, <a href="https://www-odi.nhtsa.dot.gov/recalls/recallproblems.cfm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">contact the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration</a>.

The next thing you do is call your local dealership and make an appointment to have the defect or faulty part fixed or replaced. <strong>Tire recalls must be handled within 60 days of receiving the notice<em>.</em></strong> Other issues can be handled as they arise &#x2013; but this is problematic, too. For example, Takata is stull churning out replacement airbags, and will be for years. If the dealership doesn&#x2019;t have the part, there is nothing you can do until the parts are ready, short of calling other dealerships to see if they have some in stock. You should also know that used car dealerships are under no obligation to replace recalled parts before they sell you the car, so make sure to run the vehicle through the VIN finder on the NHTSA website to see if the car has any potential issues.

If you were injured in a car or truck accident because of a defective part, you have legal options available to you. Crandall &amp; Pera Law protects the rights of car and truck crash victims throughout Kentucky and Ohio. To learn more about our services, please call our Ohio team at 877-686-8879, our Kentucky team at 877-686-8879, or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Reusing Catheters Put Some NJ Patients in &#x201C;Clear and Imminent Danger&#x201D;
BASENAME: reusing-catheters-put-nj-patients-clear-imminent-danger
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/14/2018 10:00:29 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6431" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/GettyImages-510849538-300x197.jpg" alt="Reusing Catheters Put Some NJ Patients in &#x201C;Clear and Imminent Danger&#x201D;" width="300" height="197">Catheters are useful little tools. They&#x2019;re small plastic tools used by medical professionals for an array of reasons: to measure, to drain, to give drugs, etc. They&#x2019;re also disposable &#x2013; on purpose. After all, do you really want a tube that has been in someone else&#x2019;s stomach placed into your own?

Yet reuse is exactly what one New Jersey doctor did. &#x201C;Dr. Sanjiv K. Patankar, an East Brunswick-based colon and rectal surgeon, allegedly washed and reused the small, flexible catheters that are &#x2018;inserted into patients&apos; rectums during medical procedures,&#x2019;&quot; according to NJ.com. The news site reports that <a href="http://www.nj.com/middlesex/index.ssf/2017/12/nj_doctors_license_suspended_for_allegedly_reusing.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">82 procedures were conducted</a> in Dr. Patankar&#x2019;s office over the course of 11 months (from January 1<sup>st</sup> through November 30<sup>th</sup>).

The total number of catheters ordered during that time? <strong>Five</strong>.

The state Board of Medical Examiners ruled unanimously that Dr. Patankar&#x2019;s actions &#x201C;placed patients in clear and immediate danger,&#x201D; and suspended his license as a result. A full hearing will be conducted, after which the Board will make a final ruling about how to proceed.
<h2>Suspending his license seems like an obvious choice &#x2013; but it isn&#x2019;t always that way</h2>
In this particular case, a temporary (and preferably full) revocation of Dr. Patankar&#x2019;s license seems like a no-brainer. After all, simply washing a catheter does not make it sterile. What reusing catheters did was make it easier to spread infections.

You might be surprised, then, at how often obviously negligent or abusive doctors, surgeons and other medical personnel are given no more than a pat on the wrist, or a fine, <a href="https://www.patientsrightsblog.com/national-practitioner-data-bank-reports-for-ohio-and-kentucky-reveal-critical-errors/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">despite critical errors</a>. A 2013 expose by USA TODAY uncovered thousands of cases where doctors lost their privileges at facilities, yet were <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/08/20/doctors-licenses-medical-boards/2655513/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">allowed to keep their medical licenses</a>:

&#x201C;Even the most severe misconduct goes unpunished: Nearly 250 of the doctors sanctioned by health care institutions were cited as an &#x2018;immediate threat to health and safety,&#x2019; yet their licenses still were not restricted or taken away. About 900 were cited for substandard care, negligence, incompetence or malpractice &#x2014; and kept practicing with no licensure action.&#x201D;

Most recently, and closest to home, is the story of a Cleveland Clinic surgeon who was allowed to <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2018/01/05/confidential-deals-can-obscure-sexual-misconduct-allegations-against-doctors-alleged-rape-doctors/868921001/?csp=" target="_blank" rel="noopener">continue practicing medicine despite rape accusations</a> from two former patients. If this is not a stellar example of how often accusations of wrongdoing are covered up &#x2013; or ignored &#x2013; by hospitals, we don&#x2019;t know what is.
<h2>Adverse actions on Ohio and Kentucky patients</h2>
For healthcare consumers, trying to find out whether your doctor is negligent or abusive can be challenging. The National Practitioner Data Bank (NPDB) keeps a running tally of how many adverse actions are reported each year in each state, and how many medical malpractice claims are actually paid out. Here are the 2016 numbers:

<a href="https://www.npdb.hrsa.gov/resources/npdbstats/npdbStatistics.jsp#ContentTop">Ohio</a>
<ul>
    <li>2,283 adverse action reports
<ul>
    <li>2,088 required state licensure &#x201C;actions&#x201D;</li>
    <li>28 involved clinical privilege and panel membership</li>
    <li>4 involved professional society membership</li>
    <li>12 involved drug enforcement administration</li>
</ul>
</li>
    <li>216 malpractice payments were made</li>
</ul>
<a href="https://www.npdb.hrsa.gov/resources/npdbstats/npdbStatistics.jsp#ContentTop" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Kentucky</a>
<ul>
    <li>888 adverse action reports
<ul>
    <li>779 required state licensure &#x201C;actions&#x201D;</li>
    <li>8 involved clinical privilege and panel membership</li>
    <li>9 involved drug enforcement administration</li>
</ul>
</li>
    <li>118 malpractice payments were made</li>
</ul>
(For more in-depth definitions of these terms, please see the NPDB&#x2019;s <a href="https://www.npdb.hrsa.gov/resources/definitions.jsp" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Definitions and Terms</a>.)

It&#x2019;s a good thing that the NJ Board is choosing to act. We wish it were a more common response to flagrant acts of negligence and to errors. Perhaps then, we would have a safer and more secure health system.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier medical malpractice law firm serving clients throughout Ohio and Kentucky. To learn more about our services, or to work with an experienced medical negligence attorney, please call our offices: 877-686-8879 in Kentucky, and 877-686-8879 in Ohio. You can also fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to request a free initial consultation.

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: North Dakota Rules Damage Caps in Medical Malpractice Cases Unconstitutional
BASENAME: north-dakota-rules-damage-caps-medical-malpractice-cases-unconstitutional
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/25/2018 01:33:34 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6441" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/GettyImages-882967738-300x200.jpg" alt="North Dakota Rules Damage Caps in Medical Malpractice Cases Unconstitutional" width="300" height="200">North Dakota took a giant step in the right direction for victims of medical malpractice. In early January, South Central Judicial District Judge Cynthia Feland ruled that the state&#x2019;s <a href="https://www.law360.com/medical-malpractice/articles/1000538/nd-s-med-mal-damages-cap-is-unconstitutional-judge-rules?nl_pk=bcf11761-fedd-45cb-8109-9658779bd2e1&amp;utm_source=newsletter&amp;utm_medium=email&amp;utm_campaign=medical-malpractice" target="_blank" rel="noopener">arbitrary damage cap</a> on medical malpractice verdicts was unconstitutional, &#x201C;saying it deprives the most catastrophically injured patients of full compensation and thus denies them equal protection of the laws.&#x201D; This is a victory for the people of North Dakota, and another legal precedent for those of us around the country who have been striving to end dangerous tort reform practices for years.
<h2>What did the judge do?</h2>
Last April, a woman named Chenille Condon won her trial against a Dr. Allen Michael Booth and his employer, St. Alexius Medical Center. The jury found for Ms. Condon after the doctor&#x2019;s negligence during an exploratory procedure led to her stroke, paralysis and blurred vision. The jury verdict for Ms. Condon was $3.5 million: $2 million for her economic damages and $1.5 million for past and future non-economic damages.

However, North Dakota enacted a law in 1995, capping non-economic damages at $500,000. The lawyers for Dr. Booth and St. Alexius requested that the amount be lowered, given that law.
<h2>Why did the judge strike down the defendant&#x2019;s request?</h2>
Under the 1995 North Dakota law, the reason the $500,000 cap was enacted was threefold: &#x201C;to increase access to health care, control medical expenses and maintain or increase the quality of health care.&#x201D; The amount of the cap was, as are all damage cap amounts, entirely arbitrary.

However, as Judge Feland pointed out, limiting the jury&#x2019;s verdict contributed in no way to upholding these factors. Let&#x2019;s break them down:
<ol>
    <li>It would not increase her access to care. In fact, given how expensive healthcare is, and how much hospitals stays can cost, it could actually cause her harm. And there is no evidence it has helped other people access healthcare, either.</li>
    <li>Limiting the amount of the verdict would do nothing to help control medical expenses. The mistake had already been made and she needs future care. Furthermore, <a href="http://truecostofhealthcare.org/malpractice/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">there is plenty of evidence</a> that doctors across the country are not struggling to obtain or pay for medical malpractice insurance. Thus, there is no need to increase medical costs.</li>
    <li>Limiting the verdict did not decrease anyone&#x2019;s costs. Remember, the jury awarded Ms. Condon <em>more </em>money to pay for her medical bills than it did for her noneconomic losses, and there are no caps on that amount at all.</li>
    <li>Limiting the verdict did nothing to increase the quality of healthcare. Holding doctors responsible for only a fraction of the harm they cause does not incentivize practicing safer medicine.</li>
</ol>
<h2>Why a decision in North Dakota should matter in Ohio and Kentucky</h2>
At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we have been waging our own battles against tort reform in the states where we live and practice law. Ohio&#x2019;s medical malpractice cap is $250,000 or three times the compensatory damages amount, with a maximum of $350,000 per plaintiff or $500,000 per incident. In instances where the victim has a permanent and substantial physical deformity or loss of bodily organ system, that cap rises to $500,000 per plaintiff or $1 million per incident.&#xA0; Kentucky doesn&#x2019;t have damage caps, but tort reform is here as well: we narrowly avoided having our rights denied by medical review panels, but they have currently been deemed unconstitutional.

As more and more courts come down on the right side of justice, the better we are able to uphold the rights of our clients. North Dakota has joined in the fight for what is right, and we are thrilled about it.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier medical malpractice law firm representing clients throughout Ohio and Kentucky. If you were the victim of medical negligence, or if your loved one was harmed because of a medical error, we want to hear your story. To schedule a free initial consultation at one of our offices, please our Kentucky lawyers at&#xA0;877-686-8879, our Ohio lawyers at&#xA0;877-686-8879, or use our&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>&#xA0;to make an appointment.
-----

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Fracking May Lead to Lower Birth Weights for Babies Born Nearby
BASENAME: fracking-may-lead-lower-birth-weights-babies-born-nearby
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/22/2018 02:02:54 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6438" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/GettyImages-484490828-300x200.jpg" alt="Fracking May Lead to Lower Birth Weights for Babies Born Nearby" width="300" height="200">Hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, is a natural gas extraction process. In the simplest of terms, it involves drilling down into the ground (eventually making an &#x201C;L&#x201D; and drilling horizontally) to reach the natural gas trapped below the shale. Water, sand and chemicals, including nitrogen, are then pumped into the ground. This cracks the shale and allows the gas to either rise up, or to be extracted.

Both Ohio and Kentucky have plenty of natural gas reserves, and so fracking has become an increasingly larger part of our collective economies. The arguments for and against the controversial process are myriad, but we want to focus on one in particular: namely, that babies born within a 2-mile radius (give or take) of fracking sites <a href="http://advances.sciencemag.org/content/3/12/e1603021" target="_blank" rel="noopener">routinely have lower birthweights</a> than those who are not.

A new piece published in the journal <em>Science Advances</em> evaluated <a href="http://advances.sciencemag.org/content/3/12/e1603021" target="_blank" rel="noopener">1.1 million births in Pennsylvania</a>, between 2004 and 2013. According to their findings:

&#x201C;[fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][There is] evidence for negative health effects of in utero exposure to fracking sites within 3 km of a mother&#x2019;s residence, with the largest health impacts seen for in utero exposure within 1 km of fracking sites. Negative health impacts include a greater incidence of low&#x2013;birth weight babies as well as significant declines in average birth weight and in several other measures of infant health. There is little evidence for health effects at distances beyond 3 km, suggesting that health impacts of fracking are highly local.&#x201D;

<a href="https://earther.com/something-else-to-avoid-when-you-re-pregnant-fracking-1821264078" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Earther looked into these claims</a>, and found that the primary cause for these lower birth rates is likely pollution. They quote a press release co-authored by Princeton University professor of economics and public affairs Janet M. Currie as saying, &#x201C;Given the growing evidence that pollution affects babies in utero, it should not be surprising that fracking, which is a heavy industrial activity, has negative effects on infants.&#x201D;
<h2>Why low birthweights are dangerous for babies</h2>
Low birthweight is used to describe babies who weigh 5.5lbs or less at the time of their birth. There are some <a href="http://www.stanfordchildrens.org/en/topic/default?id=low-birthweight-90-P02382" target="_blank" rel="noopener">immediate concerns for babies who weigh too little</a>, per the Lucile Packard Children&#x2019;s Hospital in Stanford. Babies with low birthweights can have difficulties gaining weight. The may also experience respiratory distress, have difficulties regulating their own body temperatures, and are more prone to infection.

Low birthweight has also been linked to developmental issues. Because the fetus, and then the baby, can have difficulty getting enough oxygen, children with lower birthweights can develop neurological problems as well, and may have bleeding in the brain. Low birthweights have also been linked to sudden infant death syndrome, or SIDS.
<h2>Lower birthweight can lead to health problems later in life</h2>
According to the March of Dimes, <a href="https://www.marchofdimes.org/complications/low-birthweight.aspx" target="_blank" rel="noopener">about 1 in 12 children are born with low birthweight</a>. While many children born with low birthweights grow up to be healthy, there are some risks associated with the condition later on, including increased chances of:
<ul>
    <li>Heart disease</li>
    <li>High blood pressure</li>
    <li>Diabetes</li>
    <li>Metabolic syndrome (a combination of all three conditions listed above)</li>
    <li>Obesity</li>
</ul>
We urge you, if you live in an industrial area (whether this is fracking or not) to make and attend regular appointments with your OB/GYN. The research is still new, but taking precautions cannot hurt. You can and should address any concerns you have with your doctors, who may be able to make suggestions to help assuage those fears.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law fights on behalf of the injured throughout Ohio and Kentucky. If your or your child were the victim of medical negligence, we may be able to help. To speak with an experienced birth injury lawyer in Ohio, please call 877-686-8879. For our attorneys in Kentucky, please call 877-686-8879. You can also fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to schedule a free initial consultation.
<h3>Related Articles</h3>
<ul>
    <li>What is the Difference Between a Birth Injury and a Birth Defect?</li>
    <li>Keeping Your Baby Safe by Eating Better During Pregnancy</li>
    <li>Avon, Ohio Child with Seizure Disorder Meets April the Giraffe</li>
    <li>When Are Medical Professionals Liable for Inadequate Prenatal Care?</li>
    <li>Birth Injuries: Avoidable Risks with Potentially Lifelong Complications</li>
    <li>Dedicated Louisville Birth Injury Attorneys Seek Justice for Families</li>
</ul>

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Cars in Buildings &#x2013; Stats, Causes, Prevention, and Legal Consequences
BASENAME: cars-buildings-stats-causes-prevention-legal-consequences
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/01/2018 12:18:41 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6453" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/GettyImages-184349968-300x200.jpg" alt="Cars in Buildings &#x2013; Stats, Causes, Prevention, and Legal Consequences" width="300" height="200">It is well known and understood that car crashes are a danger to drivers, passengers, motorcyclists, pedestrians, and bicycle riders. Many of us hear of and sometimes witness the aftermath of such accidents on the roadways. However, fewer people are accustomed to hearing about and witnessing another type of car accident &#x2013; the car incursion.

A very recent example involves an astonishing incident in which a Nissan sedan launched over a center raised median, <a href="http://abcnews.go.com/US/dramatic-video-captures-car-crashing-2nd-floor-dental/story?id=52353574" target="_blank" rel="noopener">crashing into the second floor of a dental office</a> in Santa Ana, California. According to law enforcement, the driver acknowledged using narcotics.
<h2>What is a car incursion?</h2>
When any type of vehicle crashes into a building, whether it is a bank, hospital, restaurant, home, or retail storefront, it is referred to as an incursion. These can be the most startling and surprising types of car crashes &#x2013; no person inside of a building expects to be threatened or hit by a motor vehicle. Although they seem rare, these incidents occur every day, leaving thousands injured and hundreds killed.
<h2>Causes of car incursion</h2>
The Storefront Safety Council, consisting of a number of experts in perimeter security and parking issues, has published statistics that may be surprising to some.

The data reveals that on average, about 60 times per day in the United States, a <a href="http://www.storefrontsafety.org/statistics.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">motor vehicle impacts a building structure of some type</a> &#x2013; examples include convenience stores, fast food restaurants, hospitals, grocery stores, residential homes, etc. Even more startling, in any given year, some 4,000 injuries to customers, employees, and pedestrians result from these crashes &#x2013; and, some 500 are fatally injured.

Numerous factors can precipitate the loss of control of a vehicle and its subsequent impact into a building structure. Some of the clearly negligent causes producing these crashes include:
<ul>
    <li>Driving while fatigued</li>
    <li>Pedal confusion</li>
    <li>Driving under the influence of alcohol, drugs or other controlled substances</li>
    <li>Driving while distracted (texting, talking on cell phone, using GPS, etc.)</li>
    <li>Speeding or reckless driving</li>
    <li>Nose-in, <a href="https://www.naiop.org/en/Magazine/2014/Spring-2014/Development-Ownership/How-Safe-Is-Your-Parking-Lot.aspx" target="_blank" rel="noopener">perpendicular positioning of parking lot spaces</a> to buildings</li>
</ul>
Other causes may not be due to negligence, but are nevertheless unfortunate, including:
<ul>
    <li>Auto defects causing a vehicle or its components to malfunction or fail to respond to driver control</li>
    <li>Defective design of parking lots or accompanying roads</li>
    <li>Serious medical occurrences such as strokes, heart attacks, or seizures</li>
    <li>Other debilitating medical occurrences such as hypoglycemic shock from diabetes, anaphylactic shock from an allergic to wasp or bee stings, or another health condition that causes sudden disorientation, severe pain, or unconsciousness while driving</li>
</ul>
Car incursions are not addressed by Kentucky&#x2019;s or Ohio&#x2019;s traffic laws specifically, due to the fact that these incidents usually result from statutory violations such as DUI, reckless driving, or speeding. If, however, such a crash occurs because of a defective auto part, defective design, or the negligence of a third-party, injury victims may have legal recourse to seek compensation.

Are you trying to recover physically from a serious car crash? If so, our skilled and experienced car accident attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law are able to protect your rights and fight for a favorable outcome in your case leading to the compensation you deserve. To get started with a free case evaluation, call our Ohio office at 877-686-8879 or out Kentucky office at&#xA0;877-686-8879. Or, simply email us through our&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: A New Type of Imaging Could Help Save the Lives &#x2013; and Brains &#x2013; of Stroke Victims
BASENAME: new-type-imaging-help-save-lives-brains-stoke-victims
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/09/2018 09:21:15 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6531" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/GettyImages-636332090-300x200.jpg" alt="New Type of Imaging Could Help Save the Lives &#x2013; and Brains &#x2013; of Stroke Victims" width="300" height="200">A stroke is a brain injury that occurs when the brain is cut off from its blood supply. Getting the blood supply moving back into the brain is critical to keeping brain tissue alive and functioning. For years, doctors believed that this had to be done within six hours, or the damage done to the brain would be permanent.

As it turns out, they might have much more time, after all.

<a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/new-research-will-radically-change-response-to-strokes/2018/01/24/e35da0e8-011d-11e8-8acf-ad2991367d9d_story.html?utm_term=.462e3da8e12d" target="_blank" rel="noopener">New research</a> has shown that &#x201C;While some brain tissue dies quickly after a stroke begins, in most patients, collateral blood vessels usually take over feeding a larger area of the brain that is also starved for blood and oxygen, giving doctors many more hours to save that tissue than they previously believed,&#x201D; per the <em>Washington Post.</em> Instead of six hours, doctors may have as many as 16, or even 24 hours, in which to begin treatment. The study was so successful, the <em>Post</em> reports, that the researchers put an end to it early, so they could report their findings.
<h2>Fast facts about strokes</h2>
Strokes are classified three ways:
<ul>
    <li>An <strong>ischemic stroke</strong> is caused by an obstruction in the blood vessels (clot), and it is the most common type.</li>
    <li><strong>Transient ischemic attacks</strong> are caused by temporary clots. They&#x2019;re sometimes called &#x201C;mini strokes.&#x201D;</li>
    <li><strong>Hemorrhagic strokes</strong> are the result of a ruptured blood vessel.</li>
</ul>
Strokes are responsible for approximately <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/stroke/facts.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">140,000 deaths per year in the U.S</a>., and is, overall, the fifth leading cause of death in the country. These percentages are mimicked in both Ohio and Kentucky. In 2014, the most recent year available, strokes were responsible for <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/pressroom/states/kentucky.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">2050 deaths in Kentucky</a>, and <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/pressroom/states/ohio.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">5791 deaths in Ohio</a>.
<h2>What the research found</h2>
Before, doctors believed that they had a six-hour window in which to treat the clogged or ruptured blood vessels; longer than that, and the brain tissue would be irreparably harmed. If someone had a stroke right in front of another person, who could then call 911, the doctors could feel confident in that time slot. However, for those who had strokes in their sleep or while alone, there was no way to determine how much damage had been done. Even if the person&#x2019;s life could be saved, there was no way of knowing whether he or she would suffer permanent brain damage.

However, for about half of all patients, the damage done by a stroke moves more slowly than it does for others. This means that doctors have a <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-stroke/study-confirms-late-clot-extraction-can-save-brain-cells-of-stroke-victims-idUSKBN1FD2SI" target="_blank" rel="noopener">longer window to remove the clot,</a> without fear of additional damage to the brain, per a Reuters reports.

Researchers &#x201C;looked at 182 people in 38 medical centers who suffered the kinds of blockages in brain arteries that cause 50 to 60 percent of deaths and the most severe kinds of disabilities.&#x201D; Around half of those people received the standard of care: medication and intervention; &#x201C;The other half had images taken and the clot removal procedure, known as a &#x2018;thrombectomy,&#x2019; as well as the medications.&#x201D;

The imaging was the game-changer. It could show larger areas of damaged tissue, so doctors knew exactly how much tissue was dead, and how much was in danger. It also showed how the damage was progressing. Patients with slower progressions are good candidates for thrombectomies.

The results were extraordinary: 26% of the &#x201C;control&#x201D; group died, compared to only 14% of the group who had thrombectomies. Furthermore, 45% of the patients who had thrombectomies avoided severe disabilities and were able to &#x201C;resume &#x2018;functional independence.&#x2019;&#x201D;

Time is still critical in the diagnosis and treatment of strokes, but this new research could help doctors make better choices for their patients, and give patients a better chance at survival.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law a team of award-winning medical malpractice and personal injury attorneys serving Ohio and Kentucky. We offer aggressive, comprehensive representation on behalf of injury clients and their families. To learn more about our services, or to schedule a free initial consultation, please call our Kentucky lawyers at&#xA0;877-686-8879, our Ohio team at&#xA0;877-686-8879, or use our&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Limbrel Capsules Linked to Potentially Deadly Health Problems
BASENAME: limbrel-capsules-linked-potentially-deadly-health-problems
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/06/2018 01:19:05 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6463" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/GettyImages-828607976-1-300x200.jpg" alt="Limbrel Capsules Linked to Potentially Deadly Health Problems" width="300" height="200">On December 5, 2017, the Federal Drug Administration (FDA) recommended that Limbrel capsules, intended for the treatment of osteoarthritis, be recalled. The FDA advisory concerning Limbrel, which is manufactured by Primus Pharmaceuticals, stated that the product has been connected to incidents of liver injury and other serious health issues. The agency recommended that consumers immediately stop taking the product it deems as a dangerous drug and get in touch with their healthcare provider.

Primus Pharmaceuticals markets the product as a medical food. However, in a letter to the President and Chief Executive Officer of Primus, James D. Weir, the FDA wrote &#x201C;The FDA has determined that these Limbrel products are unapproved new drugs and represent a serious health hazard.&#x201D;
<h2>What is Limbrel?</h2>
Limbrel (flavocoxid), at least as defined by its manufacturer, is a &#x201C;medical food product&#x201D; consisting of substances derived from plant sources called &#x201C;flavonoids.&#x201D; Some Limbrel products contain zinc glycinate. These products come in the form of capsules that can be taken daily. The manufacturer claims that the product reduces inflammation, which in turn reduces pain and swelling.
<h2>Reports of Lung and Liver Disease</h2>
As of November 21, 2017, the <a href="http://www.rheumatologyadvisor.com/osteoarthritis/fda-drug-safety-alert-recall-limbrel-life-threatening-drug-induced-liver-injury-hypersensitivity-pneumonitis/article/712405/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">FDA had received 194 bad incident reports</a> connected with the products. These reports led to the conclusion by the FDA that the use of Limbrel is connected to such illnesses and diseases as pancreatitis, drug induced liver injury, and hypersensitivity pneumonitis. The <a href="https://www.fda.gov/Food/RecallsOutbreaksEmergencies/SafetyAlertsAdvisories/ucm585992.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">number of adverse reports increased to 200</a> by December 4, 2017.

The nature of some of these conditions, which makes them even more dangerous and difficult to address promptly, is that they may not become noticeable immediately. Symptoms may only manifest at the point when hospitalization is required.

In response to the FDA&#x2019;s actions, on December 21, 2017, Primus Pharmaceuticals ceased all promotion and sale of its Limbrel products.
<h2>Limbrel as a &#x201C;Medical Food Product&#x201D;</h2>
In 2004, Limbrel was approved for the treatment of chronic osteoarthritis. Although the product contains ingredients that are derived from plants, it is only available to patients through a valid prescription.

The definition of a &#x201C;medical food&#x201D; is a product that is intended to be taken under the supervision and direction of the physician.

The <a href="https://www.fda.gov/Food/GuidanceRegulation/GuidanceDocumentsRegulatoryInformation/MedicalFoods/default.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Orphan Drug Act stipulates</a> that medical food products are designed for the &#x201C;dietary management of a disease or condition for which distinctive nutritional requirements, based on recognized scientific principles, are established by medical evaluation.&#x201D;

Medical food products are designed for purposes of treating a medical condition, rather than to simply enhance the health of already healthy individuals. These products do not require the pre-marketing study of their effectiveness and safety, as do drugs.

In the FDA&#x2019;s letter to Primus, the agency not only urged the recall, but also asserted that Limbrel was incorrectly branded and did not qualify under the definition of a medical food. The FDA also informed the company that it was &#x201C;not aware of any distinctive nutritional requirements for individuals with osteoarthritis.&#x201D;

If you or a loved one has suffered distinct harm from any dangerous drug or medical food product, our dangerous drug attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can help. We can fight vigorously on your behalf to help you secure justice and the compensation to which you are entitled. To set up a free consultation with an experienced attorney from our team, complete our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> or call our Kentucky office at 877.686.8879, or our Ohio office at&#xA0;877.651.7764.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: A Bird-Brained Question: Can Woodpeckers Help Prevent Brain Injuries?
BASENAME: bird-brained-question-can-woodpeckers-help-prevent-brain-injuries
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/15/2018 09:46:05 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6557" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/GettyImages-619242024-300x205.jpg" alt="A Bird-Brained Question: Can Woodpeckers Help Prevent Brain Injuries? " width="300" height="205">We have long known that football is incredibly hard on the body. Shoulder, hand, and knee injuries are par for the course, but only recently have we been paying serious attention to the issue of brain injuries in the NFL. Doctors are studying concussions, its links to dementia, and links to chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE). CTE is a degenerative brain condition believed to be caused by repeated blows to the head. It&apos;s commonly found in athletes, military veterans, and others with a history of repetitive head trauma.

Scientists recently found an interesting connection between patients diagnosed with traumatic brain injuries (TBI) and, of all things, woodpeckers. Although it&apos;s not that strange if you think about it. If you&apos;ve ever been annoyed by a woodpecker in your yard, you know that they spend hours slamming their heads back and forth into a tree. They&apos;ll do this <a href="https://www.thespruce.com/fun-facts-about-woodpeckers-387095" target="_blank" rel="noopener">20 times</a> a second, at 15 miles an hour, thousands of times a day. Despite all of this hammering, though, woodpeckers don&apos;t appear to develop serious brain damage. If they did, they likely would have knocked themselves extinct a million years ago.

However, a recently released <a href="https://search.proquest.com/openview/437ed8356ae47366083760b0a4ea4ca2/1.pdf?pq-origsite=gscholar&amp;cbl=18750&amp;diss=y" target="_blank" rel="noopener">study</a> shows that, unlike previously believed, woodpeckers actually may suffer some consequences from their relentless head-banging. This discovery could help future brain injury research.

For the study, researchers acquired dead birds from a museum, including some blackbirds as a control group. They searched their brains for a protein called tau. Usually a long, branching structure of nerve cells, tau dislodges from brain fibers during injury. After repeated injuries, tau clumps up in the brain, disrupting information flow. None of the blackbirds had tau accumulations, but eight out of 10 of the woodpeckers did.

This doesn&apos;t mean, though, that the level of tau was toxic and the woodpeckers were brain-damaged. In fact, some tau accumulation can be protective, as it lives inside the cells and can help stabilize neurons. It&apos;s unknown how much tau can dislodge and accumulate in a woodpecker brain before the bird might start behaving abnormally. A co-author of the study, Peter Cummings, who did not expect to see any tau in the birds&apos; brains, <a href="http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2018/02/could-woodpeckers-teach-nfl-how-prevent-brain-injuries" target="_blank" rel="noopener">noted</a> that more work needs to be done to find out if the excess tau is a species adaptation to deal with head trauma, or if woodpeckers have ways of dissolving too much tau and prevent CTE.

Other things to keep in mind is that, of course, woodpecker brains and human brains are not the same. Human brains slosh around more in the skull than bird brains, giving them more room for injury. And one interesting thing that woodpeckers have that we don&apos;t? A long tongue that wraps underneath, up and around the back of the skull. A muscle that rests against the bird&apos;s jugular vein moves the tongue. In theory, a woodpecker can use that muscle to reduce the amount of blood flowing from its skull. In this way, it could protect its brain from sloshing around by filling its brain with blood. Some researchers think it&apos;s possible to design protective gear using this same design&#x2014;a <a href="http://nautil.us/issue/39/sport/how-woodpeckers-will-save-football" target="_blank" rel="noopener">collar</a> that puts just enough pressure on the neck to add a little bit of blood (safely) around the brain.

Of course, all of this needs much more research, but perhaps woodpeckers are the key to unlocking some mysteries about traumatic brain injuries and CTE.

If you or a loved one suffered a traumatic brain injury due to someone else&#x2019;s negligence, look to the TBI attorneys at Crandall and Pera to help. Our experienced legal team works tirelessly to get you the compensation you deserve. Please call our Ohio office at 877-686-8879, or in Kentucky at 877-651-7764. You can also fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to schedule a no-obligation consultation.

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Could Positive Train Control Have Prevented the Amtrak Crash?
BASENAME: could-positive-train-control-have-prevented-the-amtrak-crash
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/12/2018 01:45:45 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6536" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/GettyImages-494065776-300x196.jpg" alt="Could Positive Train Control Have Prevented the Amtrak Crash?" width="300" height="196">A recent spate of train accidents&#x2014;including a crash on February 4 where an Amtrak passenger train collided with a parked freight train in Cayce, South Carolina, killing two people and injuring over 100 passengers&#x2014;is highlighting the issue of railway safety. The February accident is just the latest in a string of accidents for Amtrak.

Over the past few years, Amtrak has had its fair share of train accidents, causing fatalities and injuries.
<ul>
    <li><strong>May 12, 2015: </strong>A train killed eight passengers and injured hundreds when it derailed after traveling 106mph into a 50mph curve. An investigation found the engineer had lost awareness of where he was on the route.</li>
    <li><strong>April 3, 2016: </strong>A train traveling nearly 100mph near Philadelphia, PA slammed into a backhoe working on the track, killing two workers and injuring 39 train passengers. Investigators discovered safety and communications errors, including a failure to notify trains that the track was closed.</li>
    <li><strong>Dec. 18, 2017:</strong> A train derailed in DuPont, WA after traveling 80mph into a curve. Three passengers were killed and dozens were injured.</li>
    <li><strong>Jan. 31, 2018:</strong> A train collided with a garbage truck at a railroad crossing in Crozet, VA, killing the truck driver. The crossing had crossbars and warning lights.</li>
    <li><strong>Feb. 4, 2018:</strong> In the most recent Amtrak accident, a train collided with a CSX freight train parked on a side track in SC, killing the engineer and conductor. So far, the investigators have found that a switch was manually locked to divert the Amtrak train to the side track and toward the parked train. Work crews were in the middle of updating braking technology on the tracks when the accident occurred.</li>
</ul>
<h2>Fast facts about positive train control</h2>
Positive train control (PTC) is a technology system designed to prevent excessive speed, avoid collisions, and make up for other human errors. It combines GPS, wireless radio and computers to monitor trains and stop them from colliding, derailing or speeding. PTC systems know the location of all trains and the positions of all switches in a certain area and are designed to prevent two trains from traveling on the same track at the same time&#x2014;which would likely have prevented the fatal accident in South Carolina.

So why isn&apos;t PTC installed nationwide? Interestingly enough, in 2008 Congress mandated that PTC be installed on critical areas of railroad track by 2015. However, it became clear by late 2015 that railroads were not going to meet the deadline due to technology issues and high costs, and it was extended to the end of 2018. If certain requirements are met, that deadline can be extended further, to 2020.

PTC is set to be a focus of a February 15 meeting of the House Transportation Subcommittee on Railroads, Pipelines and Hazardous Materials.

Dealing with the aftereffects of a train accident is difficult. You can turn to a compassionate personal injury attorney at Crandall &amp; Pera Law to pursue legal justice on your behalf. We focus on the fight so you can focus on healing.&#xA0; Please call our Ohio office at 877-686-8879, or in Kentucky at 877-686-8879. You can also fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to schedule a no-obligation consultation.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: What is Surgical Malpractice?
BASENAME: what-is-surgical-malpractice
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/26/2018 03:03:52 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6581" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/GettyImages-603266080-1-300x157.jpg" alt="What is Surgical Malpractice?" width="300" height="157">Surgery, regardless of how minor it may be, is always significant to the individual undergoing the procedure. Whether the surgery involves a fast outpatient procedure or something as serious as a heart bypass, there is always a certain risk of an error occurring. However, an error involved in a surgical procedure by itself does not necessarily equate to medical malpractice.
<h2>What is a surgical error?</h2>
A surgical error is a preventable mistake that occurs during the course of surgery. Due to the fact that all surgeries in one way or the other carry an element of risk, as a patient you are typically required to sign an informed consent document that verifies you understand the risks involved.
<h2>Has surgical malpractice occurred?</h2>
In order to qualify as malpractice, the medical treatment or surgery in question must have been carried out at a substandard level &#x2013; that is, a level below the accepted medical standard of care. The standard of care is generally defined as the accepted safety standards a reasonable surgeon would be expected to meet in similar circumstances.&#xA0; If a surgical error did not fall below that standard of care, or you did not incur harm from the error, no surgical malpractice may be claimed.

It is important to hold doctors, nurses, and surgeons responsible for failures to provide proper care due to malpractice. This can be done by proving that the proper safety standards were not met and it resulted in the patient&#x2019;s injuries and suffering.
<h2>Types of surgical errors</h2>
Various types of surgical errors that constitute surgical malpractice can occur in the operating room. These include:
<ul>
    <li>Failure to properly sterilize equipment</li>
    <li>Operating on the wrong part of the body leading to health complications, physical damage, or the removal of a body part or limb in error</li>
    <li>Failure to properly handle anesthesia</li>
    <li>Mistakes that lead to cutting or damaging a body part in the vicinity of the operational zone, such as a nerve, organ, artery, tissue, intestine, or ligament.</li>
    <li>Performing an unnecessary surgery</li>
    <li>Failure to remove surgical instruments or sponges from inside the patient&#x2019;s body</li>
    <li>Performing an operation on the wrong patient</li>
</ul>
<h2>Astonishing surgical malpractice examples</h2>
Some of the stories involving surgical malpractice are truly astounding. Below are a couple of real-life occurrences:

<strong>Surgeon&#x2019;s tools left inside patient</strong>

At Washington Medical Center in June 2000, Donald Church, 49, was put under surgery with properly administered anesthesia to remove a tumor in his abdomen. The surgical removal of the tumor was successful. However, <a href="https://www.ahcmedia.com/articles/115882-found-13-inch-retractor-was-left-inside-a-patient" target="_blank" rel="noopener">in its place was left a medical instrument</a> &#x2013; a 13 inch long metal retractor.

<strong>Heart surgery on wrong patient</strong>

A 67-year-old woman had a procedure done in the hospital called a cerebral angiography. After the procedure was completed she was taken to a hospital room on a different floor from the one prior to her procedure. The plan was to have her discharged the next morning. Instead, she was taken to another area for an invasive cardiac electrophysiology study. The woman was <a href="http://annals.org/aim/fullarticle/715318" target="_blank" rel="noopener">subjected to the procedure for about an hour</a>. The procedure was stopped and the woman was returned to her room. Although in stable condition, the consequences of what was done increased her risk of infection, internal bleeding, stroke, and heart attack.

If the medical profession has failed you or a family member through medical malpractice, you need a strong advocate to ensure you can recover the damages you are owed. Our team at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can help. Call our Kentucky office at 877-651-7764 or our Ohio office at 877-686-8879, or complete our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to schedule a free, no obligation consultation with a medical malpractice lawyer.
-----
