AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: How a Personal Injury Lawyer Can Help Injured Workers
BASENAME: personal-injury-lawyer-can-help-injured-workers
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/19/2018 02:13:21 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6577" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/GettyImages-645357306-300x200.jpg" alt="How a Personal Injury Lawyer Can Help Injured Workers" width="300" height="200">Although it is common for employees injured in the workplace to obtain compensation through their employer&#x2019;s workers&#x2019; compensation insurance, sometimes workers may obtain compensation from others. These exceptions include situations in which you have the right to sue for damages as a result of your injuries. For example:
<ul>
    <li>You suffered injury from a toxic substance and file a toxic tort lawsuit against the manufacturer</li>
    <li>You suffered injury from a defective product</li>
    <li>Your employer does not carry workers&#x2019; compensation insurance</li>
    <li>Your employer caused your injury through egregious or intentional conduct</li>
    <li>A third-party caused your injury</li>
    <li>You are classified as a contractor, and therefore are ineligible for workers&#x2019; compensation</li>
</ul>
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, some <a href="https://www.bls.gov/news.release/archives/osh_11092017.htm">2.9 million worksite injuries occurred in 2016</a>. As usual, construction jobs were among the deadliest private industry jobs. Nearly a thousand workers <a href="https://www.osha.gov/oshstats/commonstats.html">lost their lives</a> that same year. Thankfully, construction workers and their families often have legal options if they wish to pursue a claim.
<h2>Filing a product liability lawsuit</h2>
When a worker incurs an injury from equipment or machinery that has a defect, fails to function properly, or is highly dangerous to use, liability may rest on the manufacturer for the injury if the manufacturer was aware of the danger and/or failed to provide proper warning to the business or employees. A legally liable manufacturer may be required to compensate an injured construction worker for pain and suffering, lost wages, and medical bills.
<h2>Toxic torts: making a claim after a work-related illness</h2>
Certain chemicals and other substances used in the workplace have the potential to cause serious injuries and illnesses to workers. Some substances that may cause such harm include radium, benzene, asbestos, silica, and chromium compounds. These and other potentially harmful substances have the potential to become the subject of a toxic tort lawsuit.

Toxic injuries can be divided into two categories: acute and latent. Acute injuries are immediately apparent. Some examples include chemical poisoning and chemical burns. Latent injuries take time to manifest &#x2013; in certain cases even years. Examples include various types of cancers as well as lung disease.

Due to the time delay often accompanying latent injuries, they are generally more difficult to prove in court than acute injuries. However, successful lawsuits concerning latent toxic injuries are certainly possible. Many successful latent injury lawsuits have occurred from workers who have suffered from mesothelioma and asbestos, for example.

The liability for a toxic substance injury often rests on the manufacture of the substance and/or any manufacturers of equipment intended to safely handle the substance, but failed to do so.

The issues surrounding exposure to toxic substances and subsequent injuries and/or illnesses can be complex and difficult to sort out. However, a skilled personal injury attorney who handles these cases can investigate your case thoroughly, sort out the issues, and litigate effectively for the best settlement possible based on your injuries.

Our team at Crandall &amp; Pera Law is experienced at successfully handling workplace injury cases for our clients in Ohio and Kentucky. We understand what is at stake for you when workers compensation coverage is not available or insufficient. We can fight vigorously on your behalf for the compensation you are owed. To arrange a free, initial consultation, fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>, or call our Kentucky team at 877-651-7764 or our Ohio team at&#xA0;877-686-8879.
-----
EXTENDED BODY:

-----
EXCERPT:

-----
KEYWORDS:

-----


--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Truck Hits Pedestrian; Drops Motorcycles on Top of Him in Fatal Accident
BASENAME: truck-hits-pedestrian-drops-motorcycles-top-fatal-accident
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/05/2018 03:02:43 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6599" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/GettyImages-182138065-300x207.jpg" alt="Truck Hits Pedestrian; Drops Motorcycles on Top of Him in Fatal Accident " width="300" height="207">A 20-year-old man lost his life in a bizarre accident in Cleveland on February 6. The man was in a crosswalk when the driver of a box truck lost control of his vehicle on some ice and went off the road. The driver hit a utility pole, struck a bus stop sign, and two more utility poles. The truck then veered back into the road and hit the pedestrian.

During the crash, the side of the truck was sheared off, causing two unsecured motorcycles to fall out of the truck onto the pedestrian. He was later pronounced dead at an area hospital. The driver initially fled from the scene, but later returned to surrender to authorities. The case has been turned over to prosecutors to consider charges against the driver.
<h2>Who is liable in a bad weather accident?</h2>
This might look like a bizarre but tragic truck accident on the surface. After all, if bad weather is responsible for the crash and subsequent falling cargo, can you really assign liability?

Yes, you can.

Drivers have a duty to other vehicles and pedestrians to drive safely and appropriately under all weather conditions, and that includes snow and ice. We are all aware of the dangers of winter weather and snow and ice, and should be able to adjust our driving to keep ourselves and others safe. In fact, the Ohio Supreme Court ruled in <em><a href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=8327530512301413932&amp;hl=en&amp;as_sdt=6,36" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Oechsle v. Hart</a></em> that &#x201C;skidding upon a wet or icy roadway due to bad road conditions alone does not excuse a driver from operating his vehicle upon the right side of the roadway.&#x201D; In this court case, a vehicle left its lane after hitting an unexpected patch of ice, and crashed into a car in the opposite direction. There was no other evidence of bad road conditions.

A reasonable person should know that if it&apos;s snowing and/or roads are icy, they should be driving with extra caution by traveling at a lower speed. They should also know if their vehicle isn&apos;t equipped to safely travel in winter conditions. And, they should know whether or not they have the driving experience to navigate winter weather conditions safely. These are all issues that your attorney should investigate.

This particular truck accident brings up even more questions of liability. Did the unsecured motorcycles contribute to the pedestrian&apos;s death? If so, who loaded the bikes on the truck? The driver? A warehouse worker? The company that owns the motorcycles? And there&apos;s also the fact that the driver initially left the scene of the accident, which could potentially bring additional charges.

If you were injured, or someone you love was killed, in a truck accident, the Kentucky and Ohio truck accident lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law are here to help you achieve justice. We have the resources and skills to hold all responsible parties accountable for wrongful death and serious injuries. Please call our Ohio office at 877-686-8879, or in Kentucky at 877-651-7764. You can also fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to schedule a no-obligation consultation.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Ohio Board of Medicine Investigating Former Cleveland Clinic Surgeon
BASENAME: ohio-board-medicine-investigating-former-cleveland-clinic-surgeon
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/01/2018 12:24:38 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6585" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/GettyImages-621701578-300x200.jpg" alt="Ohio Board of Medicine Investigating Former Cleveland Clinic Surgeon" width="300" height="200">After a USA TODAY <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2018/01/05/confidential-deals-can-obscure-sexual-misconduct-allegations-against-doctors-alleged-rape-doctors/868921001/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">article</a> revealed the Cleveland Clinic kept surgeon Ryan Williams on staff after he was accused of raping two patients, the doctor is now under investigation by the Ohio Board of Medicine. The article highlighted the issue of confidential settlements, and the legal loopholes that allow surgeons who have been accused of a crime to remain on staff and keep allegations off of their records.

First, some quick background. Ryan Williams, a colorectal surgeon formerly of the Cleveland Clinic in Ohio, was accused of rape by two patients in 2008 and 2009. One was receiving a rectal exam when she was assaulted, and the other was under sedation and didn&apos;t remember what happened for several years. Police reports were filed in both cases. The USA TODAY article uncovered that the Cleveland Clinic was aware of the allegations and kept Williams on staff. Ultimately, Williams was never charged with a crime.

However, due to the attention from the article, an investigation has been opened by the Ohio Board of Medicine. Williams is not currently seeing patients at his new position after leaving the Cleveland Clinic.
<h2>The problem with confidentiality agreements</h2>
Over the past few months, there&apos;s been a lot of talk in Hollywood about the problem with sexual assault/harassment and confidential settlements. In many cases, confidential settlements act as a gag order that prevents the victim from speaking out about their experience, potentially setting up the attacker to repeat their behavior. The same can happen with cases of alleged medical malpractice.

If a patient ends up taking a settlement, they cannot publicly talk about what happened, or reveal the amount of the settlement. And, if the hospital takes over liability from a doctor accused of malpractice or assault, the accusation will never show up in the National Practitioner&apos;s Data Bank, a database of physicians which includes any disciplinary actions or charges against them.

Another issue with Williams&apos; case&#x2014;one of the women who accused and later sued him did so after the one-year statute of limitations had passed, so her lawsuit was filed as a &#x201C;miscellaneous tort claim&#x201D; and not malpractice. Because of these loose laws that allow unscrupulous doctors to get around the system, when Williams&apos; contract at the Cleveland Clinic was not renewed, he was able to pass a background check and obtain a position at Ohio State University (OSU) Wexner Medical Center.

He is now on paid administrative leave after <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2018/01/30/ohio-medical-board-investigating-former-cleveland-clinic-surgeon-over-rape-allegations/1044736001/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">USA TODAY</a> brought the rape allegations to their attention.

Williams is denying the allegations. The Cleveland Clinic confirms they settled a civil case brought by one of the women. A spokesperson also noted that police investigated allegations from the second patient and did not find evidence anything occurred, although the incident she reported had happened five years prior. Williams also noted that he always had a chaperone with him while performing procedures, but a former assistant told the newspaper that it was not always possible to have someone in the room with him due to staffing issues.

As of this writing Williams&apos; case is still under investigation.

The skilled Ohio and Kentucky medical malpractice lawyers of Crandall &amp; Pera Law have successfully handled numerous medical malpractice cases. Please call our Ohio office at 877-686-8879, or in Kentucky at 877-651-7764. You can also fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to schedule a no-obligation consultation.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Bipartisan Underride Guard Legislation to Prevent Deadly Crashes Making its Way Through Congress
BASENAME: bipartisan-underride-guard-legislation-prevent-deadly-crashes-making-way-congress
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/12/2018 11:29:43 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6639" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/GettyImages-838467664-300x169.jpg" alt="Bipartisan Underride Guard Legislation to Prevent Deadly Crashes Making its Way Through Congress" width="300" height="169">Last March, we covered the issue of how truck underride guards are still not required by law in the United States despite the National Transportation Safety Administration&apos;s (NTSB) conclusion that they would reduce injuries and deaths on America&apos;s highways. Now, bipartisan legislation is making its way through Congress. <a href="https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/senate-bill/2219/text?format=txt" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>The Stop Underrides Act of 2017</em></a> was introduced on n December 12, 2017 by Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand (D- N.Y.) and Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.); Reps. Steve Cohen (D-Tenn.) and Mark DeSaulnier (D-Calif.) introduced the companion bill in the House.

Underride crashes occur when a car slides underneath the body of a large commercial truck. You might have noticed when you pass a large truck, if you are in a passenger car, the bottom of the cargo container of an 18-wheeler is just about eye-level with a passenger riding in a car. It does not take much of a leap to imagine what might happen in a crash if a passenger vehicle were to slide underneath a large truck when there is nothing there to keep it from happening. Passengers involved in underride crashes can become decapitated. Passengers who survive emerge with massive head and neck injuries even if the crash occurs at lower speeds.

Underride guards, which are already required for the back end of large commercial trucks, are metal and fiberglass buffers that attach to the sides of the truck and deflect the impact of a vehicle instead of allowing it to pass underneath the truck. You can see an underride guard in action at the <a href="http://www.iihs.org/iihs/news/desktopnews/iihs-tests-show-benefits-of-side-underride-guards-for-semitrailers" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Insurance Institute for Highway Safety&apos;s</a> website.

In the <a href="https://www.rubio.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?ContentRecord_id=48A97C09-7D4B-45D7-B2EE-AA4BF9395816" target="_blank" rel="noopener">press release</a> about the bill&apos;s introduction, Representative Cohen read the names of just a few of the families who have lost loved ones in truck underride crashes, some of which have tirelessly advocated for this bill which could potentially save lives including, Marianne Karth, Lois Durso, Jennifer Tierney and especially Randy and Laurie Higginbotham.

Marianne Karth, who has dedicated her life to making sure that side underride guards become mandatory in the U.S. was able to share her story: &#x201C;I am the survivor of a terrible truck crash. I&apos;m the mom of two daughters, AnnaLeah &amp; Mary, who did not survive. The difference? Their part of the car went under the truck; mine did not. When I learned that hundreds of people die each year from underride and that something could have been done to prevent their deaths, I became a mom on a mission to make truck crashes more survivable.&#x201D;

Jacqueline Gillan, President, Advocates for Highway and Auto Safety said, &#x201C;The Stop Underrides Act is a long-overdue solution to a long-standing safety problem. Every year hundreds of people are needlessly killed or severely injured in truck underride crashes. The National Transportation Safety Board has issued multiple recommendations for improved rear underride guards and for side and front underride protection systems. It is now time for action.&#x201D;

If you or someone you care about has been injured in a truck accident, or if you have lost a loved one in a truck crash, the experienced Ohio and Kentucky commercial truck accident attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law will evaluate your case and help get you the compensation you deserve. For a free consultation, call our attorneys at&#xA0;877.686.8879, or&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a>&#xA0;today to schedule your free consultation at one of our offices in Ohio or Kentucky.

TITLE: Steve Crandall to Speak about Social Media&#x2019;s Effects on Juries at the Annual OAJ Convention on May 4th
BASENAME: steve-crandall-speak-social-medias-effects-juries-annual-oaj-convention-may-4th
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/15/2018 08:39:05 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6666" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/GettyImages-916036268-300x200.jpg" alt="Steve Crandall to Speak about Social Media&#x2019;s Effects on Juries at the Annual OAJ Convention on May 4th " width="300" height="200">The Ohio Association of Justice, or OAJ, holds a convention every Spring in Columbus. This year, we are proud to announce that firm co-founder Steve Crandall has been <a href="https://s3.amazonaws.com/membercentralcdn/sitedocuments/oh/oh/0929/881929.pdf?AWSAccessKeyId=0D2JQDSRJ497X9B2QRR2&amp;Expires=1520963283&amp;Signature=sVvdKPPWz00zI%2FJIPKxi8H0GaSE%3D&amp;response-content-disposition=inline%3B%20filename%3D%222018%20Brochure%2Epdf%22%3B%20filename%2A%3DUTF-8%27%272018%2520Brochure%252Epdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">asked to speak at the convention</a>. His presentation, titled &#x201C;Social Media and its Effects on Jury Selections and Verdicts,&#x201D; will be given during the Medical Malpractice portion of the seminar.

The OAJ was founded in 1954. Originally a part of the Ohio Chapter of the National Association of Claimants&#x2019; Counsel, its original mission was to educate attorneys who represented injured workers. Over the years, the organization has had many names &#x2013; but its most impressive history was made by its members, who fought to uphold justice for all people in Ohio:
<ul>
    <li><em>Brunets v. City of Columbus</em> made sure women could be fire fighters.</li>
    <li><em>Blankenship v. Cincinnati Milicron Chemicals Inc</em>. ensured that workers could sue when their employers put them in harm&#x2019;s way.</li>
    <li><em>Griffith v. Mt. Carmel East</em> mandated that trauma victims be taken to hospitals and facilities with the ability to properly care for them.</li>
</ul>
Today, the <a href="https://www.oajustice.org/index.cfm?pg=Advocacy" target="_blank" rel="noopener">OAJ&#x2019;s mission for its members</a> is &#x201C;to advance your client&#x2019;s rights at the Statehouse, at the Bureau of Workers&#x2019; Compensation and before the Ohio Supreme Court. OAJ is constantly vigilant and responds aggressively to any threat that would negatively impact your practice or the rights of Ohioans to have their disputes resolved by a jury.&#x201D;
<h2>Upholding the mission of the OAJ every day</h2>
Steve Crandall is a proud and active member of the OAJ, which fights on behalf of injury victims in Ohio and Kentucky every day. An award-winning trial attorney, Steve practices at the state and federal level, and understands that sometimes the fight to secure a client&#x2019;s future can become a precedent for how the law is practiced. He is also a popular speaker, offering in-depth and interesting perspectives on issues that affect plaintiffs&#x2019; attorneys on a day-to-day basis. Some of his more notable lectures include:
<ul>
    <li>&#x201C;Focus Groups in Ohio&#x201D; for Ohio Association of Justice Spring Convention, 2016</li>
    <li>End Distracted Driving, various schools in Northeast Ohio for EndDD.org, 2015</li>
    <li>&#x201C;Expert Witness Presentation at Trial,&#x201D; annual convention of the Ohio State Bar, 2013</li>
    <li>&#x201C;Medical Malpractice Trial Tactics&#x201D; for Cleveland Marshall School of Law, 2011</li>
    <li>Annual Winter Conference on Clinical Issues in OB/GYN, 2008</li>
    <li>Annual National Conference on Fetal Monitoring, 2005-2007</li>
</ul>
All of us at Crandall &amp; Pera Law, LLC wish Steve well for his latest presentation.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: University Hospitals Fertility Clinic Lost Up to 4,000 Frozen Eggs and Embryos
BASENAME: university-hospitals-fertility-clinic-may-have-lost-up-to-2000-frozen-eggs-and-embryos
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/12/2018 03:26:05 PM
-----
BODY:
<h1><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6653" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/Frozen-Embryos-Were-Destroyed-University-Hospitals-Fertility-Center-Cleveland-300x201.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="201">University Hospitals Fertility Clinic Lost Up to 4,000 Frozen Eggs and Embryos in Tank Failure</h1>
Women choose to freeze their eggs, and couples to freeze embryos, for a lot of reasons. But underneath almost all of them is an undercurrent of hope: that someday, in the future, those eggs or embryos will result in babies. That optimism is what helps many people through a complicated &#x2013; and expensive &#x2013; process of extracting, freezing, and (eventually) thawing and implanting.

It is also what makes the freezer malfunction at University Hospitals Fertility Clinic in Cleveland so heartbreaking. According to multiple news sources, something went awry with a long-term storage tank at the facility, which caused the temperature to drop sometime Saturday night (March 3<sup>rd</sup>) and Sunday morning (March 4<sup>th</sup>). The Plain Dealer reported &#x201C;University Hospitals has <a href="http://www.cleveland.com/healthfit/index.ssf/2018/03/university_hospitals_notifies.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">notified about 700 fertility patients and their families</a> that the frozen eggs and embryos they had stored at one of its hospitals may have been damaged over the weekend when the temperature rose in a storage tank.&#x201D;

Dr. James Liu, Chair of UH Cleveland Medical Center&#x2019;s department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, said there is evidence of damage. However, the only way to know for sure is to thaw out the eggs and embryos. Because the freezing process can damage the specimens, there is no safe way to thaw and then re-freeze the specimens from the tank. He told the paper &#x201C;Some samples that were unfrozen for scheduled procedures this week were not viable.&#x201D;

As of March 27, 2018, approximately 950 patients are believed to have been affected. In total, more than 4,000 frozen eggs and embryos were lost. You can to read the updated letter from <a href="http://news.uhhospitals.org/news-releases/uh-fertility-clinic-update-patient-letter.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">UH Fertility Clinic here</a>.
<h2>A horrific coincidence</h2>
The same exact weekend, almost the exact same situation unfolded at Pacific Fertility Clinic in San Francisco. CBS News reported that the clinic&#x2019;s President, Dr. Carl Herbert, said <a href="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/2nd-fertility-clinic-has-freezer-failure-jeopardizing-thousands-of-frozen-eggs-and-embryos/">close to 400 patients</a> have already been informed, and that officials &#x201C;also sent out emails explaining what had happened to two other groups -- roughly 100 patients who had tissue in both the problematic tank and another tank, and another, much larger group whose stored eggs and embryos weren&apos;t affected.&#x201D;

The clinic has not thawed any embryos, Dr. Herbert said, but they did thaw out some eggs &#x2013; all of which remained viable. The <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/fertility-clinic-informs-hundreds-of-patients-their-eggs-may-be-damaged/2018/03/11/b605ea82-2536-11e8-b79d-f3d931db7f68_story.html?utm_term=.16096543d93c" target="_blank" rel="noopener">malfunctioning tank</a> &#x201C;contained &#x2018;several thousand&#x2019; eggs and embryos. Clinic spokesman Alden Romney said that represents as much as 15 percent of the total stored at the facility,&#x201D; per the Washington Post.

The two clinics are not related or connected in any way.
<h2>What happens next?</h2>
Dr. Liu told The Plain Dealer that UH is asking each patient directly how he, she or they would like to proceed. Patients who wish to transfer their eggs or embryos to another facility may do so. No discussion has been forthcoming about compensation.

The Clinic does have a telephone number set up for patients who have been contacted about their samples: 216-286-9740. You can also <a href="http://www.uhhospitals.org/make-an-appointment" target="_blank" rel="noopener">reach out to Clinic here</a>. The facility is located at:

1000 Auburn Dr.
Suite 310
Beachwood, OH 44122
<h2>Filing a lawsuit against the University Hospitals Fertility Clinic in Cleveland</h2>
<a href="https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/california/articles/2018-03-12/the-latest-california-fertility-clinic-adding-safeguards" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Two lawsuits</a> have already been filed against the clinic: the first by a couple in Ohio, and the second by a couple in Pennsylvania. The first lawsuit, on behalf of Amber and Elliot Ash, seeks class action status. The couple had two embryos stored at the facility, both of which have been deemed non-viable. The Pennsylvania couple, which has spent the last eight years trying to conceive, told the <em>Associated Press</em> that &#x201C;they were beginning the process last week of transferring the frozen embryo when they later were told something went wrong.&#x201D;

Crandall &amp; Pera Law currently accepting additional clients with claims tied to the freezer malfunction at University Hospitals Fertility Clinic in Cleveland. We urge you to contact us if you stored eggs or embryos at the location, or if you have been contacted by UH officials.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier medical malpractice law firm with offices throughout Ohio and Kentucky. To schedule a no-cost, no-obligation consultation with one of our experienced trial attorneys, please call 877-686-8879 or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Potential Dangers Lurking in Surgical Centers
BASENAME: potential-dangers-lurking-surgical-centers
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/27/2018 12:47:55 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6683" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/GettyImages-621701578-1-300x200.jpg" alt="Potential Dangers Lurking in Surgical Centers " width="300" height="200">You may have seen a new surgical center opening in your city or town. These surgery centers offer same day, outpatient surgical services that are typically more cost effective and more convenient than getting the procedure done at a regular hospital. There are more than 5,616 Medicare-certified ambulatory surgical centers throughout the country, and many of them are owned by the doctors who work there. A joint investigation by <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2018/03/02/medicare-certified-surgery-centers-safety-deaths/363172002/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">USA Today</a> and <a href="https://khn.org/news/medicare-certified-surgery-centers-are-expanding-but-deaths-question-safety/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Kaiser Health News</a>, however, uncovered dangerous conditions in these surgical centers that seem to have led to the deaths of at least 260 patients since 2013.
<h2>What are the problems with ambulatory surgical centers?</h2>
Because they are large institutions, hospitals have systems and processes in place to manage risk and deal with emergencies proactively. A small, freestanding surgical suite may not have the resources to handle life-threatening emergencies that can occur when a routine surgical procedure goes awry. Some of the inherent risks of surgical centers include:
<ul>
    <li>Lack of oversight and patient monitoring</li>
    <li>Discharging surgical patients too soon</li>
    <li>Failure to properly sterilize equipment</li>
    <li>Lack of intensive care equipment/facilities</li>
    <li>Performing procedures inappropriate for a surgical center</li>
    <li>Equipment failure/ lack of backup equipment</li>
    <li>Failure to obtain informed consent from the patient</li>
    <li>Lack of accreditation. If the surgical center is not going to accept Medicare or private insurance, they have fewer safety requirements putting patients at higher risk of injury.</li>
</ul>
The <em>USA Today</em> story highlights what happened to Paulina Tam, a 58-year-old mother who went into a surgical center for surgery and died from complications because the surgical center had to call 911 when she went into distress following the procedure.
<h2>At least 14 patients have died after complex spinal surgeries in surgical centers</h2>
Many patients have not survived the trip from the surgical center to the emergency room&#xA0; to address complications that occurred following surgery. <em>USA Today</em> and the <em>Kaiser Health News</em> network contacted 24 doctors that own surgical centers about patient deaths and none of them was willing to answer questions. The executive director of the Ambulatory Surgery Center Association declined a request for comment for the report saying only that there is no data that proves surgery centers are less safe than hospitals.
<h2>Ambulatory surgical centers in Ohio and Kentucky</h2>
The following is a list of a few of the outpatient day surgery centers in our area:
<ul>
    <li>Laser Spine Institute</li>
    <li>Big Creek Surgery Center</li>
    <li>Wright Surgery Center</li>
    <li>North Shore Gastroenterology</li>
    <li>Cleveland Surgical Suites</li>
</ul>
Lexington, KY outpatient surgical centers:
<ul>
    <li>Lexington Clinic Outpatient Surgery and Endoscopy Centers</li>
    <li>Cosmetic Surgery Center</li>
    <li>Stone Road Surgery Center</li>
    <li>Baptist-Physicians&apos; Surgery Center</li>
    <li>Surgery on Sunday</li>
</ul>
<h2>Ambulatory surgical centers generate profits for doctors</h2>
Doctors are permitted by law to steer patients to a surgical center that they own rather than to a full-service hospital, which increases the doctor&apos;s profits. When surgical centers take on complex cases they are not equipped to handle if the procedure goes wrong, those centers are thoughtless and careless. They take these complex cases because it is where the big profits can be found.

The challenge with all these cases is that most reach confidential settlements. As a result, no one hears about the stories of these needless deaths, and the public remains unaware of the potential danger of surgical centers. While these centers offer convenience and lower costs, they also carry different risks if things go wrong.

You are welcome to schedule a free consultation with a medical malpractice attorney from Crandall &amp; Pera if you or a loved one has suffered a serious injury after a procedure at an ambulatory surgical center. Crandall &amp; Pera Law is a premier medical malpractice law firm serving clients throughout Ohio and Kentucky. If a preventable medical error was the cause of your injury, you are encouraged to call our medical malpractice attorneys at&#xA0;877-686-8879. You may also schedule a free consultation through our&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>. We take cases on a contingency fee basis.

&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: The Widespread Flu Epidemic of 2017-18, the Flu Shot and Flu Vaccine Injuries
BASENAME: widespread-flu-epidemic-2017-18-flu-shot-flu-vaccine-injuries
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/19/2018 01:07:34 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6671" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/GettyImages-665515600-300x200.jpg" alt="The Widespread Flu Epidemic of 2017-18, the Flu Shot and Flu Vaccine Injuries" width="300" height="200">The 2017-2018 flu season has been the worst in almost a decade and it is finally beginning to taper off. Flu season, as the fall and winter months are often called, usually begins in late October, peaks between December and February, and can linger into May, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

The CDC publishes a weekly influenza report, and as of the third week in February, while the influenza virus continues to be predominant, the number of cases testing positive for flu began to decline for the first time since October 2017. The CDC has also published a <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/flu/about/season/flu-season-2017-2018.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">frequently-asked questions page</a> about this particularly virulent flu season.

There have been 114 pediatric deaths from flu since October, the number of regions reporting widespread flu activity is 49 of 54, and a cumulative rate of 81.7% laboratory-confirmed influenza-related hospitalizations per 100,000 population was reported. (<a href="https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/index.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CDC</a>)

A story in the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/26/health/flu-rates-deaths.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>New York Times</em></a> reported that people over age 65 are the most likely to be hospitalized for flu, but those between the ages of 50-64 are the next highest age cohort for hospitalizations from the flu.
<h2>Flu season tracking for Kentucky and Ohio</h2>
<a href="https://www.odh.ohio.gov/en/seasflu/Ohio-Flu-Activity" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Ohio Department of Health</a> tracks seasonal flu activity weekly throughout the year. The ODH website has data for weekly flu activity that goes back to 2012. Kentucky also tracks weekly flu activity, and they have a frequently-asked question section on their site with information about the flu, what to do if you think you or your children are infected, and who should get the flu vaccine.
<h2>Flu shot injuries</h2>
Dr. Roberta DeBiasi, chief of pediatric infectious diseases at Children&#x2019;s National Health System in Washington, D.C. said in a story in <a href="http://time.com/5113281/flu-death-toll-children-2018/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>Time Magazine</em></a>, &quot;The most important thing parents can do to protect their children is to make sure they get vaccinated every flu season. It&apos;s not perfect and it&apos;s not 100% effective, but it&apos;s the best thing we have, and the flu vaccine is one of the safest, most vetted and most studied vaccinations there is.&quot;

Despite the purported safety of the flu vaccine, every year the National Vaccine Injury Compensation Program (NVICP) settles cases for individuals who have been injured and for the loved ones of people who have died from vaccine injuries.

<a href="http://vaccineimpact.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/5/2017/12/DOJ-Update-12.17.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Department of Justice</a> publishes a quarterly report on vaccine injuries and deaths. In the December 2017 report, there were 85 cases listed. Of those 85 cases, 71 were injuries from the flu vaccine with the most common injury being SIRVA (shoulder injuries related to vaccine administration) and GBS (Guillain-Barre Syndrome). SIRVA is believed to be caused by an immune response following an inadvertent, direct injection of vaccine into the deltoid bursa or joint space, which brings on severe, long-lasting shoulder pain and limits range of motion. (<a href="http://www.aappublications.org/news/2017/09/01/IDSnapshot082917" target="_blank" rel="noopener">American Academy of Pediatrics</a>) The National Institutes of Health (NIH) describe Guillain-Barre syndrome as a disorder in which the body&apos;s immune system attacks part of the peripheral nervous system. Symptoms include weakness or tingling sensation in the legs that can spread to the arms and upper body and can lead to almost complete paralysis.
<h2>What can you do if you have been injured after receiving a flu shot?</h2>
What can you do if you have been injured after receiving a flu shot?

If you should suffer a flu vaccine-related injury, or an injury from any vaccine, you can consult with a vaccine injury lawyer, who will file a claim in the U.S. Court of Federal Claims in a no-fault claim. There is a statute of limitations of three years from the date of the adverse reaction for you to file your claim. The amount of your compensation depends on the extent of the illness or injury from the vaccine.

Some of the most common flu shot injuries include:
<ul>
    <li>SIRVA</li>
    <li>Guillain-Barre Syndrome</li>
    <li>CIDP (Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy)</li>
    <li>Allergic reaction</li>
    <li>Brachial Neuritis</li>
    <li>Transverse Myelitis (TM)</li>
    <li>Neuromyelitis optica (NMO)</li>
    <li>Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM)</li>
    <li>Optic neuritis</li>
    <li>Brachial neuritis</li>
    <li>Rheumatoid arthritis</li>
    <li>Seizures</li>
    <li>Peripheral neuropathy</li>
    <li>Encephalopathy</li>
    <li>Cerebellar ataxia</li>
</ul>
It does not cost anything to hire a vaccine injury attorney as the U.S. Court of Federal Claims pays our legal fees, which allows you to keep all of the compensation you receive if you win your case. If you, your child or someone else you care about has suffered an injury after receiving a vaccine, we are here to help make sure that your rights are protected.

The process of making a claim for compensation from the National Vaccine Injury Compensation Program is complicated. You want an injury lawyer you can trust and who knows how to build a successful case on your behalf. To learn more about Crandall &amp; Pera Law&#x2019;s services, or to schedule a consultation with Steve Crandall, please call&#xA0;877.686.8879&#xA0; or fill out our&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> today.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Combine Distracted Walkers with Distracted Drivers and Get Deadly Accidents
BASENAME: combine-distracted-walkers-with-distracted-drivers-and-get-deadly-accidents
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 04/02/2018 09:33:57 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6703" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/GettyImages-930104342-300x200.jpg" alt="Combine Distracted Walkers with Distracted Drivers and Get Deadly Accidents" width="300" height="200">You have most likely seen them, people who walk with their heads down, eyes glued to the screen of their smartphone as they navigate the bustling sidewalks and streets. &quot;Petextrians,&quot; as they are <em>affectionately</em> called, are engaging in what the <a href="http://www.nsc.org/learn/safety-knowledge/Pages/news-and-resources-pedestrian-safety.aspx" target="_blank" rel="noopener">National Safety Council</a> calls distracted walking. Distracted walking accident injuries are on the rise, as you might have guessed. In 2017, there were nearly 6,000 pedestrian fatalities, according a <a href="https://www.ghsa.org/issues/bicyclists-pedestrians" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Governor&apos;s Highway Safety Association</a> report. The NSC warns that Americans are losing their focus on their surroundings and placing themselves in danger.

There were so many pedestrian fatalities and injuries associated with texting while walking for the second year in a row, that the National Safety Council added the category of &quot;distracted walking&quot; to the injury statistics that they gather each year.
<h2>Distracted walkers, meet distracted drivers</h2>
People who engage in distracted walking seem to have the mistaken idea that the world around them is in suspended animation as they move through it. But, they would be wrong. Imagine the catastrophe that would occur if a distracted walker &#x2013; staring intently at their phone &#x2013; wandered across the street in front of a driver who was also staring at the screen of their mobile device.
<h2>Who is liable in a distracted walking car crash?</h2>
Pedestrians generally have the right of way within a marked pedestrian walkway.&#xA0; In fact, pedestrians almost always have the right of way when crossing the street. Drivers must remain alert when driving in locations where pedestrians are present and yield to pedestrians. For safety purposes, it is vital that pedestrians look up, and look both ways, before crossing the street. It is also vital that drivers put their phones down and keep them out of sight when they are driving.

In most instances, when there is a pedestrian collision with a motor vehicle, the driver will be held liable&#xA0; If, however, the pedestrian is jaywalking with their head down and completely unaware of traffic, the driver will probably &#xA0;not be held liable for that accident. Any kind of motor vehicle accident can be complex&#xA0; and you are best served by an experienced car accident attorney if you have been injured in a crash.

Your car crash or pedestrian accident case is important to us, and we want to help you. Please call Crandall &amp; Pera Law today at&#xA0;877-686-8879, or fill out our&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>&#xA0;to schedule a free, no-obligation consultation with an experienced car crash lawyer in Ohio or Kentucky.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Using Mediation to Resolve Car Crash Claims
BASENAME: using-mediation-to-resolve-car-crash-claims
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 03/29/2018 09:09:30 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6697" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/GettyImages-525489094-300x202.jpg" alt="Using Mediation to Resolve Car Crash Claims" width="300" height="202">Most people who have been in car accident cases would prefer to settle out of court. Litigation can be expensive, and going to court can be frightening. Mediation is an alternative dispute resolution (ADR) approach, which can be faster and more cost effective than taking a case to trial. If you and your lawyer decide that going to trial is not your best option, mediation might be another route to try.
<h2>Why would you choose mediation to resolve a car crash claim?</h2>
Mediation is a non-binding process where the two parties work with a neutral third party to come to a mutually agreeable settlement. For mediation to proceed, both parties must agree to it, split the cost of the mediator, and hire their own legal representation to guide them through the negotiations. The mediator&apos;s task is to bring the two parties together in an agreement.

It is<em> not</em> the mediator&apos;s job to make any type of ruling. If the two parties fail to come to a settlement agreement, they can take the case to court.
<h2>How does mediation work?</h2>
Each side will prepare a brief which presents the evidence supporting their position, and whatever they are demanding from the settlement. Each side submits their brief to the mediator. The mediator will give a brief introduction, and they will remind the parties that whatever happens in mediation remains confidential. (What happens in mediation stays in mediation.) If the case should end up going to trial, none of what goes on in the mediation session can be used as evidence in court.

Often, the mediator will dismiss each party and their counsel to separate conference rooms. The mediator will go back and forth between the rooms carrying back and forth the latest settlement offer. This will continue until the parties settle or realize that the case isn&#x2019;t likely to settle
<h2>How long does mediation take?</h2>
If both parties are determined to come to a workable solution, a car crash mediation session can be completed in a single work day. Sometimes, depending on the complexity of the case, and how far apart the parties find themselves, it could take a few days to resolve.

Suffering an injury in a serious car accident can be a devastating experience. If you want aggressive representation from a trusted team of car accident attorneys, look to Crandall &amp; Pera Law. For a free, no-obligation consultation at one of our offices in Ohio or Kentucky, please call&#xA0;877-686-8879&#xA0;or fill out our&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>&#xA0;today.

--------
AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: April is Distracted Driving Awareness Month
BASENAME: april-is-distracted-driving-awareness-month
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 04/09/2018 09:03:33 AM
-----
BODY:
For most of us, driving can be a leisure activity. Maybe not that sitting-in-traffic daily commute, but lovely weekend drives to admire local scenery, or just to get the car out on the open road in some nice weather. However, a pleasure drive can turn downright dangerous when confronted with hazards like distracted drivers, which is why we always need to remain vigilant behind the wheel.

April is <a href="http://www.nsc.org/learn/NSC-Initiatives/Pages/distracted-driving-awareness-month.aspx" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Distracted Driving Awareness Month</a>, so we&apos;ve put together some facts and tips about distracted driving to give you some knowledge about the issue and avoid falling into the distracted driving trap yourself.
<h2>Facts about distracted driving</h2>
Our cell phones mostly feel like an extension of ourselves, which might make us forget that they can take our attention away from the road. For example, driving and talking on the phone gives you the same level of impairment as driving while intoxicated (a BAC of 0.08%). And sending or reading a text is the same as driving the length of a football field at 55 mph blindfolded. And texting behind the wheel increases the risk of having a car accident or near-crashing by 23 times. [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][<a href="https://www.enddd.org/the-facts-about-distracted-driving/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">EndDD.org</a>]

However, using your phone while driving isn&apos;t the only form of distracted driving. Anything that takes your mind off the task at hand&#x2014;your eyes off the road or your hands off the steering wheel&#x2014;is considered distracted driving. This could include grooming, eating, adjusting a GPS or mapping app, changing your music, or talking to passengers. They might not seem like activities that distract you from driving because they&apos;re so common and we don&apos;t think twice about doing them. However, they&apos;re in fact quite dangerous. In <a href="https://www.nhtsa.gov/sites/nhtsa.dot.gov/files/documents/812_381_distracteddriving2015.pdf">2015</a>, 3,477 people were killed and an additional 391,000 were injured in auto accidents involving distracted drivers.
<h2>Typical driving distractions</h2>
All kinds of distracted driving are dangerous, but it&apos;s evident from this list that technology is playing a bigger and bigger role in car accidents.
<ul>
    <li><strong>Phone calls:</strong> Making or taking calls distracts you from what you should be doing&#x2014;paying attention to your driving. Even using hands-free technology still takes your mind off the road.</li>
    <li><strong>Using social media:</strong> As crazy as it might seem, some people update or check social media behind the wheel. We shouldn&apos;t have to say that nothing is that important. It can wait.</li>
    <li><strong>Texting:</strong> Texting while driving is extremely dangerous and takes your eyes and hands off the road. Even voice-to-text applications can be distracting.</li>
    <li><strong>Music:</strong> Many drivers also flip through songs on their phones or iPods, or fiddle around with the stereo system, while driving.</li>
    <li><strong>Eating and drinking:</strong> Consuming food or beverages while driving takes your hands off the wheel, your eyes off the road, and distracts your mind from the task at hand.</li>
    <li><strong>Drowsy driving:</strong> Driving while fatigued is as dangerous as driving drunk, and affects your cognitive function and ability to focus.</li>
    <li><strong>Rubbernecking:</strong> Slowing down to look at an accident doesn&apos;t just cause traffic slowdowns. It also takes your eyes off the road and raises the risk of causing another accident.</li>
    <li><strong>Grooming:</strong> If your eyes are looking in the mirror while you&apos;re applying makeup or grooming, they&apos;re not on the road where they should be.</li>
</ul>
<h2>Avoiding distracted driving</h2>
How can you avoid driving while distracted? Just remember a few things and incorporate them into your driving habits. If you absolutely must talk on the phone, use a hands-free device. Avoid texting and driving. Program your GPS before you start driving&#x2014;even if you think you won&apos;t need it. You never know when you might get re-routed. Set your music playlist beforehand, too. Don&apos;t let yourself get distracted by your pets or passengers.

Simply put? Stay alert behind the wheel.

Suffering injury in a car accident can be an overwhelming experience, coupled with a long healing process. If you need aggressive representation from a trusted team of car accident attorneys, look to Crandall &amp; Pera Law. Please call our Ohio office at 877-686-8879, or in Kentucky at 877-651-7764. You can also fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to schedule a no-obligation consultation.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Bootleg Cab Driver Flees from Roebling Bridge Crash...or Did He?
BASENAME: bootleg-cab-driver-flees-from-roebling-bridge-crash-or-did-he
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 04/16/2018 11:34:50 AM
-----
BODY:
The story which confused authorities for several days involved an injured pregnant woman and serious damage to a famous landmark. But now they know the truth, and a Cincinnati man has been charged for his role in a crash that forced the months-long closure of the Roebling Suspension Bridge. Demarko D. Page, 24, of Cincinnati, faces three misdemeanors&#x2014;falsely reporting an incident, operating a motor vehicle on a suspended or revoked license, and failure of owner to maintain required insurance.

On March 20, Page had a car accident and crashed into the bridge. He was driving southbound, lost control of his vehicle, and the accident caused enough damage to bend a beam on the bridge. Authorities say slippery conditions and excessive speed were likely factors in the accident.

Kentucky transportation officials say the damage was so severe, the bridge will likely be closed through June for repairs.

Police say Page, the man who caused the crash, lied to them at first, telling them a story about how another man was behind the wheel of the car at the time and fled the scene. Initially, after the accident, Page told authorities that he and another passenger were in a bootleg cab, which are unauthorized rideshare vehicles.

He claimed the driver crashed the vehicle and ran off, leaving him and a pregnant woman behind. Police found the pregnant woman semi-conscious and lying on the sidewalk when they arrived. She was taken to University of Cincinnati Medical Center with what officials believed was a broken femur, according to police. But police now say that Page was actually the driver, but told police he was a passenger in the car because he had no license or insurance on the vehicle.

The crash caused significant damage to the bridge, and officials believe it will be closed even longer than the initial week or so that was initially expected. &quot;The impact was to the vertical portion,&quot; said District 6 Kentucky Transportation Cabinet public information officer <a href="http://www.wlwt.com/article/man-charged-in-crash-that-forced-months-long-closure-of-roebling-bridge/19632783" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Nancy Wood</a>. &quot;There are several steel vertical pieces to this bridge structure and the impact did some significant damage to this particular one.... We estimate the repairs to be complete by June. Until then, the bridge will remain closed to all traffic, vehicles and pedestrians.&quot;

The Roebling Bridge was constructed in 1866 and spans the Ohio River between Cincinnati, Ohio and Covington, Kentucky. It&apos;s an integral part of the area&apos;s landscape.

If you were injured in a car crash, the Kentucky and Ohio auto accident lawyers at Crandall &amp; Pera Law are here to help you find justice. We have the resources and skills to hold all responsible parties accountable for wrongful death and serious injuries. Please call our Ohio office at 877-686-8879, or in Kentucky at 877-651-7764. You can also fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to schedule a no-obligation consultation.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Flu Season Not Over Yet, Officials Warn
BASENAME: flu-season-not-over-yet-officials-warn
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 04/12/2018 02:56:13 PM
-----
BODY:
Even though we&apos;re celebrating spring and the end of flu season, the number of cases of influenza B is actually on the rise, medical professionals say. Most of the severe cases of flu we saw this season were a strain of influenza A, according to the CDC, but people are more recently being diagnosed with influenza B.

&#x201C;It&#x2019;s often the case where influenza A starts off the flu season, and then as the season goes on, influenza B becomes more important,&#x201D; said <a href="http://www.sacbee.com/entertainment/living/health-fitness/article205619844.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Dr. Dean Blumberg</a>, an expert in infectious diseases at UC Davis Health. &#x201C;Influenza A caused almost all the influenza starting at the beginning of this season in 2017, and then once 2018 started, influenza B started causing a greater proportion of illnesses.&#x201D;
<h2>Flu season facts</h2>
Influenza B is typically not as severe as influenza A, but it can impact the health of young children more seriously. Children are <a href="http://www.sacbee.com/entertainment/living/health-fitness/article205619844.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">20 percent</a> more likely to die from influenza B than from the A strains.

In fact, five pediatric deaths were reported during the week ending March 11, which brings the national total of flu-related deaths to 133. Seventeen states reported widespread flu outbreaks to the CDC. Nearly 250,000 people tested positive for the flu during this season. Almost 27,000 people were hospitalized due to the influenza A virus. [fusion_builder_container hundred_percent=&quot;yes&quot; overflow=&quot;visible&quot;][fusion_builder_row][fusion_builder_column type=&quot;1_1&quot; background_position=&quot;left top&quot; background_color=&quot;&quot; border_size=&quot;&quot; border_color=&quot;&quot; border_style=&quot;solid&quot; spacing=&quot;yes&quot; background_image=&quot;&quot; background_repeat=&quot;no-repeat&quot; padding=&quot;&quot; margin_top=&quot;0px&quot; margin_bottom=&quot;0px&quot; class=&quot;&quot; id=&quot;&quot; animation_type=&quot;&quot; animation_speed=&quot;0.3&quot; animation_direction=&quot;left&quot; hide_on_mobile=&quot;no&quot; center_content=&quot;no&quot; min_height=&quot;none&quot;][<a href="https://weather.com/health/news/2018-03-28-flu-cases-on-rise-cdc" target="_blank" rel="noopener">source</a>]
<h2>Avoiding the flu</h2>
The best way to avoid the flu is to practice good health habits.
<ul>
    <li>Avoid close contact with people who are sick. And if you are sick, avoid others to prevent spreading your illness to others. Stay home from work, school, or running errands.</li>
    <li>Cover your nose and mouth with a tissue when sneezing or coughing to prevent germs from spreading.</li>
    <li>Wash your hands often to protect you from germs. Use soap and water. If those aren&apos;t available, use an alcohol-based hand rub.</li>
    <li>Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth&#x2014;germs are spread when a person touches something contaminated and then touches their eyes, nose, or mouth.</li>
    <li>Wipe down and disinfect surfaces at home, school, and work, especially when people are sick.</li>
    <li>Get enough sleep, drink plenty of fluids, and eat nutritious food.</li>
</ul>
It&apos;s also not too late to get a flu shot. Even if you&apos;ve already had the flu this year, you may want to consider getting the vaccine, as it&apos;s possible to become infected by multiple strains in one season. Anti-viral medications like Tamiflu are effective in minimizing flu symptoms, but they should be taken within 48 hours of onset of symptoms.

The CDC also advises that people with flu-like symptoms like fever, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, muscle or body aches, headaches and fatigue seek medical attention as soon as possible to avoid possible severe or deadly complications.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Can Medical Marijuana Ease the Opioid Epidemic?
BASENAME: can-medical-marijuana-ease-the-opioid-epidemic
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 04/23/2018 02:28:52 PM
-----
BODY:
According to two recent studies, medical marijuana may be chipping away at the opioid problem in the United States. Advocates for legalizing marijuana have long held the belief that the plant is a lower-risk alternative to opioids, and can relieve chronic pain. However, those on the other side of the issue claim that marijuana could actually encourage opioid use and possibly make the epidemic worse. Let&apos;s take a look at the study.

Although these studies don&apos;t directly look at the effect of legalizing marijuana on opioid addiction and overdoses, they do find some evidence that legalization could reduce the prescribing of opioids. And over-prescribing is one of the key factors in the country&apos;s opioid problem.

<a href="https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/fullarticle/2676999">These</a> <a href="https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/fullarticle/2677000" target="_blank" rel="noopener">studies</a> were released on April 2, 2018 in the journal JAMA Internal Medicine.
<h2>Opioid prescribing dropped under Medicaid</h2>
One of the studies, which took place between 2011 and 2016, took a look at opioid prescribing under Medicaid. Medicaid covers low-income adults. Researchers compared states where marijuana laws were in effect versus states where it was illegal. They found that when people were permitted to use marijuana to treat their medical conditions, there was a six percent lower rate of opioid prescribing for pain. In other words, for every thousand people using Medicaid, there were about 39 fewer opioid prescriptions.

Further, when states went on to allow recreational marijuana use in addition to medicinal, opioid prescriptions dropped by another six percent.
<h2>Opioid prescribing also dropped under Medicare</h2>
The second study took a deep dive into opioid prescribing under Medicare. Medicare covers those 65 years and older as well as those with disabilities. Again, researchers compared states with medical marijuana laws with those without for the years 2010 through 2015. They found that patients in these states filled prescriptions for about 14 percent fewer daily doses of opioids than those in the other states. And, patients in states that allowed them to grow pot at home showed around seven percent fewer doses.
<h2>Conclusions</h2>
&#x201C;Marijuana is one of the potential alternative drugs that can provide relief from pain at a relatively lower risk of addiction and virtually no risk of overdose,&#x201D; <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2018/04/02/two-new-studies-show-how-marijuana-can-help-fight-the-opioid-epidemic/?utm_term=.ad47046a976e" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Wen and Hockenberry</a>, the authors of the Medicaid study, wrote. &#x201C;These findings suggest that medical and adult-use marijuana laws have the potential to reduce opioid prescribing for Medicaid enrollees, a segment of population with disproportionately high risk for chronic pain, opioid use disorder, and opioid overdose.&#x201D;

There are concerns, however, that marijuana use could open the door for experimentation with harder drugs. According to a <a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28946762" target="_blank" rel="noopener">study</a> by Dr. Mark Olfson, marijuana users are six times more likely than non-users to abuse opioids.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we support everyone who is trying to improve their quality of life &#x2013; but we want to make sure you have the facts, first. If you are suffering from being overprescribed opioids, please call our Ohio office at 877-686-8879, or in Kentucky at 877-651-7764. You can also fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to schedule a no-obligation consultation.

&#xA0;

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: What is the Difference Between a Birth Injury and a Birth Defect?
BASENAME: what-is-the-difference-between-a-birth-injury-and-a-birth-defect
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 04/30/2018 11:35:29 AM
-----
BODY:
As everyone always says, &#x201C;We don&apos;t care if it&apos;s a boy or a girl, we just want our baby to be healthy.&#x201D; And, after months and months of anticipation, that&apos;s usually exactly how it goes&#x2014;a normal delivery of a healthy infant. However, in a small percentage of births, things unfortunately don&apos;t go as planned and your child is not, in fact, healthy. And you want and need answers. What went wrong? When did it go wrong? Could it have been prevented? Who is to blame?

Babies can suffer from two medical issues at birth, and it&apos;s important to be able to distinguish between the two of them: birth injuries and birth defects.
<h2>Birth defects</h2>
Birth defects occur as a baby develops in the womb. They&apos;re commonly detected&#x2014;or should be detected&#x2014;during pregnancy, although some may not show up until after delivery. Birth defects are typically caused by a genetic abnormality, but can also sometimes be caused by certain medications or drugs and alcohol.

Birth defects can occur in any part of an infant&apos;s body or brain, but the most severe focus on the nervous system. Common birth defects include heart problems, Down syndrome, spina bifida, fetal alcohol syndrome, cleft palates, or clubfoot.
<h2>Birth injuries</h2>
On the other hand, birth injuries occur during the birth process&#x2014;labor and delivery. Out of 4.3 million childbirths in United States hospitals, nearly <a href="https://www.hcup-us.ahrq.gov/reports/statbriefs/sb74.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">157,700</a> mothers and newborns sustained potentially avoidable injuries.

There are many different kinds of birth injuries, ranging from mild to serious. Babies can be born with broken bones or meconium aspiration syndrome, or with nerve or brain damage. Many of these injuries occur when an infant is deprived of oxygen during delivery. If a medical professional fails to monitor the mother&apos;s labor or any signs of fetal distress properly, or use excessive force during delivery, both the mother and child could potentially suffer injury. Common birth injuries include:
<ul>
    <li>Brachial plexus injuries</li>
    <li>Cerebral palsy</li>
    <li>Erb&apos;s Palsy</li>
    <li>Shoulder dystocia</li>
    <li>Klumpke&apos;s Palsy</li>
    <li>Subconjunctival hemorrhage (bleeding in the eyes)</li>
    <li>Fracture</li>
    <li>Paralysis</li>
</ul>
While birth defects are typically unavoidable, birth injuries are likely to have been caused by a failure in medical care. Delay to act, failure to notice complications, forceful delivery, or use of improper tools can all cause birth injuries that were otherwise avoidable. Some birth injuries are immediately noticeable, but some may not be detected until days or weeks after delivery.

You should remember, as a parent, that not all birth injuries are life-threatening. But with any injury, the most important thing is to get the best care for your child and ensure that they are as healthy as possible as they begin their life.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we fight on behalf of Kentucky and Ohio parents whose children have suffered a birth injury. For compassionate and strong advocacy, please call our Ohio office at 877-686-8879, or in Kentucky at 877-651-7764. You can also fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to schedule a no-obligation consultation.
<h3>Related Articles</h3>
<ul>
    <li>Fracking May Lead to Lower Birth Weights for Babies Born Nearby</li>
    <li>Keeping Your Baby Safe by Eating Better During Pregnancy</li>
    <li>Avon, Ohio Child with Seizure Disorder Meets April the Giraffe</li>
    <li>When Are Medical Professionals Liable for Inadequate Prenatal Care?</li>
    <li>Birth Injuries: Avoidable Risks with Potentially Lifelong Complications</li>
    <li>Dedicated Louisville Birth Injury Attorneys Seek Justice for Families</li>
</ul>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Marc Pera Secures $515,000 Verdict against General Surgeon in Cincinnati
BASENAME: marc-pera-secures-515000-verdict-against-general-surgeon-in-cincinnati
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 04/26/2018 11:18:21 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-6727" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Screen-Shot-2018-04-26-at-9.17.01-AM-300x197.png" alt="Marc Pera Secures $515,000 Verdict against General Surgeon in Cincinnati" width="300" height="197">Crandall &amp; Pera Law will always fight on behalf of those who have sustained serious injuries because of medical negligence. That is why we are proud to announce that firm co-founder Marc Pera has obtained a $515,000 medical malpractice verdict against a General Surgeon in Cincinnati on behalf of the family of Monica McKnight. Before going to trial, the defense offered our client nothing.

The case itself was simple. Ms. McKnight was in the thrall of kidney failure. Because of the advanced stage of her illness, she was only given six years to live. She had to undergo a treatment called hemodialysis (commonly shortened to dialysis). Hemodialysis literally cleans your body of toxins and removes excess fluid when your kidneys no longer can. Per the <a href="https://www.kidney.org/atoz/content/hemodialysis" target="_blank" rel="noopener">National Kidney Foundation</a>, &#x201C;In hemodialysis, a dialysis machine and a special filter called an artificial kidney, or a dialyzer, are used to clean your blood. To get your blood into the dialyzer, the doctor needs to make an access, or entrance, into your blood vessels.&#x201D;

There are three ways a doctor can create an access into your blood vessels:
<ul>
    <li>Through an arteriovenous (AV) fistula, which connects an artery to a vein</li>
    <li>Through an AV graft, where a small tube is used to connect an artery to a vein (usually for people with small or blocked veins)</li>
    <li>With a catheter, which is usually inserted into the jugular vein</li>
</ul>
But instead of inserting the catheter into the jugular, the surgeon inserted it into the carotid artery.
<h2>Arteries and veins do very different jobs</h2>
Despite the prevalence of popular media using these two terms interchangeably, there is a vast difference between arteries and veins. Arteries carry oxygenated blood from the heart to the rest of the body. Specifically, the carotid artery carries blood from the heart to the head and neck.

Veins carry deoxygenated blood from the body to the heart. The jugular vein in particular carries blood from the head and neck back to the heart.
<h2>What happened to Ms. McKnight?</h2>
Because the catheter was inserted into the carotid artery and not the jugular vein, blood clots developed. These clots traveled to Ms. McKnight&#x2019;s brain, and caused her to have a stroke the same day as the surgery was performed. She died four days later, as a result.

This was not a &#x201C;silly&#x201D; mistake; no doctor should ever mix up the carotid with the jugular. Furthermore, this act of medical malpractice cost the family of Monica McKnight precious time &#x2013; time she did not have much of, given the advanced stage of her illness &#x2013; with her, because she was denied the effective treatment she needed to survive. It caused Monica and her family undue pain, suffering and stress, and stole six years of her life away. Yet, despite the blatant surgical error, the insurance company refused to offer any compensation at all before the verdict was rendered.

Thanks to the efforts of Marc Pera, however, Ms. McKnight&#x2019;s family can rest a little easier tonight, knowing that justice has been served, and that the surgeon has been held accountable for his negligence.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law, LLC provides comprehensive counsel to victims of medical malpractice throughout Ohio and Kentucky. Our experienced trial attorneys fight on behalf of those who have suffered because of careless mistakes. To learn more about our services, or to schedule a free initial consultation with a member of our team, please call <strong>877-686-8879</strong>, or fill out our <a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>.

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Study Proves that Youth Tackle Football Can Lead to Brain Disease Later
BASENAME: study-proves-that-youth-tackle-football-can-lead-to-brain-disease-later
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 05/10/2018 02:17:46 PM
-----
BODY:
As more information came to light regarding the connection between Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy (CTE) and football, players, doctors, and managers started advocating for better and safer play. Though the NFL itself has been slow in responding (slow being the polite word), more and more people are coming around to the side of these players. Attendance has gone down at games, and a growing contingent of parents and schools have shifted from football to other sports.

Those parents are right. A study published in the <em>Annals of Neurology</em> has found &#x201C;that playing tackle football before age 12 could lead to long-term consequences later in life,&#x201D; <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/2018/04/30/cte-brain-diseases-start-earlier-tackle-football-played-before-12/563330002/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">reports USA TODAY</a>. The lead researchers were from the VA Boston Healthcare System and Boston University School of Medicine, whose previous work found a connection between youth tackle football and CTE.
<h2>What the study said</h2>
Researchers looked at <a href="https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/ana.25245" target="_blank" rel="noopener">246 donated brains</a> for the study. Of those 265:
<ul>
    <li><strong>211 had evidence of CTE</strong></li>
    <li>126 &#x201C;were without comorbid neurodegenerative diseases,&#x201D; meaning they only showed signs of CTE</li>
    <li>35 brains showed no evidence of CTE at all</li>
</ul>
According to their findings, the age of the player did not indicate how severe the CTE pathology was. In other words, playing tackle football at a younger age did not mean that the player&#x2019;s CTE was more severe than those of players who started later. But what they did find was &#x201C;In the 211 participants with CTE, every one year younger participants began to play tackle football predicted earlier reported cognitive symptom onset by 2.44 years (p&lt;0.0001) and behavioral/mood symptoms by 2.50 years (p&lt;0.0001).&#x201D;

In layman&#x2019;s terms, how severe a player&#x2019;s CTE was had nothing to do with age &#x2013; but the younger the player was when he started, the faster the signs and symptoms showed up. For players who started before the age of 12, those signs started showing up, on average, 13.39 years later (cognitive) and 13.28 years later (behavioral). The same averages held true when the researchers looked at the 126 brains of players who only exhibited signs of CTE, without other conditions like Alzheimer&#x2019;s.
<h2>Want to protect your kids? Don&#x2019;t let them play football</h2>
Three years ago, we wrote an open letter to the parents of high school football players, urging them to keep their kids from playing. We work with people with serious brain injuries and cognitive damage every day, and it was important to us then &#x2013; just as it is now &#x2013; that we do what we can to help put a stop to this needless and incurable condition. That means keeping your kids away from football altogether.

This isn&#x2019;t a high school player problem. This isn&#x2019;t a college player problem. This isn&#x2019;t a professional player problem.

These are children. Playing tackle football as a child can lead to an incurable brain disease. That disease will eventually kill them. And that disease could take root in your child&#x2019;s brain before he is even old enough to ride alone on some of the roller coasters at King&#x2019;s Island.

The science is clear. Football causes brain damage, and the younger you are when you play, the faster the symptoms could show up.

Choose the future. Choose your children. Choose life.

Crandall &amp; Pera Law is proud to represent clients throughout Ohio and Kentucky. If you believe your child has been seriously injured while playing football or another contact sport, let us help you. To schedule a free consultation with an experienced brain injury lawyer, please call&#xA0;877-686-8879&#xA0;or fill out our&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a>.

<strong>Read more:</strong>
<ul>
    <li>Friday Night Lights Out: The Truth about Football and Long Term Brain Damage</li>
    <li>Dear Parents: Please Keep Your Children Away from Football</li>
    <li>Should There Be a Legal Age Limit for Playing Football?</li>
    <li>College Football Players Diagnosed with CTE Confirms Warnings from Concussion Legacy Foundation</li>
    <li>First Extreme Sport Athlete Diagnosed with Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy</li>
</ul>

AUTHOR: Crandall Pera Law
TITLE: Steve Crandall Explored the Pros and Cons of Social Media on Juries at the 2018 OAJ Convention
BASENAME: steve-crandall-explored-the-pros-and-cons-of-social-media-on-juries-at-the-2018-oaj-convention
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 05/07/2018 02:02:44 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-7459" src="https://www.injuryverdicts.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/IMG_5833-e1525719717890-225x300.jpg" alt="Steve Crandall Explored the Pros and Cons of Social Media on Juries at the 2018 OAJ Convention" width="225" height="300">The Annual Convention of the Ohio Association for Justice was from May 2 to May 4 this year, and it was &#x2013; as always &#x2013; a rousing success. This year&#x2019;s convention offered numerous opportunities for attendees to obtain their CLE credits, to play a few rounds of golf, and to network and reconnect with colleagues from throughout the state. This year&#x2019;s speeches (once again) stole the show, and Steve Crandall&#x2019;s presentation was a very big hit.

Titled &#x201C;Social Media in the Courtroom: The Effects on Jury Selection and Jury Verdicts,&#x201D; Steve&#x2019;s presentation focused on the psychological effects of social media on empathy and narcissism in society, in general. He also analyzed how this may affect jurors who hear Crandall &amp; Pera&#x2019;s cases at trial, and what effects that might have on the verdicts for injured clients, or for families filing wrongful death and survival actions.

What Steve found through his review of research was both interesting and informative. Many articles focused on the use of social media and concluded negative effects occur to both men and women who utilize social media for many hours each day. However, other articles indicate social media usage, when focused on communication with family and friends, can result in positive results for mood and feelings of self-worth. In the end, other articles pointed out it is how and why a person uses social media that may matter the most. If an individual uses social media to stay connected, positive results occur. Meanwhile, if the user focuses on self-promotion and changes their profile photo on a weekly basis, this can result in depression and narcissistic behavior.
<h2>Why social media usage and response matters in a jury trial setting</h2>
Aside from the obvious &#x2013; what lawyer doesn&#x2019;t want an empathetic jury? &#x2013; there are many reasons why social media usage matters when it comes to selecting a jury and to going to trial. Potential and selected jurors:
<ol>
    <li>Will likely review the attorney and the firm&#x2019;s social media usage.</li>
    <li>Will likely look one another up on sites like Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn (as well as Instagram and Snapchat).</li>
    <li>May disregard directions about avoiding information from the case &#x2013; or may be unwillingly subject to it through their own social media feeds.</li>
    <li>May reveal more about who they are on their own social media pages.</li>
</ol>
Understanding the correlation between how a juror posts, and the research regarding empathy and narcissism, could help a trial attorney determine the best way to present his or her case. In a medical malpractice trial, where people must weigh the facts about the case while contending their own feelings and preconceived notions about the medical profession and healthcare, this knowledge could prove invaluable to the attorney.

All of us at Crandall &amp; Pera Law want to extend a warm &#x201C;Congratulations!&#x201D; to Steve Crandall for a job well done at this year&#x2019;s OAJ Convention.
-----
