AUTHOR: Steve Crandall
TITLE: What Will the Police Report Tell Me about My Accident?
BASENAME: what-will-the-police-report-tell-me-about-my-accident
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 02/06/2019 08:41:10 AM
-----
BODY:
Many people, after a car accident, think they don&#x2019;t need to file a police report. Maybe the accident was just a &#x201C;minor&#x201D; one, or maybe the negligent party took responsibility for the incident. However, if it ends up that you need to seek compensation for unanticipated medical bills, that police report will likely be the most valuable piece of evidence you&#x2019;ll have in your possession.

The purpose of a police report is to provide documentation of a car accident. It&#x2019;s an unbiased and third party report about what happened &#x2013; including details like contact information of drivers and witnesses, pertinent information about the accident, initial injuries, and citations issued. And, you&#x2019;ll need a police report to access your own insurance benefits.
<h2>Reading your police report after a crash</h2>
When you receive a copy of your report, the first thing you should do is check it for accuracy. Details matter, especially when you&#x2019;re bringing a case against a negligent driver. You should find the following information on a police report:
<ul>
    <li><strong>Vehicle number.</strong> This section is important &#x2013; note which vehicle number you are on the report (V1, V2, etc.). It will appear in several places, so make sure you know which one refers to you.</li>
    <li><strong>Driver information and location.</strong> Check your home address, date of birth, and driver&#x2019;s license number for accuracy, as well as the location of the accident.</li>
    <li>In this section, officers list any traffic violations they believe may have caused the accident, like alcohol or drugs, or careless driving.</li>
    <li><strong>Driver factors.</strong> Driver factors include driver condition and driver actions. These factors can be crucial pieces of evidence in your car accident case, and insurance companies tend to examine them closely when determining compensation.
<ul>
    <li><strong>Driver condition</strong> &#x2013; The police officer will check off anything he or she believes may have factored into your accident (on the part of either driver), including things like &#x201C;appeared normal,&#x201D; &#x201C;apparently asleep,&#x201D; or &#x201C;illegal drug use.&#x201D;</li>
    <li><strong>Driver actions</strong> &#x2013; Actions that might cause a car wreck include &#x201C;failure to yield right of way,&#x201D; &#x201C;failure to obey traffic controls,&#x201D; or &#x201C;inattentive.&#x201D;</li>
</ul>
</li>
    <li><strong>Driver alcohol/drugs.</strong> This section indicates whether or not either driver was under the influence of drugs or alcohol at the time of the crash. Ensure you read this section carefully as well, as it can be another critical piece of evidence in your case.</li>
</ul>
Remember, the at-fault driver may give a completely different account of the facts to their insurance company, so the police report is your most important tool in getting the maximum amount of compensation to which you&#x2019;re entitled. You can get your report from the city police department or the county sheriff&#x2019;s department that handled your accident.

Hurt in a car accident? Crandall &amp; Pera Law is here to help. To schedule a free consultation with a member of our team, please call&#xA0;877-686-8879&#xA0; or&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact us</a> today. Our car accident lawyers represent clients throughout Ohio and Kentucky.

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

--------
AUTHOR: Marc Pera
TITLE: Why Truck Back-Up Accidents Happen
BASENAME: why-truck-back-up-accidents-happen
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 0
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 0
DATE: 01/28/2019 09:42:48 AM
-----
BODY:
Various types of workplace settings require large vehicles and trailers to perform careful back-up maneuvers. It is in these settings that the potential for truck back-up accidents is elevated.

Although most drivers operate their motor vehicles in reverse gear for only a very small fraction of their driving time, <a href="https://www.tdi.texas.gov/pubs/videoresource/fsvehiclebackin.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">1 in 4 vehicle accidents occur while backing up</a>, according to the National Safety Council (NSC).

These crashes often take place at very low speeds, but they have the potential to cause serious injuries and even death. According to the National Highway Traffic and Safety Administration (NHTSA), <a href="https://crashstats.nhtsa.dot.gov/Api/Public/ViewPublication/811144" target="_blank" rel="noopener">more than 200 people are killed every year in back-up accidents</a>.
<h2>Tools to enhance back-up safety</h2>
Every vehicle on the road is equipped with at least a minimum amount of accessories and tools to help drivers reverse safely. These can include rearview mirrors, side mirrors, proximity detection devices, backing cameras, and backing alarms.

Drivers have the responsibility to pay attention to these safety devices while performing back-up maneuvers in addition to ensuring the devices are operating properly prior to commencing a new trip. It is also important for drivers to understand that even the most technologically advanced safety devices may not completely eliminate the problem of blind spots.

Rearview mirrors installed on trucks are sufficient for detecting vehicles behind the truck. However, they are often inadequate for detecting persons, small children, or objects close to the ground.
<h2>Large vehicles and tractor trailers</h2>
Semi-trucks, construction equipment, vehicles equipped with trailers, and other large vehicles pose a potentially more severe backing hazard than smaller vehicles. These vehicles are taller than standard SUVs or other passenger vehicles. As well, they are not always equipped with rear windows or accessible rearview mirrors. When a trailer reverses, it pivots in the opposite direction of the truck&#x2019;s cab. Drivers of trailers must use a spotter when backing up to compensate for the limited view and potential blind spots that exist when attempting to perform a back-up maneuver.

Drivers should take the following safety steps and precautions when backing up a large truck to prevent back-up accidents:
<ul>
    <li>Conduct a walk around prior to backing up</li>
    <li>Remove any potential obstacles from the back-up path</li>
    <li>Ensure the vehicle&#x2019;s back-up alarm is functioning properly before backing up</li>
    <li>Park in locations free of obstacles</li>
    <li>Back-up slowly, while utilizing pertinent back-up safety devices</li>
    <li>Back-up the vehicle as straight as possible to prevent the trailer from swinging out of control</li>
    <li>Back into parking spots upon arrival as opposed to backing out when leaving</li>
</ul>
<h2>Help for victims of backing-up truck accidents</h2>
Often large trucking companies and their drivers will seek to avoid liability for any accidents, back-up or otherwise, they have caused. When a trucking carrier or its insurance provider has denied your bodily injury claim, you may need the skillful representation of an experienced commercial truck crash attorney. Your attorney can interview eyewitnesses, gather evidence, and in some cases employ accident reconstruction experts to help bolster your case.

If you have suffered an injury in a truck back-up accident, our seasoned Ohio and Kentucky truck accident attorneys at Crandall &amp; Pera Law can hold those responsible to account, fighting to help you obtain the compensation you deserve. To schedule a free case evaluation, call us today at 877.686.8879&#xA0;or use our&#xA0;<a href="/Contact.shtml">contact form</a> to send us a message.

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;
-----

AUTHOR: steve
TITLE: Predicting a Premature Delivery
BASENAME: predicting-premature-delivery
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 01/25/2017 09:06:43 AM
-----
BODY:
In the United States, <a href="http://www.marchofdimes.org/complications/preterm-labor-and-premature-baby.aspx">premature birth</a> is the leading cause of <a href="http://www.marchofdimes.org/complications/long-term-health-effects-of-premature-birth.aspx">permanent disabilities,</a> and sometimes death in babies. In many cases, it is unclear why a woman experiences preterm (premature) birth. A baby that is born before the 37<sup>th</sup> week of pregnancy is considered preterm.

Physicians and scientists continue to study the various <a href="http://www.marchofdimes.org/research/finding-the-causes-of-prematurity.aspx">causes of preterm labor</a>, which may allow them to identify risk factors that would cause a woman to be at an increased risk of delivering her baby prematurely. This area of research is very important, because once preterm labor starts, it may be very difficult, and sometimes impossible, to stop it.

One method that is used to help predict which women will experience premature labor is by measuring the length of her cervix (the opening to the uterus). One of the first changes that occur in a woman&#x2019;s body before she goes into labor is shortening (effacement) of her cervix. The cervix may begin to shorten weeks before labor starts. &#xA0;If the cervix is shorter than normal early in her pregnancy, she has a higher risk of premature labor. Based on this risk, her physician can offer treatments to reduce her risk of, or prevent, premature labor.

The most accurate method to check the length of the cervix is by <a href="http://www.marchofdimes.org/complications/cervical-insufficiency-and-short-cervix.aspx">transvaginal ultrasound</a>. Because the cervix begins to thin, or shorten, from the inside, the ultrasound can detect this before a woman&#x2019;s physician or midwife could when performing a vaginal exam.

If you have already delivered a baby that was not born prematurely, or if you are expecting your first baby, it is recommended that measuring the length of your cervix is done as a part of a routine ultrasound between the 18<sup>th</sup> and 24<sup>th</sup> week of pregnancy. If the length of the cervix is within the normal range, there is no need to repeat an ultrasound for the purpose of measuring the cervix.

Women who have a history of delivering a baby before the 37<sup>th</sup> week of pregnancy due to premature labor have an increased risk of premature labor in future pregnancies. Due to this increased risk, if you experienced preterm labor and delivered a baby before your 37<sup>th</sup> week of pregnancy, The Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine recommends that you have the first transvaginal ultrasound to measure cervical length between the 14<sup>th</sup> and 16<sup>th</sup> week of your pregnancy, followed by additional ultrasounds.

One drug that has proven to reduce the risk of preterm birth is called 17-alpha-hydroxyprogesterone caproate, which is a form of <a href="http://www.marchofdimes.org/complications/progesterone-treatment-to-help-prevent-premature-birth.aspx">progesterone</a>. It&#x2019;s also known as &#x201C;17P.&#x201D; In 2011, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved this drug for the prevention of preterm delivery. It is available in three forms, a pill, injection (shot), or vaginal suppository. Women who take progesterone usually begin in the 16<sup>th</sup> week and stop when they reach the 36<sup>th</sup> week of pregnancy. How often it is given depends on what form of the medication is prescribed.

If you have a history of a preterm delivery, talk to your physician or midwife. He, or she, will be able to answer questions based on your personal history.

Berghella, V. (2017). Second-trimester evaluation of cervical length for prediction of spontaneous preterm birth in singleton gestations. <em>UpToDate</em>. Retrieved from <a href="http://www.uptodate.com">http://www.uptodate.com</a>
-----
EXTENDED BODY:

-----
EXCERPT:

-----
KEYWORDS:

--------
AUTHOR: steve
TITLE: Water Births and Relief from Labor Pains
BASENAME: water-births-relief-labor-pains
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 11/30/2016 09:48:34 AM
-----
BODY:
When you are pregnant, it&#x2019;s only natural to think ahead to the day that you finally go into labor. One aspect of labor that is bound to cross your mind is pain; more importantly, ways to reduce the pain. There is little doubt that you will hear of various methods to deal with labor pain. Depending upon where you plan to deliver your baby, you may have different options available to you.

One option that you may hear about is a water birth, where a woman gives birth to her baby while submerged in a tub of warm water. Water births have taken place for decades. In the early 1980s, a French obstetrician published a research paper on his experiences with water births, focusing on the benefits of pain relief.
<h2>Not everyone agrees on the benefits</h2>
While there are many hospitals and birthing centers around the world that give women the option of laboring in warm water, there are different views regarding a woman giving birth while submerged in water due to the risks associated with this practice. Due to concerns regarding safety for a mother and her baby, the opinion of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) on water births is that they are experimental and should only be permitted during experimental trials.<sup>1</sup> The American College of Nurse Midwives and the American Association of Birth Centers, however, consider water births to be a safe practice.<sup>2</sup>

Many hospitals and birthing centers have tubs that women can relax in during the <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/labor/induction-of-labor/">first stage of labor</a>, but they do not permit a mother to remain in the water during her second stage of labor when she is pushing. The main issue regarding water births is the fact that there have not been enough studies performed that weigh the risks and benefits of this practice. There is a risk of a baby drowning. There is also the risk of infection due to the presence of bacteria in the water, as well as the possibility of a delay in providing treatment to a mother, or baby, in case of an emergency.

Whatever option you choose, make sure to discuss it with your doctor or midwife first. He or she will be able to help you make the right decision for you and your baby.

<sup>1</sup><em>ACOG Committee Opinion no. 594.</em> (2014): Immersion in water during labor and delivery.

<em>Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, 123</em>(4), 912-915. Retrieved from https://www.

Clinicalkey.com/#!content/2.0-24785637

<sup>2</sup>Sempsrott, J., Schmidt, A., Hawkins, S., &amp; Cushings, T. (2017). Drowning and Submersion

Injuries. <em>Auerbach&#x2019;s wilderness medicine (7<sup>th</sup> ed.).</em> Philadelphia PA: Elseiver
-----

--------
AUTHOR: steve
TITLE: Delayed Cord Clamping
BASENAME: delayed-cord-clamping
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 03/20/2017 02:24:59 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-420" src="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Delayed-Cord-Clamping-300x201.jpg" alt="Delayed Cord Clamping" width="300" height="201">For many years, it was common practice for obstetricians and midwives to clamp and cut the umbilical cord immediately after a baby&#x2019;s birth. Based on results of research regarding the benefits of delayed cord clamping, The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) <a href="http://www.acog.org/Resources-And-Publications/Committee-Opinions/Committee-on-Obstetric-Practice/Delayed-Umbilical-Cord-Clamping-After-Birth">now recommends</a> that clamping of the cord be delayed at least one minute for all term and premature deliveries. The latest practice guidelines, released in December, 2016, replaces the 2012 statement recommending that cord clamping be delayed only in premature births.

Delayed cord clamping is also endorsed by the American College of Nurse Midwives, which recommends a delay of two to five minutes before clamping the umbilical cord. The American Academy of Pediatrics, as well as the World Health Organization recommends at least a one-minute delay in both term and premature babies that do not require resuscitation at birth. Also, the 2017 Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines has incorporated delayed cord clamping of at least 30 to 60 seconds into the standards of care for most term and premature newborns that do not require resuscitative measures at birth.

There is no exact amount of time that should elapse before the cord is clamped. It is recommended that there be a minimum of one minute delay, however, depending on the mother&#x2019;s preference and recommendations from the physician or midwife, it may be a longer period of time.
<h2>Benefits of Delayed Cord Clamping</h2>
In premature babies (born before the 37<sup>th</sup> week of pregnancy), delayed cord clamping:
<ul>
    <li>Improves the transition from fetal to newborn circulation</li>
    <li>Increases baby&#x2019;s blood volume, which reduces the need for blood transfusions</li>
    <li>Reduces the risk of bleeding in the brain (intraventricular hemorrhage)</li>
    <li>Reduces the risk of an intestinal disease known as necrotizing enterocolitis</li>
    <li>Helps to stabilize baby&#x2019;s blood pressure</li>
    <li>Increases urine output</li>
</ul>
In term babies (born after the 37<sup>th</sup> week of pregnancy), delayed cord clamping:
<ul>
    <li>Increases baby&#x2019;s blood volume (hemoglobin levels)</li>
    <li>Improves iron stores in the blood, reducing the risk of iron-deficiency anemia during baby&#x2019;s first year of life (iron deficiency can cause delays in cognitive development and motor skills)</li>
</ul>
<h2>The Umbilical Cord</h2>
The umbilical cord serves as the lifeline that delivers blood rich in oxygen and nutrients from the placenta to the baby before birth. Most of the time, the umbilical cord contains two arteries and one vein. The blood that is rich in oxygen and nutrients flows to baby (fetus) through the umbilical vein. The umbilical arteries carry unoxygenated blood and waste products from baby.

When baby is delivered, the placenta continues to perform gas exchange, as well as transfer blood volume to baby. Approximately 75% (80milliliters) of this blood is transferred within the first minute after birth and an additional 20 milliliters is delivered at three minutes after birth. If the umbilical cord is clamped immediately after birth, baby doesn&#x2019;t benefit from this transfer of blood. In addition to blood, immunoglobulins and stem cells are also transferred to baby&#x2019;s body.

The results of clinical trials have shown that the flow of blood from the placenta does not depend on the position of baby in relation to the placenta. In the past, it was recommended that a baby must be positioned at the level of the placenta, or lower, to allow for the blood to flow. After a vaginal delivery, it is recommended that baby be placed on the mother&#x2019;s chest or abdomen, dried and covered with dry linen, allowing for immediate skin-to-skin contact while waiting for the cord to be clamped, then cut. During a cesarean delivery, baby may be placed on the mother&#x2019;s abdomen or legs, or be held by a member of the surgical team as close to the level of the placenta as possible.

With delayed cord clamping, there is an increased risk of jaundice in babies born at term. If jaundice develops, baby may require treatment with phototherapy to reduce the bilirubin levels in the bloodstream.

Delayed cord clamping should never interfere with immediate care that is required for a baby that is not breathing, or showing signs of other difficulties. Also, it should never interfere with care that is needed if the mother is unstable. In situations where there is a known abnormality with perfusion of the placenta, the risks and benefits of delayed cord clamping should be prompt a discussion among the parents, obstetrician, and neonatology team.

In situations where <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/complications/umbilical-cord-prolapse/" target="_blank">umbilical cord</a> blood banking is desired, delayed cord clamping has been shown to significantly reduce the number of cells available for banking. If you are considering cord blood banking, talk to your physician or midwife.

&#xA0;

&#xA0;
-----
EXTENDED BODY:

AUTHOR: steve
TITLE: Use of Laughing Gas for Pain Relief During Labor
BASENAME: use-laughing-gas-pain-relief-labor
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 03/03/2017 08:01:50 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-415" src="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Nitrous-Oxide-Labor-and-Pregnancy-300x200.jpg" alt="Nitrous Oxide, Labor and Pregnancy" width="300" height="200">The use of nitrous oxide, perhaps better known as &#x201C;laughing gas,&#x201D; has been offered for several years by dentists to reduce the anxiety and discomfort in patients undergoing dental procedures. Nitrous oxide is a tasteless, odorless, nonflammable gas, and has been used in countries such as New Zealand, Great Britain, Scandinavia, and Canada for decades for relief of pain during labor.

In the United States, &#x201C;laughing gas&#x201D; was not available to pregnant women for relief of pain during labor until recently. As a result of the Food &amp; Drug Administration&#x2019;s approval for the use of nitrous oxide during labor, many hospitals now offer it as an option to reduce pain while giving birth.
<h2>How is nitrous oxide administered to women?</h2>
The gas is delivered to a woman in labor by a mask or mouthpiece that contains a blend of half oxygen, half nitrous oxide; the mother holds the mask or mouthpiece in her hand. When she places the mask over her mouth and nose, or the mouthpiece in her mouth, and inhales (breathes in), a valve that is attached to the tank opens. When this valve opens, the mixture of oxygen and nitrous oxide is delivered; that valve closes when the woman exhales (breathes out).
<h2>How does laughing gas eliminate pain during labor?</h2>
In order for the gas to be effective in relieving the pain caused by contractions, it must be timed correctly. After the gas is inhaled, it takes up to 50 seconds to work. If a woman inhales the mixture when she feels a contraction starting, it may be too late to have any effect on the pain felt during the contraction. To avoid this, it is recommended that the gas is inhaled 30 seconds before a contraction starts. This requires the laboring mother, or her support person, to be aware of how often contractions are occurring.
<h2>Is nitrous oxide safe for women in labor?</h2>
A safety feature of the use of nitrous oxide during labor is the fact that the laboring mother is in control of the mask or mouthpiece. If she is too drowsy, she will likely not be able to hold them in the correct manner necessary to receive another dose of nitrous oxide. Side effects for a laboring mother include nausea and vomiting.

Nitrous oxide is removed from the body quickly by exhaling; therefore, it does not build up in the mother&#x2019;s or baby&#x2019;s system. That aspect of nitrous oxide is well-known. What isn&#x2019;t so well-known is what effect, if any, nitrous oxide has on a baby&#x2019;s developing brain.

If you are expecting a baby and interested in this method to control the pain caused from contractions when you are in labor, talk to your physician or midwife about the safety of nitrous oxide for both you and your baby.

Grant, G. (2017). <a href="http://www.uptodate.com/contents/pharmacologic-management-of-pain-during-labor-and-delivery">Pharmacologic management of pain during labor and delivery</a>. <em>Retrieved from </em>

<em>&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0; UpToDate.com</em>.
-----

AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: Signs and Symptoms of Postpartum Depression
BASENAME: signs-symptoms-postpartum-depression
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/27/2017 07:25:44 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-455" src="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Postpartum-Depression-300x200.jpg" alt="Signs and Symptoms of Postpartum Depression" width="300" height="200">Postpartum depression is a type of depression that a woman can experience after the birth of her baby. The word &#x201C;postpartum&#x201D; refers to the period of time after giving birth. Although a woman may begin to exhibit symptoms of depression during the first month following the birth of her baby, symptoms can develop any time within the first year. It is also possible to experience postpartum depression before a woman gives birth.

It is common for a woman to develop &#x201C;baby blues&#x201D; during the first few days after <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/">giving birth</a>, causing her to be irritable, moody, cry frequently, and have trouble concentrating or sleeping. This is considered to be a mild form of depression and usually goes away within the first two weeks without any treatment. A woman suffering from postpartum depression, the symptoms are more severe and last longer than two weeks.
<h2>How do I know if it&#x2019;s postpartum depression?</h2>
Because of the fact that a new mom may feel tired and overwhelmed due to lack of sleep, as well as the stress that often comes with having a new baby, it may be difficult to tell what is considered to be normal during this time. Generally, these symptoms should improve over the first couple of weeks. For the woman with postpartum depression, instead of her symptoms improving, they tend to get worse as time goes on.
<ul>
    <li>She may feel completely overwhelmed, anxious, irritable, even angry</li>
    <li>She may feel guilty, and that she is a failure as a mother</li>
    <li>She may be unable to sleep, even when her baby is sleeping</li>
    <li>She may be unable to get out of bed and sleep for hours at a time</li>
    <li>She may have little interest in her baby</li>
    <li>She may feel isolated and unable to tell her family how she feels, afraid that she will be judged</li>
    <li>She may have thoughts of harming herself or her baby</li>
</ul>
It is important to understand that postpartum depression is a serious illness and it can be treated. It affects the woman&#x2019;s ability to function. It affects her ability to bond with her baby, her relationship with her family and friends. It can also affect her ability to care for her other children.
<h2>What causes postpartum depression?</h2>
Although an exact cause that is unique to postpartum depression has not been identified, research has found that it is associated with changes in hormones, such as decreases in estrogen, progesterone, cortisol, oxytocin, and thyroid hormones. It is normal for hormones to fluctuate during pregnancy and after the birth of a baby. Some women are more sensitive to these changes, especially the decrease in estrogen that occurs after delivery.

The United States Preventative Task force, The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, The American College of Nurse Midwives, and the American Academy of Pediatrics recommend that all women be screened for postpartum depression, and, that services be in place to provide treatment.

One method that is used to screen women for depression is by <a href="https://psychology-tools.com/epds/">The Edinburgh Postnatal Depression</a> <a href="https://psychology-tools.com/epds/">Scale,</a> which is a series of questions based on how a woman has felt over the past week. This is a screening tool only. Postpartum depression is not diagnosed by this.
<h2>Some risk factors for developing postpartum depression</h2>
Although all risk factors for developing postpartum depression are not known, the following have been identified:
<ul>
    <li>A history of depression in the past</li>
    <li>Depression during pregnancy</li>
    <li>High levels of stress either before or after delivery</li>
    <li>A family history of depression</li>
    <li>A history of experiencing either physical or emotional abuse</li>
    <li>Health problems either before, during, or after delivery</li>
    <li>Mothers of babies that require care in a Neonatal Intensive Care Unit</li>
    <li>Mothers that experienced a stillbirth, or death of baby after birth</li>
    <li>Mothers who deliver during seasons of decreased daylight (winter months)</li>
</ul>
Every woman is unique, therefore, there is no single test used to diagnose postpartum depression. The most important factor is that a new mother realizes that if she is experiencing symptoms, such as feeling sad, empty, guilty, or hopeless most every day, it is important that she tell a family member or friend, as well as contact her physician or midwife for help.
<ul>
    <li>Viguera, A. (2016). Postpartum unipolar major depression: Epidemiology, clinical features, assessment, And diagnosis. <a href="https://www.uptodate.com/contents/postpartum-unipolar-major-depression-epidemiology-clinical-features-assessment-and-diagnosis">UpToDate</a>. Retrieved from http://www.uptodate.com.</li>
</ul>

AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: Substance Abuse in Pregnancy
BASENAME: substance-abuse-pregnancy
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/19/2017 11:01:04 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-460" src="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/GettyImages-462975753-300x200.jpg" alt="Substance Abuse in Pregnancy" width="300" height="200">A pregnant woman addicted to opiates may fear that telling her physician or midwife about her addiction will be met with a judgmental attitude, as well as legal problems. It is common practice for healthcare providers to ask a woman about any substance abuse at her first <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/beginning-stages/the-first-prenatal-visit/" target="_blank">prenatal visit</a>. These questions are asked so that treatment can be offered, which will greatly improve the health of the woman and her baby. The goal of treatment during pregnancy is not to expect the woman to stop using the drug and suffer the side effects of withdrawal, but rather to replace the drug of addiction with a safe alternative medication.
<h2>The use of methadone in opioid-substitution therapy</h2>
Opioid-substitution therapy, with a medication such as methadone and suboxone, is prescribed as part of a treatment program that includes counseling and monitoring of how well the woman is responding to the medication, so that adjustments in the dose can be made.

The choice of medication is a decision that is made between the woman, her obstetrician or midwife, and the drug-treatment center physician. Methadone is more commonly used in pregnancy because more research has been done to prove that it is safe for use in pregnancy. A woman does not have to have symptoms of withdrawal from the drug that she is currently using to begin treatment. The methadone dose that she starts with varies, and daily adjustments can be made, depending on the woman&#x2019;s response to the medication. Some women may take a daily dose of methadone, while others do better with the daily dose split in half, taking it twice a day.

It is common practice to arrange a meeting between the woman and a member of the anesthesia team at the hospital where she plans to have her baby. This meeting will allow the woman to learn about how her pain can be managed during labor. Women who have a history of opioid addiction may respond to pain differently. There are treatment options in place to manage her pain effectively, such as receiving an epidural during labor.

After her baby is born, he or she will be closely monitored by the nursing staff in the nursery for signs of withdrawal symptoms, known as neonatal abstinence syndrome. If the baby demonstrates excessive symptoms of withdrawal of the methadone, there are methods to ease those symptoms. Just as the drug that the woman took before beginning a treatment program crossed the placenta, reaching the baby, the methadone also entered into baby&#x2019;s circulation, but it is much safer. Mothers on methadone or suboxone are encouraged to breastfeed, as this will lessen the symptoms of withdrawal, because both medications are found in breast milk.

If you are pregnant and suffer from addiction to an opiate substance, talk to your physician or midwife. Their main goal, and reason for asking you about the presence of any substance abuse, is that treatment be offered to you so that you will have a healthy pregnancy, and a healthy baby.

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;
-----

AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: It&#x2019;s Mosquito Season: What Pregnant Women Should Know about Zika
BASENAME: mosquito-season-pregnant-women-know-zika
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 06/22/2017 01:53:13 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-462" src="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/It&#x2019;s-Mosquito-Season-What-Pregnant-Women-Should-Know-about-Zika-300x200.jpg" alt="It&#x2019;s Mosquito Season: What Pregnant Women Should Know about Zika" width="300" height="200">The Zika virus is transmitted by mosquitoes from the Aedes species, which bite during both daytime and nighttime. These mosquitoes usually lay their eggs near, or in, containers that hold water, such as buckets, animal dishes, and animal dishes.

The <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/zika/about/index.html" target="_blank">Zika virus</a> continues to spread throughout the world. As of July, 2016, 50 countries have reported cases caused by mosquitoes from the Aedes species.

Symptoms of Zika virus infection include:
<ul>
    <li>Rash</li>
    <li>Achy joints</li>
    <li>Pink eye (conjunctivitis)</li>
    <li>Fever</li>
</ul>
Most individuals with an infection caused by the Zika virus have no symptoms, or very mild symptoms. However, if a woman becomes infected with the virus while she is pregnant, it can be passed through the placenta to her baby, which could result in certain birth defects.
<h2>How does Zika affect unborn babies?</h2>
The Zika virus is relatively new, therefore, scientists continue to conduct research regarding the exact pathway of transmitting the virus to an unborn baby. Based on the research so far, it appears that the virus reaches the placenta, causing it to become infected. The virus is then passed from the placenta to baby&#x2019;s brain. The virus may cause baby&#x2019;s brain to stop developing, resulting in a condition called<a href="https://www.cdc.gov/zika/healtheffects/birth_defects.html" target="_blank"> microcephaly</a>. In severe cases, baby&#x2019;s skull may be partially collapsed. It can also cause damage to the back of baby&#x2019;s eyes, as well as damage to the joints and muscles.

The virus may also cause the woman to have a miscarriage, or deliver a stillborn baby.
<h2>How is Zika spread?</h2>
In addition to acquiring the Zika virus from mosquitoes, it can also be passed from one individual to another by having unprotected sex with someone who has the virus. For this reason, the <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/zika/prevention/sexual-transmission-prevention.html" target="_blank">CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) recommends:</a>
<ul>
    <li>If a pregnant woman&#x2019;s significant other (sex partner) has traveled to, or lives in an area where the Zika virus is known to be present:
<ul>
    <li>a barrier method, such as a condom should be used</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
OR
<ul>
    <li>&#xA0;the woman and her partner refrain (avoid) having sex until after baby is born.</li>
</ul>
<h2>Testing for Zika virus infection</h2>
If a woman is exposed to the Zika virus during pregnancy, it does not mean that her baby will be born with birth defects. The CDC recommends that all pregnant women be screened for possible exposure to the virus at every prenatal visit. All pregnant women that may have been exposed to the virus should be tested, even if they have no symptoms.
<ul>
    <li>The virus can be detected by both blood and urine samples.</li>
    <li>Regardless of the results of testing, all women that have been tested due to possible exposure to the virus should have an ultrasound to monitor her baby for signs of Zika virus infection. The amount and timing of the ultrasounds is a decision that will be made by the woman and her physician.</li>
    <li>The exact timing of ultrasound findings suggesting that baby has been affected is unknown. If a mother is infected early in her pregnancy, ultrasound findings of infection in her baby may be present by her 18<sup>th</sup> week of pregnancy.</li>
</ul>
At this point, there is no specific treatment for the Zika virus other than rest and treating the symptoms of fever and joint pain.

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

&#xA0;

Lockwood, C., Romero, S., &amp; Nielsen-Saines, K. (2017). Zika virus infection: Evaluation and

management of pregnant women. <em>UpToDate.</em> Retrieved from https://www.

uptodate.com

Mendoza, C., Beard, C., Munoz, J., Rao, C., Meaney-Delman, D., Jamieson, D., &amp; Honein,
<ol>
    <li>(2016). Update: Interim guidance for health care providers caring for pregnant</li>
</ol>
women with possible Zika virus exposure &#x2013; United States, July, 2016. <em>Morbidity and</em>

<em>Mortality Weekly Report, 65</em>(29), 739-744. Retrieved from https://www-cdc-

gov./zika/pdfs/uszpr_toolkit_ob.pdf

AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: Marijuana Use in Pregnancy Made Lead to Complications for the Baby
BASENAME: marijuana-use-pregnancy-made-lead-complications-baby
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 07/24/2017 12:36:06 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-465" src="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/Marijuana-Use-in-Pregnancy-Made-Lead-to-Complications-for-the-Baby-300x200.jpg" alt="Marijuana Use in Pregnancy Made Lead to Complications for the Baby" width="300" height="200">Marijuana use continues to increase in the United States, including use by women who are pregnant. It is the most commonly used illicit drug used during pregnancy. A national survey involving over 200,000 women between the ages of 18 and 44, the use of marijuana during pregnancy increased by over 60 percent between 2002 to 2014.<sup>1</sup>

Although there is limited information regarding the effects on the babies of mothers who smoke marijuana in pregnancy, there does not seem to be an increased risk of premature labor and birth. There is also no evidence that marijuana use causes birth defects. Some research studies have shown that babies born to mothers that smoke marijuana on a regular basis are smaller at birth.<sup>2 </sup>

So far, what research has shown is that children born to mothers that smoked marijuana may have:
<ul>
    <li>Lower scores in verbal reasoning, especially if the mother smoked marijuana during the first trimester of pregnancy.</li>
    <li>Lower scores on tests requiring abilities related to short-term memory, math, and reasoning skills, especially if the mother smoked marijuana during the second trimester.</li>
    <li>Decreased attention spans, impulsive behavior, hyperactivity, anxiety, and depression.</li>
</ul>
Marijuana also passes through breast milk to infants. Babies that are breastfed by mothers that regularly smoke marijuana have shown a decrease in muscle tone, difficulty sucking, and a delay in motor development at one year of age.

Delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (TCH) is the main compound found in marijuana. However, there are over 450 ingredients in marijuana smoke. Many of these ingredients are toxic.

&#xA0;
<ol>
    <li>Chang, G. (2017). Substance misuse in pregnant women. <em>UpToDate</em>. Retrieved from</li>
</ol>
<a href="https://www.uptodate.com/contents/substance-misuse-in-pregnant-women">https://www.uptodate.com/contents/substance-misuse-in-pregnant-women</a>
<ol start="2">
    <li>Jansson, L. (2016). Infants of mothers with substance use disorder.<em> UpToDate</em>. Retrieved from</li>
</ol>
<a href="http://www.uptodate.com/contents/infants-of-mothers-with-substance-use-disorder">http://www.uptodate.com/contents/infants-of-mothers-with-substance-use-disorder</a>

AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: Your Baby Needs Vitamin K to be Healthy
BASENAME: baby-needs-vitamin-k-healthy
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/17/2017 01:06:02 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-467" src="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/GettyImages-660340904-300x200.jpg" alt="Your Baby Needs Vitamin K to be Healthy" width="300" height="200">Vitamin K is very important for blood to have the ability to clot so that any bleeding stops. Before birth, very little amounts of vitamin K are transferred to the baby through the placenta. Babies are not able to make vitamin K it on their own, therefore, the ability of baby&#x2019;s blood to clot is reduced due to the reduced amount of vitamin K stored in his body.

Also, at birth, a baby&#x2019;s liver is immature, so it doesn&#x2019;t process vitamin K like a mature liver does. If the vitamin K is not replaced after baby is born, he or she is at a much higher risk for vitamin K deficient bleeding (VKDB), which may involve bleeding in the brain, bruising easily, and bleeding from the gastrointestinal tract. In can also increase the amount of bleeding after a baby boy is circumcised.
<h2>Where does vitamin K come from?</h2>
We get vitamin K from the foods that we eat. It is also produced by the healthy bacteria found in our gastrointestinal tract. At birth, a baby&#x2019;s gastrointestinal tract is sterile, so there are no healthy bacteria available needed to produce vitamin K. As your baby gets older, he or she will produce this type of healthy bacteria. Small amounts of vitamin K are present in breast milk, but it is not enough.

Babies that do not receive a vitamin K injection after birth are at risk for bleeding to occur during their first six months of life. To prevent bleeding, the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that infants be given vitamin K soon after baby is born.
<h2>Why is vitamin K given in an injection?</h2>
Although vitamin K can be given to baby by mouth, it would take many doses given over several weeks, and it is not always absorbed by baby&#x2019;s body very well. At this time, there is no oral form of vitamin K that has been approved for use in the United States.

Pazirandeh, S., &amp; Burns, D. (2016). Overview of vitamin K. <em>UpToDate</em>. Retrieved from

<a href="http://www.uptodate.com/contents/overview-of-vitamin-k" target="_blank">http://www.uptodate.com/contents/overview-of-vitamin-k</a>
-----

--------
AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: Can You Give Birth Vaginally If You&#x2019;ve Already Had a C-Section?
BASENAME: can-give-birth-vaginally-youve-already-c-section
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 09/15/2017 12:13:22 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-471" src="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Can-You-Give-Birth-Vaginally-If-You&#x2019;ve-Already-Had-a-C-Section-300x200.jpg" alt="Can You Give Birth Vaginally If You&#x2019;ve Already Had a C-Section?" width="300" height="200">Women who have undergone a cesarean section often have questions about the safety of attempting a vaginal birth in the future. The safety of a trial of labor after cesarean section (TOLAC) has been the subject of debate for many years.

A successful TOLAC is one that ends with a vaginal delivery after cesarean section (VBAC).

Not every woman that has previously undergone a cesarean section is considered a good candidate for a TOLAC. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) considers the following women <a href="https://www.uptodate.com/contents/vaginal-birth-after-cesarean-delivery-vbac-beyond-the-basics" target="_blank">ideal candidates for a TOLAC</a>:
<ul>
    <li>Those in which a low, transverse, uterine incision was made during the cesarean section</li>
    <li>Those who have had a previous vaginal delivery, especially after a cesarean section (a VBAC)</li>
    <li>Those who have had only one cesarean section</li>
    <li>Those that go into labor on their own (not induced)</li>
    <li>The previous cesarean section was performed because of baby&#x2019;s position (breech, transverse)</li>
    <li>The cesarean section was performed when the woman was in early labor</li>
    <li>Labor begins before the pregnancy is post-dates (overdue)</li>
    <li>Those that have no medical conditions, such as high blood pressure, diabetes, heart conditions, and kidney disease</li>
</ul>
<h2>What are the risks?</h2>
Delivery of a baby by cesarean section requires an opening (incision) to be made within the uterus. After baby is delivered, the opening is closed by sutures (sewing). When a woman becomes pregnant again, there is a risk of her uterus rupturing (tearing apart) in the area that it was cut (incision site) when she is in labor. If the uterus ruptures, it is a medical emergency. An emergency cesarean section must be performed within minutes of the rupture, otherwise, the baby will not survive. The life of the mother may also be at risk due to a large amount of blood loss.

Women who deliver in larger, teaching hospitals have a higher TOLAC success rate compared to those that attempt a trial of labor after a cesarean section in a smaller, non-teaching hospital.

A trial of labor after cesarean section should only be considered in hospitals that have the necessary medical professionals immediately available if an emergency cesarean section is needed.

The decision to attempt a trial of labor after cesarean section is one that is made between a woman and her physician, taking into consideration the risks involved for Mom and Baby.
-----
EXTENDED BODY:

-----

AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: The Facts on Epidurals for Labor
BASENAME: facts-epidurals-labor
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 11/15/2017 09:58:54 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-480" src="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/GettyImages-489341938-300x200.jpg" alt="The Facts on Epidurals for Labor" width="300" height="200">If you are pregnant, chances are that you have heard stories from other women regarding their epidural experiences. Here are some popular myths, along with the facts:
<h2>MYTH: Epidurals are too dangerous.</h2>
FACT: Epidural analgesia is the most commonly used method for pain relief during labor. It is also the most effective. In most cases, it provides the mother with excellent pain relief with minimal risks to mom and baby.

Before placing an epidural, the anesthesia team member will talk to the woman. He, or she, will review her medical history, as well as ask about any problems that she may have had with any type of anesthesia in the past.

Before an epidural is placed, the woman will have an intravenous line in place. Most of the time, IV fluids will be given before the procedure. Epidural analgesia may cause the woman&#x2019;s blood pressure to drop. Providing fluids, known as a &#x201C;bolus,&#x201D; beforehand lessens the degree of the drop in blood pressure. If mom&#x2019;s blood pressure drops too low, medication can be given quickly to raise it. The blood pressure is taken at very frequent intervals after the epidural is in place and medication is given through the epidural catheter.
<h2>MYTH: The needle used to place an epidural is huge and the process is extremely painful.</h2>
FACT: Before any needle is placed into the epidural space, the area is numbed with a local anesthetic, the same kind that dentists use before a dental procedure. This may sting for a few seconds, but it numbs the area on the back where the epidural will be placed.

When the epidural catheter is placed, the woman will feel only pressure, but not actual pain. The epidural catheter is very small, soft, and flexible. A sterile dressing is placed over the site, and then tape is used to prevent the catheter from coming out before baby is born.
<h2>MYTH: An epidural can&#x2019;t be given if the woman is too far into her labor, missing her &#x201C;window of opportunity.&#x201D;</h2>
FACT: <strong>Epidural anesthesia can be given at any time during labor</strong>. This includes early labor, or when the cervix is fully dilated. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) states that maternal request for pain relief during labor is sufficient reason to receive an epidural, as long as there are no medical contraindications. Such contraindications may be a platelet count that is too low, which would increase the risk of bleeding, or a deformity, or previous injury to the spine that would make epidural placement too difficult
<h2>MYTH: Epidurals wear off too soon to be helpful.</h2>
FACT: The medication used for epidurals is given by a continuous infusion via a pump. Most of the time, if contractions become painful before baby is born, additional medication can be given through the epidural catheter.

When the cervix is completely dilated and baby moves lower in the birth canal, it is common for the woman to feel pressure (the same feeling as needing to have a bowel movement). It may not be possible to relieve this feeling, and, the sensation helps the woman to push more effectively.
<h2>MYTH: It will take longer to push baby out with an epidural.</h2>
FACT: If a woman begins pushing too soon, before baby drops lower into the birth canal, she may push longer because she doesn&#x2019;t feel the urge to push. It is common practice to allow the woman to &#x201C;labor down.&#x201D; This means that, although the cervix is completely dilated, pushing is delayed until baby is lower in the birth canal.
<h2>MYTH: Epidurals don&#x2019;t work.</h2>
FACT: If a woman experiences no, or minimal pain relief after receiving her epidural, there are measures that can be taken. More medication, or a different type of medication, can be given through the epidural line. Sometimes, the tiny, flexible catheter may need to be adjusted. If these measures do not work, the epidural catheter can be removed and another epidural placed.
<h2>MYTH: A woman may receive too much medication, which may cause serious side effects for mom and baby.</h2>
FACT: The medication that is given through the epidural is delivered by a pump designed for epidurals.

The dose is set by the anesthesiologist or CRNA (Certified Registered Nurse Anesthetist). If the woman is given a button to push if she begins to experience pain, the pump is programmed to deliver a specific dose at specific time intervals. If the woman pushes the button before another dose can be safely given, the pump will not administer another dose until it is time.

&#xA0;

Reference: Toledano, R., &amp; Leffert, L. (2017). Neuraxial analgesia for labor and delivery (including instrument delivery). <em>UpToDate.</em> Retrieved from <a href="https://www.uptodate.com">https://www.uptodate.com</a>

&#xA0;

AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: What is Advanced Maternal Age for Pregnancy?
BASENAME: advanced-maternal-age-pregnancy
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 01/08/2018 12:14:15 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-486" src="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/GettyImages-835757546-300x200.jpg" alt="What is Advanced Maternal Age for Pregnancy?" width="300" height="200">There are many women who delay pregnancy until they are older. Many women are surprised to hear themselves referred to as being at an &#x201C;advanced&#x201D; maternal age at their first prenatal visit. There is no precise age that is considered to be &#x201C;advanced&#x201D; when a woman becomes pregnant. The American Medical Association has defined advanced maternal age at 35, and age 45 or older as very advanced maternal age. In 2013, there were over 700 births reported to women over the age of 50.

Pregnancy in women that are 35 years, or older, carries an increased risk for complications, such as ectopic pregnancy, fetal chromosome abnormalities, miscarriage, placenta previa, <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/complications/diabetes-and-pregnancy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">gestational diabetes</a>, and preeclampsia. There is also an increased risk of delivery by cesarean section. There are also benefits to having a baby at an older age. Older couples tend to be more financially stable and emotionally mature.

Pregnancies in women considered to be at advanced maternal age are managed differently than pregnancies in younger women. For example, obesity and advanced age increases the risk for a woman to develop type 2 diabetes, as well as gestational diabetes. Because of this, it is recommended that these women be screened for gestational diabetes in their first trimester (first 13 weeks of pregnancy), rather than between 26 to 28 weeks. The risk of the baby having chromosomal abnormalities (such as Down Syndrome) should be discussed, as well as the available screenings and testing.

In the third trimester (28 weeks until delivery), performing an ultrasound between 38 and 39 weeks gestation should be considered. This will allow the woman&#x2019;s physician or midwife to monitor baby&#x2019;s growth and amniotic fluid volume. A non-stress test and biophysical profile may also be performed twice a week, beginning at 36 weeks gestation.&#xA0; Instructions may be given for the woman to monitor her baby&#x2019;s movements each day.

There is an increased risk of stillbirth in women over 40. Because of this risk, the woman&#x2019;s physician may not allow the pregnancy to continue past 39 weeks gestation, inducing labor at that time if labor has not started on its own.

A woman who becomes pregnant at an older age should have a detailed discussion with her physician or midwife regarding her plan of care. With good prenatal care, the risk of developing complications can be reduced, increasing the likelihood of delivering a healthy baby.

Fretts, R. (2017). Effects of advanced maternal age on pregnancy. <em>UpToDate.</em> Retrieved from

<a href="https://www.uptodate.com/contents/effects-of-advanced-maternal-age-on-pregnancy" target="_blank" rel="noopener">https://www.uptodate.com/contents/effects-of-advanced-maternal-age-on-pregnancy</a>

AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: Hair Dye, Nail Polish, and Tattoos: Safety in Pregnancy
BASENAME: hair-dye-nail-polish-and-tattoos-safety-in-pregnancy
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 04/24/2018 10:26:25 AM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-517" src="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/AdobeStock_107615488-300x200.jpeg" alt="Hair Dye, Nail Polish, and Tattoos: Safety in Pregnancy" width="300" height="200">Studies have shown that the use of hair dyes and styling products during pregnancy results in very little of the product being absorbed into the skin if there are no open sores on the scalp. Therefore, if you are pregnant and have no open areas on your scalp, it is unlikely that such products will cause harm to your unborn baby.

If you are planning to color your hair during your pregnancy, consider using a plant-based hair dye. There is no information available on whether or not ammonia-based hair dyes are safe. Because of the limited information regarding the safety of dyes that contain ammonia and peroxide, experts suggest that pregnant women choose hair dye that does not contain ammonia or peroxide. There are many brands that do not contain these ingredients.

It is also important to apply hair dye in a well-ventilated area if you suffer from allergies or asthma because you may be more sensitive to certain scents during pregnancy. Also, try to avoid using new products, as your skin is more sensitive when you are pregnant.

Nail polish should be applied in a well-ventilated area due to the fact that some polishes contain<a href="https://www.cdc.gov/nceh/ehhe/trailerstudy/pdfs/FEMAFormaldehydeFactSheet.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener"> formaldehyde</a>, <a href="https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxfaqs/TF.asp?id=160&amp;tid=42" target="_blank" rel="noopener">toluene</a>, and <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/biomonitoring/Phthalates_FactSheet.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">dibutyl phthalate</a>.

It is recommended that you avoid getting a tattoo while you are pregnant; however, there are no proven risks if you receive a tattoo before you are aware of pregnancy. The ink used in tattoos contains both inorganic and synthetic organic pigments, which are <a href="https://www.fda.gov/ForConsumers/ConsumerUpdates/ucm048919.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">considered cosmetics by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration</a>. Because of the wide array of pigments used unsterile practices, there is the risk of infection.

If you have questions or concerns about any product, talk to your physician or midwife before using it.

Your healthcare provider should guide you through your pregnancy, and through the childbirth process. If you, your loved one, or your child sustained an injury because of the negligence of your doctor, you may be entitled to compensation. Lockwood, C., &amp; Magriples, U. (2018). Prenatal care: Patient education, health promotion, and

safety of commonly used drugs. <em>UpToDate.</em> Retrieved from https://www.uptodate.com

Pomeranz, M. (2017). Maternal adaptations to pregnancy: Skin, hair, nails, and mucous

Membranes. <em>UpToDate</em>. Retrieved from https://www.uptodate.com

AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: The Electronic Fetal Monitor
BASENAME: electronic-fetal-monitor
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 03/30/2018 02:11:09 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-510" src="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/GettyImages-500282369-300x200.jpg" alt="The Electronic Fetal Monitor" width="300" height="200">When a woman gives birth in a hospital, it is common for her to be placed on a fetal monitor. This allows her nurse to evaluate the well-being of her baby during labor. The contractions that occur during labor cause a temporary reduction in oxygen and blood flow to baby. Most of the time, a baby will tolerate this temporary event without difficulty. The fetal monitor allows the labor and delivery nurses, physicians, and midwives to get an overall picture of a baby&#x2019;s response to the contractions that occur during labor, however, they must interpret the fetal heart pattern.

When a baby&#x2019;s heart rate down below the baseline (the rate of the heart rate over a period of time), it is called a deceleration. It is common for baby&#x2019;s heartrate to fluctuate during labor. The timing of a deceleration provides a picture of how baby is handling the contractions that occur during labor. For example, when baby moves farther down in the birth canal, his head presses against mom&#x2019;s cervix during a contraction, causing a temporary drop in the heart rate. This is called an early deceleration. Early decelerations are considered to be a baby&#x2019;s normal response to labor. However, the nurse caring for the mother must be able to interpret the fetal heart rate pattern correctly. A late deceleration is another fluctuation in baby&#x2019;s heart beat that can occur. This type of deceleration is a sign that baby is not receiving enough oxygen and blood supply from the placenta. Late decelerations can occur for different reasons. Often times, changing mom&#x2019;s position, giving extra fluids through her IV, or turning off the Pitocin (a drug given to a mother through her IV to cause contractions) will correct the issue.

The <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/tools-of-the-trade/what-does-the-efm-do/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">fetal monitor</a> also displays the fetal heart rate variability, which is another sign of the overall well-being of a baby before she is born. The fetal heart should display fluctuations in the rate, with the heart rate increasing when baby is moving. If the heart rate pattern displays more of a flat line, it should be recognized by the medical personnel and steps to correct it should be taken. Many times, giving mom extra fluids through her IV, or changing her position will correct this.

In order for the fetal monitor to be effective, a baby&#x2019;s heart rate pattern must be interpreted correctly by the medical personnel caring for the mother. Labor and delivery nurses, physicians, and midwives must be trained to recognize and respond to what they see on the fetal monitor. Unfortunately, this does not always occur, and the end result may be permanent injury to baby caused by <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/injuries/hypoxic-ischemic-encephalopathy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">oxygen deprivation</a> over a period of time. Scenarios such as this are oftentimes uncovered when a baby&#x2019;s parents consult an attorney that specialized in birth injury.

our healthcare provider should guide you through your pregnancy, and through the childbirth process. If you, your loved one, or your child sustained an injury because of the negligence of your doctor, you may be entitled to compensation. To schedule a free consultation with an experienced birth injury attorney in Ohio or Kentucky, please call Crandall &amp; Pera Law at&#xA0;877-955-0020&#xA0;or&#xA0;fill out our&#xA0;<a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/free-consultation/">contact form</a>.

AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: Low-Carb Diet Effects in Pregnancy
BASENAME: low-carb-diet-effects-pregnancy
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 03/14/2018 12:12:53 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-501" src="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/GettyImages-841956208-300x200.jpg" alt="Low-Carb Diet Effects in Pregnancy" width="300" height="200">Low-carb diets have gained popularity for individuals desiring to lose weight. The popular Keto diet is one that is high in fat, and low in carbohydrates. Its popularity is driven by the fact that individuals can lose significant amounts of weight in a relatively short period of time. When we consume a diet that contains carbohydrates, the body relies on glucose (sugars) for energy. When glucose is not available, the body relies on stored fat for energy, which is broken down in the liver. When carbohydrate intake is drastically reduced, the body will go into ketosis, due to the fact that the body produces ketones from the breakdown of fats in the liver.

Those that are following a low-carb diet cut foods such as breads and cereals from their diet. Many carbohydrate-containing foods are fortified with folic acid. Before and during pregnancy, folic acid is important in reducing the risk of neural tube defects, such as <a href="https://www.marchofdimes.org/complications/spina-bifida.aspx" target="_blank" rel="noopener">spina bifida</a> and<a href="https://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/birthdefects/anencephaly.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener"> anencephaly</a>. For a woman who is pregnant, or may become pregnant, it is important that she is consuming enough folic acid. If she is avoiding foods that contain carbohydrates, there is an increased risk that her baby may be born with a neural tube defect.

A baby&#x2019;s brain and spinal column develop during the third and fourth week after conception, before a woman may know that she is pregnant. If you are pregnant, or planning a pregnancy, it is important that you are receiving the recommended amount of folic acid through your diet and supplementation. Talk to your physician or midwife about the benefits of taking a prenatal vitamin before you are pregnant, as well as maintaining a healthy diet.

Your healthcare provider should guide you through your pregnancy, and through the childbirth process. If you, your loved one, or your child sustained an injury because of the negligence of your doctor, you may be entitled to compensation. To schedule a free consultation with an experienced birth injury attorney, please call Crandall &amp; Pera Law at&#xA0;877-955-0020&#xA0;or&#xA0;fill out our <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/free-consultation/">contact form</a>.

Dukhovny, S., &amp; Wilkins-Haug, L. (2018). <a href="https://www.uptodate.com/contents/open-neural-tube-defects-risk-factors-prenatal-screening-and-diagnosis-and-pregnancy-management" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Open neural tube defects: Risk factors, prenatal </a>

<a href="https://www.uptodate.com/contents/open-neural-tube-defects-risk-factors-prenatal-screening-and-diagnosis-and-pregnancy-management" target="_blank" rel="noopener">screening and diagnosis, and pregnancy management</a>. <em>UpToDate</em>. Retrieved from

AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: Complications: Pregnancy and Influenza
BASENAME: complications-pregnancy-and-influenza
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 05/23/2018 02:23:25 PM
-----
BODY:
<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-735" src="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/AdobeStock_118211382-300x206.jpeg" alt="Complications: Pregnancy and Influenza " width="300" height="206">Pregnancy is a time where many changes occur within a woman&#x2019;s body. Some of them are extraordinary &#x2013; you&#x2019;re growing a person in there! &#x2013; and some of them may be a bit uncomfortable or irritating. But some of these changes may increase the chances of the pregnant woman <a href="http://www.marchofdimes.org/complications/influenza-and-pregnancy.aspx" target="_blank" rel="noopener">coming down with the flu</a> (influenza). Changes in her immune system and respiratory system place her at a higher risk for complications.

When a woman becomes pregnant, her immune system must make a few changes that will prevent her body from recognizing the growing fetus as something that is foreign. Although most of these changes will protect her and her growing baby from infections, she has a greater risk of getting sick from certain viruses, such as influenza.

Influenza affects the respiratory system. The normal changes that happen in the respiratory system during pregnancy increase the risk of complications from influenza. Those changes include:
<ul>
    <li>The amount of fluid and blood in the mother&#x2019;s body increases during pregnancy.</li>
    <li>The amount of oxygen that her body uses increases.</li>
    <li>As the baby grows inside of the uterus, it continues to get bigger. As the uterus becomes bigger, it puts pressure on some of the organs inside of the mother&#x2019;s body.</li>
    <li>The growing uterus puts on mom&#x2019;s lungs, which causes a lesser amount of space for air to move in and out of her lungs.</li>
</ul>
The combination of more fluid in her body, the smaller amount of space in her lungs for air to move in and out, and changes in her immune system increase her risk of serious illness if she gets the flu.
<h2>What you can do to stay healthy</h2>
Both the <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a> (CDC) and the <a href="http://www.acog.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists</a> (ACOG) recommend that all adults receive a flu vaccine. It is especially important that pregnant women and women that may become pregnant during flu season (October through May) receive a flu vaccine.<sup>1</sup>

The <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/flu/protect/vaccine/qa_vacpregnant.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">influenza vaccine</a> given to a woman while she is pregnant is inactivated (meaning it&#x2019;s a dead form of the virus). There is a nasal spray that contains an attenuated (live) form of the virus. It <strong>should not</strong> be given to pregnant women. So, if you think you might be pregnant, or plan on getting pregnant, speak with your doctor before you get vaccinated for the flu.

Sokolow, L., Naleway, A., De-Kun, L., Shifflett, P., Reynolds, S., Henninger, M., Ferber, J., Odouli, R.,

Irving, S., &amp; Thompson, M. (2015). Severity of influenza and noninfluenza acute respiratory Illness among pregnant women, 2010-2012. <em>American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology,</em> <em>212</em>(2), 202.e1-202.e11. Retrieved from https://sslvpn.uc.edu/,DanaInfo=www.clinicalkey.comSSL+#!/content/journal/1s2.0S000293781400813
-----

-----

-----
KEYWORDS:

--------
AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: I&#x2019;m Pregnant! Now What?
BASENAME: im-pregnant-now-what
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/06/2018 02:55:05 PM
-----
BODY:
Congratulations on your new pregnancy! There&#x2019;s nothing as exciting as adding a new family member, and nothing more extraordinary than meeting your child for the first time. If you&#x2019;re like most new mothers-to-be, though, you probably have a lot of questions. Here, we&#x2019;re aiming to answer a few of them for you. We invite you to watch these short videos, to help you in the <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/labor-and-delivery/">initial stages of your pregnancy</a>.
<h2>How do you select a good OB?</h2>
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/mN7EwNlfNiM?rel=0" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

The internet is a great resource to research your OBGYN. However, you&apos;ll be surprised to know that the majority of deliveries are not done by the obstetrician that you select. When you go in the office to see someone in the prenatal period, that oftentimes isn&apos;t the individual who happens to be working the day that you deliver; so, I would suggest choosing your OB one of two ways.

One, look for an OB who is a solo practitioner or by themselves. An independent practitioner most likely will be the one to deliver your child.

Or two, select a group that has a number of OBs, but be sure to see each and every one of those OBs during your prenatal period so that you&apos;re comfortable with all of them, and when your delivery day comes, you will know your OB.

Now that you&#x2019;ve chosen your OB/GYN (or OB practice group), you&#x2019;re going to have to get used to some medical terminology. And if you&#x2019;re anything like the rest of us, you might consider buying a medical dictionary just to figure it all out!
<h2>Why are medical terms hard to pronounce and understand?</h2>
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/0QHSlNqUiRE?rel=0" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

Honestly? Because I think doctors want to sound complex. For example, the word &#x201C;diaphoresis&#x201D; means &#x201C;sweating.&#x201D; The phrase, &#x201C;myocardial infarction&#x201D; simply means &#x201C;heart attack.&#x201D; And that&apos;s not different in pregnancy and birth. You&apos;ll see when you go through this website, however, that we provide easy to understand illustrations and definitions so that the words the doctors use during pregnancy and birth process are easy for you to understand.

At our firm, we have Registered Nurses on-staff, so there&#x2019;s always someone there to help you if you get frustrated, or if you have questions about your medical records or your child&#x2019;s. But if you just want a quick primer, we suggest you check out our <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/glossary/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">glossary of common medical terms</a> and phrases that you&#x2019;ll be hearing during your pregnancy.

There is one last thing you should know. It pains us to tell you, but your pregnancy might not <em>quite</em> be as close as you think it is.
<h2>How long is a normal pregnancy, and how is it calculated?</h2>
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/CKOrmCcdU_k?rel=0" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

Most people think a normal pregnancy is nine months long. That&apos;s actually incorrect. A full-term pregnancy is 40 weeks, or 10 months. On the first visit with your OB, the doctor will ask you your first day of your last menstrual cycle. They use that to calculate what&apos;s called the EDC or the estimated date of confinement. That&apos;s your due date. You&apos;ll be surprised to know that only 4% of woman actually deliver on their due date. So the next time someone tells you that nine months is a long time to be pregnant, correct them and tell them it&apos;s actually 10 months.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we know that pregnancy and childbirth should be extraordinary events. But we also know that sometimes, &#x201C;extraordinary&#x201D; doesn&#x2019;t mean safe, secure or successful. That&#x2019;s where we come in. If you, your spouse or you baby sustained an injury, our birth injury lawyers in Ohio and Kentucky are ready and able to help you. Please call 877-955-0020, or <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/free-consultation/">request a free case review</a>, and let us help you.

<ul>
    <li><a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/2018/08/what-should-your-ob-evaluate-in-the-prenatal-period/">What Should Your OB Evaluate in the Prenatal Period?</a></li>

--------
AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: What Should Your OB Evaluate in the Prenatal Period?
BASENAME: what-should-your-ob-evaluate-in-the-prenatal-period
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/17/2018 01:23:08 PM
-----
BODY:
When you&#x2019;re pregnant, your OB/GYN should be monitoring you closely, too. There are three conditions in particular &#x2013; <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/complications/diabetes-and-pregnancy/">gestational diabetes</a>, <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/complications/high-blood-pressure/">preeclampsia</a>, and <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/complications/group-b-strep/">Group B Strep</a> &#x2013; that can lead to serious complications if they are not diagnosed and managed during your pregnancy. We have created these short videos to help you learn a bit about them.
<h2>Gestational Diabetes</h2>
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/wR8LimKNh6w?rel=0" width="100%" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"><span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_start"></span></iframe>

Another common concern during the prenatal period is whether you have gestational diabetes. I&apos;m sure you&apos;re familiar with diabetes in the general population, which is elevated blood sugar. What occurs during pregnancy is a mom who is not diabetic, or never been diabetic, can actually become a diabetic due to the pregnancy.

The concerns are the gestational diabetes can increase the risk that your child is too large to deliver, and can even increase the risks to Mom after the delivery. And therefore, you want to make sure that your OB has tested for gestational diabetes. That&apos;s typically done between your 24th and 28th week, and it&apos;s a simple blood test that&apos;s taken in the morning after you&apos;ve fasted to check your blood sugar.
<h2>Preeclampsia</h2>
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Z8BqZOJvOkU?rel=0" width="100%" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"><span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_start"></span></iframe>

Another condition that you want to watch out for in the prenatal period is called preeclampsia. No one knows what causes it, but it can cause increased risks to you and your baby during delivery.

There&apos;s three ways to make sure that you can check whether you have this condition. One is whether your blood pressure is high when you go into see your doctor. The second is a lot of swelling in your hands and feet. And the third is to run a urine test if you have protein in your urine. If you have any of these signs or symptoms, make sure you bring them to your OB&apos;s attention, because preeclampsia can cause stroke in the mom, as well as increased risk of brain damage for your baby.
<h2>Group B Strep</h2>
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Vu-56jYZjCs?rel=0" width="100%" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"><span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_start"></span></iframe>

Another area to look at in your prenatal period is detection of a bacteria called Group B Strep, or GBS. That is simply a bacteria that women have in the birth canal, and sometimes they can be colonized with it and not know it.

It&apos;s a simple blood test that is done near the end of your pregnancy, but you want to make sure that your OB takes that test to find out if you are GBS-positive or negative. Don&apos;t be concerned if you&apos;re GBS-positive. All your OB has to do is give you antibiotics as you&apos;re having the baby. But GBS testing is always important to look for.

Maternal infections and conditions can affect both mother and child. If your OB, a nurse, a midwife or other medical professional failed to perform these tests, you could be at-risk of a birth injury. At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we help families protect themselves and their futures. To speak with an experienced birth injury lawyer in Ohio or Kentucky, please call 877-955-0020&#xA0;or complete our&#xA0;<a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/free-consultation/">contact form</a>.

<ul>
    <li><a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/2018/08/im-pregnant-now-what/">I&#x2019;m Pregnant! Now What?</a></li>
