AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: Baby&#x2019;s Health and Size
BASENAME: babys-health-and-size
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/24/2018 12:01:16 PM
-----
BODY:
Two important things in your prenatal period are your baby&apos;s health, and your baby&apos;s size. An important indicator of the baby&apos;s health can be ascertained though an ultrasound where they take a wand, and put some jelly on your stomach, and use ultrasonic waves that are able to measure all areas of your baby &#x2013; from arms, legs, heart, and brain. That usually occurs at twenty weeks. If you have any concerns about that ultrasound, or later in your pregnancy, do not be afraid to ask your OB to repeat it later during your pregnancy.

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/096HJ6SK1KE?rel=0" width="100%" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"><span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_start"></span></iframe>

The second, obviously, is your baby&apos;s size, and the reason that&apos;s important is if your baby gets too large you can have an increased risk of complications during delivery. An easy way to keep track of your baby&apos;s size is what&apos;s called <strong>fundal height</strong>. That is a measurement of your uterus that you will see the doctor or nurse do during the first visit; and each visit thereafter, they will take a tape measurer and measure the size of your stomach. It is supposed to correspond with the number of weeks that you&apos;re pregnant. For example, if you&apos;re twenty-five weeks pregnant, your fundal height should by twenty-five centimeters. If your fundal height becomes too large, you need to raise a concern that your baby also may be too large.

Those are two very key areas, ultrasound and fundal height, to keep checking throughout your prenatal period.

AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: Reasons to Call Crandall &amp; Pera Law, Part One
BASENAME: reasons-to-call-crandall-pera-law-part-one
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 09/14/2018 10:06:05 AM
-----
BODY:
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/i2wDhzJADFo?rel=0" width="100%" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"><span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_start"></span></iframe>

If the delivery of your dreams has turned into a nightmare, you should call Crandall &amp; Pera so that we can evaluate the medical records. Some of the things to look for are rather obvious. If your baby is born blue, limp, or requires resuscitation &#x2013; or intubation, where they stick a tube down your baby&apos;s throat to help him or her breathe.

Some of the others are not so subtle. There&apos;s an acronym called APGAR scores. It&apos;s scores that care providers take of your baby to see if they&apos;re healthy or not. Zero is bad and 10 is good. If you ask and hear that your baby&apos;s APGAR scores were very low, for example, anything between zero or five, you should contact us afterwords for an evaluation.

If your baby unfortunately has a seizure, or has to have brain studies done &#x2013; like CTs or MRIs &#x2013; because the care providers are worried about the brain activity of your child, that&apos;s also another reason that you should call Crandall &amp; Pera so that we can investigate your medical records.
<h2>What conditions could cause these types of injuries?</h2>
There are a number of conditions that could lead to these issues. A blueish tint could indicate oxygen deprivation or cord compression, both of which can prove fatal if they&#x2019;re not handled quickly. Limpness could indicate a birth trauma, an undiagnosed genetic disorder, or another problem. Low APGAR scores often indicate respiratory or cardiac distress. If any of these signs are ignored, you could have a claim for medical malpractice.

To learn more about when you might need a birth injury lawyer, <a href="https://youtube.com/embed/Aitsxx_gWGM?autoplay=1&amp;controls=1&amp;enablejsapi=1&amp;modestbranding=1&amp;origin=https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com&amp;rel=0&amp;showinfo=0&amp;version=3&amp;wmode=transparent" target="_blank" rel="noopener">please see Part Two</a>.

AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: While in Labor, What Are Things to Watch Out For?
BASENAME: while-in-labor-what-are-things-to-watch-out-for
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 09/07/2018 10:54:20 AM
-----
BODY:
<h2>EFM</h2>
EFM stands for <strong>electronic fetal monitoring</strong>. That&apos;s the machine directly next to you that is giving a print out of your baby&apos;s heart rate on top, and your contractions on the bottom. Typically, you wear &#x2013; Mom wears &#x2013; a belt across her stomach that provides the information for that print out.

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/39zGScsjoW0?rel=0" width="100%" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"><span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_start"></span></iframe>

The three things that are important about EFM, make sure that it is always running &#x2013; that it is continuous. The physicians need to look at your EFM strip and look back and forwards as you&apos;re going through your delivery. The second thing is to make sure that the nurses and doctors are in fact looking at your EFM. Make sure that when they come into the room that they&apos;re examining it, looking at it, and looking backwards to see how your baby was doing.

The third thing is very important: if you feel uncomfortable about any part of your delivery, or you feel the EFM doesn&apos;t look or sound normal to you, please ask your nurse or doctor what is going on with the EFM, and they&apos;ll explain it to you.

<strong>Related Articles:</strong>
<ul>
    <li><a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/tools-of-the-trade/monitoring-fetal-movement-during-your-pregnancy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Monitoring Fetal Movement During Your Pregnancy</a></li>
    <li><a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/tools-of-the-trade/what-does-the-efm-do/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">What Does the EFM Do?</a></li>
</ul>
The EFM gives your doctors and nurses important information about your baby. If you&#x2019;re not being monitored accurately and appropriately, and something goes wrong, the doctors may miss it entirely.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we understand how vital electronic fetal monitoring is for protecting a mother and her child. If your nurses or doctors failed to use the EFM, or if the EFM was defective in some way, you wanted a trust birth injury lawyer on your side. Call us in Ohio or Kentucky at 877-955-0020&#xA0;or complete our&#xA0;<a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/free-consultation/">contact form</a> to schedule a free consultation.

<ul>
    <li><a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/2018/08/im-pregnant-now-what/">I&#x2019;m Pregnant! Now What?</a></li>
    <li><a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/2018/08/what-should-your-ob-evaluate-in-the-prenatal-period/">What Should Your OB Evaluate in the Prenatal Period?</a></li>

--------
AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: The Baby Is Almost Here; What Can I Expect?
BASENAME: the-baby-is-almost-here-what-can-i-expect
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 08/31/2018 01:10:50 PM
-----
BODY:
It&#x2019;s almost time to meet your child! This time can be a little fraught: on the one hand, you cannot wait to meet your child. On the other hand, you&#x2019;re probably tired of needing to use the bathroom so often.

We understand.

On important decision you&#x2019;ll need to make involves the type of birth you&#x2019;re going to have. Here are three options for you to know about.
<h2>What are common ways to deliver a baby?</h2>
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/sSvoFpcGkTU?rel=0" width="100%" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"><span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_start"></span></iframe>

There are common ways to deliver a baby: Vaginally, Cesarean Section, or VBAC. Most of you are familiar with vaginally or Cesarean section, so I&apos;d like to talk about VBAC. What does that stand for? Vaginal Birth After Cesarean section. If you are a woman who has had a baby already by Cesarean section, and you&apos;re going to deliver again, please understand a physician should give you the choice of trying to deliver this baby vaginally, which is vaginal birth after you&apos;ve had a Cesarean section, or they can offer you another Cesarean section.

The risk of a VBAC delivery is that when you attempt to deliver that baby vaginally, having had a Cesarean section operation where they&apos;ve cut your uterus after cutting your skin, it can increase the risk for both you and your baby. So if you feel uncomfortable attempting a VBAC delivery, please ask what your choices are, and ask if you can have a Cesarean section again. It is oftentimes more safe for you and for your baby.

Once you&#x2019;ve made the decision that is best for you, there&#x2019;s not much to do until the baby is ready to great the world. One way your OB/GYN will tell whether or not you&#x2019;re ready is by how dilated your cervix is.
<h2>Dilation of cervix</h2>
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/S7_m2h6Z-ng?rel=0" width="100%" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"><span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_start"></span></iframe>

When you&apos;re in the hospital and you&apos;re undergoing labor, they do exams, manual exams. And one of the things you&apos;ll hear them say is that you&apos;re five centimeters dilated, or six centimeters dilated.

What does that mean?

That&apos;s a measurement of the dilation of your cervix. The cervix is the opening of your uterus that allows the baby to be born vaginally.

When they do those exams, they&apos;re seeing how open your cervix is. Zero is completely closed and 10 centimeters is complete, and that&apos;s when you can deliver. So it&apos;s important to keep track if you can, or ask, what your dilation level is in your cervix.

Now, even before you&#x2019;re dilated and ready to start the delivery process, the doctors and nurses are going to pay close attention to where your baby is inside of you, and how she or she is positioned. The position of your child is important, because it can determine whether or not your labor will go as planned.
<h2>Baby&#x2019;s station</h2>
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/TWOq9KX2BJ8?rel=0" width="100%" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"><span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_start"></span></iframe>

Another thing that you will hear the nurses and doctors talk about when you&apos;re in the hospital during labor is what your station is. What does that mean? It&apos;s the measurement of the top of the baby&apos;s head in relation to your birth canal. And obviously you want the top of the baby&apos;s head to descend down through the birth canal until delivery. And so they measure that.

An easy way to remember what station means is that negative is bad and positive is good. They will measure your baby&apos;s descent of the head down the birth canal first in negative numbers &#x2013; negative three descending to negative two, negative one and then zero means your baby&apos;s head is engaged and ready to deliver.

As you push, station will be positive, which is good. Positive one, positive two and positive three until you finally deliver your baby girl or baby boy.

At Crandall &amp; Pera Law, we want every part of your <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/labor-and-delivery/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">labor and delivery process</a> to go as smoothly as it can. If it doesn&#x2019;t, however, we will be right there beside you, fighting for your family and your family&#x2019;s future.

To learn more about our services, or to speak with an experience birth injury lawyer in Kentucky or Ohio, please call 877-955-0020, or <a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/free-consultation/">request a free case review</a>, and let us help you.
<h3>Related Articles</h3>
<ul>
    <li><a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/2018/08/im-pregnant-now-what/">I&#x2019;m Pregnant! Now What?</a></li>
    <li><a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/2018/08/what-should-your-ob-evaluate-in-the-prenatal-period/">What Should Your OB Evaluate in the Prenatal Period?</a></li>

</ul>

AUTHOR: dlm-james
TITLE: Reasons to Call Crandall &amp; Pera Law, Part Two
BASENAME: reasons-to-call-crandall-pera-law-part-two
STATUS: Publish
ALLOW COMMENTS: 1
CONVERT BREAKS: 1
ALLOW PINGS: 1
DATE: 09/21/2018 10:12:02 AM
-----
BODY:
<em>(For more information, please see </em><a href="https://youtube.com/embed/i2wDhzJADFo?autoplay=1&amp;controls=1&amp;enablejsapi=1&amp;modestbranding=1&amp;origin=https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com&amp;rel=0&amp;showinfo=0&amp;version=3&amp;wmode=transparent"><em>Part One</em></a><em> of this video series)</em>

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Aitsxx_gWGM?rel=0" width="100%" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"><span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_start"></span></iframe>

There are many reasons to call Crandall and Pera after the delivery of your child: If your child is ever diagnosed with cerebral palsy, or has increased tone in their legs and arms. Or, if they&apos;ve suffered what&apos;s called a brachial plexus injury, which is a nerve injury to one of their arms, or a broken clavicle, which is in your shoulder.

And finally, if you&apos;ve suffered a still birth death, if your child has unfortunately died, either just before deliver, during delivery, or immediately after delivery &#x2013; please call us, so we can look at the medical records to get you and your family answers.
<h2>What you should know about delivery and post-partum negligence</h2>
When people think of &#x201C;birth injuries,&#x201D; they often mistake injuries caused by trauma with birth defects. Birth defects are genetic abnormalities; they&#x2019;re no one&#x2019;s fault. But a birth injury could be the result of medical negligence, and a serious birth injury may require a life time of care.

Sometimes, these injuries occur during the labor and delivery process. Sometimes, they are caused by post-partum negligence, which occurs <em>after</em> the baby has been delivered. Failure to monitor a baby with a medical condition, like jaundice, could be an act of negligence; so could failing to address preeclampsia in a new mother. When nurses and doctors don&#x2019;t uphold their duty of care to you, you may be able to hold them liable for your injuries.

<strong>Related Articles:</strong>
<ul>
    <li><a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/injuries/cerebral-palsy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Living with Cerebral Palsy</a></li>
    <li><a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/injuries/shoulder-dystocia/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Shoulder Dystocia and Birth Injuries</a></li>
    <li><a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/injuries/kernicterus/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Kernicterus and Your Baby</a></li>
    <li><a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/injuries/vacuum-extraction-injuries/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Vacuum Extraction and Forceps Injuries</a></li>
</ul>
If your child, or the mother of your child, has sustained serious or life-threatening injuries because of medical negligence, you have rights. Contact Crandall &amp; Pera Law in Ohio or Kentucky to work with an experienced birth injury lawyer. To schedule a free consultation, please call 877-955-0020&#xA0;or complete our&#xA0;<a href="https://www.pregnancyandbirth.com/free-consultation/">contact form</a>.
